DOC.HEADLINE: Philippine representative shares absentee voting experience
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, March 31 (CNA) 03/31/10 19:50:22 (By Chris Wang)

TEXT.P: Transparency, easy access and information examination are keys to a successful absentee voting system, the top Philippine diplomat in Taiwan said Wednesday as his office was gearing up for his country's presidential election in May.

Absentee voting for overseas Filipinos will begin April 10 and close May 10, the day when the Southeastern Asian country elects its president, vice president, 12 senators, congressmen, governors, mayors and councilmen, said Antonio Basilio, Managing Director and Resident Representative of the Manila Economic and Cultural Office (MECO).

The Philippines' practice of the system, which was enacted in 2004, could serve as an example for Taiwan's government, which has been assessing the feasibility of an absentee voting system that President Ma Ying-jeou considers a necessity in a democratic country and a must to protect the constitutional and human rights of Taiwan's electorate.

An estimated 600,000 registered voters or more -- including 15,000 in Taiwan -- among 3 million overseas Filipino workers around the world are expected to cast their votes under the absentee voting system, which includes both physical and postal voting, he said.

Implementation of the absentee voting is sometimes difficult because voting has to take place in embassies or consulates, he said, noting that voters also have to travel and can probably only vote on their days off.
"The expected turnout in Taiwan will be a little more than 50 percent, while the global turnout is expected to be around 50 percent-60 percent, " said Basilio.
Postal absentee voting was adopted in Taiwan for the 2004 Philippine presidential election but had disappointing results, he went on.

Basilio explained that a lot of oversea workers were caught between elections due to contracts, so that some registered voters never received their mailed ballots due to an address change, while those who registered in the Philippines before going abroad did not know their future addresses.

Transparency and easy access for people wishing to cast their votes are vital for a successful absentee voting system, the representative said, adding that using technology to improve information examination is equally important.

Fraud never occurs in the Philippines' voting system because the government is able to achieve this transparency and access and government officials are able to maintain neutrality throughout the whole process, according to Basilio.
The implementation of computerized vote-counting for the first time is also expected to improve the speed and accuracy of vote-counting, although it will not be done in Taiwan this year, he went on.
According to Taiwan's Ministry of the Interior (MOI) , there are several options for absentee voting, such as postal voting, proxy voting, voting in advance and transfer voting.

Interior Minister Jiang Yi-hua said that after discussions with the Central Election Commission, the ministry has tentatively decided to first introduce transfer voting, which will allow eligible voters to vote in the constituencies where they work instead of the constituencies where their legal residences are registered.

DOC.HEADLINE: Cycle race in eastern Taiwan slated for April
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, March 31 (CNA) 03/31/10 19:55:15 (By Chen Shun-hsieh and Sofia Wu)

TEXT.P: The 2010 Tour of East Taiwan, an annual cycle race now in its 10th year, will be held April 17-18 as a warm-up event in celebration of the country's centenary next year, organizers said Wednesday.

The race, which travels through the eastern counties of Hualien and Taitung known for their beautiful natural scenery, is the oldest long-haul cycle race in Taiwan, according to the Taiwan Cyclist Federation (TCF).

The event consistently attracts large numbers of cycling enthusiasts from home and abroad, a TCF spokesman said, adding that many cyclists have registered for this year's race as it will mark the event's 10th anniversary and will serve as a warm-up activity for celebrations of the country's 100th founding anniversary.
This year's race will cover three categories of competition -- a 300-km road race, a 38-km challenge and a parent-child touring event, the spokesman said.

Only those who have experience cycling 100 km per day should consider entering the 300-km race and prospective competitors for the 380-km challenge should have experience cycling 150 km per day, the spokesman said.

The Eastern Rift Valley National Scenic Area Administration under the Tourism Bureau, which is co-hosting the event, said ordinary cyclists are welcome to take part in the parent-child cycling tour to enjoy the enchanting mountain and coastal vistas of the Hualien-Taitung area along the way.
Many travel agencies have also arranged cycling tour packages to coincide with the event.

DOC.HEADLINE: Kinmen enjoys highest-ever seaweed harvest
DOC.DATELINE: Kinmen, March 31 (CNA) 03/31/10 20:09:04 (By Ni Kuo-yen and Fanny Liu)

TEXT.P: With fresh seaweed cultivated near Kinmen seeing its highest harvest ever, the Kinmen County Fisheries Research Institute announced Wednesday it would sell 30,000 kilograms of fresh seaweed to the public at favorable prices.
Seaweed production in the area reached 100,000 kilograms, up almost 100 percent compared with recent years and the highest since the institute started planting seaweed in 2004.

Seaweed was planted early this year at a 2,000-square-meter farm near Lieyu Island -- also known as "Little Kinmen" -- located southwest of Kinmen. The institute started harvesting the crop on March 29.

Wang Han-wen, director of the institute, said that seaweed used to be cultivated south of Kinmen's Hsinhu Fishing Port and that this was the first season it was planted around Lieyu Island, where the seawater is of better quality and free of pollution.
The 30,000 kilograms of seaweed were offered at NT$40 per kilogram and attracted many buyers, Wang said.
The institute said that most of its seaweed would be used to make seaweed pastes and seaweed soybean sauce.

DOC.HEADLINE: KMT lawmaker throws his hat in year-end Kaohsiung election
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, March 31 (CNA) 03/31/10 20:27:01 (By Justin Su, Lee Shu-hua and Lilian Wu)

TEXT.P: Legislator Chang Hsien-yao of the ruling Kuomintang (KMT) announced Wednesday his intention to run in the year-end mayoral election of an upgraded Kaohsiung City -- the result of amerger of Kaohsiung city and county.

Chang said he wants to run to break the imbalance in the economic development of northern and southern Taiwan, the confrontation between the blue camp led by the KMT and the green camp led by the Democratic Progressive Party.
He also wanted to counter the "closed-door mentality" of the green camp so that Chinese tourists will be willing to visit Kaohsiung.

In the past year, the tourists have stayed away from Kaohsiung, according to the city's hotel managers and travel industry officials. Local media have reported that it is due to China being angry at the city inviting the Tibetan spiritual leader the Dalai Lama to visit and showing a film about the Uighur activist Rebiya Kadeer.
Another KMT lawmaker Huang Chao-shun, who is also keen on running, said she respects Chang's decision.

Chang said that the green camp led by the DPP has maintained a closed-door mentality, and Kaohsiung Mayor Chen Chu has run her city government in that kind of ideology, affecting the willingness of Chinese tourists visiting Taiwan.
"I hereby announce that if I'm elected, I will make tourists coming to Kaohsiung raise from the one million in 2009 to five million in four years," Chang said.

Chang was accompanied by his colleagues in the legislature -- Wu Yu-sheng, Wu Ching-chih, Justin Chou -- as well as National Taiwan University professor Wang Xiaopo to announce his intention in a news conference.
Chang, originally from the People First Party (PFP) , also received a flower pot from PFP Chairman James Soong.

Professor Wang, who once taught Mayor Chen in college, said the ideology of the DPP has led to the closed-door policy in Kaohsiung, noting that whether it is Mayor Chen or Kaohsiung Magistrate Yang Chiu-hsing, both of whom have expressed intention to run, they would have been hindered by the party's ideology and harm cross-strait exchanges. Yang is also from the DPP.

Meanwhile, a KMT official said Wednesday that the nomination for the party's candidates for the five municipalities -- cities of Tainan, Taichung, Xinbei and Taipei -- will be "fair, open and transparent."

Su Jun-ping, director general of KMT's Department of Culture and Information, denied that there could be cooperation between the KMT and the PFP or that there could be "direct recruiting" without going through the preliminary selection process in nominating the party's candidates as questioned by some hopefuls.
Compared with the DPP, the KMT has yet to be certain on which candidate it will choose to represent the party in Kaohsiung, traditionally the stronghold of the green camp.

DOC.HEADLINE: Taiwan-made cartoon breaks into international market
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei March 31 (CNA) 03/31/10 20:36:00 (by Sunnie Chen)

TEXT.P: A cartoon series developed by a Taiwanese company has made a breakthrough in the international market, and its developers are preparing to test an online game derived from the TV series.

The flash animated TV series "Hero 108", co-produced by Taiwan's Gamania Digital Entertainment company, Moonscoop of the U.K and Cartoon Network International of the U.S., premiered March 1 in the United States and Britain and later in Italy and Germany.

It tells a story of how humans and animals were once friends, before an evil character named High Roller convinced animals otherwise. The young First Squad, in its quest to end the conflict between the two groups, must take on High Roller and the Zebra Brothers.

The series, composed of 52 11-minute films, was inspired by a 14th century Chinese novel "The Water Margin." It uses state-of-the-art technology to appeal to a target audience of six- to 11-year-olds.
The characters and initial storyline were created by Gamania, and the series was produced through collaboration with Moonscoop and Cartoon Network International.

"We are now also developing a 'Hero 108' massively multiplayer online game (MMOG) and we're planning to test it in the U.S in May, " said Sanvy Hsieh, Director of Gamania's Animation Development Office.
In addition, Playmates Toys will produce an extensive toy line based on the "Hero 108" series, she said.
"This is a big step for us," said Hsieh, adding that they are now discussing with Moonscoop the possibility of creating other interesting stories.
Gamania's efforts to go international with the cartoon idea started five years ago, Hsieh told the Central News Agency.
"The negotiations with the American team took a long time because of cultural differences, " she said at her office in Jhonghe City where is the company is based.
"For example, she said, people in the West have a different concept than those in the East of what a hero should be like."
In the end, the teams created an animated series that has appeal worldwide, not just in Taiwan, she noted.
"This experience is very valuable to our future development," she stressed.

"With the growth of the Asian market, there will be many opportunities for Taiwanese animation, " Hsieh said, adding that enterprises with the best creative teams and strongest promotional power will have the edge.
The responses to the series so far have been very encouraging and Cartoon Network has extended the time slot for the show, Hsieh said.
The series will be broadcast in Taiwan in this summer, she added.

DOC.HEADLINE: MECO head reviews Philippine-Taiwan relations, gauges impact of ECFA
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, March 31 (CNA) 03/31/10 22:36:06 (By Chris Wang)

TEXT.P: Although the proposed cross-strait trade agreement could present challenges to relations between Taiwan and the Philippines, it could also open opportunities, the Philippines' top diplomat in Taiwan told CNA in an interview Wednesday.

Ties between the Philippines and Taiwan are at their best in years after strained relations due to disputes over aviation rights during 1998-2000 and later the Spratly Islands, said Antonio Basilio, managing director and resident representative of the Manila Economic and Cultural Office (MECO) -- the Philippines' official authority in Taiwan in the absence of diplomatic ties.

Taiwan and its closest neighbor to the south not only have signed memorandums of understanding ranging from labor, trade and investment, science and technology, and transfer of criminals, but the Philippines is also one of the few ASEAN (Association of Southeast Asian Nations) countries that conduct regular ministerial visits to Taiwan, Basilio said.
The Philippines also attends three annual meetings on joint economic relations, science and technology, and labor relations with Taiwan, he said.

Responding to a question about the possible impact of the proposed cross-Taiwan Strait economic cooperation framework agreement, which aims to relax tariffs and trade regulations between Taiwan and China and is expected to be signed in June, Basilio said that while the agreement could have an impact on the Philippines' economy, it also presents new prospects.

"Actually we've already felt (the impact) even before the negotiations began, " he said, noting that when cross-strait travel restrictions were relaxed, the number of tourist arrivals from Taiwan to the Philippines dropped.

"We foresee that when most of the restriction to investment from the mainland is lifted, it may result in closing and moving (to China) of some Taiwanese plants. That means less employment of our workers in Taiwan," he said.

However, Basilio pointed out that the agreement could also present opportunities for the Philippines, which will be able to expand the concept of "economic corridor" to include China. The Philippines can also provide skilled labor like teachers and engineers for Taiwanese businesses aspiring to move up the value chain with high-end products.

The economic corridor is a project aimed at linking economic zones between Taiwan and the Philippines to make the Philippines "Taiwan's entry point to the ASEAN market, " taking advantage of the fact products processed in the Philippines can be seen as ASEAN products and enjoy duty-free privileges.
For Taiwanese businesses that also operate in China, it might be possible to find a mechanism to help transport products from one place to the other, depending on their needs, he said.
"We're watching the situation (of the negotiations) very closely," he said.
The MECO would like to facilitate more two-way investment, Basilio said. However, like Taiwan, China is also a major attraction for Philippine corporations.
"We have not been able to attract bigger companies, but we're successful in attracting the small- and medium-sized businesses, " he said.
Notable Taiwan investors in the Philippines include computer maker ACER, information and communication service provider Wistron Corporation, automaker Yulon Motors and some LCD manufacturers.

Basilio would like to see Taiwan relax part of its trade regulations, which "hampered our ability to export fresh food and meat products to Taiwan." He would also like to resolve the long-standing issue of high brokerage and service fees for Filipino workers in Taiwan by creating a mechanism that allows employers to directly hire Filipino workers.
He said his office is collaborating with Taiwanese counterparts to speed up the judicial process for Taiwanese fishermen detained for illegally entering Philippine waters.

Reflecting on the 10 years he has served in the office, Basilio said that he was most proud of restoring relations to the level they previously held. He added that he was happy with the signing of agreements in various areas and steady development of many cooperation projects.

Looking ahead, the seasoned diplomat said he intends to complete rules and regulations regarding the economic corridor to enable products and workers to move freely between the countries. His office would also like to make efforts to increase the Philippines' share in Taiwan's automotive parts market.

DOC.HEADLINE: Beijing urged to substantiate promised concessions in ECFA
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, March 31 (CNA) 03/31/10 23:15:29 (By Liu Cheng-ching, Chang Ming-kun, Lin Shu-yuan and Sofia Wu)

TEXT.P: Chinese negotiators should substantiate the concessions that a senior Beijing official promised would be included in a wide-reaching trade accord with Taiwan, the deputy head of the Straits Exchange Foundation (SEF) said Wednesday.

SEF Vice Chairman Kao Koong-lian was referring to five guidelines mentioned Tuesday by Wang Yi, director of the Taiwan Affairs Office of China's State Council, for China to follow in its talks on economic cooperation framework agreement (ECFA) with Taiwan.

One of the guidelines, Wang said in an interview with a Taiwan newspaper, is that the number of products from China to be included in the "early harvest" program for immediate tariff concessions or exemptions will be fewer than the number from Taiwan.
Second, regarding concessionary tariff rates, China will primarily target Taiwanese products or sectors that will benefit small- and medium-sized enterprises (SMEs) and grassroots people, he said.
Third, the products on which Taiwan will be asked to cut tariffs will be those that would not affect Taiwan's less-competitive industries, Wang promised.
In addition, he said, China will not push Taiwan to open its market wider to Chinese farm produce, and China has no intention of exporting laborer to Taiwan.
At a dinner in honor of Taiwanese and Chinese negotiators in the ongoing second round of ECFA talks, Kao said he hopes the Chinese delegation will substantiate Wang's promised concessions.

Kao said Wang's remarks reflected some key points of consensus reached in previous talks, such as the aim that Taiwan's exports to China will benefit not just its large enterprises but also its SMEs and ordinary people.
The second round of ECFA talks, to be held over two days, began at 9 a.m. Wednesday at Ta Shee Resort, a luxury hotel in Taoyuan County, some 40 kilometers south of Taipei.

After a full day of talks, Huang Chih-peng, director-general of the Bureau of Foreign Trade under the Ministry of Economic Affairs who led the Taiwanese delegation, said the two sides had already entered a bargaining stage on the "early harvest" program.
In the interest of striking a final deal soon, Huang said, the number of items to be included in the "early harvest" list should not be too large.

The two sides have already come to terms on more than one-third of the nearly 20 articles of the agreement, Huang said, adding that negotiations on the remaining articles as well as the "early harvest" program and regulations regarding products' country of origin labeling will continue.
Before the start of Wednesday talks, Huang delivered a six-minute speech in which he said the two sides should shelve controversies and find commonalities based on the principle of reciprocity.

For his part, Tang Wei, head of the Department of Taiwan, Hong Kong and Macao Affairs under China's Ministry of Commerce, who is leading the Chinese delegation, said the ECFA is neither a panacea nor a curse.
Noting that the ECFA is an economic accord with special cross-Taiwan Strait characteristics, Tang said the deal should be evaluated in an objective manner.

He further said the Chinese delegation will discuss the accord's "early harvest" programs based on the principles of "swiftness, dealing with easy issues before contentious ones, and limiting the scope of the "early harvest" lists so that a consensus can be reached as early as possible.
The "early harvest" program refers to a list of goods and services to be subject to immediate tariff concessions or exemptions that are expected to form the backbone of the ECFA deal.
"The trade deal will contribute to mutual market opening, boost cross-strait trade in goods and services, and facilitate the institutionalization of cross- strait economic cooperation, " Tang said.
Opposition Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) politicians led more than 100 supporters to demonstrate against the ECFA talks at Ta Shee Resort early in the morning.
A large number of police officers were deployed at the venue to protect the negotiators and ensure the smooth proceeding of the talks.
Protesters tried to break through the barbed wire barricades and human walls that blocked entry to the hotel complex, sparking several rounds of physical conflict, but the violence did not escalate.
The two-day round of talks will focus on the "early harvest" programs, service market access, mutual investment promotion and protection, as well as economic cooperation.
The first round of ECFA talks took place in Beijing Jan. 26.
Minister of Economic Affairs Shih Yen-shiang said Tuesday the agreement is expected to be signed in June.

DOC.HEADLINE: Officials to report to public on ECFA talks: president
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, March 31 (CNA) 03/31/10 23:19:52 (By Lee Shu-hua and Lilian Wu)

TEXT.P: President Ma Ying-jeou said Tuesday that the relevant officials will report to the public on the results of the second round of negotiations between Taiwan and China on a trade pact.

Ma said that after the two-day talks that began Wednesday in Taoyuan, northern Taiwan, the officials will report first to Legislative Speaker Wang Jin-pyng and the various party caucuses in the legislature and then to the public on the latest developments in the negotiations.

"Once it will not affect subsequent talks, we will inform the public of the results of the negotiations so as not to give the impression that we are conducting closed-door operations, " Ma was quoted as saying.
The president, in his capacity as chairman of the ruling Kuomintang, made the remarks during a KMT Central Standing Committee meeting.
According to Su Jun-pin, director of the KMT's Department of Culture and Information, Ma said he hoped the delegates would reach an agreement that would be acceptable to both sides.

On protests staged by the opposition Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) against the ECFA talks, Su said that Taiwan is a pluralistic society and everyone has the freedom to protest and express their views.
"But we hope to hear more from the DPP about its vision for Taiwan's future," he added.

The government has projected that the ECFA will be signed in June, but critics, led by the DPP, have opposed it based on grounds that it will make Taiwan too economically dependent on China and lead to job losses in certain sectors.

DOC.HEADLINE: Foreign media see Ma's South Pacific trip as successful
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, March 31 (CNA) 03/31/10 23:29:16 (By Garfie Li & Bear Lee)

TEXT.P: Major news media in Australia and the Solomon Islands have reported positively on President Ma Ying-jeou's recent visit to Taiwan diplomatic allies in South Pacific region.

The Australian, one of the leading newspapers in Australia, on March 29 carried stories titled " Taiwan in Appeal for Closer Contact, " and "Taiwan Purges Pacific Island Graft, " written by its Asian-Pacific Editor Rowan Callick who had interviewed President Ma earlier.

The Australian reported that President Ma said that world countries, in light of improved cross-strait relations, should move to improve relations with Taiwan so as to create a mutually beneficial situation.

Callick pointed out in his articles that President Ma, through this trip, has been successful in adjusting Taiwan's diplomatic policies towards the region, further stabilizing its relations with countries around Australia.

The Solomon Star, while urging Taiwan to help stop some Solomon Islands congressmen from misusing its financial aid, said that President Ma's visit has made "checkbook diplomacy" a term of "the historical past."
President Ma visited the Marshall Islands, Kiribati, Tuvalu, Nauru, the Solomon Islands and Palau from April 21-27.

DOC.HEADLINE: Today in history
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, April 1 (CNA) 04/01/10 08:51:09
DOC.TEXT:
Today is Thursday, April 1, or the 17th day of the second month of the Year of the Tiger according to the lunar calendar. The following is a list of important events that have occurred on this date in the past:
1572: The Dutch War for Independence from Spain begins.
1578: William Harvey, British physician and anatomist who discovered the circulation of blood, is born.
1815: Prince Otto Eduard Leopold von Bismarck, Prussian statesman and first chancellor of the German Empire, is born.
1908: Japan puts into practice a six-year compulsory primary education system.
1924: Adolf Hitler is sentenced by a court to five years in jail for high treason. He was released on Dec. 20.
1924: The Republic of China's Central News Agency is established in Canton by the ruling Kuomintang.
1930: Yen Hsi-shan, Feng Yu-hsiang and Li Tsung-jen revolt against the ROC National Government.
1938: The Emergency National Congress of the Kuomintang in Wuchang elects Chiang Kai-shek as its director-general and decides to organize a People's Political Council and a "Three Principles of the People" Youth Corps.
1940: The Nationalist government issues a circular to all levels of the nation's governments to call Dr. Sun Yat-sen the "National Father of the Republic of China."
1945: U.S. forces invade the Japanese island of Okinawa.
1959: The Dalai Lama arrives in India from Tibet.
1960: The United State launches Tiros I, its first weather satellite.
1965: King Hussein of Jordan appoints Prince Hassan, his younger brother, as his heir.
1968: Ma Ssu-tsung, former president of mainland China's "National Music Academy," and his wife arrive in Taipei from the United States.
1975: Cambodian President Lon Nol flees to Indonesia as Khmer Rouge guerrillas close in on Phnom Penh.
1976: President Yen Chia-kan visits the Taiwan Machinery Show at the grounds of the China External Trade Development Council.
1984: Chang Gung Memorial Hospital completes the first human pancreas transplant in Asia.
1986: The new Value Added Tax (VAT) system is inaugurated in Taiwan.
1989: Namibia gains independence from South Africa.
1992: President George Bush pledges that the United States will help finance the 24-billion dollar international aid fund for the former Soviet Union.
1995: President Lee Teng-hui starts a four-day visit to the United Arab Emirates and Jordan.
1996: Britain proposes slaughtering 15,000 of its cattle every week for the next six years in order to fight mad cow disease.
1996: Japan's Mitsubishi Bank and Tokyo Bank merge to become one of the world's largest banks, Tokyo-Mitsubishi Bank.
1998: Israel accepts a United Nations resolution calling for its withdrawal from south Lebanon.
2000: Acting Kuomintang Chairman Lien Chan says that he expects the party will rise again by winning the elections for legislators and county magistrates in two years and by regaining the presidency in 2004.
2001: Taipei Mayor Ma Ying-jeou presents a "Key to Taipei" to Tibetan spiritual leader Dalai Lama, saying that "the city always welcomes you and is always opened to you."
Confucius' lesson of the day: "A wise and good man is easy to serve, but difficult to please. If you go beyond your duty to please him, he will not be pleased. But in his employment of men, he always takes into consideration their capacity. A fool, on the other hand, is easy to please, but difficult to serve. If you go beyond your duty to please him, he will be pleased. But in his employment of men, he expects them to be able to do everything."

DOC.HEADLINE: China Times: Health insurance reform needs broad efforts
DOC.DATELINE: 04/01/10 12:11:26 (By Maubo Chang)

TEXT.P: On the heels of an increase in national health insurance premiums, a bill to revamp the debt-laden system has been submitted to the Legislative Yuan for enactment. Fierce debate over the bill is expected, but we should know it is the responsibility of all of us to keep the national health insurance (NHI) program from falling apart.
We must point out that any social security system, including national health insurance, requires funding.

If we cannot find a way to plug the financial holes in the NHI system, it will run up a deficit of around NT$49 billion by the end of this year. Nonetheless, many people prefer to turn a blind eye to this dismal fact.

People want to enjoy the medical benefits afforded by the NHI system but are unwilling to contribute a single coin more to rescue it from bankruptcy. What they do not know is that private insurance is often more expensive and offers less coverage than the NHI.

We also have to point out that health insurance means a sharing of risks by all involved, and those who are more healthy and wealthy are supposed to carry a bigger share of the burden than the poor and sick, in order to maintain the system.

Since the inception of the NHI program, it has changed the lives of many people. Previously, few families could afford to keep their premature infants in incubators, but now all premature babies are incubated under the NHI system.
The NHI has also helped save the lives of countless people with kidney problems who previously could not afford the hugely expensive dialysis treatment that could have bankrupted their families.

Although people are aware that NHI is an integral part of their lives, they are still resistant to any increase in premiums. Six national commercial and industrial groups have come together to oppose the increase in the employers' share of NHI premiums.
Actually, the health insurance premium percentage paid by employers in Taiwan is much smaller than in the United States.
Elected governments tend to reject any proposal to raise health premiums, for fear that they might lose votes, or they sweep the matter under the carpet rather than deal with it.
However, when elected leaders do this, they are failing in their duty.

Late U.S. President John F. Kennedy urged Americans to "ask not what your country can do for you, ask what you can do for your country." This is not unrealistic rhetoric. A healthy society depends on its responsible members. If we want a good health care system, we have to take the responsibility to maintain it. (April 1, 2010)

DOC.HEADLINE: Second round of ECFA talks enters final day
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, April 1 (CNA) 04/01/10 12:20:42 (By Liu Cheng-ching, Chang Ming-kun, Lin Shu-yuan and Sofia Wu)

TEXT.P: Taiwan's chief negotiator in trade pact talks with China reaffirmed Thursday that strenuous efforts will be made to protect Taiwan industries that are sensitive to competition from Chinese product and dependent on domestic demand.

Huang Chih-peng, director-general of the Bureau of Foreign Trade under the Ministry of Economic Affairs, made the statement upon arrival at Ta Shee Resort, a luxury hotel in Taoyuan County some 40 kilometers south of Taipei, to continue negotiations with the Chinese delegation on a trade pact known as an economic cooperation framework agreement (ECFA).

On reports that Taiwan had reservations about China's call for the inclusion of cross-Taiwan Strait trade normalization clauses in the ECFA, Huang said the agreement should focus on the purpose and scope of bilateral cooperation rather than highlight any other specific point.
Huang said he could not brief the media on any special aspect of the talks at the moment as negotiations were still in progress.
The second round of ECFA talks began Wednesday and was scheduled to conclude Thursday evening.

During the first day of talks, the two sides have already come to terms on more than one-third of the nearly 20 articles of the agreement, Huang said, adding that negotiations on the remaining articles as well as the "early harvest" program and regulations regarding products' country of origin labeling will continue.

Huang and his Chinese counterpart, Tang Wei, head of the Department of Taiwan, Hong Kong and Macau under China's Ministry of Commerce, are expected to give briefings later in the day on the conclusions reached during the two-day talks.

Meanwhile, police on Thursday erected barbed wire barricades at the main entrance of the hotel complex, after pro-independence groups staged a protest near the hotel the previous day against the ECFA talks.

A group of pro-unification activists showed up at the site to voice support for the ECFA, while only several pro-independence radicals appeared to chant anti- ECFA slogans. No conflict broked out between the two groups and all of them ended demonstrations peacefully around noon.

DOC.HEADLINE: Talk of the day -- Will the ECFA 'early harvest' list shrink?
DOC.DATELINE: 04/01/10 13:30:43 (By Deborah Kuo)

TEXT.P: Will there be a cutback in number of products and services to be put on an "early harvest" list under a proposed cross-Taiwan Strait economic cooperation framework agreement (ECFA)?
That is the question that has arisen after the first day of talks between Taiwanese and Chinese negotiators at the luxury Ta Shee Resort in northern Taiwan.

With the two sides aiming to sign the wide-reaching trade accord by June, their chief negotiators pledged at the begining of the current round of ECFA talks Wednesday that the discussion will follow the principles of "swiftness, convenience and simplicity."
The two sides are expected to continue discussions on the "early harvest" goods and services to be given priority under the trade pact and will also discuss the text of the agreement Thursday.

The government has reiterated that the ECFA will have no adverse effects on Taiwan in the short term but will definitely have many benefits in the long term. However, critics, led by the opposition Democratic Progressive Party (DPP), have opposed the ECFA on grounds that it will make Taiwan too economically dependent on China and lead to job losses in certain sectors.
The second round of ECFA talks will conclude Thursday evening.
The following are excerpts from local media coverage of the issue:
United Daily News:

Taiwan's top trade negotiator, Huang Chih-peng, director-general of the Bureau of Foreign Trade under the Ministry of Economic Affairs, said both sides have been working toward the goal of signing the pact before the end of June and have agreed to finalize the details of the "early harvest" program soon based on the principles of "swiftness, convenience and simplicity."

Huang said at a news conference late Wednesday that Taiwan cannot afford to waste any more time in signing the ECFA as the ASEAN Plus China trade grouping is now in effect and Taiwan's major trade rivals Japan and South Korea have been seeking free trade agreements with China.
Huang explained that the principles of "convenience and simplicity" are basically aimed at seeking easier and workable approaches in producing the "early harvest" lists.
It's worth watching to see whether the "convenience and simplicity" principles will result in a shorter "early harvest" list than the original one that had suggested 500 items.

Taiwan has listed 500 manufactured items that will be eligible for immediate tariff reductions or exemptions once the ECFA is signed, with products from the petrochemical, machinery, mid- and upstream textile, auto parts and flat panel sectors to be given top priority. (April 1, 2010).
China Times:

The DPP legislative caucus has challenged the need for the ECFA, arguing that in the absence of a trade pact, Taiwan's exports to China and Hong Kong surged 103.8 percent and 55 percent, respectively, year-on-year in the first two months of 2010, while exports to the six major Southeast Asian countries soared 65.5 percent during the same period from the year-earlier levels.

However, Polaris Research Institute President Liang Kuo-yuan said the surge in Taiwan's exports to China, Hong Kong and the ASEAN countries in the Jan.-Feb. period was just a return to "normal levels" from a low early last year when the global economic crunch was at its height.

According to Liang, the ECFA with China will be a strategic turning point for Taiwan, adding that if the government handles it wisely, the pact will give Taiwan new momentum to start another wave of growth.

There are too many noises in the country against the ECFA, he said. The government should publicize the schedule of the pact's implementation and make the contents available to the public so as to give the potential first victims of the ECFA time to adapt, he suggested. (April 1, 2010).
The Liberty Times:

Ruling Kuomintang Legislator Tsai Cheng-yuan said Taiwan's gross domestic product (GDP) is expected to increase 2 percent, or by US$8 billion a year, after the ECFA takes effect. The increased GDP will spur tax revenue growth of NT$30 billion a year, he added.

Tsai said he will propose during the screening of an amendment to the law governing the allocation of government revenues and expenditures that cities and counties which are against the ECFA be excluded from the allocation of central government funds.
In response, Kaohsiung City Mayor Chen Chu of the DPP said the ECFA and the law amendment are two different issues.
It would be madness for the government to make policy based on the ECFA and to use the ECFA to deepen the rift between the ruling and the opposition camps, Chen contended.
Tainan City Major Hsu Tain-tsair also slammed Tsai over the suggestion, saying that only people with communist leanings would say something like that. (April 1, 2010).

DOC.HEADLINE: Investigators to launch massive crackdowns on counterfeit drugs
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, April 1 (CNA) 04/01/10 13:37:41 (By Lin Chung-sen and Y.F. Low)

TEXT.P: Investigators and prosecutors will soon launch nationwide raids to stop the sale of counterfeit and controlled drugs, officials said Thursday.

The decision follows a recent directive by Premier Wu Den-yih to crackdown more heavily on fake and substandard medicine, which can be easily obtained from underground radio stations, on Internet sites and in adult stores.
The drugs have been linked to kidney failure and an increase in the number of dialysis patients in Taiwan.
Wu has asked the authorities to report to him every week, starting April, on the progress of their crackdown operations.
According to the Pharmaceutical Affairs Act, manufacturers and sellers of counterfeit drugs can be sentenced to a maximum of 10 years in prison and a fine of up to NT$10 million.

In the event of death from the consumption of such drugs, the manufacturers and sellers can face prison sentences of 10 years to life, and in the case of serious health damage, the offenders can get up to seven years.

Individuals who are knowingly involved in the supply, prescription, delivery, storage and display of counterfeit and controlled drugs could be subject to imprisonment of up to seven years, plus a fine of up to NT$5 million, the law stipulates.

DOC.HEADLINE: Group wants capital gains included in NHI premium calculation
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, April 1 (CNA) 04/01/10 14:19:47 (By Chen Li-ting and Y.F. Low)

TEXT.P: A civic watchdog group proposed Thursday that capital gains be included in the calculation of National Health Insurance (NHI) premiums as part of plans for a second-generation program that will base premiums on total household incomes.

Teng Hsi-hua, a spokeswoman for the group that is monitoring the NHI program, said that in pushing for a second-generation NHI, the most important aspect is the definition of "total household income."

In addition to salaries and wages, total income should also include capital gains, such as profits from stock and real estate transactions, said Teng, who is also a member of the NHI Supervisory Committee under the Department of Health (DOH).
Although these profits are not subject to income tax, they should be taken into account in calculating premiums to ensure the fairness of the program, she said.
"Otherwise, we will have no way of making truly wealthy people pay in proportion to their wealth," she said.
Also, Teng suggested that there should be at least 22 income brackets, with the lowest bracket set at NT$220,000, and the highest bracket at least NT$5 million.

To pave the way for the second-generation NHI to replace the present system -- which considers only individuals' salaries and wages -- the DOH has drafted a proposal to amend the National Health Insurance Act.
The proposal was set to be submitted to the NHI Supervisory Committee for discussion later Thursday before being turned over to the Cabinet.
DOH Minister Yaung Chih-liang said earlier this week that he hopes the bill will be forwarded to the Legislative Yuan for consideration by April 26.

DOC.HEADLINE: Second round of ECFA talks ends early
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, April 1 (CNA) 04/01/10 14:40:14 (By Liu Cheng-ching, Chang Ming-kun, Lin Shu-yuan and Fanny Liu)

TEXT.P: The second round of negotiations between Taiwan and China on a trade pact ended early on the final day Thursday.

Taiwan's chief negotiator in the talks, Bureau of Foreign Trade Director-General Huang Chih-peng, said that the negotiations ended at noon and a press conference would be held later in the day to explain the conclusions.
It was expected that the second-round of talks on the economic cooperation framework agreement (ECFA) would last two full days and end Thursday evening.
However, Huang said the discussions on the final day only took a half day.

DOC.HEADLINE: President, DPP chair to debate ECFA by end of April
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, April 1 (CNA) 04/01/10 14:56:04 (By Garfie Li and Sofia Wu)

TEXT.P: President Ma Ying-jeou will hold a debate with the leader of the Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) on issues regarding a proposed cross-Taiwan Strait trade pact before the end of April, the Presidential Office announced Thursday.

The announcement came after Presidential Office Secretary-General Liao Liou-yi met with DPP Secretary-General Su Jia-chyuan to discuss the format and other technical details of a much-anticipated debate on the pros and cons of Taiwan signing a wide-reaching economic cooperation framework agreement (ECFA) with China.
Presidential Office spokesman Lo Chih-chiang said at a news conference that both sides have agreed that Public Television Service organizes the debate by the end of April.
DPP spokesman Tsai Chi-chang was also at the news conference.

DOC.HEADLINE: Retailers begin accepting payment using EasyCards
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, April 1 (CNA) 04/01/10 15:23:23 (By Johnson Sun and Deborah Kuo)

TEXT.P: Contracted retailers nationwide began accepting payments Thursday using EasyCards, an electronic card previously used only for paying transport fares in Taipei.
The cards have a maximum storage value of NT$10,000 and can be used for purchases of up to NT$1,000 per payment, with a daily maximum of NT$3,000.

Initially, about one out of every 100 adult consumers in Taiwan, or 100,000 in total, are expected to use the contactless smart cards to purchase small-value goods, EasyCard Corp. Chairman Sean Lien said.

The retailers that began accepting EasyCard payments Thursday include the country's four main convenience store chains -- 7-Eleven, FamilyMart, OK-Mart and Hi-Life -- as well as Starbucks, Cosmed, Mister Donut, Afternoon Tea, Cold Stone and Muji -- brands operated by President Chain Store Corp. (PCSC), which operates 7-Eleven.

The cards will also be accepted at Wellcome and Matsusei supermarkets, Pizza Hut, Domino's Pizza, the food court of Global Mall in Taipei County, Hsin Tung Yang, Ten Ren Tea, Dunkin' Donuts, Yamazaki Bakery, Is Coffee, Bread First bakery, Watsons, Miramar Cinemas and Taroko Sports Plaza, according to EasyCard Corp.

Taipei Mayor Hau Lung-bin joined Lien and EasyCard Corp. President Jason Lin at a Starbucks and a Mister Donut store located near Taipei City Hall to buy coffee and donuts for breakfast with their cards.
"The card not only makes it more convenient for consumers, it is also a symbol of an advanced city," Hau said.
Hau's EasyCard, actually in the form of a SIM card, was built into an HTC smartphone handset.
Lin used his wristwatch, which carries an EasyCard SIM card, to pay for his coffee and donuts.
Lien said there are currently more than 8 million EasyCards in circulation.
The total number of users of these cards is far less than 50 percent of the country's population, which indicates that there is a lot of room for expansion, Lien said.
He suggested that EasyCard holders personalize their cards to avoid financial losses if their cards are lost or stolen.
"Now cardholders are only at risk for six hours after reporting a missing card, much shorter than the 12 hours before, " Lien added.

Meanwhile, Mayor Hau lauded Lien for the contribution he has made in turning EasyCard Corp.'s finances from red to black in a short 20 months, and for facilitating the launch of the new payment system.

DOC.HEADLINE: Taiwan shares break 8,000-point mark
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, April 1 (CNA) 04/01/10 15:48:54 (By Y.L. Kao)

TEXT.P: Taiwan's share prices closed above 8,000 points Thursday after gaining 1.17 percent because of bullish sentiment as the second round of negotiations on a cross-strait economic cooperation framework agreement (ECFA) entered its final day.
China-themed and construction shares led the weighted index, the market's key barometer, as it moved up 93.03 points to close at 8,013.09.
The local bourse opened at its daily low of 7,952.62 and hit a high of 8,026.06 during the day's trading. Market turnover totaled NT$138.42 billion (US$4.34 billion).
All the eight major stock categories gained ground, with construction gaining the most at 3.21 percent.

Foodstuff shares moved up 1.85 percent, banking and financial stocks were up 1.45 percent, machinery and electronics stocks rose 1.13 percent, plastics and chemicals issues gained 0.84 percent, textile issues advanced 0.64 percent, cement stocks rose 0.61 percent and paper and pulp issues gained 0.29 percent.
Gainers outnumbered losers 2,027 to 1,071, with 325 stocks remaining unchanged.
Institutional investors were on the buy side, with foreign investors and Chinese QDIIs making net purchases of NT$17.11 billion in shares.

The stock market will continue its upward trend if the Taiex stays above 7,900 points, even if market turnover drops below NT$120 billion, an analyst said, adding that it is likely to set a new high after about one month of fluctuation and gradual rebound.

DOC.HEADLINE: United Daily News: Dialogue, debate between Ma and Tsai
DOC.DATELINE: 04/01/10 16:18:40 (By Maubo Chang)

TEXT.P: The discussions on a long-awaited meeting between President Ma Ying-jeou and Democratic Progressive Party Chairperson Tsai Ing-wen on the proposed Economic Cooperation Framework Agreement (ECFA) with China has become bogged down in disputes over whether it should take the form of a dialogue as suggested by Ma, or a debate as proposed by Tsai.

In a debate that follows the format used for presidential candidates, each side would be given six minutes to present their arguments and three minutes to take four or five questions from a panel. This is dramatic format but it would not give the audience an in-depth understanding of the issue because the debaters would be focusing on tactics rather than on substance. A debate is more suitable for election candidates than for a meeting between Ma and Tsai.

Ma holds a doctorate in law from Harvard, while Tsai has a doctorate in law from the London School of Economics and Political Science. They can easily hold a debate, but it would be a waste of their ability, as they would only give sensational analyses of the issue.

Furthermore, the complicated matter of a trade pact with China does not lend itself to a debate format. It involves the questions of why should Taiwan ink such a pact with China? Should Taiwan opt to maintain the political status quo or push for independence?

It also involves issues such as which industries should be included in the early harvest list and thereby be exempted from tariffs in the early stages. Of course, this question would be irrelevant in an argument against the signing of the pact.

The problem in Taiwan is that the ruling and opposition parties never talk with each other, they only criticize each other. They use confrontation as a means of attracting voters and consolidating support.

We hope Ma and Tsai would establish a precedent of the two main political parties engaging in dialogue, not only because of the party leaders' capability and training, but also because of the broad issues involved in the trade pact with China.

However, debate and dialogue are not mutually exclusive. In a dialogue, the parties could talk and argue with each other, as the people would expect, but a debate is more like a cockfight. (April 1, 2010)

DOC.HEADLINE: More talks on financial services to be held before signing ECFA: FSC
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, April 1 (CNA) 04/01/10 16:25:43 (By Hsieh Chun-wei, Cheng Yun-hsuan and Fanny Liu)

TEXT.P: With financial services not included in the just-concluded second round of talks on a proposed trade pact with China, Financial Supervisory Commission (FSC) Chairman Sean Chen said Thursday that more negotiations will need to be held before the trade pact can be signed.

Expanding access for Taiwan's financial service companies in China was expected to be one of the main topics of discussion during the second round of talks on an economic cooperation framework agreement (ECFA) between the two countries that took place March 31-April 1 in Taiwan.

Responding to questions at a legislative committee meeting, Chen explained that as the second round of ECFA negotiations put more focus on commodities trading, the service industries were not included in the talks.
In addition, the talks were mainly responding to calls from central and southern Taiwan's small- and medium-sized companies and disadvantaged groups, he added.

Chen said more negotiations will need to be held before the deal can be signed, so the issues not included in the most recent talks -- which ended early that same day -- will be discussed at some future point.
According to Chen, the government did not abruptly put the brakes on the issue.
He also said that any cross-Taiwan Strait-related policies should be implemented through a step-by-step process and with proper timing.
Taiwanese investors should have a proper understanding of the Chinese market before any cross-strait exchange-traded funds (ETFs) are listed on both sides, he went on.

A media report quoted an official from the Taiwan Stock Exchange as saying that Taiwan and China will sign an agreement on ETF listings as early as the second half of this year after the signing of the ECFA.

DOC.HEADLINE: Children's Day to be public holiday starting in 2011: premier
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, April 1 (CNA) 04/01/10 16:30:08 (By Wen Kuei-hsiang and Y.F. Low)

TEXT.P: Premier Wu Den-yih re-affirmed Thursday the government's goal of making Children's Day a public holiday starting in 2011, a policy he said is aimed at highlighting the importance the government attaches to children.

To ensure the April 4 holiday is added to the official calendar next year, the Ministry of the Interior should speed up its effort to amend the law governing the designation of commemorative days and holidays, Wu said.
The premier raised the issue when the ministry delivered a report on the welfare of children and teenagers at a weekly Cabinet meeting.
Wu said government agencies should work to boost the country's declining birth rate by encouraging young people to get married and creating an environment suitable for raising children.
According to Wu, Taiwan's fertility rate dropped to 1.02 children per woman in 2009 -- the lowest level worldwide.

The trend in which Taiwanese people give birth to less children will decrease the country's labor force, increase the dependency ratio and tilt the balance of resource distribution between generations, which will in turn undermine the country's competitiveness, Wu said.

DOC.HEADLINE: 15 Vietnamese illegal immigrants seized in southern Taiwan
DOC.DATELINE: Kaohsiung, April 1 (CNA) 04/01/10 16:31:26 (By Chen Shou-kuo and Sofia Wu)

TEXT.P: Fifteen Vietnamese men who sneaked into Taiwan early Thursday via a coastal area of Tainan City aboard a decrepit boat purchased in China were seized by law enforcement officers later that day.

Initial investigations showed that the men, aged between 25 and 35, smuggled themselves into China in two groups last month. They then pitched in to buy a nearly worn-out wooden-hulled boat and took turns to pilot it across the Taiwan Strait to Tainan in southern Taiwan.
Upon making shore, they immediately hid in a windbreak forest and in a tin hut on the coast, but were arrested after a three-hour hunt by coast guard officers and Tainan city police.
A local police official said a task force had been formed to investigate the mens' motives and other details of the incident.

DOC.HEADLINE: U.S. dollar down on Taipei forex
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, April 1 (CNA) 04/01/10 16:36:32 (By Y.L. Kao)

TEXT.P: The U.S. dollar lost ground against the New Taiwan dollar on the Taipei Foreign Exchange Thursday, dropping NT$0.031 to close at NT$31.788.
A total of US$760 million changed hands during the trading session.
The U.S. dollar opened at the day's high of NT$31.820, and dropped to 31.728 before rebounding.

DOC.HEADLINE: State executions could hurt Taiwan's image in EU: parliamentarian
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, April 1 (CNA) 04/01/10 17:18:22 (By Alex Jiang)

TEXT.P: Any decision by Taiwan to carry out the death penalty for the first time in four years could count as a minus against the country in the European Parliament's review of a proposal to include Taiwan in its visa waiver program, a visiting member of the parliament said Thursday.

"I want to stress this: there is no direct relationship between those two -- the abolition of the death penalty and visa waiver, " said Laima Liucija Andrikiene, who is also the vice president of the parliament's Subcommittee on Human Rights.
But she added, "I don't want your country to be criticized for this in the European Parliament."

If Taiwan executes a death row prisoner now, members of the European Parliament who are not friendly toward Taiwan, those who are very good friends of China, or those who have a strong stance on human rights might criticize Taiwan when the visa-waiver proposal comes up for discussion in the parliament, she said.
"So think about this, " said Andrikiene, a member of the Taiwan Friendship Group in the European Parliament.
For example, the European Parliament is very critical of China's No.1 ranking in terms of death penalty executions, she said at a press meet.

"Let's delete all opportunities to criticize your country before this issue comes to the parliament, " said Andrikiene, noting that the parliament used to pass urgent resolutions whenever a state executed someone.
Andrikiene said that in April or May, the European Commission will send a proposal to the European Parliament on whether to wave visa requirements for Taiwanese visitors.
Andrikiene, who is leading a delegation on a visit in Taiwan, said that she brought up the issue with President Ma Ying-jeou during a meeting with him the previous day.
"We said to your countries' politicians and the president that we welcome de facto moratorium on the death penalty, but we also encourage Taiwan to abolish the death penalty," she added.
The European Union requires all its members to abolish capital punishment, according to the Lithuanian lawmaker.

Taiwan has not carried out the death penalty since 2005, but is very likely to do so later this year as the issue was recently catapulted into the spotlight by the former justice minister's refusal to sign execution orders for the 44 prisoners on death row.

Meanwhile, Andrikiene said that she and her colleagues will work to speed up the process of including Taiwan in the EU's visa-free program in order to give Taiwan a "very nice birthday present, " referring to the country's 100th founding anniversary next year.
In meetings with government and opposition politicians, the visiting delegation also raised the possibility of a free-trade agreement (FTA) between Taiwan and the EU.

However, Andrikiene said she has observed that Taiwanese politicians have not set any specific goals for such an agreement in the future. She urged Taiwan to take the European market more seriously as there are 500 million consumers there.
Meanwhile, according to another EU parliamentarian Bastiaan Belder, the delegation also gave Taiwan politicians the assurance that the European Parliament will continue its arms embargo on China.

DOC.HEADLINE: Cabinet seeks to revise poverty line formula
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, April 1 (CNA) 04/01/10 17:34:37 (By Lee Ming-chung and Y.F. Low)

TEXT.P: The Cabinet is planning to revise the formula that guides the drawing of poverty lines, to exclude the influence of extreme values, an official said Thursday.

Minister without Portfolio James Hsueh noted that the poverty lines in Taipei City, Kaohsiung City and Taiwan Province are calculated separately, and due to some extreme values, the poverty line in Taipei City tends to be higher than it should be.

According to Hsueh, the Cabinet's latest proposed amendment to the Public Assistance Act will use the median income of all Taiwanese households to calculate the poverty lines, which will help the government identify low-income households and lower-middle-income households.
Another focus of the bill will be to expand the coverage of public assistance from low-income households to lower-middle-income households, Hsueh went on.
In addition, the bill will make available additional measures to bail households out of poverty, he added.

DOC.HEADLINE: Economic Daily News: A review of 2nd industrial structure reform
DOC.DATELINE: 04/01/10 17:43:43 (By Maubo Chang)

TEXT.P: In the past five decades from 1952 to 2001, Taiwan has recorded an average growth rate of 8.1 percent, which is higher than those of Japan and South Korea, both of which were known for fast economic recovery after World War Two, and higher than the growth posted by China in the last two decades.
American economist Simon Kuznets, a Nobel laureate in economics in 1971, has pointed out that the transformation of industrial structure is a necessary element of economic development.
Taiwan's industrial structure has undergone two transformations in the last five decades, with the second less successful than the first in terms of its contribution to overall economic development.
The first transformation, which shifted Taiwan's economic focus from agriculture to industry, took place in the two decades after 1952.
The government at the time used agriculture to back up the development of industry, while at the same time harnessing industry to promote the development of agriculture.

During those two decades, the country saw an average annual economic growth rate of 9.7 percent, and an unemployment rate of 1.5 percent. The country accumulated a huge trade surplus to offset its financial deficit and distributed the wealth evenly, narrowing the gap between the rich and the poor.
It led the four Asian newly developed states in both economic growth and export volume during that period.

The second transformation began in the late 1970s when the labor-intensive industry that was the backbone of Taiwan's economy at the time was losing its competitive advantage because of the increase in local labor costs and competition from other Asian states that boasted abundant cheap labor.

The government then began to help with the development of technology-intensive industries. The pace of transformation was accelerated by many Taiwanese scientists who were educated and trained in the West and opted to return to start hi-tech companies.
Most notable among them is the electronic information industry. Their share in the country's manufacturing sector had increased from 12.6 percent in 1981 to 38 percent in 2001.

The export value of electronic information products, which stood at US$39.3 billion in 2009, declined from a peak of US$51.2 billion in 2000 because of reduced demand from the international market, accounting for 32 percent of Taiwan's total exports that year.

The second transformation, which lasted until 2001, registered an average growth rate of 6.7 percent, which is about two-thirds that of the first transformation, while the unemployment rate, at 4.6 percent, was three times more than the 1.4 percent of the first transformation.

The wealth gap also worsened, with the ratio of incomes of the richest 20 percent of the population to that of the bottom 20 percent of the population increasing from 4.2 times in 1981 to 6.4 times in 2001.
The differences were attributed to four causes:
-- The government did not do enough to help the flagging labor-intensive industries;
-- The government failed to cope with the problems of insufficient jobs and uneven distribution of wealth brought about by the hi-tech industries; and

-- The government followed economic principles in dealing with the problems during the first industrial transformation, but gave politics the top priority in handling problems during the second transformation.
Without addressing these four causes, the country's economy cannot be revived. (April 1, 2010)

DOC.HEADLINE: Examination Yuan approves new appraisal system for civil servants
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, April 1 (CNA) 04/01/10 18:31:12 (By Sophia Yeh and Deborah Kuo)

TEXT.P: The Examination Yuan approved an amendment to the Civil Service Performance Evaluation Act Thursday, which would require that all government agencies give at least 3 percent of their staffers a "C" grade in their yearly evaluations.
The amendment, which proposes that civil servants be retired or fired if they get three "Cs" over 10 years, will be forwarded to the the Legislative Yuan for review.
"We will respect whatever the decision the Legislature makes in this regard, " said Examination Yuan President John Kuan.
However, the Taiwan Civil Servants Association, a non-profit organization established in October 2009, said it will lobby the Legislative Yuan and the Presidential Office to reject the amendment.

Chairman of the association Chen Chuan-ching, who is a Taipei City government official, said Kuan's top-down decision on the 3-percent C-grade quota system would not help to boost efficiency in the civil service as Kuan has claimed, but rather would hurt morale among public servants.
"We suggest that the Examination Yuan change the 3-percent C-grade quota system from a 'ratio system' to a 'conditional system,'" Chen said.
The Examination Yuan should work out standardized assessment criteria for public servants, he added.

It would be more reasonable to stipulate that anyone who fails to meet the criteria be given a "C" grade, rather than to force government agencies to give at least 3 percent of their staffers a "C" in the yearly evaluations, he suggested.

There are many other laws such as the statute on discipline of public functionaries and law on retirement of public functionaries that include guidelines on discipline, therefore, the Civil Service Performance Evaluation Act should remain a mechanism designed to encourage civil servants, he said.

In related news, Huang Yea-baang, newly appointed secretary-general of the Examination Yuan, took up his post Thursday, filling the vacancy left by Lin Shui-ji, who recently resigned for health reasons.
Huang, who will have to address the controversy over the 3-percent C-grade quota system, said he will do his utmost to communicate with legislators on the issue.

DOC.HEADLINE: Taiwan player secures berth in semifinal women's doubles in Florida
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, April 1 (CNA) 04/01/10 18:50:03 (By Maubo Chang)

TEXT.P: Taiwan tennis player Chan Yung-jan and her Chinese partner Zheng Jie secured a berth in the semifinals of the women's doubles at the Sony Ericsson Open, according to the results posted on the organizer's Web site.
During the match held in Miami, Florida on Wednesday, Chan and Zheng defeated Ekaterina Makarova from Russia and Chinese player Peng Shuai 6-3, 6-2.

Seeded 8th, Makarova and Peng could hardly ward off the attacks from the Chan and Zheng pair. They yielded three service games in the first set and managed to hold onto only one serve in the second set.
In the semifinals on April 2, Chan and Zheng will face the pair of Nadia Petrova from Russia and Samantha Stosur from Australia.

DOC.HEADLINE: Taiwan fishing boat attacked by pirates in waters near Somalia
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, April 1 (CNA) 04/01/10 19:16:00 (By Shih Hsin-yao, Kuo Chih-hsun & Bear Lee)

TEXT.P: A Taiwanese fishing boat managed to escape to safety after it was attacked and chased by pirates in waters near Somalia in eastern Africa early Thursday morning, the Ministry of Foreign Affairs said.

The "Juimanfa, " a Donggang-based lone-line fishing boat, was in waters 395 miles southeast of Somalia's Cape Guardafui when it was attacked by pirates on cutters released from a bigger boat disguised as a Taiwanese vessel around the early hours, Chen Shih-liang, director of the ministry's African Affairs, said in a press conference.
Pirates from the cutters fired 50 to 60 rounds of bullets, injuring an Indonesian crew member in his leg.
The injured crewman is now in stable condition although the bullet remains inside his leg, Chen said, quoting Juimanfa's skipper Huang Kun-jui.
The 14-men crew of the Taiwanese fishing boat include two Taiwanese and 12 Indonesians.

After sailing at full speed for three hours, Juimanfa was able to get rid of the pirates who had chased it, Chen said, adding that the Taiwanese vessel's radar screen shows no sign of any other boat within 12 miles.
The fishing boat is now headed towards the Maldives and will take less then 100 hours to reach there.

Chen said the ministry has asked the International Maritime Bureau under the London-based International Maritime Organization to help inform other vessels in the waters of the incident and ask them to be on alert.
In addition, Taiwan's fishery commissioners in the Indian Ocean area have asked the Maldives to provide medical assistance to the injured crewman after the boat's arrival.

Meanwhile, the wife of the captain of another Taiwan long-liner operating on the waters when the incident occurred, "Zechuhtsai", asked the Liuqiu Fishermen's Association, with which it is registered, for help earlier in the day after losing contact with her husband.

A Taiwanese fishing boat, "Win Far No. 161" was released in early February after its owner paid an unannounced amount of ransom to Somalia pirates who had kidnapped the ship and held its crew captive since April 6 last year.

DOC.HEADLINE: Voluntary servicemen to be paid more: MND
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, April 1 (CNA) 04/01/10 19:16:55 (By Hsieh Chia-chen and Fanny Liu)

TEXT.P: The monthly base salary for servicemen will increase by nearly 11 percent when a completely voluntary military service is introduced, the Ministry of National Defense (MND) said Thursday.
Responding to questions at a legislative committee, Chao Ke-ta, director of the ministry's Department of Manpower, said the base salary would increase from NT$27,915 to NT$30,915.
The voluntary military service system, which is expected to be introduced in 2014, will increase personnel costs by NT$210 million for every 10,000 servicemen, he said.
Chao also said that the ministry supports the government's plans to abandon the current exemption from taxes for military personnel, civil servants and teachers.

DOC.HEADLINE: Housing prices in northern Taiwan continue to rise
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, April 1 (CNA) 04/01/10 19:44:11 (By Y.F. Lin and Flor Wang)

TEXT.P: Fueled by the anticipated inking of a Taiwan-China trade deal in the second half of this year, housing prices in northern Taiwan are expected to continue soaring in the coming months, a property expert said Thursday.

Ni Ze-jen, an executive of Housing Monthly, said the housing market in northern Taiwan will remain bullish in the second half of the year, pushed up by the signing of the economic cooperation framework agreement (ECFA) and increased difficulties in land acquisitions.

The misery index for potential home buyers in northern regions, particularly in the greater Taipei area of Taipei City and Taipei County, is set to keep on rising, he said, adding that "land and property prices will not reverse any time soon."
According to a report by Housing Monthly, house prices in 10 of the administrative areas in Taiwan's north have climbed to historic levels.
Among Taipei City's 12 districts, house prices in four of them -- Wanhua, Beitou, Nangang and Wenshan -- have surged to new highs as new projects have hit the market.

The Zenith, a luxury house project recently launched by Huaku Development Co., Ltd. in the Nangang district, fetches nearly NT$1 million (US$31,500) per ping (an equivalent to 3.305 square meters) -- the highest residential property price for that district in eastern Taipei.

DOC.HEADLINE: Taiwanese artist to be exhibited at National Palace Museum
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei April 1 (CNA) 04/01/10 20:00:38 (By Sunnie Chen)

TEXT.P: An exhibition opened at the National Palace Museum (NPM) Thursday to showcase 110 works by Taiwanese artist Chiang Chao-shen.

Nearly all the donated paintings and calligraphic works come from the mature phase of Chiang's career, with the paintings sometimes presenting a peaceful and gentle manner but sometimes a bold and forceful one that shows the artist's strong personal style, according to the organizer.

"The exhibit will show the actual seals, impressions in red from the seal faces, and ink rubbings of the engraved sides, " the organizer went on, adding that audiences will be able to appreciate Chiang's choice of materials, the content of his texts, the arrangement of the seal faces and the wonder of his carving techniques.

DOC.HEADLINE: Premier promises new homes by anniversary of typhoon
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, April 1 (CNA) 04/01/10 20:13:22 (By K. S. Wen and Flor Wang)

DOC.HEADLINE: ECFA debate aims to enhance public understanding: spokesman

TEXT.P: President Ma Ying-jeou hopes a debate with the leader of the opposition Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) will help the public better understand the contents of a proposed trade pact with China, an official said Thursday.

Lo co-hosted the news conference with DPP spokesman Tsai Chi-chang, during which they announced that Ma will hold the debate with DPP Chairperson Tsai Ing- wen on issues regarding the contentious cross-Taiwan Strait economic cooperation framework agreement (ECFA) before the end of April.

The announcement came after Liao Liou-yi, secretary-general to the president, met with DPP Secretary-General Su Jia-chyuan earlier in the day to discuss the feasibility of Ma engaging Tsai in a debate on the pros and cons of Taiwan striking the ECFA deal with China.

While the Ma administration has repeatedly touted the benefits the proposed agreement could bring for Taiwan and the potential disadvantages Taiwan could face without such a pact, the DPP-led opposition camp has questioned the wisdom of striking such a deal, which it says will undermine Taiwan's sovereignty by increasing its economic dependence on China.
The pro-independence opposition is also pushing for a national
referendum on the ECFA initiative and for greater transparency in cross-strait ECFA talks.
During the Liao-Su talks, Lo said, both sides quickly came to terms on commissioning Public Television Service (PTS) to organize the debate.

In response, Lo said the government has consistently kept all ECFA-related information transparent.
Meanwhile, PTS Vice President Chung Yu-yuan said the station will present a draft format for the planned debate next week for review by both sides.

PTS has a lot of experience organizing debates on public issues, including debates among presidential candidates. Chung said it will also study the feasibility of inviting representatives of civic groups to pose questions in the debate.

"Five schools in Taiwan have so far signed up to use the ISIC, " said James Tsai, director of the Kang Wen Culture and Education Foundation, adding that additional schools are also planning to adopt the cards.

The ISIC is issued by the ISIC Association, the only internationally accepted proof of full-time student status. According to the association, the card is endorsed by organizations such as UNESCO), the European Council on Culture and the Andean Community of Nations.

The card is recognized by universities, academic institutions, student organizations, national governments and ministries of education around the world. "More than 70 million students from 163 countries are using the cards for access to cheap flights and other travel fees," Tsai said.
"As colleges and universities seek to become more international in Taiwan, we believe more schools will consider adopting the cards," he said.

DOC.HEADLINE: Shanghai Expo's Taiwan Pavilion to enter trial run
DOC.DATELINE: Shanghai, April (CNA) 04/01/10 21:32:36 (By Chiao Hsin-hua and Fanny Liu)

TEXT.P: The Taiwan Pavilion at the World Expo 2010 Shanghai will begin a trial run on April 20 and open on May 1 as scheduled, an organizer said Thursday.

According to an official at the Taiwan External Trade Development Council (TAITRA) , a lantern-lighting ceremony will be held at the Taiwan Pavilion on May 11 to help bring success to the exhibition, which is scheduled to run from May 1 to Oct. 31.
Construction work for the 1,400-square-meter Taiwan Pavilion began Aug. 17, 2009 -- later than any of the other pavilions.

The Taiwan Pavilion will use multimedia displays to convey the building's theme -- "Mountain, Water, & Lantern of the Heart" -- with different appearances during the daytime and at night, according to its official Web site.
