DOC.HEADLINE: No `early harvest lists' exchanged in ECFA talks
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, April 1 (CNA) 04/01/10 22:59:37 (By S. Y. Lin and Flor Wang)

TEXT.P: Taiwan and China failed to exchange their formal "early harvest lists" Thursday at the end of the second round of talks on a proposed economic cooperation framework agreement (ECFA) between the two sides.

"Although both sides screened listed items and exchanged industry information one by one, and reached consensus on most of the items, we did not exchange the `early harvest lists, '" Vice Minister of Economic Affairs Liang Kuo-shin told a news conference after the talks, which kicked off a day earlier at a resort in Taoyuan County near Taipei.
The "early harvest lists" refer to lists of goods and services that will enjoy preferential or zero tariffs in future cross-Taiwan Strait trade -- a critical part of the ECFA.

"In the talks, we tried to get what we wanted and keep what we wanted to keep, " he said, adding that the Chinese side agreed not to include an opening of Chinese labor and more agricultural products on its "early harvest list" so as not to impact Taiwan's small businesses.

According to Liang, progress was made in this round of negotiations as the two sides forged common ground on the "early harvest lists" and on the text of the planned ECFA, as well as on regulations on the labeling of product origin.
"Both agreed to make the most practical and professional arrangements by fully considering the characteristics of cross-strait trade," he said.
Huang Chih-peng, director-general of the Bureau of Foreign Trade and Taiwan's chief delegate at the talks, said both sides held comprehensive discussions and exchanged opinions on the listed items.

He also urged China to consider allowing some Taiwanese agricultural and fishing exports to enter the Chinese market duty-free and the Chinese delegates promised to study the issue after returning home.

The Taipei-based Straits Exchange Foundation, which organized the just-concluded talks along with its Chinese counterpart, the Association for Relations Across the Taiwan Straits, said both sides agreed to step up the pace in clinching an ECFA and to hold a third round of negotiations in China. The first round of talks was held in Beijing in January.

Tang Wei, head of the Department of Taiwan, Hong Kong and Macau under China's Ministry of Commerce, who led the Chinese delegation at the negotiations, said that "we have not reached a final agreement on the `early harvest program'" and that "we will continue our discussions in the next round of negotiations."

"The two sides have conducted negotiations on the opening of a small number of listed items and a few industries, " he pointed out. But he added "the situation between Taiwan and China means we are still far from practicing liberalized trade."
Echoing Liang's view, Tang, however, added that "unlimited communication and exchanges of ideas have helped us forge common ground and make noticeable progress."
"China will do its best to mitigate the impact of the ECFA on Taiwan's vulnerable industries and grassroots people," he went on.
"We fully understand that the sizes and competitiveness of industries on both sides must be taken into account when negotiating the final `early harvest lists,'" he said.

DOC.HEADLINE: MAC chair upbeat about ECFA talks
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, April 1 (CNA) 04/01/10 23:11:03 (By Feng Chao, Liu Cheng-ching and Sofia Wu)

TEXT.P: Mainland Affairs Council (MAC) Chairwoman Lai Shin-yuan expressed optimism Thursday about the prospects for signing a proposed wide-reaching trade pact with China in June as scheduled.

In a press statement issued by the Cabinet-level council at the end of a second round of cross-Taiwan Strait talks on the economic cooperation framework agreement (ECFA), Lai said the significance of the just-concluded negotiations lies in ensuring that no sector will fall victim to the ECFA deal.
More strenuous efforts will be made in future rounds of talks to clearly specify the sectors that will benefit from the deal, Lai said in the statement.

She further said the talks gave form to what the government has promised over the past year -- that the "early harvest" program that forms the backbone of the ECFA will not include any agricultural items that Taiwan does not import from China at present, or traditionally domestic demand-oriented industries that are sensitive to market changes.
The two sides have also reached consensus that China will not ask Taiwan to open its doors to Chinese workers, Lai added.
The second round of ECFA talks began Wednesday at Ta Shee Resort in northern Taiwan and concluded at noon Thursday, half a day earlier than originally scheduled.
The Chinese delegation, headed by Tang Wei, chief of the Department of Taiwan, Hong Kong and Macau under China's Ministry of Commerce, is scheduled to depart for home Friday.

DOC.HEADLINE: Taiwan fishing boat might have been taken by Somali pirates
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, April 1 (CNA) 04/01/10 23:12:07 (By Shih-Hsin-yao and Bear Lee)

TEXT.P: A Taiwanese fishing boat that has not been in contact for days might have been taken by Somali pirates, the Ministry of Foreign Affairs said in a pres release late Thursday.

The ministry said that it was informed by the Fishery Agency under the Council of Agriculture and the Coast Guard Administration earlier in the day that the Zechuhtsai, a long-line fishing boat, had not made contact since the afternoon of March 30.

At the time of the last contact, the Zechuhtsai was around 395 nautical miles southeast of Somalia's Cape Guardafui, where another Taiwanese long-liner, the Juimanfa, was later attacked and chased by Somali pirates.
Pirates from cutters released from a bigger boat disguised as a Taiwanese vessel fired 60 to 80 rounds at the Juimanfa in the early hours of Thursday, injuring an Indonesian crewman.
The Juimanfa managed to escape to safety after being chased by the cutters for three hours. As of press time, it was headed toward the Maldives to seek medical assistance for the injured man.

The ministry said that it has called on the International Maritime Bureau's Piracy Reporting Center and the Bahrain liaison office of the U.S. Fifth Fleet Command, as well as other international anti-piracy organizations, to help search for and rescue the missing Taiwan fishing boat.

Another Taiwanese boat, the Win Far No. 161 was released in early February after its owner paid an undisclosed amount of ransom to the Somali pirates who kidnapped the ship and held its crew captive since April 6 last year.

DOC.HEADLINE: Eight Taiwanese apply for space trip
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, April 1 (CNA) 04/01/10 23:16:08 (By Chen Shun-hsieh and Y.L. Kao)

TEXT.P: Eight Taiwanese citizens have applied to take part in a space journey at a cost of US$200,000 per person, which is expected to create a fad for space travel if they return safely to Taiwan, a local travel agency said Thursday.

Virgin Galactic, a space tourism operator affiliated with billionaire Richard Branson's London-based Virgin Group, which launched the travel plan initiative, has collected fares from more than 330 aspiring amateur astronauts who are willing to spend big money to experience about six minutes of suborbital spaceflight, according to Royal China Express, the Taiwan agent for Virgin Galactic.

The company's suborbital spaceship SpaceShipOne will be airlifted into the skies for its maiden flight at the end of this year after receiving approval from the National Aeronautics and Space Administration, according to the local travel agency.

Six of the eight aspiring space travelers, including a surgeon, engineers at the Hsinchu Science-Based Industrial Park and businessmen, have already paid their fares, while a couple operating a jewelry business who filed applications earlier that day were scheduled to pay their fares next week in the hope of getting a fairytale journey into outer space in August 2011, the travel agency said.
Another 10 people have also expressed interest in experiencing the trip if it is proved safe, it added.

DOC.HEADLINE: Taiwan fishing boat attacked by pirates in waters near Somalia
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, April 1 (CNA) 04/01/10 19:16:00 (By Shih Hsin-yao, Kuo Chih-hsun & Bear Lee)

TEXT.P: A Taiwanese fishing boat managed to escape to safety after it was attacked and chased by pirates in waters near Somalia in eastern Africa early Thursday morning, the Ministry of Foreign Affairs said.

The "Juimanfa, " a Donggang-based lone-line fishing boat, was in waters 395 miles southeast of Somalia's Cape Guardafui when it was attacked by pirates on cutters released from a bigger boat disguised as a Taiwanese vessel around the early hours, Chen Shih-liang, director of the ministry's African Affairs, said in a press conference.
Pirates from the cutters fired 50 to 60 rounds of bullets, injuring an Indonesian crew member in his leg.
The injured crewman is now in stable condition although the bullet remains inside his leg, Chen said, quoting Juimanfa's skipper Huang Kun-jui.
The 14-men crew of the Taiwanese fishing boat include two Taiwanese and 12 Indonesians.

After sailing at full speed for three hours, Juimanfa was able to get rid of the pirates who had chased it, Chen said, adding that the Taiwanese vessel's radar screen shows no sign of any other boat within 12 miles.
The fishing boat is now headed towards the Maldives and will take less then 100 hours to reach there.

Chen said the ministry has asked the International Maritime Bureau under the London-based International Maritime Organization to help inform other vessels in the waters of the incident and ask them to be on alert.
In addition, Taiwan's fishery commissioners in the Indian Ocean area have asked the Maldives to provide medical assistance to the injured crewman after the boat's arrival.

Meanwhile, the wife of the captain of another Taiwan long-liner operating on the waters when the incident occurred, "Zechuhtsai", asked the Liuqiu Fishermen's Association, with which it is registered, for help earlier in the day after losing contact with her husband.

A Taiwanese fishing boat, "Win Far No. 161" was released in early February after its owner paid an unannounced amount of ransom to Somalia pirates who had kidnapped the ship and held its crew captive since April 6 last year.

DOC.HEADLINE: Voluntary servicemen to be paid more: MND
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, April 1 (CNA) 04/01/10 19:16:55 (By Hsieh Chia-chen and Fanny Liu)

TEXT.P: The monthly base salary for servicemen will increase by nearly 11 percent when a completely voluntary military service is introduced, the Ministry of National Defense (MND) said Thursday.

The voluntary military service system, which is expected to be introduced in 2014, will increase personnel costs by NT$210 million for every 10,000 servicemen, he said.
Chao also said that the ministry supports the government's plans to abandon the current exemption from taxes for military personnel, civil servants and teachers.

The Taipei-based Straits Exchange Foundation, which organized the just-concluded talks along with its Chinese counterpart, the Association for Relations Across the Taiwan Straits, said both sides agreed to step up the pace in clinching an ECFA and to hold a third round of negotiations in China. The first round of talks was held in Beijing in January.

Tang Wei, head of the Department of Taiwan, Hong Kong and Macau under China's Ministry of Commerce, who led the Chinese delegation at the negotiations, said that "we have not reached a final agreement on the `early harvest program'" and that "we will continue our discussions in the next round of negotiations."

"The two sides have conducted negotiations on the opening of a small number of listed items and a few industries, " he pointed out. But he added "the situation between Taiwan and China means we are still far from practicing liberalized trade."
Echoing Liang's view, Tang, however, added that "unlimited communication and exchanges of ideas have helped us forge common ground and make noticeable progress."
"China will do its best to mitigate the impact of the ECFA on Taiwan's vulnerable industries and grassroots people," he went on.
"We fully understand that the sizes and competitiveness of industries on both sides must be taken into account when negotiating the final `early harvest lists,'" he said.

DOC.HEADLINE: MAC chair upbeat about ECFA talks
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, April 1 (CNA) 04/01/10 23:11:03 (By Feng Chao, Liu Cheng-ching and Sofia Wu)

TEXT.P: Mainland Affairs Council (MAC) Chairwoman Lai Shin-yuan expressed optimism Thursday about the prospects for signing a proposed wide-reaching trade pact with China in June as scheduled.

In a press statement issued by the Cabinet-level council at the end of a second round of cross-Taiwan Strait talks on the economic cooperation framework agreement (ECFA), Lai said the significance of the just-concluded negotiations lies in ensuring that no sector will fall victim to the ECFA deal.
More strenuous efforts will be made in future rounds of talks to clearly specify the sectors that will benefit from the deal, Lai said in the statement.

She further said the talks gave form to what the government has promised over the past year -- that the "early harvest" program that forms the backbone of the ECFA will not include any agricultural items that Taiwan does not import from China at present, or traditionally domestic demand-oriented industries that are sensitive to market changes.
The two sides have also reached consensus that China will not ask Taiwan to open its doors to Chinese workers, Lai added.
The second round of ECFA talks began Wednesday at Ta Shee Resort in northern Taiwan and concluded at noon Thursday, half a day earlier than originally scheduled.
The Chinese delegation, headed by Tang Wei, chief of the Department of Taiwan, Hong Kong and Macau under China's Ministry of Commerce, is scheduled to depart for home Friday.

DOC.HEADLINE: Taiwan fishing boat might have been taken by Somali pirates
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, April 1 (CNA) 04/01/10 23:12:07 (By Shih-Hsin-yao and Bear Lee)

TEXT.P: A Taiwanese fishing boat that has not been in contact for days might have been taken by Somali pirates, the Ministry of Foreign Affairs said in a pres release late Thursday.

The ministry said that it was informed by the Fishery Agency under the Council of Agriculture and the Coast Guard Administration earlier in the day that the Zechuhtsai, a long-line fishing boat, had not made contact since the afternoon of March 30.

At the time of the last contact, the Zechuhtsai was around 395 nautical miles southeast of Somalia's Cape Guardafui, where another Taiwanese long-liner, the Juimanfa, was later attacked and chased by Somali pirates.
Pirates from cutters released from a bigger boat disguised as a Taiwanese vessel fired 60 to 80 rounds at the Juimanfa in the early hours of Thursday, injuring an Indonesian crewman.
The Juimanfa managed to escape to safety after being chased by the cutters for three hours. As of press time, it was headed toward the Maldives to seek medical assistance for the injured man.

The ministry said that it has called on the International Maritime Bureau's Piracy Reporting Center and the Bahrain liaison office of the U.S. Fifth Fleet Command, as well as other international anti-piracy organizations, to help search for and rescue the missing Taiwan fishing boat.

Another Taiwanese boat, the Win Far No. 161 was released in early February after its owner paid an undisclosed amount of ransom to the Somali pirates who kidnapped the ship and held its crew captive since April 6 last year.

DOC.HEADLINE: Eight Taiwanese apply for space trip
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, April 1 (CNA) 04/01/10 23:16:08 (By Chen Shun-hsieh and Y.L. Kao)

TEXT.P: Eight Taiwanese citizens have applied to take part in a space journey at a cost of US$200,000 per person, which is expected to create a fad for space travel if they return safely to Taiwan, a local travel agency said Thursday.

Virgin Galactic, a space tourism operator affiliated with billionaire Richard Branson's London-based Virgin Group, which launched the travel plan initiative, has collected fares from more than 330 aspiring amateur astronauts who are willing to spend big money to experience about six minutes of suborbital spaceflight, according to Royal China Express, the Taiwan agent for Virgin Galactic.

The company's suborbital spaceship SpaceShipOne will be airlifted into the skies for its maiden flight at the end of this year after receiving approval from the National Aeronautics and Space Administration, according to the local travel agency.

Six of the eight aspiring space travelers, including a surgeon, engineers at the Hsinchu Science-Based Industrial Park and businessmen, have already paid their fares, while a couple operating a jewelry business who filed applications earlier that day were scheduled to pay their fares next week in the hope of getting a fairytale journey into outer space in August 2011, the travel agency said.
Another 10 people have also expressed interest in experiencing the trip if it is proved safe, it added.

DOC.HEADLINE: Today in history
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, April 2 (CNA) 04/02/10 09:16:29
DOC.TEXT:
Today is Friday, April 2, or the 18th day of the second month of the Year of the Tiger according to the lunar calendar. Following is a list of important events that have occurred on this date in the past:
742: Charlemagne, King of the Franks and founder of the first empire in Western Europe after the fall of Rome, is born. His court at Aix-le-Chapelle becomes the center of the Carolingian Renaissance.
1792: The first silver dollar of the new U.S. currency is struck in Philadelphia by the Bank of the United States.
1801: Britain's Admiral Horatio Nelson, aboard the HMS Elephant, sinks the pro- French Danish fleet off its home port of Copenhagen.
1805: Hans Christian Andersen, the Danish writer of fairy tales including "The Emperor's New Clothes" and "The Ugly Duckling," is born.
1840: Emile Zola, the French realist novelist whose books include "Therese Raquin," "Nana," "Germinal," and " La Terre," is born.
1872: Samuel Finley Breese Morse, the American painter and inventor who refined and patented the telegraph and developed the telegraphic code that bears his name, dies at the age of 81.
1902: The first U.S. movie theater is opened in Los Angeles, California.
1912: The provisional Senate of the Republic of China resolves to move the seat of the government to Beijing.
1917: Thomas Woodrow Wilson, the 28th president of the United States and the winner of the 1919 Nobel Peace Prize, summons a special session of Congress to declare war on Germany. At the Paris Peace Conference in 1919, he included the establishment of the League of Nations in the Treaty of Versailles.
1922: Soviet leader Nikolai Lenin appoints Joseph Stalin as general secretary of the Communist Party.
1938: The Spanish Civil War ends with General Franco's fascists as the victors.
1947: The United Nations Security Council votes to appoint the United States as the trustee for Pacific Islands formerly held by the Japanese.
1951: General Dwight Eisenhower assumes command of all allied armies in Europe and the Western Mediterranean area.
1953: Karl L. Rankin becomes American ambassador to the ROC.
1954: The ROC Legislative Yuan passes the Extradition Law.
1965: The ROC government declares that "protocols" signed recently by the Beijing regime with Afghanistan are illegal and not binding on China.
1971: Garuda Indonesia Airlines makes its maiden flight to Taipei.
1973: Brig. Gen. Majed Al Haj Hassan and two other members of a Jordanian military goodwill mission arrive in Taipei for a 10-day visit.
1974: Georges Pompidou, president of France, dies at the age of 62.
1974: Madame Gloria de Lopez Arellana, the first lady of Honduras, arrives in Taipei for a six-day visit.
1981: ROC President Chiang Ching-kuo is re-elected chairman of the Kuomintang by acclamation at the 12th National Congress in Taipei.
1982: Argentine military forces invade the British Falkland Islands.
1983: Chang Da-chien, a noted Chinese painter, dies in Taipei at the age of 85.
1991: Diego Maradona, star of Napoli soccer team, flies home to Argentina hours before being banned from every sporting activity in Italy after failing a dope test.
1996: Lech Walesa, Poland's first post-war democratic president, resumes his old job as an electrician at the Gdansk shipyard.
1997: U.S. House of Representatives Speaker Newt Gingrich meets with ROC President Lee Teng-hui during a four-hour visit to Taipei. Gingrich praises Taiwan's political progress and economic achievements.
1997: The Statute Governing Relations with Hong Kong and Macau is promulgated by President Lee Teng-hui to go partially into effect on July 1, 1997 for Hong Kong, and in 1999 for Macau.
2000: ROC President-elect Chen Shui-bian denies that he sent an American scientist as special envoy to mainalnd China to discuss cross-strait relations with Beijing leaders.
2001: Exiled Tibetan spiritual leader the Dalai Lama says in Taipei that he wants to pursue "a genuine autonomy" for Tibet, not independence. He makes the remarks while delivering a speech at the Legislative Yuan.
Confucius' lesson of the day: "A wise man is dignified, but not proud. A fool is proud, but not dignified."

DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, April 2 (CNA) 04/02/10 09:31:26 (By Sofia Wu)

DOC.HEADLINE: `Pursuing excellence' project shows good results: MOE
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, April 2 (CNA) 04/02/10 10:46:45 (By Lin Szu-yu and Y.F. Low)

TEXT.P: The Ministry of Education (MOE) said Thursday that a second five-year, NT$50 billion (US$1.58 billion) project aimed at encouraging excellence among local universities will be launched in 2011, building on the success of the previous phase.
The first phase of the project covered the period from 2005 to 2009, with 12 universities awarded funding.

During the period, the investment funneled by these universities in industrial collaboration increased by NT$4.4 billion, the admissions of disadvantaged students rose by 160 percent, the number of international students enrolled in degree programs jumped by 41 percent, and the number of internationally published research papers was up 51 percent, the MOE said.
In terms of the performance in internationalization, the number of students going overseas for student exchange programs increased by 106.08 percent, from 625 in 2004 to 1,288 in 2009.

While the number of courses taught entirely in English for foreign students rose by 103.63 percent, from 2,013 to 4,099, the number of foreign formal and exchange students was up 90.21 percent, from 3,075 people to 5,849 people.

In terms of research results, the number of frequently cited papers published in the last decade jumped by 109.52 percent, from 294 pieces to 616 pieces. The number of full-time teachers who are members of research institutes or important international societies grew by 107.35 percent, from, 245 to 508.
Meanwhile, the number of excellent teachers and research fellows recruited soared by 334 percent, from 182 to 1,276.

In terms of industrial collaboration, the sponsorship provided by the business sector for collaboration projects increased by 16.15 percent, the revenue from intellectual property rights surged by 165.58 percent, and the number of patents obtained and new inventions rose by 77.34 percent, according to the MOE.

DOC.HEADLINE: China Times: Expecting a debate on trade pact with China
DOC.DATELINE: President Ma Ying-jeou and Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) 04/02/10 11:23:44 (By Maubo Chang)

TEXT.P: Chairperson Tsai Ing-wen have finally agreed to debate the pros and cons of the Economic Cooperation Framework Agreement (ECFA) , a proposed trade pact with China, before the end of April.

The debate might not sort out their differences and produce a consensus, but it will be the first step for people of different views to discuss their opinions sensitively rather than calling each other names.

Opinion polls conducted by this newspaper have shown that more than 67 percent of the respondents and 90 percent of the DPP followers are looking forward to the debate, which has driven home to the leaders of the government and the DPP the necessity for such a debate.

Although it is us who initiated the debate first, we welcome the idea of having the Taiwan Broadcasting System organize it in light of the fact that the system has experience in staging debates among candidates in various elections.
However, the debate on ECFA will be different from the candidate debates because it involves many economic issues that might not be known to the layman.

The mass media, which is supposed to cover the debate, should prime itself for the debate by learning about the relevant issues and should make judgments based on reason rather than on political ideology.
Scholars can help ensure the success of the debate by questioning the debaters' views during the debate and offering their comments afterward.

We also hope the general public, regardless of their stance on the issue, will support the debate and scrutinize the views presented by both sides. They should at least learn the other side's opinions even they do not agree with them.

We can forecast that the debate will not stymie Ma's plan to conclude the pact with China in June, but this will not make much difference, because the pact is only a framework agreement to be fleshed out in subsequent talks.
The debate, however, might expose some shortcomings in the government's proposal and should be addressed before the inking of the pact.

By the same token, the debate will not stop the DPP from pushing for a referendum to kill the pact, but it will help the party to judge a policy by its merits rather than by the party's political conviction favoring Taiwan independence.

Given Ma's and Tsai's education backgrounds and their gentle manners, their debate will not be a fierce one rife with bad language -- as is often in debates between candidates -- and therefore it will set an example of sensitive discussion for local politicians. (April 2, 2010)

DOC.HEADLINE: Commercial Times: Regrets about ECFA talks

TEXT.P: The second round of cross-Taiwan Strait talks on the proposed economic cooperation framework cooperation (ECFA) concluded Thursday. The most regrettable part of the talks was their failure to include the financial services and the flat panel (TFT-LCD) industries in the negotiations of "early harvest" items that will enjoy immediate tariff concessions or waivers under the agreement.

While financial services are the most important part of Taiwan's services sector, the TFT-LCD industry is the most essential in Taiwan's manufacturing sector. If these two issues are not given priority in negotiations with China, what are Taiwan's substantive benefits in signing the ECFA?

The government has told the public that obtaining the "early harvest" status would exempt the financial services sector from restrictions set by China on foreign financial institutions, thus clearing the way for their access to the Chinese market.
However, not only were financial services excluded from the just-concluded talks, there are also uncertainties as to whether this issue will be covered in the next round of talks.

At present, large-area display panels from Taiwan are subject to import duties of 3 percent-5 percent in China. If the products are granted tariff concessions, Taiwan will obtain an absolute edge when competing with Japan and South Korea. Furthermore, Taiwan's flat panel industry is China's best partner, with Taiwan focusing on the upstream and China on the downstream. Reducing the tariffs on Taiwan's flat panels is fully consistent with China's interests.

The Chinese negotiators said they expected the two sides to reach consensus on the ECFA soon, based on the principles of "rapidity, ease and small number." Excluding the two issues from the talks was indeed in line with these principles. The question is: Will the Taiwanese people be satisfied with an ECFA like this? (April 2, 2010)

DOC.HEADLINE: Talk of the day -- ECFA talks end with less-than-expected results
DOC.DATELINE: 04/02/10 13:18:35 (By Elizabeth Hsu)

TEXT.P: The two sides of the Taiwan Strait wrapped up their second round of talks on a proposed cross-strait economic cooperation framework agreement (ECFA) Thursday, a half-day earlier than scheduled, at a resort in Taoyuan County, northern Taiwan.

The two sides had been expected to exchange "early harvest lists" -- which are expected to form the backbone of the agreement -- in the two-day talks, to enable the sealing of the deal in June. However, this did not happen.

Under a "fast, easy and less" principle for the talks on the much-anticipated "early harvest" items, the two sides reached consensus that the "early harvest" program will not include any agricultural items that Taiwan does not import from China at present, or traditionally domestic demand-oriented industries that are sensitive to market changes, according to Taiwan's Cabinet-level Mainland Affairs Council (MAC).

The two sides have also reached consensus that China will not ask Taiwan to open its doors to Chinese workers, said MAC Chairwoman Lai Shin-yuan, while expressing optimism the prospects for the signing of the ECFA in June as scheduled.
Some local media, however, appear less optimistic than Lai.

The "early harvest" program refers to lists of goods and services that will be subject to immediate tariff concessions or exemptions in future cross-Taiwan Strait trade -- a critical part of the ECFA.
Taiwan has reportedly listed 500 items on its "early harvest" list.
The following are excerpts from local media coverage of the issue:
United Daily News:

Relevant government sources have disclosed that Taiwan's "early harvest" list will likely be cut shorter to include just 350 items, at least 300 of which are products that Taiwan insists should be essential items for inclusion on the list.

It is certain that the flat panel sector will not be included in the "early harvest" program. Officials have revealed that the reasons for the exclusion are that Taiwan does not want the sector to edge other industries out of the program because Taiwan exports an enormous amount of flat panels to China every year.
In addition, the sector is not a major competitor with the Association of Southeast Asian Nations (ASEAN) regarding sales to the vast Chinese market, the officials said.

Products from the petrochemical, textile and machinery industries -- which face an immediate threat from ASEAN competitors after China and the regional economic bloc began their free trade exchanges this year -- are the items that need China's preferential tariff treatment most urgently, they added.
Liberty Times:
The second round of ECFA talks were frayed at the end, despite wide expectations that the negotiations on the "early harvest" lists would be completed smoothly.

The breakdown was attributed to the fact that the two sides shared little consensus on the "less-competitive sectors" they want to protect, as well as the fact that Taiwan demanded a bigger tax drop on its farming and fishery exports to China.
Tang Wei, head of the Department of Taiwan, Hong Kong and Macau under China's Ministry of Commerce, said China also has many weaker businesses that require protection.
Eventually, the China side only agreed to "do its utmost not to affect" Taiwan's weaker industries and small- and medium-sized enterprises.
Meanwhile, opposition Taiwan Solidarity Union Chairman Huang Kuen-Huei blasted the administration of President Ma Ying-jeou for having never reported bad news regarding the ECFA talks.

Huang said that in the ECFA negotiations, which began in Beijing in January, only Taiwan's "early harvest" list has ever been talked about, but not China's list, which in other words is an "early damage" list for Taiwan.
While many industries appear to be "waiting in fear" amid the talks, he strongly urged the government to immediately make public China's "early damage" list.
China Times:
Countries in the Asia-Pacific region have been closely monitoring the latest changes in the ECFA talks.

According to high-ranking officials, they anticipate that if the TWO sides sign the trade pact in June as scheduled, it will help Taiwan recover free trade agreement talks with Singapore. In the meantime, it will also help Taiwan to start trade talks with Indonesia, Malaysia and the Philippines. (April 2, 2010)

DOC.HEADLINE: Taipei opens recycling stations for expired drugs
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, April 2 (CNA) 04/02/10 13:18:43 (By Jian Chen and Sofia Wu)

TEXT.P: The Taipei city government opened recycling stations for expired medications at 219 community and hospital pharmacies Friday as part of its efforts to prevent discarded drugs and medical products from polluting the environment.

According to the results of a recent survey conducted by a national association of pharmacists, 61.5 percent of the respondents said they usually dispose of unused or expired drugs in the trash, 4.3 percent said they flush expired drugs down the toilet, 2.9 percent said they give the drugs to friends or relatives, and only 16.2 percent said they take the items to pharmacies, hospitals or clinics for recycling.

Citing the findings of field surveys by local academics, Chiu Wen-hsiang, director of the city government's Department of Health, said trace amounts of antibiotics in the Dahan and Sindian rivers in northern Taiwan exceed permissible levels set by the European Union 7,500 fold, probably because of the habit of flushing unused or expired drugs down the toilet, or high trace amounts in human excreta.

Against this backdrop, Chiu said, the department has installed recycling stations in community drug stores and hospital pharmacies to collect expired or unused solid and liquid medications, syringes and needles, medication packaging and bottles. The city government's Environmental Protection Bureau will be in charge of subsequent cleanup and treatment of the waste, he added.

DOC.HEADLINE: Apple Daily: Finance minister makes a joke of himself
DOC.DATELINE: 04/02/10 13:20:13 (By Maubo Chang)

TEXT.P: Finance Minister Lee Sush-der is a fool sui generis, so it is little wonder he was the Cabinet member ridiculed most by Web users on April Fools' Day.

In order to dampen the overheated real estate market as instructed by Premier Wu Den-yih, Lee suggested replacing the current flat housing tax with a progressive one. However, the premier called it off out of concern that it might drive away voters in the year-end special municipality elections.

It was a slap in the face for Lee, which the minister took lying down. He even went to the defense of the premier's abrupt reversal in policy by claiming that the premier did what had to be done, as if it were not his suggestion to make the changes.
He even described the premier as a scapegoat, saying that he felt hurt by critics' groundless criticism of the premier.

In a defense of the government policy of offering the lion's share of government's revenues to the five municipalities to be formed by the end of this year, the minister, in a derogatory manner, likened the other counties as kindergarten pupils who cannot be expected to be treated the same as graduate school students.

When a lawmaker suggested, tongue in cheek, that he should revise the law to withhold financial aid to counties that oppose the proposed trade pact with China or criticize Taipei City wrongfully for failing to pay health insurance premiums, the minister's response of "you said it" showed his complete agreement with a comment that he failed to comprehend was made in jest.
If the minister can starve opposition-controlled counties of financial aid, would this not violate the Constitution? Both the lawmaker and the minister are idiots.

Lee feels content with his own performance, anyway. He claimed a couple of days ago that Taiwan's finances are in perfect shape, in defiance of the fact that Standard & Poor has downgraded Taiwan's sovereign rate because of its massive debts. What a joke the minister is. (April 2, 2010)

DOC.HEADLINE: Premier praises HTC as innovative role model
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, April 2 (CNA) 04/02/10 15:29:57 (By Tien Yu-pin and Elizabeth Hsu)

TEXT.P: Premier Wu Den-yih praised Taiwan-based HTC Corp. Friday for its dedication in pursuing innovation and cultivating talented designers.

At a ground-breaking ceremony for the global smartphone designer's new Taipei headquarters in Taipei County, Wu lauded HTC's achievements in research, innovation and branding. He also acknowledged its role in cultivating talent and creating jobs, saying the company embodied the spirit of the government's drafted industrial innovation act.
"I have been very pleased to see HTC grow into a leading global brand," Wu said at the ceremony.
He also said he looked forward to seeing the company "create more innovation opportunities for our local youth while continuing to market Taiwan to the world."

The ground-breaking ceremony, jointly hosted by HTC Chairman Cher Wang and Chief Executive Officer Peter Chou, was also attended by Taipei County Magistrate Chou Hsi-wei, as well as industry leaders including Qualcomm Chairman and CEO Paul E. Jacobs, Google Vice President of Engineering Andy Rubin, and John Kalkman, vice president of Microsoft Corp.'s OEM engineering and services division.

Chunghwa Telecom Chairman Lu Shyue-ching and Taiwan Cellular President Harvey Chang were also present to witness the launching of construction on the planned 17-story building, which will be able to accommodate 2,200 workers.
The construction is scheduled to be completed in 2011, according to HTC.

DOC.HEADLINE: Presidential Office rebuts DPP's call for ECFA referendum
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, April 2 (CNA) 04/02/10 15:48:34 (By Garfie Li and Maubo Chang)

TEXT.P: A spokesman for the Office of the President called the opposition Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) hypocritical Friday for pushing for a referendum to quash the government's proposed Economic Cooperation Framework Agreement (ECFA) with China.
Lo Chih-chiang noted that the DPP did not bother to put any of the five free trade agreements the country concluded with other states to a referendum during the eight years it was in power.
"Why should it now ask for a referendum on ECFA, which is the same kind of thing?" Lo asked.

He made the statement in response to remarks by DPP Secretary- General Su Jia- chyuan, who claimed the previous day that the Kuomintang administration should step down if it refuses to hold a referendum on the trade pact that the DPP believes would undermine Taiwan's sovereignty.

"There are more than 200 free trade pacts or similar agreements around the world, the majority of which were not put to referendum. Should all the administrations that signed these pacts be defined as undemocratic and step down?" Lo asked.

Naming the United States, Japan and South Korea as a few nations that have entered such pacts without seeking approval through referendum, Lo asked rhetorically: "Should they be characterized as non-democratic?"

It is highly unlikely that the DPP would be unaware of the importance of the trade pact with China, and as a responsible opposition, the DPP should tell the public how Taiwan can avoid being isolated as regional trade blocs continue to sprout up around the world, Lo said.
He urged the DPP not to try to keep the country isolated from the rest of the world, as this would only harm Taiwan's economy.
President Ma Ying-jeou's administration is working hard to clinch the pact in June, while the DPP is making every effort to block it.

DOC.HEADLINE: Timing not right for child-rearing subsidies: MOI
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, April 2 (CNA) 04/02/10 15:50:38 (By Chiachen Hsieh, Justin Su and Y.F. Low)

TEXT.P: The Ministry of the Interior (MOI) denied Friday that it is planning to issue a monthly subsidy of NT$5,000 for children aged 0-3 in a bid to boost the country's declining birth rate.
In a statement issued in response to a media report, the MOI said that it is not a good time to launch a child-rearing subsidy program, given the country's tight fiscal situation.

The MOI said that it is considering various programs -- including the one mentioned above -- as part of the country's long-term population policy, but it has not made a final decision on what approach to take.

According to a front-page story in the China Times, the monthly NT$5,000 subsidy program, which would include children of wealthy families, would cost the government NT$36.9 billion a year. It would run parallel to the existing monthly NT$3,000 babysitting subsidy for households in which both parents are working and earn less than NT$1.5 million a year, the report stated.

However, the MOI said although experts have suggested that the child-rearing subsidy program should cover all households regardless of their income levels, in the interest of fairness the ministry would prefer to exclude wealthy households.
Commenting on the issue Friday, lawmakers across party lines said the subsidy program would be too narrow if it covered only children aged 0-3.

Legislator Ho Tsai-feng of the ruling Kuomintang proposed that all children under six should be included, while Yeh Yi-jin of the opposition Democratic Progressive Party suggested that the subsidy should be extended to all children under 12.

There are approximately 2.8 million children under 12 in Taiwan, accounting for 12.14 percent of the country's total population, Yeh noted. However, government spending on child welfare totals only NT$5 billion a year -- less than 1 percent of the total budget, she said.

According to Yeh, the government should offer a subsidy of NT$12,000 per child per year. She said this amount would be affordable to the government because it would only cost NT$33.6 billion a year in total, or just 1.9 percent of the government's annual expenditure.

DOC.HEADLINE: Taiwan share prices close higher
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, April 2 (CNA) 04/02/10 15:56:56 (By Olivia Wang)

TEXT.P: Taiwan's share prices closed higher Friday with the weighted index, the market's key barometer, moving up 12.84 points, or 0.16 percent, to close at 8,025.93.
The local bourse opened at 8,046.29 and fluctuated between a low of 8,021.91 and a high of 8,050.99 during the day's trading. Market turnover totaled NT$108.12 billion (US$3.41 billion).

Five of the eight major stock categories lost ground, with textile issues dropping the most at 0.36 percent. Construction shares plunged 0.25 percent, paper and pulp issues were down 0.19 percent, foodstuff shares moved down 0.05 percent and banking and financial stocks were down 0.02 percent.
Two of the major stock categories gained ground, with cement issues gaining the most at 0.42 percent and machinery and electronics stocks rising 0. 21 percent.
Plastics and chemicals remained unchanged.
Gainers outnumbered losers 1,584 to 1,409, with 372 remaining unchanged.
Foreign investors and Chinese QDIIs were net buyers of NT$8.47 billion-worth of shares.

DOC.HEADLINE: Bracing for debate, DPP sets up task force
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, April 2 (CNA) 04/02/10 16:36:10 (By Wen Kui-hsiang and Maubo Chang)

TEXT.P: The opposition Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) set up a task force Friday to help its chairwoman, Tsai Ing-wen, to prepare for a debate with President Ma Ying-jeou on a proposed economic cooperation framework agreement (ECFA) with China.

DPP spokesman Tsai Chih-chang said the task force is made up of DPP Deputy Secretary-General Hung Yao-fu, DPP Policy Committee Deputy Executive Director Liu Chien-hsin, the spokesman himself and various other party officials.
"We will begin operations next week by seeking opinions from scholars and China affairs experts, as well as commercial and industrial leaders," Tsai said.
DPP Secretary-General Su Jia-chyuan and Presidential Office Secretary-General Liao Liou-yi agreed a day earlier to set up a debate between Tsai and Ma on the pact before the end of April.
The debate will be organized by the Public Television Service.
Tsai Chih-chang said he will meet Ma's spokesman Lo Chih-chiang and Public Television Service Chairman Cheng Tung-liao next week to hammer out details of the debate.

Ma's administration is pushing hard for the conclusion of the pact with China, hopefully in June, out of concern that the country could be isolated as other states in the region form trade blocs that do not include Taiwan.
However, the DPP is making every effort to block it, claiming that it will undermine Taiwan's sovereignty.

DOC.HEADLINE: Yo-Yo Ma to hold outdoor concert in Taichung City
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, April 2 (CNA) 04/02/10 16:38:56 (By Lee Hsi-chang and Elizabeth Hsu)

TEXT.P: Renowned cellist Yo-Yo Ma has prepared a "Taichung Project" for his visit to Taiwan in late April that will include an outdoor concert for local music lovers to see "how a cello talks with stars in the sky, " Taichung Mayor Jason Hu said Friday.
"It is a music project especially for Taichung City, " Hu said as he and organizers announced the concert featuring Ma and the Silk Road Ensemble, scheduled for April 24.
In addition to the concert, the visit will include two seminars at which Ma will speak with local musicians. One will be aimed at young people between 12 and 18 years old, the organizers said.
Hu said he expects the Taichung Project to "trigger a musical fever" in the central Taiwan city.
Ma's Taichung concert will be the only open-air performance of three he will give in Taiwan as part of his "Silk Road Project."
The other two concerts will be held at the National Concert Hall in Taipei on April 22 and at the Jhihde Hall in Kaohsiung City April 25, the organizers said.
The Silk Road Project, a non-profit artistic, cultural and educational organization, was started by Ma in 1998 to promote innovation and learning through the arts.

The Silk Road Ensemble was established in 2000 with the participation of internationally renowned performers and composers from more than 20 countries. It includes classical instruments such as piano and violin as well as Chinese traditional instruments including pipa and erhu.

DOC.HEADLINE: U.S. dollar down on Taipei forex
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, April 2 (CNA) 04/02/10 16:48:34 (By Olivia Wang)

TEXT.P: The U.S. dollar lost ground against the New Taiwan dollar on the Taipei Foreign Exchange Friday, dropping NT$0.029 to close at NT$31.759.
A total of US$ 632 million changed hands during the trading session.
The U.S. dollar opened at the day's high of NT$31.788, and fell to a low of NT$31.714 before rebounding.

DOC.HEADLINE: Subsidence does not threaten safety of high-speed rail: MOTC
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, April 2 (CNA) 04/02/10 18:17:59 (By Chen Shun-hsieh and Sofia Wu)

TEXT.P: Taiwan's high-speed railway does not face a safety threat even though a six- kilometer section that cuts through Yunlin County sits on land that has subsided considerably in recent years, transport officials said Friday.

The site where the elevated railway crosses over Provincial Expressway No. 78 in the central-south county has subsided the most, sinking 55 centimeters over the past seven years, according to data compiled by Taiwan High-Speed Rail Corp. (THSRC), which operates the bullet train.

Officials of the Bureau of Taiwan High Speed Rail under the Ministry of Transportation and Communications (MOTC) said, however, that the "differential settlement" -- the rate of uneven settling -- between adjacent piers of the railway viaduct in Yunlin remains within tolerable levels, and they stressed that the railway's structure and operation remained safe.
According to the officials, the THSRC has closely monitored the subsidence of the Yunlin section's pier and foundation since 2004.
The differential settlement for the section crossing over Provincial Expressway No. 78 stands at 1.08/1,500 at present, far lower than the maximum permissible level of 6/1,500, the officials said.

They added that the pace of subsidence along the Yunlin section had slowed from nearly 10 cm per year in the past to 6.8 cm last year because a number of deep wells were closed in the area, reducing the use of groundwater.

Though pleased by the slower pace of settlement, the bureau said it hopes the central and local governments will collaborate to close even more water wells, including those for aquacultural use, to contain further subsidence in Yunlin County, which is known for agriculture and aquaculture.
Echoing the bureau's safety assurance, THSRC spokesman Ted Chia said the high- speed railway is safe and structurally sound.

DOC.HEADLINE: Chinese delegation departs following 2nd round of ECFA talks
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, April 2 (CNA) 04/02/10 18:24:45 (By Chiu Chin-chun and Sofia Wu)

TEXT.P: The Chinese delegation to the just-concluded second round of talks on a proposed framework agreement on trade between Taiwan and China headed home Friday.

Tang Wei, head of the Department of Taiwan, Hong Kong and Macao Affairs under China's Ministry of Commerce and China's lead negotiator at the talks, maintained a low profile and did not make any public comments prior to his departure.
Asked whether any concrete results were achieved at the talks, Tang only gave a polite "thank you all" response.
To avoid encountering pro-independence or anti-China protesters at Taiwan Taoyuan International Airport, the Chinese delegation arrived at the airport two hours before their flight's departure time.

According to Taoyuan police authorities, the Chinese delegation toured a tourism dairy farm in Taoyuan County's Yangmei Township on Friday morning to relax before heading to the airport. Many Chinese negotiators were reportedly visiting Taiwan for the first time.
The second round of ECFA talks began Wednesday at Ta Shee Resort in Taoyuan County, some 40 kilometers south of Taipei, and concluded at noon Thursday, half a day earlier than originally scheduled.

At the end of the talks, Mainland Affairs Council (MAC) Chairwoman Lai Shin- yuan expressed optimism Thursday about the prospects for signing the wide- reaching trade pact with China in June as scheduled.
Lai said in a statement that the significance of the just-concluded negotiations lies in ensuring that no sector will fall victim to the ECFA deal.
More strenuous efforts will be made in future rounds of talks to clearly specify the sectors that will benefit from the deal, Lai said in the statement.

She further said the talks gave form to what the government has promised over the past year -- that the "early harvest" program, a list of items for which duties will be reduced or exempted immediately, will not include any agricultural items that Taiwan does not import from China at present.
It would also not include conventional domestic demand-oriented industries that would be sensitive to new inflows of Chinese goods.
The two sides have also reached a consensus that China will not ask Taiwan to open its doors to Chinese workers, Lai added.

DOC.HEADLINE: Vice premier inspects construction work in Taoyuan County
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, April 2 (CNA) 04/02/10 18:30:58 (By H.S. Huang and Flor Wang)

TEXT.P: Vice Premier Eric Liluan Chu stressed the importance of execution, safety and quality Friday when inspecting construction work related to a planned aviation park in northern Taiwan's Taoyuan County.

Chu heard briefings by officials about the improvement work being carried out at Terminal One of Taiwan Taoyuan International Airport and about the ongoing construction of the Mass Rapid Transit (MRT) system's Linkou line linking Taipei with the country's largest airport.

According to Transportation Ministry officials, the renovation of the airport's shabby terminal is slated for completion in 2011, while construction of the MRT's Linkou line, now 41 percent complete instead of the 28 percent that had been originally projected, is also slated to wrap up in 2012.

Taipei Magistrate Chou Hsi-wei accompanied Chu during the inspection of a construction site on the Linkou line and both expressed hope that completion of the line will boost development in the areas adjacent to the airport.

It was their first encounter since Chou forswore his bid to seek a second term as magistrate in late February at a time when Chu was widely reported as the favored candidate to be picked by the ruling Kuomintang (KMT) to run in the year-end mayoral elections in Xinbei City (upgraded from Taipei County into one of five special municipalities).

However, Chu was reluctant to answer reporters' questions related to the election campaign, while Chou explained that relevant issues will be made public after the KMT officially fields Chu as its candidate.

Meanwhile that day, Lin Chia-long of the opposition Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) , who is seeking the party's nomination to take part in the mayoral race in Taichung, said he will continue moving toward his goal despite reports that the party's Frank Hsieh, a former premier, wants to run there.
Incumbent Taichung Mayor Jason Hu, a heavyweight of the ruling Kuomintang (KMT) who has made known his intention to vie for the post of Taichung mayor, declined to comment on the speculation.
"This is a matter for the DPP and I am not in a position to talk about it," he said.

DOC.HEADLINE: Reports of child abuse increasing significantly
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, April 2 (CNA) 04/02/10 18:47:47 (By Chen Ching-fang and Y.L. Kao)

TEXT.P: Reported cases of child abuse increased by about 30 percent between 2005 and 2009, according to statistics from the government and the Taiwan Fund for Children and Families (TFCF) , a fund executive said Friday, ahead of the April 4 Children's Day.

The number of child abuse cases reached 13,400 in 2009, 35 percent more than in 2005. Most victims were elementary school children improperly disciplined by their parents, TFCF CEO Wang Ming-ren said, citing statistics compiled by the Ministry of the Interior.
Meanwhile, 3,177 abused children and juveniles sought TFCF's protection last year, an increase of 29 percent from 2005, according to the organization.

Of the 3,177 cases, 87.95 percent involved children abused by their own parents, with parents in the 30- to 39-year-old age bracket the main perpetrators, accounting for 30.14 percent of the cases, TFCF statistics show.

Children between nine and 11 years old were the most frequent victims of abuse, accounting for 23.29 percent of the cases, with those in the six- to eight-year- old group accounting for 21.47 percent, according to the statistics.
Evidence showed that parents torn between the demands of the workplace and the family tended to be rougher when disciplining young children, Wang said.

Pointing to a recent criminal case in which a girl in Pingtung County is suspected of colluding with her boyfriend to murder her father after being subject to long-term abuse, Wang said that if police and social services groups could have intervened earlier, the tragedy could have been prevented.
There are many parenting problems involved in child abuse cases, such as lack of parenting skills, negligence and overly strict parenting, Wang said.
He also said parents who are inclined to improperly discipline their children are often overly demanding, alcoholic or have anger management problems.

To promote healthy relationships and intimate interaction between young children and their parents, the TFCF has developed a set of playful body movements that parents can perform with young children, Wang said.

DOC.HEADLINE: Taiwan's foreign exchange reserves hit US$355 billion in March
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, April 2 (CNA) 04/02/10 18:47:54 (Kao Chao-fen and Fanny Liu)

TEXT.P: Taiwan's foreign exchange reserves climbed to a record high US$355 billion at the end of March, up US$2.31 billion from the previous month, the Central Bank of the Republic of China (Taiwan) said Friday.
The bank attributed the increase of forex reserve growth in March mainly to returns on foreign exchange reserve investments.

Taiwan remained the world's fourth largest foreign exchange holder, trailing China (US$2.4 trillion as of December 2009), Japan (US$998.7 billion in February) , and Russia (US$402.8 billion in February).

DOC.HEADLINE: EU likely to give visa-free privileges for Taiwanese: president
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, April 2 (CNA) 04/02/10 18:48:34 (By Garfie Lee and Flor Wang)

TEXT.P: The European Union (EU) is likely to grant visa-exempt privileges to Taiwanese passengers by the end of this year, following in the footsteps of Britain and Ireland, which made the move last year, President Ma Ying-jeou said Friday.

"The measure has helped Britain attract more tourists from Taiwan and bolster two-way ties. Now, the EU is ready to make the same decision, " Ma told Nicholas Winterton, a Conservative member of the British Parliament, during a meeting at the Presidential Office.
Upbeat about the improvements in relations between Taiwan and Britain, Ma said bilateral trade links and cultural exchanges are particularly close.

According to the president, Britain is Taiwan's 17th-largest trade partner, while some 15,000 Taiwanese students are studying in Britain. Britain is the second-largest overseas destination for Taiwanese students after the United States, he noted.

DOC.HEADLINE: Taiwan teams make clean sweep at mini-robot competition in Japan
DOC.DATELINE: Kaohsiung April 2 (CNA) 04/02/10 19:19:59 (By Chang Che-fang and Fanny Liu)

TEXT.P: Student teams from two Taiwanese universities won all 18 medals in the six categories of a recent international mini-robot competition in Japan.
A five-member team from Minhsin University of Science and Technology (MUST) brought home five gold, one silver, and four bronze medals and seven special awards for their 2-cm3 mini-robot designs.

The two students on the team from National Kaohsiung University of Applied Sciences (KUAS) and its sister university Harbin Institute of Technology in China, bagged one gold, five silver and two bronze medals and one special award.

The participants in the 4th International Micro-Mechanisms Contest that opened in Tokyo March 17 competed in three main categories, each of which featured manipulation of mini-robots by wire and wireless control. The competing teams were required to manipulate the mini-robots in barrier climbing, sumo wrestling, and dice operation.
The U.S., Japan, Thailand and other countries entered a total of more than 250 mini robots in the competition, which was organized by the Japan Society for Precision Engineering.

The 20 mini-robots developed by the MUST team won five of the six gold medals in the competition and took the top three prizes in category of dice operation with wireless control. Last year, the university also bagged five gold medals in the contest.
The KUAS team, which entered 15 robots in the 2010 competition, achieved its best performance in the category of sumo wrestling with wireless control, winning a gold and a silver medal.
Pan Tien-tzu, a KUAS assistant professor who led the Taiwan delegation to Japan, said it was the first time that universities across the Taiwan Strait had sent a joint team to the competition.

Lin Chih-sheng of KUAS, who was participating in the contest for the third time, said that he and his Chinese teammate faced a lot of pressure because most of the other competitors showed more speed than in previous years.

Taiwan has been excelling in mini-robot competitions internationally in the past few years, with the support of the Ministry of Education and the National Science Council, said Pan, who had led the Dayeh University team that won all the medals in the Japan contest in 2007.
KUAS said it is planning to host an international micro-robot contest next year. ENDITEM /pc ===

DOC.HEADLINE: Children want to grow up to be performers: survey
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, April 2 (CNA) 04/02/10 19:28:08 (By Lin Szu-yu and Y.F. Low)

TEXT.P: What jobs do Taiwanese children want the most when they grow up? According to a survey released Friday ahead of the April 4 Children's Day, they want to be singers and actors.
The survey, conducted by Mandarin Daily News, found that doctors were the second-most popular profession among children, followed by computer engineers.
Meanwhile, the three most unpopular professions were morticians, explosion stuntmen and farmers.

Also on the unpopular job list was president, which took fifth place. Many respondents said that becoming president would make them an easy target of public protests and that the job was too stressful and tiresome, though it offered high pay.
The survey was conducted in March among 1,588 fifth and sixth graders from 48 schools around the country. It had a margin of error of plus or minus 2.46 percent.

According to Feng Yen, a professor at National Taiwan University's Department of Social Work, the fact that show business was so attractive to the younger generation demonstrated that children are affected more by media and social influences than by their families or schools.
"They see only the pompous appearances but fail to see the hard work behind it," Feng said.
She advised parents not to allow their children to spend too much time watching TV or using the Internet to keep the media from taking their place in raising their children.
Feng also expressed concern over results that suggested children prefer jobs that offer high pay and little work.
She presumed that if hi-tech professionals, entrepreneurs and business owners were among the options provided in the survey, many children probably would have chosen them.
The survey results show that the top considerations in choosing professions among the children were pay, stability and whether they are interesting.
The most common reasons mentioned by the children for avoiding certain professions were that the jobs are strenuous, dangerous or unstable, or that the jobs do not interest them.
The study found obvious gender differences in choosing professions.
Among boys, the top five professions were computer engineers, baseball players, athletes, policemen and doctors.
The top five among girls were singers or actresses, fashion designers, teachers, beauticians and pastry chefs.
