DOC.HEADLINE: Economic Daily News: Taiwan's 'good' finances

TEXT.P: Minister of Finance Lee Sush-der has recently made a number of remarks that have sparked controversy, including his contention that "the Republic of China has the best finances."
One should not comment on finances based on sentiment but should only do so after examining all aspects objectively.

In terms of revenue, the government has often cut taxes based on election considerations or because of pressure from interest groups. In 2009, for example, the government revenue shortfall hit a record high of NT$265 billion, and accumulated overdue taxes totaled NT$313.8 billion. Meanwhile, none of the proposals to adjust the tax system has been put in place, and plans for tax hikes have repeatedly been postponed. How can we call this tax system good?

As for expenditures, non-discretionary spending on personnel, education and social welfare accounts for 70 percent of the government's total expenditures, leaving very limited flexibility for discretionary spending.

Another problem is the high level of government debt. As of the end of 2009, central government debt -- defined as general obligation debt with a maturity of over one year -- totaled NT$4.1 trillion, accounting for 33.1 percent of Taiwan's gross domestic product (GDP). But if hidden debt is added, government debt totals between NT$14 trillion and NT$20 trillion, far exceeding Taiwan's annual GDP. Based on this, how can Taiwan's finances be considered good?

Taiwan suffers from a budget deficit every year, regardless of whether the economy is good or bad. Can this chronic fiscal imbalance be overlooked? The government urgently needs to reform the worsening situation to enhance fiscal sustainability. (April 7, 2010)

DOC.HEADLINE: Ex-premier's planned Shanghai visit not political: spokesman
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, April 7 (CNA) 04/07/10 12:27:23 (By Garfie Li and Sofia Wu)

TEXT.P: President Ma Ying-jeou has not given former Premier Liu Chao-shiuan any specific mission for his planned visit to Shanghai, Presidential Office spokesman Lo Chih-chiang said Wednesday.

In line with current rules regulating travel to China by former officials, Liu filed an application with the National Immigration Agency under the Ministry of the Interior (MOI) Tuesday to visit Shanghai May 11-16 to preside over the Taiwan Pavilion's formal opening ceremony at the Shanghai World Expo.
The MOI will first solicit the opinion of Liu's successor, Premier Wu Den-yih, and then present the case for review by a cross-agency task force.

As Liu stepped down as premier less than seven months ago, his application has drawn the attention of the local news media. A newspaper front-page report said President Ma had appointed Liu to attend the Shanghai Expo lantern-lighting ceremony.
Commenting on the report, Lo said Ma has not assigned any mission to Liu.
"Liu has indeed informed Ma of his plan to travel to Shanghai, but the president has not given him any mission or directive, " Lo said.
Lo further said the former premier's planned Shanghai visit is purely a cultural event and has nothing to do with politics.
The China Times reported Wednesday in a front-page story that Liu will depart on a visit to Shanghai May 11 in his capacity as president of Taiwan's National Cultural Association.

Liu was quoted as having confirmed the travel plan, saying that he was invited by Taiwan External Trade Development Council Chairman Wang Chih-kang to attend the Taiwan Pavilion's official opening ceremony.
On the question of whether his visit to China less than a year after his retirement from government service was proper, Liu said he will visit Shanghai as a private cultural promoter.

"I will meet with academics and people in cultural circles in the Shanghai area to promote cultural and academic exchanges, " Liu was quoted as saying by the newspaper. "It is an appropriate and very meaningful event."

On the suggestion that he should wait three years before making any visit to China, Liu recalled that the former Democratic Progressive Party administration approved his visit to China in 2001, less than a year after he stepped down as deputy premier in 2000.

Former National Security Council Secretary-General Su Chi was forced to cancel a plan to attend the Boao Forum for Asia in Hainan, China after critics said he should not visit China shortly after leaving government service.

DOC.HEADLINE: Talk of the day -- Ma reaffirms reform in Harvard video conference
DOC.DATELINE: 04/07/10 12:31:40 (By Elizabeth Hsu)

TEXT.P: President Ma Ying-jeou's approval ratings remain low, but he made clear during a video conference with faculty and students at his alma mater Harvard University Tuesday that he will continue to push reforms, "regardless of the opinion polls or even the chances of a second term."
Ma said he was elected because people wanted reform, and he contended that if he managed to improve the economy, implement reform and demonstrate strong leadership, his popularity would bounce back.

During the forum, Ma also answered questions on some of his controversial policies, including rapprochement in cross-Taiwan Strait ties and a proposal to sign an economic cooperation framework agreement (ECFA) with Beijing.
The following are excerpts from local media coverage of the forum:
United Daily News:

President Ma regarded signing the cross-strait ECFA as part of an obvious trend if Taiwan wants to avoid being economically marginalized. He said Taiwan is 10 years late in taking the step, which he described as very crucial to the country.

He also said firmly that he believes the government's cross-strait policy is on the right track, and that his government will insist on doing what is right while trying its best to explain to the public the government's policy.

"I have always considered mainland China both a risk and an opportunity. My policy is to maximize the opportunity, but minimize the risk, " he said, stressing that he will continue efforts to lower cross-strait tensions and remove the Taiwan Strait from among the region's potential hot spots. (April 7, 2010).
Liberty Times:

Harvard scholar Steven M. Goldstein and the audience at Harvard at the forum aggressively questioned the Ma government's cross-strait policy. He asked Ma how he would handle, over the next two years, the dilemma of China not showing signs of giving up its military threat against Taiwan while claiming to do things in favor of Taiwan.

Another questioner brought up Ma's approval ratings and asked him why he was so unpopular. In response, Ma said he will focus on the job at hand regardless of opinion polls or re-election considerations.

Contending that people chose him as president because they hoped for change and reform, Ma said he believes his popularity will rebound if he meets people's expectations by reviving the economy, carrying out reforms and exhibiting strong leadership.
China Times:
In response to a question about the controversy in Taiwan over whether to scrap the death penalty, Ma reiterated that the death penalty is not the only way to lower serious crime.

In order to prevent dangerous inmates from harming society after being released from jail, Ma said the country has extended the time convicts sentenced to life imprisonment must serve before being eligible for parole, from 20 years to 25 years.
He also indicated Taiwan is considering changing the procedures leading up to the sentencing of a defendant to the death penalty.
"What the government should do is to provide the opportunity, the platform for rational discussion and debate, and try to find out the solution," Ma said. (April 7, 2010).

DOC.HEADLINE: Ministry denies report of military drill targeting China
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, April 7 (CNA) 04/07/10 12:34:20 (By Lee Ming-chung and Elizabeh Hsu)

TEXT.P: Taiwan's Ministry of National Defense (MND) on Wednesday denied a report that it was preparing a military drill in which it will simulate an attack on China.

The MND said in a statement that the report by the tabloid weekly Next Magazine, which said the military will include mid-range ballistic missiles and cruise missiles in the 2010 Han Kuang live-fire war games, was factually inaccurate.
The military exercise is scheduled to take place before the end of April.
The MND urged news media to check facts with the ministry before publishing reports on national defense affairs to ensure that they are accurate and balanced and avoid misleading society.

DOC.HEADLINE: Apple Daily: Opening to Chinese white-collar workers is correct

TEXT.P: The Ministry of the Interior recently relaxed regulations governing the transfer of Chinese employees to Taiwan by multinational companies, allowing extensions of up to three years upon the expiration of the workers' permitted duration of stay in Taiwan. Before the amendment, the allowable extension was up to one year.

The opposition Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) , however, is against the amendment. In addition to appealing to the fear of communist spies, the DPP also argued that the amendment would pave the way for the entry of Chinese laborers and technical workers.

In fact, the DPP's concerns are unwarranted. First, those Chinese workers sent by multinational businesses to Taiwan are white-collar managerial-level personnel, who account for only small numbers and are unrelated to opening Taiwan to Chinese laborers.
Second, communist spies have long been all around us. Those supervisors assigned to Taiwan are not necessarily spies, and there is no need to get terrified.
Complex bureaucratic controls are the phantom that is scaring foreign investors away. Deregulation of laws has long been overdue in Taiwan.
It is correct for the government to amend the regulations. The green camp has no need to exaggerate the risks. (April 7, 2010)

DOC.HEADLINE: Liberty Times: 'No Chinese workers' is a lie

TEXT.P: After fully understanding the pros and cons at a recent debate on the proposed Taiwan-China economic cooperation framework agreement (ECFA) , an invited jury of 16 undergraduates judged in favor of the opponent.

Frankly speaking, if undergraduates understand what an ECFA is, they will certainly oppose the proposal. Based on factor-price equalization, the high wages of Taiwanese workers will be dragged down if Taiwan and China open their markets to each other. This means that Taiwanese university graduates will have to face lower starting salaries and competition from Chinese job-seekers.

The administration of President Ma Ying-jeou may say that Chinese workers will definitely not be allowed into Taiwan. However, does the promise include a sunset clause or is it for good? The Ma administration has obviously failed to give a clear explanation of the issue, not to mention a firm guarantee.

According to recently amended regulations governing the transfer of Chinese employees to Taiwan by multinational companies, extensions of up to three years are allowed after the expiration of the workers' permitted duration of stay. The regulations allow Chinese nationals to work in Taiwan under multinational companies using the term "internal transfers." Aren't such loose restrictions equal to opening Taiwan to Chinese workers?

After Chinese capital is allowed into Taiwan following the signing of the ECFA, Chinese businesses with investment in Taiwan will definitely use the excuse of "internal transfers" to introduce large numbers of Chinese blue-collar and white-collar workers into Taiwan.

In conclusion, the concessions offered by China are only lip service, talk of cross-Taiwan Strait brotherhood is merely publicity, and promises by the Ma administration are just empty rhetoric that we can never believe in. (April 7, 2010)

DOC.HEADLINE: Labor affairs chief clarifies remarks on internship program pay
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, April 7 (CNA) 04/07/10 14:49:42 (By Chen Shun-hsieh, Hsu Jui-ting and Sofia Wu)

TEXT.P: There is no clear correlation between a perceived decline in entry-level pay in the private sector and a government internship program that pays new university graduates NT$22,000 (US$696.20) a month, a senior official said Wednesday.

Council of Labor Affairs (CLA) Minister Wang Ju-hsuan was responding to criticism from labor rights groups over a comment she made in an interview with the CommonWealth Magazine on the internship program.

Wang told the magazine that the NT$22,000 monthly salary given to new university and college graduates working as interns under the program "wasn't bad, " because many of them might not have found work in the soft labor market if the program had not been launched.

"When the new graduate internship program was launched last year, there were actually few job openings available, " Wang was quoted as saying. "New college and university graduates should not complain about the salary.... Without this program, they would not be earning anything."

Wang explained Wednesday that most private companies were reluctant to hire any new employees last year amid a global economic slump and said the approach at the time for first-time job seekers was to "try and get a job first and then look for something better."

Labor rights activist groups disagreed with Wang's assessment that the pay level "wasn't bad, " arguing that entry-level salaries have fallen because of the internship program, more commonly known as the "22K" program.

But Wang responded Wednesday that the correlation is not as clear-cut as critics have alleged, adding that she was actually against the "22K" program at the time because the NT$22,000 per month subsidy financed by taxpayers was too high.
A group of opposition Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) lawmakers urged Wang to apologize for her comments on the program.

DPP Legislator Lee Chun-yee said the "22K" program, advertised by the government as giving new job-seekers immediate job opportunities, had only helped reduce the unemployment rate marginally in 2009, from 5.98 percent to 5.94 percent.

Lee also contended that Wang's remarks indicated that President Ma Ying-jeou's administration had failed to put itself in other people's shoes in formulating policy, and he said Wang should apologize or step down from her post.

DOC.HEADLINE: Taiwan share prices close higher
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, April 7 (CNA) 04/07/10 15:32:23

TEXT.P: Taiwan's share prices closed higher Wednesday with the weighted index, the market's key barometer, moving up 32.13 points, or 0.39 percent, to close at 8,121.78.
The local bourse opened at 8,131.4 and fluctuated between a low of 8,091.28 and a high of 8,133.45 during the day's trading. Market turnover totaled NT$129.83 billion (US$4.11 billion).

All eight major stock categories gained ground, with textile issues gaining the most at 1.51 percent. Paper and pulp shares rose 1.36 percent, followed by construction issues at 1.31 percent and foodstuff shares at 1.16 percent. Plastics and chemicals issues rose 1.14 percent, banking and financial stocks moved up 0.35 percent, machinery and electronics issues were up 0.21 percent and cement shares advanced 0.02 percent.
Gainers outnumbered losers 1,590 to 1,512, with 318 remaining unchanged.
Foreign investors and Chinese QDIIs were net buyers of NT$11.39 billion in shares. (by Olivia Wang)

DOC.HEADLINE: 7-time NBA champion Robert Horry to visit Taiwan
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, April 7 (CNA) 04/07/10 15:44:26 (By Chris Wang)

TEXT.P: Robert Horry, one of only nine players to have won at least seven National Basketball Association (NBA) championships, is scheduled to visit Taiwan next week for the official launch of the NBA's traditional Chinese character Web site, organizers said Wednesday.

Horry, who collected one more championship ring in his 17-year NBA career (1992-2008) than Michael Jordan, will visit Taiwan from April 14-16 and attend the launching ceremony of the NBA.com/Taiwan Web site, a collaboration of local sports Web site Pixnet and the NBA, Pixnet announced in a statement.
According to Pixnet, basketball-crazy Taiwan at one point ranked third, behind the U.S. and Canada, in visitors to the NBA's official Web site.

One of only three players to win consecutive NBA championships with two different teams -- the Houston Rockets and the Los Angeles Lakers -- Horry was best known for his clutch three-point shooting in the playoffs, earning him the nickname "Big Shot Bob."
The 208-centimeter sweet-shooting forward still holds the record for most career three-pointers made in the NBA Finals and is second on the all-time list for three-pointers made in the playoffs.
Hong Kong-based media company TOM Group Limited signed a four-year deal with the NBA in 2008 for the rights to operate the NBA Web site in China, Taiwan and Hong Kong.

Taiwanese fans complained, however, that the company merely converted text in simplified Chinese characters, used in China, into traditional Chinese characters for the Taiwanese audience, neglecting the differences in basketball terms and the transliteration of player names between Taiwan and China.

DOC.HEADLINE: U.S. dollar down on Taipei Forex
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, April 7 (CNA) 04/07/10 16:40:49 (By Olivia Wang)

TEXT.P: The U.S. dollar lost ground against the New Taiwan dollar on the Taipei Foreign Exchange Wednesday, dropping NT$0.067 to close at NT$31.628.
A total of US$1.09 billion changed hands during the trading session.
The U.S. dollar opened at the day's high of NT$31.695, and fell to a low of NT$31.561 before rebounding.

DOC.HEADLINE: Taiwan business leaders meet visiting Shanghai mayor
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, April 7 (CNA) 04/07/10 16:55:08 (By Lin Shu-yuan and Elizabeth Hsu)

TEXT.P: Taiwanese business leaders, including Hon Hai Group Chairman Terry Gou, had breakfast with visiting Shanghai Mayor Han Zheng Wednesday, the second day of the Chinese official's high-profile visit to the island.

At the event hosted by Taiwan External Trade Development Council Chairman Wang Chih-kang and Taipei-based Chinese National Federation of Industries (CNFI) Chairman Chen Wu-hsiung, Han expressed hope for more cooperation with Taiwanese businesspeople operating in Shanghai.

Han's wish drew a positive response from Chen, who said that over two-thirds of the federation's more than 90,000 members had invested in the mainland. He said he looked forward to more cross-strait cooperation, saying the two sides could "work together to earn money from around the world."
Wang lauded the Taiwan Pavilion that will be part of the Shanghai World Exposition in May. It will be the first time in 40 years that Taiwan participates in the expo.

The breakfast was also attended by Ting Hsin Group Chairman Wei Ying-chiao, Delta Electronics Group Chairman Bruce C.H. Cheng, Cathay Financial Holdings Group Chairman Tsai Hong-tu, ASUSTek Computer Chairman Jonney Shih and Uni- President Enterprises Corp. President Alex Lo.
Delta Group's Cheng took advantage of the meeting's media attention to announce his company's plans to develop an electricity-powered automobile.

Cheng said that Delta Electronics is developing the electric automobile industry in Taiwan and on the mainland "at the same time," noting that while operating a large research and development base in Taiwan's Taoyuan area, the company has also opened a research and development center in Shanghai's Pudong district.
Asked whether he hoped that China would offer preferential investment opportunities, the business tycoon answered that Shanghai had already provided Taiwan enterprises many, including cheap land.
Cheng said that "when doing business you should rely on your own strength and competitiveness."

Taiwan-based Delta Group is the world's largest provider of switching power supplies and DC brushless fans, as well as a major source for power management solutions, components, visual displays, industrial automation, networking products and renewable energy solutions.

The Shanghai mayor, leading an over 200-member delegation, arrived in Taipei for a four-day visit Tuesday, culminating 10 years of exchanges between the two cities that began in 2001 when President Ma Ying-jeou was mayor of the capital city.

DOC.HEADLINE: No entry of Chinese office workers to Taiwan: interior minister
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, April 7 (CNA) 04/07/10 17:22:18 (By C. C. Hsieh and Flor Wang)

TEXT.P: The government's recent changes in regulations regarding short stays of Chinese professionals in Taiwan will not affect Taiwan's employment market, Interior Minister Jiang Yi-huah told a news conference Wednesday.
In line with recently revised regulations, Chinese salaried workers are allowed to make short-term stays here for visit, study or to attend meetings for a period up to three months, Jiang said.
These short-term visitors from China are not permitted to engage in paying jobs while in Taiwan, and they will not become either white-collar or blue-collar workers, he said.

Jiang was responding to charges by opposition Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) lawmakers that visits by Chinese professionals had already doubled in the past year, and that the government's easing of restrictions on their visits was opening a channel that would be abused to allow Chinese into Taiwan to work.
The Ma Ying-jeou government has insisted that it will not open Taiwan's doors to Chinese workers in an economic framework cooperation agreement (ECFA) it is currently negotiating with China.
Jiang denied that looser restrictions on professional visits meant opening the doors to Chinese workers.

In the past, he said, local companies whose annual revenue was over NT$30 million were allowed to invite 200 Chinese professionals to visit Taiwan, while those with an annual revenue below that level could invite 45.
The policy change will now allow companies whose annual revenue exceeds NT$100 million to invite 400 persons a year.
Citing statistics compiled by his ministry, Jiang reported that from 2005-2009, 351,706 professionals and 149,705 businesspeople from China were approved to visit Taiwan.

DOC.HEADLINE: Scholars unveil snapshot of galaxy cluster growth
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, April 7 (CNA) 04/07/10 17:50:55 (by Sunnie Chen)

TEXT.P: A team of astrophysicists from Academia Sinica and Japan have captured a snapshot showing the growth of a galaxy cluster for the first time, according to a press release issued by Taiwan's top research institute.

Academia Sinica's Postdoctoral Fellow Nobuhiro Okabe and Associate Research Fellow Keiichi Umetsu from the Institute of Astronomy and Astrophysics at Academia Sinica (ASIAA) cooperated with Madoka Kawaharada, special postdoctoral researcher from the Institute of Physical and Chemical Research (RIKEN) in Japan, to develop the result.

Galaxy clusters are composed of thousands of galaxies and X-ray-emitting hot gas as well as dark matter. The research team has revealed a snapshot of the dramatic growth of a galaxy cluster titled "Abell 1689."

According to their study, which will be published online in "The Astrophysics Journal" on April 9, the cluster grows through heating that is triggered by matter falling from a filamentary large-scale structure outside the cluster known as a "cosmic web."

Using Japan's Suzaku X-ray satellite, the team was able to measure emissions from hot gas in the outermost regions of Abell 1689. They discovered that the anisotropic temperature distribution of the hot gas is 58 million degrees Celsius in one direction and 23 million degrees in the other around the boundary of the cluster.

They then compared their X-ray data with a galaxy map made from Sloan Digital Sky Survey (SDSS) data as well as with "gravitational lensing" data from the Japanese Subaru telescope and the Hubble Space Telescope, eventually finding that the cooler gas is likely to have subsonic motion.

Analyzing the X-ray, optical and gravitational lensing data, the team developed a clear snapshot showing the growth of the galaxy cluster being affected by the large-scale structure in which clusters are embedded.
"This new finding provides proof and inspires further research in this field, " said Seng Yao-huan, an ASIAA scholar.

DOC.HEADLINE: Myanmar girl thanks Taiwan for facial reconstruction
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, April 7 (CNA) 04/07/10 18:02:06 (By Chen Shun-hsieh and Y.F. Low)

TEXT.P: A girl from Myanmar expressed her gratitude Wednesday after facial reconstruction surgery by a Taiwanese medical team.
Nine-year-old Mi Tho, who arrived in Taiwan Feb. 27 to receive the procedure at Taipei's Chang Gung Memorial Hospital, will return home Thursday.

On the eve of her departure, the girl presented surgeon Lo Lun-jou and nurse Chou Su-yeh pictures she had drawn while recovering and said "thank you" in Mandarin in appreciation for their care and services.
According to the hospital, Mi Tho was born with a cleft lip, a cleft palate, an exposed nasolacrimal sac and without a nose ridge. As a result, she had difficulty speaking properly.

Her condition came to the attention of the Global Hope Network International (GHNI) in 2008, when the humanitarian aid organization was operating a rescue mission in Myanmar in the wake of a hurricane.

With the help of GHNI, Mi Tho received cleft lip and palate treatment in her country in 2009 but failed to see significant improvement. She was later transferred to Chang Gung Hospital using funds from the World Craniofacial Foundation and Taiwan's Noordhoff Craniofacial Foundation.
Lo said one person in 50,000 is born with a cleft lip and palate and at the same time without a nose ridge.
The most difficult part of the surgery was reconstructing the girl's nose ridge, which involved removing a fragment of her sixth right rib for implantation into her face, Lo said.

He said the medical team also treated Mi Tho's exposed nasolacrimal sac and her cleft lip and palate, successfully improving her appearance. With practice, the girl should now be able to pronounce words correctly, he added.
Mi Tho has another condition -- extreme width between her eyes -- that the medical team determined should only be treated after she reaches adulthood, Lo said.

DOC.HEADLINE: Malfeasant civil servants may see pension cut or forfeited
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, April 7 (CNA) 04/07/10 18:04:02 (By Su Lung-chi and Sofia Wu)

TEXT.P: Taiwan's lawmakers warned Wednesday that civil servants who commit wrongdoings could see their pension cut or eliminated if new legislation passes the legislature.
Currently, civil servants found to be corrupt, guilty of dereliction of duty or other misconduct can sometimes evade punishment by retiring early or quitting their jobs.
But once a raft of draft amendments to the current statute governing the discipline of civil servants clears the legislature, they will no longer be able to do so, lawmakers said.

The Legislative Yuan's Judiciary and Organic Laws and Statutes Committee finalized a first review of the draft package earlier in the day, which includes a "retroactivity clause" to legalize forfeit of overall retirement pension or severance pay or a 10 percent to 20 percent cut in such payments for malfeasant officials who resign or apply for early retirement to avoid discipline.

The draft "retroactivity clause" also stipulates that retiring or departing public servants who failed to carry out their official duties can be slapped with fines ranging between NT$10,000 (US$316.46) and NT$1 million.
The "retroactivity clause, " if passed, will also be applied to political appointees, the Judicial Yuan said in a statement served to the legislature.

The Judicial Yuan, which initiated the draft package, said that the existing disciplinary sanctions for public functionaries, such as job deprivation, suspension from work, pay cuts, reprimand, demerit and demotion, are not effective enough to deter government workers from malfeasance or dereliction of duty because they can evade penalties by early retirement or resignation.

The draft package also stipulates that military service members should not apply for retirement so long as the Commission on the Disciplinary Sanctions of Public Functionaries is still screening relevant disciplinary cases involving them or the Control Yuan is screening relevant impeachment cases and that they will also be subject to the same "retroactivity" regulations.

The package of draft bills further proposes that public servants should not take jobs at other public agencies or state-owned enterprises when they are suspended from their original work and that the period of suspension should not be shorter than six months nor longer than three years.
They will also be prohibited from getting any promotion or being transferred to a leading position within two years of returning to work.

Meanwhile, the package proposes a new clause that authorizes discipline of public servants who do anything seriously detrimental to the government's credibility or reputation, even though such moves have not violated any law regarding their official duties.

All new disciplinary proposals included in the package passed the legislative committee's first review, but individual lawmakers remain divided on the duration of "retroactive periods" for various disciplinary measures, which are subject to consultations between ruling and opposition parties before the package is put up for a second reading at the legislative plenary session

DOC.HEADLINE: President pledges support for islandwide cultural development
DOC.DATELINE: Kaohsiung, April 7 (CNA) 04/07/10 18:37:54 (By Chen Shou-gow and Y.L. Kao)

TEXT.P: President Ma Ying-jeou said Wednesday that the government will continue give priority to cultural development, no matter which party is in power.

At a groundbreaking ceremony for the Wei-Wu-Ying Center for the Performing Arts in Kaohsiung, Ma said the government must achieve balance in terms of cultural development in the north and south of the island as well as in building infrastructure and installing cultural "software."

Towards this end, the NT$9.97 billion arts center in southern Taiwan will be built as a world-class facility, bigger than the National Chiang Kai Shek Cultural Center in Taipei, he said. Its theater will have a seating capacity of 2,260, compared to 1,522 at the National Theater Hall in Taipei, he added.
Ma said that despite the government's tight budget, funding for the construction of the Kaohsiung arts center remains in place.

In addition to the Wei-Wu-Ying center, a maritime cultural and pop music center is being built in Kaohsiung City, southern Taiwan, Ma noted, adding that the government should also have a role in expanding the people's involvement in culture.

Ma said that he believes the Wei-Wu-Ying center will be put to the good use because some 200 performing groups have settled in southern Taiwan as a result of the Cultural and Creative Industries Act and revised regulations which allow subsidies for such groups.
The president also said he has asked chairman of the National Chiang Kai Shek Cultural Center Kuo Wei-fan to arrange for the Wei-Wu-Ying center to also host shows that have been staged in Taipei.

The 10-hectare Wei-Wu-Ying center, scheduled to be completed in 2013, will comprise a 2,000-seat Concert Hall, a 2,260-seat Lyric Theater, a 470-seat Play House, a 1,254-seat Experimental Theater and other service facilities.
The Dutch firm Mecanoo Architecten B.V. won the contract for the design of the center.

DOC.HEADLINE: TSU demands government publish China's 'early harvest list'
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, April 7 (CNA) 04/07/10 19:05:35 (By K. H. Wen and Flor Wang)

TEXT.P: Opposition Taiwan Solidarity Union (TSU) Chairman Huang Kun-huei demanded Wednesday that the government immediately publish a list of goods put forth by China that could receive priority tax cuts after recent cross-Taiwan Strait trade talks.

Speaking at a news conference, Huang cited anonymous government sources as saying China put a 700-item "early harvest list" on the negotiating table during last week's second round of talks on a proposed economic cooperation framework agreement (ECFA).

China demands preferential or zero-tariff privileges from Taiwan for the 700 items, Huang said, adding that they are mainly in the telecommunications, information, financial and media sectors -- industries in which Taiwan is competitive.

"This will affect the livelihoods of more than 630,000 Taiwanese workers," he said, citing statistics compiled by the Council of Labor Affairs which show that as of February, 207,000 Taiwanese worked in the IT and communications sectors and 425,000 in the financial and insurance sectors.
"In total, China's 'early harvest list' could affect the lives of more than 1 million Taiwanese people," he said.

Huang also criticized the Mainland Affairs Council (MAC) for saying the signing of the ECFA is to protect vulnerable industries and the underprivileged in Taiwan. "The MAC has become a propaganda machine of the government sector," he said.

C. S. Liu, deputy executive director of the major opposition Democratic Progressive Party, said China was trying to expand its strategic position by gaining control of Taiwan's key industries. "This is terrible," he said.
"Taiwan's signing of an ECFA with China will only benefit certain enterprises at home, and China will benefit the most," he said.

DOC.HEADLINE: Taiwan launches business alliance in cloud computing
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, April 7 (CNA) 04/07/10 19:40:55 (By Alex Jiang)

TEXT.P: More than 50 companies in Taiwan's information and communications technology (ICT) and service industries launched an alliance Wednesday in bid to grab a share of the growing cloud computing market.

Cloud computing, which means outsourcing online data storage and applications, will effectively lower companies' operational costs and reduce systematic risk, Chunghwa Telecom Co. Chairman Lu Shyue-ching said at the inauguration of the Taiwan Cloud Computing Consortium in Taipei.
"Cloud computing is an ongoing revolution in the information industry, " said Lu. "It makes data management easy, cheap and time-efficient and is also energy- saving and eco-friendly."
According to Lu, who is head of the new consortium, Taiwan will be able to boost the production value of its ICT industries by investing in cloud computing.

"Taiwan's ICT hardware industry will generate an estimated production value of US$366 billion by 2020, while the ICT software industry is forecast to grow from US$20 billion in 2009 to US$50 billion in 2014," he said.
The share of the software industry in the entire ICT industry will increase from 15 percent to 25 percent during that period, Lu forecast.

Globally, the production value of the consumer service component of the cloud computing industry would grow from US$38.7 billion in 2008 to US$101.8 billion in 2012, representing a compound annual growth rate of 26 percent, he said, citing Ministry of Economics Affairs figures.
The output of business applications in the industry is projected to rise from US$59 billion in 2008 to US$213.3 billion in 2012, at a compound annual growth rate of 38 percent, Lu added.
In addition, the output of computing service in the industry would grow by a compound annual rate of 90 percent, increasing from US$3.4 billion in 2008 to US$94.5 billion in 2012, he added.
The consortium aims to promote three aspects of cloud computing -- infrastructure, platform and software -- and will also develop a platform to incorporate energy-saving technologies, he said.

The inaugural ceremony showcased cloud computing applications in personalized Internet TV, personal health care, education, street image and video conferencing and featured a mobile data center developed by Taiwan's Inventec Corp., the world's largest server maker.
The center, which looks like a container, can accommodate 576 servers and 1,200 hard drives, said Richard Lee, chairman of the company and deputy head of the consortium.
"It can be used by a company with up to 3,000 employees and can help save 20 percent in costs," he added.

DOC.HEADLINE: International artists display pastels in Taipei
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, April 7 (CNA) 04/07/10 19:42:50 (by Sunnie Chen)

TEXT.P: An international pastel exhibition featuring 60 works by almost 50 artists opened at the National Taiwan Arts Education Center in Taipei recently.

The exhibit, titled the "2010 International Pastel Artists Invitational Exhibition, " showcases works by well-known artists from the United States, France and Taiwan that exemplify the beauty of the medium, Jason Chang, an organizer of the event, said Wednesday.

"Pastel art is very popular in the United States, where [around] 60 associations promote the art form, but it is not as popular in Taiwan, " said Chang, president of the North America Pastel Artists Association.

Chang has lived in New York almost 30 years and taught at the College of New Rochelle, St. John's University and the National Arts Club for many years. Since retiring, he has devoted his time to promoting pastel art in the place he was born -- Taiwan.

He first held the exhibit in 2007. This time the show includes works by American artist Rae Smith, president of the Pastel Society of America, and French artist Sylvie Cabal, the founder of Art du Pastel en France as well as the president of Art du Pastel en Normandie.
Cabal's works range from figurative to abstract and have been exhibited and bought by collectors all over the world. The artist is displaying her work "Mature" in the exhibition.

DOC.HEADLINE: President outlines four tasks for better economy this year
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, April 7 (CNA) 04/07/10 19:55:43 (By Lee Su-hua and Y.L. Kao)

TEXT.P: President Ma Ying-jeou said Wednesday that if Taiwan completes four major tasks, its economic performance this year will be better than last year.

Ma said the World Bank predicted earlier in the year that Taiwan's economy would reach 4.5 percent this year, the highest among the "four Asian tigers, " which also comprise South Korea, Hong Kong and Singapore.
Without directly saying whether Taiwan could reach the target, Ma outlined four tasks for the country.

The first is to bring down unemployment and create jobs, Ma said, adding that the Executive Yuan hopes to decrease the unemployment rate to less than 5 percent this year. He said this would be a challenge for the government because it needs to create a lot of jobs to reach the goal.
To this end, private investment and consumption should also be expanded along with the implementation of other economic stimulus projects, Ma said.

He also said that the legislature needs to clear an industrial innovation bill this year. The bill aims to meet the needs of industrial development and innovation by offering tax incentives to replace those that were lost when the Statute for Industrial Upgrading expired at the end of 2009.

Meanwhile, more efforts should be made in energy conservation and carbon reduction, said Ma, adding that the country should work to develop several emerging industries -- including the green energy and LED industries -- that are vital to economic growth.
Taiwan should join regional economic integration to allow it to keep abreast with economic growth in Asia, Ma said.

Chinese tourist arrivals made a great contribution to Taiwan's economy last year, Ma said, citing statistics that found the 970,000 visits made by Chinese tourists contributed to 0.49 percent of Taiwan's GDP last year.
Ma made the remarks after being briefed on the overall economic situation this year by Council for Economic Planning and Development Chairman Tsai Hsung- hsiung.
Tsai reported that as the global economy recovers, the government expects private investment in Taiwan will reach NT$1.857 trillion this year.

DOC.HEADLINE: Shanghai visit simply for cultural purposes: ex-premier
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, April 7 (CNA) 04/07/10 19:58:17 (By Garfie Li and Sofia Wu)

TEXT.P: Former Premier Liu Chao-shiuan said Wednesday his planned visit to Shanghai is purely for the promotion of Taiwanese culture and has absolutely nothing to do with politics.

In line with current rules regulating travel to China by former officials, Liu filed an application with the National Immigration Agency under the Ministry of the Interior (MOI) Tuesday to visit Shanghai May 11-16 for the formal opening of the Taiwan Pavilion at the 2010 Shanghai World Expo.
The MOI will first solicit the opinion of Liu's successor, Premier Wu Den-yih on the application and then present the case to a cross-agency task force for review.
As Liu stepped down as premier less than seven months ago, his application has drawn the attention media attention locally and objections from the opposition parties.

Liu, who is now president of Taiwan's National Cultural Association (NCA), said in an interview with the Central News Agency that President Ma Ying-jeou has been informed of his plan to visit Shanghai to officiate at the Taiwan Pavilion opening ceremony.

"This is a very good thing...It is very fitting for me to attend the event in my capacity as the NCA head, " Liu said, adding that his current mission is to promote Taiwanese culture and he is more than willing to attend the Shanghai event to fulfill his duty.
During his planned visit, Liu said, he may also take part in some cultural, artistic or academic activities. "But I will not be involved in any political events during my stay," he stressed.

On the suggestion that he should wait three years before making any visits to China, Liu recalled that the former Democratic Progressive Party administration approved his visit to China in 2001, less than a year after he stepped down as deputy premier in 2000.

Former National Security Council Secretary-General Su Chi was forced to cancel a plan to attend the Boao Forum for Asia in Hainan, China after critics said he should not visit China so soon after leaving government office.

Meanwhile, Presidential Office spokesman Lo Chih-chiang said earlier in the day that President Ma is aware of Liu's travel plans but has not given any specific directives for Liu to carry out during his planned visit.
Lo further said the former premier's planned visit to Shanghai is purely a cultural matter and has nothing to do with politics.
In response, the opposition Democratic Progressive Party reiterated that it is opposed to Liu's Shanghai travel plans at this time because of national security concerns.

"We do not understand why many former senior officials of the Ma administration want to visit China so soon after they leave office, " said DPP spokesman Tsai Chi-chang. "What is their purpose or motivation? Would such visits benefit Taiwan? The administration has not given clear any explanation."

While the DPP supports normal exchanges across the Taiwan Strait, Tsai said, it is worried that the Ma administration may send former officials to conduct behind-the-scenes political negotiations with China.

DOC.HEADLINE: Trans Asia to launch flights from Kaohsiung to Fuzhou, Xiamen
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, April 7 (CNA) 04/07/10 20:00:07 (By H. H. Chao and Flor Wang)

TEXT.P: Taiwan's Trans Asia Airways announced Wednesday that it will launch non-stop flights from Kaohsiung City in southern Taiwan to Xiamen and Fuzhou cities in southeastern China's Fujian Province this week.
According to the Taipei-based carrier, it will use 182-seat Airbus 321 planes to ply the two routes.

The airline said it will start the weekly Kaohsiung-Fuzhou route from Thursday and the Kaohsiung- Xiamen route from Friday, mainly to serve the many Taiwanese businesspeople working in the two Chinese cities.

Those who fly from Kaohsiung to Fuzhou or Xiamen will save at least one-hour of travel time than if they were to take ferries to those Chinese cities via Taiwan's outlying Kinmen or Matsu islands, a company spokesperson said.
Trans Asia already offers direct cross-Taiwan Strait flights from the Taipei Songshan Airport to Fuzhou and from the Taichung Chingchuankang Airport in central Taiwan to Fuzhou and Xiamen cities.
China Airlines, Taiwan's largest carrier, also announced recently that it will offer non-stop flights from Kaohsiung to Guangzhou and Xiamen beginning in June.

DOC.HEADLINE: Shanghai enterprises encouraged to invest in Taiwan
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, April 7 (CNA) 04/07/10 20:12:01 (By Kuo Mei-lan, Feng Chao and Elizabeth Hsu)

TEXT.P: Taiwan promoted its investment environment to investors from China's biggest city Shanghai at an investment presentation held Wednesday in the capital city.
Taiwan External Trade Development Council (TAITRA) Chairman Wang Chih-kang said geographically, Taiwan is in the center of the entire Asia-Pacific region.
"It is shorter to travel from Taipei to Shanghai than from Beijing to Shanghai," Wang said.
Therefore, Wang said he believes Taipei and Taiwan are the "ideal spot" for Chinese enterprises to open Asia-Pacific operational headquarters.
The presentation targeted an audience of Shanghai companies' representatives who are visiting Taiwan as part of a delegation led by Shanghai Mayor Han Zheng.

Attending the presentation were more than 50 Shanghai companies, including the SAIC Motor, Bailian Group and Shimao Group. The event was jointly organized by the TAITRA, the Taipei-based Chinese National Federation of Industries (CNFI) and Shanghai's Council for the Promotion of International Trade.
The Chinese businesses are mostly big enterprises whose assets were reported totalling over NT$1 trillion each.

Han arrived in Taipei on Tuesday for a four-day visit, which is regarded as the climax of 10 years of exchanges between the capital city and Shanghai that began in 2001 when President Ma Ying-jeou was Taipei's mayor.
At the event Wednesday, Han said he will encourage Shanghai enterprises to invest in Taiwan.
Since the first Taiwanese investor went to Shanghai in 1987, the city has become a heaven of Taiwanese investments. Han said he hopes Taiwan will also become a heaven of Chinese investments.
The mayor expressed that by linking Shanghai and Taiwan together, he believes companies on each side of the Taiwan Strait will be able to enjoy better development.

The presentation was part of Han's tight schedule on his second-day stay in Taipei, which started with a breakfast meeting with Taiwan's influential entrepreneurs. Later in the day, Han rode together with Taipei Mayor Hau Lung- bin on the city's Mass Rapid Transit Danshui Line and visited the Beitou Incinerator.

Also on his agenda is a visit to Taipei's popular tourist attractions, including the National Palace Museum, the Taipei 101 skyscraper and the Eslite Bookstore in the bustling Xinyi district, according to the city government.

DOC.HEADLINE: Yani Tseng within reach of world No. 1 woman golfer
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, April 7 (CNA) 04/07/10 20:24:17 (By Neil Lu and Luke Sabatier)

TEXT.P: Taiwanese golfer Yani Tseng has vaulted to second in the women's world golf rankings after winning the Kraft Nabisco Championship, the first major tournament of the season, leaving her in good position to make a run at dethroning long-time world No. 1 Lorena Ochoa.

Tseng, who started last week ranked sixth, regained the spot she had occupied between Nov. 24, 2008 and Aug. 31, 2009 after her one-shot victory in the Kraft Nabisco. She has not been ranked outside the top six since winning her first major, the LPGA Championship, in June 2008.
The rankings are determined by a complicated formula weighting players' performances over the past 104 weeks on all major women's professional golf tours around the world.
Points earned based on tournament finishes are divided by tournaments played to give a points average used to rank the players. Anything over a 10 is considered phenomenal.
Ochoa who has reigned as the top player in woman 's golf for 155 weeks, averaged over 13 for much of 2009, far outdistancing Tseng and other challengers.

Tseng had fallen as far as sixth in the rankings after suffering through an inconsistent second half of 2009, but her recent surge (she also won the Australian Women's Open in mid-March) and Ochoa's inability to reproduce her incredible run between 2006-2008 have pulled the two much closer.

Ochoa, who won only three events in 2009 after averaging seven tour wins per year the previous three years and who has not won a major in two years, has grown vulnerable at the top, falling to an average of 9.34, only 0.53 ahead of Tseng' s 8.81.

Another LPGA tournament win by Tseng could end Ochoa's reign, but Tseng herself has to be careful about maintaining her own standing as another three top players -- Korea's Jiyai Shin, Norway's Suzann Pettersen, and Japan's Ai Miyazato -- are fairly closely bunched behind the 21-year-old Taiwanese.
Aside from soaring up the world rankings, Tseng catapulted to the top of other major lists by winning this past weekend's major in Rancho Mirage, California.
Her US$300,000 first prize made her the leading prize money winner on the LPGA Tour after its first four events of the year.
She also moved into the top spot in the standings for the highly coveted LPGA Player of the Year award, ahead of Miyazato and Pettersen.

DOC.HEADLINE: Taipei Int'l Flora Expo unveils PET pavilion
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, April 7 (CNA) 04/07/10 21:01:35 (By Johnson Sun, Yang Su-min and Y.L. Kao)

TEXT.P: A pavilion in the shape of an ark built with 1.5 million recyclable plastic PET bottles was unveiled Wednesday ahead of the Taipei Int'l Flora Expo scheduled to open Nov. 6.

The pavilion promoting the concept of environmental conservation was the only one among 14 expo pavilions that was designed and constructed by a private enterprise. The structure cost the Far Eastern Group NT$100 million and can be dismantled for future use after the expo concludes.

Douglas Hsu, chairman of the Far Eastern Group, said earlier plans had called for the use of 1 million bottles for the facility, but it eventually took 1.5 million bottles to complete the 130-meter, nine-story pavilion.
Taiwan produces more than 2.4 billion PET bottles annually, of which only 4 percent are recycled, Hsu said. The others are disposed of as nondegradable garbage, damaging the environment, he said.
After being specially processed, the transparent bottles were used to provide protection from the wind, sun and rain, while also insulating the pavilion, Hsu said.

To promote environmental awareness by making good use of PET bottles, the group is scheduled in August to launch souvenir LED light balls in four colors that can be attached to any type of PET bottle and used as portable flashlights, Hsu added.

DOC.HEADLINE: Taiwan institute unveils e-reading technologies
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, April 7 (CNA) 04/07/10 21:09:29 (By Alex Jiang)

TEXT.P: Taiwan's semi-official Institute for Information Industry unveiled technologies Wednesday to meet demands for digital reading and help local publishing and media industries in their transformation to the digital age.

"The Content Roaming Service System (C.Ro.S.S.) technology, or seamless reading technology, allows one to stick with a certain page of an e-book on different devices, " said Nick Cheng, an engineer of the institute's Innovative DigiTech- Enabled Applications and Services Institute.

"The devices can be a smartphone, a computer or an e-reader," he said at a ceremony in Taipei. "With the technology, you can read a book on a cell phone on the subway and continue to read the book on a big screen equipped with the Wi-Fi wireless technology when you get home."
Cheng showed how to transfer a digital content from one device to another by swiping a finger across a cell phone screen.
Cheng's colleague demonstrated how digital content automatically fits the screen of a computer screen, a smartphone or an e-reader by using another new technology to process the content first.
"These new technologies will bring opportunities for content providers, " Yu Kuo-ting, the head of the Magazine Business Association of Taipei, said at the ceremony.
Shih Mu-piao, vice president of Chunghwa Telecom Co. -- Taiwan's largest telecommunications company -- said he hopes the technologies will be widely adopted in the world.

Danny Yao, vice president of BenQ Asia Pacific and president of BenQ Taiwan, urged local publishers to work together to quickly overcome difficulties in digital content conversion, pricing and digital copyright.

DOC.HEADLINE: Taiwanese lovers to cycle around the world in 30 months
DOC.DATELINE: Taoyuan, Taiwan April 7 (CNA) 04/07/10 21:24:18 (By Chris Wang)

TEXT.P: A Taiwanese couple are embarking on a cycling trip that would take them to four continents in 30 months to promote the centenary of the Republic of China (Taiwan), as well as environmental awareness and Taiwanese products.
Lin Hsiau-kai, 37, and his girlfriend Yen Yi-hui, 27, began their 55,000-kilometer trip on Wednesday by flying from Taoyuan International Airport to Bangkok, Thailand, where the cycling will begin.

"Ever since I was a high school freshman in 1986, I've dreamt about taking this trip and it has finally come true. But the road is long and there's a big challenge ahead, " Lin told the CNA at the airport.

Lin and Yen plan to travel the world on bicycles from April 2010 to October 2012. During the 30 months, they will cycle across Southeast Asia, Oceania, Central Asia and Europe before flying across the Atlantic Ocean to the United States and then Japan, the final stop.

Lin, who worked at the technical department of the renowned Taiwanese dance troupe Cloud Gate together with Yen before the two quit their jobs, said this has been a dream of his since he read about the story of Hu Jung-hua, the first Taiwanese to cycle around the world in the 1980s, and was greatly inspired.
Interestingly, he said, a coincidence made the trip happen.

"My landlord told us a couple of months ago that we had to move out because he had decided to sell his apartment. I thought about taking a break from work before coming up with the idea to turn the break into a cycling tour around the world, " Lin said.

He thought the year 2010 would be a good time to make the trip because preparations are beginning this year to celebrate the ROC's centenary next year and cycling is a good way to promote awareness of climate change and alternative energy.

Yen joined without hesitation although she had no previous cycling experience. Lin has been a long-time cyclist and cycled across Australia in 1996. Yen said all she wanted was to go out and see the world and cycling is one of the options of transportation.
Yen and Lin said they would like to dedicate the trip to the Republic of China (Taiwan) , which was established in 1911, as a birthday present to the country.

"I guess we'll be somewhere in Australia on January 1, 2011 to celebrate the first day of the centenary. And maybe we can get married on October 10, ROC's National Day somewhere in Europe, " she joked.
Lin drew up the travel itinerary after consulting with a senior cyclist, who advised them which countries to avoid and which countries would be good places to cycle in.
Lin half-jokingly said Wednesday that he was still struggling with whether to make the trip, but also noted that the most important factor of the long trip is not stamina, but determination.
The pair will cycle between 60 to 120 kilometers on average each day, Lin said.

With a budget of around NT$2 million (approximately US$63,400) , Lin said, the trip would not be possible without the sponsorship of several local bicycle companies, which provided them with bicycles priced at NT$200,000 each, and the assistance of the Ministry of Foreign Affairs, which asked Taiwan's foreign offices to provide help.
Cloud Gate founder Lin Hwai-min also encouraged the couple to make the trip with a donation of NT$100,000.
"Mr. Lin jokingly told me that I would have to pay him the money back if I drop out of the trip, " Lin said.
A certified historical sites guide in Taiwan, Lin said he believes that he will be able to share Taiwan's stories with foreigners and "show Taiwan to the world" during his trip.
"And about 90 percent of our equipment are Taiwan-made. We would like to tell people these products are very well-made in Taiwan, " he said.
Cycling is an ideal way of travel, which is faster than walking and slower than driving cars, Lin said, adding that it also makes connecting and communicating with local people possible.

Looking ahead to the trip, Yen said that the place she would like to visit the most is Lijiang in the southern China's Yunnan province, because of the difficulty of the route, which is 2,800-3,000 meters above sea level.

However, Lin acknowledged that it is very much possible that the trip will turn out differently than it was originally planned due to weather conditions, accidents and the situations in different countries.
"We might have to change our plan along the way, " he said.

But no matter how the world tour turns out, the couple said they plan to document their dream trip every step of the way by taking photographs and shooting videos. They also plan to regularly update their blogs and Facebook fan pages to keep in touch with friends.
Lin and Yen are scheduled to kick start the 2,100-kilometer first leg of the two-and-a-half-year trip from Thailand to Malaysia and Singapore from April 7-28.
After that, they will travel to Australia and New Zealand as well as make stops in China, Kazakhstan, Russia, and Belarus before entering eastern and central Europe in the second half of 2011.

DOC.HEADLINE: Two imported cases of measles found in Kaohsiung County
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, April 7 (CNA) 04/07/10 21:38:35 (By L. T. Chen and Flor Wang)

TEXT.P: There have been two overseas-acquired cases of measles in Taiwan since the start of this year, and both patients were from Kaohsiung in southern Taiwan, government agencies reported Wednesday.
The two patients, who were infected in a Southeast Asian country, have both recovered, the county's health bureau said.

Another case of German measles was also found in Kaohsiung County in late February and the patient has also recovered, local health officials said, urging the public to be careful when traveling to China or Southeast Asian countries.
The Center for Disease Control (CDC) under the Cabinet-level Department of Health on Wednesday confirmed the imported cases of measles.
The individuals are a 26-year-old Vietnamese woman residing in Kaohsiung County and her 15-month-old baby girl, CDC deputy director-general Lin Ting said.

The woman, who is married to a Taiwanese man, and her child were found to have contracted the infectious disease in Vietnam in late March. They developed fever, rashes and Koplik spots -- symptoms of measles -- more than a week ago, and are receiving treatment at a hospital, Lin said. Neither the woman nor her baby have inoculation records, he added.
According to Lin, no one else in the home has so far developed any symptoms of measles, but they are being closely monitored by health authorities.

In the last three years, a total of 19 cases of overseas-acquired measles -- nine from Vietnam, seven from China, and one each from India, Japan and Thailand -- have been found in Taiwan, Lin reported.
He urged that the public, especially children, get vaccinated against the disease.

DOC.HEADLINE: Taiwan developing one of world's top plant conservatories
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, April 7 (CNA) 04/07/10 22:17:22 (By Sofia Wu)

TEXT.P: The Dr. Cecilia Koo Botanic Conservation Center (KBCC) in southern Taiwan has successfully collected 13,091 tropical plant species, which makes the center the largest of its kind in Asia in terms of varieties, academic sources said Monday.

Named after the mother of Koo Cheng-yun, who is the chairman of Taiwan Cement Corp. and sponsor of the center, the KBCC has eight greenhouses spread over five acres of the Koo family's farm in Gaoshu township in Taiwan's southernmost county of Pingtung.

With the support of the National Science Council (NSC) , the center is expected to expand its germplasm collection of tropical and subtropical plant strains and varieties to 30,000 within the next 15 years to become one of the top plant centers in the world.

The center's collection of some plant families, such as Orchidaceae (orchid family), Bromeliaceae and Begoniaceae (pineapple family) and Pteridophyta or fern species, already ranks among the best in the world.
Li Chia-wei, a National Tsing Hua University biology professor who heads the conservation center, said the world now has about 300,000 plant species, half of which thrive in tropical areas.

However, many species face the threat of extinction because of habitat destruction and environmental degradation, Li said. An estimated two-thirds of the plant species may disappear from the planet by the end of this century if special efforts are not made to protect and conserve them, he added.
In an effort to rescue plant species and maintain biodiversity, Li said, the NSC and the KBCC are collaborating to collect and nurture tropical and subtropical botanical strains and varieties.
To date, the conservatory has collected 13,091 tropical plant species in 14 families, including Orchidaceae, Bromeliaceae, Zingiberaceae, Marantaceae, Musaceae and Pteridophyta.
According to Li, the center has outstripped the Xishuangbanna Tropical Botanical Garden in China's Yunnan Province to become Asia's largest conservation center of tropical tree genetic resources.

Founded in January 2008, the center has since collected and cultivated 6,057 orchid strains, surpassing the botanical gardens in New York City, Missouri, Singapore and Indonesia to become the world's largest orchid species conservation center.

The landmark conservatory is now open only to scholars and experts for research purposes. In the past couple of years, it has attracted many world-renowned academics in the field. The public will have a chance to view certain rare plant species from the conservatory at the Taipei International Flora Expo, which is scheduled to open in Nov. 6, Li said.

DOC.HEADLINE: President, DPP chairwoman to debate ECFA on April 25
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, April 7 (CNA) 04/07/10 22:58:39 (By Wen Kuei-hsiang, Lee Su-hua and Y.L. Kao)

TEXT.P: A televised debate between President Ma Ying-jeou and opposition Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) Chairperson Tsai Ing-wen on a proposed trade pact with China will be held April 25 and broadcast live on Public Television Service (PTS) , spokesmen for the two sides and the station announced Wednesday.

An agreement on the format and other details of the debate was reached Wednesday between the two sides, Presidential Office spokesman Lo Chih-chiang, DPP spokesman Tsai Chi-chang and PTS President Ho Kuo-hua announced at a joint news conference.
The debate will be broadcast live from PTS studio in Neihu, Taipei City and no questions will be taken, but a press conference will be held afterwards, PTS said.
According the spokesmen, Ma and Tsai would both stand during the debate on the proposed economic cooperation framework agreement (ECFA) between Taiwan and China.
The planned debate took center stage at the weekly meeting of the ruling Kuomintang Wednesday, said KMT spokesman Su Jun- pin.

Ma, who is also chairman of the KMT, said during the meeting that the debate is part of the government's efforts to push the proposed trade pact with China and that his administration will continue its public campaigns and seek to strengthen communication with the opposition on the issue, according to Su.

Ma said that the promotional work on the ECFA will become easier after certain details of the pact have been hammered out, in particular the goods and services early-harvest list for tariff exemptions.
Meanwhile, Ma dismissed a suggestion by KMT lawmakers that city and county governments that are opposed to the ECFA should not receive central government allocations, according to Su.

The president gave the assurance that the benefits brought about by the government's cross-Taiwan Strait policies would be shared by all the people, regardless of where they live or their political affiliation. The policies include building closer economic and trade ties with China, launching more cross-strait direct flights, and attracting more Chinese tourists to Taiwan, Su said.

DOC.HEADLINE: Shanghai mayor has a casual afternoon in Taipei
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, April 7 (CAN) 04/07/10 23:21:51 (by Tseng Chih-yuan and Lillian Lin)

TEXT.P: Shanghai Mayor Han Zheng had a casual afternoon Wednesday on the second day of his brief visit to Taiwan, touring the National Palace Museum, riding the Taipei Mass Rapid Transit (MRT), and window shopping at Taipei 101.

Despite his tight schedule of intensive meetings with politicians and business leaders and promoting World Expo Shanghai, Han took an afternoon to experience the leisure time of many Taipei nine-to-five workers.

After a busy morning that included a breakfast meeting between Taiwanese and Shanghai businessmen at 8: 00 a.m. and an investment climate briefing for the Shanghai visitors by the Taiwan External Trade Development Council (TAITRA), Han and his entourage were hosted for lunch by Chiang Pin-kung, chairman of the Straits Exchange Foundation (SEF).

Han arrived in Taipei Tuesday for a four-day visit. Most of his itinerary is business-related, but he has been able to spend some time at the National Palace Museum and the Taipei 101 skyscraper, which are at top of the sightseeing agenda for most Chinese visitors to Taipei, and visit other sights in the city.

While the mayor from Shanghai might have found the encounter with the large crowds at a night market in downtown Taipei Tuesday evening merely an interesting experience, he was impressed by the Taipei MRT and said that Shanghai could learn from Taipei in terms of MRT management.
Passengers at the MRT Beitou station were surprised to see the mayor of Shanghai, who has been in the TV news headlines for the past few days, on a subway train at rush hour.

At the National Palace Museum, Han was also recognized by many Chinese tourists who tried to get near him, and he was therefore not able to get a good look at the museum's many cultural treasures as he was forced to cut shout his visit there.

His visit to the Beitou incinerator, accompanied by Taipei Mayor Hau Lung-bin, was part of his semi-official itinerary. Han learned about Taipei City Government's garbage management and heard from Mayor Hau how the city government managed to reduce the amount of waste by establishing a recycling system and by stipulating that only garbage placed in city government issued bags would be picked up.

DOC.HEADLINE: ECFA vital to continued cross-strait stability: U.S. scholars
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, April 7 (CNA) 04/08/10 00:10:26 (By Lillian Lin)

TEXT.P: The proposed economic cooperation framework agreement (ECFA) between Taiwan and China is very important to the continuity of cross- Taiwan Strait stability, which was achieved after the 2008 presidential election in Taiwan, some American scholars suggested Wednesday.

Dr. Douglas Paal, former director of the American Institute in Taiwan, Taipei office, said in a Taipei-New York video conference Wednesday evening (Taipei time) that "beyond the merits of economic expansion after a global economic crisis and of detente in an area of long-term hostility, the ECFA promises to bring Taiwan greater economic and political stability in the region and globe."

Paal, who is now vice president of the Washington, D.C.-based think tank Carnegie Endowment for International Peace, commented that the attempt to frighten Taiwan's traditional economic sectors with threats of cheap and dangerous Chinese goods swamping their markets is a "familiar phenomenon among protectionist forces."

Daniel Rosen, visiting fellow at the Peterson Institute for International Economics in New York, suggested that "the ECFA does not amount to an economic development strategy but only achieving a 'level playing field' with competitors in the region."
"Taiwan needs to think beyond ECFA to the much harder question of how to maintain its comparative advantages," he said.

The video conference, co-chaired by Dr. Lin Bih-jaw of National Chengchi University in Taipei and William Holstein, president of the Overseas Press Club of American Foundation in New York, was attended by members of the press club and scholars from think tanks in New York and Washington and scholars from universities and research institutes in Taiwan.

DOC.HEADLINE: Today in history
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, April 8 (CNA) 04/08/10 08:46:37
DOC.TEXT:
Today is Thursday, April 8, or the 24th day of the second month of the Year of the Tiger according to the lunar calendar. Following is a list of important events that have occurred on this date in the past:
217 AD: Caracalla, or Marcus Aurelius Antonius, the Roman emperor who was obsessed with and sought to imitate Alexander the Great, is assassinated after a bloody reign.
1513: Juan Ponce de Leon, the Spanish explorer who completed the conquest of Puerto Rico, discovers Florida and claims it for the Spanish throne.
1861: Elisha Graves Otis, the American inventor of the passenger elevator which was first installed in 1857, dies at the age of 50.
1902: China's Ching court and Russia reach agreement on the evacuation of Manchuria. After the Boxer Uprising in 1900, Russia took the opportunity to occupy Manchuria. When the troops of the other foreign powers withdrew from Chinese territory, Russia refused to leave Manchuria.
1907: France and Britain sign a convention confirming the independence of Siam (now Thailand).
1914: The Republic of China's first Congress is organized in Beijing.
1913: Brazil officially recognizes the Republic of China, which was founded on Jan. 1, 1912, becoming the first country in the world to do so.
1925: The Australian government and the British Colonial Office offer low- interest loans to encourage 500,000 Britons to emigrate to Australia.
1946: The League of Nations holds its final session in Geneva. It was later replaced by the United Nations.
1958: U.S. President Dwight D. Eisenhower proposes mutual inspection as a means of enforcing the nuclear test ban.
1965: The ROC severs diplomatic relations with the Republic of Dahomey.
1966: Leonid Brezhnev is elected general secretary of the Soviet Communist Party. He later became president of the USSR in 1977.
1973: Dr. Mohammed Abder Rahman Basbeer, minister of communications of Jordan, arrives in Taipei for a week-long visit.
1973: Pablo Picasso, the Spanish artist who was one of the most prolific and influential artists of the 20th century, dies in his chateau at Mougins at the age of 92. He excelled in painting, sculpture, etching, stage design, and ceramics.
1979: Lee Pao-chen, a noted Chinese musician, dies in Taipei at the age of 73.
1981: Omar Nelson Bradley, the American general who played a major part in the Allied victory in World War II, dies at the age of 88. He commanded the U.S. forces in the Normandy invasion and later led the 12th Army Group as France was liberated.
1986: Clint Eastwood, the screen tough guy famed for his portrayal of "Dirty Harry," is elected mayor of Carmel, a Californian resort town.
1989: More than 60 Soviet submariners die after a nuclear-powered Mike-class submarine refuses assistance from nearby Western merchant ships after catching fire off the coast of Norway.
1990: ROC Economics Minister Chen Li-an and Singaporean Minister of Trade and Industries Lee Hsien Loong preside over the first ministerial-level conference on economic cooperation between the two countries.
1991: The second extraordinary session of the First National Assembly is convened in Taipei to discuss constitutional reforms.
1992: Palestinian leader Yasser Arafat is found alive 12 hours after his plane crashes in the Sahara desert.
1994: Japanese Prime Minister Morihiro Hosokawa resigns over a loan scandal.
1995: At a meeting of the National Unification Council, ROC President Lee Teng-hui offers a six-point proposal for Taiwan-mainland China relations.
1999: NATO continues airstrikes against Yugoslavia while the eastern European country says its 14-month war against ethnic Albanian separatists is over.
2000: Hong Kong Chief Executive Tung Chee-hwa tells U.S. President Bill Clinton that granting mainland China permanent normal trade relations status would give Hong Kong's recovering economy a further boost.
2001: Republic of China President Chen Shui-bian says while attending the inauguration of Taiwan's Anti-Cancer Federation that a heart full of pleasure is the best medicine against cancer.
Confucius lesson of the day: "A gentleman who only thinks of the comforts of life cannot be a true gentleman."
