DOC.HEADLINE: Cheng Kung University Hospital to set up branch in Kinmen
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, April 8 (CNA) 04/08/10 10:37:22 (By Chang Jung-hsiang and Lilian Wu)

TEXT.P: National Cheng Kung University Hospital and the Kinmen County government signed a letter of intent Wednesday to cooperate in setting up a branch of the hospital on the outlying island within three years.
The letter of intent was signed by National Cheng Kung University President Michael M.C. Lai and Kinmen Magistrate Lee Wo-shi.

According to figures released by the Kinmen County government, the number of Taiwan businessmen traveling between Kinmen and Taiwan proper is 100,000, and the number of tourists is about 500,000 annually.
But every year, the number of those transported to Taiwan proper for emergency medical treatment is between 200 and 300, with transportation alone costing NT$100 million.
Lee noted that the population of Kinmen is 50,000, but said it is a rich county, with deposits in the county's banking system of NT$80 billion.
In a past survey of Kinmen residents, 67 percent expressed hope for better medical care and the Kinmen County government is giving its support to the establishment of a branch.
"The budget of the branch should not be a problem," Lee said.
National Cheng Kung University Hospital Superintendent Lin Pin-wen is scheduled to visit Kinmen next week to inspect medical facilities there.

DOC.HEADLINE: United Daily News -- Two versions of Beijing's 'one China principle'
DOC.DATELINE: 04/08/10 10:51:48 (By Maubo Chang)

TEXT.P: Beijing's Chinese People's Political Consultative Conference resolved to push for a framework of peaceful development of links with Taiwan this year.
Beijing's idea of one China has undergone a subtle change recently. It has transformed from denying the existence of the Republic of China to not denying the existence of the Republic of China.

Chinese President Hu Jintao said: "Although Taiwan and the Chinese mainland have not been unified since 1949, this doesn't change the fact that they both belong to China... This is not only our stance but is also provided in Taiwan's documents."
His remarks indicated that Beijing has changed its claim that "the People's Republic of China is the sole legitimate regime of China" to simply "sticking to the one China principle."

Beijing has been trying to deal with Taiwan in the same way it did with Hong Kong, Macau, Xinjiang and Tibet, without realizing that unlike the others, Taiwan has a popularly elected president and Beijing should deal with all of the people on the island rather than any political party.
Only if Beijing admits the existence of the Republic of China can it draw up a pragmatic framework for peaceful development of links with Taiwan. (April 8, 2010)

DOC.HEADLINE: Commercial Times: Inconvenient fiscal truths

TEXT.P: Minister of Finance Lee Sush-der has recently drawn wide-ranging criticism for his improper remarks. In one incident, he contended that "the Republic of China has the best finances" in the world, dismissing the belief that government finances are worsening as a "mistaken notion."

Lee argued that the government's fiscal deficit has stemmed from the capital budget and that there is surplus on the current budget every year. He also said that the debt levels and flows of the government have not violated the ceiling stipulated in the Public Debt Act.
However, we must point out that a correct assessment should derive from professional knowledge and training, not from evasion and the concealment of truths.
First, if what the minister said is correct, why has every prominent international credit rating agency downgraded Taiwan's sovereign credit rating in recent years?

Second, if what the minister said is correct, then Taiwan has never suffered from a budget deficit since the Budget Act was in place, because the law stipulates that the government's current revenue must be higher than current expenditure.

Lee's budget notions are mainly based on corporate finance, which believes that debts incurred for capital investment do not worsen a company's fiscal status, because there has not been any change to its "net worth."

However, unlike investment projects by private businesses, public construction projects are not "self-liquidating." Thus, government should be more careful and conservative about its finances than private businesses. As the country's financier, Lee should know these economic concepts.
His claim that government debt has not exceeded the legal limit is even more unacceptable to the well-informed.

The fact that government finances have not broken the law does not mean there is no problem or crisis. Furthermore, the government has accumulated hundreds of billions in debt that "according to law" are excluded from the calculation of the debt ceiling. (April 8, 2010)

DOC.HEADLINE: Carrier announces cross-strait price cuts
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, April 8 (CNA) 04/08/10 12:22:32 (By S. F. Wang and Flor Wang)

TEXT.P: Taipei-based China Airlines (CAL) announced Wednesday that it will slash about 20 percent from ticket prices for non-stop flights from Taiwan to four popular destinations in China.
According to Taiwan's largest carrier, it will cut ticket prices on flights from Taiwan's Taoyuan and Kaohsiung airports to airports in China's Shanghai, Beijing, Guangzhou and Shenzhen.
Tickets for 26 weekly cross-Taiwan Strait economy flights on or after April 16 will be affected.
Tickets on the Taipei-Shanghai route will fall to NT$15,410 (US$487.66) from NT$19,100, while the price for a Taipei-Beijing flight will be cut to NT$15,000 from NT$18,600, according to the company.

The CAL attributed its decision to lower the flight ticket prices to Q1 profits due to a recovering global economy. "We hoped to pay back our customers, " a CAL executive said, stressing that this is an "instituted" measure, rather than an interim practice.

Other Taipei-based airlines, such as Trans Asia Airways and EVA Airways, meanwhile, said later the same day they will assess the possibility of following suit and could come out with a decision Thursday.

The CAL's initiative to cut the prices came after Lee Long-wen, director-general of the Civil Aeronautics Administration, demanded at a public hearing in the Legislative Yuan Tuesday that airlines "show some conscience" in the face of high air travel prices.
Attending Taiwan businessmen voiced anger about the issue, arguing that the benefits of direct cross-strait flights should be shared among all Taiwanese people, not just aviation companies.

DOC.HEADLINE: Talk of the day -- China Airlines leads rate cuts
DOC.DATELINE: 04/08/10 12:26:33 (By Deborah Kuo)

TEXT.P: Taiwan's largest airline company, China Airlines, announced unexpectedly Wednesday a whopping 20-percent cut in rates for direct flights between Taiwan and four major Chinese cities including Shanghai, pressing other carriers to follow suit.

The rate cuts were the result of customer complaints of unreasonably high rates, legislators' criticism and pressure from the Civil Aeronautics Administration (CAA) . They were also seen as a far-sighted scheme anticipating increased need for direct cross-strait flights and soaring demands to and from Shanghai in particular as the 2010 World Expo will be kicking off in May.
The following are excerpts from local media coverage of the issue:
United Daily News:

One day after CAA Director-General Lee Long-wen bashed Taiwan's airline carriers for hoarding seats and tickets and told them to "show some conscience, " China Airlines took the initiative in reducing the rates for economy seat tickets. Round-trip tickets between Taipei and Shanghai will drop from NT$19,100 (US$602) to NT$15,400, while Taipei-Beijing tickets will fall from NT$18,600 to NT$15,000.

The deepest price-cut to date was nevertheless considered by many Taiwanese citizens maintaining business operations in China who fly across the strait frequently as "belated justice." "Not as sweet as expected, but it serves as a good start anyway," some said. (April 8, 2010).
Economic Daily News:

EVA Airways and Trans Asia Airways were forced to meet China Airline's lower rates. The rate cuts will result in financial losses for the Taiwanese carriers in the short run, but are also seen to increase their bargaining chances for increased numbers of cross-strait flights and extra flights for special dates.
The next round of cross-strait air transportation negotiations are scheduled to take place in Taipei this month.

Yao Ta-kuang, chairman of the Travel Agent Association of Taiwan (TAAT) , said that unless the number of direct cross-strait flights doubles, the lower rates would not help. He suggested cross-strait negotiators increase the number of such flights from the current 270 per week to 405 to meet actual needs. (April 8, 2010).
China Times:

CAA Director-General Lee Long-wen said Wednesday he was pleased with China Airlines' plan to cut rates for economy tickets for cross-strait flights beginning from April 16. "I think that the Chinese airline companies plying the cross-strait routes will do the same before long," Lee said.

Taiwan's travel agents, however, were lukewarm about the lower prices. They said the reduced tickets were still higher than prices at the beginning of the year. For example, they said, the price for an economy seat on a direct Taipei- Shanghai round-trip flight increased by NT$4,000 over the past three months -- compared with the NT$3,700 cut introduced by China Airlines. (April 8, 2010).

DOC.HEADLINE: ECFA 'early harvest' list still in the works: MAC
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, April 8 (CNA) 04/08/10 12:36:04 (By Liu Cheng-ching and Sofia Wu)

TEXT.P: Taiwan is still working on an "early harvest" list for concessionary tariff treatment under a proposed economic cooperation framework agreement (ECFA) with China, the country's top China policy planner said Thursday.

Mainland Affairs Council (MAC) Chairwoman Lai Shin-yuan made the remarks at the Legislative Yuan's committee on internal affairs while briefing lawmakers on the recent second round of ECFA talks across the Taiwan Strait.

During the meeting, opposition Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) legislators criticized the administration of President Ma Ying-jeou for what they called a lack of transparency in dealing with the negotiations.

DPP Legislator Lai Ching-te accused the administration of looking down on the legislature as it has so far not presented the draft text of the agreement and the related "early harvest" list for screening.

In response, Lai said that during the March 31-April 1 ECFA talks in Taiwan, Chinese negotiators did not produce any "wish list" of goods and services for immediate tariff concessions or reductions that could form the backbone of an ECFA, seen as a scaled-down free trade agreement.
Likewise, Lai said, Taiwan did not unveil any "early harvest" list at the talks because the content is still in the works.
"It would put Taiwan at a disadvantage if we unilaterally revealed our 'early harvest' list at this moment, " Lai told lawmakers.

Huang Chih-peng, director-general of the Bureau of Foreign Trade under the Ministry of Economic Affairs who led the Taiwanese delegation at the second round of ECFA talks, was also present at the legislative meeting.

DOC.HEADLINE: Liberty Times: Ma attempts to market his lies overseas

TEXT.P: Empty rhetoric, bluffs and lies were abound when President Ma Ying-jeou discussed his policy in a recent video conference with Harvard University faculty and students.

Obviously, Ma was attempting to win international support to try to reverse the decline in his approval ratings. However, since Ma has failed to convince his own people, how could he fool those well-trained foreign experts?

In terms of economy, Ma told the Harvard audience that his administration has successfully led Taiwan out of the latest economic downturn. But the fact is that even if Taiwan achieves 4.72 percent economic growth this year as projected by Ma, the performance would still be the worst among the "four little dragons" in Asia. The unemployment rate of 5.7 percent recorded in February, meanwhile, is the highest among the four.

Ma also said that "agreeing to disagree on 'one China'" has been a principle of his China policy. However, over the past two years, we have only seen Ma fawn over Beijing and honor the People's Republic of China as the legitimate heir of "one China." He has seldom dared to show any hint of "agreeing to disagree."

On the proposed economic cooperation framework agreement (ECFA) with China, Ma said that only by signing the trade pact will Taiwan prevent itself from being marginalized and increase the likelihood of forging similar agreements with other countries. The fact is: Begging for China's patronage to help Taiwan seal free trade agreements with other countries is as foolish as hoping the sun will rise in the west. (April 8, 2010)

DOC.HEADLINE: Taiwanese runner finishes third in North Pole marathon
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, April 8 (CNA) 04/08/10 13:29:23 (By Chris Wang)

TEXT.P: Braving gusty winds of 45 kilometers per hour and temperatures of minus 20 degrees Celsius, Taiwanese runner Chen Yen-po finished third in the 2010 North Pole Marathon Thursday after the competition was briefly suspended for severe weather conditions.
Chen completed the 42.195-kilometer route in five hours, 29 minutes and 47 seconds to place third among 26 runners from 10 countries in the competition dubbed "the world's coolest marathon."
Chen's mother told CNA by telephone that what she cared about most was Chen's safety, but she was happy to know her son had finished in the top three.
Joep Rozendal from the Netherlands won the men's event in five hours and 58 seconds while Emer Dooley from Ireland took first place in the women's race.
Chen, a 23-year-old graduate student from National Taiwan Sports University, surpassed the top-10 goal he made before the competition.
The competitors arrived at the Norwegian town of Longyearbyen on Spitsbergen island off the coast of Norway April 5. They were flown to an international North Pole Camp called Barneo for the race.
Chen is no stranger of running in extreme conditions, having finishing third in the 600-kilometer Polar Challenge race in 2008 and fourth in the 2009 Himalayan 100-Mile Stage Race.

The circuit of 42.195 kilometers meanders among hillocks of ice and incorporates part of an aircraft runway. Participants have to have the nerve and drive to run on Arctic ice floes only six to 12 feet above 12,000 feet of Arctic Ocean.
According to Chen's mother, Chen told her by satellite telephone at 5 p.m. Wednesday local time that the race had been postponed due to a severe storm.
The 2010 North Pole Marathon was the seventh edition of competitive marathons in the Arctic, with races previously held in 2003, 2004, 2006, 2007, 2008 and 2009.

DOC.HEADLINE: Ex-Japanese prime minister concludes Taiwan visit
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, April 8 (CNA) 04/08/10 13:43:49 (By Bien Chin-feng, Garfie Li and Sofia wu)

TEXT.P: Former Japanese Prime Minister Taro Aso returned to Japan Thursday after wrapping up a four-day visit to Taiwan.
Aso, widely seen as pro-Taiwan, arrived April 5 for a private visit at the invitation of Chinatrust Group Chairman Jeffrey Koo.

Although Aso kept a low profile during his stay, the visit drew much attention. President Ma Ying-jeou hosted a luncheon in his honor Wednesday at the Taipei Guest House, during which Aso was quoted as having praised Ma's modus vivendi approach toward relations across the Taiwan Strait.
Aso was said have expressed admiration for Ma's efforts to improve cross-strait relations and normalize bilateral trade and economic ties.
He also said that security cooperation between Japan and the United States is crucial to Asia-Pacific stability and prosperity, a view that Ma supported fully, diplomatic sources said.
Several senior Taiwanese officials, including Minister of Foreign Affairs Timothy Yang and National Security Council Secretary-General Hu Wei-chen, were also present at the luncheon.
This was Aso's first trip to Taiwan since he stepped down as Japanese prime minister in September 2009.
He last visited Taiwan in April 2003 in his capacity as head of the then-ruling Liberal Democratic Party's policy coordination council.
Only two other retired Japanese prime ministers have visited Taiwan. Takeo Fukuda visited in March 1992 and Yoshiro Mori visited in both December 2003 and November 2006.

DOC.HEADLINE: Half of population to pay more under new health insurance system
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, April 8 (CNA) 04/08/10 14:15:54 (By Lee Ming-chung and Sofia Wu)

TEXT.P: About half of the local population will have to pay more once a second- generation national health insurance system is put in place, Department of Health (DOH) Minister Yaung Chih-liang said Thursday.
In contrast, Yaung said, the other half of the population will see a decline in their health insurance premiums.

The new system will calculate insurance premiums based on the insured's overall household incomes, including stock dividends, instead of solely on their earned income as is the case under the current system.
Moreover, Yaung said, the new system will have single people pay more than those who have dependents.

DOC.HEADLINE: New proxy agencies to sign H.K.-Taiwan air pact
DOC.DATELINE: Hong Kong, April 8 (CNA) 04/08/10 14:51:56 (By Stanley Cheung and Deborah Kuo)

TEXT.P: Hong Kong and Taiwan will discuss air links through two intermediary councils that have recently been established by the two sides, a source said Thursday.

David Lie, a vice chairman of the Hong Kong-Taiwan Economic and Cultural Cooperation and Promotion Council, said during an interview with Radio Television Hong Kong that the council will soon engage in talks with its Taiwanese counterpart -- the Taiwan-Hong Kong Economic and Cultural Cooperation and Promotion Council -- to work out an MOU on air transport exchanges between the two sides.
The existing Hong Kong-Taiwan aviation pact expires at the end of June.

Talks about air links between Hong Kong and Taiwan have previously been held by representatives of the airline business sectors from the two sides. The Taiwan airline carriers, however, were not completely satisfied with the pact, Lie said.
"This year's MOU on Hong Kong-Taiwan air exchanges is expected to be signed by the two newly established councils -- a new communication platform between the two sides," Lie said.
Lie also chairs the newly established Hong Kong-Taiwan Business Cooperation Committee, which is comprised of members of Hong Kong's commerce and industry sector.

The Hong Kong-Taiwan Economic and Cultural Cooperation and Promotion Council was set up April 1 by the government of the Hong Kong Special Administrative Region as an intermediary body in the absence of official ties between Hong Kong and Taiwan.

The Taiwan-Hong Kong Economic and Cultural Cooperation and Promotion Council is being established under the supervision of the Hong Kong and Macao Affairs Department under the Cabinet-level Mainland Affairs Council.

The two councils will work to facilitate broader and deeper exchange between the two sides. Possible areas of cooperation include public health, financial regulation and supervision, avoidance of double taxation, tourism, culture, sports and document authentication, according to the Hong Kong government.

It is hoped that the councils will help tackle matters of mutual concern, including simplicility in taxation regulations and financial cooperation, to create mutually beneficial business opportunities, Lie said.
"It is keenly hoped that Hong Kong-Taiwan business and trade exchanges will not be compromised as a result of closer cross-Taiwan Strait ties," he added.

DOC.HEADLINE: Shanghai mayor meets wife of late Taiwanese negotiator with China
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, April 8 (CAN) 04/08/10 16:10:42 (By Feng Chao, Chen Ching-ping and Deborah Kuo)

TEXT.P: Visiting Shanghai Mayor Han Zheng paid a courtesy call Thursday on Cecilia Y. Koo, wife of the late Koo Chen-fu, Taiwan's former top negotiator with China, who died in 2005.
Koo extended a warm welcome to Han during the meeting held at the Cheng Hsin Rehabilitation Medical Center in suburban Taipei.

She told Han that he reminded her of the common wish of her late husband and of Wang Daohan, the late president of Beijing's Association for Relations Across the Taiwan Straits -- peace across the Taiwan Strait.
Wang also formerly served as secretary of the Communist Party of China's Shanghai Municipal Committee and as Shanghai mayor.

Koo and Wang were the first two cross-strait officials to start ice-breaking cross-strait dialogue after an impasse of five decades since 1949. Koo visited Shanghai for an SEF-ARATS meeting, but Wang never visited Taiwan.
"Your visit here convinces me that the prospects for peace across the strait are getting increasingly brighter," Koo told Han.
Koo, in her capacity as chairwoman of the Cheng Hsin Rehabilitation Medical Center, accompanied Han on a brief tour of the hospital established by Madame Chiang Kai-shek in 1967.
In return, Han made a donation of 1.5 million Chinese yuan (US$219,700) to the hospital for the treatment and rehabilitation of children suffering from hearing impairment.
The hospital was the final stop on the itinerary of Han and his entourage in Taipei City since their arrival two days earlier.

Han, who had a tight schedule of meetings with Taiwanese politicians and business leaders to promote the 2010 World Expo Shanghai during his four-day visit, later proceeded to Taipei County on a whirlwind visit.
Taipei Magistrate Chou Hsi-wei hosted a lunch in honor of Han and his delegation at a beach-side restaurant in Wanli township.
After the lunch, they visited the nearby Yeliou Geopark to see the locally renowned "Queen's Head, " one of several rock formations that dot the Yeliou Cape, located on the north coast of Taiwan.
Han also presented 200 tickets to the expo to Chou, who has visited Shanghai and had met with Han twice before.
