DOC.HEADLINE: Former economic planner backs trade pact with China
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, April 8 (CNA) 04/08/10 16:21:59 (By Maubo Chang)

TEXT.P: Chen Tain-jy, a professor at National Taiwan University and former minister of the Council for Economic Planning and Development, said at a seminar that Taiwan's proposed trade pact with China will normalize cross-strait economic relations.

In the video conference organized by the Government Information Office and held at 1230 GMT Wednesday in Taipei and New York simultaneously, Chen said an economic cooperation framework agreement (ECFA) would provide a platform for Taiwan and China to resolve all their bilateral trade issues under the World Trade Organization framework.
For Taiwan firms, the pact will convert China from an offshore export processing zone into an attractive market, he said.
This is very important in light of the fact that China is losing its luster as a global processing zone because of rising labor costs and a policy shift toward domestic market development, Chen said.
In addition to providing a level playing field for Taiwan businesspeople in China, Chen said the pact will open up new chances for them to cooperate with their Chinese counterparts.
"This will allow the two sides to pool their technologies and know-how for industrial applications," he said.
"When free trade is achieved across the Strait, Taiwan will become a nice gateway to China for multinational firms," Chen added.
Taiwan's vicinity to China enables multinational firms based in Taiwan to better serve their Chinese customers along the coast than their competitors located within China, Chen said.
Taiwan offers free access to information, almost unlimited support of financial credits, and free flow of personnel -- services that are not available in China, Chen said.

Two other local scholars also spoke at the teleconference: Lin Bih-jaw, vice president of Taipei's National Chengchi University; and S. Philip Hsu, executive director of the Center for China Studies at National Taiwan University.

They exchanged views with William Holstein, president of the Overseas Press Club Foundation; Douglas Paal, vice president of the Carnegie Endowment for International Peace; and Daniel Rosen, visiting fellow at Peterson Institute for International Economics.

President Ma Ying-jeou's administration is working hard to conclude the pact with China in June, but has had difficulty selling it to the opposition parties, which are worried that the pact will undermine Taiwan's sovereignty.
The seminar is part of the Government Information Office's efforts to muster support for the pact.

DOC.HEADLINE: Taiwan looks forward to enhanced competitiveness: president
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, April 8 (CNA) 04/08/10 16:52:03 (By Lee shu-hua and Sofia Wu)

TEXT.P: President Ma Ying-jeou said Thursday his administration has been actively promoting the signing of a wide-reaching trade pact with China to help upgrade Taiwan's national competitiveness through participation in regional integration.

Such efforts, however, have met strong objection from the opposition camp, led by the Democratic Progressive Party (DPP), as it worries that the proposed economic cooperation framework agreement (ECFA) may lead to Taiwan's overreliance on the Chinese market, Ma said while meeting with Michael Porter, a leading authority in corporate strategy.

According to a Presidential Office official present at the meeting, Ma briefed the visiting American management guru on the strategic and economic significance to Taiwan of the proposed cross-Taiwan Strait ECFA, seen as a scaled-back free trade agreement.
After listening to Ma's briefing, Porter expressed support for the ECFA initiative and endorsed Ma's views on the pact's value to Taiwan, the official said.

During their meeting, Ma also outlined strategies "with Taiwanese characteristics" to accelerate the country's economic recovery that will contribute to Taiwan's goals of achieving high job growth, industrial innovation, energy conservation and carbon reduction, as well as participation in regional economic integration.

As the two sides of the Taiwan Strait are still in talks on the pact, Ma solicited Porter's opinions on whether his administration's present strategy can effectively help upgrade Taiwan's competitive edge and which aspects could be improved or amended, the official said.

Porter was scheduled to deliver a speech later Thursday in which he was expected to emphasize the importance of regional integration to economic development and to present his views on the challenges that Taiwan may face this year and how the country can create a win-win scenario in the development of cross-strait relations, the official said.

DOC.HEADLINE: `Taiwan's Susan Boyle' becomes Internet hit
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, April 8 (CNA) 04/08/10 17:01:18 (By Y.F. Low)

TEXT.P: A video of local KTV singer Lin Yu-chun singing Whitney Houston's hit song "I Will Always Love You" was spreading fast across the Internet Thursday, winning him a reputation as "Taiwan's Susan Boyle."
The performance by the 24-year-old on local talent show "Million Star" was first posted on YouTube two days ago and has since "rolled around the world" on the Web.
According to an article published on Yahoo! TV Blog, the video already has had over 150,000 views, and searches for "Lin Yu-chun" had gone up over 200 percent in the previous 24 hours.

Lin's rendition is "a near-perfect sound-alike of Whitney Houston's original, with barely a hint of an accent, " the author commented, predicting that Lin will become an "international sensation" and be invited to that holiest-of- holies for this type of performer -- a slot on an American TV morning show.

"Even if singing competitions are not your thing, you have to admire the technical prowess that the baby-faced, bowl-cut-wearing Lin displays: How often can a male of any age sound exactly like a female pop star singing one of the most demanding songs in the karaoke catalog?" the author asked.
There have been immediate comparisons between Lin and Susan Boyle, a British KTV singer who rose to stardom after auditioning for "Britain's Got Talent" last year.
The Sun online, a British tabloid, introduced Lin as "the next SuBo on Taiwan show, " saying that he is "threatening to steal Susan Boyle's crown as this year's most unexpected musical superstar."
The Mail Online, another British tabloid, said that "Susan Boyle needs to look out -- there's another YouTube singing sensation shooting up the popularity charts."
Some, however, were critical about his looks.
"I can't get past the haircut. Dude looks like a pokemon, " one poster wrote.

DOC.HEADLINE: U.S. dollar up on Taipei forex
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, April 8 (CNA) 04/08/10 17:04:25 (By Y.L. Kao)

TEXT.P: The U.S. dollar gained ground against the New Taiwan dollar on the Taipei Foreign Exchange Thursday, rising NT$0.073 to close at NT$31.701.
A total of US$886 million changed hands during the trading session.
The U.S. dollar opened at the day's high of NT$31.630 and fluctuated between NT$31.557 and NT$31.701.

DOC.HEADLINE: Taiwan shares drop 64.18 points
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, April 8 (CNA) 04/08/10 17:19:30 (By Y.L. Kao)

TEXT.P: Taiwan's stock market snapped a four-day winning streak to close 0.79 percent lower Thursday, a day after the Taiex index reached to 8,121.78, its highest since Jan. 24.
The weighted index -- the market's key barometer -- fell 64.18 points to close at 8,057.6 following overnight losses on Wall Street.
The local bourse opened at 8,106 and fluctuated between 8,149.68 and 8,038.37 during the day's trading. Market turnover totaled NT$146.57 billion (US$4.63 billion).

Four of the eight major stock categories gained ground, with construction stocks moving up the most at 2.11 percent. Textile shares rose 1.34 percent, banking and financial stocks gained 0.51 percent, and foodstuff issues were up 0.28 percent.

The four other major categories lost ground, with machinery and electronics stocks shedding the most at 1.44 percent, followed by cement issues at 0.95 percent, plastics and chemicals at 0.55 percent and paper and pulp issues at 0.28 percent.
Losers outnumbered gainers 2,200 to 1,074, with 249 remaining unchanged.
Foreign investors and Chinese QDIIs were net buyers of NT$2.12 billion in shares.

DOC.HEADLINE: Death penalty to be phased out eventually: justice minister
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, April 8 (CNA) 04/08/10 17:29:14 (By Chi-shen Ann and Deborah Kuo)

TEXT.P: Phasing out the death penalty is the government's ultimate goal, but the executions of 44 death row inmates will be carried out in accordance with the law, Justice Minister Tseng Yung-fu said Thursday.

A task force will be formed by the Ministry of Justice to determine the order of the executions once all avenues for appeal have been exhausted, although so far there is no timetable for any of the executions, Tseng said during a Legislative Yuan session.

"The prosecutors are authorized to recommend death sentences based on their duties and professional judgment, although they are also required to be extra careful when they make decisions, " Tseng said.

Meanwhile, he went on, the Ministry of Justice will sponsor a number of public hearings around the country beginning mid-April on the issue of whether the death penalty should be abolished once and for all.

On a decision by the Nantou District Prosecutors Office to seek three death sentences for Lin Yu-ju for murdering her mother, husband and mother-in-law, Tseng said he respects the prosecutors' decision.
Taiwan has not carried out a death sentence since late 2005.
It was the first time Tseng had appeared at a question-and-answer session at the Legislative Yuan since taking office last month.

Controversy over the death penalty issue resurged after Wang Ching-feng, Tseng's predecessor, made clear her support of the abolition of the death penalty and refused to sign off on outstanding execution orders.
Wang's decision sparked outrage among the families of the victims and in society in general, which prompted her to resign from her post in March.
Tseng has said he has no problem signing execution orders once all the required procedures have been completed.

DOC.HEADLINE: Tseng wins Taiwan basketball league MVP award
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, April 8 (CNA) 04/08/10 17:34:35 (By Chris Wang)

TEXT.P: Tseng Wen-ting was named the Most Valuable player of Taiwan's Super Basketball League (SBL) for the months of February and March, the league announced Thursday.

A media poll awarded the honor to Tseng, a 204-centimeter center, after he led the Yulon Luxgens to a 10-game winning streak in March as they regained momentum after the Lunar New Year break. Tseng averaged 13.1 points, 9.1 rebounds, 1.93 steals and 2.3 blocked shots during the month.
"It's a big surprise. I guess I got this award because we did pretty well after the New Year break," the 26-year-old said.

Yulon, a perennial powerhouse in Taiwanese basketball that has won three SBL titles in the league's seven-year history, suffered the first four-game losing streak in team history around the New Year vacation. But now they have a record of 17 wins and five losses, one game behind the league-leading Dacin Tigers.

The season has been especially difficult for Tseng because Yulon is the only team in the seven-team league that did not hire foreign players after the SBL decided for the first time this year to allow all of its teams to hire imports to improve the level of competition.

The decision left Tseng the undesirable task of having to defend against taller and stronger foreign players. Injuries to both of his knees made the challenge even more difficult, but Tseng played through and didn't complain about not getting enough support from the bench players.

"It's not a surprise at all for me because when you look at him (Tseng), you can't just look at the numbers. He has been contributing to the team in a lot of ways and he always plays his heart out and gives 100 percent on the court, " said Yulon head coach Zhang Xu-lei, a naturalized Taiwan citizen who formerly played for the Chinese national team.
Tseng, a Taiwan national team regular, said his goal for the season would first be making the post-season and then hopefully returning to the championship series in June.

DOC.HEADLINE: MOFA upgrades travel advisory for Thailand
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, March 8 (CNA) 04/08/10 18:53:39 (By Liu Te-chang and Bear Lee)

TEXT.P: The Ministry of Foreign Affairs upgraded the level of alarm Thursday for Taiwanese planning to travel to the Thai capital of Bangkok and neighboring areas amid escalating tension there.
The Thai government declared a state of emergency in the capital a day earlier after "red-shirt" protesters stormed the parliament building.
The protests by supporters of ousted Prime Minister Thaksin Shinawatra have been continuing for four weeks, paralyzing traffic and tourism around Bangkok and surrounding areas.

The ministry issued an orange level warning -- which advises Taiwanese nationals to avoid going to the destination and to be on high alert if they have to go -- in the four-level tourism advisory system.

A red alert -- the highest level in the system -- advises that no-one should visit the destination under any circumstances, while a yellow alert advises would-be travelers to think of their personal safety when deciding whether to visit. A grey alert means there is no perceived danger.
The orange alert covers Bangkok and the adjacent provinces of Nonthaburi, Samut Prakan, Pathum Thani, Nakhon Pathom and Ayutthaya.

DOC.HEADLINE: Contemporary Chinese artists to show oil paintings in Taipei
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei April 8 (CNA) 04/08/10 19:01:31 (by Sunnie Chen)

TEXT.P: An exhibition featuring over 50 oil paintings by 10 prominent artists from China, will open at the Taipei Fine Arts Museum (TFAM) this weekend.
The exhibit will open from April 10 until May 9 and is one of the cooperation programs between the TFAM and the National Art Museum of China (NAMOC) in Beijing.

Fan Di'an, the director of the Beijing museum and also the organizer of the exhibit titled "The Moment of the LandscapeVOil Paintings by Contemporary Chinese Masters", has invited the artists to show 56 compelling works in Taipei.

In addition, these artists, including Dai Shi-he, Li Yan-zhou, Wang Ke-ju, Wang Hui and several others, will come to Taipei around April 26 to use their talents to depict famous tourist spots in Taiwan.
The result of their works in Taiwan will be displayed later in the same exhibit.

Fan said the reason for focusing on the theme of "landscape paintings" is because Chinese artists have developed innovative approaches in recent years to painting landscapes, which do not limit them to landscape, but also allow them to exhibit their creativity and personal styles, according to the press release issued by the TFAM.
Fan will come to Taipei on April 21 for the upcoming opening of the exhibit on April 25.
The NAMOC is a national museum dedicated to the collection, research and exhibition of modern and contemporary artistic works in China.
It and the TFAM began their collaboration in 2006. This is the second time the NAMOC will showcase its artists' works in the TFAM.

DOC.HEADLINE: MOFA raises travel alert for Kyrgyzstan
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, April 8 (CNA) 04/08/10 19:02:49 (By Chris Wang)

TEXT.P: The Ministry of Foreign Affairs (MOFA) elevated its travel alert level for Kyrgyzstan Thursday over concern about the unstable political situation in the Central Asian country, the ministry said in a statement that day.

The Kyrgyztan opposition said earlier in the day that it had seized power and taken control of the government after a massive protest that began Tuesday, sparked by increases in fuel and electricity rates, against President Kurmanbek Bakiyev, who was reported to have fled Bishkek, the capital.
The ministry elevated the travel alert level to orange, the second-highest on the MOFA's four-color system.
An orange alert advises travelers against making unnecessary trips to the place in question and to maintain high alert if they do go.

The ministry said in a statement that the massive anti-government protests had led to more than 60 deaths and hundreds injured, and that the political situation was expected to remain highly unstable.

DOC.HEADLINE: Taiwan March trade surplus at US$1.5 billion
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, April 8 (CNA) 04/08/10 19:18:27 (By I.F. Lin and Flor Wang)

TEXT.P: Exports and imports in March totaled US$23.37 billion and US$21.87 billion in value, leaving Taiwan with a trade surplus of US$1.5 billion, the Ministry of Finance (MOI) reported Thursday.
The March export figure represented a monthly growth for the fifth month in a row and marked a 50.1 percent increase year-on-year, according to the MOI's Department of Statistics.
The March import figure also recorded an annual growth rate of 80.3 percent, which is also the fifth single-month rise since last year, the same statistics show.

DOC.HEADLINE: Wrangle over ECFA debate between government and DPP
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, April 8 (CNA) 04/08/10 19:31:12 (By S. H. Lee and Flor Wang)

TEXT.P: The Presidnetial Office and the main opposition Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) argued Thursday about conditions over a planned debate between President Ma Ying-jeou and DPP Chairwoman Tsai Ing-wen on whether Taiwan should sign a controversial trade pact with China.

Speaking at a news conference at the Presidential Office, Presidential Spokesman Lo Chih-chiang demanded that Tsai, prior to the April 25 debate with Ma, give a list detailing what items and how many items should be included in Taiwan's list of items to enjoy priority tariff cuts, known as an "early harvest list."
The list of items would be the first to enjoy tariff cuts once Taiwan and China sign the economic cooperation framework agreement (ECFA), which the two sides hope to by June.

Since the DPP is strongly opposed to Taiwan signing the deal with China, Tsai should come up with an alternative on how to help Taiwan break through the increased regional economic integration that Taiwan has been excluded from, Lo said.
If Tsai contends that not a single item should be named in the early harvest list to ask for a tariff-exemption treatment from China, she should also provide an explanation, Lo insisted.

If Tsai has no ideas on how to help Taiwan face the pressure it will face once other countries sign free-trade agreements with China and enjoy zero-tariff privileges for their exports, then Tsai should make it clear to the public, Lo said.
Lo also insisted that the DPP chairwoman make public her assessment of the situation to explain why she objects to the planned ECFA.

The two parties reached agreement Wednesday to organize a 2-hour and 20-minute Ma-Tsai debate on the disputed ECFA on April 25. The debate will be the first ever between the two parties' leaders since Ma was elected in 2008, ending eight years of DPP control over the presidency.
According to DPP spokesman Tsai Chi-chang, Tsai Ing-wen will explain her alternative to the ECFA and other questions to Taiwan's people in the coming televised debate.

For its part, the DPP demanded late Wednesday that the KMT reveal the items on a 700-item "early harvest list" as well as relevant information and documents reportedly put forth by China on the trade agreement.
The DPP has warned that signing the agreement would cause a flood of cheaper Chinese products to Taiwan and cause job losses for Taiwan's workers.
But the government and KMT have argued that Taiwan's exports to China -- its biggest export market -- would not be able to compete once China signs similar agreements with other countries.

DOC.HEADLINE: 2nd carrier announces cross-strait price cut
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, April 8 (CNA) 04/08/10 20:00:38 (By H.H. Chao and Flor Wang)

TEXT.P: Trans Asia, following in the footsteps of Taipei-based China Airlines (CAL) , announced Thursday that it will slash fares by 20 percent on its economy flights from Taipei to Shanghai from April 16.
The price cut will reduce the price of a round-trip Taipei- Shanghai flight from NT$19,000 (US$602) to NT$15,200, according to a Trans Asia spokesperson.

CAL, Taiwan's largest carrier, took the lead a day earlier when it announced that it will slash about 20 percent from ticket prices for its non-stop economy flights from Taoyuan and Kaohsiung to four popular destinations in China -- Shanghai, Beijing, Guangzhou and Shenzhen -- also from April 16.

Under CAL's new pricing scheme, round-trip tickets on the Taipei-Shanghai route will fall to NT$15,410 from NT$19,100, while the price for a two-way Taipei- Beijing flight will be cut to NT$15,000 from NT$18,600.
CAL attributed its decision to lower fares to Q1 profits due to the recovering global economy and said it is a measure designed to give back to customers, rather than just an interim practice.
Meanwhile, EVA Airways, another major provider of direct cross-Taiwan Strait flights, was tight-lipped about whether it will follow suit.
Taiwanese businessmen with operations in China have long complained about the high cost of direct cross-strait flights.

At a public hearing at the Legislative Yuan Tuesday, Lee Lung-wen, director- general of the Civil Aeronautics Administration, asked airlines to "show some conscience" in the face of high air travel prices across the strait.
"The benefits of direct cross-strait flights should be shared among all Taiwanese people, not just the aviation companies, " he argued.
Later Thursday, the Consumers' Foundation (CF) said it is meaningless to arbitrarily cut the face value of ticket prices and that prices should reflect travel time.
Taking as an example the Taipei-Shanghai flight, which takes only around 80 minutes, the retail price for the customer should not be higher than NT$10,000, CF Chairman Hsieh Tian-jen said.

The Ministry of Transportation and Communications should intervene in the pricing of cross-strait flights to protect consumers' interests, especially during specific holidays such as the Lunar New Year holiday and Tomb Sweeping Day, he contended.

DOC.HEADLINE: 55%-60% of population to be unaffected by healthcare system changes
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, April 8 (CNA) 04/08/10 20:24:05 (By Chen Li-ting, Lee Ming-chung and Sofia Wu)

TEXT.P: The Executive Yuan passed Thursday a draft package of amendments to the National Health Insurance Act that, once it clears the legislative floor, will result in higher premiums for about 45 percent of the population.

Premier Wu Den-yi said after the approval of the package at an Executive Yuan weekly meeting that he feels sorry that single people will have to pay higher premiums under the proposed legal amendments that will pave the way for the enforcement of a second-generation national health insurance system.

"It is unlikely that the new program will satisfy everybody... I am sorry that single people will have to pay higher premiums... The government has several programs in place to help young people form their own families, " Wu said at a news conference after the Executive Yuan meeting.

Speaking on the same occasion, Department of Health (DOH) Minister Yaung Chih- liang said the new system's insurance premium rate will range between 3 percent and 3.5 percent of the insured person's total income.
"The premium rate will not be the previous 4.55 percent nor the current 5.17 percent... In my estimation, the rate is likely to be 3 percent to 3.5 percent," Yaung said.

Unlike the present system, in which premiums are calculated based solely on the insured's earned income, the new scheme will calculate premiums based on total household income, including wages, stock dividends, rental income and other unearned income.

The broader income base is expected to help keep the healthcare system out of the red, Yaung said, adding that the new scheme will be more equitable, as wealthy households in which income does not mainly rely on earned income will have to pay more, while the financial burden on single-income households and those with many family members will be reduced.

Citing a preliminary estimate by the DOH's Bureau of National Health Insurance (BNHI), Yaung said that 50 percent to 60 percent of the population will see their health insurance premiums being lowered or remaining unchanged.
The one possible drawback of the new system will be that single people will end up paying more, Yaung said.

Under the present system, a family of four with a monthly income of NT$50,000 (US$15,82.28) has to pay more than NT$3,000 in total health premiums per month, an amount that will be lowered to about NT$1,600 under the new system.
In comparison, a single-person household will see its monthly premium rise from the present NT$785 to NT$1,750 if the premium rate is set at 3.5 percent.
Yaung said it is a common trend in advanced countries for single people with higher incomes to have to shoulder a higher financial burden for public health insurance programs.

Meanwhile, he went on, the health insurance premiums will continue to be jointly paid for by the insured, their employers and the government under the new system. At present, the government subsidy comes from both central and local governments, but the new system will exempt local governments from the financial burden.
The new system will also set a minimum payment of about NT$3,600 per person per annum, Yaung said.
The draft package will soon be sent to the Legislative Yuan for screening.
Yaung said he will personally call on individual lawmakers to seek their support for the package so that the new system can be put into effect as soon as possible.
Earlier this month, Yaung said that if all goes well, the new program could be implemented by 2012.
Moreover, the DOH and the BNHI were scheduled to hold a series of public hearings to brief the public on details of the new healthcare program.
As of the end of last year, the health insurance program had accumulated a deficit of NT$58.8 billion.

DOC.HEADLINE: U.S. management strategist supports Taiwan-China trade pact
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, April 8 (CNA) 04/08/10 21:10:40 (By Alex Jiang)

TEXT.P: Harvard Business School Professor Michael Porter said Thursday in Taipei that he supports a proposed trade pact between Taiwan and China, but he also urged Taiwan to work on its weaknesses to attract foreign investment.
"Taiwan already has a huge economic relationship with China despite the fact that there is no framework, " he said in a speech delivered at a forum held at the National Dr. Sun Yat-sen Memorial Hall.
"What we are talking about here actually is just, formalizing something that's already happening, " the well-known economist-turned-strategist said.

Michael DeNoma, chairman of the Taipei-based Chinatrust Commercial Bank and one of the panelists at the forum, asked Porter if there are any alternatives to the economic cooperation framework agreement (ECFA) that is due to be signed between the two sides of the Taiwan Strait later this year.
"I thought about that, " Porter replied. "I don't see any alternative, any practical alternative. But more importantly, I don't see why we would want an alternative."
Taiwan can construct a formal trade relationship with China, which can allow Taiwan to continue to substantially enhance its economy over time, he said.
There are many agreements like this that other countries have signed with China and in many cases, these countries have much less strength than Taiwan, Porter said.
"I am confident that you will be much better off with such a framework than you will be without it," he added.

Porter also urged Taiwan to focus on "getting the fundamentals right" by building an attractive business environment or establishing a good infrastructure rather than worrying about the size of China.
"Size, per se, is nothing to fear," he said.
Porter said, that for example, his home state of Massachusetts in the United States has to compete with much bigger states such as New York, Connecticut, Texas and California.

"Because we have a very educated workforce, because we are a knowledge center, because we are innovative, because we have a very strong base in financial services and a few other fields, we have been able to prosper," he noted.
While lauding Taiwan for its economic achievements over the past decades, Porter said the country needs to work harder to attract world-class companies.

He also called on the country to address "some chronic weaknesses" by reducing corruption, bureaucracy and regulatory complexity, as well as improving labor force flexibility and the quality and transparency of the financial market.

He further noted that Taiwan needs to strengthen innovation and research development in local universities, pointing out that they did not rank high on the list of Taiwanese originators of U.S. patents between 2004 and 2008.

DOC.HEADLINE: Taiwan-Palau ties stable: foreign minister
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, April 8 (CNA) 04/08/10 21:14:09 (By S.Y. Shih and Flor Wang)

TEXT.P: There is no solid evidence to show that China is trying to undermine Taiwan's diplomatic ties with Palau, but government agencies will continue keeping a close watch on related developments, Foreign Minister Timothy C. T. Yang said Thursday.

Fielding questions from opposition Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) lawmaker Chen Ying at a legislative session, Yang said his ministry and the National Security Bureau (NSB) will keep monitoring ensuing developments between the two countries, as a Chinese petroleum company, through a regional agent, has signed a US$40 million cooperation plan with Palau to help the South Pacific nation exploit oil reserves.
Noting that China often uses economic cooperation ventures to cement ties with other countries, Chen warned the government of possible changes in the Taiwan- Palau formal diplomatic links.
Yen Mong-han, deputy director-general of the NSB, said that apart from the oil venture, no solid evidence has been detected that Beijing is plotting to spoil Taiwan's diplomatic relations with Palau.
Palau is one of the 23 countries that maintain full diplomatic ties with Taiwan. Most of these countries are in the South Pacific, Africa and Latin America.

DOC.HEADLINE: Taiwan free to sign FTAs: MAC head
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, April 8 (CNA) 04/08/10 21:24:57 (By Liu Cheng-ching and Bear Lee)

TEXT.P: Mainland Affairs Council (MAC) Chairwoman Lai Shin-yuan said Thursday that Taiwan is free to negotiate and sign free trade agreements (FTAs) with foreign countries without the need for China's approval.

Lai made the remarks at a legislative session while answering questions raised by Chiu Yi-ying of the opposition Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) , who said China will still seek to block Taiwan's efforts to ink FTAs with its trade partners even if a planned cross- strait economic cooperation framework agreement (ECFA) is signed.

Lai said Taiwan is seeking to forge the ECFA with China because it has been the country's largest export market for the past seven years and is the one that is most hotly sought-after by all other leading trading countries.
In the meantime, Taiwan is redoubling its efforts to seek FTAs with the world's major economic players, Lai went on.

"Both sides (Taiwan and China) should take into account each other's concerns in negotiating the ECFA.... and I believe China dare not say that you (Taiwan) should not sign FTAs after the cross-strait deal is signed,'" Lai said.

Earlier that same day, the Legislative Yuan's Interior Affairs Committee voted down a motion initiated by several DPP lawmakers to include a phrase that reads: "China should not stand in the way of Taiwan's signing of FTAs with other counties" in the text of the planned trade pact.

The DPP lawmakers had asked that the pact should be in both Chinese and English, with "agreement" being in the official wording of the pact rather than "arrangement, " which is the word used in the trade deal between Hong Kong and China -- the Closer Economic Partnership Arrangement.
The DPP-led pan-green camp has been vigorously opposed to the ECFA over concerns that it will increase Taiwan's economic dependence on China and cause job losses in some local sectors.
President Ma Ying-jeou, who doubles as chairman of the ruling Kuomintang, is scheduled to hold a TV debate on the ECFA with DPP Chairperson Tsai Ing-wen May 25.

DOC.HEADLINE: EVA follows other carriers in announcing fare cuts
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, April 8 (CNA) 04/08/10 21:34:44 (By H.H. Chao and Flor Wang)

TEXT.P: EVA Airways, Taiwan's second-largest carrier, announced Thursday that it will cut prices for direct economy flights from Taiwan to four major Chinese cities from April 16, the third Taipei-based airline to do so.
EVA Airways made the announcement after similar moves by Trans Asia earlier that same day and by China Airlines (CAL) , Taiwan's largest carrier, a day earlier.

EVA Airways said its fare cuts for non-stop flights from Taiwan to Shanghai, Beijing, Guangzhou and Shenzhen will range between 11 percent and 20 percent, depending on the routes, flight times and ticket categories.

Both Trans Asia and CAL had earlier announced 20 percent cuts on prices for cross -Taiwan Strait flights. Trans Asia plies the Taipei-Shanghai and Taichung- Shanghai routes, while CAL offers direct flights from Taoyuan and Kaohsiung to Shanghai, Beijing, Guangzhou and Shenzhen.

The Consumers' Foundation (CF) later responded to the move by Trans Asia and CAL, saying that it is meaningless to arbitrarily cut the face value of ticket prices and that prices should reflect travel time.
Taking as an example the Taipei-Shanghai flight, which takes only around 80 minutes, the retail price for the customer should not be higher than NT$10,000, CF Chairman Hsieh Tian-jen said.

The Ministry of Transportation and Communications should intervene in the pricing of cross-strait flights to protect consumers' interests, especially during specific holidays such as the Lunar New Year holiday and Tomb Sweeping Day, he contended.

DOC.HEADLINE: Employers urged to give foreign fishery workers insurance coverage
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, April 8 (CNA) 04/08/10 22:07:02 (By Chou Yung-chieh and Sofia Wu)

TEXT.P: The government should heed the plight of the more than 6,000 foreign crew working aboard Taiwanese fishing vessels, many of whom are not fairly paid and are even denied labor and health insurance coverage, activists said Thursday.

Opposition Democratic Progressive Party Legislator Lin Shu-fen and Ku Yu-ling, president of the Taiwan International Workers Association (TIWA) , made the appeal at a joint news conference held at the Legislative Yuan.

A 28-year-old Philippine fishery worker identified only by his first name of Joseph said at the news conference that he has only been paid NT$20,418 (US$646.14) despite having worked for more than eight months aboard a deep-sea fishing boat out of Suao in the northeastern county of Yilan.

Joseph said he originally expected to receive between NT$70,000 and NT$80,000 in wages and was shocked and despondent when he saw the figure written on the salary envelope handed over to him by a manpower broker.

The broker not only rejected his request for a detailed breakdown of his pay, but also threatened to repatriate him. Joseph then took shelter on a fishing boat on which one of his friends was working but the manpower broker refused to return his Alien Resident Certificate and only gave him a copy, forcing him to seek the assistance of the Yilan County labor affairs bureau and the TIWA.

Since Taiwan opened its doors to foreign fishery workers in 1992, Lin said, 6,600 nationals from the Philippines and Indonesia have worked aboard Taiwanese fishing boats. There have been many reports about these workers failing to receive reasonable pay or even being denied labor and health insurance coverage.

For her part, TIWA President Ku said fishery workers account for only 2 percent of the total foreign laborers in Taiwan, with most of them based in Suao and in the eastern counties of Hualien and Taitung.
"They tend to work at sea, with few holidays, and have to work long hours without overtime pay," Ku said, adding that their salaries are also often subject to arbitrary deductions by their employers.

Worse still, she went on, there have been many cases in which local employers have refused to offer them labor and health insurance coverage, instead buying far cheaper group accident insurance policies for them.

Ku urged the Bureau of Labor Insurance (BLI) under the Council of Labor Affairs and the Bureau of National Health Insurance (BNHI) under the Department of Health to investigate whether foreign fishery workers are being covered by their employers in terms of labor and health insurance.

In response, Lin Fang-chu, a BLI official, said the bureau had already demanded that the 2,500-plus local employers present full name lists of their foreign fishery workers and provide labor insurance coverage to all their employees.

Hung Ching-jung, a BNHI official who attended the news conference on behalf of the bureau, said his agency will collect more information through cross-agency cooperation and push employers to provide health insurance coverage to foreign fishery workers.

DOC.HEADLINE: 3 Taiwan fishing boat crew missing in Philippines, 3 rescued: MOFA
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, April 8 (CNA) 04/08/10 22:46:26 (By Chris Wang)

TEXT.P: Three fishermen aboard a stranded Taiwanese fishing boat in the northern Philippines were rescued Thursday while another three were missing, Taiwan's Ministry of Foreign Affairs (MOFA) said later that day.
The Okinawa-registered Taiwanese fishing boat the Cheng Cheng Feng, with a crew of six -- two Taiwanese and four Indonesians -- ran aground early Thursday, the ministry said.

However, a story published by German's Deutsche Presse-Agentur (DPA) reported that all six had been rescued. The story quoted Chief Superintendent Roberto Damian, a regional police director, as saying that one was rescued by helicopter and the other five were rescued by other vessels from rough waters off Mabudis Island, Batanes Province, 540 km north of Manila.

The MOFA said it immediately instructed Taiwan's representative office in the Philippines to contact the Philippine authorities upon learning that the three men were still missing. After receiving approval from the Philippines, Taiwan's Coast Guard Administration dispatched rescue boats to the area for a joint search and rescue mission with its Philippine counterparts, the ministry said.
The mission to find the three missing men was still ongoing, the MOFA said.
Local authorities suspect that the fishermen were poaching in the area when the accident occurred, Damian was quoted by DPA as saying.

DOC.HEADLINE: Taiwanese delegation arrives in China for Boao forum
DOC.DATELINE: Boao, China, April 8 (CNA) 04/08/10 22:50:20 (By He Hsiu-ru and Maubo Chang)

TEXT.P: A Taiwanese delegation led by Fredrick Chien, a former president of the Control Yuan, arrived in southern China's Hainan Province Thursday for the Boao Forum for Asia 2010.
Chien is attending the forum in his capacity as the top adviser to the Taipei- based Cross-Straits Common Market Foundation, a private organization.
Notable among the Taiwanese delegates is Chiu Cheng-hsiung, chairman of the Taiwan-based Bank SinoPac and a former vice premier in President Ma Ying-jeou's administration.

The delegates also include Schive Shih, chairman of the Taiwan Stock Exchange, Shea Jia-dong, chairman of the Taiwan Academy of Banking and Finance, and Shaw Daijee, president of the Chung-hua Institution for Economic Research.

In addition to attending the regular annual conference of the forum, the Taiwanese delegates are expected to exchange views with Chinese delegates during an April 11 cross-strait round table conference on the Economic Cooperation Framework Agreement currently under negotiations between Taiwan and China.
That conference will be chaired by Chien and Dai Xianglong, former chief of Beijing's People's Bank of China.

The delegation's stay in Boao is expected to be rounded off with a meeting, at an as-yet unspecified time, with Chinese Vice President Xi Jingping, the man tipped to succeed Hu Jintao as China's president, who will preside over the forum's opening Friday and deliver a keynote speech.
The forum, founded in 2001 by Australia and 25 Asian states, has held its annual meeting in Boao since 2002 to promote high-level dialogue on regional issues.
The theme of this year's three-day meeting is "Green Recovery: Asia's Realistic Choice for Sustainable Growth."

DOC.HEADLINE: Certain Chinese to be banned from buying real estate in Taiwan
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, April 8 (CNA) 04/08/10 22:56:10 (By C.C. Hsieh and Flor Wang)

TEXT.P: The Ministry of the Interior approved a law amendment Thursday banning personnel in China's military, political parties and government sectors from acquiring real estate in Taiwan.

Under the revised regulations, Chinese citizens who are members of political parties or groups, members of the military or employed in public agencies, will not be permitted to obtain land or property here, mainly to prevent them from speculating in the local real estate market.

At present, the law allows Chinese individuals, including those in these categories to transfer ownership of their residential properties in Taiwan after their property has been registered in their names for three years.
The law revisions will be submitted to the Legislative Yuan for final screening and approval before being implemented.

DOC.HEADLINE: Impact of ASEAN-China free trade pact not obvious: official
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, April 8 (CNA) 04/08/10 23:08:10 (By Lin His-feng and Lillian Lin)

TEXT.P: As the six initial members of the Association of Southeast Asian Nations (ASEAN) have formed a zero-tariff zone with China, concern over how the ASEAN-China free trade agreement will impact Taiwan's exports has been a hot topic in Taiwan.
A finance official said Thursday, however, that the impact might not be reflected in short-term trade figures.

Lin Li-chen, director-general of the Department of Statistics of the Ministry of Finance said that in the first three months of this year, Taiwan's exports to the six nations -- Brunei, Indonesia, Malaysia, the Philippines, Singapore and Thailand -- amounted to US$9.04 billion, up 64.4 percent from the corresponding period of last year.

Meanwhile, Taiwan exported US$26.4 billion-worth of products to China in the first quarter, representing a 75.6 percent growth from the amount of the same period of the preceding year, according to government statistics.

In the January-March period, exports to China accounted for 28.9 percent of Taiwan's overall export value, while exports to Hong Kong accounted for 13.8 percent and exports to the six ASEAN nations accounted for 14.6 percent.

Lin said that since the ASEAN-China free trade agreement took effect only three months ago, it would not be easy to assess the impact on Taiwan's foreign trade. Many elements, such as overall economic environment and export structure, must be taken into consideration while making an analysis, she added.

According to a Finance Ministry press release, continuous improving of the economic environment has helped boost Taiwan's export business, and high growth rates in two-way trade were seen mainly because of the low base for comparison.

In the first quarter of this year, the export value totaled US$61.8 billion, an increase of US$21.3 billion, or 52.5 percent, over the same period of last year. Imports in the January-March period totaled US$56.9 billion, an increase of US$25 billion, or 78.4 percent, from the year-earlier level.

While electronic products remained the leading foreign exchange earners, grossing US$17 billion in the first quarter of this year, other major export items were metal products, optical equipment, plastic products, chemical products, machinery and textiles, as well as information and telecommunications products.

DOC.HEADLINE: Government set to create 115,000 more jobs
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, April 8 (CNA) 04/08/10 23:37:51 (By Hsieh Chun-wei and Bear Lee )

TEXT.P: The government is planning to unveil a series of measures that will create around 115,000 new jobs starting from June, Council for Economic Planning and Development (CEPD) Vice Chairman San Gee said Thursday.
Speaking at a press conference, San elaborated on a CEPD program delivered at a Cabinet meeting earlier that same day. The program is aimed at boosting the economy and stabilizing employment.

As low private investment is the major reason behind the present high unemployment, the government is set to encourage private investment worth NT$1.18 trillion (US$3.74 billion) this year, which in return will create 57,200 jobs, San said.

Another 30,000 jobs will be made available under a plan by the Council of Labor Affairs in case the Industrial Innovation Regulations designed to attract leading international enterprises to Taiwan fail to pass the legislature in June.

The government will also reintroduce a program to offer 30,000 jobs to new university graduates for six months from June. The program has been in place since April 1, 2008, and will come to an end in September 30.
Meanwhile, a program in which the central government subsidizes local governments that hire temporary workers will also be extended for another six months, providing 25,000 new jobs, San added.

DOC.HEADLINE: Employers urged to give foreign fishery workers insurance coverage
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, April 8 (CNA) 04/08/10 22:07:02 (By Chou Yung-chieh and Sofia Wu)

TEXT.P: The government should heed the plight of the more than 6,000 foreign crew working aboard Taiwanese fishing vessels, many of whom are not fairly paid and are even denied labor and health insurance coverage, activists said Thursday.

Opposition Democratic Progressive Party Legislator Lin Shu-fen and Ku Yu-ling, president of the Taiwan International Workers Association (TIWA) , made the appeal at a joint news conference held at the Legislative Yuan.

A 28-year-old Philippine fishery worker identified only by his first name of Joseph said at the news conference that he has only been paid NT$20,418 (US$646.14) despite having worked for more than eight months aboard a deep-sea fishing boat out of Suao in the northeastern county of Yilan.

Joseph said he originally expected to receive between NT$70,000 and NT$80,000 in wages and was shocked and despondent when he saw the figure written on the salary envelope handed over to him by a manpower broker.

The broker not only rejected his request for a detailed breakdown of his pay, but also threatened to repatriate him. Joseph then took shelter on a fishing boat on which one of his friends was working but the manpower broker refused to return his Alien Resident Certificate and only gave him a copy, forcing him to seek the assistance of the Yilan County labor affairs bureau and the TIWA.

Since Taiwan opened its doors to foreign fishery workers in 1992, Lin said, 6,600 nationals from the Philippines and Indonesia have worked aboard Taiwanese fishing boats. There have been many reports about these workers failing to receive reasonable pay or even being denied labor and health insurance coverage.

For her part, TIWA President Ku said fishery workers account for only 2 percent of the total foreign laborers in Taiwan, with most of them based in Suao and in the eastern counties of Hualien and Taitung.
"They tend to work at sea, with few holidays, and have to work long hours without overtime pay," Ku said, adding that their salaries are also often subject to arbitrary deductions by their employers.

Worse still, she went on, there have been many cases in which local employers have refused to offer them labor and health insurance coverage, instead buying far cheaper group accident insurance policies for them.

Ku urged the Bureau of Labor Insurance (BLI) under the Council of Labor Affairs and the Bureau of National Health Insurance (BNHI) under the Department of Health to investigate whether foreign fishery workers are being covered by their employers in terms of labor and health insurance.

In response, Lin Fang-chu, a BLI official, said the bureau had already demanded that the 2,500-plus local employers present full name lists of their foreign fishery workers and provide labor insurance coverage to all their employees.

Hung Ching-jung, a BNHI official who attended the news conference on behalf of the bureau, said his agency will collect more information through cross-agency cooperation and push employers to provide health insurance coverage to foreign fishery workers.

DOC.HEADLINE: 3 Taiwan fishing boat crew missing in Philippines, 3 rescued: MOFA
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, April 8 (CNA) 04/08/10 22:46:26 (By Chris Wang)

TEXT.P: Three fishermen aboard a stranded Taiwanese fishing boat in the northern Philippines were rescued Thursday while another three were missing, Taiwan's Ministry of Foreign Affairs (MOFA) said later that day.
The Okinawa-registered Taiwanese fishing boat the Cheng Cheng Feng, with a crew of six -- two Taiwanese and four Indonesians -- ran aground early Thursday, the ministry said.

However, a story published by German's Deutsche Presse-Agentur (DPA) reported that all six had been rescued. The story quoted Chief Superintendent Roberto Damian, a regional police director, as saying that one was rescued by helicopter and the other five were rescued by other vessels from rough waters off Mabudis Island, Batanes Province, 540 km north of Manila.

The MOFA said it immediately instructed Taiwan's representative office in the Philippines to contact the Philippine authorities upon learning that the three men were still missing. After receiving approval from the Philippines, Taiwan's Coast Guard Administration dispatched rescue boats to the area for a joint search and rescue mission with its Philippine counterparts, the ministry said.
The mission to find the three missing men was still ongoing, the MOFA said.
Local authorities suspect that the fishermen were poaching in the area when the accident occurred, Damian was quoted by DPA as saying.

DOC.HEADLINE: Taiwanese delegation arrives in China for Boao forum
DOC.DATELINE: Boao, China, April 8 (CNA) 04/08/10 22:50:20 (By He Hsiu-ru and Maubo Chang)

TEXT.P: A Taiwanese delegation led by Fredrick Chien, a former president of the Control Yuan, arrived in southern China's Hainan Province Thursday for the Boao Forum for Asia 2010.
Chien is attending the forum in his capacity as the top adviser to the Taipei- based Cross-Straits Common Market Foundation, a private organization.
Notable among the Taiwanese delegates is Chiu Cheng-hsiung, chairman of the Taiwan-based Bank SinoPac and a former vice premier in President Ma Ying-jeou's administration.

The delegates also include Schive Shih, chairman of the Taiwan Stock Exchange, Shea Jia-dong, chairman of the Taiwan Academy of Banking and Finance, and Shaw Daijee, president of the Chung-hua Institution for Economic Research.

In addition to attending the regular annual conference of the forum, the Taiwanese delegates are expected to exchange views with Chinese delegates during an April 11 cross-strait round table conference on the Economic Cooperation Framework Agreement currently under negotiations between Taiwan and China.
That conference will be chaired by Chien and Dai Xianglong, former chief of Beijing's People's Bank of China.

The delegation's stay in Boao is expected to be rounded off with a meeting, at an as-yet unspecified time, with Chinese Vice President Xi Jingping, the man tipped to succeed Hu Jintao as China's president, who will preside over the forum's opening Friday and deliver a keynote speech.
The forum, founded in 2001 by Australia and 25 Asian states, has held its annual meeting in Boao since 2002 to promote high-level dialogue on regional issues.
The theme of this year's three-day meeting is "Green Recovery: Asia's Realistic Choice for Sustainable Growth."

DOC.HEADLINE: Certain Chinese to be banned from buying real estate in Taiwan
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, April 8 (CNA) 04/08/10 22:56:10 (By C.C. Hsieh and Flor Wang)

TEXT.P: The Ministry of the Interior approved a law amendment Thursday banning personnel in China's military, political parties and government sectors from acquiring real estate in Taiwan.

Under the revised regulations, Chinese citizens who are members of political parties or groups, members of the military or employed in public agencies, will not be permitted to obtain land or property here, mainly to prevent them from speculating in the local real estate market.

At present, the law allows Chinese individuals, including those in these categories to transfer ownership of their residential properties in Taiwan after their property has been registered in their names for three years.
The law revisions will be submitted to the Legislative Yuan for final screening and approval before being implemented.

DOC.HEADLINE: Impact of ASEAN-China free trade pact not obvious: official
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, April 8 (CNA) 04/08/10 23:08:10 (By Lin His-feng and Lillian Lin)

TEXT.P: As the six initial members of the Association of Southeast Asian Nations (ASEAN) have formed a zero-tariff zone with China, concern over how the ASEAN-China free trade agreement will impact Taiwan's exports has been a hot topic in Taiwan.
A finance official said Thursday, however, that the impact might not be reflected in short-term trade figures.

Lin Li-chen, director-general of the Department of Statistics of the Ministry of Finance said that in the first three months of this year, Taiwan's exports to the six nations -- Brunei, Indonesia, Malaysia, the Philippines, Singapore and Thailand -- amounted to US$9.04 billion, up 64.4 percent from the corresponding period of last year.

Meanwhile, Taiwan exported US$26.4 billion-worth of products to China in the first quarter, representing a 75.6 percent growth from the amount of the same period of the preceding year, according to government statistics.

In the January-March period, exports to China accounted for 28.9 percent of Taiwan's overall export value, while exports to Hong Kong accounted for 13.8 percent and exports to the six ASEAN nations accounted for 14.6 percent.

Lin said that since the ASEAN-China free trade agreement took effect only three months ago, it would not be easy to assess the impact on Taiwan's foreign trade. Many elements, such as overall economic environment and export structure, must be taken into consideration while making an analysis, she added.

According to a Finance Ministry press release, continuous improving of the economic environment has helped boost Taiwan's export business, and high growth rates in two-way trade were seen mainly because of the low base for comparison.

In the first quarter of this year, the export value totaled US$61.8 billion, an increase of US$21.3 billion, or 52.5 percent, over the same period of last year. Imports in the January-March period totaled US$56.9 billion, an increase of US$25 billion, or 78.4 percent, from the year-earlier level.

While electronic products remained the leading foreign exchange earners, grossing US$17 billion in the first quarter of this year, other major export items were metal products, optical equipment, plastic products, chemical products, machinery and textiles, as well as information and telecommunications products.

DOC.HEADLINE: Government set to create 115,000 more jobs
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, April 8 (CNA) 04/08/10 23:37:51 (By Hsieh Chun-wei and Bear Lee )

TEXT.P: The government is planning to unveil a series of measures that will create around 115,000 new jobs starting from June, Council for Economic Planning and Development (CEPD) Vice Chairman San Gee said Thursday.
Speaking at a press conference, San elaborated on a CEPD program delivered at a Cabinet meeting earlier that same day. The program is aimed at boosting the economy and stabilizing employment.

As low private investment is the major reason behind the present high unemployment, the government is set to encourage private investment worth NT$1.18 trillion (US$3.74 billion) this year, which in return will create 57,200 jobs, San said.

Another 30,000 jobs will be made available under a plan by the Council of Labor Affairs in case the Industrial Innovation Regulations designed to attract leading international enterprises to Taiwan fail to pass the legislature in June.

The government will also reintroduce a program to offer 30,000 jobs to new university graduates for six months from June. The program has been in place since April 1, 2008, and will come to an end in September 30.
Meanwhile, a program in which the central government subsidizes local governments that hire temporary workers will also be extended for another six months, providing 25,000 new jobs, San added.

DOC.HEADLINE: Today in history
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, April 9 (CNA) 04/09/10 08:54:34
DOC.TEXT:
Today is Friday, April 9, or the 25th day of the second month of the Year of the Tiger according to the lunar calendar. Following is a list of important events that have occurred on this date in the past:
1241: Batu Khan, grandson of Genghis Khan, leads his Mongol horsemen to victory over the Teutonic Knights at Liegniz, Silesia.
1626: Sir Francis Bacon, English philosopher, essayist, courtier, jurist, and statesman, dies at the age of 65. His writings include "The Advancement of Learning," and the "Novum Organum," in which he proposed a theory of scientific knowledge based on observation and experiment that came to be known as the inductive method.
1667: The world's first art exhibition opens in Paris, and lasts for 15 days.
1682: La Salle, the title of Robert Cavelier, the French explorer of North America who claimed Louisiana for France in 1682, reaches the Gulf of Mexico after traveling down the Mississippi River.
1865: Confederation Gen. Robert E. Lee surrenders to Union Gen. Ulysses S. Grant at the Appomattox Courthouse in Virginia, ending the U.S. Civil War.
1926: Tuan Chi-jui resigns as provisional chief executive of the Republic of China.
1928: Islam is no longer recognized as the state religion of Turkey.
1940: German troops invade Norway and Denmark.
1942: American and Filipino forces on Bataan surrender to the Japanese after a four-month siege.
1957: Egypt announces the opening of the Suez Canal after the withdrawal of invading troops from Great Britain and France from Port Said.
1961: The Republic of Vietnam holds its first presidential elections with Ngo Dinh Diem elected as president.
1963: British Prime Minister Winston Churchill is proclaimed an honorary U.S. citizen at the White House.
1965: The ROC and the United States conclude in Taipei an accord to establish a Sino-American fund for economic and social development in Taiwan.
1969: The Concorde, the supersonic passenger jet, makes its maiden flight from Bristol to Fairford in England.
1973: Hedley Donavan, editor-in-chief of Time magazine, arrives in Taipei for a two-day visit.
1973: Lt. Gen. Thomas K. McGebee, commander of the U.S. Aerospace Defense Command, arrives in Taipei from Bangkok for a three-day visit.
1974: Nguyen Van Kieu, newly elevated Vietnamese ambassador-extraordinary and plenipotentiary, presents a copy of his credentials to ROC Foreign Minister Shen Chang-huan.
1976: The fifth congress of the Federation of Asian Photographic Arts opens with 200 representatives from South Korea, the Philippines, India, Indonesia, Sabah and the ROC attending.
1976: Bernard B. Matawali, permanent secretary of the Ministry of Agriculture of Malawi, arrives in Taipei for a five-day visit.
1988: Mainland China's National Peoples Congress names Li Peng as premier.
1990: The Democratic Forum of Hungary sweeps to power in elections, after 40 years of communism.
1991: Georgia declares independence from the Soviet Union.
1998: More than 100 Muslim pilgrims are crushed to death in a stampede at the Haj pilgrimage in Saudi Arabia.
2000: Paraguay's first flower exhibition center is inaugurated in the Central Province city of Caacupe, with Paraguayan President Luis Gonzalez Macchi and Republic of China Ambassador to Asuncion Liu Ting-tsu cutting the ribbon.
2001: Former Republic of China Vice President Shieh Tung-min passes away at the age of 95 at his home in a suburb of Taipei from cardial infarction.
Confucius' lesson of the day: "When there is justice and order in the government of the country a man may be bold and lofty in the expression of his opinions as well as in his actions. When, however, there is no justice and order in the government of the country, a man may be bold and lofty in his actions, but should be reserved in the expression of his opinion."

DOC.HEADLINE: Taiwan shares open higher
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, April 9 (CNA) 04/09/10 09:12:55 (By Sofia Wu)

TEXT.P: The Taiwan Stock Exchange's main index opened higher Friday than its previous close, moving up 15.92 points at 8,073.52 on a turnover of NT$2.54 billion (US$80.38 million).
The weighted price index lost 64.18 points, or 0.79 percent, to close at 8,057.6 Thursday.

DOC.HEADLINE: China Times: Original innovation version is the best

TEXT.P: A bill on industrial innovation is on the priority list for this legislative session. While the legislation was shelved in the previous session because of a controversial article concerning tax breaks for multinational corporations with operations headquarters in Taiwan, two new controversies over the bill are emerging.

One of them is a clause initiated by the ruling Kuomintang (KMT) that would provide temporary subsidies for small- and medium-sized businesses that increase staff hiring, especially older workers. The other is a proposal by the opposition Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) to further lower the corporate income tax rate to 17.5 percent, down from the 20 percent proposed by the Ministry of Finance.

First, the DPP's proposal is a product of populism that is against the Budget Act. It is aimed at winning favor with voters and lacks careful consideration. Lowering the tax rate by 2.5 percentage points would mean reducing the government's annual revenue by NT$33 billion. Is this something a responsible political party should be doing?

As for the hiring subsidies, anyone can see that they are totally irrelevant to "industrial innovation." Subsidizing the hiring of older workers would in fact be unfavorable to innovation. Furthermore, measures to ease unemployment can be implemented through administrative means. Including them in a law would deprive them of flexibility.
We support the original version of the bill that was drafted by the Ministry of Economic Affairs. The two recent proposals have demonstrated the laziness and worthlessness of our legislators.
If the ruling and opposition parties keep using this kind of attitude to deal with legislation, we can say nothing that is any more pleasant to the ears than "shameful." (April 9, 2010)
