DOC.HEADLINE: Exports expected to hit new high in 2010
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, April 9 (CNA) 04/09/10 11:42:13 (By Lin Ye-fong and Deborah Kuo)

TEXT.P: Surmounting the 2008-2009 global recession, Taiwan's export trade is expected to ride a recovery wave this year and to surpass the previous record performance set in 2008, a local economist forecast Friday.

The rise in export trade in January and February was understandable because of increased demand during the Chinese New Year holiday from China -- Taiwan's largest export outlet -- but a surge in March, to the tune of US$23.37 billion, up 50.1 percent year-on-year, is an indication that the upward trade trend is back, said Cheng-mount Cheng, a vice president and economist with Citibank Taiwan.
"Judging from the brisk performance in the first quarter, totaling US$61.8 billion, the country's exports this year may surpass the 2008 record of US$255.63 billion, " Cheng said.

The Q1 export value was an increase of US$21.3 billion, or 52.5 percent over the same period of 2009, while imports in the January-March period totaled US$56.9 billion, up US$25 billion, or 78.4 percent year-on-year, said Lin Lee-jen, director of the Department of Statistics under the Ministry of Finance (MOF).

Lin said that although recovery in the United States and the European Union has been relatively slower, the U.S. per capita consumption had climbed for five consecutive months as of February, while the purchase manager index in the euro region surged to a new high in March -- both good news for Taiwan in terms of export trade.

Meanwhile, Kung Ming-hsin, vice president of the Taiwan Institute of Economic Research, a local think tank, said Taiwan's brisk exports in the first quarter symbolize that the global economy is on a fast track to recovery.
"Unless governments suspend their stimulus mechanisms that have been in place since late 2008, the recovery trend is set here and any reverse will not be possible in the short run," Kung estimated.
"I forecast that the rebound and growth trend will continue at least until the middle of the year," he said.

Nevertheless, William Fu, a senior business manager with Standard Chartered Bank in Taipei, sees the trend differently, and said that fast or slow recovery in the U.S. and Europe will be the major variable.
"Whether U.S. and European employment will pick up significantly will be the major observation benchmark," Fu contended.

In related news, Taiwan exported US$26.4 billion-worth of products to China in the first quarter, representing a 75.6 percent growth over the figure posted in the same period of 2009, according to MOF statistics.
In the January-March period, exports to China accounted for 28.9 percent of Taiwan's overall export value, while exports to Hong Kong accounted for 13.8 percent.

DOC.HEADLINE: Apple Daily: Some problems are unrelated to who is in power

TEXT.P: We used to think that incompetence and lack of control over the legislature were the reasons why former President Chen Shui-bian failed to resolve some problems during his eight years in power.

But we were wrong. After several rounds of changeovers of power in Taiwan, we have come to realize that while some of those problems were not resolved because of the democratic nature of our political system, others could be attributed to human nature.

One example is the country's suicide rate, which has remained almost as high during the present administration of President Ma Ying-jeou as it was during the former Chen administration. Another is government efficiency, which is as low during the Ma administration as it was in the Chen administration.

When judging government efficiency, we tend to compare the present time to the past under the rule of the late President Chiang Ching-kuo. There is also a tendency to compare Taiwan's vacillation and procrastination to China's high efficiency.

This is unfair. Unlike the authoritarian regime of Chiang and the communist regime in China, both of which stress efficiency, the democratic government of Taiwan in the most recent decade pays more attention to the rights of the people.
Since democracy is our choice, we have to endure the problems caused by inefficiency. As for corruption, it is human nature.

Taiwan's democracy is only a little more than 10 years old and is still in its breaking-in period. With more effort by the ruling and opposition parties, we can expect a bright future. (April 9, 2010)

DOC.HEADLINE: Talk of the day -- Is ECFA Taiwan's only option?

TEXT.P: The question of whether Taiwan should sign an economic cooperation framework agreement (ECFA) -- seen as a scaled-back free trade agreement (FTA) -- with China remains a hot-button issue in local society.

In a speech delivered in Taipei Thursday, Harvard Business School Professor Michael Porter said he supports the proposed ECFA deal between the two sides of the Taiwan Strait because it would allow Taiwan to continue to substantially enhance its economy over time.

On that same day, tension crackled between the Presidential Office and the opposition Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) as both sides stepped up preparations for an April 25 debate between President Ma Ying-jeou and DPP Chairperson Tsai Ing-wen on ECFA-related topics.
The following are excerpts from local media coverage of the issue: United Daily News:
Speaking in a forum held at the Dr. Sun Yat-sen Memorial Hall in Taipei Thursday, Porter said the proposed cross-strait trade pact is just a move to formalize "something that's already happening."
"Taiwan already has a huge economic relationship with China despite the fact that there is no framework, " the renowned corporate management strategist observed.

Responding to a question by Michael DeNoma, chairman of the Taipei-based Chinatrust Commercial Bank and one of the panelists at the forum on whether there are any alternatives to the ECFA initiative, Porter said he had thought about that.
"I don't see any alternative, any practical alternative. But more importantly, I don't see why we would want an alternative, " he replied.
There are many ECFA-like agreements that other countries have signed with China and in many cases, these countries have much less strength than Taiwan, Porter said.
"I am confident that you will be much better off with such a framework than you would be without it," he added.

Porter also urged Taiwan to focus on "getting the fundamentals right" by building an attractive business environment and establishing a good infrastructure rather than worrying about the size of China.
"Size, per se, is nothing to fear," he said. (April 9, 2010). Liberty Times:

The administration of President Ma Ying-jeou has repeatedly intimidated the people of Taiwan, claiming that if Taiwan fails to sign an ECFA with China, it will be marginalized after the formation of the ASEAN Plus One (China) free trade area.

The trade data released by the Ministry of Finance (MOF) Thursday, however, seemed to be a slap in the face for the Ma administration. While ASEAN Plus One took effect at the beginning of this year, Taiwan's exports remained robust in the first quarter, with the amount reaching US$61.8 billion -- the second highest in history for the same period.

Moreover, Taiwan's exports to six major ASEAN member states amounted to US$9.04 billion in Q1, which was also the second highest in Taiwan-ASEAN trade history. Taiwan's Q1 shipments to China and Hong Kong as a whole even set a new quarterly record of US$26.42 billion.
All these figures point to the strength and resilience of Taiwan's economy even after the formation of ASEAN Plus One.

Nevertheless, Lin Lee-jen, director-general of the MOF's Department of Statistics, said it might be premature to make any judgment on the impact of ASEAN Plus One on Taiwan's foreign trade simply based on a quarterly statistical report. (April 9, 2010). China Times:

Tempers flared between aides of President Ma and DPP Chairperson Tsai Thursday over whether the Presidential Office should furnish Tsai before the April 25 debate with information about the ECFA content and the "early harvest" items to be subject to immediate tariff concessions or exemptions under the agreement.

Instead of responding directly to the DPP's request for such information, Presidential Office spoeksman Lo Chih-chiang asked Tsai to answer three questions before the debate, including how many items Tsai thought should be included in the "early harvest" list as well as what alternative Tsai would propose to an ECFA and that she should make public her reasons for deciding to oppose the pact. (April 9, 2010).

DOC.HEADLINE: Industrial innovation tax likely to be lowered to 17%
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, April 9 (CNA) 04/09/10 13:50:23 (By Chou Yung-chieh, Hsu Jui-ting and Deborah Kuo)

TEXT.P: Controversies over tax legislation to be included in an industrial innovation bill are likely to be cleared up now that the Executive Yuan has reportedly agreed to accept a new version that puts corporate income tax rate at 17 percent, Legislative Yuan sources said Friday.

If the 17-percent rate is acceptable to the Executive Yuan -- which had proposed a drop from the existing rate of 20 percent to 15 percent in its initial version referred to the Legislative Yuan for deliberation -- further negotiations by the ruling Kuomintang (KMT) and the opposition Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) over the bill are expected to go much more smoothly.

The industrial innovation bill failed to clear the legislative floor in late March due to a filibuster by DPP lawmakers over many controversies, mainly on tax breaks for multinational corporations with operations headquarters in Taiwan and relaxed restrictions on the establishment of industrial parks or zones.

A member of the KMT legislative caucus said that at present, the Executive Yuan appears to accept two versions concerning the tax breaks -- either maintaining the existing rate or lowering it to 17 percent, with the latter enjoying greater favor.
Meanwhile, according to the KMT legislator, a 17.5 percent corporate income tax rate proposed by the DPP will definitely not be considered.

Lee Chun-yi, a whip of the DPP legislative caucus, said prior to negotiations with the KMT legislators that the 17-percent concessionary tax rate proposal significantly narrows the gap between the two parties on the issue.
"We welcome it as a positive move," Lee said.

Meanwhile, Legislative Yuan Speaker Wang Jin-pyng said Friday that legislators of different political persuasions had been working hard since early that morning on screening, discussing and deliberating the bill article by article.
"Patience is needed here," Wang said.

DOC.HEADLINE: United Daily News: Police, betel nut girl, betel nut stall owner

TEXT.P: A police officer in Taipei County has made headlines for knocking down a scantily clad betel nut girl and dragging her to the police station after she called him names in response to his warning that she should dress properly.
The incident came to light because it was caught on a security camera installed by the owner of the betel nut stall, and the officer was disciplined and transferred to another job for his brutality.
Police will have difficulty carrying out their jobs if there are no clear guidelines on how to stop betel nut girls from attracting customers by dressing in as little as possible.

The practice will not die out if these girls simply throw on a jacket in front of the police and take it off once the police leave. However, if the police want to crack down on the practice, they have to do it properly in the eyes of the law and of the people. They are debasing themselves and their job by beating a girl.
Betel nut girls dressed scantily are not a serious crime, and the police could easily ticket them or treat them in a more appropriate way than beating them, even when they abuse the police.

But while public attention was caught by the policeman and the girl, the betel nut stall's owner, who hid behind the scenes and recorded the whole fracas with a camera without bothering to come to the aid of the girl, was missing from the coverage of the story.
We have to ask does he or she have no responsibility at all?

DOC.HEADLINE: Taiwanese minor leaguers toil their way up
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, April 9 (CNA) 04/09/10 14:49:28 (By Chris Wang)

TEXT.P: As most local fans set their eyes on Washington Nationals pitcher Chien-Ming Wang, the most successful Taiwanese baseballer in the U.S. Major League to date, more than 20 Taiwanese players in the U.S. minor leagues are trying to work their way up, hoping some day to make it to the big league.

Twelve of the 27 Taiwanese players in the minors, including former Los Angeles Dodgers shortstop Hu Chin-lung -- now demoted to the Albuquerque Isotopes in the Triple-A -- open their baseball season Friday, the opening day of the 2010 full- season minor leagues, while the other 15 are still participating in extended spring training and have not been assigned.

The 2010 major league season opening day on April 5 was not so exciting for local fans, as they did not have many players to cheer about. Left-handed reliever Ni Fu-te of the Detroit Tigers was the only Taiwanese player to make the 25-man roster on opening day, with Wang and Dodgers left-hander Kuo Hong- chih both still undergoing rehabilitation from injury.

The good news is that there are eight players in the Double-A teams -- a record for Taiwanese players -- who could earn callups to the Majors in the later part of the season if they perform well like Wang, who was called up to the big league in 2005 after six years in the New York Yankees farm system.

Among these major league hopefuls are Hu, who played sparingly with the Dodgers, and right-handed pitcher Lo Chia-jen of the Houston Astros, who made Double-A in his first season and accumulated three saves to go with a 2.10 earned run average (ERA).

Lo has been ranked as the second-best Asian prospect in the minors by Baseball Digest Daily (BDD), a website focusing on baseball coverage. The other three also made the top 10 list, including fifth -ranked Boston Red Sox outfielder Lin Che-hsuan, Cleveland Indians pitcher Lee Chen-chang at No. 6 and Seattle Mariners outfielder Lo Kuo-hui at No. 9

Other players in the Double-A are Oakland Athletics outfielder Chen Yung-chi, Colorado Rockies pitcher Lo Chin-lung, Boston Red Sox infielder Chiang Chih- hsien and Chicago White Sox pitcher Chen Hun-wen.
According to the BDD, the mid-level minors are crammed with Asian talent, which also includes players from Japan and South Korea.

DOC.HEADLINE: Taiwan share prices close higher
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, April 9 (CNA) 04/09/10 15:25:04 (by Olivia Wang)

TEXT.P: Taiwan's share prices closed higher Friday with the weighted index, the market's key barometer, moving up 34.43 points, or 0.42 percent, to close at 8,092.03.
The local bourse opened at 8,073.52 and fluctuated between a low of 8,039.41 and a high of 8,094.35 during the day's trading. Market turnover totaled NT$107.41 billion (US$3.4 billion).

Six of the eight major stock categories gained ground, with banking and financial stocks gaining the most at 0.75 percent. Paper and pulp issues rose 0.66 percent, textile shares moved up 0.62 percent, and machinery and electronics issues advanced 0.43 percent.
Construction shares rose 0.28 percent and plastics and chemicals shares edged up 0.2 percent.
Two major stock categories lost ground, with cement issues dropping 0.64 percent and foodstuff issues falling 0.44 percent.
Losers outnumbered gainers 1,553 to 1,481 with 339 remaining unchanged.
Foreign investors and Chinese QDIIs were net buyers of NT$4.54 billion in shares.

DOC.HEADLINE: Taichung's recycling efforts impress Shanghai mayor
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, April 9 (CNA) 04/09/10 16:05:09 (By Lee Hsi-chang, Hao Hsueh-ching, Chiu Chun-chin and Deborah Kuo)

TEXT.P: Visiting Shanghai Mayor Han Zheng toured a recycling park in Taiwan's central city of Taichung Friday, where he said he was particularly impressed by measures adopted to collect and recycle kitchen leftovers.

Han, on his fourth and final day in Taiwan, was briefed by officials from the Taichung Environmental Protection Bureau on how kitchen leftovers were collected and sent to a location for processing. Part of the leftovers are made into organic compost and then sold to farmers, he was told.

At the park, Han visited a store where recycled clothes and apparel were displayed for sale, and was shown electric vehicles that Taichung Environmental Protection Bureau inspectors ride while traveling around the city.
The Shanghai mayor was accompanied by Taichung Mayor Jason Hu.

Han invited Hu to visit Shanghai this year, particularly during the 2010 World Expo. Hu thanked Han but said he may not be able to find time for a Shanghai trip this year because crucial municipality elections take place in November.
Han and his entourage then boarded a north-bound high-speed train and before long arrived in northern Taiwan's Taoyuan City, the final stop for the Shanghai delegation.

They were met by Taoyuan Magistrate Wu Chih-yang, who briefed them on the county government's plan to build Taoyuan into a smart, environmentally friendly city surrounding the existing Taiwan Taoyuan International Airport.
For his part, Han said he hopes Shanghai will continue to strengthen air ties with Taoyuan International Airport and sea ties with Kaohsiung Harbor in southern Taiwan.
Han and his entourage arrived in Taiwan Tuesday and have had a tight schedule of meetings with Taiwanese politicians and business leaders while promoting the 2010 World Expo.

DOC.HEADLINE: DPP chairwoman renews call for referendum on ECFA
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, April 9 (CNA) 04/09/10 16:09:21 (By Y.F. Low)

TEXT.P: Opposition Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) Chairwoman Tsai Ing-wen on Friday renewed her party's call for a referendum to settle the differences over a proposed economic cooperation framework agreement (ECFA) with China.
Tsai said she will responsibly present her party's views when debating the issue with President Ma Ying-jeou April 25 and will "leave the final choice to the people."

"The most effective way to resolve social confrontation is to hold a referendum to allow the people to decide on the ECFA on their own, " Tsai said when receiving representatives of the Citizen Congress Watch, a civic organization monitoring legislators.
According to Tsai, Taiwan is a country suitable for referendums because of the high educational level of its people and its maturing society.
Multiple options should be available in a democratic society, she said, expressing disagreement with a media report claiming that "ECFA is Taiwan's only option."

She noted that President Ma has insisted since 2008 that signing the agreement with China was a necessity but said that the opposition had yet to obtain any comprehensive information regarding its details.
She voiced disappointment at the Presidential Office's refusal to provide the information requested by the DPP in preparation for the debate.
The DPP has requested access to the early harvest list proposed by the government, the draft of the agreement, and government-commissioned ECFA assessment reports.
The Presidential Office turned down the proposal, however, saying the information had to be withheld because the negotiations are still going on.

Tsai explained that the DPP was asking for the information because it wants to ensure the debate will be conducted on an equal footing, not because it was "playing a dirty trick, " as the Presidential Office alleged.
Through the debate, the DPP hopes that Ma will directly explain to the people the purposes and possible impact of the ECFA and the government's countermeasures, she said.

DOC.HEADLINE: Lack of content for 3D TVs: experts
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, April 9 (CNA) 04/09/10 16:37:46 (By Alex Jiang)

TEXT.P: Visitors to a computer show that opened in Taipei a day earlier lined up to experience the latest 3D technology for TVs, but experts said it is still too early for the technology to become popular due to a lack of content.

Samsung is showcasing the first 3D LED TV that will be available in Taiwan at the show, which runs until April 12 and features a wide variety of electronics products, including smartphones, LED monitors, e-readers and digital cameras.
"It is the first time consumers in Taiwan have seen the Samsung C7000 3D LED TV, which is due to hit the local market in early May," the South Korean company said in a press statement.
Sony Taiwan also set up a small exhibition hall in which visitors could wear 3D glasses while watching a U.S. animated film. Sony is scheduled to release its 3D TV in Taiwan in June.
However, several visitors were dissatisfied with their viewing experience.
A group of students told CNA that the 3D effect was not as good as they had expected.
"It made me a bit dizzy," said one girl.
Another visitor, a middle-aged man surnamed Chen, complained that the images are "shaky."
"I also felt a sense of oppressiveness," he added.
Taking into consideration the quality and the price, which is much higher than that of a traditional TV, Chen said he wouldn't buy a 3D TV at the moment.
"If you buy a 3D TV, what are you going to watch on it? There are very few 3D movies, " said Danny Yao, managing director of BenQ Taiwan.
Kevin Fang, a senior executive at LG Electronics Taiwan, agreed that there is a lack of content and that the 3D TVs are impractical.
"Right now, these companies are demonstrating that they are capable of developing 3D technology," he said.

DOC.HEADLINE: Premier touts Taiwan-China trade pact
DOC.DATELINE: Kaohsiung, April 9 (CNA) 04/09/10 16:52:24 (By C.F. Chen and Flor Wang)

TEXT.P: The government is planning to allocate a budget of NT$95 billion (US$3 billion) over a 10-year period to assist workers in vulnerable industries after Taiwan signs an economic cooperation framework agreement (ECFA) with China, Premier Wu Den-yih said Friday.

The funds will be used to help affected workers make the move to other professions and stabilize their lives after the ECFA is implemented, Wu told a seminar on the impact of the proposed cross-Taiwan Strait trade deal held at I-Shou University in southern Taiwan.

Saying that the tariff-concession agreement is aimed at stepping up Taiwan's competitiveness and helping businessmen amid fierce foreign competition, he pledged that the government will stick to its principle of protecting the interests of Taiwan's people when negotiating the pact.

Taiwan and China are expected to hold the third round of ECFA talks in Beijing soon after concluding their second round of talks in Taiwan, which produced little progress on forging common ground regarding "early harvest lists" drawn up by the two sides for priority treatment.
The items included on each side's list would be allowed to enter the other side with preferential customs rates or duty free, making Taiwanese goods more competitive in the Chinese market.
Wu reiterated that the government will not allow the entry of Chinese workers or open Taiwan's doors wider to vegetables and other farm products from China.
Earlier that same day, the premier inspected reconstruction work on the Shuanyuan Bridge connecting Kaohsiung County with Pingtung County.
Reconstruction of the bridge, which was seriously damaged by Typhoon Morakot in August last year, is slated for completion by late April, before the onset of typhoon season.

DOC.HEADLINE: President affirms Defense Ministry's anti-corruption campaign
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, April 9 (CNA) 04/09/10 17:10:42 (By Maubo Chang)

TEXT.P: President Ma Ying-jeou affirmed the Ministry of National Defense's (MND's) efforts to stamp out corruption Friday, saying that the scrutiny was necessary to protect the honor of the country's senior military officials.

Speaking at a news conference organized to mark the first anniversary of the military's anti-corruption campaign, the president said the blanket probe of all promotions involving general and flag officers might have caused displeasure to some, but the integrity of those who held up to scrutiny is now ensured.

"Their sacrifice is worthwhile," the president said, adding that he had asked Minister of National Defense Kao Hua-chu to convey his apologies to the officers who turned out to be innocent after being probed.
He lauded the MND's efforts to weed out corruption by probing more than 4,000 people and looking into more than 80,000 cases.
"I was briefed monthly by the ministry during the past year and offered my advice," the president said.
He invited the public, including TV commentators who often criticize the government for alleged corruption, to provide any information they can find about corruption involving officials.
"It is our motto that no one will be spared and that no one will be punished wrongfully," the president said.

Ma ordered a sweeping probe April 8 last year when the image of the armed forces was in tatters because of a series of corruption cases, which prompted widespread allegations that promotion-buying was rampant among senior military officers.
In a news conference the previous day, Chang Shan-dong, a leading military inspector, said that military prosecutors had probed 58 alleged corruption cases involving 156 officers.

The investigation of 50 of them had already closed, leading to the indictment of 13 people, notably Lt. Gen. He Yung-chien, former deputy commander-in-chief of the Reserve Command, and Maj. Gen. Chen Ching-chon, former chief of the Defense Mission to the United States.

On the allegations that some senior officers owe their posts to bribes paid to their superiors, Chang said the Ministry of National Defense has examined the promotions of 900 to the rank of general or flag officers, including some who have already retired.
Among them, 124 have been referred to an ad hoc investigation team for further investigation because of irregularities in their promotions.
Chang said the anti-corruption campaign is a long-term effort that will be continued by the Defense Ministry without any let up.
In a related development Friday, the MND decided to set up an ethics unit with the help of the Ministry of Justice (MOJ) to crack down on the corruption.
During a meeting presided over by Minister without Portfolio Kao Su-po, the MOJ agreed to revise the law to pave the way for the ethics unit.
Under the existing law, the military, the legislature and schools cannot have ethics units.
The revision, which will have to be approved by the Executive Yuan, is considered necessary to carry out Ma's instruction to weed out corruption in the military.

In the preliminary stage, the military service ethics unit will be led by a lead prosecutor from the MOJ who will work independently from the armed forces' chief ombudsman, who at present is the official responsible for probes into corruption allegations involving military officers.
Meanwhile, the MOJ will train anti-corruption officers who will man the ethics unit under the MND.

DOC.HEADLINE: U.S. dollar down on Taipei Forex
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, April 9 (CNA) 04/09/10 17:13:16 (By Olivia Wang)

TEXT.P: The U.S. dollar lost ground against the New Taiwan dollar on the Taipei Foreign Exchange Friday, dropping NT$0.086 to close at NT$31.615.
A total of US$ 1.06 billion changed hands during the trading session.
The U.S. dollar opened at the day's high of NT$31.701, and fell to a low of NT$31.534 before rebounding.

DOC.HEADLINE: Only 22% of office workers own homes: poll
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, April 9 (CNA) 04/09/10 17:20:02 (By Cheng Yun-hsuan and Y.L. Kao)

TEXT.P: Only 22.1 percent of office workers in Taiwan own their homes, and 87.01 percent of homeowners are burdened with home loans, according to the results of a poll published Friday by 1111 Job Bank.
Among homeowners, 82.18 percent use their houses themselves, while others rent out their houses or have relatives living in them, the poll found.

Meanwhile, 76.24 percent of homeowners bought their houses themselves, with 51.49 percent using only their own money and 24.75 percent receiving financial support from their parents, the study showed.

According to the poll, those with home loans spend an average 38 percent of their monthly salaries repaying their debts, with 13.43 percent of them using between 51 percent and 60 percent of their monthly salaries.

Asked to rate the level of financial pressure they are under based on a scale of 0-100 points, 22.39 percent of those with loans ranked themselves between 91 and 100. The average ranking given by those with loans was 63.

It also found that females felt more financial pressure than males. Ho Chi- sheng, a public relations chief at the job bank, said that was because men are normally better paid and had a better chance of receiving financial assistance from their parents as the purchases are usually made to raise a family.
Most women purchased houses as an investment, Ho said.
By industrial sector, office workers in the real estate sector were found more likely to own homes than workers in other sectors.
The online poll was conducted between March 26 and April 8, with 1,097 valid samples collected. It had a confidence level of 95 percent and a 2.95 percent margin of error.

DOC.HEADLINE: Water supplies to remain normal until June: Taiwater
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, April 9 (CNA) 04/09/10 17:29:29 (By Lin Hui-chun, Lee Hsi-chang and Deborah Kuo)

TEXT.P: Taiwan's only running water supplier said Friday that with the exception of the southern Kaohsiung area, the country's water reserves are sufficient to meet demand until the end of June.

Hu Nan-jer, a vice president of Taiwan Water Corp. (Taiwater) , said that stable water supplies will be ensured until that time, thanks to several cold fronts since the beginning of this year that brought large quantities of rain to northern and central regions.

Hu said that although water in major reservoirs in northern and central Taiwan have reached normal levels, southern Taiwan is still suffering from a lack of water, with major reservoirs in the Kaohsiung area at low levels.

He added that the water company has been undertaking a series of measures to increase supplies in the Kaohsiung area, work that has included drilling new wells, tapping more underground water sources, and deepening and dredging reservoirs.
"After these measures are complete, the water output in the Kaohsiung area is expected to be increased by 200,000 cubic meters to 400,000 cubic meters daily," Hu said.
"The increased water output will ensure stable water supplies in the Kaohsiung area until mid-May," he continued.
Meanwhile, Taiwater said that if drought conditions persist in southern Taiwan, contingency measures will be put in place under the supervision of the Ministry of Economic Affairs.
These measures will include lower water pipe pressure during daily off-peak periods as a level one move. At level two, water supplies to heavy water users such as swimming pools will be restricted.

At level three, water supplies will be stopped alternately in different districts, and at level four, a water rationing mechanism will be put in place to supply water only at certain times and at a certain volume, Taiwater said.

DOC.HEADLINE: Taiwanese rock band hits Los Angeles
DOC.DATELINE: Los Angeles, April 8 (CNA) 04/09/10 17:33:37 (By Chiang Chin-yeh and Y.F. Low)

TEXT.P: Taiwanese rock band Mayday arrived in Los Angeles Thursday on the second leg of a 2010 world tour following their opening show in New York.
The L.A. concert will take place April 10.
Ashin, the group's lead vocalist, noted in a news conference that it has been two years since Mayday last played in Los Angeles and that the new show will include new material.
This is the group's fifth world tour. It is scheduled to perform in San Francisco April 11 before going to China, where the stops will include Xiamen, Beijing, Wuhan and Xian.

Asked about dream venues for future Mayday concerts, bassist Matthew Tsai said he would like to play on a container vessel on the high seas for a large number of fans, singing all night with beer and food.

DOC.HEADLINE: Taiwan to develop 25 low-carbon communities this year
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, April 9 (CNA) 04/09/10 17:39:06 (By Hsieh Chia-chen and Elizabeth Hsu)

TEXT.P: Taiwan will focus on energy conservation and carbon reduction in 2010, with a goal of using 3.34 million kilowatts of recycled energy and building 25 low- carbon communities by the end of the year.
The Ministry of Economic Affairs (MOEA) presented 18 motion projects to the Executive Yuan Thursday.
Under the plans, Taiwan will seek to improve energy efficiency by at least 2 percent a year over the next eight years while cutting the nation's carbon emissions to 2005 levels by 2020.

With the 18 projects, the MOEA will establish a new energy recycling mechanism, encouraging the public to use small energy recycling facilities and expanding the collection of wind power from land-based generators to offshore generators.
As for low-carbon communities, the ministry has set a goal of developing two model communities each in 25 cities and counties, for a total of 50, before the end of 2011.
Four cities will be developed into low-carbon cities by 2014, according to the MOEA.
Furthermore, Taiwan will adopt energy efficiency grading systems for air conditioners, refrigerators and automobiles, the ministry said.

DOC.HEADLINE: Taiwan railway launches luxury 7-day tour of Taiwan
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, April 9 (CNA) 04/09/10 17:49:16 (By Wang Shu-feng and Lilian Wu)

TEXT.P: The Taiwan Railway Administration (TRA) and a leading online travel agency unveiled on Friday a number of new train tour packages they have put together to explore Taiwan, including a seven-day luxury tour of the island that will cost NT$70,000 (US$2,215).

The seven-day package will take travelers to Taroko Gorge in Hualien, the Bunun aboriginal community in Taitung, Taiwan's ancient capital of Tainan, Kenting in southern Taiwan, and Sun Moon Lake and will put them up at six five-star hotels along the way.

Special attendants will be on board the train to provide assistance to passengers and serve them local delicacies, such as Donghe meat buns from Taitung, "Chou's" shrimp rolls from Tainan, and steamed red bean cake favored by the late first lady Soong Mei-ling, according to Jack Yo, president of travel agency ezTravel.
With airfares to overseas destinations on the rise, Yo said many people are choosing to travel around Taiwan, with a growing number opting for the tourism train.
The TRA launched the tourism train with ezTravel in 2001, initially targeting only eastern and southern Taiwan. But it later evolved into more varied offerings that connect all parts of the island.
At present, the cheapest "Formosa Star" tour is a one-day tour of Taroko Gorge, costing NT$1,999.
Most of the tour packages span two or three days, with prices ranging from NT$2,500 to NT$12,500.
More information on the packages offered can be found in Chinese on ezTravel's Web site.

DOC.HEADLINE: Taiwan's export competitiveness on decline: official
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, April 9 (CNA) 04/09/10 17:49:35 (By Lin Shu-yuan and Sofia Wu)

TEXT.P: Taiwan's export competitiveness has been on a steady decline over the past nine years in comparison with its major trade competitors, a senior Ministry of Economic Affairs (MOEA) official said Friday.

Citing government statistics, Deputy Minister of Economic Affairs Lin Sheng- chung said Taiwan posted an average annual growth of 7 percent in exports to the 10 member states of the Association of Southeast Asian Nations (ASEAN) between 2001 and 2009, far lower than South Korea's 9.4 percent and China's 23.1 percent.
In terms of amount, Lin said, Taiwan's shipments to the 10 ASEAN states doubled during the nine-year period, lagging behind South Korea's 2.5-times growth, Lin added.

He made the remarks after the Liberty Times, a local daily, said in the front- page report that same day that Taiwan's export figures for the first quarter of this year seemed to be a slap in the face for the administration of President Ma Ying-jeou.

While the Ma administration has repeatedly claimed that if Taiwan fails to sign an economic cooperation framework agreement (ECFA) with China, it will be marginalized after the formation of the ASEAN Plus One (China) free trade area, the paper said Taiwan's Q1 exports remained robust, with the amount reaching US$61.8 billion -- the second highest in history for the same period.

Moreover, it said, Taiwan's exports to six of the major ASEAN member states amounted to US$9.04 billion in Q1, which was also the second highest in Taiwan- ASEAN trade history. Taiwan's Q1 shipments to China and Hong Kong as a whole even set a new quarterly record of US$26.42 billion.
All these figures point to the strength and resilience of Taiwan's economy even after the formation of the ASEAN Plus One at the beginning of this year, according to the paper.
In response, Lin said that trade competitiveness rather than export figures better reflects Taiwan's true economic situation in the global macroeconomy.
"The annual growth rate only measures one's own performance in different periods... We should compare with others to better understand our actual strength," Lin explained.
According to him, Taiwan is actually losing its export competitiveness because of its lack of access to regional economic integration.
In contrast, A South Korea-ASEAN free trade agreement (FTA) covering goods took effect in June 2007 and a similar agreement covering services came into force in May 2009.
Meanwhile, the ASEAN-Japan Comprehensive Economic Partnership Agreement took effect in December 2008, while the ASEAN Plus China free trade area was inaugurated Jan. 1 this year.

To sum up, Lin said, ASEAN, Japan, South Korea and China have signed FTAs to boost their economic exchanges and cooperation. These developments have taken a toll on Taiwan's trade competitiveness, he argued, adding that Taiwan needs to conclude an ECFA deal with China to facilitate its trade expansion and sustain its economic growth.
The proposed ECFA is seen as a scaled-back FTA and Taiwan's government hopes that its FTA talks with other countries will become easier after the ECFA is signed with China.

China still claims sovereignty over Taiwan, but the Ma administration's modus vivendi diplomatic approach has contributed to significant improvements in cross-strait relations in the last couple of years, giving optimism to the prospects of signing a cross-strait ECFA and FTAs with other trade partners.

DOC.HEADLINE: Taiwan high schools win titles in tug-of-war competition
DOC.DATELINE: Seoul, April 9 (CNA) 04/09/10 18:20:01 (By Y.L. Kao)

TEXT.P: Three Taiwanese senior high schools swept the three divisions of the Asian Tug- of-War Open Club competition in South Korea Thursday, the opening events of the 8th Asian Tug-of-War Championships.

National Nantou Senior High School, Taichung County Dali Senior High School, and Nuan Nuan Senior High School in Keelung won the male, female and mixed events, respectively, according to Lin Li-hua, principal of Taipei Jingmei Girls High School and the leader of Taiwan's teams at the championships.

Meanwhile, Taiwan's national women's team, composed of students from Taipei Jingmei Girls High School, and the men's team, composed of Chiao Tai High School and Asia University, Taiwan, both reached the final four in their respective divisions in the main championships after a round robin qualifying round.
The men's team was to face South Korea and the women's team Vietnam Friday for places in the gold medal round.

DOC.HEADLINE: DPP challenged to come up with alternative to ECFA
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, April 9 (CNA) 04/09/10 19:12:09 (By Garfie Li and Lilian Wu)

TEXT.P: The Presidential Office on Friday challenged opposition Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) Chairwoman Tsai Ing-wen to come up with its own economic strategy to deal with the crisis of Taiwan being marginalized.
Presidential Office spokesman Lo Chih-chiang said Tsai has led the party for two years but has so far said nothing about how to address the crisis.
If Tsai is opposed to a proposed cross-strait economic cooperation framework agreement (ECFA), she should clearly explain her "constructive alternative," Lo said.

The spokesman wondered how Tsai would cope with the problem of lower tariffs on the trade of goods between other countries and China as free trade blocs and global free trade agreements take hold, hurting Taiwan's exports and contributing to its marginalization.

Earlier in the day, Tsai criticized President Ma Ying-jeou for his insistence since 2008 that signing the agreement with China was a necessity and said that the opposition had yet to obtain any comprehensive information regarding its details.
She asked to have access to the early harvest list proposed by the government, the draft of the agreement and government-commissioned ECFA assessment reports.

But Lo said the request by the DPP for more information before a scheduled TV debate between Ma and Tsai April 25 was unwarranted, saying that all of the information has appeared in previous policy presentations and is open to everybody.
President Ma has instructed the Mainland Affairs Council and the Ministry of Economic Affairs to provide the information.

On the DPP's request for information on the ongoing negotiations, Lo said that Tsai, as an experienced negotiator, "should know that if information from an ongoing negotiation is recklessly made public, the damage to the negotiating process will be great."

DOC.HEADLINE: Boiling live chickens legal: official
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, April 9 (CNA) 04/09/10 19:36:06 (By Yang Shu-min and Elizabeth Hsu)

TEXT.P: Workers at restaurants, seafood stores or certified traditional markets may kill fowl or fish by placing them in boiling water, but do so as part of a public performance is illegal, a Council of Agriculture official said Thursday.

Animal Industry Department Director Hsu Kuei-sen made the remarks in response to questions about a hotel in Taipei County that was fined NT$100,000 (US$3,170) after a chef from China gave a demonstration called "stewing a chicken in three minutes" at a promotional event March 21.
The chef, Zhang Xiaochun, killed the chicken by placing it in boiling water before plucking it and continuing the cooking process.
The performance drew protests from the Environment and Animal Society of Taiwan, which denounced the killing as animal abuse.

The county government fined the hotel for violating the Animal Industry Act, which stipulates that slaughtering can only be performed at certified slaughterhouses, traditional markets or private homes.
Tsai Kuang-jung, director of the county's Agriculture Bureau, told reporters that the public killing showed no respect for life.
The Environment and Animal Society of Taiwan said the case raises questions about whether cooking live fish at seafood restaurants also violates the law.
In response to the disputes, Hsu said the hotel was punished because it conducted the slaughter at a public show.
Hsu added that while humans may not be able to get rid of the habit of eating meat, it is better to cook in "a humane way" to show respect for life.

DOC.HEADLINE: Most recalled dehumidifiers not returned: official
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, April 9 (CNA) 04/09/10 20:00:11 (By Lin Su-yuan and Y.L. Kao)

TEXT.P: Up to 120,000 defective dehumidifiers produced between 2003 and 2006 have not been returned since a recall was announced in 2007, Taiwan's top product certification body said at a press conference Friday.

Following a recent fire suspected to have been caused by a faulty dehumidifier, the Bureau of Standards, Metrology and Inspection (BSMI) and dehumidifier manufacturers and distributors urged the public to check product model numbers and immediately stop using recalled appliances.
Owners of recalled dehumidifiers were told to contact the service offices of product providers for repair or replacement.

BSMI Deputy Director-General Huang Lai-ho said a recall was issued for some 210,000 defective dehumidifiers, including 27 models and nine brands: Tatung, Sanyo, Sampo, Teco, Westinghouse, Gibson, Frigidaire, Kolin and Whirlpool. Only 41.6 percent of the products have been returned, Huang said.
Huang said that more details about brands, model numbers and production dates of the defective products are available online at www.bsmi.gov.tw.
Over the past 21 months, 83 accidents related to defective dehumidifiers were reported, Huang added.

DOC.HEADLINE: 3D TV draws mixed views at Taipei computer show
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, April 9 (CNA) 04/09/10 20:08:14 (By Alex Jiang)

TEXT.P: Televisions featuring 3D technology drew a mixed response from visitors at a computer show in Taipei Friday as experts considered a lack of content to be one of the major barriers to the devices' popularity.
Softex Taipei, which opened Thursday and runs until April 12, features a wide variety of electronics products, including smartphones, LED monitors, e-readers and digital cameras.
Visitors lined up to see the latest in 3D technology for TVs, with Samsung showcasing its first 3D LED TV, which will soon be available in Taiwan.
"It is the first time consumers in Taiwan have seen the Samsung C7000 3D LED TV, which is due to hit the local market in early May, " the South Korean company said in a press statement.
"More than 500 people gave a positive response to Samsung's 3D TV on the first day of the show," said Mandy Kao of Samsung.
To cope with the lack of 3D content, Samsung provides a technology that allows viewers to experience a simulated 3D effect on its 3D TV when watching a 2D film, she added.
Sony Taiwan set up a showroom in which visitors could wear 3D glasses while watching a U.S. animated film. Sony is scheduled to release its 3D TV in Taiwan in June.
However, several people were dissatisfied with their viewing experience.
A group of students told CNA that the 3D effect was not as good as they had expected.
"It made me a bit dizzy," a girl said.
Another visitor, a middle-aged man surnamed Chen, complained that the images are "shaky."
"I also felt a sense of oppressiveness," he added.
Taking into consideration the quality and the price, which is much higher than that of a traditional TV, Chen said he would not buy a 3D TV at the moment.
"If you buy a 3D TV, what are you going to watch on it? There are very few 3D movies, " said Danny Yao, managing director of BenQ Taiwan.
Kevin Fang, a senior executive at LG Electronics Taiwan, agreed that there is a lack of content and that the 3D TVs are impractical.
"Right now, these companies seem to be demonstrating that they are capable of developing 3D technology," he said.

DOC.HEADLINE: DOH urged to improve health insurance financial management
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, April 9 (CNA) 04/09/10 20:09:47 (By Yang Shu-min and Sofia Wu)

TEXT.P: The Department of Health (DOH) should improve its financial management of the national health insurance program to keep the system afloat and save taxpayers money, the Consumers' Foundation said Friday.

The foundation made the appeal a day after the Executive Yuan passed a package of draft amendments to the National Health Insurance Act that will pave the way for a second-generation health insurance program, which is expected to be in place by 2012 at the earliest.

Speaking at a news conference, Consumers Foundation Chairman Hsieh Tien-jen said the DOH's Bureau of National Health Insurance (BNHI) needed to improve its financial management, which he said partly accounted for the system's NT$58.8 billion (US$1.86 billion) accumulated deficit as of the end of 2009.
Hsieh took particular aim at the simplified form used by health care institutions to claim reimbursements for drug expenses, which he called a "black hole."
He advocated scrapping the simplified form, which exempts clinics and hospitals from itemizing claims for prescription drugs if the unit price of the drug falls below a specified amount.
Previously, the amount was set at NT$25 but was cut to NT$22 at the end of March. The BNHI said the reduction will bring down its annual drug reimbursement by an estimated NT$1.2 billion.
Hsieh said, however, that such a reduction was too limited to be acceptable because according to information provided by state-run hospitals, the actual cost for many drugs is only about NT$7 apiece.

That means that an annual "black hole" of NT$7.2 billion could exist in the drug reimbursement system, he said, figuring that if an NT$3 drop in the unit price needed to itemize costs could save NT$1.2 billion, then an NT$18 drop from NT$25 to NT$7 could save NT$7.2 billion.

Hsieh argued that despite the recent adjustment, an unplugged "black hole" of NT$6 billion still remained, and he urged the bureau to end the practice of allowing non-itemized claims for the reimbursement of drug expenses.

He also urged the bureau to improve the function of the health system's IC cards to prevent patients from securing the same medications at different health care facilities for the same health condition.
Hsieh contended that it would be extremely unfair if the bureau failed to do its best to prevent the waste of medical resources at a time when it is raising health premium rates.

To temporarily cover the health insurance system's deficit before the second generation program takes effect, the DOH recent raised health insurance premium rates from the previous 4.55 percent to 5.17 percent, effective April 1.
But only those whose earnings base on which premiums are calculated exceeds NT$40,100 per month will actually pay more. The government plans to subsidize the hikes of lower income individuals.

DOC.HEADLINE: Taiwan's national teams sweep Asian Tug-of-War Championships
DOC.DATELINE: Seoul, April 9 (CNA) 04/09/10 20:26:21 (By Y.L. Kao)

TEXT.P: Taiwan's national women's and men's teams won the gold medals in their respective divisions at the 8th Asian Tug-of-War Championships in South Korea Friday.
The women's team, composed of students from Taipei Jingmei Girls High School, took the championship after defeating Vietnam in the semifinals and Mongolia in the final.
The Taipei Jingmei Girls High School team also won the 2010 World Indoor Championships in Italy in February.
The men's team, composed of athletes from Chiao Tai High School and Asia University, Taiwan, won in its division after reaching the final four and shutting out South Korea and Japan.
President Ma Ying-jeou, Vice President Vincent Siew and Premier Wu Den-yih all sent messages of congratulations to the teams.

On Thursday, three Taiwanese senior high schools -- National Nantou Senior High School, Taichung County Dali Senior High School, and Nuan Nuan Senior High School in Keelung -- swept the male, female and mixed events of the Asian Tug- of-War Open Club competition, a lesser event that opened the two-day championships.

DOC.HEADLINE: NTU announces breakthrough in using MRIs to detect tumors
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, April 9 (CNA) 04/09/10 22:02:07 (By S. Y. Lin and Flor Wang)

TEXT.P: National Taiwan University (NTU) announced Friday that it has developed a method that will enhance the ability of magnetic resonance imaging (MRI) devices to accurately detect tumors and identify them a week earlier than would be possible through a traditional approach.

Speaking at a news conference to unveil the finding, Dennis W. Hwang, an assistant professor at National Chung Cheng University who took part in the study, said the NTU team and its collaborators optimized MRI tumor contrast enhancement by improving "active feedback" techniques.
According to Hwang, the techniques make it easier for doctors to detect the difference between smaller and larger objects and possibly better differentiate between lesions and surrounding tissues.
In their experiments, Hwang said, this imaging method helped doctors more precisely and more quickly detect tumors in mice that were injected with cells of malignant tumors from humans.

MRIs produce a signal that can be detected by the scanner based on the difference in energy between when the electromagnetic field in the device is turned on and turned off. Normally, however, the images can lack clarity because of the decay of the signals.

Hwang's team used an active feedback enhanced MRI technique that limited the decay by manipulating the sound signals and bouncing them off each other to amplify them to a contrast four times sharper than using traditional methods.
The technique permitted doctors to precisely determine the size and location of a two millimeter cancerous tumor that had grown in a mouse in one week, Hwang said.
If the technique can be used on humans, Hwang said it could dramatically reduce examination fees for cancer patients. enditem/ls @ @

DOC.HEADLINE: Health minister not opposed to 'revolving door' clause
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, April 9 (CNA) 04/09/10 22:08:53 (By Yang Shu-min and Sofia Wu)

TEXT.P: The Department of Health (DOH) will not oppose amending the law to prevent its senior staff from taking jobs at pharmaceutical plants or medical institutions within a specified period after retirement, an official said Friday.

DOH Minister Yaung Chih-liang made the remarks in response to an appeal by the Consumers' Foundation earlier in the day that a "revolving door" clause be introduced to block senior DOH officials from taking positions at health care- related institutions within three years following their retirement from public services.

Speaking at a news conference, Consumers' Foundation Chairman Hsieh Tien-jen said a lot of DOH officials have taken up important positions at medical institutions or pharmaceutical companies shortly after stepping down from department posts.
Among them are two former DOH ministers, Hou Sheng-mao and Lin Fang-yu, who now head Shin Kong Wu Ho-Su Memorial Hospital and Taipei Veterans General Hospital, respectively.
Hsieh said that such moves could cause concern that they may illegitimately or improperly benefit from their new posts due to their links with the DOH.
In response, Yaung said current law does not have any regulations governing the post-retirement career choices of DOH officials.
"If necessary, I would not oppose revising the law to impose some career restrictions on retired DOH officials to stem speculation or public misgiving," he said.

DOC.HEADLINE: Pension system paid out NT$37.7 billion last year: DGBAS
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, April 9 (CNA) 04/09/10 22:48:30 (By Hsieh Chun-wei & Bear Lee)

TEXT.P: Nearly 1.03 million of the insured received a total of NT$37.7 billion in payments from the national pension system in 2009, the Directorate General of Budget, Accounting and Statistics (DGBAS) said Friday.

More than 4.01 million of Taiwan's population are now covered by the system inaugurated on Oct. 10, 2008 for those aged between 25 and 65 and not covered by public functionary insurance, labor insurance or any other public-sponsored insurance scheme, the DGBAS said.

The government opened the service as part of its national welfare net with the insured, who pay 60 percent of premiums, entitled to receive pensions depending on how long they have been covered when they turn 65.

DOC.HEADLINE: Control Yuan takes pension fund management to task
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, April 9 (CNA) 04/09/10 22:54:57 (By Sophia Yeh and Lilian Wu)

TEXT.P: The management of the Public Service Pension Fund is not transparent and its risk control is lax, according to an investigation conducted by the Control Yuan, which is in charge of monitoring the behavior of government officials.

In a report on the investigation presented Friday, the Control Yuan said the fund, which manages the pensions of nearly 700,000 military personnel, civil servants and teachers in the nation, lost more than NT$86 billion due to the global financial crisis in 2008.
The Control Yuan therefore conducted an investigation after public misgivings over the safety of the fund's investments.
Control Yuan member Chao Chang-ping said that between 1999 and 2008, the fund's portfolio had an average rate of return of minus 4.58 percent and lost more than NT$48.7 billion.

The rate was lower than that of Taiwan's weighted stock index average return of a negative 0.92 percent and far lower than the average rate of return of 2.5 percent had the money been kept in a time deposit over the same period, Chao said.

He said the fund management board was trying to rationalize its poor performance over the long-term by citing the global financial crisis, which he instead described as a "failure to fulfill its duty of professional investment and management."

Also, the public often wonders if the government is "propping up stock prices or dumping stocks" on the stock market if the fund buys or sells stocks, but Chao said that "propping up sagging stocks" is not the mission of the pension fund.

If the fund can formulate a "take-profit point" or "stop-loss point" quantitative assessment, where specific targets for cutting losses or locking in profits are set, it would help dispel speculation about improper intervention of the fund management board, Chao said.

Meanwhile, Tsai Feng-ching, deputy chairman of the fund management board, said Friday that regulations of the fund have followed set procedures, and that the rate of return of 19.5 percent in 2009 was the highest ever.

He also dismissed allegations that the fund was operated privately without supervision in a "secret room, " saying it was just an ordinary room set up to trade stocks located on the third floor of the Examination Yuan building.
The Control Yuan has questioned two former chairmen of the fund management board -- Chu Wu-shien and Chang Che-shen.
The report said that Chu had intervened too deeply in the fund's investments and set up professional equipment on his office desk, which was improper.

Chu, the former head of the Ministry of Civil Service, contended that he set up the equipment because he was in charge of the management of the fund and that he needed to pay attention to it from time to time.

DOC.HEADLINE: Stock stabilization fund racks up handsome profits
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, April 9 (CNA) 04/09/10 23:02:34 (By I. F. Lin and Flor Wang)

TEXT.P: The National Stabilization Fund earned around NT$25 billion (US$792 million) in selling off NT$62 billion in shares on Taiwan's stock market between March 1 and April 9, a financial official said Friday.

According to the official, who met reporters after a regular meeting of the fund, the fund racked up NT$21.5 billion in profits in March alone after sales of shares valued at NT$52 billion. It was the fund's best performance in any single month in its history.
During the month-long period, the weighted index, the local bourse's key indicator, surged to 7,920 from 7,577, he noted. The weighted index closed at 8,092 on Friday.

The National Stabilization Fund still holds NT$31.1 billion worth in local shares, with NT$11.1 billion in unrealized profits, the official said, adding that the fund would sell more shares without affecting the stock market as the economy regained some momentum.
The government-run fund bought as much as NT$59.9 billion in shares in September 2009 to stabilize Taiwan's stock exchange after the global financial crisis erupted.
The fund has gradually sold the shares it held since the beginning of this year as the economy improves.
The fund was established to stabilize volatility in local share prices created by external factors, but its transactions can also lead to fluctuations in stock prices.

DOC.HEADLINE: New private investment in Q1 totals NT$386 billion
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, April 9 (CNA) 04/09/10 23:09:14 (by Lin shu-yuan & Bear Lee)

TEXT.P: Taiwan's private investment totaled NT$386 billion (US$ 12.2 billion) in the first quarter of the year, the Ministry of Economic Affairs said Friday.

The amount was 37.57 percent of the private investment target of NT$1.272 trillion (US$43.1 billion) set for the whole of 2010 and bodes well for Taiwan's ability to move further away from the shadows cast by the 2008-2009 global financial crisis, the ministry said.
Noteworthy among all industries was the green energy sector, which attracted investment worth NT$41.8 billion, amounting to 78 percent of the 2010 target, it added.

The government was also on pace to meet its target of having Taiwanese businesses operating in China and other parts of the world invest NT$38 billion back in their home country in 2010, after such enterprises injected NT$9.5 billion into Taiwan in the first three months of the year, the ministry said.

DOC.HEADLINE: 'ASEAN Plus One' impacts Taiwan's exports: minister
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, April 9 (CNA) 04/09/10 23:15:23 (By Hsieh Chia-chen and Y.L. Kao)

TEXT.P: A free trade area formed between China and the Association of Southeast Asian Nations (ASEAN) that was inaugurated Jan. 1 this year has affected Taiwan's exports, Minister without Portfolio Yiin Chi-min said in a statement released Friday.

Yiin was dismissing a report in the Chinese-language Liberty Times newspaper that said Taiwan's exports to China and ASEAN did not suffer because of ASEAN plus one after first-quarter exports to the trade area were the second highest ever recorded for the same period.

The ASEAN plus China free trade framework agreement was signed in 2002 and contains an "early harvest" list of products and services for tariff concessions. In 2004, ASEAN and China signed a further agreement on trade in goods.
The tariff reduction process under the FTA was initiated on a full scale long before the agreement became effective, Yiin noted.

As an example, Yiin said that Taiwan's shipments to the 10 ASEAN states doubled between 2001 and 2009, lagging behind Singapore's 1.5-times growth and China's 4.7-times. "How can it be said that the 'ASEAN Plus One' has not affected Taiwan's exports? " Yiin asked.
It's unreliable to draw a conclusion based merely on Q1 export figures, Yiin said.
Yiin also pointed out that Q1 exports to the six major ASEAN states did not return to the 2008 level and exports to China barely reached the 2008 level.

DOC.HEADLINE: Shanghai mayor concludes Taiwan visit
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, April 9 (CNA) 04/09/10 23:33:59 (By Carol Yeh, Kuo Mei-lan and Lilian Wu)

TEXT.P: Shanghai Mayor Han Zheng concluded his four-day visit of Taiwan Friday, saying that Taiwan was beautiful and that he was deeply impressed by the hospitality of Taiwan's people.

Falun Gong protesters tried to get Han's attention as he arrived at Taiwan Taoyuan International Airport, but he may not have noticed them because he was surrounded by a heavy contingent of media workers.
Taoyuan County Magistrate Wu Chih-yang and Taipei Deputy Mayor Lee Yong-ping saw Han and his delegation off. Lee joked to Han that he had received "star-like treatment" during his stay in Taiwan.

Yang Hsiao-tung, head of the Research, Development and Evaluation Commission of the Taipei City government, presented Han with an album of newspaper clippings and a DVD covering his delegation's visit in Taiwan.

Han spent his last day in Taichung, where he visited an area where kitchen leftovers were being recycled before going to Taoyuan, where he was briefed by Magistrate Wu on an aviation city and Hakka Cultural Village.
Wu told Han that the production value of Taoyuan science technology has surpassed that of the Hsinchu Science Park.
Han also visited the R&D center of the cloud computing service of high-tech electronics manufacturer Inventec Corporation.
The Inventec group has invested over US$400 million in Pudong Park in Shanghai.

Han was invited by the Taipei City government to attend a Taipei-Shanghai forum, during which he signed four memorandums of understanding to boost cooperation between the two cities in the fields of culture, tourism, environmental conservation and science and technology.
Han and his entourage have had a tight schedule of meetings with Taiwanese politicians and business leaders while promoting the 2010 World Expo, which will kick off on May 1.

DOC.HEADLINE: Today in history
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, April 10 (CNA) 04/10/10 10:24:00
DOC.TEXT:
Today is Saturday, April 10, 2010, or the 26th day of the second month of the Year of the Tiger according to the lunar calendar. Following is a list of important events that have occurred on this date in the past:
1512: James V of Scotland, who became king at the age of 17 months, is born. He allied Scotland with France against the English.
1810: Pirate chieftainess "Dragon Lady" Cheng Yi-sao surrenders herself and the 1,800 junks under her command to China's Ching court.
1814: British and Spanish forces defeat Napoleon's army at the Battle of Toulouse, leading to his abdication and exile to the island of Elba the next day.
1829: William Booth, the British religious leader who founded the Salvation Army with his wife Catherine Mumford Booth and who served as its first general, is born.
1847: Hungarian-born American journalist Joseph Pulitzer is born. The newspaper publisher owned newspapers in St. Louis and New York City and established and endowed the Pulitzer Prizes for achievements in journalism and literature.
1858: Chinese Governor-General Ye Ming-chen of Canton and a prisoner of Britain, dies in Calcutta during an Anglo-French expedition against Beijing in 1858.
1898: France obtains concessions from China's Ching court.
1921: Dr. Sun Yat-sen is elected president of the Republic of China.
1932: German general and politician Paul von Hindenburg is re-elected president of the Weimar Republic with 19 million votes to Adolf Hitler's 13 million. He appoints Hitler chancellor in 1933.
1938: More than 99 percent of Austrian voters in a referendum cast their ballots in favor of a merger with Germany.
1944: Brigadier General Charles de Gaulle, who is number one on the hit list of the collaborationist Vichy government of Marshal Petain, becomes commander- in-chief of all the Free French forces.
1946: Japan holds general elections with women voting for the first time.
1953: The ROC Executive Yuan approves the resignation of Taiwan Governor Wu Kuo-chen and names Yu Hung-chun as his replacement.
1958: Dr. Hu Shih assumes office as president of the ROC's Academia Sinica.
1960: The U.S. Senate passes the Civil Rights Bill.
1963: The USS Thresher, an American atomic submarine, sinks in the northern Atlantic, killing all 290 aboard.
1971: Ethnic Chinese hold a mass rally in Washington, D.C., to show their support for the protection of a disputed territory known to the Chinese as the Tiaoyutai Islands.
1972: The ROC Ministry of Foreign Affairs announces the establishment of diplomatic relations with the Kingdom of Tonga.
1972: The United States and the Soviet Union sign a treaty banning biological warfare.
1976: Miguel Urrutia Montoya, director of the national planning department of the Republic of Colombia, arrives in Taipei for a week-long visit.
1979: U.S. President Jimmy Carter signs legislation permitting continued commercial and cultural relations between the American government and the ROC following the break in their diplomatic ties.
1980: Mainland China and the Soviet Union end a friendship pact they signed in 1950.
1983: U.S. President Ronald Reagan's Middle East peace plan collapses when King Hussein of Jordan fails to reach an accord with the Palestine Liberation Organization on the terms of the deal.
1986: The United States conducts a nuclear test in the Nevada desert.
1991: Georgia becomes the latest of the Soviet republics wishing to break away from central control.
1996: Mainland Chinese Premier Li Peng's visit to France is marred by a diplomatic wrangle with his French counterpart Alain Juppe over human rights in Beijing.
2000: Republic of China President Lee Teng-hui confers the Order of Brilliant Star with Grand Cordon on David Dean, former Taipei director of the American Institute in Taiwan.
2001: The 13th annual convention of the Overseas Chinese Council in Asia opens in Osaka, Japan, with more than 400 delegates from the Asia-Pacific region participating.
2002: Vice President Annette Lu wins a civil suit against the Taipei-based Journalist weekly, for damage to her image arising from a false report carried by the magazine.
Confucius' lesson of the day: "A man who possesses moral worth will always have something to say worth listening to, but a man who has something to say is not necessarily a man of moral worth."
