DOC.HEADLINE: China Times: Don't be afraid of giving ECFA information
DOC.DATELINE: 04/10/10 12:55:20 (ECFA) with China, opposition Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) (By Y.F. Low)

TEXT.P: In preparation for the April 25 debate with President Ma Ying-jeou on the proposed economic cooperation framework agreement Chairperson Tsai Ing-wen recently requested access to relevant information, including the early harvest list proposed by the government, the draft of the agreement, and government- commissioned ECFA assessment reports.
The request, however, was rejected by the Presidential Office.
As a matter of fact, the Presidential Office, or the ruling Kuomintang, committed a major strategic mistake: being too attentive to debate details and being too concerned with its results.

The Presidential Office probably failed to realize that the upcoming debate is not one between two presidential candidates, but one between the president and an opposition leader. As the president, he cannot monopolize national policy to his advantage. With such an attitude, he may win the debate, but lose the ECFA battle.
After resisting exchanges with China for a long time, the DPP finally is trying to understand the ECFA policy.
The government should generously provide the DPP with the necessary information and see this as a rare opportunity for communication. (April 10, 2010)

DOC.HEADLINE: Talk of the day -- Taiwan's Susan Boyle

TEXT.P: A 24-year-old Taiwanese man, Lin Yu-chun, became a hit on the Internet and conquered the hearts of a big audience with his unique voice after a video showing him singing Whitney Houston's famous song "I Will Always Love You" was posted on YouTube.
Lin's performance on a local talent show "Million Star" was first posted on YouTube April 6 and he has since become an overnight celebrity on the Web.

The three major U.S. television networks introduced him as "Taiwan's Susan Boyle." Invited by several TV stations in the U.S. and Japan to take part in their programs, Lin has decided to head for the U.S. and have an interview with comedian George Lopez on his program "Tonight Show."
The following are excerpts from local media coverage of the issue:
China Times:

Lin, who has never been to the U.S., exclaimed: "Oh, my god, It's just like a dream come true." "I feel that I have been stricken by lightening, and I want to kneel down and thank the person who posted my video on the Internet," he said.

Lin became famous around the world overnight. Requests for interviews from local and foreign media came one after another the very next day. Some paparazzi even waited for him at the door of his home.
"I keep telling myself 'calm down' and take it as 'business as usual, '" he said when asked whether he is afraid of being a flash in the pan.
In view of some criticism against him, Lin said he can still handle it as he has taken criticisms so many times in singing competitions since he was a child, despite objections from his father.
"I'll give my future to my agent," he said.
"Fatty (Lin's nickname) will not show up in Taiwan's TV programs, and we will first market him on the international stage, " his agent said.
"If Susan Boyle and Paul Potts could become so popular, why not Lin, " the agent said, adding that "we will make him a phenomenon when he stages a comeback in Taiwan." (April 10, 2010)
United Daily News:

Lin Yu-chun, dubbed "Taiwan's version of Susan Boyle, " lost the most recent race in the "Million Star" program broadcast on April 9 by a Taiwanese TV station. But he has only found increased interests from foreign media in him. A program of Japan's Fuji Television Network reportedly will send a host to interview him in Taiwan.
"We have been contacting several companies in a bid to find someone to release an album for him," his agent said.
Lin, a graduate from a university in Taoyuan, now works as a part-timer at a store that sells musical instruments. Although he has fast surged to fame, he only earns NT$15,000 (US$470) a month.
Jacky Wu, a popular entertainer in Taiwan, said he does not believe that Lin will maintain his current popularity for long.
"His voice is exceptional and arouse widespread public interest in him but his looks are ordinary, " Wu contended. "It is not easy to survive in show business." (April 10, 2010)

DOC.HEADLINE: Opinions differ on what metaphors to use for cross-Strait relations
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, April 10 (CNA) 04/10/10 14:38:17 (By Chris Wang)

TEXT.P: While Chinese Premier Wen Jiabao has depicted Taiwan-China relations as a "brotherhood" in his recent speech, Taiwanese academics and politicians have also offered their own metaphors for relations across the Taiwan Strait, which academia said would dictate the future cross-Strait development roadmap.
Wen used the term "brotherhood" to describe cross-Strait relations as early as 2008 and did the same again in the closing press conference of China's National People's Congress last month.

Frederick Chien, a senior diplomat who is leading a 39-member Taiwan delegation to the ongoing Boao Forum for Asia (BFA) in the resort town Boao of China's southern Hainan province, echoed the same idea.
"Both sides (Taiwan and China) should be brothers, not enemies, " Chien told the media in Boao, where he is scheduled to meet with Chinese Vice President Xi Jinping Saturday.

Meanwhile, President Ma Ying-jeou responded to Wen's comment by sidestepping the term "brotherhood" and saying that both sides of the strait "belong to one Chinese nation and are both Chinese people."

As a political and cultural metaphor, brotherhood in Chinese means that both sides come from the same family, maintain close and friendly relations, will help each other and often share the same values.
Taiwan academia raised similar discussions in a recent forum on cross-Strait relations in which scholars presented different interpretations of their own.
The metaphorical interpretation of cross-strait relations is important, they agreed, because it would reveal and dictate the Taiwanese government's China policy.
Chang Ya-chung, a political scientist at National Taiwan University, agreed with the "brotherhood" description and said that "relations of brotherhood can be uneven, but must be equal."
In comparison, he described China-Hong Kong relations as "father and son" and interpreted cross-strait relations in President Ma's "Chinese people theory" as "cousins."

Chang advocates a "One China, Three Constitutions" theory which calls for eventual cross-strait integration. Wen's comment, he said, was like "an opportunity of a lifetime" to promote integration as "China's interior affairs."
The pro-independence opposition Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) always views cross-strait relations as relations between "friends" or "neighbors, " Chang said.

Even some of the heavyweight Taiwan independence supporters accepted the "brotherhood" theory, such as former presidential advisor Koo Kuan-min, who has voiced support for the idea and said that it would be fine if China views itself as the big brother, but then it has to look after the kid brother -- Taiwan.

Political scientist Tang Shao-cheng argued that the brotherhood theory will be difficult to carry out because no one knows who is going to be the big brother. The neighborhood theory, he added, is more practical.

Huang Guangguo, a professor at National Taiwan University, brought up an idea submitted by Chinese academia that described Taiwan and China as different halves of a planet in a political solar system, in which every planet was seen as a country.

The brotherhood theory could result in misunderstanding for foreign countries, said Gunter Schubert, a visiting research fellow of Academia Sinica's Institute of Sociology who came from the University of Turbingen, Germany.

The (brotherhood) theory suggests that it is a family matter unrelated to the outside world, Schubert said, adding that it would be better to promote integration from the stand point of "friends" so that it's easier for foreigners to understand.
The neighborhood theory basically means Taiwan and China are unrelated entities, which marks the regression of Taiwan-China relations and is exactly what the DPP wants, Chang said.

In terms of cross-strait relations, it's obvious that the most important phenomenon at present is the lack of trust between the two sides, Ho Szu-shen, a professor at Fu Jen Catholic University, observed.
"Without trust, any theory wouldn't work, " he said.

Joseph Wu, a political scientist at National Chengchi University who served during the DPP administration as chairman of the Mainland Affairs Council (MAC) -- Taiwan's top China policy-making body -- and Taiwan's representative to the United States, said that regardless of theories, it's important to consider the possibility of the DPP returning to power.
American and Japanese authorities and academia have both urged the DPP to review and revise its party platform and resolution, which contains support for Taiwan independence, Wu said.

While the DPP always calls for a peaceful co-existence with China and is believed to respect all the documents and agreements signed during the ruling Kuomintang (KMT) administration once it returns to power, it's not likely to accept the "One China Principle" and the "1992 consensus, " he said.

DOC.HEADLINE: Regional forum helps boost cross-strait exchanges: Taiwanese banker
DOC.DATELINE: Boao, China, April 10 (CNA) 04/10/10 14:56:17 (By He Hsiu-ru, Tang Pei-chun and Elizabeth Hsu)

TEXT.P: As heads of the delegations from the two sides of the Taiwan Strait attending the Boao Forum for Asia 2010 prepared to meet Saturday, Taiwanese delegate Chiu Cheng-hsiung said the meeting helps future exchanges between the two sides.

Chiu, chairman of the Taiwan-based Bank SinoPac, previously served as a vice premier in President Ma Ying-jeou's administration. He told CNA before attending the forum's opening ceremony that day that it is a good place for the two sides to get to know each other better and to exchange opinions.

The Taiwanese delegation is led by Fredrick Chien, a former president of the Control Yuan, and is composed of members of banking companies and financial institutes. The group's presence is expected to help boost cross-strait banking exchanges.

Chiu said the two sides will discuss financial exchanges in detail during talks on a proposed cross-strait economic cooperation framework agreement. "No matter what the results might be, it will be better for cross-strait financial exchanges," he said.

He noted that Taiwan is overflowing with funds that should be properly led to overseas markets such as China. Taiwan could provide loans to Taiwanese businesses there through credit rating and credit checks, he suggested
Taiwan's financial sector, which is experienced in supporting small- and medium- sized enterprises, could also lend its experience in this area to China, Chiu added.
Chiu was also expected to attend a meeting later that day between Chien and Chinese Vice President Xi Jinping, who is heading the Chinese delegation at the forum.

Other Taiwanese delegates who are to attend the meeting include Cathay Financial Holdings Chairman Tsai Hong-tu, Fubon Financial Holdings Chairman Daniel Tsai, and Schive Shih, chairman of the Taiwan Stock Exchange.
The Boao Forum, founded in 2001 by Australia and 25 Asian states, has held its annual meeting in Boao since 2002 to promote high-level dialogue on regional issues.
The theme of this year's three-day meeting is "Green Recovery: Asia's Realistic Choice for Sustainable Growth."

DOC.HEADLINE: Commercial Times: Remove the political veil over ECFA

TEXT.P: In an upcoming debate between President Ma Ying-jeou and opposition Democratic Progressive Party Chairperson Tsai Ing-wen on the proposed economic cooperation framework agreement (ECFA) , they will have the responsibility of pulling the politicized issue back to the economic sphere where it belongs.
Here are some suggestions for the two leaders.
First, they should avoid making their value judgments absolute because the advantages and disadvantages of the future ECFA will be relative, not absolute.

Second, they should discuss more about medium- and long-term plans and tell the people how the ECFA will relate to Taiwan's medium- and long-term development. It will be necessary for Ma, who advocates the agreement, to explain in detail what substantive measures his administration will take after the pact is signed, and what their expected effects will be.

Third, they should dissociate the ECFA issue from the year-end mayoral elections in the five special municipalities. Under pressure over the elections, both the blue and green camps are keen on manipulating the ECFA issue to their advantage. This has been one of the main reasons why the simple issue has been politicized and has lost its focus.

If the ECFA issue is restored to its original state, we will discover something forgotten: the ECFA is economic in nature, mutually beneficial to both sides of the Taiwan Strait, and related to the World Trade Organization.
Taiwan should avoid the disadvantages and try to maximize the benefits. It must not miss an opportunity for development because of a fight over whether the ECFA is "black or white."

DOC.HEADLINE: Invitations for `Taiwan's Susan Boyle' keep flowing in
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, April 10 (CNA) 04/10/10 15:57:48 (By Huang Hui-min and Lilian Wu)

TEXT.P: Invitations for Lin Yu-chun, a local talent show winner who has been described as "Taiwan's Susan Boyle" -- a British KTV singer who achieved celebrity after winning a British talent show -- have been flooding in from Japan, the United States and South Korea, the staff of a local talent training school said Saturday.
A-List Entertainment, a company that produces top singers, stars, models and entertainers, said they had been inundated by calls looking for Lin.
The invitations included those from three major U.S. TV groups, asking for interviews and performances from Lin.
Lin became an Internet hit after his performance of "I Will Always Love You" on local talent show " Million Star" was posted on YouTube April 6.
Before his overnight celebrity, however, the 24-year-old Lin endured slights for four years, according to his mentor Hsu Nai-chung, better known by his nickname "Blue."
In 2006, both Lin and Blue's daughter took part in a music competition, winning in the creative and singing categories, respectively.
They later signed a six-year contract with an agency, which is how Blue, who is also president of the Pure Music company, got to know Lin.
Blue saw Lin's potential and thought his ability to sing in a girlish falsetto, as well as his fleshy and baby-faced appearance, made him stand out.
Blue therefore coached Lin, hoping to lead him on the path to being a professional singer.

Under Blue's encouragement, Lin took part in several local TV talent shows, but failed to draw attention. In addition, his agency failed to support him and poured cold water on his desire to take part in TV talent shows.
Lin finally terminated his contract with the agency last year and enrolled in A-List Entertainment last October.
His rendering of Whitney Houston's song "I Will Always Love You" has spread fast across the Internet, enabling him to taste the sweetness of success for the first time.

Listening to Lin sing another Houston's signature song, "Saving All My Love for You," some people might get the idea why he is called the "male Whitney Houston, " with his "near exact" rendition of the Houston original.
Blue said Lin might sound like a sissy, but pointed out that this is perfect for his singing style.
According to Blue, Lin's voice is also ideal for one of the greatest jazz singers of all time -- Ella Fitzgerald.
He said he also plans to nurture Lin as a "creative" singer.

Lin, who is 171-cm and weights 110 kg, said that he has been called "fat" since his childhood and that he used to care very much about his obesity, but now " I can live and be happy with my appearance."

DOC.HEADLINE: Late Italian priest's cultural legacy still felt in Hakka community

TEXT.P: When James Hsu, a young Hakka man from Pingtung County, was performing his alternative military service in Hsinchu County by helping to renovate a church seven years ago, little did he know that his entire existence would be reshaped by the late priest who created it.

It was working on the church -- built by the late Italian Jesuit missionary Guerrino Marsecano in 1965 -- that he learned of a unique book, a 627-page English-Hakka dictionary compiled by Marsecano and a group of editors, that left him full of admiration.

"Even Hakka people might not have been able to put together such a great dictionary, " marvels Hsu, who said it even went as far as listing different Hakka pronunciations for the same word to reflect linguistic differences within the various Hakka communities in Taiwan.

Hsu's passion for a man he never met -- Marsecano died in 2000 -- is indicative of the power of the Jesuit priest's legacy among the Hakka people, one that remains especially evident in Hukou Township, where the church is a major landmark and tourist draw.

The church, which boasts exotic architecture manifesting the influence of the Italian priest, is located at the entrance of the Hukou Old Street -- one of the must-see attractions in the traditionally Hakka community.

The church site had historical significance even before Marsecano appeared on the scene. It housed the Da Hukou railway station on Taiwan's first railway line, a 106.7-km line connecting Keelung and Hsinchu that was built in 1885.
But the station was abandoned in 1929 by the Japanese who then colonized the island because its location on a hillside made it difficult for steam locomotives to reach.

After the church was built in 1965, it was home to religious services for nearly three decades, with Marsecano delivering Mass in Hakka there in its early years before he was transferred to another parish in Hsinchu County's Guansi Township.
The church gradually lost its pull, however, and was forced to shut down in 1993 because of the declining congregation and number of children attending the church-affiliated kindergarten.

In 2001, the residents decided to renovate the church as part of a project to revive the 300 meter-long Old Street, lined with two-story Minnan-style red brick houses noteworthy for their baroque porches.

The church was converted into a center for local art and culture and an exhibition hall featuring Catholic missionary history in the Hsinchu area, where the English-Hakka dictionary, a prime example of the Italian priest's dedication, is displayed.
Published in 1959 by Kuangchi Press (now called Kuangchi Cultural Group) , it contains the Hakka equivalents for 13,721 English words and 20,000 English phrases.

Father Wang Wen-lin, director of the Old Hukou Church Museum, said the "great book" had actually been forgotten for a long time until he and other community residents recovered it from dusty relics left behind in the church as they were cleaning it before it was renovated.
He was thankful the volume was found, and he praised Marsecano's immersion into Hakka culture.
"When a foreigner knows the Hakka dialect so deeply, it means that the person has treated Hakka villages as his home, " Wang said.
Touched by the Italian missionary's devotion to fitting into the Hakka way of life, Hsu was inspired by the church and the dictionary to learn more about the priest.

Marsecano, born in 1915 in Ferentino in the Italian province of Frosinone, came to Taiwan in 1955 from the Philippines. He had been stationed in China but was expelled by the communists before traveling to the Philippine province of Iloilo.
After he arrived in Taiwan, the Jesuit missionary was posted to the parish in Hukou.

Hsu thoroughly researched Marsecano's life in Taiwan and then traveled around Italy for 80 days on a "dream trip" sponsored by the Council for Hakka Affairs in 2005, visiting schools Marsecano once attended in his home country and meeting with his sister Vittorina, who is a Jesuit nun.

He brought documents related to Marsecano's life in Taiwan to Vittorina -- the only member of Marsecano's family who is still living -- and in return received a big hug and the nun's heartfelt gratitude for his work, Hsu said.
At that moment he felt it was worth making the effort to find out even more about the priest, described by Hsu as a man with a big heart and love for the world.

After tracing Marsecano's steps in Taiwan and Italy, Hsu said his next plan is to fly to Iloilo to track down the priest's legacy there, but the 31-year-old Hsu said he has already learned an important lesson from the Italian missionary he never met.

"There are many possibilities in life. Even if something is not perfect, as long as you make an effort you will reap rewards, " he said. CNA photos Nos. 24, 25 (By Huang Yen-yu and Elizabeth Hsu)/ls/J Photos available

DOC.HEADLINE: United Daily News: Getting married for lower premiums?

TEXT.P: The proposed second-generation National Health Insurance program has recently sparked doubts that it will "punish singles" because single individuals will have to pay higher premiums. Stopping short of giving a proper explanation, Department of Health Minister Yaung Chih-liang and Premier Wu Den-yih instead encouraged people to get married and start families soon.
It seems the way of thinking of our government officials is too "singular" and out of sync with reality.

The government must recognize the changes going on in society and accept that staying single is one of the options for life. With regard to the distribution of social resources, the government should give equal treatment to all options and family types and should not discriminate against any of them.
Japan, for example, has seen the trend in which more people are choosing to stay single and has introduced residential projects for singles as part of its long- term care policy.

For a long time, our government has been advocating family values and passing caregiving responsibilities to families to make up for the deficiencies in the social welfare and care system. However, while the government can compel single individuals to pay higher premiums by law, should singles have to tie the knot in a hurry just so that they can pay less premiums?

DOC.HEADLINE: President meets U.S. congresswoman
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, April 10 (CNA) 04/10/10 17:14:01 (By Carfie Lee and Flor Wang)

TEXT.P: President Ma Ying-jeou received U.S. Congresswoman Loretta Sanchez (D-CA) Saturday at the Presidential Office and described good Taiwan- U.S. relations as something Taiwan's people look forward to seeing.

Since assuming office, the president said, he has done his best to rebuild Taiwan's mutual trust with the U.S., and two-way ties have rapidly improved despite minor incidents such as the dispute surrounding Taiwan's restrictions on U.S. beef imports.

At the same time, he has tried hard to improve Taiwan's links with China, Japan, the European Union and Southeast Asian countries, Ma told Sanchez, who is a member of the Committee on Armed Services of the House of Representatives.
Ma voiced appreciation to Sanchez for U.S. approval of two military sales to Taiwan over the past two years, which he said has made the people of Taiwan sense the friendship of the U.S.

The president also called for strengthened security cooperation between the two sides and a resumption of two-way talks over a long-delayed trade and investment framework agreement. He also urged the U.S. to grant visa-waiver privileges to Taiwan.

DOC.HEADLINE: Cross-strait tourism representative offices to be set up
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, April 10 (CNA) 04/10/10 17:30:36 (By Liu Teh-chang and Lilian Wu)

TEXT.P: Taiwanese and Chinese tourism representative offices will be set up on each side of the Taiwan Strait in early May, Taiwan Strait Tourism Association (TSTA) sources said Saturday.
They will be the first semi-official organizations to set up offices in Taipei and Beijing, respectively, in the six-decade separation of the two sides of the Taiwan Strait.

Taiwan's Tourism Bureau Director-General Janice Lai will open the TSTA office in Beijing May 4, while Shao Qiwei, commissioner of the China National Tourism Administration and president of the Cross-Strait Tourism Association (CSTA), will lead a delegation that will open an office in Taipei May 7.

TSTA officials noted that based on an agreement signed between the Straits Exchange Foundation (SEF) and its Chinese counterpart, the Association for Relations Across the Taiwan Straits, on Chinese tourists traveling to Taiwan, the TSTA and the CSTA agreed that tourism offices should be set up on each side to provide quick, convenient and effective services.
The TSTA and the CSTA started negotiations more than a year ago and had originally planned to open the offices late last year.
Tourism operators said they were happy with the latest development, describing it as a "major event" in cross-strait tourism.
They noted that since Taiwan began allowing military veterans to return to China to visit their families in 1987, cross-strait tourism has boomed.
The number of people traveling to China to visit family, for tourism or for business has increased every year to more than 3 million, accounting for half of the outbound visits.

DOC.HEADLINE: Number covered by national pension system drops to new low
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, April 10 (CNA) 04/10/10 17:51:35 (By Hsieh Chia-chen and Elizabeth Hsu)

TEXT.P: The number of people covered by the national pension system had declined to 4.01 million as of the end of 2009, 26,000 fewer than that when the system was launched in 2008 as part of the national welfare network, according to government statistics.
Commenting on the issue, Vice Minister of the Interior Chien Tai-lang said Saturday that the drop was because some of the insured dropped out and turned instead to labor or farmer insurance schemes.
"People are free to pay into the insurance scheme that is most beneficial for them," Chien noted.

The national pension system was designed for those aged between 25 and 64 years old and who are not covered by public functionary insurance, labor insurance or any other publicly sponsored insurance schemes.
The insured, who pay 60 percent of the premiums while the government covers the remaining 40 percent, are entitled to receive pensions depending on how long they have been covered when they turn 65.

The national pension system completed the country's social insurance network after it took effect Oct. 1, 2008, said Huang Pi-hsia, director of the Department of Social Affairs under the Ministry of the Interior (MOI).

Under the network, people can choose their insurance scheme based on their vocational status. Should they become jobless, they will be automatically classified as insured under the national pension system, Huang said.

Asked about those who are forced to drop out of the insurance system because they cannot afford to pay the premiums, Huang said the government provides subsidies for those whose "incomes are below standard."

According to MOI statistics, the 4.1 million insured, including the jobless, street vendors, housekeepers, naturalized foreign spouses and students older than 25, account for 29.4 percent of the country's population aged between 25 and 64.
More women than men have joined the national pension system at a percentage of 52.5 percent, while the average age of insured females is 44.4 years, higher than the 43.9 for men, the tallies show.
Nearly 1.03 million of the insured received a total of NT$37.7 billion in payments from the national pension system in 2009, the ministry said.

DOC.HEADLINE: Atomic Energy Council gives assurance on tile safety
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, April 10 (CNA) 04/10/10 18:39:10 (By Lin Huei-chun and Lilian Wu)

TEXT.P: The Atomic Energy Council (AEC) said Saturday that it conducts random checks on tiles sold locally every season and that there is no need for the public to worry about their safety.

The AEC made the remarks one day after domestic tile manufacturers went to the legislature to call attention to claims that the government has been allowing substandard Chinese tiles to enter Taiwan via Vietnam and Indonesia.
The Taiwan Ceramic Industries Association has estimated Taiwan's tile market to be worth about NT$25 billion a year, with tiles from China now accounting for 40 percent of the figure.
Lin Chin-tsai, secretary-general of the association, also said the Chinese tiles are not examined, are uneven and break easily. He also claimed that they could have high radioactivity.

However, the AEC pointed out that it conducts random checks on tiles every season and that they come from Taiwan, Turkey, Spain, Thailand, Italy, Vietnam and Indonesia, as well as various other countries.
The test results show that the tiles fall within 0.07 mSv/h and 0.09 mSv/h, well within the tolerance level for radioactivity, so that there is no need for concern.
"The council will continue to conduct checks on tiles to ensure public safety," the AEC said.

DOC.HEADLINE: Parkinson's disease sufferers enjoy some sun
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, April 10 (CNA) 04/10/10 18:44:08 (By Lin Heng-li and Y.F. Low)

TEXT.P: A group of around 300 sufferers of Parkinson's disease from around Taiwan went on an outing in the central county of Nantou Saturday to mark the April 11 World Parkinson's Day.
The participants, some of whom are confined to a wheelchair, gathered in the Chung Hsing New Village for a walk despite their movement disorders, while others went cycling.

Tseng Kuo-hsiu, a 47-year-old who has suffered from the disease for 19 years, said he began cycling as a form of exercise two years ago after taking part in a cycling activity held by a patient support group in Kaohsiung City.
According to Tseng, cycling is a very suitable exercise for Parkinson's sufferers because it helps strengthen the muscles as well as increasing physical strength and willpower.
While medication can control and relieve the tremors that are a symptom of the disease, cycling can improve and even prevent them from worsening, he said.

The Taiwan Tulip Movement Disorders Association, the organizer of the activity, said the outing was aimed at allowing patients to share their life experiences with each other and encouraging them to bravely overcome their disabilities.
The event was also a warm-up for an international conference on Parkinson's disease to be held in March 2011 in Taipei, which is expected to draw more than 1,000 participants, the association added.

DOC.HEADLINE: Carriers urged to come up with bolder fare cuts
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, April 10 (CNA) 04/10/10 20:07:15 (By S.F. Wang and Flor Wang)

TEXT.P: The Consumers Foundation urged local air carriers Saturday to come up with bolder fare cuts on cross-Taiwan Strait flights amid widespread complaints about the high cost of air travel between Taiwan and China.

Foundation Chairman Hsieh Tian-jen said that although Taipei-based China Airlines (CAL) , Trans Asia and EVA Airways have recently announced fare cuts of up to 20 percent on their cross-strait flights, they are only reductions in the face values of the tickets.
He reiterated that the price cuts should be reflected in the actual retail price to the customer.

According to Hsieh, many China-based Taiwanese businessmen are still dissatisfied that a round-trip Taiwan-Shanghai flight cost over NT$20,000 (US$640) in early April. The price was much higher than that offered by travel agencies late last year, he noted.

He prodded the Civil Aeronautics Administration (CAA) to intervene in airlines' pricing, saying that they should not be left on their own to set prices in the particularly oligopolistic cross-strait air travel market.
At present, only Taiwanese and Chinese carriers can conduct non-stop direct flights across the strait.

On April 7, both CAL and Trans Asia announced 20 percent fare cuts on direct cross -strait economy flights from April 16. Trans Asia plies the Taipei- Shanghai and Taichung-Shanghai routes, while CAL offers direct flights from Taoyuan and Kaohsiung to Shanghai, Beijing, Guangzhou and Shenzhen.
EVA Airways followed suit the next day, announcing reductions ranging between 11 percent and 20 percent on its economy flights from Taiwan to the same four Chinese cities.
Sources familiar with the business, however, contended that the price cuts were more a symbolic gesture than a substantial move.
They said the cuts will have no real effect on popular flights in the coming summer peak season and over the period of the 2010 Shanghai World Expo, because tickets are already fully booked.
The Fair Trade Commission also said the CAA should come up with more aggressive measures to push the carriers to reduce their ticket prices further and provide feedback to their customers.

DOC.HEADLINE: Oyster farmers protest threat from industrial development
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, April 10 (CNA) 04/10/10 20:27:52 (By Hsu Jui-ting and Bear Lee)

TEXT.P: Oyster farmers from the western coastal areas of Taiwan staged a protest in Taipei Saturday against industrial facilities near their farms that they said have seriously threatened their operations.

Lin Lien-tsung, secretary-general of the Fangyuan Anti-Pollution Association in Changhua, said that an investigative report by Ted Smith, founder of the U.S., Silicon Valley Toxics Coalitions, found that the waste water released by panel makers in Changhua is highly poisonous.

The 1,000-hectare oyster farms in Changhua's Yungxing, Wanggong, and Hanbou townships will be highly polluted and even disappear in several years if the waste water from the Central Taiwan Science Park , which houses many hi-tech manufactures, continues to be released into the sea through the townships, Lin added.

Lin was echoed by Tsai Chia-yang, chairman of the Changhua Oyster Farmers' Association, who said there are 5,000 hectares of oyster farms in the central county and that they are now bearing the brunt of the establishment of the Central Taiwan Science Park.

Lin Chin-lang, chairman of the Yunlin Offshore Aquaculture Association, said that the Sixth Naphtha Cracker Project of the Formosa Plastic Group (FPG) has also ruined oyster farming in neighboring Yunlin County.

The farmers demanded that the government immediately call to an end the several ongoing industrial development projects in the coastal area, including the Guoguang petrochemical complex in Changhua, the FPG Yunlin cracker, and the Central Taiwan Science Park sub-projects.

DOC.HEADLINE: Charity group calls for good deeds to help fight global warming
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, April 10 (CNA) 04/10/10 20:37:41 (By Lin Szu-yu and Lilian Wu)

TEXT.P: Taiwan's largest charity foundation called on the public Saturday to practice "five good deeds a day" to help fight global warming.

The Buddhist Compassion Relief Tzu Chi Foundation said that the "five good deeds" refers to following a vegetarian diet, conserving water and electricity, always carrying three environmentally friendly things (your own cup, bowl and chopsticks) and walking more.

The foundation made the appeal at its Pa De environmental protection station in Taipei. On hand were flood-affected victims from Shanlin Township in Kaohsiung County who now reside in a community built by the foundation after their homes were destroyed by Typhoon Morakot last August.
The visitors, who traveled to Taipei to express their appreciation, donned traditional Bunun aboriginal tribal costume and sang the "Song of Five Good Deeds."

The foundation said that according to Wang Chung-ho, a researcher of Academia Sinica, the nation's highest research institute, if Taiwan is to return to the 1999 carbon dioxide emissions level by 2020, it will have to cut emissions by least 50 percent.

What this means is that from now on, emissions should be cut by 5 percent every year. Based on carbon emissions of 11.17 tons per person per year in Taiwan, each person must cut their emissions by 1.53 kg per day to achieve the goal.
In Chinese, the pronunciation of 1.53 sounds similar to "five good deeds a day, " and the foundation urged that the public to start cutting their carbon emissions by 1.53 kg per day.
"The faster the carbon emissions are cut, the slower will be the speed of global warming," according to the foundation.

DOC.HEADLINE: ROC flag raised at stamp show in Belgium despite China protest
DOC.DATELINE: Brussels, Belgium, April 10 (CNA) 04/10/10 21:04:49 (By Tsao Yu-fan and Elizabeth Hsu)

TEXT.P: The Republic of China flag survived an attempted suppression by Beijing at an international stamp show in the Belgian city of Antwerp that opened Friday, with over 50 postal administrations and more than 100 stamp dealers from around the world taking part.

It is the first time Taiwan has been represented at Antverpia 2010, and it was attending as a special guest. Hanging the ROC flag along with those of the other countries attending the international exhibition reflects the organizer's respect for such a special guest, according to officials of the Taipei representative office in Belgium.
The move, however, drew a strong protest from officials at the Chinese Embassy in Belgium to Frank Daniels, the project manager of the event, before the opening ceremony, they said.
Daniels rejected the protest and pointed out to the Chinese officials that they were in Belgium and should show some respect, the Taiwanese officials said.

Amid warming relations between the two sides of the Taiwan Strait since President Ma Ying-jeou assumed office in May 2008, the protest by the Chinese officials shows a different face of China that is not good for its international reputation. the Taiwan officials said.

Antverpia 2010 is an international stamp fair organized by the Royal Belgian Federation of Philatelic Associations to celebrate the 120th anniversary of the founding of the group. It opened April 9 and was scheduled to run until April 12.

DOC.HEADLINE: Taiwan's first flight school to open January
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, April 10 (CNA) 04/10/10 21:20:24 (By Alex Jiang)

TEXT.P: Taiwan is likely to have its first civil pilot training school in January next year at the earliest, the country's former top civil aviation official said Saturday.
However, Billy Chang, who retired as head of the Civil Aeronautics Administration in 2008, said he has encountered several obstacles so far.
"I plan to set up the school in Taitung (in eastern Taiwan), but it is very difficult to acquire land, as the regulations are complex," he said.

There have been discussions about establishing such a flight school in Taiwan over the past three decades, but the idea has never come to fruition, he told an event organized by Privilege Aero LLC, a U.S. pilot training school, to recruit students in Taipei.
As a result, local airline companies have to send their pilots abroad to receive training, he said.
"Taiwan should be capable of training its own pilots and airplane maintenance specialists, " noted Chang, who is chairman of the Taipei-based Aviation Education Foundation.
He said he had already received funds from a German friend, but still needs to seek financial sponsorship from local investors, as Taiwanese law sets a limit on foreign investment.
Chang estimated that the school would cost NT$3 billion (US$95 million) to NT$4 billion for operations for the first five years.
He also revealed a plan to recruit 60 professional instructors.

To get more experience, Chang recently visited four flight schools in the United States, including Privilege Aero LLC, which was established in 2003 by James Young, the first Taiwanese founder of a pilot training school in the U.S.
Young said his school now has more than 100 students, 14 of whom are Taiwanese.
Chang also lauded Young for inventing a ground-based flight simulator, the only one of its kind in the world liscensed by the Federal Aviation Administration of the U.S.
Young explained that he created the invention after he had to do certain "dangerous" moves in a real plane when he was receiving his own training at pilot schools in the U.S.
"Using this simulator, a student can also take a pause or rewind what he or she just did and listen to the instructor explain how it is supposed to be done," he said.
