DOC.HEADLINE: Today in history
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, April 11 (CNA) 04/11/10 12:20:16
DOC.TEXT:
Today is Sunday, April 11, or the 27th day of the second month of the Year of the Tiger according to the lunar calendar. Following is a list of important events that have occurred on this date in the past:
1713: France cedes Newfoundland and Gibraltar to Britain.
1775: James Parkinson, the British physician who defined Parkinson's disease, a progressive disease of the nervous system also called paralysis agitans or shaking palsy, is born.
1814: Louis XVIII accedes to the throne as Napoleon Bonaparte abdicates and is banished to the island of Elba under the Treaty of Fontainebleau.
1893: Dean Acheson, the U.S. politician and secretary of state who helped to formulate the Truman Doctrine and the Marshall Plan and who promoted the setting up of the North Atlantic Treaty Organization (NATO), is born.
1899: Spain transfers control of the Philippines to the United States.
1919: The International Labor Organization is founded in Geneva in affiliation with the League of Nations to improve living standards and working conditions.
1926: American horticulturist Luther Burbank dies at the age of 77. He developed countless new varieties of fruits, vegetables and flowers, including the Burbank potato and the Shasta daisy.
1935: Dust storms wreak havoc in the so-called "Dust Bowl" states of Kansas, Colorado, Wyoming, Oklahoma, Texas and New Mexico in the United States.
1945: U.S. forces capture the German towns of Essen and Weimar and liberate the Buchenwald concentration camp near the end of World War II.
1950: The Bank of Taiwan issues its first lottery.
1950: China lodges a complaint with the United Nations against Soviet aid to the Chinese communists, the Soviet invasion of China and Soviet violation of the U.N. Charter.
1951: U.S. President Harry Truman relieves Gen. Douglas MacArthur, the World War II hero who accepted the Japanese surrender in Tokyo Bay in 1945, of all his command, including that of U.N. forces in Korea.
1957: Singapore is granted self-government by the United Kingdom.
1969: Taiwan's Executive Yuan approves the "Guidelines for the Population Policy of the Republic of China."
1970: The government of Prime Minister Lon Nol announces abolishment of the monarchy and proclaims Cambodia a republic.
1974: U.S. Secretary of Agriculture Earl L. Butz, leading a party of 19, arrives in Taipei for a three-day visit.
1974: The ROC Executive Yuan approves the Sino-Honduran Fishery Technical Cooperation Agreement.
1976: An ROC education mission headed by Education Minister Y.S. Tsiang leaves for the Middle East on a visit.
1976: Col. Carlos Humberto Romero, secretary of defense and pacific security of El Salvador, arrives in Taipei for a six-day visit.
1978: The Taiwan Province Black Foot Disease Control Center is inaugurated in Peimen Village, Tainan County.
1979: A combined force of Ugandan exiles and Tanzanian troops captures the Ugandan capital of Kampala, ending the eight-year rule of Idi Amin.
1981: Chen Ta, a noted singer of Taiwanese folk songs, dies at the age of 76.
1994: U.S. President Bill Clinton orders trade sanctions against Taiwan in accordance with the Pelly Act.
1995: Chen Yun, one of Communist China's leading veteran hardliners and one of its leading economic planners, dies in Beijing at the age of 90.
1997: Turin Cathedral is engulfed by flames, but firefighters manage to save the famous Turin Shroud.
2000: Foreign ministers of the 113-member Non-Aligned Movement endorse the Philippine-led regional code of conduct in the South China Sea to promote peace and stability in the region.
2001: The Executive Yuan signs an agreement with the Netherlands Trade and Investment Office (NTIO) in Taipei to enact regulations to prevent double taxation on Dutch people working in Taiwan as well as those from Taiwan in the Netherlands.
2002: The European Parliament passes a pro-Taiwan resolution urging mainland China to dismantle missile deployment against Taiwan.
Confucius' lesson of the day: "A moral character always has courage; but a man of courage is not necessarily a moral character."

DOC.HEADLINE: China Times: Health minister, could you just shut up?

TEXT.P: After Department of Health Minister Yaung Chih-liang drew astorm of criticism for saying single people are more prone to mental illness and should therefore pay higher health insurance premiums, it is uncertain whether the second- generation National Health Insurance system will clear the legislature.

The system would calculate premiums based on household income, allowing single- income families and those with many dependents to pay less while subjecting high-income earners and single people to higher premiums.
The approach has drawn broadsides from various sectors of society, who say it punishes people for not getting married.

Yaung should have been more careful in handling the issue, but he continued to make indiscreet remarks, such as calling for single people who want to pay less to quickly start families and have more children.
His comments not only failed to address public concern, but fueled people's anger at the government and undermined public confidence in the second- generation health insurance scheme.
We cannot help but say: Yaung Chih-liang, could you please just shut up?

The scheme has been designed to raise premiums. Some will have to pay more and some will be allowed to pay less. The government should give convincing explanations for the different rates for various groups by citing statistics, not by making irrelevant comments. (April 11, 2010).

DOC.HEADLINE: Taiwan headline news
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, April 11 (CNA) 04/11/10 15:32:29

DOC.HEADLINE: Premier upbeat about Taiwan's job prospects
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, April 11 (CNA) 04/11/10 16:10:08 (By Lee Hsi-chang and Sofia Wu)

TEXT.P: Taiwan's job market will continue to improve this year as its economy has recovered from a year-long recession and its 2010 GDP growth is expected to surpass those of other Asian "little dragons, " Premier Wu Den-yih said Sunday.

Delivering an address at the opening of a central Taiwan job fair at the Taichung World Trade Center, Wu cited a recent World Bank assessment as saying that Taiwan will top the three other Asian "little dragons" in terms of gross domestic product (GDP) growth this year.

According to the World Bank report, Taiwan was the "little dragon" hardest-hit by the 2008-2009 global economic slump, with its 2009 GDP growth rate lagging behind those of South Korea, Singapore and Hong Kong.
"The trend will reverse itself this year as the worst is over... Our economy has weathered the gloom and gradually regained momentum," Wu said.
Against this backdrop, Wu said, domestic job prospects have become increasingly bright, with the number of job openings rising steadily over the past four months.

To sustain the momentum, Wu said, the government will work even harder to boost economic development in collaboration with the private sector in hopes of creating more jobs and driving the unemployment rate below 5 percent by year's end.

More than 200 enterprises in central Taiwan set up booths at the job fair, offering a total of 14,000 jobs. Another 100-plus companies also commissioned the fair organizers to help collect resumes from prospective job seekers.
Wu promised that the government will help track private enterprises' recruitment operations to ensure the event generates the best possible effects in helping local job seekers land jobs.

DOC.HEADLINE: Talk of the day -- Boao Forum used to test the waters
DOC.DATELINE: 04/11/10 16:31:51 (By Deborah Kuo)

TEXT.P: Frederick Chien, a retired veteran diplomat leading Taiwan's delegation at the 2010 Boao Forum for Asia in Hainan, met Chinese Vice President Xi Jinping, on the sidelines of the forum Saturday.
The forum included nearly 2,000 political and business leaders from around the world.

While Chien tested the waters by stressing the importance of closer cross-cross commercial ties, particularly in the development of green industries and the financial sector, Xi pushed the signing of a proposed cross-strait economic cooperation framework agreement (ECFA).
The following are excerpts from local media coverage of the issue:
United Daily News:

Xi, who is familiar with Taiwan affairs as he had been a deputy mayor of Xiamen City and a Communist Party of China's No. 2 man in Fujian province -- one of the Chinese provinces where Taiwanese investments are centered -- spoke with Chien in his capacity as a Chinese leader for the first time.
Xi told Chien the signing of the ECFA "should proceed without interruptions and be allowed to yield positive results and economic efficiency the sooner the better."
He said that "all issues can be discussed and all problems can be addressed if we engage as members of a family."
He called for closer cooperation across the strait to create a new era of cooperation now that the global economic meltdown has passed.
Meanwhile, Wang Yi, China's top official in charge of Taiwan relations, also pushed the ECFA signing at a cocktail party to welcome the Taiwan delegation.
Wang said Taiwan will benefit substantially if cross-strait economic and trade exchanges become closer and institutionalized.
"We want to pass more real, positive and objective information about the ECFA to our Taiwanese compatriots via the Boao forum," Wang said.
He also stressed that it is time for the two sides to cooperate more closely on innovation industries.

Xi and Wang's talks reflect Beijing's stance that it will focus on economic cooperation with Taiwan and it is not in a hurry to enter into political negotiations, political analysts said. (April 11, 2010).
China Times:

Xi made positive and constructive comments on the signing of the proposed ECFA. He called for the two sides to seize opportunities after the global economic crunch and collaborate to create a "common memory" for both sides.
Chien, meanwhile, called for closer cross-strait cooperation in the development of green industries, echoing Xi's remarks during his opening speech.
Xi had said China is willing to make concerted efforts with its Asian neighbors to jointly develop environmentally friendly industries that have low carbon footprints.
"Once we say it, we mean it and will put it into practice," Xi said.

Meanwhile, Zhang Xiaoqiang, vice minister of China's National Development and Reform Commission, said China will encourage foreign investors to make "good investments" in China and "will no longer welcome foreign investment in energy- and resource-depleting industries."

The Boao Forum, founded in 2001 by Australia and 25 Asian states, has held its annual meeting in the resort town Boao of China's southern Hainan province since 2002 to promote high-level dialogue on regional issues. The theme of this year's three-day meeting is "Green Recovery: Asia's Realistic Choice for Sustainable Growth." (April 11, 2010).

DOC.HEADLINE: Taiwan-designed porcelain assumes new role in people's lives

TEXT.P: Franz Collection Inc., a Taiwan company that produces high-quality porcelain, is renowned for beautiful ceramic art that is popular worldwide and a favorite gift choice of celebrities in recent years.

CEO Francis Chen unveiled a new corporate direction recently: Franz will collaborate with a well-known French company to make porcelain tableware for hotels, and is planning to bring porcelain into ordinary people's homes.
The company was founded in 2001 and is primarily known for works that blend creative design and underlying functionality.

Franz's tableware, vases and jewelry have won various honors worldwide such as the Best in Gift Award at the New York International Gift Fair in 2002, Best Ceramic Gift in Britain in 2005, Fashion Accessory Line of the Year in the United States in 2006, and many others.
Chen based his idea for the new product line on his strong belief that "life should always involve art" and the project aims to create "porcelain for daily life."
Chen has received many accolades for his role in promoting cultural creativity in Taiwan. He has expanded his business to 53 countries with about 6,000 stores, but he has an even bigger dream.
"I want to introduce my porcelain into the everyday lives of ordinary people, pieces that are affordable and practical to own, " Chen told the Central News Agency.
"People should welcome art into their lives and become more involved in the arts," Chen said.

The first new works were a set of white porcelain products that debuted on April 8. They were produced in cooperation with Bernardaud, a French company founded in 1863 in the city of Limoges. Bernardaud is the main source of tableware for top Michelin-rated restaurants.
This white porcelain tableware has a clean, modern esthetic that is quite different from products previously designed by Franz.
Franz's products are made in the town of Jingde in Jingxi province, China -- known as the "Porcelain Capital" since it has been producing quality porcelain for 1,700 years.
From its founding as an original equipment manufacturer (OEM) to developing its own brand, it has been a long journey to prominence, Chen said.

According to the management of Franz, developing its own brand allowed the firm to successfully expand and become more easily accepted and trusted by their customers. Prior to the debut of Franz's new line, many five-star hotels such as the Peninsula Shanghai and the Grand Hyatt Beijing had already placed orders.

Chen said that creativity emanates from the values embodied in traditional culture and that he continually strives to embrace those cultural norms while exploring new directions and extending customary ideas.

In addition to his goal of emulating the role of Bernardaud -- but in the Chinese-speaking world -- by providing top restaurants and hotels in the area with high-quality tableware, Chen wants his Taiwan-made brand to be well- received by people in the region.

Chen is currently conducting a survey on the preferences of Taiwanese people. He not only wishes that his products will enjoy commercial success, but also expects to continue to develop new items to enrich people's daily lives. CNA Photo 47 By Sunnie Chen CNA Staff Reporter

DOC.HEADLINE: Economics ministry devises plan to promote catering industry
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, April 11 (CNA) 04/11/10 17:31:03 (Lin Su-yuan and Y.L. Kao)

TEXT.P: The Ministry of Economic Affairs (MOEA) has mapped out a project to promote the hotel and catering service industry, hoping to generate investment of NT$1.5 billion (US$31.74 million) and create 2,000 jobs, a ministry official said Sunday.

Although starting a catering business requires a low amount of capital investment, the catering industry offers a number of jobs to middle-aged and older people and is a major source of services sector employment, according to the official.
The ministry is therefore giving high priority to further developing the industry, he said.
In 2009, the number of hotel and catering facilities totaled 98,932, generating production value of NT$321.8 billion and offering 693,000 jobs, according to MOEA statistics.
Despite a drop in domestic demand amid the global financial crisis beginning in the fourth quarter of 2008, the sector still posted a 2.4 growth rate between 2007-2009, the official said.
In view of the importance of the sector's contribution to Taiwan's services industry employment, the ministry has devised the 2010-2013 investment project.
The government's goal is to both bring gourmet foods from around the world to Taiwan and to introduce Taiwanese delicacies abroad, the official said.
Taiwan's cafe chain 85 Degrees Celsius has 422 outlets around the globe, while Din Tai Fung, a restaurant famous for its steamed pork dumplings, also has numerous overseas branches, he added.
The ministry plans to hold 50 business-matching meetings for Taiwanese and foreign enterprises this year with the aim of helping them open 400 stores in Taiwan.
The ministry will also help catering operators organize
friendship associations, assist in training for hospitality and catering professionals, and set up a gourmet food "special zone" to promote delicacies from around the world.

DOC.HEADLINE: Czech woman, Taiwanese man win Miaoli Triathlon
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, April 11 (CNA) 04/11/10 18:09:51 (By Chen Shu-fen and Deborah Kuo)

TEXT.P: Radka Vodickova, a triathlon athlete from the Czech Republic, won the women's race at the Miaoli Triathlon Sunday with a time of 1:52:48.
A Taiwanese man, Wang Hao-hsiang from Kinmen, took the men's title with 1:46:01.

Upon winning the women's title, Vodickova, who has won 10 gold medals in international triathlons since 2004, said it was her first competition in Taiwan and that she will depart with a very good impression, including the island's beautiful scenery and kind, gentle people.
She said the 20km cycling and 5km standard run were challenging due to uphills in many road sections.
"The beautiful scenery by the roadsides, however, compensated for my fatigue," a light-hearted Vodickova said.
Wang thanked his coach for extending "crucial and endless support" to him after he suffered neck and back injuries in 2008.
He said he will continue to compete in triathlons while seeking to enter a graduate school for advanced studies in sports.
The 2010 Miaoli Triathlon kicked off at the West Lake Resortopia in the northern county of Miaoli Saturday, with nearly 2,000 local and foreign athletes participating.

King Pu-tsung, secretary-general of the ruling Kuomintang, and former Department of Health Minister Yeh Chin-chuan were among the participants. King finished the men's triathlon in 3: 17: 39 and Yeh finished in 4:04:31.

Meanwhile, two men proposed to their girlfriends when they reached the finish line. Moved by their love, the management of West Lake Resortopia offered the two couples free admission to the recreation park for the rest of their lives.

DOC.HEADLINE: Lawmakers divided over nominee for prosecutor general
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, April 11 (CNA) 04/11/10 18:41:57 (By Maubo Chang)

TEXT.P: Two days before the Legislative Yuan is to hold a vote on the presidential nominee for the country's prosecutor general, lawmakers are divided along party lines.

A team of legislators from the ruling Kuomintang (KMT) , which controls a majority of the legislative seats, is set to recommend that their party's lawmakers throw their weight behind Huang Shih-ming.

Legislator Lu Hsueh-chang, convener of the 11-member KMT team, said on Sunday that Huang was deemed the best candidate for the post by an association of prosecutors because he is rarely involved in any controversy and his integrity is impeccable.
"We will submit our recommendation to a Monday meeting of party lawmakers who are supposed to heed our suggestion," Lu said.
Meanwhile, the legislative caucus of opposition Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) said it would ask DPP lawmakers to vote against the nominee.
DPP Legislator Tsai Huang-liang said that Huang is biased against the DPP, citing his 1995 indictment of former Penghu Magistrate Kao Chih-peng, a member of DPP.
Kao was given a suspended 15-month jail term for forgery in that case.
However, DPP Legislator Ker Chien-ming -- who doubles as the director of the DPP Policy Committee -- said the DPP caucus will not discipline party lawmakers who vote across the party line.
President Ma Ying-jeou nominated Huang to fill the post left vacant by Chen Tsung-ming after Chen, who was impeached by the Control Yuan, resigned on Jan. 19.
With the KMT controlling 75 seats at the 113-seat legislature, the nomination is almost sure to be approved on Tuesday.

DOC.HEADLINE: Taiwan faces crisis of trust among generations: DPP chair
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, April 11 (CNA) 04/11/10 19:19:16 (By Wen Kuei-hsiang and Sofia Wu)

TEXT.P: Taiwan is very likely to see a crisis of trust among generations because of its quickly aging population, opposition Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) Chairperson Tsai Ing-wen predicted Sunday.

Speaking at a seminar on the impact of the aging population on social development, Tsai said that elderly people will account for 16 percent of Taiwan's total population in 10 years and that the ratio will probably rise even higher.
"Against this backdrop, what our society will face in the future may not be distrust between our two major political camps, but distrust among different generations," Tsai said.

Acting on her directive, the DPP plans to draw up a package of "10-year policy guidelines" later this year as the first step to help address challenges Taiwan will face in the coming decade, Tsai said.
"I hope the DPP will be a visionary and forward-looking party that is able to foresee future problems our country may face and map out tactics to resolve them," Tsai said.
With the local population aging, Tsai said, Taiwan may see its population decline after peaking in the next decade.
Moreover, she went on, young people will shoulder an increasing financial burden while facing substantial changes in industrial trends and job markets.
In the coming decade, Tsai said that local people may become increasingly reliant on public health care and that society could undergo wealth redistribution.
With the younger generation assuming increasing financial burden, Tsai predicted that a crisis of trust could erupt among different generations.
"To avoid the worst-case scenario, we need to have foresight, insight and a broad perspective in formulating policy initiatives, " Tsai said.
Expressing her aversion to intransigence, Tsai said the DPP will promote social dialogue to pool wisdom and resources to deal with future challenges and boost the well-being of Taiwan's people.
Sunday's seminar was presided over by Chu Hai-yuan, a research fellow at Academia Sinica's Institute of Social Sciences, and attended by many noted sociologists and economists.

Three other seminars will be held April 22, April 24 and May 2, to deal with three topics: the next wave of ecological disaster, Taiwan's new economic development strategy amid globalization, and Taiwan's strategy in the face of a changing international situation.
The DPP is scheduled to unveil its "10-year policy guidelines" at its 2010 national congress in August.
Responding to criticism that the guidelines are election platforms, Tsai said they would by no means be formulated for that purpose.
"Election platforms outline a short-term agenda, while the planned 10-year policy guidelines will mainly target long-term problems," she said.

DOC.HEADLINE: Mayday wows Hollywood
DOC.DATELINE: Los Angeles, April 10 (CNA) 04/11/10 19:31:45 (By Leaf Jiang and Jenny W. Hsu)

TEXT.P: Taiwan's alternative rock band sensation Mayday left its mark in tinsel town last night as thousands of diehard fans flooded into the Gibson Amphitheater at Universal Studio Hollywood to rock out to the group's tunes.
Mayday was the first Taiwan band to perform at the venue.
With fame sweeping across the globe, the award-winning group -- comprised of five best friends -- attracted over 4,500 devotees from Japan, Malaysia, Singapore, Hong Kong, China and Taiwan.

Waving glow sticks and wearing Mayday 2010 DNA World Tour t-shirts, fans screamed as the band brought the house down with popular songs such as "Drag Race, " "You are Not Truly Happy" and "Exploding Liver."
The decibel level in the theater shot through the roof when the lead singer, Ashin, belted out one of their most popular hits, "Depart from Earth," bringing the entire audience to their feet.

At one point, the hard-edged ambiance mellowed out and turned borderline tear- jerking when the five band members, sometimes dubbed the "Beatles of the Chinese community, " held hands and sang to their friendship throughout the years.
Connie Yang and Illy Zhou, two students from Taiwan and China, said driving five hours from Las Vegas to hear their favorite group was well worth the time.

"I love their songs because they energize me. But most importantly, their lyrics really speak to me, as if we share the same perspective on life, " said Zhou, who saw Mayday perform in Beijing last year.
For North Carolina native Jesse Gyongyos and his new bride Amanda Hsu from Taiwan, coming to the Mayday concert just one month after their wedding "was part of the celebration of our marriage."
Gyongyos became familiar with Mayday when he studied Chinese in college and Hsu became a fan after her American husband introduced her to their music.
It was Mayday's second trip to Los Angeles after their previous gig in 2007, but guitar player Ming said that if time allowed, the group would come back every year to meet their overseas fans.
This is the band's fifth world tour since its formation in 1997. The tour started in New York and will continue on to San Francisco before heading to China and Singapore.

DOC.HEADLINE: Groups push for land trust to protect white dolphins
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, April 11 (CNA) 04/11/10 20:16:37 (By Lee Hsien-feng and Deborah Kuo)

TEXT.P: Two environmental groups called on Taiwan's people Sunday to purchase public land near the estuary of the country's longest river and put the land under trust to protect endangered Chinese white dolphins.

Tsai Chia-yang, chairman of the Taiwan Environmental Protection Union Changhua Division, said that fewer than 100 Chinese white dolphins -- also known as Indo- Pacific humpback dolphins -- remained along the west coast of Taiwan because of industrial and land development.

The dolphins, which are white in color and endemic to Taiwan, were discovered in 2002 off the island's west coast and in 2008 listed by the International Union for Conservation of Nature as critically endangered. They are usually seen between 20 to 800 meters from shore as they prefer shallow coastal waters.
The dolphins are on the verge of extinction in the area, where biodiversity has been seriously threatened by economic development over the past three to four decades, Tsai said.

He said the government has preserved over 4,000 hectares of land near the estuary of Jhuoshuei River between the western counties of Changhua and Yunlin to be used for the development of a new naphtha cracking plant.
The area, however, has traditionally been a haven for Chinese white dolphins, other marine animals and migratory birds.

Meanwhile, Tung Chin-sheng, chairman of the Taipei-based Taiwan Environmental Information Center, said his office invited Oliver Maurice, an official with the International National Trust Organization in charge of planning and development, to Taiwan to help residents buy public land.

Tung said that according to the center's plan, a corridor of 200 hectares of land along the estuary will be purchased in the first phase of the project, with each unit of 1 square meter zoned as one share and selling at a cost of NT$119.
A trust fund will be raised through the land sales, Tung said, adding that the drive is expected to finish in 90 days.
"All the nation's citizens are welcome to be a landlord, " he said.
So far, over NT$1.8 million (US$57,100) has been raised through an online fund- raising drive, he said.
Maurice said that all the land, coastline and cultural assets, once under trust, would be prohibited from being resold for generations to come.

The Chinese white dolphins have an extremely low birth rate and a life span of 30-40 years. It takes 10-12 years for them to reach sexual maturity and a female dolphin gives birth once every 3-4 years, Tung said.
The function of the trust is to raise public awareness of the plight of the dolphins, which are regarded as an indicator of the health of the coastal waters, he said.

The humpback dolphins are called "Matsu Fish" by local fishermen because they are seen most frequently between March and April when when the birthday of Matsu, the Chinese goddess of the Sea, is celebrated in Taiwan.

DOC.HEADLINE: Taipei City to turn trash into treasures
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, April 11 (CNA) 04/11/10 20:20:42 (By Chen Hung-chin and Y.L. Kao)

TEXT.P: The Taipei City government said on Sunday that some of the artifacts displayed at the planned Taipei City Museum would be utter garbage.

Lee Chien-chang, a city councilor of the opposition Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) , said at a press conference that a wide variety of souvenirs and artifacts, including ceramic Buddha statues, bronze medals, ancient coins and commemorative bottles of wine marking the 69th birthday of late President Chiang Ching-kuo were recovered from the Neihu garbage landfill area.
Some of the recovered pieces date back to about 40 years ago and play an important role in the city's culture, Lee said.
The landfill site is about 53 meters above sea level and was in operation from 1968 to 1985. The volume of garbage at the site is about 2,228,000 cubic meters, Lee said.
Saying that excavated artifacts reflected residents' daily lives in the past, Lee suggested that the city government commission contracted cleaning workers to better search for hidden treasures.
DPP Councilor Hsu Shu-hua urged the government to value unearthed artifacts from a cultural and historical angle.

Wang Yi-chun, chief secretary of the city's Department of Cultural Affairs, told the Central News Agency that his department will collaborate with the Department of Environmental Protection and garbage disposal contractors to commission appraisal experts to estimate the worth of recovered artifacts before including them in the collection.

DOC.HEADLINE: Taiwan's green investment accounts for 1% of GDP: CEPD
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, April 11 (CNA) 04/11/10 20:43:57 (By Hsieh Chun-wei and Sofia Wu)

TEXT.P: Taiwan invested up to 1 percent of its gross domestic product (GDP) in green technology in 2009, compatible with other major countries around the world, the Cabinet-level Council for Economic Planning and Development (CEPD) said Sunday.

According to data released by the United Nations Environmental Programme (UNEP) , 15.4 percent of the US$3.163 trillion that countries around the world funneled into various economic stimulus packages as of June 2009 was channeled into the green sector, accounting for 0.7 percent of global GDP.

In terms of UNEP data, the council said in a statement that Taiwan matched the general world standard in green investment last year as the government spent NT$133.9 billion (US$4.25 billion) , about 1 percent of the country's GDP, in the green sector.
The report said China led the world in terms of green investment in 2009, pumping in US$216.4 billion or 3 percent of its GDP.
The United States came in second, with US$94.1 billion or 0.7 percent of GDP, followed by South Korea with US$36.3 billion or 3 percent of its GDP and Japan at US$36 billion or 0.8 percent.

In terms of per capita green investment, South Korea topped all other countries, with US$1,238 per person, and up to 95.2 percent of its stimulus package was funneled into the green sector, the CEPD said.

With global warming becoming a major concern, the CEPD said, the development of low-carbon industries is the wave of the future. In line with the trend, it added, the government has launched 10 landmark projects, with the goal of raising the energy efficiency by 2 percent annually in the next eight years and the annual carbon emission being lowered to the 2000 level by 2025.

DOC.HEADLINE: United Daily News -- Improving health care
DOC.DATELINE: 04/11/10 20:48:33 (By Maubo Chang)

TEXT.P: A plan to revamp the debt-laden National Health Insurance program has been presented to the Legislative Yuan for approval.

It has come under fire from civil groups for sharply rising insurance premiums, from business and industrial groups for putting undue financial burdens on them, and from lawmakers who question its disproportionately heavy premiums for single people.
What is more important is that the plan is intended more to replenish the program than to improve the quality of medical care.

The program, started in 1995, is one of the country's prides -- providing reliable, safe and convenient health care to 99 percent of the population. It is a vital part of the country's social security system and we would never let it collapse because of a lack of funds.
The government's plan is focused on funneling more funds into the program and a hike in premiums is widely anticipated.
As insurance premiums are shared by employers, employees and the government at a ratio of 6: 3: 1, employers have good reason to be concerned.

However, we believe the plan should also improve the medical care it offers, which lies in the adoption of standardized payments for certain treatments and the enhancement of the transparency of medical information.

The legislature's job is to examine whether the proposed premium rates as well as maximum and minimum payments were properly determined, whether to set up a monitoring group to determine premium rates, and how the legislature and civil groups can supervise the new system. (April 11, 2010)

DOC.HEADLINE: Vice president drums up support for trade pact with China
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, April 11 (CNA) 04/11/10 20:49:08 (By Huang Kuo-fang and Maubo Chang)

TEXT.P: Vice President Vincent Siew made a pitch in the southern Taiwan city of Chiayi Sunday for the country's proposed trade pact with China.
In a speech to a local Lions Club, the vice president said the economic cooperation framework agreement is vital to the island's economic development.

Owing to its geographic location on leading regional shipping lines, Siew said Taiwan has engaged actively with other states ever since it began to shift its economic cornerstone from agriculture to industry.
"The history of the last five or six decades has proved that we are moving on the right path," said Siew, who served as the country's economic architect for many years.
The future development of Taiwan's economy rests on industrial innovation, research and development, designing and marketing.
It also rests on its incorporation into international communities in view of the increasing number of regional trade pacts, such as the North American Free Trade Agreement and the European Union.

"Unfortunately, Taiwan was excluded from most of these regional trade blocs due to political reasons, " the vice president said, referring to its long-time political confrontation with China, which has gone out of its way to crowd Taiwan out of international stage.

However, Taiwan's trade pact with China will serve as a stepping stone for the island to move into a prominent position on the international stage and stimulating the United States and Japan to cooperate with Taiwan more closely in the field of economics.

As with any other bilateral agreement, the pact will bring about both positive and negative effects on the island's economy, and what the government should do is to maximize the positive while minimizing the negative.
"We are on a threshold in terms of the country's economic development," the vice president said, adding that Taiwan should not draw in its horns at this critical moment.

President Ma Ying-jeou's administration is working hard to conclude the pact with Beijing in June in hopes of reducing the island's marginalization after the introduction of the China-ASEAN Free Trade Agreement in January.

However, the opposition parties, led by the Democratic Progressive Party, are pulling out all the stops to block the pact out of concern that it would integrate the island more closely into China and result in damage to Taiwan's sovereignty.
Ma is slated to defend his policy in a public debate with DPP Chairperson Tsai Ing-wen on April 25.

DOC.HEADLINE: Water-splashing festival celebrated in Taiwan
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, April 11 (CNA) 04/11/10 20:54:27 (By Chiu Chun-chin, Huang Hsu-sheng and Maubo Chang)

TEXT.P: The water-splashing festival, called Songkran in Thai, was held in northern Taiwan's Zhonghe, Taipei County and Taoyuan City on Sunday.

In Zhonghe, which boasts the island's largest population of Burmese, the festival was opened by Taipei County Magistrate Chou Hsi-wei. Chou touted his NT$27 million (US$855,000) project to refurbish Zhonghe's Huaxin Street, which is lined with restaurants serving Southeast Asian food, saying that the county's efforts had converted the dilapidated street into a sightseeing spot.
The magistrate hardly finished his opening speech when he was hit by a volley of water gun shots by a group of children near the podium.

Although Songkran is mostly celebrated by people in Southeast Asia to usher in the new year, many local people joined in as well, and the fire department used fire engines to ensure the participants had ample ammunition.

A similar celebration was held at the stadium of Taoyuan City, the capital of Taoyuan County. The county houses more than 20,000 laborers from Thailand, accounting for 25 percent of Thai workers in Taiwan.
The celebration began with a brief speech from Taoyuan County Magistrate Wu Chih-yang, who thanked Thai laborers for their contribution to the country's economy and wished them a happy new year.
The remaining part of the celebration was conducted by a Thai emcee, with a performance by well-known Thai singer Tai Arrathai and other Thai entertainers.
As usual, the festival, the 12th of its kind in Taoyuan, culminated in a fierce water battle among the participants.

DOC.HEADLINE: Green energy to be included in 'bridge-building project': MOEA
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, April 11 (CNA) 04/11/10 21:33:21 (By Lin Shu-yuan and Deborah Kuo)

TEXT.P: Ministry of Economic Affairs (MOEA) officials denied categorically Sunday that green energy development will be included in the "early harvest" lists that precede the proposed economic cooperation framework agreement (ECFA) across the Taiwan Strait.

MOEA officials discounted a local media report that cross-strait cooperation in the development of green energy will be included in the "early harvest" lists as Chinese Vice President Xi Jinping proposed Saturday in his speech to the 2010 Boao Forum for Asia in Hainan province, China.
"We don't have the slightest idea about that," the officials said.

They said that the green energy development plan has been proposed under the "bridge-building project" initiated by the MOEA and aimed at bolstering industrial exchange and cooperation between Taiwan and China.

Even if cross-strait cooperation in green energy development is carried out under the proposed ECFA, it should be included as one of the plans for economic cooperation and has nothing to do with the "early harvest" lists, which are related to tariff and tax concessions, they said.

The MOEA has since 2008 sponsored dozens of "bridge-building" meetings in Taiwan on the use of cleaner production technologies in electronics and the areas of digital content (including e-book/animation/games) , textiles and fibers, biomedicine and aviation maintenance, and industrial waste management.

Similar meetings were also held in China to build "bridges" for the bicycle, precision machinery, automobile, telecommunications, green energy, food, wholesale and retail, e-commerce and logistics industries, they said.

DOC.HEADLINE: Taiwan raises travel alert for Bangkok to red
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, April 11 (CNA) 04/11/10 21:44:29 (By Chen Shun-hsieh and Y.L. Kao)

TEXT.P: After the Ministry of Foreign Affairs raised its travel alert for Bangkok to red Sunday, Taiwanese tourists will have to sign responsibility waivers if they want to travel to the city, according to the Travel Agent Association of R.O.C, Taiwan.
The ministry raised its alert level to red after at least 20 people died and 800 were hurt in clashes between security forces and opposition protesters in the Thai capital.

A red alert -- the highest level in the system -- means that travel agents have to cancel all packaged tours to Bangkok from Monday and offer refunds to their customers after deducting visa and passport fees, said Hsu Kao-ching, secretary-general of the association.
Travelers who were scheduled to depart for Bangkok Monday were being informed individually, Hsu added.
The stipulations do not apply to passengers only transiting at Bangkok airport, Hsu said.
Refunds will likely include the cost of airline tickets and hotel deposits, a travel agent said Sunday.
Meanwhile, both China Airlines and EVA Air said they will offer full refunds to those who already booked tickets.

The announcement of a red alert stirred mixed reactions from outgoing travelers. Some at Taiwan Taoyuan International Airport expressed concern about their safety and said they received the information too late to change their itineraries.
Others, however, said they weren't worried and would go on with their trips as planned.

DOC.HEADLINE: Boao delegates call for prompt signing of ECFA
DOC.DATELINE: Boao, China, April 11 (CNA) 04/11/10 22:02:25 (By Erin Ho and Sofia Wu)

TEXT.P: Taiwanese and Chinese delegates to a roundtable meeting in Boao, China unanimously called Sunday for the two sides of the Taiwan Strait to sign a proposed economic cooperation framework agreement (ECFA) as early as possible.
The meeting was part of the Boao Forum for Asia, an annual event that brings together politicians, economists and business executives to discuss regional development strategies.
Frederick Chien, a veteran diplomat who heads the Taiwanese delegation, and former Tianjin Mayor Dai Xianglong co-chaired the roundtable session.
"Signing the ECFA is just a matter of course for the two sides, " Dai said at the opening of the session.
Stressing that both sides will benefit from the deal, Dai said he sees no reasons for any delay in striking the deal.
Chien echoed Dai's views, expressing his hope that the agreement can be signed by June as scheduled.

On Saturday, Chien met with Chinese Vice President Xi Jinping for wide-ranging talks. During their meeting, Xi also expressed support for prompt signing of ECFA, widely seen as a scaled-back free trade agreement (FTA).

Taiwan is working hard to conclude ECFA talks with China in hopes that the deal will facilitate its participation in regional economic integration and its bid to sign FTAs with its major trade partners.
Without striking an ECFA deal with China, many countries that maintain diplomatic ties with China seem to be reluctant to hold FTA talks with Taiwan for fears of offending Beijing.

DOC.HEADLINE: Taiwan's green investment accounts for 1% of GDP: CEPD
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, April 11 (CNA) 04/11/10 20:43:57 (By Hsieh Chun-wei and Sofia Wu)

TEXT.P: Taiwan invested up to 1 percent of its gross domestic product (GDP) in green technology in 2009, compatible with other major countries around the world, the Cabinet-level Council for Economic Planning and Development (CEPD) said Sunday.

According to data released by the United Nations Environmental Programme (UNEP) , 15.4 percent of the US$3.163 trillion that countries around the world funneled into various economic stimulus packages as of June 2009 was channeled into the green sector, accounting for 0.7 percent of global GDP.

In terms of UNEP data, the council said in a statement that Taiwan matched the general world standard in green investment last year as the government spent NT$133.9 billion (US$4.25 billion) , about 1 percent of the country's GDP, in the green sector.
The report said China led the world in terms of green investment in 2009, pumping in US$216.4 billion or 3 percent of its GDP.
The United States came in second, with US$94.1 billion or 0.7 percent of GDP, followed by South Korea with US$36.3 billion or 3 percent of its GDP and Japan at US$36 billion or 0.8 percent.

In terms of per capita green investment, South Korea topped all other countries, with US$1,238 per person, and up to 95.2 percent of its stimulus package was funneled into the green sector, the CEPD said.

With global warming becoming a major concern, the CEPD said, the development of low-carbon industries is the wave of the future. In line with the trend, it added, the government has launched 10 landmark projects, with the goal of raising the energy efficiency by 2 percent annually in the next eight years and the annual carbon emission being lowered to the 2000 level by 2025.

DOC.HEADLINE: United Daily News -- Improving health care
DOC.DATELINE: 04/11/10 20:48:33 (By Maubo Chang)

TEXT.P: A plan to revamp the debt-laden National Health Insurance program has been presented to the Legislative Yuan for approval.

It has come under fire from civil groups for sharply rising insurance premiums, from business and industrial groups for putting undue financial burdens on them, and from lawmakers who question its disproportionately heavy premiums for single people.
What is more important is that the plan is intended more to replenish the program than to improve the quality of medical care.

The program, started in 1995, is one of the country's prides -- providing reliable, safe and convenient health care to 99 percent of the population. It is a vital part of the country's social security system and we would never let it collapse because of a lack of funds.
The government's plan is focused on funneling more funds into the program and a hike in premiums is widely anticipated.
As insurance premiums are shared by employers, employees and the government at a ratio of 6: 3: 1, employers have good reason to be concerned.

However, we believe the plan should also improve the medical care it offers, which lies in the adoption of standardized payments for certain treatments and the enhancement of the transparency of medical information.

The legislature's job is to examine whether the proposed premium rates as well as maximum and minimum payments were properly determined, whether to set up a monitoring group to determine premium rates, and how the legislature and civil groups can supervise the new system. (April 11, 2010)

DOC.HEADLINE: Vice president drums up support for trade pact with China
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, April 11 (CNA) 04/11/10 20:49:08 (By Huang Kuo-fang and Maubo Chang)

TEXT.P: Vice President Vincent Siew made a pitch in the southern Taiwan city of Chiayi Sunday for the country's proposed trade pact with China.
In a speech to a local Lions Club, the vice president said the economic cooperation framework agreement is vital to the island's economic development.

Owing to its geographic location on leading regional shipping lines, Siew said Taiwan has engaged actively with other states ever since it began to shift its economic cornerstone from agriculture to industry.
"The history of the last five or six decades has proved that we are moving on the right path," said Siew, who served as the country's economic architect for many years.
The future development of Taiwan's economy rests on industrial innovation, research and development, designing and marketing.
It also rests on its incorporation into international communities in view of the increasing number of regional trade pacts, such as the North American Free Trade Agreement and the European Union.

"Unfortunately, Taiwan was excluded from most of these regional trade blocs due to political reasons, " the vice president said, referring to its long-time political confrontation with China, which has gone out of its way to crowd Taiwan out of international stage.

However, Taiwan's trade pact with China will serve as a stepping stone for the island to move into a prominent position on the international stage and stimulating the United States and Japan to cooperate with Taiwan more closely in the field of economics.

As with any other bilateral agreement, the pact will bring about both positive and negative effects on the island's economy, and what the government should do is to maximize the positive while minimizing the negative.
"We are on a threshold in terms of the country's economic development," the vice president said, adding that Taiwan should not draw in its horns at this critical moment.

President Ma Ying-jeou's administration is working hard to conclude the pact with Beijing in June in hopes of reducing the island's marginalization after the introduction of the China-ASEAN Free Trade Agreement in January.

However, the opposition parties, led by the Democratic Progressive Party, are pulling out all the stops to block the pact out of concern that it would integrate the island more closely into China and result in damage to Taiwan's sovereignty.
Ma is slated to defend his policy in a public debate with DPP Chairperson Tsai Ing-wen on April 25.

DOC.HEADLINE: Water-splashing festival celebrated in Taiwan
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, April 11 (CNA) 04/11/10 20:54:27 (By Chiu Chun-chin, Huang Hsu-sheng and Maubo Chang)

TEXT.P: The water-splashing festival, called Songkran in Thai, was held in northern Taiwan's Zhonghe, Taipei County and Taoyuan City on Sunday.

In Zhonghe, which boasts the island's largest population of Burmese, the festival was opened by Taipei County Magistrate Chou Hsi-wei. Chou touted his NT$27 million (US$855,000) project to refurbish Zhonghe's Huaxin Street, which is lined with restaurants serving Southeast Asian food, saying that the county's efforts had converted the dilapidated street into a sightseeing spot.
The magistrate hardly finished his opening speech when he was hit by a volley of water gun shots by a group of children near the podium.

Although Songkran is mostly celebrated by people in Southeast Asia to usher in the new year, many local people joined in as well, and the fire department used fire engines to ensure the participants had ample ammunition.

A similar celebration was held at the stadium of Taoyuan City, the capital of Taoyuan County. The county houses more than 20,000 laborers from Thailand, accounting for 25 percent of Thai workers in Taiwan.
The celebration began with a brief speech from Taoyuan County Magistrate Wu Chih-yang, who thanked Thai laborers for their contribution to the country's economy and wished them a happy new year.
The remaining part of the celebration was conducted by a Thai emcee, with a performance by well-known Thai singer Tai Arrathai and other Thai entertainers.
As usual, the festival, the 12th of its kind in Taoyuan, culminated in a fierce water battle among the participants.

DOC.HEADLINE: Green energy to be included in 'bridge-building project': MOEA
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, April 11 (CNA) 04/11/10 21:33:21 (By Lin Shu-yuan and Deborah Kuo)

TEXT.P: Ministry of Economic Affairs (MOEA) officials denied categorically Sunday that green energy development will be included in the "early harvest" lists that precede the proposed economic cooperation framework agreement (ECFA) across the Taiwan Strait.

MOEA officials discounted a local media report that cross-strait cooperation in the development of green energy will be included in the "early harvest" lists as Chinese Vice President Xi Jinping proposed Saturday in his speech to the 2010 Boao Forum for Asia in Hainan province, China.
"We don't have the slightest idea about that," the officials said.

They said that the green energy development plan has been proposed under the "bridge-building project" initiated by the MOEA and aimed at bolstering industrial exchange and cooperation between Taiwan and China.

Even if cross-strait cooperation in green energy development is carried out under the proposed ECFA, it should be included as one of the plans for economic cooperation and has nothing to do with the "early harvest" lists, which are related to tariff and tax concessions, they said.

The MOEA has since 2008 sponsored dozens of "bridge-building" meetings in Taiwan on the use of cleaner production technologies in electronics and the areas of digital content (including e-book/animation/games) , textiles and fibers, biomedicine and aviation maintenance, and industrial waste management.

Similar meetings were also held in China to build "bridges" for the bicycle, precision machinery, automobile, telecommunications, green energy, food, wholesale and retail, e-commerce and logistics industries, they said.

DOC.HEADLINE: Taiwan raises travel alert for Bangkok to red
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, April 11 (CNA) 04/11/10 21:44:29 (By Chen Shun-hsieh and Y.L. Kao)

TEXT.P: After the Ministry of Foreign Affairs raised its travel alert for Bangkok to red Sunday, Taiwanese tourists will have to sign responsibility waivers if they want to travel to the city, according to the Travel Agent Association of R.O.C, Taiwan.
The ministry raised its alert level to red after at least 20 people died and 800 were hurt in clashes between security forces and opposition protesters in the Thai capital.

A red alert -- the highest level in the system -- means that travel agents have to cancel all packaged tours to Bangkok from Monday and offer refunds to their customers after deducting visa and passport fees, said Hsu Kao-ching, secretary-general of the association.
Travelers who were scheduled to depart for Bangkok Monday were being informed individually, Hsu added.
The stipulations do not apply to passengers only transiting at Bangkok airport, Hsu said.
Refunds will likely include the cost of airline tickets and hotel deposits, a travel agent said Sunday.
Meanwhile, both China Airlines and EVA Air said they will offer full refunds to those who already booked tickets.

The announcement of a red alert stirred mixed reactions from outgoing travelers. Some at Taiwan Taoyuan International Airport expressed concern about their safety and said they received the information too late to change their itineraries.
Others, however, said they weren't worried and would go on with their trips as planned.

DOC.HEADLINE: Today in history
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, April 12 (CNA) 04/12/10 08:40:29
DOC.TEXT:
Today is Monday, April 12, or the 28th day of the second month of the Year of the Tiger according to the lunar calendar. Following is a list of important events that have occurred on this date in the past:
1606: The Union Jack becomes the United Kingdom's official flag.
1860: Vajirananavarorasa, prince and patriarch of Buddhism in Siam, is born. He institutionalized Thai Buddhism.
1861: The U.S. Civil War breaks out as Confederate forces under Gen. Pierre Beauregarde take Fort Sumter in Charlestown harbor, South Carolina.
1927: The Kuomintang starts a "purification" movement by expelling communist members.
1945: U.S. President Franklin D. Roosevelt dies in office at the age of 63. Vice President Harry S. Truman is sworn in as his successor.
1949: The 37.5 Per Cent Farm Rental Reduction Program goes into effect in Taiwan.
1953: The Legislative Yuan passes a bill submitted by President Chiang Kai-shek, extending the term of office for legislators by an additional year, to May 7, 1954.
1958: The first national meeting for commending "Good Men and Good Deeds" is held at Chung Shan Hall in Taipei.
1961: The Russians put the first man into space when cosmonaut Yauri Gargarin is launched in the Vostok I space vehicle for a single orbit of the earth.
1963: Indonesian forces launch an armed attack against Malaysia as part of a new policy of confrontation.
1966: Cheng Wan-fu, former chairman of the "Taiwan Democratic Party" and a leader of the "Taiwan Independence Movement" in Tokyo, returns to Taipei after 20 years of self-imposed exile in Japan.
1973: Deng Xiaoping, who was purged during the Cultural Revolution, resumes his position as the vice premier of Communist China.
1973: Vietnamese President Nguyen Van Thieu and his wife arrive in Taipei for a visit.
1974: Economic Affairs Vice Minister K.S. Chang, leading a group of government officials and businessmen, depart for San Francisco to attend a Sino-U.S. conference on economic relations.
1974: Tsinghwa University completes the installation of its second nuclear reactor for research purposes. This is the fourth research reactor installed in Taiwan.
1975: President Yen Chia-kan calls on the people to carry out the Last Testament of the late President Chiang Kai-shek.
1975: Taipei building contractors pledge NT$1 million to start a fund-raising campaign for the proposed Chiang Kai-shek Memorial Hall.
1979: Taiwan's first geothermal power plant formally begins operations.
1981: Joe Louis, American prize fighter, dies at the age of 67. He held the heavyweight title for nearly 12 years (1937-1949), successfully defending it a record 25 times.
1981: Columbia, the world's first reusable space shuttle, is launched at Cape Canaveral.
1983: China Airlines inaugurates its regular flight service to Amsterdam as the first step toward establishing worldwide commercial air services.
1989: Honduran President Jose Azcona Hoyo and his wife arrive in Taipei for a visit.
1994: The Mainland Affairs Council decides to suspend all cultural and educational exchanges with the mainland until Beijing provides reasonable and satisfactory explanations for the Qiandao Lake tragedy of March 31 in which 24 Taiwan tourists were killed.
1996: The Petronas Towers in Kuala Lumpur, Malaysia, are declared the world's tallest buildings.
2000: Republic of China Premier Vincent Siew meets with Guenter Rexrodt, a former German economics minister, to exchange views on bilateral relations between the two countries.
2001: an IBM-Linux Development Center is inaugurated in Taiwan. The center will provide local individual and group users with system testing, technical exchanges, experience sharing and training on using the Linux operating system.
Confucius' lesson of the day: "There are wise men who are not moral characters; but a fool is never a moral character."

DOC.HEADLINE: No Taiwan nationals injured in Solomon Islands earthquake: MOFA
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, April 12 (CNA) 04/12/10 11:01:16 (By Lee Ming-chung and Elizabeth Hsu)

TEXT.P: No one at the Taiwan embassy or the technical mission in the Solomon Islands was injured in a 7.1-magnitude earthquake that struck the South Pacific island state Sunday, according to the Ministry of Foreign Affairs (MOFA).

MOFA spokesman Henry Chen said late Sunday that the ministry made several phone calls to Taiwan Ambassador George Chan immediately after the earthquake and was assured that the embassy staff and technical mission members as well as their families were all safe.
Ambassador Chan contacted Solomon Islands Prime Minister Derek Sikua and its police commissioner to obtain information in the aftermath of the quake and to extend Taiwan's sympathy, Chen said.
Meanwhile, Foreign Minister Timothy C.T. Yang has instructed Chan to provide any possible aid to the Solomon Islands, one of Taiwan's allies in the region, Chen said.

According to other MOFA officials, local media outlets have learned that some people in a remote tribal village in the Solomon Islands' Isabel Province were injured, but that the damage there was not severe.
The reports cited their source as the chieftain himself, Stanley Tabeva, who made a laborious effort to offer aid to the victims of Typhoon Morakot in Taiwan last year.
On Monday, the China Times reported that the village had suffered some damage during the earthquake and that Tabeva's wife had sustained minor leg injuries.
According to foreign wire reports, the earthquake hit the Solomon Islands at 8.40 p.m. Sunday. The epicenter of the quake was located 97 kilometers southwest off Kira Kira in the Pacific Ocean.
No tsunami warning had yet been issued yet, the reports stated.

The Solomon Islands, which is located in the South pacific Ocean east of Papua New Guinea, consists of nearly 1,000 islands. It covers a land mass of 27,986 square kilometers. The capital, Honiara, is on the island of Guadalcanal.

DOC.HEADLINE: Taipei City's last green area may soon disappear
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, April 12 (CNA) 04/12/10 11:54:44 (By Sofia Wu)

TEXT.P: Long-term control by the military helped save a tract of land in metropolitan Taipei from development and thus preserve its natural ecology, but the situation may change soon, as part of the area will be bulldozed to make way for a biotechnology park.

The 185-hectare area in Nangang district near Academia Sinica originally housed a military equipment production facility, commonly known as Factory No. 202, under the jurisdiction of the Ministry of National Defense (MND).

The factory complex comprises three sections, with the administrative and weaponry production facilities in the west wing and the ammunitions workshop occupying the other two-thirds of the compound, MND sources said.

Based on security concerns, only one-third of the factory staff are allowed to enter the ammunitions workshop, the sources said, adding that the restriction has helped protect the natural ecology in the area.

The three ponds on the site not only contribute to the beautiful scenery but are also ideal natural habitats for a wide variety of aquatic plants and waterbirds, the sources said. Even some endangered species, such as Formosan blue magpies and hawks, nest in the area.

However, the landscape may soon change as the the military, under instructions from the Executive Yuan, has decided to allocate 25.5 hectares of land to Academia Sinica, the country's top academic institution, for a new biotechnology research park.

As a matter of fact, MND sources said, only 35 percent of the Factory No. 202 area is suitable for new construction. The topography of rest of the land is mostly hills and gorges, which makes it unsuitable for construction purposes, the sources said.

Apart from the natural scenery and special ecology on the site, it is also rich in history and culture. The centuries-old cemetery of a senior Qing Dynasty official, an ancient artillery and three temples built centuries ago are all located within the complex.

The MND's Armaments Bureau is scheduled to hand over the 25.5-hectares of land to Academia Sinica next year, but some environmental groups are pushing the Executive Yuan to reconsider its decision. Environmentalists said they hope the area would be retained as an ecological conservation site.

Responding to the call, an Academia Sinica spokesman said that less than 10 hectares of land to be allocated by the MND will be used to build the planned biotech research park, while the remainder will be developed as a recreational area.
The institution will aim for low-impact development of the land in order not to spoil the natural environment, the spokesman added.

DOC.HEADLINE: China Times: Tax cuts will eat into national coffers
DOC.DATELINE: The ruling Kuomintang (KMT) 04/12/10 12:26:32 (By Deborah Kuo)

TEXT.P: and the opposition Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) are engaged in a race to advocate tax cuts for the industrial sector, putting on a pre-election tax holiday show.

The KMT has proposed a new version of an industrial innovation bill that would slash the corporate income tax rate from the current 20 percent to 17 percent and retain four functionary tax breaks, while the DPP has put forth a version that would lower the corporate income tax rate to 17.5 percent but remove the four tax incentives.
This tax cut race by the two parties will eat into government revenues, which already suffered from a record shortfall of more than NT$240 billion in 2009.
What is even more regrettable is that the Ministry of Finance has been sitting idly by in the face of these tax cut race.

Minister of Finance Lee Sush-der has been a target of public criticism. How can a finance minister be so reluctant to defend government policy or to take responsibility to win the electorate's support and trust?

The KMT's version of the bill is likely to clear the legislative floor soon, as it is not expected to encounter much opposition from the DPP. But the bill will only serve to further deplete the national coffers as it will also cater to big industrial players even more than the Statute for Industrial Upgrading which expired at the end of 2009.
The new plan is unfair and ill-advised because it does not include small and medium-sized enterprises or ordinary taxpayers and it leaves very little room for discretionary spending.

However, not all key business players favor the tax cuts. Taiwan Semiconductor Manufacturing Co. Chairman Morris Chang has said that given the current situation, the tax cut proposal is wrong and the government definitely should not cut the tax.
"The business sector should be allowed to stand on its own feet," Chang said.

President Ma Ying-jeou would risk ruining his record in Taiwan's history by condoning an irresponsible tax cut proposal that would leave the country's finances in an unprecedented crisis. (April 12, 2010).

DOC.HEADLINE: Taiwanese lawmakers visit British Parliament to promote exchanges
DOC.DATELINE: London, April 11 (CNA) 04/12/10 12:40:10 (By Jennifer Huang and Elizabeth Hsu)

TEXT.P: Taiwanese lawmakers Chu Fong-chi and Lii Ming-shing of the ruling Kuomintang (KMT) visited the British Parliament over the weekend and met with pro-Taiwan members to exchange opinions on issues concerning bilateral relations.

The visiting legislators, accompanied by Republic of China Representative to the United Kingdom Chang Siao-yue, called on Lord Rosser in the House of Lords -- the upper house -- who is a member of the British-Taiwan all-party parliamentary group.
During a tour of the Parliament, Lord Rosser explained the history of the development of Britain's party politics and how the Parliament runs.

Chu and Lii also met with David Atkinson, a former member of the House of Commons -- the lower house -- who now heads the British branch of the World League for Freedom and Democracy, for a discussion of Taiwan-U.K. ties and the upcoming U.K. elections.
Atkinson, a friend of Taiwan, was active in promoting the development of Taiwan-U.K. relations during his service in the Parliament from 1977 until 2005.

He has visited Taiwan many times and has been deeply impressed by Taiwan's democratic reforms and opening to different cultures, as well as its economic achievements and development of high-tech industries, he said.
Chu and Lii left Taiwan April 7 for their U.K. visit to promote parliamentary exchanges. They were scheduled to return Monday.
Taiwan does not have diplomatic relations with the U.K.

DOC.HEADLINE: Five climbers conquer Taiwan's Coastal Range
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, April 12 (CNA) 04/12/10 14:43:29 (By Lu Tai-cheng and Sofia Wu)

TEXT.P: Five members of the Taiwan Mountain Rescuers Association have the first successful expedition to conquer the Coastal Mountain Range in eastern Taiwan, which they dubbed as "Taiwan's Amazon jungle."

"The 37-day expedition was a challenge because the pristine forest is thick with sturdy wild growth and full of venomous snakes, leeches, mosquitoes and yellow vines (Calamus Burret) , " Ke Cheng-ming, leader of the team, said at the end of the tough 170-kilometer trek Sunday.
Although the range elevates only 600 to 700 meters above sea level and its highest peak is just 1,682 meters, its rugged terrain makes it hard to scale, Ke said.

"Many of its ridge lines are formed by fault breccia... sometimes, we had to brave strong winds to climb the steep cliffs.... I have scaled the Central Mountain Range, Jade Mountain and Syueshan Mountain, but the Coastal Range was the most difficult to conquer, " Ke said.

Because of the Coastal Range's rough topology, no one had ever before completed a vertical exploration of the east coast mountains that stretch 150 kilometers from Hualien County in the north to Taitung County in the south, with the Hsiukuluan River cutting through it.
Ke's team set off March 6 from Hualien Mountain in Hualien County's Shoufeng township and finished Sunday on Shihtou Mountain in Taitung County's Beinan township.
The exploration was part of the Taiwan Forestry Bureau's efforts to document all of the country's peaks.
During its expedition, the team mapped suitable points for the installation of communication facilities, shelter camps, rescue stations, water resources, and rescue helicopter landings and takeoffs.

DOC.HEADLINE: Talk of the day---Business income tax to be cut

TEXT.P: As the ruling and opposition lawmakers squared off over an industrial innovation bill, President Ma Ying-jeou weighed in late Sunday with a five-point argument in support of a business income tax cut.
This rare intervention by the president in a legislative matter made the headlines of leading newspapers Monday. The following are excerpts of their reports: China Times:

President Ma's five-point argument in favor of the tax cuts showed that there is consensus among Presidential Office, the Executive Yuan and the ruling party lawmakers that the business income tax should be cut from 20 percent to 17 percent.

But, the tax breaks offered for personnel training and the establishment of business headquarters and international logistics hubs would be removed. Tax incentives would only be allowed for research and development, in line with the goals of the bill.
But a KMT lawmaker expressed doubts that the R&D category would be approved by the legislature in light of the fact that business income tax will be slashed by 3 percent.

According to one analyst, the loss of government revenue as a result of the business income tax cut will be offset by the increase in revenues from personal income tax derived from higher employment. United Daily News:

The Executive Yuan flip-flopped on the industrial innovation bill when it agreed to slash the business income tax to 17 percent. However, it intends to retain the four categories of tax incentives mentioned in the bill.

The Executive Yuan gave in to KMT lawmakers who insisted that the ruling part should 'outbid' the opposition Democratic Progressive Party, which has suggested a proposed abusiness income tax of 17.5 percent. (April 12, 2010) Economic Daily News:

According to Ministry of Finance (MOF) estimates, government revenue from business income tax will decrease by NT$50 billion a year if the tax rate is cut to 17 percent and the four categories of tax incentives are retained.
If the rate is cut to 17.5 percent and tax incentives are offered in two categories, the revenue will drop by NT$30 billion, the MOF projected.
According to an MOF official, either proposal would be acceptable to the ministry, as lower taxes would encourage multinational corporations to relocate their headquarters to Taiwan.
However, the MOF hopes to exclude the four categories of tax breaks which would entail a lot of paperwork, the official said.

Preston W. Chen, chairman of the Chinese National Federation of Industries, said he don't care whether the tax rate is set at 17 percent or 17.5 percent, as long as the bill is enacted as soon as possible.
"I am very disappointed that the bill has been bogged down in the legislature because of partisan bickering," he said. (April 12, 2010) Commercial Times:
The Legislative Yuan will vote on the industrial innovation bill Friday, and negotiations on the bill will begin Tuesday between the different party caucuses.
In a statement late Sunday night, the president backed the the proposal to lower the business income tax, and KMT lawmakers are expected to follow his lead.
Finance Minister Lee Sush-der, who has defended the 20 percent business income tax rate originally stipulated in the bill, said Sunday he would respect the legislature's decision on the matter.
Even if the tax rate is cut to 17 percent, the decrease in revenue will not be as much as expected, the minister said. (April 12, 2010)

DOC.HEADLINE: Taiwan completes plans for environmental hormone management
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, April 12 (CNA) 04/12/10 15:26:27 (By Lin Szu-yu and Elizabeth Hsu)

TEXT.P: Taiwan has completed plans to control endocrine disrupter substances (EDS), commonly known as environmental hormones, in different stages, the Environmental Protection Administration (EPA) said Monday.

The plans were drawn up by an inter-ministerial task force put together by the EPA, with clear definitions of which ministries and government agencies should be responsible for which fields of EDS management and control, according to an EPA statement.

Endocrine disrupters are exogenous substances that act like hormones in the endocrine system and disrupt the physiological function of endogenous hormones. The U.S. government defines an environmental endocrine or hormone disrupter as "an exogenous agent that interferes with the synthesis, secretion, transport, binding, action, or elimination of natural hormones in the body that are responsible for the maintenance of homeostasis, reproduction, development, and/or behavior."

Taiwan was alerted amid rising concerns in the international community over harm caused by environmental hormones. While endocrine disrupters exist in a wide range of different fields, controlling their spread needs cooperation among a variety of different ministries and government agencies, the EPA said.
To that end, the plans call for six government authorities to be assigned to the management of EDS in their respective fields, according to the statement.

The Department of Health will be responsible for EDS in food, food containers and medical equipment and devices, while the Council of Agriculture will be assigned to EDS in pesticides, feed and agricultural products, the Ministry of Economic Affairs will deal with commodities and toys, the EPA will be responsible for household pesticides, drinking water and indoor air quality, the Ministry of the Interior will deal with green architecture and green construction materials and the Ministry of Finance will handle liquor safety, the statement said.

This year, efforts will also be made to review and modify regulations stipulating the management of environmental hormones in commodities, food products and the environment, such as principles for screening and defining toxic substances, the EPA said.

DOC.HEADLINE: New cluster of endangered Taiwan cow-tail firs sighted
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, April 12 (CNA) 04/12/10 15:26:41 (By Lu Tai-cheng and Deborah Kuo)

TEXT.P: The recent sighting of a new cluster of the endangered Taiwan cow-tail fir in Taitung County gives a shot in the arm to the efforts to protect the rare plant species, officials in charge of forestation said Monday.

About 40 full-grown Taiwan cow-tail firs were found late last year on a mountain ridge 750 meters above sea level in Daren township in the southeastern county of Taitung, said Huang Chun-tse, a division chief with the Forest Bureau under the Cabinet-level Council of Agriculture (COA).
However, the new sighting of the 40 healthy trees has not allayed worry over the risk of extinction of the species, Huang said.

The cow-tail fir is an evergreen giant plant of the Pinaceae family and Keteleeria genus that has existed on Taiwan soil since the Ice Age. A healthy tree usually yields about 100 seedlings, 20 to 30 of which manage to survive, Huang said.
Unfortunately, only two young trees were found in the new cluster, he added.
"Even in the Dawu and Pinglin buffer zones, where some 400 trees are growing, only one or two new plants are seen occasionally," Huang said.

Taiwan cow-tail firs, also known as Formosana Hayata, have been under threat from illegal loggers because of its fine oily wood. It is called one of the four wonder trees in Taiwan, along with Cycas taiwaniana, Amentotaxus formosana Li, and Taiwan date palm.

It is categorized as "critically endangered" by the COA and is listed as one of the 11 rare and precious plants in the country by the Cabinet-level Council for Cultural Affairs. Currently, there are fewer than 500 trees on the island, most of which are found in Pinglin, Taipei County and Dawu, Taitung County, Huang said.

Tung Shih-liang, director of the Taitung Forest District Office's Guanshan Station, said the Taiwan cow-tail fir is on the verge of extinction because of factors such as logging, typhoons, fires, and climate change. The species' narrow gene pool is another major reason why it is declining, he added.
"Expanding its gene pool may help it to develop greater adaptability to environmental changes," Tung suggested.
