DOC.HEADLINE: Taiwan share prices close higher
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, April 12 (CNA) 04/12/10 15:38:39 (By Olivia Wang)

TEXT.P: Taiwan's share prices closed higher Monday with the weighted index, the market's key barometer, moving up 25.72 points, or 0.31 percent, to close at 8,117.75.
The local bourse opened at 8,149.76 and fluctuated between a low of 8,092.94 and a high of 8,152.53 during the day's trading. Market turnover totaled NT$105.91 billion (US$3.36 billion).

Six of the eight major stock categories gained ground, with textile shares gaining the most at 2.5 percent. Paper and pulp issues rose 0.9 percent, cement issues and construction shares edged up 0.7 percent, plastics and chemicals were up 0.4 percent and machinery and electronics shares gained 0.2 percent.
Foodstuff shares dropped 0.4 percent, and financial and banking stocks remained unchanged.
Losers outnumbered gainers 1,625 to 1,468, with 285 remaining unchanged.
Foreign investors and Chinese QDIIs were net buyers of NT$ 3.55 billion-worth of shares.

DOC.HEADLINE: Asia's biggest auto parts, electronics shows open in Taipei
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, April 12 (CNA) 04/12/10 15:46:09 (By Alex Jiang)

TEXT.P: The largest auto parts show and automobile electronics show in Asia this year opened together Monday in Taipei, touting eco-friendly products as demand for green energy increases.

"This year's Automobile Electronics Show for the first time offers an area showcasing electrical and hybrid auto parts, " said Chao Yuen-chuan, president and chief executive of the Taiwan External Trade Development Council (TAITRA) , a government-sponsored trade promotion body.
The area was set up as electric vehicles have become a mainstream idea in the future of the automobile industry, he said at an opening ceremony.
"It showcases the technical strength of Taiwan's R&D and manufacturing ability in lithium-iron batteries, motor modules and other key components for electric vehicles, " he added.
The global automobile electronics market is expected to be worth US$176 billion by 2012, said Arthur Chiao, chairman of the Taiwan Electrical and Electronic Manufacturers' Association (TEEMA).
The market will continue to grow thanks to robust growth in the automobile market in Asia and stable demand from markets in Europe and the United States, he told the show's opening ceremony.
Taiwan's competitive edge in information and communications technology (ICT) can help establish the country as a major supplier for the world's automobile electronics industry, he added.
The number of exhibitors at the two shows totaled 1,011 this year, occupying 2,711 booths and representing a 6-percent rise from last year.

"By contrast, exhibitions in other countries have posted declines due to the global financial crisis, " said Huang Chih-peng, head of the Bureau of Foreign Trade under the Ministry of Economic Affairs.
Both shows will run until April 15 at the Taipei World Trade Center's Nangang Exhibition Hall, open only to trade visitors except for the final two days, when they will be open to the general public.
More than 55,000 people from home and 5,500 people from abroad are expected to visit the shows, according to the organizers.

DOC.HEADLINE: Apple Daily -- Foreign Ministry's sluggish response
DOC.DATELINE: 04/12/10 16:55:59 (By Maubo Chang)

TEXT.P: "Slow to respond" has become the Foreign Ministry's signature. It did its duty by issuing an orange travel alert for the Thai capital of Bangkok last Wednesday when large-scale demonstrations took place there.

However, the ministry failed to warn travelers against visiting Bangkok after bloody conflicts erupted between demonstrators and the security forces Saturday, issuing a warning only the following morning.
There are more than 3,000 Taiwanese tourists in Thailand, 2,000 of whom are in Bangkok. If any of them have been injured, what level of responsibility should the ministry be held accountable for?
The ministry has inherited the bureaucratic tradition of the Qing dynasty's Tsungli Yamen, or foreign office, and has become known for its sluggish reactions and its arrogance.

Many ministry officials think that with the diplomatic truce with China in place they do not have to go to great lengths to cement ties with Taiwan's allies. If that is true, should the ministry be wiped out altogether once Taiwan has entered a peace agreement with China?

DOC.HEADLINE: Commercial Times -- Taiwan cannot sit on hands
DOC.DATELINE: 04/12/10 16:56:58 (By Maubo Chang)

TEXT.P: The heads of the ruling and opposition parties are set to have a debate April 25 on whether Taiwan should enter into an economic cooperation framework agreement with China. We regret that an economic option amid the rapid transformation of the global economy has degenerated into an argument over betraying Taiwan versus loving Taiwan.

The agreement of course will give rise to political concerns, but it is more an economic issue. The question is, can Taiwan sit on its hands while the rest of the Asian states are quickly coalescing into a single market?

Free trade blocs have been sprouting up around the world, with Japan having forged trade agreements with the Association of Southeast Asian Nations (ASEAN) , Mexico, Chile, Australia, South Korea and India, while China has made similar agreements with ASEAN, Chile, New Zealand, Australia and South Africa.

There are more such pacts brewing among ASEAN, the United States, the European Union, and South American states. Amid this proliferation of free trade agreements, Taiwan is becoming increasingly isolated and is watching its trade power declining year by year.

By export volume, Taiwan ranked 14 in the world in 2000, two places behind South Korea, but had fallen to 17 in 2009 compared with South Korea's 9. With its exports less than half of those of South Korea, how can Taiwan resign itself to the downward spiral?
Huang Chih-peng, director-general of the Bureau of Foreign Trade, said in a televised debate that " the question is how to conclude the pact, not whether to conclude the pact or not."

Some critics ask why the government would seek such a deal with China, rather than other states. The fact is Taiwan has tried to negotiate such pacts with the United States, Japan, the European Union and ASEAN for many years but has got nowhere, probably because of Chinese disapproval.

However, China is Taiwan's biggest export market, accounting for 31 percent of the country's exports compared to 11.3 percent for the United States, 10.9 percent for the European Union and 6.4 percent for Japan, so it is only natural that we should seek to enter into such a deal with China.
We fully agree with Huang Chih-peng's view that the question is how, not whether, to conclude the pact.
Anyone who is concerned about the island's future should do his part to help with the negotiation of the deal rather than trying to block it. (April 12, 2010)

DOC.HEADLINE: More effort needed in tourism industry: AmCham Kaohsiung
DOC.DATELINE: Kaohsiung, April 12 (CNA) 04/12/10 17:09:19 (By Emmanuelle Tseng and Fanny Liu)

TEXT.P: Kaohsiung needs to spend more effort developing its tourism industry and doing so would also benefit the local production industry, the American Chamber of Commerce in Kaohsiung (AmCham Kaohsiung) said in its first white paper, which is scheduled to be released Thursday.

The report, which focuses on Kaohsiung City and County, is based on 1,737 questionnaires AmCham Kaohsiung sent to companies beginning last year to collect views and offer suggestions on southern Taiwan's business environment.

Brian Aiello, president of AmCham Kaohsiung, said that as Kaohsiung City and Kaohsiung County will merge into a special municipality by the end of this year, there will not only be difficulties and challenges, but also a lot of opportunities.

Aiello said that Taiwan is one of the most beautiful islands he has ever been to and that Kaohsiung should pay better attention to understand what will really attract foreign tourists and meet their expectations.

A tourism industry that relies on Chinese tourists would be "fragile," he said, noting that the visit of Tibet's exiled spiritual leader the Dalai Lama affected the tourism business in Kaohsiung for several months last year.
To develop local tourism, Aiello said that signs at popular tourist spots should be presented in three languages -- Chinese, English and Japanese.
Aiello said that he hopes the white paper will help southern Taiwan build a friendly business environment and attract more foreign investment in the hi- tech, green technology and tourism industries.

For more than 20 years, the American Chamber of Commerce in Taipei has released white papers focusing mostly on northern Taiwan, Aiello said, adding that AmCham Kaohsiung would expand its survey area to other regions in southern Taiwan next year.

DOC.HEADLINE: Trade pact with China will not affect local workers: president
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, April 12 (CNA) 04/12/10 17:25:00 (By Lee Su-hua and Y.L. Kao)

TEXT.P: President Ma Ying-jeou assured labor representatives Monday that the government will not open Taiwan to Chinese workers in the cross-Taiwan Strait economic framework cooperation agreement (ECFA) that is currently being negotiated.
Ma also dismissed reports that the controversial trade pact will cost 3 million workers their jobs.

During a meeting with representatives from various labor unions, Ma praised local workers for their contributions to Taiwan's economic development, and he tried to mitigate their concerns about the proposed ECFA.

The president argued that Taiwan's economic recovery should be joined together with the process of Asia-Pacific regional integration, and it was "based on this consideration that we have been negotiating the trade pact with China," he said.

Ma reassured his audience that no labor issue has been included in talks on the cross-strait economic pact, and he guaranteed the labor representatives that no Chinese workers would be allowed to work in Taiwan.
He also promised that his administration will develop complementary measures to fully protect Taiwanese workers when the trade accord is signed.
Ma noted that a special article on employment protection has already been added to an industrial innovation bill which is still being considered in the Legislative Yuan.

The bill would provide subsidies of NT$10,000 per month for six months for each worker hired by small- and medium-sized enterprises and businesses in conventional industries, such as textiles, metals, and basic machinery, and the period could be extended to one year under special circumstances.
The measure indicates that the government aims to help not only high-tech and big companies but also smaller companies as well, Ma said.

During the meeting, National Trade Union Confederation President Jen Moo-shan complained that labor groups have had difficulty meeting with the president since he took office two years ago, compared to the considerable time he has spent meeting with owners of big enterprises.
Jen suggested that Ma allocate more time for talks with workers to hear their opinions.
In response, Ma told the Council of Labor Affairs to arrange forums for local workers and said that he himself will also attend if his schedule permits him to go.

DOC.HEADLINE: Taiwan will be isolated without ECFA: Premier
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, April 12 (CNA) 04/12/10 17:28:16 (By Lin Hui-chun and Fanny Liu)

TEXT.P: Premier Wu Den-yih said Monday that reaching an economic cooperation framework agreement (ECFA) with China will prevent Taiwan's isolation, and that the focus should be on its contents rather than on whether or not it should be signed.

The key point of debate should be how the deal can best serve Taiwan's interests and how it can be crafted to have the least impact on local industries, Wu said while addressing the 20th National Quality Award Ceremony at the Ministry of Economic Affairs.
If Taiwan does not sign the ECFA with China, it may lose big opportunities and trigger deeper economic contraction, the premier argued.
Wu said the government must do its best to sign the best deal and is willing to be supervised by the people, the legislature, opposition parties and the private sector.

The government is planning to allocate a budget of NT$95 billion (US$3 billion) over a 10-year period to assist workers in vulnerable industries after Taiwan signs the ECFA with China, the premier said last Friday.
Calling Taiwan's people the country's biggest asset in the face of limited natural resources, Wu said the persistence, diligence and hard work of the people had helped spur the country's development.
But facing tough global competition, Taiwan still needs to become more closely integrated with the Asia-Pacific region or it will become easily marginalized, Wu argued.
Taiwan and China are expected to hold the third round of ECFA talks in China soon, after concluding their second round of talks in Taiwan in early April.

The talks, which took place in Taoyuan County March 31-April 1, made little progress toward forging a consensus on the agreement's "early harvest lists" drawn up by the two sides for priority tariff treatment or access.

DOC.HEADLINE: Migratory butterflies linger in the south
DOC.DATELINE: Kaohsiung, April 12 (CNA) 04/12/10 18:06:59 (By Chen Shou-kuo and Deborah Kuo)

TEXT.P: Many purple crow butterflies are lingering in southern Taiwan longer than usual this year, a group of butterfly conservationists said Monday.

After wintering in Kaohsiung County's Maolin area, most of the migratory butterfly species returned north as usual, but some appear to have turned further south to the Hengchun Peninsula, said Liao Chin-shan, chief of southern Taiwan operations for the non-profit Taiwan Purple Crow Butterfly Ecological Preservation Association.
Purple crow butterflies usually fly from southern to northern Taiwan in late March and early April.
Liao said butterfly researchers are not sure why some of the butterflies have flown southward from Maolin or Taitung.

But this year and last year's conditions for migration have not been ideal, Liao said, adding that the butterflies only fly north when a south wind is blowing, skies are clear and temperatures are over 28 degrees Celsius.

In order to study the butterflies' behavior, the association invited volunteers to catch, mark and release the species. The work was tough and time-consuming, Liao said, but so far little results have been found because very few of the marked butterflies have been recaptured.
As the annual migration route crosses roads at rates of more than 300 per minute, the National Freeway Bureau seals off some sections of freeways to facilitate the butterflies' travel.
The migration has also attracted the attention of foreign mass media, including the BBC, CNN and National Geographic.
Recorded migration of purple crow butterflies in Taiwan dates back to 1971.

DOC.HEADLINE: Taiwanese diplomat visits Italy's Catania to promote city sisterhood
DOC.DATELINE: Rome, April 11 (CNA) 04/12/10 18:10:45 (By Huang Yia-shi and Elizabeth Hsu)

TEXT.P: Taiwan's representative to Italy, Yih Jung-tzung, visited the Italian province of Catania on the island of Sicily Sunday, and paid a call on the provincial governor, Giuseppe Castiglione.

During the meeting, they discussed proposals for cooperation between Taiwan and the province, including a plan for the province's capital city, also called Catania, to forge sisterhood ties with Kaohsiung City in southern Taiwan, according to Taiwan's representative office in Italy.
The office said it is convinced the planned sisterhood ties will help boost cultural and trade exchanges between Italy and Taiwan.

Yih stated that although the world and Taiwan suffered an economic recession in 2009, Italy enjoyed a trade surplus of US$44 million with Taiwan that year, thanks to its exports of olive oil and wine.

There is still room in the Taiwan market for exploration by Italian exporters, Yih said, suggesting that Italian enterprises could cooperate with Taiwanese businesses in tapping the vast China market, amid ongoing talks between Taiwan and China on a proposed trade pact.

Yih also expressed to Castiglione -- who has served as a member of the European Parliament -- his wish that Castiglione could help Taiwan's bid for Shengen visa-waiver treatment for Taiwanese travelers.
He also presented to the governor a copy of a painting by Italian Jesuit missionary Lang Shihling (1688-1766) who served as a court painter in China's Qing dynasty.

Lang, who was also christened Giuseppe Castiglione, represents the origin of exchanges between Italy and China, Yih said, expressing hope for continued friendship and cooperation between the two nations.

DOC.HEADLINE: Tour groups leave for Bangkok despite red travel alert
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, April 12 (CNA) 04/12/10 18:12:58 (By Beien Chin-feng and Y.L. Kao)

TEXT.P: Several tour groups left for Bangkok Monday, despite a red travel alert for the Thai capital issued a day earlier by the Ministry of Foreign Affairs (MOFA).

The MOFA raised its travel alert from orange to red -- the highest level on its four-tier travel advisory alert system -- as clashes between Thai anti- government protesters and security forces intensified.

Taiwanese tourists were asked to sign responsibility waivers before traveling to the city and the members of one tour group were asked to sign a hastily scrawled agreement at Taiwan Taoyuan International Airport shortly before boarding their flight, which raised questions about the validity of the agreement, although all agreed to sign.

Some of the travelers said they were going to Pattaya, not Bangkok, and that they would avoid areas where the bloody clashes were taking place, adding that they were not terribly worried about their safety.

Among other passengers bound for Bangkok, some said they were returning to Bangkok for work, while others said they were going home. All of them noted that they decided to go ahead with their travel plans after making inquiries about the situation there.
Meanwhile, those who arrived in Taiwan after transiting through Bangkok airport said they were not worried about their safety because the situation at the airport was not serious.

DOC.HEADLINE: Labor rights group plans to take to streets May 1 over wage decline
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, April 12 (CNA) 04/12/10 18:20:30 (By Chen Shun-hsieh and Sofia Wu)

TEXT.P: The Taiwan Confederation of Trade Unions (TCTU) said Monday it plans to organize a street rally on May 1 to protest what it calls the "obviously inequitable distribution of wealth in the country."
"We will mobilize at least 10,000 members to take to the streets on May Day to protest declines in real wages," TCTU Secretary-General Hsieh Chuang-chih said at a news conference.

Citing figures from the Cabinet-level Directorate General of Budget, Accounting and Statistics, Hsieh said the average monthly wage of employed individuals was NT$42,509 (US$1,303.96) in 2009, but the real, or inflation-adjusted, wage was only NT$40,690, lower than the NT$41,874 recorded in 2000.
Even though Taiwan's gross domestic product (GDP) contracted last year because of the global financial crisis, Hsieh said, the country still posted a 30 percent growth in GDP over the past decade.
"The decline in real wages indicates that the benefits of our economic growth have all been taken by capitalists," Hsieh said.
Worse still, he added, 70 percent of the country's tax revenues come from wage earners, a phenomenon that has exacerbated inequitable income distribution in local society.

While wage earners are growing poorer, the government has failed to come up with any effective measures to alleviate the situation, instead simply blaming the global economic downturn for their plight, Hsieh argued.

He also accused the government of favoring employers over employees, citing its efforts to pass an industrial innovation bill and sign an economic cooperation framework agreement (ECFA) with China while turning a deaf ear to labor group calls for early passage of amendments to the Labor Standards Act and the legislation of laws governing dispatched workers and labor unions.
Dispatched workers refer to those who work for manpower agencies and are "dispatched" full-time to companies on a contract basis.
Some companies prefer this arrangement because of the flexibility it gives them in managing their work forces and because they do not have to pay benefits or severance to the contract workers.
Because of the disparity in treatment between employers and workers, Hsieh said the federation needed to take to the streets to call on the government to heed the appeals of regular workers.

Dubbing the May 1 demonstration as an anti-poverty march, Hsieh said the federation will highlight four appeals -- "fighting poverty and forbidding dispatched work, " "labor union autonomy, " "labor participation in and democratic supervision of ECFA, " and "allowing all wage earners to receive monthly pensions."
Hsieh said the confederation has asked all of its member groups to begin preparations for the May 1 Labor Day demonstration.

DOC.HEADLINE: Mayor hopes some stilt homes can be preserved
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, April 12 (CNA) 04/12/10 18:34:46 (By Hao Hsueh-chin and Deborah Kuo)

TEXT.P: Taichung Mayor Jason Hu expressed hope Monday that some of the 30-odd stilt homes built along the banks of the Green River can be preserved as a historical site.

The stilt homes -- built along the river's banks six decades ago as shelters for Nationalist soldiers who moved to Taiwan in the wake of a Chinese civil war in 1949 -- are scheduled to be torn down soon as part of a railway development project.
The central Taiwan city's mayor said that if some of the buildings can be preserved, as called for by some residents, they can serve as cultural and historical relics of the post-war era.
Huang Kuo-jung, chief of the Cultural Affairs Bureau, Taichung City, said the bureau was planning to make a documentary about the stilt homes.
However, he added that "the bureau will not seek to have the homes preserved because all the buildings were built illegally and will eventually be dismantled."

Taichung City Deputy Mayor Hsiao Chia-chi, meanwhile, said there was still hope that some stilt homes on one side of the river can be retained because the railway project will only affect the other side.

DOC.HEADLINE: International Lego robotics competition to be held in Kaohsiung
DOC.DATELINE: Kaohsiung, April 12 (CNA) 04/12/10 19:00:32 (By Cheng Che-fon and Fanny Liu)

TEXT.P: The First Lego League (FLL) Open International Championship (OIC), a robotics competition for students aged 9-16, is scheduled to be held in Kaohsiung May 6-8, an organizer of the event said Monday.
It will be the first time the FLL OIC has been held in Taiwan since the competition started in the United States in 1989, and 64 teams from 23 countries will be competing, the organizer said.
Eight teams from Taiwan -- including three elementary school teams from the host city Kaohsiung -- will take part.

Kaohsiung Mayor Chen Ju said the theme of this year's challenge is "Smart Move." The students are required to design and produce robots three months ahead of the contest, as well as work out solutions to various problems they are given.
"It is just as difficult as writing a doctoral thesis, " Chen said at a press conference to announce the competition.
Su Hsu-sheng, a fifth-grader from the Kaohsiung Municipal Ling-Jhou Primary School team, said that speaking English to attract the judges' attention at the contest will be a great challenge for him.

According to its official website, the competition consists of two parts -- presentation and robot performance, in which sensor- equipped robots built by the students out of Lego are required to gain access to places and things, while avoiding or surviving impact.
The performance match will last for two-and-a-half minutes, and the tournament will run for three rounds.

DOC.HEADLINE: WiMAX Forum Congress Asia comes to Taipei
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, April 12 (CNA) 04/12/10 19:33:20 (By Alex Jiang)

TEXT.P: An international organization that focuses on WiMAX wireless technology will open its third annual trade show Tuesday in Taipei, the organizer said.
WiMAX Forum Congress Asia, which runs through April 14 at the Taipei International Convention Center, will be held in Taiwan for the first time.
The event will be attended by more than 2,000 representatives from around the world, according to the WiMAX Forum Web site.
Established in 2001, the industry-led organization has hundreds of members worldwide, comprising the majority of operators, component vendors and equipment vendors in the communications field.
The event will also feature a Taiwanese pavilion in association with Taiwan's semi-official Industrial Technology Research Institute (ITRI) to showcase local WiMAX technology.
WiMAX is forecast to have 130 million subscribers by 2013, according to the Web site.

DOC.HEADLINE: Do not be fooled by false Nanomark label on cosmetics: official
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, April 12 (CNA) 04/12/10 19:56:05 (By Chen Ching-hung and Lillian Lin)

TEXT.P: A Taipei city government health official said Monday that no locally produced foodstuffs or cosmetics have passed the Nanoproduct testing and that the NanoMark Certification labeling on many foodstuffs and cosmetics are not genuine.

Chiu Yiu-ling of the city government's Department of Health was replying to several city council members during an interpellation session who suggested that some shops have been found selling cosmetic products such as facial masks and soaps, as well as coffee and nutritional supplements, bearing NanoMark certificates on their packaging, for much higher prices.

According to council member Huang Shan Shan, only 15 categories of items produced by 20 local enterprises have been given the NanoMark certification issued by the Ministry of Economic Affairs, and the some 400 items that have genuine NanoMark certificates are household electrical appliances, textile products, and other industrial products. The quality of the cosmetics and foodstuffs with Nanoproduct labels are questionable, according to the city councilwoman.
Chiu pointed out that it is illegal to sell products with false labeling and said the city government will conduct an investigation into the matter.

DOC.HEADLINE: Israeli, British choreographers to present works in Taipei in May
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei April 12 (CNA) 04/12/10 20:07:08 (By Sunnie Chen)

TEXT.P: Award-winning choreographers from Israel and Britain will present some of their work at Novel Hall in Taipei in May, Lin Hwai-min, the artistic director of the Novel Dance Series 2010.
The Israeli choreographer, Emanuel Gat, will present "Winter Voyage, " "Silent Ballet" and "The Rite of Spring" during his fist visit to Taiwan May 14-16.
Born in 1969, Gat studied music at the Tel Aviv Academy but switched to choreography after attending a workshop for amateurs led by Israeli choreographer Nir Ben Gal.

Gat joined the Liat Dror Nir Ben Gal Company at the age of 23, with which he toured the world. He founded his own dance group in 2004 and staged the premieres of "Winter Voyage" and "The Rite of Spring" that same year.
"The 14-minute duet of `Winter Voyage' that Gat performs with Roy Assaf shows the masculine, powerful and unique styles for which they have received rave acclaim around the world," Lin said.
Lin also noted that Gat received a New York Dance and Performance Award, informally known as a Bessie award, for presenting the programs at the Lincoln Center Festival in New York in 2008.
The British dance artist is Akram Khan, who will return to his classical Indian dance roots to present his latest solo work titled "Gnosis," which will be performed May 21-23.

Khan has been the recipient of numerous awards throughout his career. Making his fourth visit to Taipei, the choreographer-dancer will present a piece that Lin described as having the most amazing tempo and dialogue between the music and the dancers.

DOC.HEADLINE: Corporate income tax breaks to cost NT$34.3 billion in revenues
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, April 12 (CNA) 04/12/10 20:33:16 (By Justin Su and Lilian Wu)

TEXT.P: Finance Minister Lee Sush-der said Monday that additional cuts in Taiwan's corporate income tax should enhance the country's international competitiveness but will cost national coffers NT$34.3 billion (US$1.09 billion) in tax revenues.

Lee based the estimate on a consensus reached by ruling Kuomintang (KMT) lawmakers on the terms of a controversial industrial innovation bill that the government considers essential to encouraging innovation and investment in Taiwan.

The caucus decided to keep targeted tax incentives for innovation and R&D included in a previous version of the bill but dump those for training and setting up operations headquarters and logistics centers.
It also decided to add a provision to cut the corporate income tax from the current 20 percent to 17 percent, creating a package that would cost the government NT$34.3 billion, Lee estimated.

In comparison, a plan suggested by the opposition Democratic Progressive Party to simply cut corporate income taxes to 17.5 percent and eliminate all targeted tax incentives would cost the government approximately NT$17.5 billion in tax revenues, Lee estimated.

The finance minister also said a key benefit of the new tax cut package in the bill would be that they would streamline the operations of companies and the government, leaving only innovation and R&D among more than 30 categories of tax breaks on investment under previous regulations.
If the bill is approved, the new corporate income tax will be similar to that of Singapore, which Lee said will increase the nation's international competitiveness.
Taiwan had only just recently reduced its corporate income tax from 25 percent to 20 percent, a reduction that took effect on income beginning in 2010.

Meanwhile, the Ministry of Finance announced that tax revenues in March totaled NT$151.4 billion, up NT$52.6 billion, or 53.2 percent year-on-year, mainly because corporate income tax receipts were up NT$29.8 billion from March 2009.

DOC.HEADLINE: Caregivers to form backbone of foreign work force in Taiwan
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, April 12 (CNA) 04/12/10 20:57:26 (By Sofia Wu)

TEXT.P: Caregivers will eventually become the mainstay of Taiwan's foreign work force if the government fails to quickly launch a well-devised long-term care system to deal with the country's aging population, a labor affairs official said Monday.
According to the latest figures from the Council of Labor Affairs (CLA) , foreign caregivers outnumbered foreign manual laborers in February for the first time ever in Taiwan, 177,926 to 177,210.

Although the trend reversed itself in March, with the 180,000 migrant workers in manual labor jobs slightly outnumbering the 179,000 migrant caregivers, the CLA official expected that caregivers will form the backbone of the foreign work force in the long run.

"The demand for caregiving services will continue rising along with the aging of our population, if no long-term care system is put in place soon, " said the official, who spoke on condition of anonymity.
Taiwan began to import migrant workers in 1989 to make up for labor shortages in manufacturing and construction sectors where harsh working conditions existed.
Early on, the number of foreign workers in the manufacturing sector consistently far exceeded that of foreign caregivers, with laborers outnumbering caregivers by a 10: 1 ratio as recently as 1995.

Taiwan's rapid economic growth in the second half of the 1990s only increased the demand for foreign manual laborers, pushing their numbers above 200,000. The gap between the two categories of migrant workers reached a peak of 170,000 in 1997.

But even then, the number of foreign caregivers entering Taiwan was also growing rapidly, and the gap between the two groups has narrowed as the number of foreign manual laborers remained flat over the past decade and even declined recently amid a global economic slump.
In 2009, the number of migrant workers in the manufacturing and construction sectors decreased to 176,000 while the number of foreign caregivers increased to more than 174,000.
Over the past 15 years, the CLA official said, the number of foreign caregivers has grown 13-fold, from 13,000 in 1994 to 174,000 at the end of last year.
During the same period, the number of foreign manual laborers has only risen 25 percent.

The lackluster growth in the manufacturing sector was partly related to the exodus of labor-intensive industries to China and other countries with cheaper labor and the government's inability to stimulate industrial innovation and nurture new industries, local scholars said.
But the rapid growth in the number of migrant caregivers has also signified the aging of the local population and the absence of a long-term care system, they added.

DOC.HEADLINE: Labor unions want to be consulted over labor issues in ECFA
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, April 12 (CNA) 04/12/10 21:07:47 (by Chen Sun-hsieh and Lillian Lin)

TEXT.P: Labor union officials suggested Monday that unions must be consulted as the government negotiates the contents of a proposed economic cooperation framework agreement (ECFA) with China.

Though President Ma Ying-jeou assured labor representatives in a meeting Monday morning that the agreement would not oblige Taiwan to open its doors to Chinese workers, union officials said labor issues should be discussed in the negotiations, and the opinions of labor unions must be included.

Hsieh Chuang-chih, secretary-general of the Taiwan Confederation of Trade Unions, said after the meeting that labor rights and job opportunities are closely related to the prospects of business and industry.
He indicated that the unions are very concerned about the impact of the trade deal on certain industries, despite the president's guarantee.

Sun Yu-lien, secretary-general of the Taiwan Labor Front, also called on the government to make the ECFA negotiations open and transparent. Laborers should be allowed to give their opinions rather than simply endorsing the government's decisions, he said.

DOC.HEADLINE: Price for choice seats at Taipei Arena increases

TEXT.P: The cost of the best seats at Taipei Arena concerts appears to be increasing as the economy recovers, with tickets for Taiwanese musician Jay Chou's June show set to run as much as NT$5,500 (US$174), a concert organizer said Monday.
Choice seats in the house at last week's concert for Harlem Yu, a Taiwanese singer-songwriter said to have performed the first Mandarin rap song, were priced at NT$4,200.
And organizers for the well-known Taiwanese female singer A-mei, or Chang Hui- mei, also charged NT$4,200 for top seats in the Taipei Arena last month.
Chou, who has won many musical awards and is famous for composing songs, said the ticket price reflects the high cost of producing his first indoor concert at the venue.
The pop star said at a press conference Monday that he will focus closely on stage design and that the total cost of the concert will be near NT$100 million.
One highlight will be a 360-degree three-dimensional projection that alone cost nearly NT$40 million, the organizer of the concert said.
However, Chou's concert is still not the most expensive this year.

Taiwanese heavy-weight musician Liu Chia-chang, 68, held a farewell concert early this month, and the highest ticket price for what was billed his final concert in Taiwan reached NT$8,000 -- the priciest gig so far this year.
The highest concert ticket price among female singers was NT$5,800 for prime seating at CoCo Lee's performance in late March.
Lee has not held a concert in Taipei since 1998 and the event was reported to have cost over NT$100 million -- the highest ever for the venue, organizers said.
Other concerts by local singers have not been cheap either, with fans forking out NT$3,000 to see Rainie Yang and NT$3,600 for the Super Band at the Taipei Arena earlier this year.

DOC.HEADLINE: Computer show attracts record crowds
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, April 12 (CNA) 04/12/10 21:59:06 (By Chou Pin-chun and Lilian Wu)

TEXT.P: A five-day spring computer show in Taipei ended Monday after attracting a record number of visitors, according to the organizer.
The Taipei Computer Association (TCA) said that this year's visitor number of 437,000 marked a 20 percent increase from last year, while sales by participating manufacturers grew 30 percent.
TCA officials said that notebooks, digital cameras and smart phones were the mainstays of this year's show, noting that sellers "could hardly meet demand" for Legend, HTC's smartphone.
Organizers said that sharp price cuts for Intel's CULV (Consumer Ultra-Low Voltage) computing platform drove healthy notebook sales, especially those by ASUStek, Acer and Toshiba.
Among them, sales of Toshiba's notebooks grew by 100 percent.

As for digital cameras, Cannon said that sales for high-end models grew seven- fold, showing that consumers are no longer focusing only on the price tag, but are becoming more concerned about functions.

DOC.HEADLINE: Conventional industries seen as biggest beneficiaries of tax cuts
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, Feb. 12 (CNA) 04/12/10 22:19:44 (By Y.L. Kao)

TEXT.P: An agreement reached Monday by the ruling Kuomintang (KMT) legislative caucus to cut the corporate income tax in Taiwan to 17 percent is expected to give across- the-board benefits to domestic businesses, industry representatives and analysts said.

The caucus reached the consensus during a meeting to discuss a KMT-proposed version of an industrial innovation bill that would slash the corporate income tax rate from the current 20 percent to 17 percent and retain tax breaks targeted at R&D and subsidies for small- and medium-sized businesses for hiring workers.
The bill must still be approved by the Legislative Yuan, in which the KMT has a big majority, before it can become law.
Analysts believe the bill, if passed, will help improve Taiwan's investment environment and boost foreign investors' interest in injecting money into the country.
Taiwan's largest real estate conglomerate said the move could also benefit the construction and real estate sector.
Far Glory Group estimated the tax cut could help it save NT$240 million annually in taxes, a contribution of NT$0.34 per share.
After the cut, Taiwan's corporate income tax rate will be the same as Singapore's and slightly higher than that of China's two special administrative regions -- Hong Kong and Macau.
It will make Taiwan more attractive for foreign investors and overseas Taiwanese businesses, according to Far Glory.
The petrochemical sector along with automobile and steel manufacturers also welcomed the plan, but they voiced concerns that the proposed tax cut would hurt national coffers.

Grand Pacific Petrochemical (GPPC) Group said that lowering the corporate income tax rate is good news for all, but it should be ensured that the plan will be carried out fairly and not only cater to the electronics sector and big enterprises.

Analysts suggested that conventional industries will be the biggest beneficiary of the proposal, because they rarely benefited from previous tax breaks directed primarily at high-tech companies and were also less likely to benefit from the targeted tax breaks in the original version of the industrial innovation bill.

The package is expected to help boost after tax earnings per share (EPS) by 3-5 percent for some companies in conventional industries that usually pay corporate income tax rates of 20 percent and higher, such as President Chain Store Corp. and China Steel Corp., a foreign analyst said.

Makalot Industrial Co., one of Taiwan's leading garment makers, estimated the bill will help the company save NT$36 million, or NT$0.23 per share, if calculated based on its pretax profits of NT$1.2 billion last year.
The company's EPS last year was NT$5.8.

Meanwhile, many manufacturers of rubber products, such as tire maker Cheng Shin Rubber Ind., reported that as they usually pay taxes at rates below 10 percent, the planned tax cut would have a limited impact on them.
Upstream rubber material manufacturers, however, including Taiwan Synthetic Rubber Corp., that normally pay taxes at rates of between 17 percent and 26 percent will benefit more, analysts said.

Companies in the paper and pulp and foodstuff sectors said the biggest companies in the sectors would be biggest beneficiaries because they earn more and pay more in taxes and can therefore save more.
In contrast, small glass and other building materials producers, such as the Champion Group and the China Blaze Group, will benefit more than big companies like Taiwan Glass.
Taiwan Glass does not have to pay taxes on most of its income, which is derived from investments overseas, because it has set up a global operating center in Taiwan.

The corporate income tax reduction will only affect its domestic earnings, which account for less than 20 percent of its total income, and it will have a limited impact on the company's overall earnings picture.

Representatives from the cable and wire companies also said the bill will advance the industry's development and suggested that government should also consider offering tax rebates for investments and research and development.

The measure drew a mixed reaction from the semiconductor industry. United Microelectronics Corp., the world's second largest contract chip maker, said that because the government provided tax rebates and investment benefits to high-tech companies, the bill would not affect the company.
However, Siliconware Precision Industries (SPIL), a leading wafer bumping service provider, expressed optimism that it would benefit from the bill.

DOC.HEADLINE: EasyCard may be accepted on Taichung buses next year
DOC.DATELINE: Taichung, April 12 (CNA) 04/12/10 22:22:29 (By Hao Hsueh-chin and Fanny Liu)

TEXT.P: All prepaid bus cards issued by other cities in Taiwan will be able to be used in Taichung City as early as mid-2011, the Taichung City government said Monday.
The central Taiwan's city's public transportation system at present only accepts Taiwan Easy Go prepaid bus cards, which can also be used in central Taiwan's Changhua and Nantou.

Wen Tai-hsin, director of the Department of Transportation of Taichung City government, said that if everything goes smoothly, all prepaid transportation cards operated in other cities -- including Taipei's EasyCard -- will be able to be used in the central Taiwan region.
The total cost for launching the integrated system is estimated at NT$100 million, he added.

More than 1,500 card reader systems on buses in Taichung, Changhua and Nantou will need to be reconfigured, and the city has applied for a subsidy of NT$45 million from the Ministry of Transportation and Communications to integrate the system, Wen said.

DOC.HEADLINE: 88 national relics to undergo on-site checks: official
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, April 12 (CNA) 04/12/10 22:22:47 (By Sofia Wu)

TEXT.P: The Council for Cultural Affairs will complete on-site checks on all 88 national-level cultural and historical relics by the end of this year, a senior official said Monday.

Fielding questions at a Legislative Yuan Education and Culture Committee hearing, the council's vice minister, Hung Ching-feng, said the council has traditionally commissioned local governments to help manage and supervise national cultural and historical sites.

"This year, we will conduct a thorough check of all national-level cultural and historical sites to determine whether local governments have fulfilled their custodial duties, " Hung said, adding that those failing to properly maintain or protect such heritage sites will be disciplined.
If any of the relics national relics is damaged, the supervisory agency may be slapped with a maximum fine of NT$1 million, Hung said.
The national-level relics include the Presidential Office, the Chiayi Prison, the North City Gate of Taipei and the Lin Family Garden of Wufong.

Noting that the Ministry of Justice has agreed to set aside a budget of NT$200 million in the coming years to repair and refurbish the Chiayi Prison, Hung said the council will oversee the restoration project.

DOC.HEADLINE: President calls for release of data on ECFA
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, April 12 (CNA) 04/12/10 22:49:31 (By Lee Su-hua and Y.L. Kao)

TEXT.P: President Ma Ying-jeou will ask government agencies to provide information on a proposed trade pact with China to opposition Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) Chairperson Tsai Ing-wen ahead of a TV debate on the issue, a presidential spokesman said Monday.
Ma said the information should be ready by April 19, with the debate scheduled for April 25, Presidential Office spokesman Lo Chih-chiang said.

Except for information related to negotiations with China on the pact, Ma said that all documents should be open to the public, according to Lo. Ma gave the order at a five-member panel meeting attended by high-ranking officials from the Presidential Office and the Executive Yuan, he said.
Ma said he will ask the Mainland Affairs Council and the Ministry of Economic Affairs to compile relevant documents and deliver them to Tsai for reference, according to Lo.
The president hoped Tsai will also provide data that justify opposition to the proposed cross-Taiwan Strait economic cooperation framework agreement (ECFA), Lo said.

Based on the principle of equality, the president would request a DPP proposal on how Taiwan could cope with the crisis of being marginalized from bilateral and regional free trade agreements, or left out of a regional bloc, he said.

DOC.HEADLINE: Suao port free trade zone to open operations in May
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, April 12 (CNA) 04/12/10 23:07:38 (By Hsien Chun-wei and Lilian Wu)

TEXT.P: The Suao port free trade zone in northeastern Taiwan is expected to begin operations in late May after the nation's top economic planning agency approved its establishment Monday.
The Council for Economic Planning and Development (CEPD) said the Suao trade zone is expected to evolve into a green energy industry cluster, creating NT$6.77 billion in trade in the next five years.
The CEPD said the Suao free trade zone will become the nation's sixth free trade port zone, after Taipei, Keelung, Kaohsiung, Taichung and Taoyuan.
According to the Ministry of Transportation and Communications, the Suao free trade zone will have a cargo volume of 40,300 tons and create 932 jobs in five years.

Wang Chun-yu, director-general of Keelung Harbor, said electric car maker Pihsiang Machinery Manufacturing Co. entered the Suao port free trade zone last month and expects to invest NT$1 billion in a facility with an annual production capacity of 30,000 cars.
It is expected to begin commercial production in the first quarter of 2011.

After related industries enter the zone, they will form a green industry supply chain and could extend the chain to the nearby Letzer and Lungte industrial parks to develop sources of product processing, the official believed.

Wang said the Suao port free trade zone will be distinct from the nearby Taipei and Keeling free trade port zones, as Taipei's focuses on deep-sea container and international logistics, while Keelung's has put a priority on near-sea container traffic and tourism and leisure.

Wang said manufacturers entering the free trade zone will receive a number of benefits. Up to 40 percent of their staffs can be foreign nationals; they will be given import duty concessions; and they will be able to process landing visas through a single one-stop counter.

DOC.HEADLINE: Today in history
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, April 13 (CNA) 04/13/10 08:03:19
DOC.TEXT:
Today is Tuesday, April 13, 2010, or the 29th day of the second month of the Year of the Tiger according to the lunar calendar. Following is a list of important events that have occurred on this date in the past:
1732: Frederick North, the English prime minister who introduced the Tea Act that led to the "Boston Tea Party," is born. His policies finally led to Britain's loss of America.
1743: Thomas Jefferson, the third president of the United States, is born. He drafted the Declaration of Independence in 1776. His presidency was marked by the purchase of the Louisiana Territory from France in 1803 and the Tripolitan War from 1801 to 1805.
1862: France and Annam (now Vietnam) sign the Treaty of Shanghai, annexing the province of Cochin China to France.
1898: Prompted by the success of the Meiji Reformation in Japan, Kang Yu-wei initiates a reform movement and submits a report to Emperor Kuang Hsu of China's Ching dynasty, requesting government reformation.
1904: In the Russo-Japanese War, a mine sinks the flagship of the Russian fleet at Port Arthur (Lushun) in northeastern China, killing 600.
1906: Samuel Beckett, Irish dramatist and winner of the Nobel Prize for Literature in 1969, is born.
1919: British troops under the command of Brig. Gen. Dyer open fire on some 380 followers of Mohandas K. Gandhi in an incident known as the Amritsar massacre.
1939: Italian dictator Benito Mussolini's forces invade Albania.
1941: Japan and the Soviet Union sign the Soviet-Japanese Neutrality Pact in Moscow.
1945: Allied bombers launch massive bombing raids over Japan, destroying a large part of Tokyo.
1960: The construction of an atomic reactor at Taiwan's National Tsinghwa University in Hsinchu, the first of its kind in Southeast Asia, is completed.
1964: Sidney Poitier wins an Oscar for his performance in Ralph Nelson's "The Lilies of the Field," becoming the first black actor to receive the award.
1966: Iraq's President Abdul Salam Arif is killed in a helicopter crash.
1978: Communist China and Portugal formally sign a "joint statement" that clears the way for the return of Macao to Beijing on Dec. 20, 1999.
1980: Twenty-three-year-old Spanish golfer Severiano Ballesteros becomes the first European and also the youngest person ever to win the U.S. Masters in Augusta, Georgia.
1982: U.S. Secretary of State Alexander Haig returns to Washington following failed attempts in London and Buenos Aires to settle the Falkland Islands dispute.
1988: Hainan Island becomes the 23rd province and the fourth "special economic region" of mainland China under communist rule.
1990: The Soviet Union admits that its secret police was responsible for the 1940 systematic murder of 1,500 Polish army officers at Katyn, Poland.
1995: The Ukraine agrees to close the Chernobyl nuclear reactor by 2000.
1995: Lang Chin-shan, known as "China's father of photography," dies at the age of 104.
1999: Willi Stoph, chairman of the Council of Ministers of the former German Democratic Republic, dies at the age of 84.
2000: The World Trade Organization ranks Taiwan as the world's 14th-largest exporting country and the 15th largest importing country in terms of merchandise in 1999.
2000: The International Monetary Fund ranks the people of Taiwan as the 18th richest people in the world, with the nation's annual per capita income based on purchasing power parity expected to reach US$16,854 in 2000.
2001: U.S. Congressman David Wu (D-OR) arrives in the Republic of China at the head of a four-member delegation making a five-day visit.
Confucius' lesson of the day: "Where there is affection, exertion is made easy; where there is disinterest, instruction will be neglected."

The weighted price index gained 25.72 points, or 0.31 percent, to close at 8,117.75 Monday.

DOC.HEADLINE: U.S. helicopter sale to Taiwan to be finalized in May
DOC.DATELINE: Washington, April 12 (CNA) 04/13/10 11:26:27 (By Zep Hu and Maubo Chang)

TEXT.P: The U.S. sale of 30 AH-64D Apache Longbow attack helicopters to Taiwan is expected to be finalized in May, a weekly said here Monday.
The Defense News reported in a story from Taipei that representatives of the U.S. government and the helicopters' U.S. manufacturer, Boeing Co., will arrive in Taipei in May to wrap up the deal.
The weekly said that although there had been speculation that Beijing might force Boeing to cancel or delay the sale, the deal, announced by the U.S. in 2008, is expected to remain in place.

It quoted Rupert Hammond-Chambers, president of the U.S.-Taiwan Business Council, as saying that the Apaches, to be equipped with Stinger Block I air-to- air missiles and AGM-114L Longbow Hellfire air-to-surface missiles, will begin to arrive in Taiwan between the end of 2012 and the beginning of 2013.
The helicopters were originally offered by the United States to Taiwan in 2002, but the U.S. Defense Security Cooperation Agency did not formally notify Congress of the sale until October 2008.

DOC.HEADLINE: Economic Daily News: New NHI plan too much like 'Robin Hood'
DOC.DATELINE: While the existing National Health Insurance (NHI) 04/13/10 11:31:33 (By Y.F. Low)

TEXT.P: system is flawed because it unfairly favors the rich, the problem with the proposed second-generation NHI lies in its desperation to become a "Robin Hood" who robs the rich to give to the poor.

Under the government's second-generation NHI plan, premiums would be calculated based purely on total household income. Families with identical income levels would be charged the same premiums no matter how many members each family has. This has drawn criticism because it would "punish singles."

We support the idea of having those who earn more to pay more. However, the goal should be achieved in a fair and reasonable manner. If the new plan were to use "total personal income" instead of "total household income" as the basis to calculate premiums, the situation would be greatly improved.

Under our proposal, the premium of each individual covered by the compulsory insurance program would be calculated based on his or her total income, with low-income earners and those having no income charged a basic premium of NT$300 per month.

If the premium rate were set at 5 percent, a family of four supported by a sole breadwinner earning NT$80,000 a month would have to pay NT$2,100 (NT$1,200 + NT$900 for the three dependents) in premiums per month. A single individual earning NT$80,000 would pay NT$1,200. (Each individual pays 30 percent of the total premium. The individual's employer and the government pick up the balance.)
This would satisfy everybody and enable the second-generation NHI system to be introduced early. (April 13, 2010)

DOC.HEADLINE: Two French awarded for promoting Taiwan-France cultural exchanges
DOC.DATELINE: Paris, April 12 (CNA) 04/13/10 11:38:19 (By Lo Yuan-shao and Elizabeth Hsu)

TEXT.P: Former Avignon Festival Artistic Director Bernard Faivre d'Arcier and Guimet Museum curator Jacques Gies received a Taiwan-France cultural award Monday and were acclaimed as "modern Marco Polos."

The 14th French-Taiwanese Cultural Foundation Award was presented at the French Academy, with Michel Albert, permanent secretary of the Academy of Moral and Political Sciences, Jean Mesnard, head of the Academy of Moral and Political Sciences, and Taiwan's Council for Cultural Affairs chief Emile C.J. Sheng jointly hosting the ceremony.
At the event, Sheng described the award winners as "bridge builders" similar to the Italian merchant Marco Polo (1254-1324), who introduced Europeans to Central Asia and China.
All recipients of the award, which was established in 1996, have made contributions to boosting the visibility of Taiwanese culture in Europe, Sheng said.

In his address, Faivre d'Arcier, awarded for his enthusiasm in inviting Taiwanese artists and cultural troupes to perform at the Avignon Festival, said he was not the first person in France that did so, saying it was Patrice Martinet, artistic director of the Paris Summer Quarter Festival, who was the real pioneer.

Faivre d'Arcier invited Taiwan to serve as the theme state of the 1998 Avignon Festival. In that year, over 200 Taiwanese performers with eight troupes came to France to demonstrate their skills, and since then, Taiwanese artists have been regularly featured at the event.
Gies received the award on behalf of the Guimet Museum in Paris, which has organized exhibitions to showcase collections of Taipei's National Palace Museum and National Museum of History.
Gies was also recognized for his contributions in promoting exchanges and cooperation between the Guimet Museum and Taiwan's museums and universities.

The French-Taiwanese Cultural Foundation was established in 1996 under the joint aegis of the Council for Cultural Affairs and the French Academy to award two prizes every year for artistic or literary works that shed light on relations between Taiwan and Europe and contribute to the enhancement of cultural exchanges between the two.
Individuals and legal entities from European countries and Taiwan are entitled to apply for the award, which comes with prize winnings of 25,000 euros (NT$1.07 million).

DOC.HEADLINE: Chinese mayor to visit Taiwan to promote agricultural exchanges
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, April 13 (CNA) 04/13/10 11:58:29 (By Kuo Mei-lan and Elizabeth Hsu)

TEXT.P: The mayor of Linyi in China's Shandong Province will visit Taiwan for the first time on April 18 on a trip that will focus on bilateral agricultural exchanges and cooperation, according to the Taiwan Farm Products Agents Association (TFPAA).

Invited to Taiwan by the association, Linyi Mayor Zhang Shaojun will visit cities and counties in the Taipei, Changhua, Yunlin, Tainan, Kaohsiung, Taitung and Hualien areas, TFPAA Secretary-General Chang Yu-cheng said Tuesday.

Zhang will visit fruit and vegetable wholesale markets and agricultural biotech parks in those areas and call on the Taiwan Agriculture and Animal Industry Development Foundation to talk about possible cooperation between his city and Taiwan, Chang added.

Linyi, located in the southeastern part of Shandong, is the province's largest city, with a population of more than 10 million. It is known for being rich in mineral resources, including iron, titanium, copper, gold, silver and aluminum.
Its temperate climate and fertile land also make the city an agricultural base for wheat, peanuts, corn, cotton and soybeans.

DOC.HEADLINE: Talk of the day -- KMT sets tune for corporate income tax
DOC.DATELINE: The ruling Kuomintang (KMT) 04/13/10 13:23:30 (By Deborah Kuo)

TEXT.P: legislative caucus reached a consensus Monday to cut the country's corporate income tax rate from the current 20 percent to 17 percent, setting the tune for a controversial industrial innovation bill.

The consensus, spurred by a push from President Ma Ying-jeou, was not met favorably by the opposition Democratic Progressive Party, which insists on its proposal to drop corporate tax rates to 17.5 percent.

It is not yet certain whether the KMT's tax incentive package will be passed into law this week or next, but two things are certain if the bill passes. Government revenues from corporate income tax receipts will fall by at least NT$34.3 billion a year, and conventional industries will be the biggest beneficiary.
The following are excerpts from local media coverage of the issue:
United Daily News:
The KMT version of the 17 percent tax rate also retains a tax credit for R&D spending and subsidies for small- and medium-sized businesses for hiring workers.
The KMT government contended that the 17 percent rate, modeled after Singapore's, will help sharpen Taiwan's international competitiveness.

The Ministry of Finance (MOF) said the impact of the new measure on tax revenues will not be as serious as imagined. It argued that although the 17 percent corporate income tax will cost national coffers some NT$38 billion a year, it will spur investment demand.
When profits increase because of the lower tax rate, the government will in turn levy taxes on those profits, contributing to narrowing the tax revenue gap, the MOF argued.
In response to the KMT decision, DPP Chairwoman Tsai Ing-wen gave directives to bar the passage of the KMT proposal.
DPP Legislator Yeh Yi-jin called Minister of Finance Lee Sush-der the most spendthrift manager in Taiwan's history.

The DPP estimated that if the DPP's proposed 17.5 percent rate is implemented, with all four targeted tax incentives eliminated, the losses in tax revenue will be around NT$40 billion a year, but the losses could top NT$90 billion a year if the KMT version is adopted. (April 13, 2010).
Economic Daily News:
If the KMT's tax incentive package clears the legislative floor this Friday, the statute will be implemented retroactively from Jan. 1 this year.
It means that when companies pay their income taxes in 2011, they will be taxed at a 17 percent rate, down dramatically from the 25 percent rate they will pay in 2010 on 2009 income.
The tax incentives, representing the greatest concession in Taiwan's taxation history, are poised to create benefits to the tune of NT$130 billion for the private sector. (April 13, 2010).
Commercial Times:

The 17 percent corporate income tax rate, proposed by the ruling KMT, which dominates the Legislature, is poised to give across-the-board benefits to domestic businesses, particularly conventional industries.
Some business executives even called it "belated justice."
Formosa Plastics, China Steel Corp., and Uni-President Enterprises all said lower corporate income taxes will not only reduce their financial burdens but also spur fresh investment.
Formosa Plastics welcomed it as a "constructive policy." The lower tax policy is definitely a shot in the arm for domestic and foreign businesses in terms of investing in Taiwan, the company said.

Lin Ming-ju, chairman of the Taiwan Steel and Iron Industries Association, said lower taxes will enable businesses to make some profit in this era of tiny margins. When the companies' finances improve because of the lower tax rates, they will be able to use the windfall to beef up their production facilities, which will in turn hone their international competitiveness, Lin said.

Hung Yao-kun, chairman of the Taiwan Feed Industry Association, said the tax incentives will help breathe new life into the sector, which has operated in a low-margin environment due to high taxes. "Now we can survive a little bit easier, " he said. (April 13, 2010).
