DOC.HEADLINE: Commercial Times: Will financial minister defend his policy?

TEXT.P: The Legislative Yuan is set to act on an industrial innovation bill on Friday. Lawmakers of the ruling Kuomintang, with the support of the party, decided to lower the corporate income tax to 17 percent and offer employment subsidies to small- and medium-sized enterprises and tax credits for R&D expenses.

Their decision is a slap in the face to Finance Minister Lee Sush-der, who insisted on either keeping the corporate income tax rate at 20 percent or scrapping all four tax breaks targeted at innovation included in the bill's original version.

The bill was mapped out jointly by the Finance Ministry and the Economic Affairs Ministry with the purpose of promoting industrial innovation. The Economic Affairs Ministry focused on innovation while the Finance Ministry stressed the health and fairness of the taxation system.

That is why the Finance Ministry urged the legislature to opt for either a tax rate of 20 percent with all four tax breaks preserved, or a tax rate of 17.5 percent, as requested by the opposition Democratic Progressive Party, without any tax incentives.

Unfortunately, the advice of the Finance Ministry was thrown to the wind by KMT lawmakers during an inner-party discussion, and the finance minister was forced to agree with the lawmakers to cut the rate to 17 percent in an attempt to underbid the DPP.
If the lawmakers have their way, the country's already deteriorating finances will take a turn for the worse, and the general public will be forced to pick up the tab.

In the face of this crisis, the ministry should warn the public of the government's financial crisis and debunk the myth that lower taxes will promote the growth of taxable income, while also stressing the necessity of broadening the tax base while lowering tax rates.

Health Minister Yaung Chih-liang won applause for tendering his resignation to make a case for the necessity to increase national health insurance premium rates. Will the finance minister follow Yang's lead to defend his proposal? (April 13, 2010)

DOC.HEADLINE: Singles should not be punished by new NHI program: lawmaker
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, April 13 (CNA) 04/13/10 14:53:07 (By Chou Yung-chieh and Deborah Kuo)

TEXT.P: Singles should not be punished by the second generation National Health Insurance (NHI) program that will be introduced and implemented in the future, ruling Kuomintang Legislator Hsieh Kuo-liang said at a press conference Tuesday.

Under the government's second-generation NHI plan, premiums would be calculated based purely on total household income. Households with identical income levels would be charged the same premium no matter how many family members they have.
This has drawn criticism because it would force singles to pay proportionately higher premiums than couples or members of a family.
Hsieh, who is single himself, said many factors led people to remain single, and he stressed that being without a spouse was not a crime.
He appealed to the Department of Health to empathize with the choices of single individuals and refrain from making them feel stigmatized because of the new NHI plan.

Citing figures compiled by the Ministry of the Interior's Population Administration, Hsieh said there are 5.11 million single people in Taiwan aged 20 or over, not including those who are divorced or have lost a spouse.
"Since these individuals did not cause the NHI's financial woes, why is the government asking them to shoulder the responsibility? " Hsieh questioned.
He also noted that people are getting married later than in the past, with the average man tying the knot at 31 and the average women at 28 in 2009, an indication that marriage is not an easy choice.

In today's difficult economic environment, imposing an even greater economic burden on singles through a second-generation health insurance plan only makes it more difficult for people to contemplate marriage, Hsieh contended.

A Mr. Lin who spoke at the press conference said he has never resisted marriage, but at a time when prices for many commodities are on the rise while pay levels remain flat, getting married is hard for him.
"Higher NHI premiums are pushing my dream of getting married even further away," he claimed.

DOC.HEADLINE: Taipei, Kaohsiung zoos exchange animals
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, April 13 (CNA) 04/13/10 15:10:58 (By Johnson Sun and Elizabeth Hsu)

TEXT.P: Kaohsiung's Shou Shan Zoo sent a female llama to the Taipei Zoo Tuesday as part of an exchange of animals between the two facilities.

In return, Taipei Zoo will ship 11 animals to Kaohsiung Wednesday, consisting of a white-handed gibbon, a Formosan Reeves' Muntjac, a Formosan serow, two common elands, three Aoudad sheep, and three Chapman's zebras, according to the zoo.
Animal exchanges are a common practice among zoos in different cities and countries as a way to enrich their variety of species and maintain existing species, the Taipei Zoo said.
The female llama from the Kaohsiung zoo in southern Taiwan is being sent north to join the Taipei Zoo's two male llamas.

DOC.HEADLINE: Taiwan researchers develop new LED encapsulation technology
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, April 13 (CNA) 04/13/10 15:11:20 (By Maubo Chang)

TEXT.P: A team of researchers from National Central University (NCU) in Chungli, Taoyuan County has developed a new LED encapsulation technology that is touted as the world's most advanced.
Sun Ching-cherng, director of NCU's Department of Optics and Photonics, said Tuesday in Taipei that the new technology developed by his team will enhance LED color rendering index (CRI) to 90.

The CRI is a quantitative measure of the ability of a light source to reproduce the colors of various objects faithfully in comparison with an ideal or natural light source, with 100 being the highest CRI attainable.
Most of the fluorescent lamps on market has a CRI of between 80 and 85.
Sun said his team has developed a phosphor optical model that can predict precisely the color temperature of different phosphor compounds.
With this model, Sun said, his team developed a two-light optical model that led to a phosphor formula capable of producing white light with a CRI of more than 90.
He said the technology will help local LED producers to reduce their defect and will give them an advantage in the field of white LED production.

DOC.HEADLINE: Taiwan share prices close lower
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, April 13 (CNA) 04/13/10 15:23:31 (by Olivia Wang)

TEXT.P: Taiwan's share prices closed lower Tuesday, with the weighted index -- the market's key barometer-- falling 88.02 points, or 1.08 percent, to close at 8,029.73.
The local bourse opened slightly down at 8,090.54 and fluctuated between 8,022.94 and 8,104.14 during the day's trading. Market turnover totaled NT$103.15 billion (US$3.27 billion).

All eight major stock categories lost ground, with construction shares dropping the most at 2.6 percent. Financial and banking stocks and textile issues fell 1.8 percent, paper and pulp issues lost 1.7 percent, and machinery and electronics shares were down 1.1 percent.
Cement issues fell 0.9 percent, plastics and chemicals shares lost 0.5 percent and foodstuff shares shed 0.2 percent.
Losers outnumbered gainers 2,402 to 807, with 198 remaining unchanged.
Foreign investors and Chinese QDIIs were net buyers of NT$1.39 billion in shares.

DOC.HEADLINE: Apple Daily: The right to choose one's surname

TEXT.P: Examples are rife that Taiwan's Civil Code is shackled by outdated patriarchal thinking. Among them is a clause that requires that those who seek to change their family names must prove that their surnames "have an unfavorable impact" on them.

On Monday, women's rights activists and 26 legislators jointly put forth a proposal to amend the Civil Code to grant adults the freedom to change their surnames and allow a parent to apply for a surname change for a child who has not come of age "for the best interests" of the child.
We think the restriction on minors should be removed altogether so that any requests for a surname change can be approved.

The legal sector has always been conservative. According to a department chief in the Ministry of Justice, family names are linked to kinship and inheritance under the Civil Code, and relaxing the restrictions on the adoption of surnames would also cause changes in family relationships and inheritances.

If this is such a big deal, how do other countries do it? In Taiwan, the household registration authorities keep records of surname changes by individuals. We wonder if the department chief has heard of a device called a computer, which was invented decades ago and can store large quantities of data.
The right to choose one's surname is a basic human right. The government should get its dirty hands off the people and return them the right to choose their own surnames. (April 13, 2010)

DOC.HEADLINE: U.S. dollar up on Taipei Forex
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, April 13 (CNA) 04/13/10 16:41:35 (By Olivia Wang)

TEXT.P: The U.S. dollar gained ground against the New Taiwan dollar on the Taipei Foreign Exchange Tuesday, rising NT$0.02 to close at NT$31.580.
A total of US$635 million changed hands during the trading session.
The U.S. dollar opened at NT$31.575 and fluctuated between NT$31.519 and NT$31.587.

DOC.HEADLINE: Lower corporate tax will encourage Taishang to return: premier
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, April 13 (CNA) 04/13/10 16:43:00 (By Ming-chung Lee and Deborah Kuo)

TEXT.P: A lower corporate income tax will induce Taiwan citizens who maintain business operations abroad to repatriate some of their capital, Premier Wu Den-yih said Tuesday.

Speaking at press conference on a proposal by the ruling Kuomintang (KMT) legislative caucus to cut the corporate income tax rate from the current 20 percent to 17 percent, Wu said this would remove one of the two major deterrents for overseas Taiwan entrepreneurs -- known as Taishang -- to return.
The other obstacle is the cost of foreign labor, he said. Currently foreign laborers are paid in line with the country's minimum wage of NT$17,280 per month, as stipulated by law.

The premier said that if the foreign laborer wage issue can be addressed, for example, by lowering wages to reflect actual take-home pay and to a level on par with mainland China and Southeast Asian countries, Taishang will probably be more willing to invest in Taiwan.
It is no secret that most of the foreign laborers working in Taiwan take home only between NT$8,000 and NT$9,000 per month and the balance goes to brokers, Wu said.
"If the wage issue can be addressed, we can expect Taishang to head home like schools of salmon, " he said. "We can even expect whales to come home."

Meanwhile, after extensive assessment and deliberation, the Executive Yuan has decided on the 17 percent corporate income tax rate and referred it to the Legislative Yuan for screening, the premier said.

DOC.HEADLINE: 'Taipei Culture Week' to be held during World Expo Shanghai in June
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, April 13 (CNA) 04/13/10 16:52:18 (By Johnson Sun, Lin Shu-yuan and Fanny Liu)

TEXT.P: To promote Taiwan during the World Expo 2010 Shanghai, Taipei Mayor Hau Lung-bin announced Tuesday that he will lead seven performing arts groups in bringing an unprecedented "Taipei Culture Week" to Shanghai in June.

In what will be the biggest Taiwanese group of performing artists ever to visit China, 1,000 performers will demonstrate various Taiwanese arts and creativity during the festival that will run in Shanghai from June 3 to June 28, Hau said at a news conference to announce the event.

On June 16 -- the day of the traditional Dragon Boat Festival and "Taipei Day" at the World Expo -- the Taiwanese opera company Ming Hwa Yuan will perform its signature "Legend of the White Snake, " known for its dramatic use of stage technology.

Taipei Deputy Mayor Lee Yong-ping said that the planned Taipei Culture Week in Shanghai will feature many activities, including a performing arts festival, a visual art exhibition, a cultural seminar, a cultural and creativity exhibition, a film festival, and an outdoor exhibit introducing the Taipei International Flora Expo.

In addition to Ming Hwa Yuan, other performing groups participating the event include the Taipei Symphony Orchestra, Taipei Chinese Orchestra, Ping-Fong Acting Troupe, Guo Guang Opera Company, Contemporary Legend Theater, and the U-Theatre.
Meanwhile, Wang Chih-kang, chairman of the Taiwan External Trade Development Council (TAITRA) , said the Taiwan Pavilion at the World Expo 2010 Shanghai, will open on May 1 as scheduled.

Wang said in a press conference on Tuesday that the Taiwan Pavilion, which is able to accept 4,300 visitors per day, is expected to attract a total of nearly 800,000 visitors during the 185-day exhibition period.
The Taiwan Pavilion will use multimedia displays to convey the building's theme -- "Mountain, Water & Lantern of the Heart."

The pavilion consists of a seamless glass exterior shaped like a sky lantern that houses a huge LED globe representing the "Heart of Taiwan." Spectacular views of the island will be projected onto the globe.

DOC.HEADLINE: Kaohsiung Medical University Hospital fined for massive fraud
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, April 13 (CNA) 04/13/10 17:04:57 (By Chen Ching-fan, Chen Chao-fu and Lilian Wu)

TEXT.P: Kaohsiung Medical University Chung-Ho Memorial Hospital in southern Taiwan has been fined $150 million (US$4.75 million) for fraud on a massive scale, the Department of Health (DOH) said Tuesday.
The fine is the heaviest ever meted out to any medical institution for this type of violation since the National Health Insurance system was put in place in 1995.
DOH Minister Yaung Chih-liang said the point is not so much about "fraudulently claiming health insurance reimbursement, but about the fact that doing so is a serious violation of medical ethics."

Cheng Shou-hsia, chief of the Bureau of National Health Insurance(BNHI) , said the prime suspect, Hsu Shih-cheng, a former director of the Department of Obstetrics and Gynecology of Kaohsiung Medical University hospital, colluded with a fraud ring headed by Fu Chien-shen when Hsu was working at the Kaohsiung Medical University hospital and at the Kaohsiung Municipal Hsiao-kang Hospital.
The fraud ring worked with 10 hospitals, seven doctors and 20 patients to claim payments from the BNHI and insurance companies.
The matter only came to light because one of the seven doctors came forward and reported the scam.

According to Cheng, the doctors switched cancer patient specimens and let "phony" patients undergo chemotherapy treatment as well as surgery, in order to claim reimbursement on the procedures from the BNHI and insurance companies.

As a result, the BNHI decided to terminate its contracts with the Departments of Obstetrics and Gynecology of the Kaohsiung Medical University hospital and the Hsiao-kang Hospital for one year and three months, respectively.

However, after considering a request by the Kaohsiung Medical University hospital for reconsideration of the punishment and the rights of the hospital's ob-gyn patients, the termination was changed to a fine of NT$150 million.
A spokesman for the hospital said Tuesday that the case was simply a fraud by a single doctor, that the hospital is itself a victim of the scam, and that it will file for administrative relief.
The spokesman said that Hsu left the hospital in May 2009, but before that date, the hospital was unaware of his dishonesty and had claimed insurance reimbursements according to his diagnosis.
"The hospital regrets the ethical issue of the individual doctor," he added.

DOC.HEADLINE: Taiwan to open innovation research zone
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, April 13 (CNA) 04/13/10 17:15:53 (By Hsieh Chun-wei and Elizabeth Hsu)

TEXT.P: Taiwan's government is moving ahead with a plan to open a new technology research center to serve as the country's industrial innovation and research base, according to the Council of Economic Planning and Development (CEPD).

The plan was approved by the Executive Yuan in November as part of Taiwan's hopes of promoting innovations in Taiwan's industries through cooperation among industry, academics and research institutes.

The Ministry of Economic Affairs (MOEA) will begin in this year to establish the research and development park in central Taiwan to spur development of the innovation industry. It plans to invest NT$3.6 billion in constructing the park.

The ministry will invite domestic research institutes, such as the Institute for Information Industry and the Industrial Technology Research Institute to open their innovation and incubation centers in the planned zone in Jhongxing New Village, Nantou County. Tenants are expected to move in as early as the end of this year.

It is hoped that the special innovation park will help with technology upgrades and innovations of the industries in central Taiwan, said Lin Hao-chu, an official at the MOEA's Department of Industrial Technology.
Aside from the innovation park, a market intelligence technology research center will also be opened in Jhongxing Village, Lin added.
The new center will be commissioned to develop green intelligence mobile technologies through cloud computing, Lin noted.
Under the MOEA assessment, the two facilities will attract 1,450 talents in advanced research after their inauguration, the CEPD said.
It noted that at least 115 companies are expected to move or open incubation centers in the innovation park after its completion.
Industrial investments in the park and the research center are expected to generate a production value ranging from NT$15 billion to NT$60 billion a year, the CEPD anticipated.

DOC.HEADLINE: Triumphant tug-of-war teams return home
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, April 13 (CNA) 04/13/10 17:24:20 (By Bien Chin-feng and Lilian Wu)

TEXT.P: Members of the Taiwanese teams that won at the 8th Asian Tug-of-War Championships in South Korea last week returned home to a warm welcome Tuesday.
The Taiwan teams won five gold medals in the competition in Seoul last Thursday and Friday.
The women's team, composed of students from Taipei Jingmei Girls High School, emerged as champions in the female division after defeating Vietnam in the semifinals and Mongolia in the final.
The men's team, composed of athletes from Chiao Tai High School and Asia University, Taiwan, won in its division, shutting out South Korea and Japan.

On Thursday, three Taiwanese senior high schools -- National Nantou Senior High School, Taichung County Dali Senior High School, and Nuan Nuan Senior High School in Keelung -- swept the male, female and mixed events of the Asian Tug- of-War Open Club competition, a lower-level event that opened the two-day championships.
Members of the Taiwan teams said Tuesday that in preparation for the championships, some of them had to work hard to gain weight, while others tried to lose weight or maintain the right weight.
"All the hard work paid off," a team member said, adding that the teams started training six months ago, keeping in mind Japan, the strongest contender.

DOC.HEADLINE: Taiwan, South Korea to promote tours for seniors, students
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, April 13 (CNA) 04/13/10 17:29:56 (By Chen Shun-hsieh and Fanny Liu)

TEXT.P: Representatives from Taiwan and South Korea agreed at a conference Tuesday that they should promote more travel packages for seniors, as well as more study tours for teenagers, in order to promote tourism on both sides.
The Taiwan-South Korean tourism exchange conference attracted about 180 representatives from both sides -- the largest number in the past six years to attend such a conference, the organizer said.

David Hsieh, deputy director-general of the Tourism Bureau under the Ministry of Transportation and Communications, said South Korean tourist arrivals have been growing since January, showing a recovery in the South Korea-Taiwan tourism business.

Hsieh pointed out that the total number of visitors from South Korea was 167,641 in 2009 -- down 33.55 percent from the previous year, because of the economic slump, the H1N1 influenza outbreaks and the depreciation of the South Korean won.

However, the depreciating won helped increase the number of Taiwanese people who visited South Korea, with the number of Taiwanese tourists visiting the country increasing by 25,000 to reach 388,000 last year, Hsieh added.

Looking ahead, the year-end Taipei International Flora Expo and a bicycle festival, as well as a two-year "Taiwan Touch Your Heart" tourism promotion event, will help the tourism industries on both sides to package more tours and boost the number of tourists, Hsieh said.

To signify the importance of the conference, the South Korean government included an official from the Ministry of Culture, Sports and Tourism on the delegation that attended this year's conference, the organizer added.

DOC.HEADLINE: Environmentalists call for ban on seal products from Canada
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, April 13 (CNA) 04/13/10 17:54:24 (By Yang Shu-ming and Maubo Chang)

TEXT.P: A local environmental group has called for a ban on imports of seal oil and related products from Canada to condemn what they describe as the brutal culling of the animal permitted by Canadian authorities.

Chen Yu-ming, a leader of the Environment & Animal Society of Taiwan, told a news conference Tuesday that Canada allows its fishermen to cull 380,000 seals a year, even though the seals account for only 5 percent of the fishermen's annual income.

According to Chen, the culling process is brutal. Canadian fishermen kill these seals by knocking them on head with a cudgel and skinning them while they lie helplessly in a pool of blood struggling to stay alive.
Chen urged the public to watch a film of the culling shot by the Humane Society International (HSI) and posted on the group's Web site before buying Canadian seal products.

"Many of the seal cubs, which are only one month old, are killed while lying on the ice and waiting for their mothers to feed them, " Chen said. "The world's largest massacre of marine mammals takes place every year in Canada."

Although seals are not listed as an endangered species by the United Nations Convention on International Trade in Endangered Species of Wild Fauna and Flora, products using seal ingredients are widely boycotted in the West, Chen said.
Citing the European Union (EU) as an example, Chen said the EU imposed a ban in 1983 on sales of seal fur in its member states and expanded the ban in 2010 to cover all seal products.

The U.S. has banned the import of goods with ingredients from marine mammals since 1977, and it forbids the trapping, gathering or killing of pregnant animals or cubs less than eight months old in inhumane ways, even for research purposes.
Taiwan has become the fourth leading market for Canadian seal products. From 2003 to 2009, it imported 431,364 kilograms of seal oil, an amount requiring the killing of 120,000 seals, Chen said.

Seal oil is rich in omega-3 fatty acids, but its proponents contend that it provides a higher concentration of the essential fatty acids that reduce the risk of cardiovascular disease than other fish oils, driving demand for the product.
Chen argued, however, that seals need not be killed because every nutrient found in the seal oil can be obtained from other natural sources.
She urged the Council of Agriculture to screen the HSI film to raise public awareness that purchasing Canada's seal products is contributing to their slaughter.
An anonymous agriculture official rejected her call, saying that there was no rule to ban the imports of seal products, including those from Canada.
"Before the law is revised, we do not have the authority to impose a ban, and we are not in a position to screen the HSI film, "the official said.

DOC.HEADLINE: Taiwan gets new prosecutor general
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, April 13 (CNA) 04/13/10 18:08:13 (By Y. C. Chou and Flor Wang)

TEXT.P: The Legislative Yuan approved the presidential nominee Huang Shih-ming as Taiwan's new prosecutor general Tuesday, with Huang promising to work hard to solve long lingering unsolved crime cases.
Huang, who served as deputy minister of justice before being picked by Ma for the new post, will serve a four-year term as the country's top prosecutor.

His predecessor Chen Chung-ming resigned from the position in mid-January after being impeached by the Control Yuan. Chen's close relations with politicians and business people were frowned upon by the government and the public.

The new prosecutor general said he will meet with members of a special investigation division under the Supreme Prosecutor's Office in a week to gain an understanding of the progress of the cases they have been handling.

Huang said his goal is to close all major cases within two years, including the scandals surrounding a plane procurement by Taiwan's largest carrier, China Airlines; the high-profile pre-election shooting of former President Chen Shui- bian; and the political contribution cases involving many former ranking officials in the government administrations of both the ruling and opposition parties.

Justice Minister Tseng Yung-fu immediately gave his congratulations to Huang upon learning he had been confirmed by the legislature. Tseng praised Huang as a capable and upright prosecutor and voiced hope that he could solve long unsolved serious crimes soon.
Huang issued a brief statement, in which he stressed his determination to do a good job amid high expectations of him from the president and the public.

In a meeting with Legislative Yuan Speaker Wang Jin-pyng later Tuesday, Huang expressed appreciation for the legislature's support for him and vowed to fulfill his official duties without any regard for the political affiliations of those indicted.
Huang said that he has no political loyalties and emphasized that he handles cases according to solid evidence.

"I will also demand prosecutors follow due process of law, adequately and quickly deal with violent crime cases, increase and improve their prosecution quality and overhaul the morals among prosecutors," he said.
Huang was approved by a vote of 75-32 in the legislature, as expected.

The ruling Kuomintang (KMT) controls 75 seats in the 113-member legislature. Four lawmakers, two of the KMT, one of the opposition Democratic Progressive Party and one of the Non-Partisan Solidarity Union, were absent from the voting.

DOC.HEADLINE: ECFA early harvest list will not be disclosed to DPP
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, April 13 (CNA) 04/13/10 18:20:07 (By Su Lung-chi, Wen Kuei-hsiang, Lee Shu-hua and Y.F. Low)

TEXT.P: The Executive Yuan will provide the opposition Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) with information on the proposed economic cooperation framework agreement (ECFA) with China, but will withhold the details on Taiwan's early harvest list, Deputy Minister of Economic Affairs Lin Sheng-chung said Tuesday.

According to Lin, the proposed list for early harvest items that will enjoy immediate tariff concessions or waivers under the agreement cannot be disclosed at present because negotiations with China are still ongoing.

In preparation for an April 25 debate on the ECFA with President Ma Ying-jeou, DPP Chairperson Tsai Ing-wen had requested access to the early harvest list proposed by the government, the draft of the agreement, and any government- commissioned ECFA assessment reports.

Ma therefore instructed the Ministry of Economic Affairs and the Mainland Affairs Council Monday to compile the relevant documents and deliver them to Tsai. The president said that all documents should be open to the public "except for information related to the negotiations with China."
At the same time, Ma expressed the hope that Tsai will provide data that justifies her party's opposition to the ECFA.

Lin Yu-chang, a DPP spokesman, criticized the Presidential Office Tuesday as "lacking sincerity" for planning to provide the party with unimportant publicity materials and to withhold the actual data that the party requested.

Lin also said the DPP's doubts over the ECFA and its call for a referendum on whether it should go ahead have been widely reported by the media and that the Presidential Office has no need to ask for further related information from the DPP.
Tsai Chi-chang, another DPP spokesman, reportedly described the ruling party as being "good-for-nothing" for requesting such information from the opposition party.

In response, Presidential Office spokesman Lo Chih-chiang said the DPP should not hold a double standard, since it was that party that set the precedent in which a debater would request information from his or her rival.

DOC.HEADLINE: Ma calls Solomon Islands tribal chief in wake of earthquake
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, April 13 (CNA) 04/13/10 18:25:50 (By S. H. Lee and Flor Wang)

TEXT.P: President Ma Ying-jeou called a Solomon Islands tribal chief, Stanley Tapeva, Tuesday to inquire about his safety after a strong earthquake hit the South Pacific island nation Sunday.

The president was deeply concerned about Tapeva's safety and made the call at 1: 25 p.m. Tuesday in the wake of reports about the 6.8 magnitude quake, according to Presidential Spokesman Lo Chih-chiang.
"Stanley said he and his wife were OK, and asked me not to worry about them," Ma was quoted as saying.

According to Lo, the president talked to Tapeva for about seven or eight minutes. Tapeva also thanked Ma for the fertilizer that the ROC government donated to the people of the Solomon Islands, which is one of Taiwan's diplomatic allies.

The president got to know Tapeva on a state visit to the Solomon Islands late last month when the chief of Kava Village presented Ma with a donation of NT$4,000 (US$127) , on behalf of his fellow villagers, for Taiwan's victims of Typhoon Morakot. In return, Ma gave Tapeva a smartphone.

DOC.HEADLINE: Taiwanese AMC scores drop; still above world average
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei April 13 (CNA) 04/13/10 18:33:27 (By Sunnie Chen)

TEXT.P: Taiwanese students' American Mathematics Competitions (AMC) scores dropped this year but were still above the world average, the president of the Nine-Nine Cultural and Educational Foundation said Tuesday.

Ho Yang-ming said the results show that no students in Taiwan scored full marks among the 6,647 contestants -- the first time this has happened in 10 years -- while five students in AMC10 and four students in AMC12 got perfect scores in the United States.
"The average score of Taiwanese students in AMC10 was 90.8 which is a drop of 9.9, but the world average was still only 70.8, up 0.4," Ho said.
Ho said the average score of Taiwanese high school students in AMC12 was 77.9, while that of vocational high school students was 62.6.

The AMC, which was established in 1950 and has been used in Taiwan for 10 years, is the first of a series of competitions for high school mathematics and includes three levels -- AMC8, AMC10 and AMC12 -- for students in grades 8, 10 and 12. The annual event is held by the American Mathematics Competitions organization.

Major universities such as the Massachusetts Institute of Technology (MIT) are beginning to take AMC scores as important references in student applications, since the AMC tests a deeper level of math than the SAT and can help identify students who are ready for a rigorous undergraduate curriculum, according to Ho.

"This situation (of Taiwan's poorer showing this year) could be caused by many reasons, such as the date of the test this year being too close to the local General Scholastic Ability Test, so some students did not choose to take the AMC tests, "Ho said.

Another reason is the questions in the tests are divided between two opposing extremes -- some are too difficult while some are too easy for the students here -- such as some questions related to discrete mathematics, which students in Taiwan do not learn until 11th grade, Ho went on.

DOC.HEADLINE: Gov't urged to address trade mark, patent infringement issue
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, April 13 (CNA) 04/13/10 18:56:51 (By Justin Su and Deborah Kuo)

TEXT.P: Private sector representatives called on the government Tuesday to squarely face and address the problems derived from the serious infringement of trade marks and patent rights by mainland Chinese businesses.

The local businessmen made the call at a hearing organized by ruling Kuomintang Legislator Ting Shou-chung on the signing of a cross-Taiwan Strait accord on intellectual property rights. Government officials and academics also attended the hearing to answer questions and make suggestions.
A Shihlin Electric executive said that his company's trademark, which is registered in both Taiwan and China, has been appearing on products in China since 2000 without Shihlin Electric's consent.
Lin Chih-cheng said his company filed several complaints with the relevant Chinese authorities about the trade mark infringement, but it took three to four years before a ruling was obtained.
"Some complaints were not even heard," he said.
Chu Juo-yu, a legal affairs manager at the food company Hsin Tung Yang, said it is a long tiring process to obtain a ruling in China on intellectual property rights violations.
"It should be easier for legal authorities in China to establish the ownership of patent rights now that cross-strait exchanges have improved and expanded," Chu said.

Responding to the businessmen's concerns, Vice Minister of Economic Affairs Lin Sheng-chung said the intellectual property rights issue will be put on the agenda of the next round of cross-strait talks between Chiang Pin-kung, chairman of Taiwan's Straits Exchange Foundation, and Chen Yunlin, president of Beijing's Association for Relations Across the Taiwan Straits.

Meanwhile, Jerry Gen-yu Fong, professor and director of National Chengchi University's Graduate Institute of Intellectual Property, suggested that the cross-strait patent infringement issue should be resolved under the framework of the World Trade Organization (WTO) , with the participation of private business organizations and members of the academic sector.

DOC.HEADLINE: MOFA probing alleged slavery in Costa Rica involving Taiwanese
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, April 13 (CNA) 04/13/10 19:04:26 (By Chris Wang)

TEXT.P: The Ministry of Foreign Affairs (MOFA) said Tuesday that it was trying to collect information on the involvement of Taiwanese nationals in an alleged case of the enslavement of 36 Asians on fishing boats and suspected human trafficking in Costa Rica.

The MOFA was responding to reports from media outlets stating that three men and one woman -- three of which are Taiwanese -- were arrested by the Costa Rican authorities at the port of Puntarenas and accused of using 36 Asians on two fishing boats as slave labor. All the suspects were released under their own recognizance.

The ministry instructed its embassies in Panama and Nicaragua to monitor the situation and collect information, as there are no diplomatic ties between Taiwan and Costa Rica, MOFA deputy spokesman James Chang said.
Costa Rica severed diplomatic relations with Taiwan in 2007 after maintaining official ties for almost 60 years.

"We would like to express our concern from a humanitarian standpoint for the people abused if the case proves to be true, " he said, adding that although the four had been released, the Costa Rican authorities were still investigating the case.

Costa Rican police Sunday freed the 36 Asians -- 15 Vietnamese, 13 Indonesians, five Filipinos, two Taiwanese and a Chinese national -- from "inhumane" conditions aboard two fishing boats, Agence France-Presse (AFP) and local paper La Nacion reported, adding that the men were allegedly beaten and forced to work for up to 20 hours a day without pay.
The case surfaced after nine Vietnamese men escaped by jumping overboard, swimming to shore and alerting the authorities four months ago.

Two employees surnamed Espinoza and Wang, and a brother and sister by the family name of Tseng who are the president and treasurer, respectively, of the Imperio Pesquero del Pacifico S.A. company, were finally arrested Saturday.
A local newspaper reported that the three Taiwanese and one Costa Rican were charged with human trafficking, which in Costa Rica carries a sentence of between eight and 16 years in prison.

DOC.HEADLINE: NTU, Fudan University jointly open EMBA class
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, April 13 (CNA) 04/13/10 19:07:35 (By Lee Hsien-fong and Lilian Wu)

TEXT.P: National Taiwan University (NTU) announced Tuesday that it is cooperating with Fudan University in Shanghai to open an EMBA class for both sides of the Taiwan Strait.
The two-year EMBA program is aimed at nurturing talents from mainland China and Taiwan on business strategy, leadership and effective organization ability.
NTU Vice President Tang Ming-je said that since the school opened the EMBA class in 1997, it has already nurtured more than 1,900 members over the years.
With increased cross-strait exchanges, closer linkage between the two sides of the Taiwan Strait on advanced learning is inevitable, Tang said.
Lu Xiongwen, dean of the Fudan University School of Management, said via a video conference that "Chiwan" -- China+Taiwan -- has become the latest emerging economy in Asia.
Lu said that bilateral exchanges would definitely bring more benefits than unilateral learning, noting that Greater China needs to step up efforts to nurture more management talents.
Chen Houn-gee, executive officer of NTU's EMBA program, said that the class will recruit 30 students from each side of the Taiwan Strait.
The students will spend one third of their time in Taipei and two-thirds of the program in Shanghai so as to learn more about their respective cultural and business environment.

TEXT.P: June 18. Ma calls Solomon Islands tribal chief in wake of earthquake 19. ECFA early harvest list will not be disclosed to DPP 20. DOC.HEADLINE: Innovative, eye-catching tactics at auto parts show
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, April 13 (CNA) 04/13/10 19:43:50 (By Alex Jiang)

TEXT.P: While many exhibitors at an automobile component trade show being held in Taipei are simply displaying their products, a few have chosen to use innovative methods to attract the attention of visitors.
Most of the companies at the show merely lined up their products, such as car lights, steering wheels, car seats or bumpers, on shelves in their booths.
However, after taking a few steps into the exhibition venue at the Taipei World Trade Center's Nangang Exhibition Hall, visitors can hear the sounds of air pumps in the distance.

The sounds come from a yellow race car in the booth of D2 Racing Sport Co., a Taiwanese maker of air suspension systems for passenger cars. The car moves up and down or leans right or left as the driver inside plays a video game.
"We spent three months remodeling the car to create the effect, " said Linda Lin, a spokeswoman for the company based in the central county of Changhua.
"There is an air suspension system on each wheel that allows you to adjust the height of the vehicle, " she told CNA Monday.
"You can also use a remote control to change the height, " Lin added.
The company has more than 10 years' experience equipping passenger vehicles with the air suspension system in Southeast Asia, the United States and Europe.
Another attraction at the show is a car that plays a race car film simultaneously on 10 screens of different sizes on the inside of the car's doors and trunk.
"It took us about a year to design it, " said Jovi Hung, manager of Red Wood Enterprise Co.'s business department.
"The car has helped attract many visitors to our booth," he said.
The 30-year-old company, in fact, sells safety belts and race car seats, mostly in the U.S. and Europe.
Two heavy motorcycles set up by Taiwan's Lifetech Energy Inc. and placed close to the entrance were also attracting visitors' attention.

"One of the bikes, using our company's lithium iron batteries, was the winner of the TTXGP in the United Kingdom in 2009, " company president Alan Hsu, said, referring to the world's first zero emissions electric motorcycle race.
Another heavy motorbike at the venue, albeit with no extra remodeling, is a Harley-Davidson featuring a light-emitting diode (LED) headlight.
"The headlight is the result of six years of research, " said Peter Yen of the Automotive Research and Testing Center based in Changhua.
"We launched the headlight early this year, and a local company has already received orders from the United States," he added.
The LED headlight can give power savings of up to 80 percent compared with a traditional headlight, Yen noted.
The show is being held along with an auto electronics show, and the two are considered to be the largest of their kinds in Asia this year, the organizer said.
This focus of this year's shows is eco-friendly products, as demand for green energy increases, it added.
Both shows will run until April 15, open only to trade visitors except for the final two days, when they will be open to the general public.

DOC.HEADLINE: Taiwan travel website launched in China
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, April 13 (CNA) 04/13/10 20:18:06 (By Lin Hui-chun and Fanny Liu)

TEXT.P: A new website for travel and tourism in Taiwan was launched in China Tuesday, targeting 400 million Chinese Internet users with comprehensive online travel information about the island.

The website "Koubei Taiwan"(http: //taiwan.koubei.com/) is aimed at providing Chinese tourists more complete and useful information about destinations in Taiwan other than the most well-known popular tourist spots, such as Alishan and Sun Moon Lake, an operator of the website said.

Yu Shih-yi, CEO of Taiwan's eDynamics Inc, which was authorized by China's leading classified listing website Koubei.com to operate the website, said that Koubei Taiwan, established in China, will strive to help Chinese Internet users experience Taiwan online.
"Chinese tourists will be encouraged to visit the website before visiting Taiwan," the official said.
The number of Chinese tourists coming to Taiwan is expected to increase to 1.4 million this year from 970,000 in 2009, according to Taiwan's Tourism Bureau.

As China's Koubei.com has access to 250 million internet users, its subsidiary site Koubei Taiwan will easily grab those members' attention and create massive business opportunities, the company said.
The website provides various listings on popular tourist spots, recreational and cultural activities, shopping and dining choices, and it also recommends some theme tours in Taiwan.

Koubei.com at present provides information on 2,864 cities in China and has 50 million members, and it can also access 200 million members of its parent company Taobao (www.taobao.com) -- the largest Internet retail website in China.

DOC.HEADLINE: Taiwan operators display WiMAX applications at trade show
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, April 13 (CNA) 04/13/10 20:32:36 (By Alex Jiang)

TEXT.P: Six Taiwan operators showcased WiMAX applications in the fields such as emergency rescue and health care, at a regional trade show that opened in Taipei Tuesday.
The applications were on display at the Taiwan pavilion at the WiMAX Forum's Congress Asia, which was held in Taiwan for the first time, April 13-14.
At the Taiwan pavilion, the WiMAX rescue equipment was displayed on two dummies dressed as rescue specialists.

"With this equipment, rescuers can send real-time images to a nearby operation center as soon as they arrive at the emergency site, " said James Pao, an executive of Comm Tec Corp. that was commissioned to develop the gear for First International Telecom Corp.
"The equipment can also monitor the rescuer's heartbeat and body temperature and can detect any toxic fumes in the environment, " he told reporters.
This gear can be used by firefighters, security guards, police, and the military, he said.
Another Taiwanese operator, Far EasTone Telecommunications Co., highlighted a network that can monitor the health of senior people who live in remote areas or are not very mobile.

The WiMAX equipment allows such seniors to check their blood sugar and pressure levels and then transmit the data via a network that would immediately alert a medical team if there are any irregularities.
For its part, VMAX Telecom Co. was offering free rides on taxis equipped with the WiMAX technology that allows passengers to surf the Internet or watch online videos in the cabs.
VMAX also showcased a cellphone-based mobile TV service that provides information on stock markets and sports events such as the upcoming football World Cup.
However, these advanced applications have not yet taken off in the wider consumer market in Taiwan, said Hsieh Ching-tarng, the director of the WiMAX Forum's office in Taiwan.

Ron Resnick, president and chairman of the WiMAX Forum, said that at the moment the situation is different in Taiwan than in Moscow, where there is a buzz among consumers about the advantages of the wireless technology.

He said it will take a while for such a buzz, or word-of-mouth marketing, to take off in Taiwan, but when it does it will help speed up the development of what he described as "fast Internet service everywhere."

WiMAX is just taking off in Taiwan, but has been growing rapidly in many countries in the past year, said Johnsee Lee, the president of Taiwan's semi- official Industrial Technology Research Institute (ITRI).
Most of Taiwan's six WiMAX operators obtained their commercial license from the government between December of 2009 and March this year.
Established in 2001, the WiMAX Forum now tracks 559 deployments in 147 countries, with estimated coverage of more than 620 million people worldwide, one third of which are in Asia.
The annual congress, which was held in Singapore in the last two years, attracted an estimated 2,500 people, including operators and component and equipment vendors in the communications field.

DOC.HEADLINE: Incumbent might be drafted by KMT to run for Taichung mayor
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, April 13 (CNA) 04/13/10 20:48:31 (By S.H. Lee and Flor Wang)

TEXT.P: Incumbent Taichung Mayor Jason Hu might be drafted by the ruling Kuomintang (KMT) to run in the upgraded central Taiwan's Taichung City -- a merger of the existing city with Taichung County -- in Nov. 27 mayoral elections.

Quoting KMT Secretary-General King Pu-tsung after a party meeting, KMT spokesman Su Jun-pin said Legislator Chi Kuo-tung has expressed willingness to withdraw from seeking the party's nomination as candidate for the sake of party unity.
His withdrawal would mean that Legislator Liu Chuan-chung would be Hu's sole competitor within the KMT.

Although the KMT will adopt a "coordination and recruitment" mechanism and combine the results of public opinion surveys as an important reference to pick the best candidate for the race, Su said the party will further "coordinate" with Liu (implicitly meaning that it will be Hu who will represent the KMT in Taichung).

The November special municipality elections will also see voting for the mayors of Taipei City, as well as for Xinbei City (an upgrade of Taipei County), Kaohsiung City (a merger of the city and county of Kaohsiung, and Tainan City (a merger of the city and county of Tainan).
To date, Hu and Vice Premier Eric Liluan Chu might be directly drafted by the KMT to run in Taichung City and Xinbei City, respectively, analysts said.
Chu is the only KMT member who has displayed willingness to take part in the mayoral election in Xinbei City.
In the case of the nomination process to select candidates in Taipei City, Kaohsiung City and Tainan City, the KMT is slated to launch public opinion polls later this month.
Apart from incumbent Taipei Mayor Hau Lung-bin, City Councilor Yang Shih-chiu has also made his bid for Taipei mayor clear.

In Kaohsiung City, six KMT members, including four legislators -- Huang Chao- shun, Ho Tsai-feng, Lin Yi-shih and Chang Hsien-yao -- as well as former lawmaker Su Ying-kui and incumbent Presidential Vice Secretary-General Lai Feng- wei, have made known their intentions to vie for the mayoral post.
In Tainan City, meanwhile, former KMT lawmakers Lee Chuan-chiao and Kuo Tien- tsai and incumbent Tainan City Councilor Hsieh Lung-chieh are potential contenders for the party's nomination.

DOC.HEADLINE: Ex-Latvian president offers political insights
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, April 13 (CNA) 04/13/10 21:16:42 (By Chris Wang)

TEXT.P: Former president of the Republic of Latvia Vaira Vike-Freiberga shared her observations on various political topics from her unique point of view as a psychologist Tuesday before concluding a week-long visit to Taiwan.

All countries are advised to use referendums cautiously because in some cases people tend to be misinformed, she told reporters, adding that her training in psychology gave her an advantage as "a good listener" in comparison to other politicians.

Vike-Freiberga, 72, visited Taiwan amid heated local debate on whether to hold a referendum on a proposed Economic Cooperation Framework Agreement (ECFA) between Taiwan and China aimed at lowering tariffs and relaxing trade regulations.

Citing the example of a failed ratification of the European Constitution in France in 2005, Vike-Freiberga said French voters did not vote for the Constitution not because they did not support the treaty but because they did not like the government led by then-President Jacques Chirac.

The failed first referendum on the Lisbon Treaty in Ireland in 2008, she added, was a classical case of misinformation because under Irish law the government is not allowed to promote its policy. The opposition gave the electorate false information and successfully prevented the passage of the referendum.

"This is the danger in referendum... It's very easy to mislead them (the voters) . Psychologically this potential of misinformation of the issue of referendum makes referendum, I think, an insecure instrument for finding out the true position of the people, " she said.

Vike-Freiberga was elected president of Latvia in 1999. In 2003, she was re- elected for a second term. During her tenure, she played a crucial role in leading Latvia to join the North Atlantic Treaty Organization (NATO) and the EU.

Vike-Freiberga, who has previously been nominated to run for the position of Secretary-General of the United Nations and for President of the European Council, declined to comment any further on Taiwan's political relations and economic initiative with China.

However, she said she saw nothing but a promising economic future for Taiwan because the country has always been at the forefront of innovation, development of high technology, and re-orienting itself to an economy of high value-added products, which she described as "the only way of survival in a modern world of free trade."

In a free trade world, "you cannot protect yourself the way you did before, " but at the other end of the spectrum Taiwan is able to gain the access to the huge China market and create a huge opportunity, she said.
In terms of the sensitive agriculture issue, she acknowledged that it has been a complicated issue and "one of the thorniest problems in the world, which everyone has to face."

"Any country has to think about having enough food to feed its people in case something happens. To some extent, each country has to produce some food, " she said, adding that this is why farmers in the EU are so heavily subsidized.

DOC.HEADLINE: Improving cross-strait ties will not affect ties with Paraguay
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, April 13 (CNA) 04/13/10 22:04:25 (By Lee Shu-hua and Fanny Liu)

TEXT.P: President Ma Ying-jeou assured Paraguay Tuesday that his moves to improve Taiwan's relations with China are aimed at reducing tension across the Taiwan Strait and enhancing economic and trade ties, and will not affect the long-term friendship between Taiwan and Paraguay.

In a meeting with Paraguayan Foreign Minister H.E. Hector Lacognata at the Presidential Office that same day, Ma praised the development of Paraguay under the administration of President Fernando Lugo in recent years.

He pointed out that Taiwan has built solid relations with Paraguay and enjoys sound cooperation with the country in a variety of fields such as agriculture, industry, the military, medicine, culture and economics.
Ma said he believes Taiwan's relations with Paraguay will become even more consolidated in the future, as the two sides have always supported freedom, democracy and prosperity.
He also expressed his gratitude to Lacognata for sending regards to Taiwan after Typhoon Morakot hit southern Taiwan last August, and for his enthusiasm in continuing to enhance bilateral relations.
Taiwan, which now has 23 formal allies, has had diplomatic ties with Paraguay since 1957, the country's sole diplomatic ally in South America.

DOC.HEADLINE: 3K sector to see foreign labor ratio increase
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, April 13 (CNA) 04/13/10 22:05:06 (By Chen Shun-hsieh and Lilian Wu)

TEXT.P: The Council of Labor Affairs (CLA) said Tuesday that to meet the needs of different manufacturing sectors, the current three-tier system for hiring foreign labor will be changed, with the labor-intensive industries getting the highest ratio of foreign laborers.
Under the proposed change, high-tech manufacturers will see their ratio for foreign laborers compared to locals drop to 10 percent from the present 15 percent.
However, those in the 3K industries -- referring to dirty, dangerous and demanding working conditions -- the ratio will be increased from the present 20 percent to 35 percent.

The CLA said that it convened a counselling meeting on foreign laborers in January to discuss whether to adjust the three-tier system -- 15 percent, 18 percent and 20 percent -- to a five-tier system -- 10 percent, 15 percent, 20 percent, 25 percent and 30 percent.
As those taking part in the meeting were not familiar with the labor situation in the 3K sector, they decided to make an on-site inspection, after which they agreed to the change.

Tsai Meng-liang, section chief of the CLA's foreign labor management, said that "under the principle of not increasing the total number of foreign laborers, we have made a more flexible adjustment in the ratio of foreign laborers according to different trades."
The measures will be put into practice in July or August at the earliest, he added.

The CLA said that the members of the counselling meeting originally worried that the five-tier system might squeeze job opportunities for local workers, but after careful calculation, decided that the new system will only create 400 additional jobs for foreign laborers.

In addition, a single major manufacturer with more than 1,000 local laborers will see the ratio for employing foreign laborers drop by 1 percent, and if over 2,000 local workers, the ratio will be cut by 2 percent.

DOC.HEADLINE: Possible showdown over innovation bill: legislative speaker
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, April 13 (CNA) 04/13/10 22:49:49 (By Y.C. Chou and Flor Wang)

TEXT.P: A series of votes might need to be called in legislative meetings from April 16 in a bid to swiftly ram an industrial innovation bill through the legislature, Legislative Yuan President Wang Jin-pyng said Tuesday.

According to Wang, the vote might be held in order to force lawmakers of the ruling Kuomintang (KMT) and the opposition Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) to decide the fate of some provisions of the bill upon which the two sides have been unable to reach common ground.

Wang, who chaired a round of negotiations between KMT and DPP legislative caucus members on the bill's latest version earlier in the day, said he will preside over a new round of negotiations the following day in an attempt to bridge the remaining differences.

One critical point on which the two main political parties have failed to reach agreement is corporate income tax, and the two camps might have to resort to a vote to decide its fate, according to high-ranking KMT sources.
As the innovation bill contains 74 clauses, its final passage could be delayed until an April 20 legislative meeting, they added.

Lin Yi-shih, a KMT legislative caucus whip, said the party insists on lowering corporate income tax from 20 percent to 17 percent, granting innovation incentives of NT$10 billion, and providing small- and medium-sized companies with government subsidies for additional workers they hire.

The DPP, meanwhile, supports a 17.5 percent corporate income tax, and is strongly opposed to the government subsidy measure on the grounds that it goes against what the party calls the "innovation sprit."

DPP caucus whip Ker Chien-ming said his party will never yield to the KMT's 17 percent corporate income tax proposal and he also predicted that an April 16 vote will be unavoidable on the subsidy measure.

DOC.HEADLINE: CLA opposes delinking of foreign laborer wages to minimum wage
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, April 13 (CNA) 04/13/10 23:00:54 (By Chen Shun-hsieh and Lilian Wu)

TEXT.P: The Council of Labor Affairs (CLA) said Tuesday that the delinking of foreign laborers' wages to the country's minimum wage would involve wide-ranging issues and that the current policy should be maintained.
Meanwhile, a labor rights group also said that it "vehemently opposes such a delinking."
They were responding to remarks made by Premier Wu Den-yih earlier in the day that "there is room for discussion on whether to delink the wages for foreign laborers to the nation's minimum wage."
Wages for foreign laborers were adjusted to those of the minimum wage for local laborers of NT$17,280 (US$546.8) in July 2007.
Many enterprises and legislators have since said that the wages should be delinked to induce overseas Taiwan businessmen to return to Taiwan and enhance industrial competitiveness.
CLA Minister Wang Ju-hsuan, speaking through Pan Shih-wei, a council spokesman, said the link should not be removed and that the current policy should be maintained.
Pan said that if the link is removed, then the Labor Basic Law should be revised.
The policy of industrial development and the perception of the international community should also be taken into consideration, Pan said.

Chu Wei-li, secretary-general of the National Federation of Independent Trade Unions, said that only employers of foreign laborers in the manufacturing industry have the minimum wage problem and that the large number of foreign caregivers are not covered.

Entrepreneurs are trying relentlessly to ask the government to delink the minimum wage, and if they get their way, will introduce massive numbers of cheap foreign laborers, squeezing the job opportunities for local laborers, Chu noted.
"The federation has long been opposed to such a proposal, " Chu said.
According to the latest figures from the CLA, foreign caregivers outnumbered foreign manual laborers in February for the first time ever in Taiwan, 177,926 to 177,210.

Although the trend reversed in March, with the 180,000 migrant workers in manual labor jobs slightly outnumbering the 179,000 migrant caregivers, the CLA official said caregivers will form the backbone of the foreign workforce in the long run.

DOC.HEADLINE: Incumbent might be drafted by KMT to run for Taichung mayor
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, April 13 (CNA) 04/13/10 20:48:31 (By S.H. Lee and Flor Wang)

TEXT.P: Incumbent Taichung Mayor Jason Hu might be drafted by the ruling Kuomintang (KMT) to run in the upgraded central Taiwan's Taichung City -- a merger of the existing city with Taichung County -- in Nov. 27 mayoral elections.

Quoting KMT Secretary-General King Pu-tsung after a party meeting, KMT spokesman Su Jun-pin said Legislator Chi Kuo-tung has expressed willingness to withdraw from seeking the party's nomination as candidate for the sake of party unity.
His withdrawal would mean that Legislator Liu Chuan-chung would be Hu's sole competitor within the KMT.

Although the KMT will adopt a "coordination and recruitment" mechanism and combine the results of public opinion surveys as an important reference to pick the best candidate for the race, Su said the party will further "coordinate" with Liu (implicitly meaning that it will be Hu who will represent the KMT in Taichung).

The November special municipality elections will also see voting for the mayors of Taipei City, as well as for Xinbei City (an upgrade of Taipei County), Kaohsiung City (a merger of the city and county of Kaohsiung, and Tainan City (a merger of the city and county of Tainan).
To date, Hu and Vice Premier Eric Liluan Chu might be directly drafted by the KMT to run in Taichung City and Xinbei City, respectively, analysts said.
Chu is the only KMT member who has displayed willingness to take part in the mayoral election in Xinbei City.
In the case of the nomination process to select candidates in Taipei City, Kaohsiung City and Tainan City, the KMT is slated to launch public opinion polls later this month.
Apart from incumbent Taipei Mayor Hau Lung-bin, City Councilor Yang Shih-chiu has also made his bid for Taipei mayor clear.

In Kaohsiung City, six KMT members, including four legislators -- Huang Chao- shun, Ho Tsai-feng, Lin Yi-shih and Chang Hsien-yao -- as well as former lawmaker Su Ying-kui and incumbent Presidential Vice Secretary-General Lai Feng- wei, have made known their intentions to vie for the mayoral post.
In Tainan City, meanwhile, former KMT lawmakers Lee Chuan-chiao and Kuo Tien- tsai and incumbent Tainan City Councilor Hsieh Lung-chieh are potential contenders for the party's nomination.

DOC.HEADLINE: Ex-Latvian president offers political insights
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, April 13 (CNA) 04/13/10 21:16:42 (By Chris Wang)

TEXT.P: Former president of the Republic of Latvia Vaira Vike-Freiberga shared her observations on various political topics from her unique point of view as a psychologist Tuesday before concluding a week-long visit to Taiwan.

All countries are advised to use referendums cautiously because in some cases people tend to be misinformed, she told reporters, adding that her training in psychology gave her an advantage as "a good listener" in comparison to other politicians.

Vike-Freiberga, 72, visited Taiwan amid heated local debate on whether to hold a referendum on a proposed Economic Cooperation Framework Agreement (ECFA) between Taiwan and China aimed at lowering tariffs and relaxing trade regulations.

Citing the example of a failed ratification of the European Constitution in France in 2005, Vike-Freiberga said French voters did not vote for the Constitution not because they did not support the treaty but because they did not like the government led by then-President Jacques Chirac.

The failed first referendum on the Lisbon Treaty in Ireland in 2008, she added, was a classical case of misinformation because under Irish law the government is not allowed to promote its policy. The opposition gave the electorate false information and successfully prevented the passage of the referendum.

"This is the danger in referendum... It's very easy to mislead them (the voters) . Psychologically this potential of misinformation of the issue of referendum makes referendum, I think, an insecure instrument for finding out the true position of the people, " she said.

Vike-Freiberga was elected president of Latvia in 1999. In 2003, she was re- elected for a second term. During her tenure, she played a crucial role in leading Latvia to join the North Atlantic Treaty Organization (NATO) and the EU.

Vike-Freiberga, who has previously been nominated to run for the position of Secretary-General of the United Nations and for President of the European Council, declined to comment any further on Taiwan's political relations and economic initiative with China.

However, she said she saw nothing but a promising economic future for Taiwan because the country has always been at the forefront of innovation, development of high technology, and re-orienting itself to an economy of high value-added products, which she described as "the only way of survival in a modern world of free trade."

In a free trade world, "you cannot protect yourself the way you did before, " but at the other end of the spectrum Taiwan is able to gain the access to the huge China market and create a huge opportunity, she said.
In terms of the sensitive agriculture issue, she acknowledged that it has been a complicated issue and "one of the thorniest problems in the world, which everyone has to face."

"Any country has to think about having enough food to feed its people in case something happens. To some extent, each country has to produce some food, " she said, adding that this is why farmers in the EU are so heavily subsidized.

DOC.HEADLINE: Improving cross-strait ties will not affect ties with Paraguay
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, April 13 (CNA) 04/13/10 22:04:25 (By Lee Shu-hua and Fanny Liu)

TEXT.P: President Ma Ying-jeou assured Paraguay Tuesday that his moves to improve Taiwan's relations with China are aimed at reducing tension across the Taiwan Strait and enhancing economic and trade ties, and will not affect the long-term friendship between Taiwan and Paraguay.

In a meeting with Paraguayan Foreign Minister H.E. Hector Lacognata at the Presidential Office that same day, Ma praised the development of Paraguay under the administration of President Fernando Lugo in recent years.

He pointed out that Taiwan has built solid relations with Paraguay and enjoys sound cooperation with the country in a variety of fields such as agriculture, industry, the military, medicine, culture and economics.
Ma said he believes Taiwan's relations with Paraguay will become even more consolidated in the future, as the two sides have always supported freedom, democracy and prosperity.
He also expressed his gratitude to Lacognata for sending regards to Taiwan after Typhoon Morakot hit southern Taiwan last August, and for his enthusiasm in continuing to enhance bilateral relations.
Taiwan, which now has 23 formal allies, has had diplomatic ties with Paraguay since 1957, the country's sole diplomatic ally in South America.

DOC.HEADLINE: 3K sector to see foreign labor ratio increase
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, April 13 (CNA) 04/13/10 22:05:06 (By Chen Shun-hsieh and Lilian Wu)

TEXT.P: The Council of Labor Affairs (CLA) said Tuesday that to meet the needs of different manufacturing sectors, the current three-tier system for hiring foreign labor will be changed, with the labor-intensive industries getting the highest ratio of foreign laborers.
Under the proposed change, high-tech manufacturers will see their ratio for foreign laborers compared to locals drop to 10 percent from the present 15 percent.
However, those in the 3K industries -- referring to dirty, dangerous and demanding working conditions -- the ratio will be increased from the present 20 percent to 35 percent.

The CLA said that it convened a counselling meeting on foreign laborers in January to discuss whether to adjust the three-tier system -- 15 percent, 18 percent and 20 percent -- to a five-tier system -- 10 percent, 15 percent, 20 percent, 25 percent and 30 percent.
As those taking part in the meeting were not familiar with the labor situation in the 3K sector, they decided to make an on-site inspection, after which they agreed to the change.

Tsai Meng-liang, section chief of the CLA's foreign labor management, said that "under the principle of not increasing the total number of foreign laborers, we have made a more flexible adjustment in the ratio of foreign laborers according to different trades."
The measures will be put into practice in July or August at the earliest, he added.

The CLA said that the members of the counselling meeting originally worried that the five-tier system might squeeze job opportunities for local workers, but after careful calculation, decided that the new system will only create 400 additional jobs for foreign laborers.

In addition, a single major manufacturer with more than 1,000 local laborers will see the ratio for employing foreign laborers drop by 1 percent, and if over 2,000 local workers, the ratio will be cut by 2 percent.

DOC.HEADLINE: Possible showdown over innovation bill: legislative speaker
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, April 13 (CNA) 04/13/10 22:49:49 (By Y.C. Chou and Flor Wang)

TEXT.P: A series of votes might need to be called in legislative meetings from April 16 in a bid to swiftly ram an industrial innovation bill through the legislature, Legislative Yuan President Wang Jin-pyng said Tuesday.

According to Wang, the vote might be held in order to force lawmakers of the ruling Kuomintang (KMT) and the opposition Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) to decide the fate of some provisions of the bill upon which the two sides have been unable to reach common ground.

Wang, who chaired a round of negotiations between KMT and DPP legislative caucus members on the bill's latest version earlier in the day, said he will preside over a new round of negotiations the following day in an attempt to bridge the remaining differences.

One critical point on which the two main political parties have failed to reach agreement is corporate income tax, and the two camps might have to resort to a vote to decide its fate, according to high-ranking KMT sources.
As the innovation bill contains 74 clauses, its final passage could be delayed until an April 20 legislative meeting, they added.

Lin Yi-shih, a KMT legislative caucus whip, said the party insists on lowering corporate income tax from 20 percent to 17 percent, granting innovation incentives of NT$10 billion, and providing small- and medium-sized companies with government subsidies for additional workers they hire.

The DPP, meanwhile, supports a 17.5 percent corporate income tax, and is strongly opposed to the government subsidy measure on the grounds that it goes against what the party calls the "innovation sprit."

DPP caucus whip Ker Chien-ming said his party will never yield to the KMT's 17 percent corporate income tax proposal and he also predicted that an April 16 vote will be unavoidable on the subsidy measure.

DOC.HEADLINE: CLA opposes delinking of foreign laborer wages to minimum wage
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, April 13 (CNA) 04/13/10 23:00:54 (By Chen Shun-hsieh and Lilian Wu)

TEXT.P: The Council of Labor Affairs (CLA) said Tuesday that the delinking of foreign laborers' wages to the country's minimum wage would involve wide-ranging issues and that the current policy should be maintained.
Meanwhile, a labor rights group also said that it "vehemently opposes such a delinking."
They were responding to remarks made by Premier Wu Den-yih earlier in the day that "there is room for discussion on whether to delink the wages for foreign laborers to the nation's minimum wage."
Wages for foreign laborers were adjusted to those of the minimum wage for local laborers of NT$17,280 (US$546.8) in July 2007.
Many enterprises and legislators have since said that the wages should be delinked to induce overseas Taiwan businessmen to return to Taiwan and enhance industrial competitiveness.
CLA Minister Wang Ju-hsuan, speaking through Pan Shih-wei, a council spokesman, said the link should not be removed and that the current policy should be maintained.
Pan said that if the link is removed, then the Labor Basic Law should be revised.
The policy of industrial development and the perception of the international community should also be taken into consideration, Pan said.

Chu Wei-li, secretary-general of the National Federation of Independent Trade Unions, said that only employers of foreign laborers in the manufacturing industry have the minimum wage problem and that the large number of foreign caregivers are not covered.

Entrepreneurs are trying relentlessly to ask the government to delink the minimum wage, and if they get their way, will introduce massive numbers of cheap foreign laborers, squeezing the job opportunities for local laborers, Chu noted.
"The federation has long been opposed to such a proposal, " Chu said.
According to the latest figures from the CLA, foreign caregivers outnumbered foreign manual laborers in February for the first time ever in Taiwan, 177,926 to 177,210.

Although the trend reversed in March, with the 180,000 migrant workers in manual labor jobs slightly outnumbering the 179,000 migrant caregivers, the CLA official said caregivers will form the backbone of the foreign workforce in the long run.

DOC.HEADLINE: Today in history
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, April 14 (CNA) 04/14/10 08:43:40
DOC.TEXT:
Today is Wednesday, April 14, or the first day of the third month of the Year of the Tiger according to the lunar calendar. Following is a list of important events that have occurred on this date in the past:
1629: Christiaan Huygens, the Dutch physicist and astronomer, is born. He discovered Saturn's rings in 1655, pioneered the use of pendulum in clocks in 1657, and formulated Huygens' principle.
1865: US President Abraham Lincoln is failing fast after being shot in the back of the head at point-blank range by actor John Wilkes Booth, a Confederate fanatic, at the Ford Theater in Washington, D.C. He died the next day and was succeeded by Andrew Johnson.
1889: Arnold Toynbee, British historian and author of a 12-volume work entitled "A Study of History," is born.
1903: The typhus vaccine is discovered by Dr. Harry Plotz in New York.
1912: The Titanic strikes an iceberg and sinks in the North Atlantic, killing 1,500 people.
1941: Condemning the Soviet-Japanese Neutrality Pact, Foreign Minister Wang Chung-hui of the Republic of China declares that Outer Mongolia and the northeastern provinces are Chinese territory and that the Soviet-Japanese statement is not binding on China.
1945: US bombers pound Japan's Imperial Palace during World War II.
1949: The Taiwan provincial administration announces a decision to carry out the "37.5 Percent Farm Rental Reduction" and the "Land-to-the-Tiller" policies.
1956: USS Saratoga, a US Navy aircraft carrier which joined the fleet in 1927 as the largest warship in the world, is formally decommissioned.
1956: The first videotape is demonstrated in Chicago.
1962: French Prime Minister Michel Debre resigns and is succeeded by Georges Pompidou.
1971: The new Tourism Bureau of the Ministry of Communications is inaugurated in Taipei.
1972: The first satellite observation station in the Republic of China is inaugurated at National Cheng Kung University.
1973: President Nguyen Van Thieu of the Republic of Vietnam leaves Taipei for home after a three-day visit.
1973: Dr. Jesus Soto Amesty, chairman of the Venezuela Senate Foreign Policy Committee, arrives in Taipei for a ten-day visit.
1975: Sikkim abolishes its monarchy and seeks full Indian statehood.
1976: A total of 3,460 students from 642 middle schools compete in the Taiwan Area Games.
1977: The ROC Ministry of Foreign Affairs announces severance of diplomatic relations with the Hashemite Kingdom of Jordan.
1982: Armed bandit Lee Shih-khe robs the Land Bank of Taiwan's Kuting Branch in Taipei City of more than NT$5 million, a major criminal case at that time.
1988: The Soviet Union ends its intervention in Afghanistan and allows its troops to withdraw.
1993: On International Women's Day, a Chinese newspaper asks 100 women what they would most like to be. Sixty say that they want to be men.
1994: Two US F-15 fighters shoot down two American helicopters over northern Iraq killing 26 people.
1999: Pakistan test-fires a 2,000-km range ballistic missile.
2000: Ovidio Manuel Barbosa Pequeno, the new Sao Tome and Principe ambassador to the Republic of China, presents his credentials to President Lee Teng-hui.
2001: A four-member U.S. Senate delegation led by Sen. Phil Gramm (R-TX) arrives in Taipei to begin a three-day visit.
Confucius' lesson of the day: "To be poor without complaining is not easy; but it is easy to be rich without being proud."

DOC.HEADLINE: Taiwan shares open higher
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, April 14 (CNA) 04/14/10 09:10:18 (By Sofia Wu)

DOC.HEADLINE: Taiwan headline news
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, April 14 (CNA) 04/14/10 10:21:48

DOC.HEADLINE: China Times: A clear explanation on ECFA

TEXT.P: We expect to see a rational and professional discussion when President Ma Ying- jeou debates opposition Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) Chairperson Tsai Ing- wen on the proposed economic cooperation framework agreement (ECFA) later this month. We also hope that both sides will clearly answer the doubts held by the public.

What the DPP needs to explain clearly is if Taiwan does not sign the ECFA with China, then what other methods can it adopt to offset the decline in its export competitiveness as a result of its exclusion from an East Asian free trade bloc?

The DPP should also clearly tell us its views on cross-Taiwan Strait economic and trade ties. If the ECFA is signed by the Ma administration as planned and if the DPP returns to power in 2012, will the DPP abrogate the ECFA?

As to the Kuomintang, as a responsible ruler, it cannot report only the good news and withhold the bad. It should reveal which sectors will be the possible winners and losers under the future ECFA and what relief measures the government will provide to help the losers.

This issue concerns the livelihoods of many people and the survival of many businesses. The government cannot play down the issue by saying that it has earmarked so many billions in relief funds. There should be employment measures for those workers who lose their jobs as a result of the ECFA.

Also, the government has repeatedly emphasized that the signing of the ECFA will make possible Taiwan's bids to forge free trade agreements (FTAs) with other countries. It needs to specify the extent of its effects. Can it make a commitment as to how long it will take for the bids to succeed and how many FTAs are in sight?
