DOC.HEADLINE: Nine moderate quakes hit Taitung in eastern Taiwan
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, April 14 (CNA) 04/14/10 11:36:56 (By Chen Shun-hsieh and Sofia Wu)

TEXT.P: Nine earthquakes with magnitudes ranging between 3.6 and 5.1 struck eastern Taiwan between late Tuesday and early Wednesday, according to the Central Weather Bureau's Seismology Center.
Although the quakes were felt by residents in the eastern counties of Taitung and Hualien, no damage or casualties have been reported, authorities said.

The first of the nine quakes, a magnitude 4.7 temblor that occurred at 10:29 p.m. Tuesday, was centered 9.8 kilometers northwest of the Chenggong seismological monitoring station in Taitung County and struck at a depth of 5 km, said Seismology Center Director Kuo Kai-wen.

The biggest quake of the series, a magnitude 5.1 quake, struck at 4: 49 a.m. Wednesday at a depth of 10 km. Its epicenter was located around 5.4 km northwest of the Chenggong seismological monitoring station.

A magnitude 4.1 aftershock occurred six minutes later at a nearly identical depth and location. Its epicenter was located 5.5 km northwest of the Chenggong station, and its focus was at a depth of 9.8 km.
Kuo said that although the frequency of preshocks and aftershocks was relatively high, their magnitudes were not strong and the areas affected were limited.
Even though the main shock reached a magnitude of 5, it lasted for only 1.18 seconds and had little impact on the safety of buildings in the area, Kuo said.

Noting that the Chenggong area lies where the Eurasian and Philippine Sea tectonic plates converge, Kuo said the area is earthquake-prone, with the plates being pushed down an average of 8 centimeters annually.

By helping release energy building up between the tectonic plates, the latest series of earthquakes may have helped prevent a potentially larger earthquake capable of inflicting more serious damage, he added.

DOC.HEADLINE: Apple Daily: Fraud prevalent in NHI system

TEXT.P: Few higher-income earners affected by the recent hikes in National Health Insurance (NHI) premiums have expressed opposition to the increases because they think it is their social obligation to pay more than the poor.

However, when authorities turn a blind eye to flaws in the system, such as fraudulent NHI reimbursement claims by hospitals, a lack of transparency in drug prices, and the refusal by local governments to honor their premium obligations, how can we ask these higher-income earners pay the higher premiums willingly?

The Department of Health (DOH) disclosed Tuesday that 10 hospitals, seven doctors and 20 patients were allegedly involved in NHI fraud, including Kaohsiung Medical University Hospital, which was fined NT$150 million.
This is in fact is only the tip of the iceberg. If all these problems are not resolved, the hikes in NHI premiums will lose their justification and draw more and more protests.

The Bureau of National Health Insurance has the responsibility and obligation to supervise the disbursement of the premiums we have paid. In particular, those people who are affected by the hikes should be provided with a fair explanation. (April 14, 2010)

DOC.HEADLINE: Local scientists identify keys to bipolar disorder in Chinese
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei April 14 (CNA) 04/14/10 12:17:39 (By Sunnie Chen)

TEXT.P: A group of Taiwan scientists have successfully identified four genes that are associated with bipolar I disorder in people who are ethnically Chinese.

"This study marks important progress in the identification of disease genes for bipolar I disorder. It is the only large scale bipolar I disorder study ever done on Han Chinese or on any Asian population, " said the team's leader, Andrew Tai-Ann Cheng, a distinguished research fellow in Academia Sinica's Institute of Biomedical Sciences.
Bipolar I disorder is a mood disorder defined by the presence of recurrent episodes of abnormally elevated mood (mania), according to the research team.
Some patients who experience manic episodes also experience depressive episodes, or mixed episodes in which features of both mania and depression are present at the same time.
The affliction, which affects approximately 1 percent of the world's population, often interferes with patients' personal lives and affects their ability to function socially.
The scientists said the heritability of bipolar I disorder has been estimated to be around 80 percent and is passed down through multiple genes, but the exact cause of the disease remains unclear.
In this study researchers analyzed the genes of 1409 patients with bipolar I disorder and 1000 normal individuals using high density genotyping technology.
They linked four genes -- SP8, ST8SIA2, CACNB2 and KCTD12 -- to bipolar I disorder in ethnic Chinese people, and three of them (SP8, CACNB2 and KCTD12) were identified for the first time.

Because SP8 and ST8SIA2 influence the development of the brain, the scientists said their study supports a model attributing the development of bipolar I disorder to the growth of the brain or central nervous system.

CACNB2 and KCTD12 are genes regulating calcium and potassium ion channels, which also suggested that disorders of the ion channels -- proteins that regulate the flow of ions across cell membranes -- contribute to the development of bipolar I disorder.
"The genes identified in this study pave the way for researchers to elucidate pathogenic mechanisms for bipolar disorder and perhaps new drug targets for the disease," Cheng said.

With the combined effort of public health and medical centers, Cheng hopes that in the future genetic factors associated with the pharmacological effects of mood stabilizers can also be identified, leading to advances in health care, personalized medication, and the prevention of bipolar disorder and suicide.

The study was the result of a collaboration between the Institute of Biomedical Sciences and 25 medical centers and psychiatric institutes in Taiwan. A Taiwan Bipolar Consortium was established by Cheng in 2003 to cement the collaboration of the many organizations.
The study was published online in the international scientific journal Molecular Psychiatry on April 13.

DOC.HEADLINE: TransAsia Airways to resume Taipei-Kaohsiung flights May 1
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, April 14 (CNA) 04/14/10 13:03:51 (By Chao Hsiao-hui and Sofia Wu)

TEXT.P: Taipei-based TransAsia Airways will resume Taipei-Kaohsiung flights May 1 for the convenience of southern Taiwan travelers who need to make transit stops at Taipei Songshan Airport during direct cross-Taiwan Strait flights, a spokesman said Wednesday.

Initially, the spokesman said, the carrier will offer one flight in each direction daily, using a 70-seater ATR-72 turboprop. The southbound flight will take off from Taipei at 8 p.m. and is scheduled to arrive at Kaohsiung International airport at 9 p.m.
The northbound flight will take off from Kaohsiung at 6: 45 a.m. and will land at Songshan Airport at 7:45 a.m., the spokesman said.
TransAsia Airways suspended the service 18 months ago amid rising competition from the high-speed railway.

"The resumption of flight services is mainly aimed at meeting the demands of southern Taiwan passengers who want to take TransAsia flights to China from Songshan Airport, " the spokesman said, adding that the resumption is also part of preparations to cash in on business opportunities to be generated from the planned opening of more outbound flight routes from Songshan Airport in the near future.

DOC.HEADLINE: Talk of the day -- Interviews with President Ma
DOC.DATELINE: 04/14/10 13:23:05 (By Elizabeth Hsu)

TEXT.P: President Ma Ying-jeou's policies to sign a trade pact with China and cut the corporate tax rate to 17 percent have stirred plenty of controversy. But Ma has shown little hesitation in explaining his positions in the face of severe criticism.

The corporate tax rate reduction became the centerpiece of a bill on industrial innovation under review in the legislature. The new provision, which was pushed by Ma, replaced a number of targeted tax incentives in the bill designed to spur innovation and industrial upgrading.
On Tuesday, Ma addressed the issues in interviews with Taiwan's two main business dailies.
The following are excerpts of Ma's interviews with the Economic Daily News and the Commercial Times published Wednesday:
Economic Daily News:

Speaking of the plan to lower the corporate income tax rate from the current 20 percent to 17 percent, which will consequently lead to a decline in the country's general revenues, Ma said "no policies are perfect."
"I know there will be gunfire outside, but I must make the decision," he said.
Opposition Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) Legislator Ker Chien-ming criticized the government's policy reversal and denounced reported talks between the ruling and opposition parties as "fake."
"The only thing that's true was the directive of Ma Ying-jeou, " he complained.
Ker denounced Ma as a disgrace to constitutional politics for publicly getting involved in legislative proceedings.

In the interview, Ma stressed that the proposed cross-Taiwan Strait economic cooperation framework agreement (ECFA) and the industrial innovation bill will both play crucial roles at the present stage of Taiwan's economy.
Once the bill clears the floor of the Legislative Yuan, the government's planned "special zones for economic and trade operations" will more easily become reality.
"Once the zones are drawn up and other arrangements made, they will draw investment from overseas Taiwanese businesses and foreign companies," he said.
Ma said he believes that the loss in revenue due to the corporate income tax cut will only be a short term phenomenon. In the longer term, as investment kicks in, tax revenues will rise, he said.

Asked whether his government has concrete and effective measures to promote employment, the president stated that the first thing that needs to be done is to adjust the country's industrial structure.
Taiwan is currently actively promoting the development of service sectors, such as tourism. He expects the number of visitors to Taiwan will surge to 5 million this year, from 4.4 million in 2009.
The visits are expected to generate revenues of NT$500 billion for Taiwan in 2010, Ma anticipated.
Commercial Times:
Asked about whether signing the ECFA will trigger growth of property prices, Ma explained that the proposed trade pact does not focus on "investment" but "trade."

Acknowledging that overseas funds are expected to flow in after the agreement is sealed, Ma said the Financial Supervisory Commission and the central bank will closely monitor the movements of the funds.

As to the problem of rising prices of residential housing in metropolitan areas, Ma explained that the government has a program of providing free-interest loans for young people to buy a home after they get married and have their first child.
Under the program, the government has subsidized mortgages for more than 10,000 applicants. "I have demanded the Executive Yuan to open the program to another 10,000 people or so," Ma said.

Addressing the ECFA, Ma said he hoped the pact will be signed as early as June, and he reiterated that Taiwan's market will not open its doors to any Chinese agricultural imports beyond the 1,415 agricultural items that are already allowed in.
He also stressed that no issues related to the movement of laborers will be put on the agenda of the ECFA negotiations and that the agreement will be based on the principles of "small and necessary."
Speaking of his upcoming public debate with DPP Chairwoman Tsai Ing-wen on the ECFA issues on April 25, President Ma described Tsai as an "opponent worthy of respect."

In the debate, he will not avoid answering questions on Taiwan's sovereignty amid warming cross-strait relations, Ma noted. The debate is an opportunity for him and Tsai to explain their thinking on the controversial ECFA, he said.
He also sees the debate as meaningful because it allows the ruling and opposition parties to converse with each other on national affairs, Ma said. (April 14, 2010).

DOC.HEADLINE: Economic Daily News: A big gamble on innovation bill

TEXT.P: The fight over the corporate income tax rate has been what is stalling the passage of the industrial innovation bill.

We think the simplest solution to the problem is for the ruling Kuomintang (KMT) to endorse a simple tax rate of 17 percent or 17.5 percent as proposed by the opposition Democratic Progressive Party and drop the redundant "17+1+1" package -- which would lower the tax rate to 17 percent plus offer employment subsidies to small- and medium-sized enterprises and tax credits for R&D expenses.
Research and development is the responsibility of businesses in the first place, and using tax breaks to encourage R&D activities will confuse cause with effect.

International data show that even without any R&D incentives, R&D spending still accounts for a 1 percent share of gross domestic product (GDP) . The absence of government incentives does not mean businesses will stop investing in R&D.

The ruling party's effort to maintain tax credits for R&D spending may appear to uphold the core idea of industrial innovation. In substance, however, the move will only expand the government's financial losses and add more controversy to the bill.
Doing away with the tax breaks does not mean the government will stop supporting industry. There are other methods that can be used, such as providing direct subsidies to selected sectors.

It is unnecessary for the ruling party to make a big gamble and challenge the government's financial limits. A 17 percent tax rate is already sufficient to boost the international competitiveness of Taiwanese businesses and attract an influx of foreign investors.

DOC.HEADLINE: Taiwan share prices close higher
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, April 14 (CNA) 04/14/10 15:23:27 (by Olivia Wang)

TEXT.P: Taiwan's share prices closed higher Wednesday with the weighted index, the market's key barometer, moving up 67.4 points, or 0.83 percent, to close at 8,097.13.
The local bourse opened at 8,077.97 and fluctuated between 8,040.01 and 8,102.38 during the day's trading. Market turnover totaled NT$98.04 billion (US$3.12 billion) .

Foodstuff shares were up 0.67 percent, textile issues advanced 0.49 percent and cement issues gained 0.13 percent.
Gainers outnumbered losers 1,894 to 1,139, with 338 remaining unchanged.
Foreign investors and Chinese QDIIs were net buyers of NT$ 5.99 billion in shares.

DOC.HEADLINE: Taiwan downgrades travel alert for Bangkok to orange
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, April 14 (CNA) 04/14/10 15:34:19 (By Hsieh Chia-chen and Sofia Wu)

TEXT.P: The Ministry of Foreign Affairs (MOFA) has downgraded its travel alert for Bangkok to orange from red as the volatile clashes that gripped the Thai capital over the weekend have dissipated, the ministry said in a statement Wednesday.
"The downgrade takes effect immediately," the statement said.

The ministry raised the alert level to red last Sunday as clashes between security forces and anti-government protesters escalated in downtown Bangkok, leaving at least 20 dead and 800 others injured.

In Taiwan's four-tier travel advisory system, a red alert is the highest level of warning, which advises local people to refrain from traveling to the affected region. Orange is the second most serious warning level.

The MOFA statement said it decided to downgrade its travel warning to orange after the Thai government announced it will no longer use armed security forces to disperse the "red shirt" demonstrators and because traffic in the Thai capital has almost returned to normal.

As protesters still occupy the Phan Fa Bridge intersection and another in the Ratchaprasong commercial district, the ministry said it has asked the Tourism Bureau under the Ministry of Transportation and Communications to advise local travel agencies not to take Taiwanese travelers to those areas.
The ministry also promised to keep close tabs on the situation in Thailand and inform the public of up-to-the-minute developments there for the reference of local would-be visitors.

Although the confrontation between security forces and protesters has calmed a bit, the ministry suggested that local people still avoid non-essential visits to Bangkok, Nonthaburi, Samut Prakan, Pathum Thani, Nakhon Pathom and Ayutthaya.
For those who are already in Thailand, the ministry said, they should pay greater attention to their personal safety.
Those who encounter an emergency situation in Thailand are welcome to dial a hot line operated by Taiwan's representative office in Thailand, the ministry added.

DOC.HEADLINE: Taiwan remains closed to Chinese white-collar workers: minister
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, April 14 (CNA) 04/14/10 16:20:44 (By Chou Yung-chieh and Elizabeth Hsu)

TEXT.P: Taiwan has never opened its doors to Chinese white-collar workers, Minister of the Interior Jiang Yi-huah said Wednesday, after lawmakers questioned a government move to allow Chinese employees in cross-national companies to stay in Taiwan for longer periods.

Cross-national companies are foreign companies which have operations in Taiwan and are permitted to staff certain positions in such operations with personnel from outside Taiwan, some of whom might happen to be Chinese. The government considers such workers to be in a separate category from Chinese white-collar workers.

The National Immigration Agency (NIA) revised its regulations in early April to relax restrictions on Chinese workers in cross-national enterprises who apply for an extension of the period for which they can work and stay in Taiwan. Under the amendment, the extended stay was prolonged from one year to three years.
The measure was taken to allow enterprises to be more flexible in how they deploy their workforces, according to the agency.
However, the amendment, made at the request of industrial and commercial business groups, triggered concerns among legislators over a possible impact on local white-collar workers.

Speaking at the Legislative Yuan, Legislator Lai Ching-te argued that the law has never banned Chinese people from doing skilled work such as quality control or providing technical services in Taiwan, and that they can be paid in Taiwan for work done here.
"The Chinese employees pose an impact on local white-collar workers, " he contended at a meeting of the legislature's Interior Administration Committee.
In response, Jiang explained that the NIA's move did not open the country's doors to Chinese white-collar workers.

The restrictions on the Chinese people who come to Taiwan for business activities are still in place, including that they can only stay in the country for a maximum of three months, are not allowed to apply for a work permit, and are prohibited from doing any paid work, the minister said.

Acknowledging that a growing number of visits by Chinese people for business activities could have an impact on local workers, their visits, however, also bring economic benefits to the country, he said.
Jiang pointed out that in 2008, 33,000 Chinese people came to Taiwan for business activities. The number increased to 48,000 in 2009, he added.

DOC.HEADLINE: Taiwan should drop 'politics of hate': KMT official
DOC.DATELINE: Singapore, April 14 (CNA) 04/14/10 16:30:59 (By Charles Kang and Y.F. Low)

TEXT.P: The two major political parties in Taiwan should move toward positive competition and stop promoting the "politics of hate, " ruling Kuomintang (KMT) Secretary-General King Pu-tsung has said in a recent interview with a Singaporean newspaper.

An example of such politics is the accusation by former Vice President Annette Lu of the Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) that President Ma Ying-jeou "does not know Taiwan" and "does not identify with the Taiwanese people, " King told Lianhe Zaobao daily in the interview conducted Monday in Taipei.
The content of the interview was published Wednesday.
According to King, the DPP used to manipulate the hate between native Taiwanese and mainlanders to its advantage, and such manipulation has since been expanded to the broader Taiwan-China context.
In this context, King noted, Taiwan is portrayed as the weaker party that is bullied by China, and every KMT member like Ma is seen as trying to sell out Taiwan.
"You may not like Ma, but you have no need to hate him," he said.
King said the Ma administration will show the people that everything it has done is in the interests of Taiwan and that the people will be wise enough to make their own judgment.

On the year-end mayoral elections in five special municipalities, King acknowledged there is not a region where the KMT will be 100 percent assured of winning, and he said the campaigns in Tainan and Kaohsiung would be especially difficult.
King said, however, that he has told his colleagues to stay confident, adding that he will step down if the KMT wins fewer than three of the five races.
King said that as Ma's senior aide, he will carry through the party chairman's ideal for reforms to shed the KMT's negative image as a vote-buyer.

DOC.HEADLINE: U.S. dollar down on Taipei Forex
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, April 14 (CNA) 04/14/10 16:31:57 (By Olivia Wang)

TEXT.P: The U.S. dollar lost ground against the New Taiwan dollar on the Taipei Foreign Exchange Wednesday, dropping NT$0.12 to close at NT$31.460.
A total of US$1.17 billion changed hands during the trading session.
The U.S. dollar opened at the day's high of NT$31.580 and dropped to a low of NT$31.419 before rebounding.

DOC.HEADLINE: DPP's anti-ECFA arguments flawed: premier
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, April 14 (CNA) 04/14/10 16:43:48 (By Hsieh Chia-chen and Fanny Liu)

TEXT.P: Premier Wu Den-yih said Wednesday that the opposition Democratic Progressive Party's (DPP's) arguments against a proposed trade pact with China are flawed, as the government will not open markets to more Chinese agricultural products or allow imports of Chinese labor.

In addition, the government will not lower tariffs on existing Chinese agricultural products after signing the economic cooperation framework agreement (ECFA) with China, Wu said during a television interview.

Wu said that "early harvest lists" drawn up by the two sides for priority tariff treatment or access will not necessarily include 500 or 600 items at one time, but would prioritize urgent and necessary items.
The government will not accept an early harvest list proposed by the Chinese side that would have an adverse impact on Taiwan, he added.

While the DPP continually argues that signing an ECFA with China will allow imports of Chinese agricultural products, Wu said, it was the administration of former President Chen Shui-bian of the DPP that opened imports of 936 Chinese agricultural products.

Wu said that many businesses in the U.S., Europe and Japan hope that the ECFA can be signed as soon as possible, which would lower Taiwan's tariffs. He said foreign businesses would prefer to establish plants or operation headquarters in Taiwan after the ECFA is signed because it is more democratic and experienced than China.
The premier also said that as Taiwan's automobile industry has better technology and credibility, even China National Heavy Duty Truck Group Corp. is thinking about setting up plants in Taiwan.
Some Taiwanese food manufacturers have cooperated with Chinese partners to establish plants in Taiwan and then sell their products made in Taiwan back to China, he said.
People have more confidence in products which are made in Taiwan, Wu said, adding that "MIT (Made in Taiwan) products have higher prices than MIC (Made in China) ones."

DOC.HEADLINE: Lawmakers agree on NT$54 billion dredging project
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, April 14 (CNA) 04/14/10 17:10:42 (By Y.F. Low)

TEXT.P: The government will set aside NT$54 billion over six years to dredge the three major reservoirs in southern Taiwan in an effort to stabilize the water supply in the Tainan and Kaohsiung areas, according to an agreement reached by legislators Wednesday.

In a consultation session on a draft bill to allow for the cleanup of the Tsengwen, Nanhua and Wushantou reservoirs, legislators agreed to draw NT$26.5 billion from a special economic stimulus budget and another NT$2 billion from a special public construction budget to fund the reservoir project.

In the original version of the bill proposed by the Cabinet, the cost of the project, which would involve clearing sediment in the reservoirs and maintaining their watersheds, was estimated at NT$50 billion.
The reservoirs have had a severe silt problem since Typhoon Morakot struck last August, which has greatly reduced their water storage capacity.

DOC.HEADLINE: DPP's corporate income tax rate has no solid basis: PM
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, April 14 (CNA) 04/14/10 17:19:34 (By Hsieh Chia-chen and Lilian Wu)

TEXT.P: Premier Wu Den-yih said Wednesday that the opposition Democratic Progressive Party's (DPP's) advocacy of a 17.5 percent corporate income tax rate is merely following one of the options the administration has been considering.

The premier said that when the Executive Yuan considers an industrial innovation bill -- which it considers essential to encouraging innovation and investment in Taiwan -- to replace the Statute for Upgrading Industry that expired at the end of 2009, it has several options, including cutting the corporate income tax to 17 percent or 18 percent.
The DPP only picked up one of the options under consideration, and the party has "no solid basis" for its advocacy, according to Wu.

The ruling Kuomintang (KMT) legislative caucus decided earlier this week to lower corporate income tax from 20 percent to 17 percent, granting innovation incentives of NT$10 billion, and providing small- and medium-sized enterprises (SMEs) with government subsidies for additional workers they hire.

The DPP, meanwhile, supports a 17.5 percent corporate income tax, and is strongly opposed to the government subsidy measure, on the grounds that it goes against what the party calls the "innovation sprit."
The two parties face a possible showdown Friday, as the legislature might decide to hold a series of votes on the controversial provisions of the innovation bill.
The premier said that although corporate income tax cuts will result in tax revenue losses in the short term, it will increase the nation's international competitiveness in the long run.
Finance Minister Lee Sush-der estimated that the tax revenue losses will amount to NT$34.3 billion (US$1.08 billion).
Wu noted that the Statute for Upgrading Industry allowed the high-tech industry to enjoy big tax incentives.

This will be the first time the government has used a streamlined tax to cover the high-tech industry, traditional industries and those industries that target domestic consumption on equal terms so that SMEs will also enjoy the single lowered tax rate.

The premier noted that Singapore cut its corporate tax from 18 percent to 17 percent this year, while the corporate tax in Hong Kong is 16.5 percent. The administration, he added, decided to follow the Singapore model when selecting the 17 percent rate.

DOC.HEADLINE: Move to make surname changes easier takes step forward
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, April 14 (CNA) 04/14/10 17:24:27 (By Su Lung-chi and Y.L. Kao)

TEXT.P: An amendment to the Civil Code to allow adults to change their own surnames without the written consent of their parents was passed by the Legislature's Judiciary and Organic Laws and Statutes Committee Wednesday.
Adults who want to change their family names have been required under existing regulations to obtain written consent from their parents.

If, however, the amendment is passed in the future by the full legislature, adults will be permitted to freely choose to assume the surname of their father or mother, but they will only be allowed to make one change during their lifetime.

The amendment would also allow minors to change their surnames without having to file an explanation in specific circumstances: if their parents get divorced; if their father or mother does not protect and educate them as required by law; or if their parents have been dead or missing for three years.

During the committee's review of the amendment Wednesday, Deputy Justice Minister Wu Chen-huan expressed concerns that the revision would create a security loophole in financial and banking transactions.
Ruling Kuomintang Legislator Hsieh Kuo-liang said, however, that based on Wu's logic, if name changes could cause financial security issues, then they should be banned.

KMT legislators Lu Hsueh-chang and John Chiang argued that because all citizens have national identity card numbers to identify them, there was no need to worry about the potential security implications of the revision.
The amendment must still be approved by the full Legislative Yuan before it becomes law.

DOC.HEADLINE: KMT begins surveys for Kaohsiung, Tainan hopefuls
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, April 14 (CNA) 04/14/10 17:41:44 (By S.H. Lee and Flor Wang)

TEXT.P: The ruling Kuomintang (KMT) kicked off two-day public opinion surveys Wednesday to gauge support for party members seeking to run for Tainan and Kaohsiung mayoral seats in the November elections.
In Tainan City, former KMT lawmakers Lee Chuan-chiao and Kuo Tien-tsai and incumbent Tainan City Councilor Hsieh Lung-chieh are potential contenders.

In Kaohsiung City, six KMT members, including four legislators -- Huang Chao- shun, Ho Tsai-feng, Lin Yi-shih and Chang Hsien-yao -- as well as former Legislator Su Ying-kui and incumbent Presidential Deputy Secretary-General Lai Feng-wei have made known their intentions to vie for the mayoral post.

Results of the surveys will be used by the KMT as a reference in its nomination procedure to select candidates for the race in five areas -- Taipei City, Xinbei City, Taichung City, Tainan City and Kaohsiung City -- in the Nov. 27 mayoral election.

After the elections, Kaohsiung City will be merged with Kaohsiung County; Tainan City will merge with Tainan County; Taichung City and Taichung County will merge; and Taipei County will be upgraded to "Xinbei City." These four special municipalities will enjoy the same status as Taipei City.

As incumbent Taichung Mayor Jason Hu and Vice Premier Eric Liluan Chu are likely to be directly drafted by the KMT for the elections in Taichung City and Xinbei City, Taipei City is the only remaining slot where the KMT plans to hold opinion polls to gauge support for potential contenders.
If two party members receive similar amounts of public support, the KMT has said it will evaluate the candidates' qualifications and coordinate between them to determine who will run.

DOC.HEADLINE: 4th nuclear plant will not be ready by 2011 national day: Taipower
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, April 14 (CNA) 04/14/10 18:07:56 (By Lin Huei-chun and Elizabeth Hsu)

TEXT.P: Following reports of Premier Wu Den-yih's hope that the fourth nuclear power plant will begin commercial operations ahead of schedule, state-run Taiwan Power Co. (Taipower) Chairman Edward K.M. Chen said Wednesday that "it cannot be achieved."

Responding to lawmakers' questions at the Legislative Yuan, Chen explained that he came up to the conclusion based on the current progress of construction of the new power plant in Gongliao Township in Taipei County, northern Taiwan.

According to media reports, Wu had expressed hope that Taipower could move up the schedule for the start of commercial operations of the plant from Dec. 15, 2011 to Oct. 10 of that year as part of celebrations for the country's 100th founding anniversary.

Chen said Wu did not instruct his company to alter the schedule, although he did say it would be nice to see the plant, described as efficient in terms of both economics and reducing carbon emissions, to start operating ahead of schedule.
According to Taipower's schedule, the plant's first generator will not be loaded with fuel until Dec. 15 this year and will not begin operating until one year after that date.

Meanwhile, also at the Legislative Yuan, as frequent reports in the past few months of earthquakes in other countries have raised concerns among lawmakers about the safety of nuclear power plants in Taiwan, Atomic Energy Council Minister Tsai Chuen-horng was asked if the plants can withstand earthquakes and quake-triggered tsunami.
In response, Tsai said that all four nuclear power plants were or are being built based on international standards for earthquake resistance.
Two of the three existing plants are situated in Taipei County and the third is in Hengchun, at the island's southern tip.

Citing research results released in 2009 by the Central Geological Survey, Legislator Chen Shu-huei of the ruling Kuomintang said the first nuclear plant is located seven kilometers away from a fault line, while the second is only five kilometers away.

The third nuclear plant is located only 20 km away from a sea area with many undersea volcanos, she went on, expressing worry that the damage would be massive if one of the volcanoes were to erupt, triggering earthquakes.

DOC.HEADLINE: Taiwan orchestra to share the stage with Bocelli in May
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, April 14 (CNA) 04/14/10 18:14:46 (By Sunnie Chen)

TEXT.P: A Taiwan orchestra will share the stage with award-winning tenor Andrea Bocelli at two concerts next month in Hong Kong and Taipei respectively, one of the organizers announced Wednesday.

"We are pleased and honored to have an opportunity to perform in Hong Kong with the renowned tenor, " said Joyce Chiou, the executive director of the Philharmonica Taiwan, the National Symphony Orchestra (NSO) which is affiliated with the National Chiang Kai-shek Cultural Center.
The orchestra will perform with Bocelli May 4 in Hong Kong and at Taipei Arena May 6, said Niu Hsiao Hwa, the head of Management of New Arts (MNA).

The concert will open with "Carmen Overture" and will include other pieces such as Verdi's "La donna emobile -- Rigoletto", Brindisi's "Cavalleria rusticana", Puccini's "O soave fanciulla -- La Boheme," according to Niu.
"Bocelli was impressed by the central city of Taichung during a visit in 2008 and is pleased to make his Taipei debut this time around," Niu said.

Bocelli emerged as a vocal phenomenon in the 1990s, from a piano bar singer to an internationally renowned tenor. He has since gone on to become one of the most successful artists of all time, selling over 65 million albums worldwide.

With one of the most unique voices in the world, his expressed goal is "to communicate with the listener, to touch his heart in the same way I was touched as a child by my favorite singers, who made me dream and moved me to tears."

In recent years, Bocelli has effortlessly straddled the realms of both classical and popular music, winning an impressive array of prestigious awards, including a Golden Globe for Best Song, Grammy and Academy Award nominations.
He was awarded a star on Hollywood's Walk of Fame March 2.

DOC.HEADLINE: TSMC expects global semiconductor industry to grow 22% in 2010
DOC.DATELINE: Hsinchu, Taiwan April 14 (CNA) 04/14/10 18:25:53 (By Jackson Chang and Fanny Liu)

TEXT.P: The chairman and CEO of the world's largest contract manufacturer of semiconductors, Taiwan Semiconductor Manufacturing Company (TSMC) , has reiterated his forecast that the global semiconductor industry's production value will grow by 22 percent this year, and will continue to increase by 7 percent next year.

Last month, Chang had revised his 2010 forecast of the industry's growth to 22 percent, up from his January forecast of 18 percent, citing that downstream clients' demand have been better than expected.

Speaking at the 2010 Technology Symposium in California Tuesday, Chang maintained his forecast of 22 percent growth and said that as his company has been expanding its business, it will increase its number of employees to 29,000 by the end of this year, up from 25,000 at present and 20,000 at the end of 2009, according to a TSMC press release.

In addition, Chang said that the company will keep developing advanced process technology to meet customers' demand, with the number of its R&D people triple compared to the number the company had five years ago. Spending on R&D was also doubled from five years ago, he said.

Meanwhile, the company also announced at the symposium -- attended by nearly 1,500 TSMC customers and third-party alliances -- that it will skip the 22nm manufacturing process node and move directly to a 20nm technology.
Chiang Shang-yi, senior vice president of TSMC Research & Development, said that TSMC is expected to enter 20nm risk production in the second half of 2012.
"We have reached a point in advanced technology development where0we need to be actively concerned about the ROI (Return on Investment) of advanced technology, " said Chiang.
He said that the move to 20nm creates a better gate density and chip performance-to-cost ratio than a 22nm process technology and makes it a more viable platform for advanced technology designers.

DOC.HEADLINE: Taiwan ready to deliver relief aid to quake-hit Chinese province
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, April 14 (CNA) 04/14/10 18:42:31 (By Y.L. Kao)

TEXT.P: Taiwan has sent a letter of condolence and has promised to provide humanitarian relief to China's Qinghai Province after it was hit Wednesday by a 7.1 magnitude earthquake that had left at least 400 people dead and 8,000 injured at the latest count.

The Straits Exchange Foundation (SEF) , the semi-official intermediary body set up to deal with cross-Taiwan Strait exchanges in the absence of official ties between the two sides, sent the letter of condolences Wednesday, an SEF spokesman said later that day.

Meanwhile, the National Fire Agency said that upon receiving orders, a 23-member rescue team organized by the agency can leave for the northwestern Chinese province, an area that is home to 100,000 Tibetans, within hours to begin carrying out earthquake-relief work.
The Red Cross Society of the Republic of China also said it had been in contact with China's Red Cross and was ready to set off for the earthquake-hit region to provide support and assistance.

According to Chinese state media reports, 700 paramilitary personnel were clearing the rubble and trying to rescue people buried in the quake zone, with another 3,000 troops on their way to the area to assist in search and rescue efforts.

One local military official, Shi Huajie, told a local TV station that many elementary school students had been buried and that rescuers were racing against time to dig them out from collapsed schoolrooms, sometimes working with their bare hands.
"The difficulty we face is that we don't have any excavators, " Shi said. "It is very difficult to save people with our bare hands, " he added.
China' Ministry of Civil Affairs has already initiated an emergency budget program and has sent a task force to disaster affected area, according to media reports.
The quake was centered on Yushu County, which has a population of about 100,000, mostly herders and farmers. Most buildings near the epicenter collapsed in the quake, according to media reports.
Tents, medical equipment and supplies and medical workers are in short supply, according to reports.
However, the earthquake did not affect the Qinghai-Tibet Railway because it is about 200 km from the earthquake epicenter, said a local official.

DOC.HEADLINE: ECFA meant to make Taiwan a 'duty-free shop': president
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, April 14 (CNA) 04/14/10 18:46:12 (By S.H. Lee and Flor Wang)

TEXT.P: President Ma Ying-jeou said Wednesday that a proposed cross-Taiwan Strait trade deal is meant to gradually make Taiwan a "duty-free shop" and help it earn a niche amid global competition.

Speaking after a weekly meeting of the ruling Kuomintang's (KMT) policy-making Central Standing Committee, Ma used the metaphor when describing the importance of the economic cooperation framework agreement (ECFA) for Taiwan.
"The planned ECFA is meant to transform Taiwan into a duty-free shop in phases to sharpen the country's overall competitiveness, " he said.
"But the pact will definitely not touch on opening Taiwan's market to labor or agriculture products from China," he added.

The president suggested local farmers, in line with the government's policy, engage in speciality agriculture and promote their products to the rest of the world, which he said would be very advantageous to them.

The ECFA has met strong opposition in some parts of central and southern Taiwan that rely heavily on agriculture. The areas are also traditional strongholds of the opposition Democratic Progressive Party, which has vowed to block the agreement with China out of fear that it might seriously harm Taiwan's job and agricultural markets.

DOC.HEADLINE: Porn film copyright hinges on court ruling: official
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, April 14 (CNA) 04/14/10 19:10:36 (By Lin Shu-yuan and Sofia Wu)

TEXT.P: The question of whether porn films should be subject to copyright protection hinges on the opinions of local courts rather than on the country's Copyright Act per se, an intellectual property rights (IPR) official said Wednesday.

Wang Mei-hua, director-general of the Intellectual Property Office (IPO) under the Ministry of Economic Affairs, made the remarks after lawyers representing Japan's top eight porn companies urged Taiwan earlier that same day to protect their clients' copyrighted productions against pirating.

Lawyers retained by the Japanese producers of adult videos (AVs) said at a news conference that an increasing number of their productions are being sold on the local black market, aired on cable television channels in Taiwan and distributed by telecommunications service providers, causing huge revenue losses for the film makers and distributors.
Taiwan police do crack down on peddlers of pirated pornography, but they only punish the sellers for distributing obscene material, not for violating intellectual property rights, the lawyers said.

On behalf of the Japanese companies, the lawyers called for negotiations within one month with local platform and solution providers, cable TV operators and mobile phone service providers on the issue of authorization. Otherwise, the attorneys said, they will bring commercial piracy suits against the Taiwanese platform service providers.

Chen Chien-hung, one of the lawyers, took issue with a 1999 Supreme Court ruling, arguing that Taiwan should grant the same copyright protection to original porn films as to other types of films, regardless of the effect of adult films on social morals and customs.

In a copyright lawsuit brought by Japanese porn companies against Taiwanese pirates in 1999, the Supreme Court ruled that porn films are obscene material and are therefore not entitled to copyright protection.

Commenting on the issue, Wang said the Intellectual Property Office agrees with copyright scholars and experts that intellectual property should be given copyright protection as long as the material is original.

However, the decisions on the issue lie with the local courts, Wang stressed, noting that since the 1999 Supreme Court ruling, the lower courts have followed that lead in a number of subsequent cases.

Nevertheless, Wang said the Supreme Court ruling has not yet become precedent. "It is not impossible that the tide will turn in favor of porn film copyright protection... But all this will depend on the local courts... Our bureau will fully respect the court rulings, "Wang added.

DOC.HEADLINE: Anti-ECFA groups hope for 1 million at protest
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, April 14 (CNA) 04/14/10 19:38:23 (By Sophia Yeh and Fanny Liu)

TEXT.P: The Taiwan National Alliance and other pro-localization political groups said Wednesday that they want to rally 1 million people on June 6 for a protest against signing a proposed trade pact with China.

Yao Chia-wen, one of the organizers of the protest and a former chairman of the opposition Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) , said the groups had made the decision about the protest at a meeting earlier Wednesday. The Taiwan Society North and Taiwan Rescue Action Alliance are also ready to launch a series of activities against the government's plans to sign an economic cooperation framework agreement (ECFA) with China, Yao said.

With the Taiwan Solidarity Union (TSU) having collected more than 260,000 signatures in a campaign for a referendum on the proposed trade pact, Yao said other Taiwan-centric groups decided to cooperate with the TSU to plan their next move.

Media reports said that some people at the meeting suggested the protest continue until the government agrees to hold a referendum on the ECFA, while others called for follow-up protests outside the Legislative Yuan and the Presidential Office building.

The opposition say the ECFA will cause massive unemployment in Taiwan because Chinese people will be allowed to work in Taiwan at lower wages. They also say they have yet to obtain any comprehensive information regarding the pact's details.
DPP Chairperson Tsai Ing-wen is scheduled to debate President Ma Ying-jeou about the ECFA on April 25.
Tsai said earlier that she will present her party's view in the televised debate with Ma and ask the government to hold a referendum to allow the people to decide on the pact.

DOC.HEADLINE: Hard to guarantee doctors will not cheat: DOH head
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, April 14 (CNA) 04/14/10 19:56:12 (By Chen Li-ting and Lilian Wu)

TEXT.P: Department of Health (DOH) Minister Yaung Chih-liang said Wednesday that he cannot guarantee that a series of frauds in three hospitals, including one under the jurisdiction of the DOH, will not be repeated.
"How can I give such a guarantee when there are still thieves around even though there are a lot of police deployed?" Yaung asked.

He made the remarks after three hospitals -- Kaohsiung Medical University Chung-Ho Memorial Hospital and Hsiao-Kang Municipal Hospital in southern Taiwan and Keelung Hospital under the DOH in northern Taiwan -- were found to have engaged in fraud on a massive scale to claim health insurance payments from the Bureau of National Health Insurance (BNHI) and insurance companies.

The prime suspect, Hsu Shih-cheng, a former director of the Department of Obstetrics and Gynecology of Kaohsiung Medical University hospital, colluded with a fraud ring to switch cancer patient specimens when he was working at that hospital and at the Kaohsiung Municipal Hsiao-Kang Hospital.
Hsu even performed surgery on healthy "phony" patients, removing uteruses, ovaries and breasts and putting them on chemotherapy regimens.

The fraud ring worked with 10 hospitals, seven doctors and 20 patients to claim reimbursement on the procedures from the BNHI and insurance companies. The matter only came to light after one of the doctors came forward to report it.
Legislator Ho Tsai-feng of the ruling Kuomintang asked the BNHI to guarantee that no women will ever be victims and that similar incidents will not take place in future.
But BNHI Director General Cheng Shou-hsia said that "no-one would dare to make such a promise."
Yaung pointed out that "there are more than 30,000 doctors in Taiwan, so how can I guarantee that there will be no similar incidents in the future?"
But the DOH has imposed what Yaung described as "steep disciplinary measures" in a bid to deter such incidents from happening again, Yaung continued.
Kaohsiung Medical University hospital has been given two options: terminate the contract with the BNHI for one year, or repay an equivalent health insurance payment of NT$150 million.

The hospital chose the latter, the steepest fine ever to have been imposed since the national health insurance system was lunched in 1995, but it also decided to file for administrative relief, contending that the offenses were the behavior of an individual doctor.
Hsiao-Kang Hospital said it would return NT$13.67 million, while the Keelung Hospital's Surgery Department said it would return NT$80 million.

Yaung said in a radio interview earlier in the day that it is the right of the Kaohsiung Medical University hospital to appeal, but the DOH is "100 percent sure that the hospital will not win with such solid evidence against it."
In light of the fraud scandal, the DOH will reassess the hospital and if it receives a failing grade, it could be downgraded from a medical center to a regional hospital, Yaung added.

DOC.HEADLINE: DPP legislators voice support for Tsai's re-election bid
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, April 14 (CNA) 04/14/10 20:12:34 (By Su Lung-chi and Y.L. Kao)

TEXT.P: More than 20 legislators of the opposition Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) on Wednesday announced their support for DPP Chairperson Tsai Ing-wen's re-election bid.

The legislators -- including Lai Ching-te, Su Chen-ching, Pan Meng-an and DPP Policy Committee Executive Director Ker Chien-ming -- voiced their support at a news conference after former Taipei County Magistrate Yu Ching registered April 9 to run in the election for DPP chief slated for May 23.

Entertainer-turned-DPP Legislator Yu Tien told the press conference that at present, Tsai should focus on readying herself for her April 25 debate with President Ma Ying-jeou on a proposed trade pact with China, rather than spend time on a re-election bid.
Yu said that Tsai can rest assured because all members of the DPP legislative caucus will campaign for her to solicit support from grassroots party members.
Ker said that the legislators' move is aimed at allowing Tsai to concentrate on the debate.
The DPP currently holds 30 legislative seats.

DOC.HEADLINE: Premier Wu: Time not ripe for cross-strait political talks
DOC.DATELINE: Brussels, April 13 (CNA) 04/14/10 20:26:23

TEXT.P: Time is not ripe for Taiwan to hold political talks with China as more time is needed for the Taiwanese public to forge a consensus on this issue, Premier Wu Den-yih has told a European magazine.
In a recent interview with the Greek bimonthly, the "European Business Review", Wu made the comment as he explained President Ma Ying-jeou's policy towards China.
Wu said that President Ma has decided to talk with China on the principle of "economic issues ahead of political ones, " with no timetable set for political dialogue.

Wu said that this is because political talks could not take place until Taiwan and China can fully understand and trust each other, and more importantly, they cannot happen until the people on both sides can throw their full support behind their respective governments to undertake such talks.
He rejected a proposal by many Chinese scholars that now is the right time for Taiwan and China to begin talking about political issues, as there already have been too much economic talks.

DOC.HEADLINE: Taiwan mulling WTO complaint against Canada over textile tariffs
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, April 14 (CNA) 04/14/10 20:27:27 (By Lin Shu-yuan and Sofia Wu)

TEXT.P: Taiwan may file a complaint with the World Trade Organization (WTO) against Canada over its long refusal to allow generalized preferential tariffs (GPT) on Taiwan-made textile products, an economic affairs official said Wednesday.

Since 1974, Canada has been giving GPT treatment to more than 1,000 products, including bicycles, lumber, machine tools, sanitation equipment, steel goods, eyeglasses, auto parts and textiles, from China, South Korea and several other countries that are similar to Taiwan in terms of economic development.

Since its accession to the WTO in 2002, Taiwan has been lobbying Canada for similar tariff terms but Canada has remained cool to the requests and not made any goodwill gestures in response, the Ministry of Economic Affairs (MOEA) official said.
"When our two countries held an economic and trade consultation conference in January, Canada finally gave a slight response, but its promise only further disappointed us," the official sighed.
At present, Canada allows Taiwan most favored nations (MFN) tariff treatment, under which tariff rates range between 3 percent and 6 percent.

In comparison, most of the 1,000-plus items that are given GPT treatment enjoy zero tariffs. The tariff gap between GPT and MFN for textile goods is 3.51 percent, which has seriously hampered the competitiveness of Taiwan-made textiles in the Canadian market compared to similar products from South Korea and China.

Minister of Economic Affairs Shih Yen-shiang has directed relevant MOEA agencies to try every possible means to protest Canada's discrimination against Taiwan's textile products, the official said, adding that if necessary, Taiwan may lodge a protest, or even file a complaint, with the WTO.

DOC.HEADLINE: Campaign, TV program to promote ocean preservation
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, April 14 (CNA) 04/14/10 20:43:41 (By Chris Wang)

TEXT.P: A public campaign endorsed by Taiwan government officials will be launched with the screening of a television program to raise awareness of ocean preservation, organizers said Wednesday.

The "Happy Ocean Campaign" aims to draw public attention to the deteriorating ocean environment and pollution in Taiwan ahead of the 40th anniversary of World Earth Day on April 22, the National Geographic Channel announced.

A Maritime Affairs Council will be included in the government structure reform and will start operation Jan. 1, 2013, he said.
Environmental Protection Administration Minister Stephen Shu-hung Shen described the ocean as "the heart of the Earth" while calling on the public to protect the environment.

According to the campaign, the extinction of all life forms in the ocean by 2048 is possible if the issues of environmental pollution and overfishing, among others, are not addressed and resolved in time.

The campaign encourages young people in Taiwan to document the ocean with photographs or videos and send their works to the television company, which will display all those works in three local museums starting from June 8, World Oceans Day.
Lin Chiling, one of Taiwan's most popular models, was invited to endorse the campaign as its ambassador.

DOC.HEADLINE: Flexible diplomacy enhances Taiwan-US ties: minister
DOC.DATELINE: Taichung, April 14 (CNA) 04/14/10 21:54:54 (By Hao Hsueh-chin and Fanny Liu)

TEXT.P: Taiwan's flexible diplomacy not only improves cross-Taiwan Strait relations, but also enhances mutual trust between Taiwan and the United States, Foreign Minister Timothy C. T. Yang said Wednesday.

DOC.HEADLINE: Belgian newspaper runs special report on Taiwan
DOC.DATELINE: Brussels, April 13 (CNA) 04/14/10 22:01:18 (By Tsao Yu-fan and Lilian Wu)

TEXT.P: A Belgian French-language newspaper has urged the international community to create more opportunities for Taiwan to participate in international activities, by taking into consideration the unique situation Taiwan faces, from an economic point of view.

DOC.HEADLINE: Hundreds of pox-infected goats culled in Yunlin
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, April 14 (CNA) 04/14/10 22:04:58 (By Yeh Tzu-kang, Yang Shu-min and Sofia Wu)

TEXT.P: Nearly 800 goats infected with goat pox virus (GPV) have been culled at two ranches in Yunlin County's Siluo Township in central-south Taiwan, animal health officials said Wednesday.

"The animals were slaughtered after two goats in the Yunlin meat wholesale market were found to have symptoms of GPV on April 9, " said Huang Kuo-ching, deputy director of the Bureau of Animal and Plant Health Inspection and Quarantine (BAPHIQ) under the Council of Agriculture.
None of the infected animals had entered the retail market, Huang said, adding that the two sick goats were spotted by vets during routine health checks.

Staff members of the Yunlin animal health inspection and quarantine bureau immediately traveled to the two problem ranches to examine and test all the animals there, Huang said. A ban was also imposed on the movement of animals at both ranches, he added.

Follow-up tests at the BAPHIQ on samples collected at the ranches confirmed that the goats had contracted GPV, a highly contagious disease of small ruminants that is characterized by fever, ocular and nasal discharges. It also causes pox lesions on the skin and on the mucous membranes of the nostrils, mouth and vulva. Mortality can be high. Most kids and lambs with the disease tend to die and the death rate among adult animals is around 50 percent.
GPV cannot infect humans and can be destroyed at high temperatures, according to Huang.
To prevent the spread of the virus, all of the animals on the two farms were culled and the farms disinfected, Huang said.

The bureau has already informed the World Organization for Animal Health (OIE) of the case, he added. According to OIE regulations, Taiwan will be removed from the list of sheep and goat pox (SGP) affected areas if no new cases are reported in the next three years.
The bureau has also launched a nationwide inspection of sheep ranches, which will be completed by April 16, Huang said. About 200,000 goats and 1,000-plus sheep are being raised in Taiwan.
Huang said the bureau will immediately procure the relevant medications and vaccines in order to wipe out the disease as soon as possible.
The bureau is also investigating the source of the infection, Huang said.

This is the second time that the disease has been reported in Taiwan. The first outbreak was in July 2008 in northern Taiwan's Taoyuan County, and was believed to be related to animal smuggling from GPV-affected areas, including Vietnam, China, Mongolia, Africa and the Middle East, but the exact source is till unclear, Huang said.

DOC.HEADLINE: Sports minister stresses importance of pro baseball
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, April 14 (CNA) 04/14/10 22:22:16 (By Chiang Chun-liang and Y.L. Kao)

TEXT.P: As baseball is not only the national sport but also a core sporting industry in Taiwan, the collapse of the country's professional baseball league could cause 30,000 people to lose their jobs, Sports Affairs Council (SAC) Minister Tai Hsia-ling said Wednesday.
Tai made the comments in a speech at National Chung Cheng University in Chiayi County, southern Taiwan.

Tai said that although she often felt helpless when asked by legislators to guarantee there will no more game-rigging after five major scandals in the Chinese Professional Baseball League's 21-year history, she still called for keeping the league afloat.
According to Tai, the SAC has mapped out a plan to help resolve unemployment among retired baseball players.
The government also plans to set up 12 amateur baseball teams in the coming four years.

The sports sector has received less favorable treatment than many industries in Taiwan, she said, but added that after the launch of the Taiwan Sports Lottery in 2008, an estimated NT$2.4 billion (US$75.95 million) from it will be used to promote sports this year.

Tai also said she will do what she can to foster the development of the sports industry, create more jobs for former athletes and provide preferential loans for them. She said she hoped never to have to see athletes on TV calling on the government to give them jobs.

To encourage people to exercise regularly, the government will increase the annual budget for sports from NT$4 to NT$28 per capita and has already allocated NT$400 million toward a program aimed at building Taiwan into a sports island, Tai said.
The government will also issue a sports IC card to promote the industry and is scheduled to complete the construction and connection of around-the-island cycling trails in 2013, Tai added.

DOC.HEADLINE: Fragile soil played large part in Siaolin disaster: researchers
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, April 14 (CNA) 04/14/10 23:29:33 (By S. M. Yang and Flor Wang)

TEXT.P: A fragile geological system coupled with torrential rains caused the mudslide that buried Kaohsiung County's Siaolin Village when Typhoon Morakot hit in August last year, a research team reported Wednesday.

Led by Hongey Chen, a professor at National Taiwan University's Geosciences Department, and Chien-Chih Chen, a professor at National Central University's Department of Earth Science, the team reported its findings to the National Science Council.
Chien-Chih Chen said Siaolin Village was leveled in two stages.
First, excessive rains brought about by Typhoon Morakot caused the 1,445-meter Siantu Mountain to begin collapsing at 6: 16 a.m. on Aug. 9.

The slide, carrying the equivalent of some 23 million cubic meters of mud, silt and rocks, plunged to a lower area of the mountain above Siaolin and began building up after about 33 seconds, Chien-Chih Chen said. The entire slide lasted only 110 seconds and buried Siaolin's northern part, he reported.
Another cause was debris that clogged the flow of the Cishan Stream, creating a quake lake that built up and breached its bank in 50 minutes, submerging southern Siaolin.
The village was totally devastated by the two disasters and most residents were unable to escape, Chien-Chih Chen said.
Some Siaolin villagers survived, but a majority of about 600 were killed.

In response to widespread speculation that excessive precipitation was the prime cause leading to the disaster, Hongey Chen stressed that the fragile soil formation in the region played an important part in the village's burial.

According to Hongey Chen, as much as 91 million tons of silt piled up in the Cishan and Laonong streams during the five days the typhoon affected the region. That was more than 80 percent of the silt that the Gaoping River, a major river in southern Taiwan, carries a year, he noted.

The researchers began the probe in the wake of Typhoon Morakot, which was the worst to hit southern Taiwan in over 50 years. The team examined 144 villages and townships across the country, 92 of which were found to be unsafe.
As typhoon season approaches, the research team submitted the list of these flood-prone villages to the Executive Yuan for its reference.

DOC.HEADLINE: China universities will not attract many Taiwanese students: MOE
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, April 14 (CNA) 04/14/10 23:41:58 (By Liu Cheng-ching, Lin Szu-yu and Lilian Wu)

TEXT.P: The Ministry of Education (MOE) said Wednesday that China's latest move of opening its universities to top Taiwanese students will not attract many applicants.

The MOE was commenting on an announcement by China earlier in the day that Taiwanese senior high school students who score within the top 12 percent in the scholastic aptitude tests can now apply directly to 123 universities in China and will only be required to pass an interview.

Fan Liqing, a spokeswoman for the Taiwan Affairs Office under China's State Council, said that following China's decision last year to allow top Taiwanese students to enter its universities, the preparatory work has been now completed.

But Yang Yu-hui, deputy director of the MOE's Department of Higher Education, said that currently, Taiwan only recognizes the academic credentials of 41 universities in China, and Taiwanese students who want to pursue higher education in China should consider carefully whether that would be in their best interests.

"Despite China's move to open up so many of its universities, it will be up to Taiwanese students to decide if they want to study there, " Yang said. If they decide to go to China, they must remember that Taiwan only recognizes diplomas from 41 universities there, she stressed.
In addition, Taiwanese students in the top 12 percentile should be able to gain admission to top universities in Taiwan, she said.
Surveys have shown that 70 percent of parents are not willing to let their children study in China because of political and social order factors, Yang noted.
An official of Taiwan's Mainland Affairs Council (MAC) said that the main consideration will be the overall environment on both sides of the Taiwan Strait.
According to MAC Vice Chairman Liu Teh-shun, based on that factor, it is more than likely that Taiwan will be able to retain its top students.

He noted that while China is moving to attract Taiwanese students, Taiwan still maintains various restrictions regarding Chinese students. For example, they are not eligible for scholarships and are not allowed to moonlight or seek jobs in Taiwan after graduation, Liu said.

Meanwhile, several prestigious universities said that China's opening of its universities to Taiwan students is an inevitable trend, but they expressed full confidence in the quality of Taiwan's universities.
Chiang Been-huang, Dean of National Taiwan University's Academic Affairs Office, said that top students will only be attracted to top quality schools.

Chiang said he is not worried about an exodus of top Taiwanese students to China as he thinks that it is only under certain circumstances, such as if their parents are working in China, students will consider studying there.

Lin Chin-teng, Dean of National Chiao Tung University's Academic Affairs Office, said that Taiwan's universities still have the competitive edge. However, China has invested a great deal in higher education, and Taiwan universities will also need continued government support, he added.

Meanwhile, an organization that represents Taiwanese students studying in China said that the use of Taiwan's scholastic aptitude test score as the basis for enrolling in Chinese universities will be more convenient for Taiwanese students.
But Chen Cheng-teng, vice president of Taiwan Students Union, suggested that the 12 percent threshold should be removed to give all Taiwanese students the option of studying in China.

DOC.HEADLINE: Hard to guarantee doctors will not cheat: DOH head
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, April 14 (CNA) 04/14/10 19:56:12 (By Chen Li-ting and Lilian Wu)

TEXT.P: Department of Health (DOH) Minister Yaung Chih-liang said Wednesday that he cannot guarantee that a series of frauds in three hospitals, including one under the jurisdiction of the DOH, will not be repeated.
"How can I give such a guarantee when there are still thieves around even though there are a lot of police deployed?" Yaung asked.

He made the remarks after three hospitals -- Kaohsiung Medical University Chung-Ho Memorial Hospital and Hsiao-Kang Municipal Hospital in southern Taiwan and Keelung Hospital under the DOH in northern Taiwan -- were found to have engaged in fraud on a massive scale to claim health insurance payments from the Bureau of National Health Insurance (BNHI) and insurance companies.

The prime suspect, Hsu Shih-cheng, a former director of the Department of Obstetrics and Gynecology of Kaohsiung Medical University hospital, colluded with a fraud ring to switch cancer patient specimens when he was working at that hospital and at the Kaohsiung Municipal Hsiao-Kang Hospital.
Hsu even performed surgery on healthy "phony" patients, removing uteruses, ovaries and breasts and putting them on chemotherapy regimens.

The fraud ring worked with 10 hospitals, seven doctors and 20 patients to claim reimbursement on the procedures from the BNHI and insurance companies. The matter only came to light after one of the doctors came forward to report it.
Legislator Ho Tsai-feng of the ruling Kuomintang asked the BNHI to guarantee that no women will ever be victims and that similar incidents will not take place in future.
But BNHI Director General Cheng Shou-hsia said that "no-one would dare to make such a promise."
Yaung pointed out that "there are more than 30,000 doctors in Taiwan, so how can I guarantee that there will be no similar incidents in the future?"
But the DOH has imposed what Yaung described as "steep disciplinary measures" in a bid to deter such incidents from happening again, Yaung continued.
Kaohsiung Medical University hospital has been given two options: terminate the contract with the BNHI for one year, or repay an equivalent health insurance payment of NT$150 million.

The hospital chose the latter, the steepest fine ever to have been imposed since the national health insurance system was lunched in 1995, but it also decided to file for administrative relief, contending that the offenses were the behavior of an individual doctor.
Hsiao-Kang Hospital said it would return NT$13.67 million, while the Keelung Hospital's Surgery Department said it would return NT$80 million.

Yaung said in a radio interview earlier in the day that it is the right of the Kaohsiung Medical University hospital to appeal, but the DOH is "100 percent sure that the hospital will not win with such solid evidence against it."
In light of the fraud scandal, the DOH will reassess the hospital and if it receives a failing grade, it could be downgraded from a medical center to a regional hospital, Yaung added.

DOC.HEADLINE: DPP legislators voice support for Tsai's re-election bid
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, April 14 (CNA) 04/14/10 20:12:34 (By Su Lung-chi and Y.L. Kao)

TEXT.P: More than 20 legislators of the opposition Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) on Wednesday announced their support for DPP Chairperson Tsai Ing-wen's re-election bid.

Yu said that Tsai can rest assured because all members of the DPP legislative caucus will campaign for her to solicit support from grassroots party members.
Ker said that the legislators' move is aimed at allowing Tsai to concentrate on the debate.
The DPP currently holds 30 legislative seats.
