DOC.HEADLINE: Sports minister stresses importance of pro baseball
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, April 14 (CNA) 04/14/10 22:22:16 (By Chiang Chun-liang and Y.L. Kao)

TEXT.P: As baseball is not only the national sport but also a core sporting industry in Taiwan, the collapse of the country's professional baseball league could cause 30,000 people to lose their jobs, Sports Affairs Council (SAC) Minister Tai Hsia-ling said Wednesday.
Tai made the comments in a speech at National Chung Cheng University in Chiayi County, southern Taiwan.

Tai said that although she often felt helpless when asked by legislators to guarantee there will no more game-rigging after five major scandals in the Chinese Professional Baseball League's 21-year history, she still called for keeping the league afloat.
According to Tai, the SAC has mapped out a plan to help resolve unemployment among retired baseball players.
The government also plans to set up 12 amateur baseball teams in the coming four years.

The sports sector has received less favorable treatment than many industries in Taiwan, she said, but added that after the launch of the Taiwan Sports Lottery in 2008, an estimated NT$2.4 billion (US$75.95 million) from it will be used to promote sports this year.

Tai also said she will do what she can to foster the development of the sports industry, create more jobs for former athletes and provide preferential loans for them. She said she hoped never to have to see athletes on TV calling on the government to give them jobs.

To encourage people to exercise regularly, the government will increase the annual budget for sports from NT$4 to NT$28 per capita and has already allocated NT$400 million toward a program aimed at building Taiwan into a sports island, Tai said.
The government will also issue a sports IC card to promote the industry and is scheduled to complete the construction and connection of around-the-island cycling trails in 2013, Tai added.

DOC.HEADLINE: Fragile soil played large part in Siaolin disaster: researchers
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, April 14 (CNA) 04/14/10 23:29:33 (By S. M. Yang and Flor Wang)

TEXT.P: A fragile geological system coupled with torrential rains caused the mudslide that buried Kaohsiung County's Siaolin Village when Typhoon Morakot hit in August last year, a research team reported Wednesday.

Led by Hongey Chen, a professor at National Taiwan University's Geosciences Department, and Chien-Chih Chen, a professor at National Central University's Department of Earth Science, the team reported its findings to the National Science Council.
Chien-Chih Chen said Siaolin Village was leveled in two stages.
First, excessive rains brought about by Typhoon Morakot caused the 1,445-meter Siantu Mountain to begin collapsing at 6: 16 a.m. on Aug. 9.

The slide, carrying the equivalent of some 23 million cubic meters of mud, silt and rocks, plunged to a lower area of the mountain above Siaolin and began building up after about 33 seconds, Chien-Chih Chen said. The entire slide lasted only 110 seconds and buried Siaolin's northern part, he reported.
Another cause was debris that clogged the flow of the Cishan Stream, creating a quake lake that built up and breached its bank in 50 minutes, submerging southern Siaolin.
The village was totally devastated by the two disasters and most residents were unable to escape, Chien-Chih Chen said.
Some Siaolin villagers survived, but a majority of about 600 were killed.

In response to widespread speculation that excessive precipitation was the prime cause leading to the disaster, Hongey Chen stressed that the fragile soil formation in the region played an important part in the village's burial.

According to Hongey Chen, as much as 91 million tons of silt piled up in the Cishan and Laonong streams during the five days the typhoon affected the region. That was more than 80 percent of the silt that the Gaoping River, a major river in southern Taiwan, carries a year, he noted.

The researchers began the probe in the wake of Typhoon Morakot, which was the worst to hit southern Taiwan in over 50 years. The team examined 144 villages and townships across the country, 92 of which were found to be unsafe.
As typhoon season approaches, the research team submitted the list of these flood-prone villages to the Executive Yuan for its reference.

DOC.HEADLINE: China universities will not attract many Taiwanese students: MOE
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, April 14 (CNA) 04/14/10 23:41:58 (By Liu Cheng-ching, Lin Szu-yu and Lilian Wu)

TEXT.P: The Ministry of Education (MOE) said Wednesday that China's latest move of opening its universities to top Taiwanese students will not attract many applicants.

The MOE was commenting on an announcement by China earlier in the day that Taiwanese senior high school students who score within the top 12 percent in the scholastic aptitude tests can now apply directly to 123 universities in China and will only be required to pass an interview.

Fan Liqing, a spokeswoman for the Taiwan Affairs Office under China's State Council, said that following China's decision last year to allow top Taiwanese students to enter its universities, the preparatory work has been now completed.

But Yang Yu-hui, deputy director of the MOE's Department of Higher Education, said that currently, Taiwan only recognizes the academic credentials of 41 universities in China, and Taiwanese students who want to pursue higher education in China should consider carefully whether that would be in their best interests.

"Despite China's move to open up so many of its universities, it will be up to Taiwanese students to decide if they want to study there, " Yang said. If they decide to go to China, they must remember that Taiwan only recognizes diplomas from 41 universities there, she stressed.
In addition, Taiwanese students in the top 12 percentile should be able to gain admission to top universities in Taiwan, she said.
Surveys have shown that 70 percent of parents are not willing to let their children study in China because of political and social order factors, Yang noted.
An official of Taiwan's Mainland Affairs Council (MAC) said that the main consideration will be the overall environment on both sides of the Taiwan Strait.
According to MAC Vice Chairman Liu Teh-shun, based on that factor, it is more than likely that Taiwan will be able to retain its top students.

He noted that while China is moving to attract Taiwanese students, Taiwan still maintains various restrictions regarding Chinese students. For example, they are not eligible for scholarships and are not allowed to moonlight or seek jobs in Taiwan after graduation, Liu said.

Meanwhile, several prestigious universities said that China's opening of its universities to Taiwan students is an inevitable trend, but they expressed full confidence in the quality of Taiwan's universities.
Chiang Been-huang, Dean of National Taiwan University's Academic Affairs Office, said that top students will only be attracted to top quality schools.

Chiang said he is not worried about an exodus of top Taiwanese students to China as he thinks that it is only under certain circumstances, such as if their parents are working in China, students will consider studying there.

Lin Chin-teng, Dean of National Chiao Tung University's Academic Affairs Office, said that Taiwan's universities still have the competitive edge. However, China has invested a great deal in higher education, and Taiwan universities will also need continued government support, he added.

Meanwhile, an organization that represents Taiwanese students studying in China said that the use of Taiwan's scholastic aptitude test score as the basis for enrolling in Chinese universities will be more convenient for Taiwanese students.
But Chen Cheng-teng, vice president of Taiwan Students Union, suggested that the 12 percent threshold should be removed to give all Taiwanese students the option of studying in China.

DOC.HEADLINE: Today in history
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, April 15 (CNA) 04/15/10 08:38:49
DOC.TEXT:
Today is Thursday, April 15, or the second day of the third month of the Year of the Tiger according to the lunar calendar. Following is a list of important events that have occurred on this date in the past:
1865: Andrew Johnson is sworn in as the 17th president of the United States following the assassination of Abraham Lincoln.
1912: The British luxury liner the Titanic sinks after hitting an iceberg during its maiden voyage to New York. More than 1,500 people are feared drowned in the icy waters of the North Atlantic.
1923: Insulin is made available for general use by diabetics when Canadian physiologist Sir Frederick Grant Banting shares a 1923 Nobel Prize for the discovery of insulin.
1927: Chiang Kai-shek, commander-in-chief of the National Revolutionary Forces, organizes the Republic of China government in Nanjing.
1942: Japanese artillery blasts U.S. positions on Corregidor in the Philippines.
1945: Art treasures looted by the Nazis, including paintings by Rubens, Goya, Raphael, and Leonardo da Vinci, are found in an Austrian mine shaft.
1949: The Chinese communists demand ROC government acceptance of their eight- point proposal by April 20, following talks which began in Beijing on April 5.
1952: U.S. President Harry S. Truman signs a peace treaty between the United States and Japan.
1958: The first meeting of independent African nations is held in Accra, Ghana.
1959: U.S. Secretary of State John Dulles resigns due to illness. The American diplomat and politician pursued a policy of opposition to the USSR largely through military and economic aid to American allies.
1966: A team of American virologists develops a vaccine for German measles, known medically as rubella.
1971: President Joseph Desire Mobutu of Congo and his wife arrive in Taipei for a visit.
1971: London and Beijing agree to the reopening of a telephone link between London and Shanghai which had been closed for 22 years.
1975: Praising the late ROC President Chiang Kai-shek as "an old friend and a great leader," Vice President Nelson A. Rockefeller of the United States arrives in Taipei to attend the National Memorial Services for the generalissimo.
1975: ROC Premier Chiang Ching-kuo reveals President Chiang's last written instruction to him. The late leader told his eldest son to assume full responsibility for the fate of the nation without regard to his personal fate.
1976: India and Communist China resume diplomatic relations.
1976: Dr. Alfredo Lamaison, a member of the State Council of Uruguay, and Arg Gustave Nicolich, president of National University, arrive in Taipei for a nine- day visit.
1980: Jean-Paul Sartre, the French writer and philosopher who declined the 1957 Nobel Prize for literature, dies in Paris at the age of 74. A leading existentialist, he wrote literary works such as the autobiographical novel "Nausea" and the play "No Exit," as well as philosophical volumes that include "Being and Nothingness."
1988: President Kim Il Sung receives 43,000 gifts as he celebrates his 76th birthday in style. The North Korean dictator died in 1994.
1989: Hu Yaobang, former general secretary of China's Communist Party, dies of a heart attack in Beijing at the age of 73. A democracy movement is launched by Beijing University students following his death.
1989: Ninety-five soccer fans are crushed to death and 200 injured at Sheffield's Hillsborough Stadium in Britain's worst-ever sports disaster.
1994: The Uruguay Round of talks on the General Agreement on Tariffs and Trade (GATT) concludes with ministers from more than 100 of the world's trading nations signing the GATT pact, the biggest market-opening treaty in history, and also with the announcement of the setting up of the World Trade Organization (WTO).
1996: The United States and Japan announce the closure of six more U.S. military facilities on Okinawa.
1997: The first locally-developed Ching Kuo tactical combat aircraft wing, a second generation ROC Air Force warplane, is founded at the Chingchuankang air force base in Taichung.
1998: Pol Pot, former Khmer Rouge leader, dies of a heart attack.
2000: Republic of China Defense Minister Tang Fei, who has been designated as the next premier by President-elect Chen Shui-bian, checks into Veterans General Hospital to undergo a thymoma operation.
2001: At least four persons are killed and more than 40 injure in an accident involving two buses near Encore Garden in Taichung, central Taiwan.
Confucius' lesson of the day: "A wise and good man looks upwards in his aspirations; a fool looks downwards."

DOC.HEADLINE: Liberty Times: Take to the streets against ECFA

TEXT.P: Alongside a referendum campaign promoted by the Taiwan Solidarity Union, pro- Taiwanization groups are planning to gather 1 million people to take to the streets against the proposed economic cooperation framework agreement (ECFA) with China.

Refusal by the administration of President Ma Ying-jeou to disclose details of the agreement is the main reason why the policy has drawn wide-ranging discontent. The administration has even turned down the people's request for a referendum.

Ma recently told trade union representatives that the ECFA will benefit workers because tariff waivers provided by the agreement will boost the competitiveness of Taiwanese products in the Chinese market, which will in turn stimulate exports and employment. He seemed to completely disregard warnings by experts that the influx of white-collar Chinese workers to Taiwan will impact the more than 3 million workers in Taiwan's services sector.

In order to sign the ECFA, Ma is selling out Taiwan's sovereignty altogether. He has defined the agreement as one between the "Taiwan area" and "mainland area, " rather than one between two countries. He is lying to the people by saying that the ECFA will help reduce the obstruction faced by Taiwan in seeking to forge free trade agreements (FTAs) with other countries. In the future, Taiwan will have to obtain China's permission before signing FTAs with other countries.
The Taiwanese people will soon lose their livelihood and national sovereignty. How can they sit idly by and wait for their doom? (April 15, 2010)
