DOC.HEADLINE: Economic Daily News: The conspiracy behind blocking ECFA

TEXT.P: Taiwan's exclusion from regional economic integration is probably the main reason why exports have been declining, with the country's world ranking in export volume dropping from 14th to 18th during the eight years the Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) was in power.

The situation can be attributed to the DPP's adherence to the ideology of Taiwan independence, which seriously damaged relations with China. As a result, except for five Latin American allies, other countries refused to negotiate free trade agreements (FTAs) with Taiwan for fear of offending China.

Since his inauguration in May 2008, President Ma Ying-jeou has actively improved cross-strait relations, turning Taiwan from a "troublemaker" into a "peace creator." After Taiwan signs the proposed economic cooperation framework agreement (ECFA) with China, the doubts held by other countries with regard to forging FTAs with Taiwan will clear up.

However, the DPP, now in the opposition, is vigorously resisting the signing of the ECFA. The party not only wants a debate on the issue, but is also pushing for a referendum and planning to take to the streets. Furthermore, it is using false, sensational statements to stir up the people's emotions and create conflict.

The DPP opposes the ECFA because it fears that once the agreement is signed, Taiwan will regain its economic vigor, boosting Ma's chances for a 2012 re- election bid and even dampening any DPP hopes of returning to power in 2016.
Voters have long seen through the DPP's tactics. Unless the party reverses its course, it will be rejected by the voters again. (April 15, 2010)

DOC.HEADLINE: Taipei Songshan Airport to turn 60
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, April 15 (CNA) 04/15/10 11:29:34 (By Wang Shu-fen and Sofia Wu)

TEXT.P: Taipei Songshan Airport, Taiwan's first international airport, will celebrate its 60th birthday Friday with an elaborate party to usher in its revival as an important entrance to the capital city, an official said Thursday.

"The birthday celebration is also part of publicity efforts for the Taipei International Gardening and Horticulture Exposition slated to open Nov. 6, as the airport will be a major gateway to the dazzling floral show, " said Wei Sheng-chih, director of the Taipei International Airport Office under the Ministry of Transportation and Communications.
The birthday party will be held near the fountain in front of the mass rapid transit (MRT) system's Songshan Airport Station, where six 10-tiered cakes will be cut to mark the occasion, Wei said.

Mascots of the Taipei International Flora Exposition will join the birthday celebration to add to the fanfare and festive mood, Wei said, adding that a series of performances will also be made to promote the upcoming floral expo.

"With the advent of the gardening and horticulture event, Taipei will definitely become a global focal point and Songshan Airport will be a main gateway to various events associated with the exposition... We are organizing the birthday party to highlight the floral exhibition," Wei explained.
During the Nov. 6-April 25, 2011 exhibition period, there will be several special city bus lines to ferry passengers from Songshan Airport to various exhibition sites, Wei said.

Songshan airport was inaugurated in 1950 as Taiwan's first international airport. It used to operate routes to the United States, Europe, Japan, South Korea and Southeast Asia. Its current building was completed in 1961 when it ranked among the best in the region.
The airport has experienced ups and downs over the past six decades. Its functions as the international airport declined after the inauguration of the Taiwan Taoyuan International Airport in 1969.

It got a new lease on life in 1987 when the government adopted an "open sky" policy to allow for establishment of private carriers. In the following decade, the airport thrived on booming domestic flight services, with the traffic volume reached a peak of dealing with more than 15 million passengers in 1997.

However, the number began a downward streak since 1998 and the opening of high- spped railway service in 2008 gave the domestic flight service another fatal blow, with the passenger number falling to slight more than 3.1 million that year.

The opening of direct cross-Taiwan Strait flights brought another opportunity to Songshan Airport. With the inauguration of scheduled cross-strait flights in August 2009, the number of passengers surged to 3.13 million last year.

The airport is now undergoing a facelift in preparation for a resurrection amid booming cross-strait flight services and anticipated opening of direct flights to Tokyo's Haneda Airport and Seoul's Gimpo Airport later this year.

DOC.HEADLINE: Talk of the day -- China woos Taiwanese students
DOC.DATELINE: 04/15/10 12:28:46 (By Deborah Kuo)

TEXT.P: In an unusually open move, China announced Wednesday it would open its universities to top Taiwanese high school graduates.

Fan Liqing, a spokeswoman for the Taiwan Affairs Office under China's State Council, said preparatory work was complete, paving the way for elite Taiwanese students to enter 123 universities without having to pass Chinese entrance exams, starting this fall.
The surprising gesture met with mixed reactions in Taiwan.
The following are excerpts on the issue carried in Thursday's United Daily News and China Times:
United Daily News:

Liu Te-shun, a vice chairman of the Mainland Affairs Council, Taiwan's top China policy coordinating body, said that top Taiwanese students and their parents will take into consideration the overall cross-strait environment, including China's political and social conditions, before making decisions.
"As far as I know, the Ministry of Education is confident that Taiwan's universities will be able to retain most of the elite high school graduates despite China's beckoning," Liu said.

On Taiwan's preparation for accepting students from China, Liu said amendments are still pending legislation. "Even if the amendments are passed into law in this legislative session, which ends in late June, the Chinese students would not be able to enroll in Taiwan's universities in time for this fall," he added.
China's latest move of wooing Taiwan's best students is seen not only as a "Taiwan-favoring policy, " but also a forward-looking scheme to further consolidate its national strength.

With Taiwan's reserved and wavering educational policy, it will witness an increasing exodus of top Taiwanese students to China, while being unable to attract elite students from China. This serious imbalance in China's favor will eventually deplete the country's national strength. (April 15, 2010).
China Times:

China announced that it is ready to accept top Taiwanese students after an initial decision last year to allow them to enter its universities. One cause for this was aggressive measures adopted by Hong Kong and Singapore to solicit elite students from China and Taiwan that have spurred China's "sense of crisis."
Wu Hemao, a pundit with Peking University's China Center for Economic Research, said Taiwan should not be left out of the race if it intends to reform its higher education system.

He said university competitiveness is like tectonic plates, which can sometimes move very quickly. Citing the 2009 world university rankings compiled by London's Times, he said six Chinese universities entered the top 200 ranks, while Hong Kong had three and Taiwan had only one.

Liu Chun-hao, an educator in Taipei, forecast that China's soliciting of students will not attract many applicants from Taiwan this year, but the beginning of an exodus of top Taiwanese students to China could be expected next year "after students and parents are prepared psychologically." (April 15, 2010).

DOC.HEADLINE: Taiwan offers rescue aid to quake-hit China
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, April 15 (CNA) 04/15/10 12:35:58 (By Garfie Li, Chou Yung-chieh, Liu Cheng-ching and Y.F. Low)

TEXT.P: President Ma Ying-jeou expressed his condolences Thursday over the loss of lives and offered rescue aid after a 7.1-magnitude earthquake hit China's Qinghai province a day earlier.

As soon as he learned of the disaster Wednesday, Ma instructed Minister of the Interior Jiang Yi-huah and the Mainland Affairs Council (MAC) to gather information from Chinese authorities and convey Taiwan's offer to help, Presidential Office spokesman Lo Chih-chiang said.
Jiang said the MAC has asked the semi-official Straits Exchange Foundation to consult Beijing about whether it needs any rescue aid from Taiwan, and Taipei is currently waiting for China's response.
A 23-member rescue team organized by the National Fire Agency is on standby and can depart within hours upon receiving China's consent, he said.

According to China's state-owned Xinhua news agency, the confirmed death toll from the earthquake -- centered on Yushu County, home to 100,000 Tibetans -- has risen to 617, with 313 others reported missing and 9,110 injured.
Chinese authorities are delivering 20,000 tents, 50,000 coats and 50,000 blankets to the area for those left homeless by the disaster, according to reports.

DOC.HEADLINE: MOTC inclined to retain drinking ban on MRT trains
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, April 15 (CNA) 04/15/10 13:38:49 (By Kelven Huang and Deborah Kuo)

TEXT.P: The Ministry of Transportation and Communications (MOTC) , which oversees the operations of the Taipei mass rapid transit (MRT) system, thinks that the regulations banning eating and drinking on MRT trains should be retained, an MOTC official said Thursday.

Legislators Chao Li-yun and Cheng Ru-fen of the ruling Kuomintang proposed Thursday that the "no eating or drinking" rule be amended to allow passengers to drink water on the subway because there are people who might need water regularly for medical or health reasons.

Responding to the lawmakers' suggestion, Deputy Transportation and Communications Minister Chang Chiou-chien said the ministry would be inclined to retain the current regulations, as the Taipei MRT system was designed for short trips that take an hour at most.
It is undeniable that the "no eating or drinking" rule has contributed significantly to the cleanliness of the city's MRT trains, Chang said.

In addition, it would be difficult for Metro Taipei which runs the Taipei MRT system to verify whether passengers were drinking water or beverages, given that many bottled beverages are labeled "water," she said.
Besides, since the launch of the Taipei MRT system in 1996, Taipei Metro has never had to fine a passenger for drinking water on the trains, she added.
"Further consideration would have to be given to the question of whether to lift the no eating or drinking ban," Chang told lawmakers.

DOC.HEADLINE: MOJ looking to replace death penalty with non-parole life sentence
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, April 15 (CNA) 04/15/10 14:43:34 (By An Chih-hsien and Sofia Wu)

TEXT.P: The Ministry of Justice (MOJ) will propose amendments to the Criminal Code within a year to pave the way for a gradual abolition of the death penalty, Minister of Justice Tseng Yung-fu said Thursday.

"We are working on a raft of measures, including life imprisonment without parole and the establishment of special prisons to house such convicts, in preparation for the eventual elimination of capital punishment, " Tseng said at a Legislative Yuan hearing on Taiwan's death penalty policy.

However, he added that while the MOJ's ultimate goal is to abolish the death penalty, it has not set a timetable for completion of the process as there is no public consensus yet on the contentious issue.

"Our fundamental position is to deal with relevant cases in accordance with the existing laws, but we will also gradually reduce the use of capital punishment by introducing substitute penalties, " Tseng told lawmakers from the Legislative Yuan's Committee on Judicial and Legal Affairs.

Since the death penalty is still on the country's law books, Tseng said, the ministry will propose the addition of clauses to the Criminal Code that would allow for some criminals convicted of violent crimes to be given sentences of life imprisonment without parole.

Responding to some lawmakers' worries that such an option may exacerbate the problem of overcrowding in local prisons, Tseng said the ministry will draft complementary measures to prevent that from happening.

"Our draft package will include a blueprint for establishing special correctional facilities for those who are sentenced to life imprisonment without parole, " Tseng said. Such convicts will be offered vocational training so that they would not add to the country's financial burden, he added.
In addition, Tseng said, the amendment proposals will include broader compensation as well as educational and employment aid to victims of violent crimes.

DOC.HEADLINE: Laborers to take to streets over rights
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, April 15 (CNA) 04/15/10 15:38:08 (By Chen Ching-fang and Deborah Kuo)

TEXT.P: The Taiwan Confederation of Trade Unions (TCTU) said Thursday that members of several labor rights groups will take to the streets May 1 -- Labor Day -- to protest poverty in Taiwan and what it calls the "obviously inequitable distribution of wealth in the country."

The demonstration, dubbed an anti-poverty march, will highlight four appeals, including an appeal for democratic supervision of an economic cooperation framework agreement (ECFA) that Taiwan is set to sign with China, and that blue- collar workers' rights should be included in the ECFA talks, said TCTU Chairman Shih Chao-hsien.
Shih said many workers see the ECFA as benefiting only big business conglomerates and their owners, to the detriment of lower-echelon workers.
"Without any positive prospects in sight, laborers will take to the streets on Labor Day to protest President Ma Ying-jeou's administration," he said.

Another appeal to the government is to forbid dispatched work and oppose service outsourcing -- under which business owners enjoy lower labor costs because they do not have to pay benefits, severance or other packages to such workers -- according to Shih.
The two other appeals will be for "labor union autonomy and opposition to schemes to destroy labor unions, " as well as "allowing all wage earners to receive monthly pensions," Shih added.

Meanwhile, TCTU Secretary-General Hsieh Chuang-chih said the demonstration will start at around noon May 1 at the Chiang Kai-shek Memorial Hall in downtown Taipei and end in front of the Executive Yuan.
"The demonstrators will be ready for further moves if the Executive Yuan does not give constructive answers that day, " Hsieh warned.

DOC.HEADLINE: Taiwan share prices gain 74 points
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, April 15 (CNA) 04/15/10 15:41:25 (By Y.L. Kao)

TEXT.P: Taiwan's share prices rose 0.92 percent Thursday after Wall Street climbed for a fifth day on better-than- expected quarterly financial reports from chipmaker Intel Corp and other companies.
The weighted index, the market's key barometer, gained 74.81 to close at 8,171.94, the biggest advance since April 1.

The Dow Jones industrial average closed higher Wednesday for a fifth day, gaining 103.69, or 0.9 percent, to 11,123.11. It marked the highest finish since September 2008, after expectations grew that stronger corporate earnings would signal a recovery is on track.
The local bourse opened at 8,168.11 and fluctuated between 8,136.32 and 8,190.01 during the day's trading. Market turnover totaled NT$142.55 billion (US$4.54 billion).

All eight major stock categories gained ground, with cement shares moving up the most at 2.83 percent. Textile issues rose 2.62 percent, foodstuff stocks gained 1.91 percent, and plastic and chemical shares moved up 1.05 percent.
Both construction shares and machinery and electronics issues gained 0.7 percent, and paper and pulp issues as well as financial and banking stocks each rose 0.46 percent.
Gainers outnumbered losers 2,130 to 1,084, with 332 remaining unchanged.
Foreign investors and Chinese QDIIs were net buyers of NT$10.08 billion in shares. They have been net buyers for 13 consecutive trading days.

The Taiex is expected to gain growth momentum on hopes that the New Taiwan dollar will appreciate further and a proposed economic cooperation framework agreement between Taiwan and China will be signed around May or June, said Chu Yu-chih, an analyst with Grand Cathay Securities Corp.
Chu predicted selling pressure after the Taiex broke the 8,100 mark, but said that after a correction it may rise to between 8,300 and 8,500.

DOC.HEADLINE: Taiwan should admit Chinese students to boost competitiveness: MOE
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, April 15 (CNA) 04/15/10 16:06:33 (By Lin Szu-yu and Y.F. Low)

TEXT.P: Opening Taiwanese universities to Chinese students will allow universities on both sides of the Taiwan Strait to compete on an equal footing, a Ministry of Education (MOE) official said Thursday.

Chu Chun-chang, a section chief in the MOE's Department of Higher Education, said that at present there is an imbalance because China permits Taiwanese students to enter its universities but as yet there are no reciprocal regulations in Taiwan.
He called on the public to support the government's plans to allow Chinese students to study in Taiwan and to recognize Chinese diplomas and degrees.
Chu made the remarks in the wake of China's latest policy to attract top students from Taiwan to its universities.

Under the policy, Taiwanese high school graduates who score within the top 12 percent in Taiwan's General Scholastic Ability Test will be able to apply directly to 123 universities in China without having to take China's entrance exams, starting this fall.
Although the new measure may sound attractive to Taiwanese students, Chu said, students intending to study in China should be reminded that Chinese diplomas and degrees are not recognized in Taiwan.

He noted that this policy will remain in place until three related laws -- the University Act, Junior College Law, and the Statute Governing the Relations between the People of the Taiwan Area and the Mainland Area -- have been amended.
The MOE forecast Tuesday that China's new policy will not attract many Taiwanese applicants in light of the general distrust of China among people in Taiwan.

According to the results of a survey conducted by the MOE, 77.2 percent of Taiwanese parents are not willing to send their children to schools in China, based on concerns such as poor public order there, adaptation difficulties, and the inconsistent quality of Chinese schools.

DOC.HEADLINE: Nobel laureate to visit Taiwan
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, April 15 (CNA) 04/15/10 17:04:51 (By Sunnie Chen)

TEXT.P: Leland H. Hartwell, a Nobel laureate in physiology and medicine, will visit Taiwan April 18-25, according to Academia Sinica, Taiwan's top research institute.

"Academia Sinica President Wong Chi-Huey will present Hartwell with an Academia Sinica Honorary Academician's medal April 22, " said a spokesman for the institute Thursday, adding that Hartwell, who is president of the Fred Hutchinson Cancer Research Center, will give a lecture titled "Sustainability Science" at Academia Sinica after the presentation ceremony.

In addition to his lecture at Academia Sinica, Hartwell will also serve as a keynote speaker at a conference held by Chang Gung University (CGU) and the Taiwan Proteomics Society April 23, a CGU official said.
He will also exchange ideas and opinions with local experts from the biomedical field about the importance of the development of disease diagnostics in Taiwan.

Hartwell and United Kingdom-based scientists Paul Nurse and Timothy Hunt received the Nobel Prize "for their discoveries of key regulators of the cell cycle" in 2001. They identified key molecules that regulate the cell cycle in all eukaryotic organisms, including yeasts, plants, animals and humans.

Using yeast, Hartwell unmasked the genes that control cell division, the universal machinery for cell growth in organisms, thus opening new avenues for research into the prevention, diagnosis and treatment of various cancers.

The new direction of Hartwell's research has been investigating the use of powerful protein biomarkers -- early indicators of disease -- to identify individuals at high risk of disease, detect cancer and other diseases at an early stage when they can be cured, and provide improved prognostic information and better therapeutic response.

DOC.HEADLINE: U.S. dollar down on Taipei Forex
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, April 15 (CNA) 04/15/10 17:18:46 (By Y.L. Kao)

TEXT.P: The U.S. dollar lost ground against the New Taiwan dollar on the Taipei Foreign Exchange Thursday, dropping NT$0.085 to close at NT$31.375.
A total of US$1.14 billion changed hands during the trading session.
The U.S. dollar opened at the day's high of NT$31.460 and dropped to a low of NT$31.339 before rebounding.

DOC.HEADLINE: Premier stresses determination to fight counterfeit drugs
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, April 15 (CNA) 04/15/10 17:26:24 (By Hsieh Chia-chen and Fanny Liu)

TEXT.P: Premier Wu Den-yih said Thursday that strengthening crackdowns on counterfeit drugs and underground radio stations was not meant to suppress freedom of speech or hurt the pharmaceutical industry, but to protect the public's health.

Underground radio stations in Taiwan sometimes broadcast advertisements for fake or substandard medicine, and the premier issued a directive earlier this year asking authorities to report to him every week from April 1 on the progress of their crackdowns.
From Jan. 1 to April 14, police discovered 65 cases involving the sale of unlicensed drugs and arrested eight suspects, the Ministry of Justice reported at a Cabinet meeting earlier Thursday.
The National Communications Commission (NCC) said the number of active underground radio stations had dropped to 27 as of April 13, compared to a record high of 190 in 2008.
The NCC also said that beginning this week, it will work overtime and intensify its crackdown to include those underground radio stations that broadcast only on the weekend.

In addition, the NCC will provide information to the Construction and Planning Agency under the Ministry of Interior so that illegal radio stations' broadcast- tower antennas can be removed within a month.

The Department of Health (DOH) reported that from April 1 to April 13, local public health bureaus uncovered nine cases involving the possession of unlicensed medicine and handed out 13 fines. The bureaus also administered sanctions for 323 cases involving the illegal advertising of counterfeit medications and food products.

Speaking at the Cabinet meeting, Wu reiterated that it is the government's responsibility to eradicate the sale of unlicensed drugs and that every department should continue to work diligently toward that goal.

DOC.HEADLINE: 2nd-generation NHI premiums too high: watchdog group
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, April 15 (CNA) 04/15/10 17:37:01 (By Chen Li-ting and Y.F. Low)

TEXT.P: A civic watchdog group said Thursday that a proposed 3.2 percent premium rate for a second-generation National Health Insurance (NHI) is too high because it would lead to premium hikes for all insured persons.

Teng Hsi-hua, a spokeswoman for the group that is monitoring the NHI program, said the new system, which will base premiums on total household incomes rather than the existing system that bases premiums on individual salaries, is expected to increase the premium basis by 40 percent.
Therefore, the premium rate -- which currently stands at 5.17 percent -- should be cut to 3.11 percent under the new system, according to Teng.

With each individual required only to pay 30 percent of the total premium and the employer and the government picking up the balance, the actual premium rate for individuals would be 0.93 percent, she added.
She said that only those with unearned incomes should be made to pay higher premiums under the new system and that wage and salary earners and those with many dependents should not be affected.

However, if the version of the proposal put forward by the Department of Health is adopted, even those fresh out of school who perhaps earn only NT$22,000 per month would see their premiums double, according to Teng.

In response to her comments, Bureau of National Health Insurance Director- General Cheng Shou-hsia said the 3.2 percent premium rate is not final and that the details of the reforms are open to discussion.

On concerns that single individuals would have to pay significantly higher premiums if the household is used as the basic unit of premium calculation in the future, Cheng said the government has yet to determine the definition of "household" but he predicted that not many people will have to pay their premiums independently.

DOC.HEADLINE: China Times: Policy muddling unhelpful to Ma's rating

TEXT.P: The results of the latest Global View Magazine survey shows President Ma Ying- jeou's approval rating rising only 0.9 percent from the lowest level of 22.9 percent recorded after last August's typhoon disaster, while its disapproval rating remains at a high of 66 percent.

Over the past eight months, many things have changed, including the Cabinet line-up, improvements in major economic indicators and the passage of critical amendments to the Local Government Law. Why do so many people remain unimpressed by Ma's performances?

Perhaps, Ma himself has not discerned what has not changed so far is his policy- making team, model and mechanism. Take for example the controversial Industrial Innovation Bill that will soon be put to a showdown vote in the Legislative Yuan.

According to media reports, a major policy U-turn on a corporate income tax cut to be adopted in the bill was made by Ma in a high-level meeting attended by Vice President Vincent Siew and Premier Wu Den-yih. The Presidential Office especially issued a news release after the meeting to set the tone on the contentious tax reduction issue.

The move seemed to be decisive. However, it lacked an in-depth overview of the decision's possible impact. Tax losses will be an immediate result that will exacerbate the government's financial straits. The tax cut apparently favors corporate owners at the expense of regular taxpayers and even future generations.
Worse still, such a decision was made by the country's top three leaders, without reference to the 1,000 pages of written opinions presented by the finance and economics ministries.

Such a "muddling through" policy-making approach violates the principles of good governance that require professionalism and policy transparency. Moreover, it will not help improve the president's approval ratings as he owed the public a detailed explanation of the reasons for a 3 percent cut on corporate income tax at a time when the domestic wealth gap is widening significantly.

DOC.HEADLINE: ECFA will help U.S.-Taiwan trade relations: AIT official
DOC.DATELINE: Kaohsiung, April 15 (CNA) 04/15/10 18:14:06 (By Emmanuelle Tseng and Fanny Liu)

TEXT.P: A U.S. official said Thursday that a proposed economic cooperation framework agreement (ECFA) between Taiwan and China will also be beneficial for Taiwan-U.S. trade relations.
However, Chris Castro, chief of the American Institute in Taiwan's (AIT's) Kaohsiung branch, noted in an interview with CNA that Taiwan's stance on the ECFA is strictly an internal affair.

The AIT's Kaohsiung office will not interfere in discussions about the ECFA, but it will support everything that it thinks can foster peaceful development of the cross-Taiwan Strait relationship, said Castro, who took office in March 2008.
Castro expressed hope that the political leaders in southern Taiwan will help protect vulnerable industries and workers, as well as grab new opportunities once the ECFA is signed.

AIT will also encourage American architecture firms to seek participation in many of the important construction projects under way in Kaohsiung, such as a maritime cultural and pop music center, a passenger terminal at Kaohsiung Harbor, a trade exhibition and convention center, and a planned marina, Castro said.
The Dream Mall in Kaohsiung, Taiwan's largest shopping mall, was designed by a U.S.-based architecture firm, Castro added.

In his remaining year in office, Castro went on, he will focus on further boosting the functions of the Sun Yat-sen America Center, which re-opened last September at National Sun Yat-sen University, to ensure that AIT maintains close contact with the academic community in southern Taiwan.
He also said he will assist the American Chamber of Commerce in Kaohsiung to enhance its functions.

DOC.HEADLINE: Siaolin villagers skeptical over findings of disaster probe
DOC.DATELINE: Kaohsiung, April 15 (CNA) 04/15/10 18:27:26 (By S. K. Chen and Flor Wang)

TEXT.P: Siaolin villagers expressed skepticism Thursday over the findings of a research team that examined the cause of a mudslide that wiped out the village last August, and they demanded a better explanation of the disaster.

Hsu Po-yin, chief delegate of a local development association, asked the government to give a clear explanation of why the soil structure in Kaohsiung County's Siaolin Village was so fragile that Typhoon Morakot's torrential rains triggered a massive mudslide that buried the village.

Hsu said he agreed that the destruction was caused by the mudslide, but he questioned whether the geological environment in Siaolin Village was really as unstable as the investigators claimed. "How come the local residents never noticed that?" he asked.

Hsu's comments came one day after a research team from National Taiwan University and National Central University unveiled the findings of their investigation into the cause of the Siaolin Village disaster.

In a report to the National Science Council, the team said a fragile geological system coupled with torrential rains resulted in a mudslide that buried Siaolin Village during Typhoon Morakot in August last year.

Chien-Chih Chen, a professor at National Central University's Department of Earth Science, said the side of the 1,445-meter Siantu Mountain began collapsing at 6: 16 a.m. on Aug. 9., plunging downhill at a speed of 50 meters per minute.

The slide, carrying the equivalent of some 23 million cubic meters of mud, silt and rocks, lasted only 110 seconds and buried the northern area of Siaolin, Chen reported. On the way downhill, the slide created a debris dam above the village, he said.
According to Hongey Chen, a professor at National Taiwan University's Geosciences Department, the debris dam in the Cishan Stream broke 50 minutes after the musdslide, submerging southern Siaolin.
The village was totally devastated by the two events and most residents were unable to escape. About 600 villagers were killed.
As part of its investigation, the research team examined 144 villages and townships across the country, 92 of which were found to be unsafe.
The team has submitted a list of the flood-prone villages to the Executive Yuan for its reference as this year's typhoon season is approaching.

DOC.HEADLINE: Taiwan to vigorously develop electric car sector
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, April 15 (CNA) 04/15/10 18:51:41 (By Chiachen Hsieh and Deborah Kuo)

TEXT.P: Taiwan will vigorously develop the electric car industry with the goal of creating a production value of NT$120 billion (US$3.8 billion) by 2016, the Ministry of Economic Affairs (MOEA) said Thursday.

Deputy Minister of Economic Affairs Hwang Jung-chiou said in a report at the Executive Yuan on the development of the industry that 10 operational projects will be launched in the coming three years under five development strategies to facilitate the development of the local electric car industry.

The government will allocate a total of NT$9.7 billion over six years to help speed up the development of electric cars, with the hope that Taiwan will have one or several of the top 10 electric car makers in the world by 2016. Electric cars are an irreversible trend amid growing environmental awareness, according to MOEA officials.
It also hopes that within six years, domestic sales of electric vehicles will have topped 45,000 units, with 15,000 exported units, they added.
In six years, the electric car manufacturing sector is envisioned to be worth NT$120 billion, while the relevant service sector will be worth NT$31.2 billion, they continued.
Combined, the electric car manufacturing and service sectors will create jobs for some 24,000 people in the same period, they concluded.
After hearing the reports, Premier Wu Den-yih exhorted the MOEA and other relevant agencies to cooperate closely to expedite the development of the industry.
"Your concerted efforts are needed to allow the local electric car industry to flourish, globalize and eventually make Taiwan a country with a low carbon footprint," he said.

DOC.HEADLINE: 4 Chinese tourists injured in boating accident at Sun Moon Lake
DOC.DATELINE: Nantou, Central Taiwan, April 15 (CNA) 04/15/10 19:16:01 (By Lin Heng-li and Fanny Liu)

TEXT.P: Six people, including four elderly Chinese tourists, were injured Thursday in a boating accident at Sun Moon Lake in central Taiwan's Nantou County, the Sun Moon Lake National Scenic Area administration reported later that day.

According to administration officials, a heavy fog that reduced visibility to less than 100 meters on the lake was suspected as the cause of the accident in which a boat carrying 26 passengers from northeastern China's Dalian City collided with a boat carrying 40 Taiwanese tourists.
The injured were treated at a local hospital for various minor injuries, the administration said, adding that police were investigating the accident.

Sun Moon Lake is one of the most famous scenic spots in Taiwan and is especially popular with Chinese tourists. The number of tourists visiting the park increased 24 percent to 3.6 million in 2009 -- about 600,000 of whom were Chinese tourists, the administration said.

DOC.HEADLINE: Health minister will speak at WHA: MOFA
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, April 15 (CNA) 04/15/10 19:35:20 (By Shih Sin-yao and Sofia Wu)

TEXT.P: Department of Health (DOH) Minister Yaung Chih-liang will deliver a five-minute speech at the 2010 World Health Assembly (WHA) to be held May 17-21 in Geneva, Switzerland, a Ministry of Foreign Affairs (MOFA) official said Thursday.

Thanks to improvements in relations across the Taiwan Strait, China for the first time last year did not block Taiwan's participation as an observer in the annual WHA -- the decision-making body of the World Health Organization (WHO) -- and then-DOH Minister Yeh Ching-chuan made history by delivering a brief speech at that assembly.

Paul W.L. Chang, director of the MOFA's Department of International Organizations, said Yaung will follow the precedent set by Yeh by speaking briefly at the upcoming WHA to share Taiwan's experiences in operating a universal health insurance system and offering international medical aid.

Moreover, Chang went on, Taiwanese delegates will speak at meetings of two special WHA committees and will also hold bilateral meetings with their American, Japanese and European Union counterparts on matters of mutual concern.

"We hope WHA attendance will update our understanding of the latest global developments in health care and medical services while contributing to our bid for expanded international cooperation, " Chang said.

After gaining access to the WHA, Chang said, Taiwan is now eyeing meaningful participation in two U.N.-affiliated organizations -- the United Nations Framework Convention on Climate Change (UNFCCC) and the International Civil Aviation Organization (ICAO).
In the past few months, he continued, Taiwan's embassies and overseas representative offices have been lobbying support of their host countries for the ICAO bid.
Such efforts have borne some fruit, as the European Parliament has already passed a resolution supporting Taiwan's participation in the ICAO as an observer, Chang said.
Heads of state of some of Taiwan's diplomatic allies have also written to the ICAO secretary-general expressing their support for Taiwan's presence in ICAO activities, he added.
In addition, he went on, state senates or houses of representatives in eight U.S. states have also passed resolutions backing Taiwan's observer status in the ICAO.
Also, 85 Czech Republic parliamentarians have sent a joint letter to the ICAO secretary-general expressing their support for Taiwan's presence, Chang said.
Noting that Taiwan is a linchpin in East Asian aviation services, Chang said an average of 1.5 million flights pass through Taiwan's aviation zone annually.

"Therefore, it is very important for Taiwan to obtain updated flight information to ensure aviation safety, " he said, adding that Taiwan's participation in the ICAO would allow the international community to hear Taiwan's opinions on and visions of improvements in international flight safety.

DOC.HEADLINE: Award-winning violinist Mayuko Kamio to make Taiwan debut in May
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei April 15 (CNA) 04/15/10 19:43:12 (by Sunnie Chen)

TEXT.P: Award-winning Japanese violinist Mayuko Kamio will present her first concerto in Taiwan, at the National Concert Hall in Taipei on May 22, according to an organizer from the New Aspect Cultural and Educational Foundation Thursday.
"Kamio is the first musician we are inviting in a series of concerts entitled '21st Century Rising Stars, '" the organizer indicated.
The Japanese violinist won the Gold Medal in the 13th International Tchaikovsky Competition in Moscow in 2007.
She not only won the prize, but also an invitation from Vladimir Spivakov, a leading Russian conductor and violinist, to perform the Tchaikovsky Violin Concerto with the Russian National Orchestra.

A gifted musician, Kamio began to learn the violin at the age of four, and made her concerto debut in Tokyo at the age of 10 under the baton of Swiss conductor Charles Dutoit in a concert broadcast on NHK television.

Born in 1986, Kamio has won several important competitions, including the Menuhin International Violin Competition in 1998, the Young Concert Artists International Auditions in 2000, the Monte Carlo Violin Masters Competition in 2004 and the international David Oistrakh Violin Competition in the Ukraine the same year.
She has also worked with many famous orchestras, such as the BBC Philharmonic, the Israel Philharmonic under Zubin Mehta, the Boston Pops and many others.

In the Taipei concerto, Kamio will use a 1727 Stradivarius violin to present a repertoire with Schubert's "Fantasy in C major" as the opening. The repertoire will also include Prokofiev's "Violin Sonata No. 1 in F minor", Ysaye's "Poeme Elegiaque in D minor" and R. Strauss's " Violin Sonata in E flat major."

DOC.HEADLINE: Fun, exhausting: `best job' winner
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, April 15 (CNA) 04/15/10 19:58:08 (By Alex Jiang)

TEXT.P: Ben Southall, a British man who beat 34,683 hopefuls last year to get what Australia's Tourism Queensland described as "the best job in the world," said when asked if he would have wanted to have his six-month contract extended to a year that the job "was exhausting."

"12 months would be a lovely contract, but it's just this chapter of life," the 35-year-old said at a press conference in Taipei during a visit in his new capacity as an ambassador for Tourism Queensland.

During his stint as caretaker of Hamilton Island, a resort island on the Great Barrier Reef, from July to December 2009, Southall published 71 articles comprising more than 84,000 words, took 1,800 photos and made 52 video diary entries.
He also gave interviews to more than 300 media outlets from all over the world. He earned A$150,000 (US$139,910) for the job.

Quoting the chief executive of Hamilton Island, Southall said that between September and November last year, there had been a roughly 74 percent increase in the number of British tourist visits, and a 236 percent rise in visitor numbers from China.
The tourism marketing campaign was launched at "one of the worst times ever" because of the financial crisis, but the result was successful nevertheless, Southall noted.
Asked about his Taiwanese competitor in the final 16 round of job applicants, Clare Wang, Southall said he is still in touch with her and the other finalists.

"Clare got the support of the entire country here in Taiwan. She won the wild card entry. She was the one who got the most votes at the early stages of the competition when it was down to the top 16, " he said.
"Everybody does stay in touch," he went on. "Once a month, we all send an e-mail between all the best job finalists."
"We all now have 15 other places that we can go to sleep on a sofa," he added to a laughing audience.
Southall had visited the United States, Canada, Japan, Denmark, Ireland, the United Kingdom and China before coming to Taiwan as part of his tourism ambassador job.
On his new role, Southall said that "it's really still about making people jealous around the world -- making people jealous enough to book a flight out to Queensland."
"All I am doing is giving presentations, showing the real photos I took and making people realize that they can do the same thing," he said.

DOC.HEADLINE: Taiwanese basketball player shares 'go west' experience
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, April 15 (CNA) 04/15/10 20:02:59 (By B.H. Shiao and Flor Wang)

TEXT.P: A star Taiwanese professional basketball player who now plays in China encouraged local players Thursday to "go west" to China to gain more experience in the Chinese Basketball Association's (CBA's) Chinese League.

Speaking at a news conference after returning from China for a break, Lin Chih- chieh, a former star of the Taiwan Beer team who has played for the Zhejiang Guangsha Lions since late last year, said Taiwanese professional basketball players should try to take more challenges and sharpen their skills by playing in CBA teams.

Lin, who has signed a two-season contract with the CBA team over a period of 19 months, has made a strong showing playing for the Zhejiang Guangsha Lions. He scored 11.7 points per game this season, seized four rebounds and got 2.9 assists per game. He also took the championship in the CBA's All-Star technical skills competition for this season.
"It is worth playing for CBA teams, as the league provides a good environment for professional players," Lin said.

He also voiced support for a proposal to allow Chinese professional players to play in Taiwan's Super Basketball League, saying that "it would be good if the two sides could have more exchanges in the field of professional basketball."
Asked about his prospects for next season in the CBA, Lin said he is "looking forward to seeing more talented Taiwanese players competing in CBA events."

DOC.HEADLINE: Former NBA player Horry predicts Cavs-Lakers finals
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, April 15 (CNA) 04/15/10 20:34:14 (By Chris Wang)

TEXT.P: Robert Horry, an ESPN commentator and retired basketball player who is visiting Taiwan, predicted Thursday that the 2010 NBA Finals will be a matchup between the Los Angeles Lakers and Cleveland Cavaliers.

Horry, who earned the nickname "Big Shot Rob" for his clutch three-point shooting in playoffs during his 16-year career, also told the media that he would pick Oklahoma City Thunder young star Kevin Durant as the next great big shot maker.

The 208-centimeter forward, who retired in 2008, is one of only two players to have won NBA championships with three different teams -- two with the Houston Rockets, three with the Los Angeles Lakers and two with the San Antonio Spurs.
Horry was invited to Taiwan to endorse the official launch of the NBA's traditional Chinese character Web site.

The NBA.com/Taiwan Web site, a collaborative effort by the local sports Web site Pixnet and the NBA, will be operated by Pixnet starting this month and will present live Internet streaming of games during the 2010 NBA playoff season from April to June.
Doug Creighton, who played for Bank of Taiwan in Taiwan's Super Basketball League (SBL) , said it will be a great way for Taiwanese basketball fans to learn more about NBA players.
Currently, Taiwan cable television channels broadcast three or four NBA games per week, featuring the more popular teams such as the Lakers, Cavaliers and Boston Celtics.
The Hong Kong-based media company TOM Group Limited signed a four-year deal with the NBA in 2008 for the rights to operate the NBA Web site in China, Taiwan and Hong Kong.

However, Taiwanese fans complained that the company merely converted simplified Chinese text, used in China, into traditional Chinese characters for Taiwanese audiences, in disregard of the differences in Taiwan and China regarding basketball terms and the transliteration of player names.
The NBA playoffs begin Saturday with 16 teams competing in the best-of-seven first round. The best-of-seven finals will be played in June.

Asked about the most memorable big shot of his career, Horry said it would have to be a three-pointer at the buzzer that gave the Lakers a 100V99 win over the Sacramento Kings in Game 4 of the 2002 Western Conference Finals. The shot tied the series at 2-2 and the Lakers went on to defeat the Kings in the seven-game series to take their third straight championship.

The 39-year-old veteran, who is on his first visit to Taiwan, told the media that he was very impressed by the local people's knowledge of basketball and with the Taipei 101 tower, which he said is "like a Transformer every time I look at it."

Prompted by reporters, Horry picked his "best starting lineup of today's NBA, " which included himself, Utah Jazz point guard Deron Williams, Lakers shooting guard Kobe Bryant, Dallas Mavericks power forward Dirk Nowitzki and Cavaliers center Shaquille O'Neal.
Horry jokingly said that as both Bryant and Nowitzki like to shoot, he would select the veteran O'Neal as center so "I could get some shots."

DOC.HEADLINE: Electric motorbikes dominate trade show in Taipei
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, April 15 (CNA) 04/15/10 21:33:19 (By Alex Jiang)

TEXT.P: A motorcycle show highlighting the latest electrical models kicked off in Taipei Thursday as Taiwan's government is promoting the production and use of eco-friendly scooters in a country with the highest scooter density in Asia.

"The Ministry of Economic Affairs allocated NT$1.6 billion (US$51 million) for a four-year subsidy plan in 2009 to encourage the public to buy electrical scooters or motorcycles, " said Hsu Chun-fang, deputy director-general of the ministry's Bureau of Foreign Trade.
"That is part of the government's goal to promote the use of eco-friendly products," she told the opening ceremony of the four-day Motorcycle Taiwan show.
The target of the show is to see sales of 100,000 such scooters or motorcycles over the next four years, Hsu added.
Earlier this month, however, leaders of local major business groups urged the government to raise the target for electrical motorbike sales to one million over the four-year period.
They also asked the government to set up lanes especially for electrical motorbikes and recharging stations for the bikes in cities throughout Taiwan.

Taiwan has the highest scooter density in Asia, with every 1.6 person owning a scooter on average, according to government figures. There are some 14.55 million scooters or motorcycles on the island of 23 million people.

As Taiwan's domestic market for motorbikes is reaching maturation, local companies have begun shifting their focus to overseas markets in the United States and Europe in recent years, Hsu said at the ceremony.
The ratio of the country's motorbike exports to total bikes produced rose from 32.94 percent in 1999 to 41.23 percent in 2009, Hsu noted.

Taiwan's motorbike companies are now facing low-price competition from counterparts in China and Southeast Asian countries, but their quality has helped them play a leading role in the industry, Hsu said.
Outside the Taiwan International Motorcycle Show, there is a small area to allow people to experience a ride on new models of motorbikes. Stunt performances will also take place in the area.
In its fifth year, the show also features sand beach motorbikes, heavy bikes and motorcycle parts.
The show will run until April 18 at the Taipei World Trade Center's Exhibition Hall, with the first two days open to buyers and the final two days open to the general public.
Some 17,000 people are expected to visit the event, with 195 companies from the U.S., Germany, Italy, Spain, Russia, Hong Kong and Malaysia displaying their products in 429 booths.

DOC.HEADLINE: Poor roads drag number of visitors to Alishan to 27-year low
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, April 15 (CNA) 04/15/10 21:39:56 (By Chiang Chun-liang and Sofia Wu)

TEXT.P: Road damage has taken a heavy toll on travel services in the Alishan area, one of Taiwan's most iconic tourist destinations, causing the number of visitors to the mountain resort during this year's spring flower season to drop to a 27-year low, sources said Thursday.

According to statistics released by the Alishan Highway Toll Station, only 102,853 people visited the Alishan National Scenic Area between March 15 and April 15, the lowest number for the period since the inauguration of the Alishan Highway in 1983.
The Taiwan Forest Bureau designates the month-long period as the Alishan's flower season to coincide with the blossoming of various species of the many flowering cherry trees grown there.
A toll station official said this year's visitor number was even lower than that recorded in the flower season immediately following the deadly Sept. 21, 1999 earthquake.
In its 2000 flower season, Alishan still managed to attract 136,000-plus visitors, the official said.
"Normally, the number can be expected to exceed 200,000 or even hit 300,000 during the season," said the official.

He attributed this year's record low number mainly to the suspension of services of the well-known Alishan alpine railway in the wake of Typhoon Morakot, which wreaked havoc in the region and several other parts of southern Taiwan last August.
Two branch railway lines, including one that leads to Chushan, the traditional destination for watching the sunrise, have also been closed since the typhoon.

Worse still, the Alishan Highway, the region's main traffic link, has been closed to large tour buses since the typhoon. Some sections of the highway are still being repaired and are only open to small buses and cars.
Local tour operators said they hope highway and railway repair work can be completed as soon as possible to give a much-needed shot in the arm to the region's tourism industry.

DOC.HEADLINE: Ex-president's cash to be handed over as soon as possible
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, April 15 (CNA) 04/15/10 21:50:54 (By Neil Lu, Lin Chung-sen and Fanny Liu)

TEXT.P: Swiss judicial authorities said Thursday that they expect to hand over the assets of former President Chen Shui-bian's relatives frozen in Swiss bank accounts to the Taiwanese authorities as early as possible, but gave no specific timetable as to when the money would be forthcoming.
It was the first time the Office of the Attorney General (OAG) of Switzerland had commented publicly on the ex-first family's case.
"There is an excellent collaboration between the Taiwanese authorities and the OAG, " Jeannette Balmer, spokeswoman of the OAG, wrote in a statement to CNA.
"The objective target of this collaboration is the handover of the assets to the Taiwanese authorities as early as possible (i.e. practicable)," she went on.
The Swiss authorities' attitude and their handling of the case are seen as key in deciding whether Chen will be released on bail.

On April 2, the High Court gave an ultimatum to Chen's relatives, demanding that they return the money, and said Chen will have a good chance of being released on bail if the money is returned and little chance if it is not.

The former president, indicted on corruption and embezzlement charges, has been in custody at the Taipei Detention Center in Taipei County since Dec. 30, 2008. He was given a life sentence and a fine of NT$200 million last September. He is presently appealing against the sentence and the High Court is expected to hand down a ruling on it June 11.
However, it is uncertain whether the Swiss handover of the assets can be completed by that time.
Balmer said that measures for such a procedure take time and that no further information would be given at this stage.

According to sources familiar with the case, after Taiwan's Special Investigation Division under the Supreme Prosecutors Office, which is responsible for the former president's case, sent an agreement signed by Chen's family to the OAG at the end of March, the Zurich-based RBS Coutts Bank AG and Merrill Lynch Bank (Suisse) S.A. started account-closing procedures.

With Chen's current detention period slated to expire April 23, his family are hopeful that the money held in Switzerland -- roughly NT$700 million (US$21 million) -- can be transferred to a bank account designated by prosecutors, increasing the chances that Chen can be released on bail.

DOC.HEADLINE: Taiwanese businessman indicted for spying for China
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, April 15 (CNA) 04/15/10 21:55:09 (By Lin Chang-shun and Bear Lee)

TEXT.P: A Taiwanese businessman with operations in China was indicted by the Shihlin Prosecutors Office Thursday for spying for China, according to the indictment released that day.

Ho Chih-chiang, a China-based Taiwanese businessman, had been recruited by China's national security authorities since 2007 to collect Taiwanese national security secrets in return for financial subsidies and other privileges, the indictment said.

Acting under the instructions of Chinese officials, Ho returned to Taiwan and tried to recruit a Taiwan National Security Bureau (NSB) officer, surnamed Chao, to serve as a Chinese spy by collecting information related to the government's policies on Falun Gong, Tibetan independence, Japan and diplomacy, between December 2008 and February this year.

Ho also offered Chao US$20,000, liquor and additional pay several times that of Chao's retirement pension in exchange for information on NSB overseas deployments and its satellite communication routings, but this was rejected by Chao.
Ho was indicted on charges of bribery and of violating laws on national security and on protection of national secrets.

DOC.HEADLINE: Civil aviation chief wants more Taipei-Shanghai flights
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, April 15 (CNA) 04/15/10 23:09:35 (By S.F. Wang and Flor Wang)

TEXT.P: Civil Aviation Administration (CAA) Director-General Lee Lung-wen urged Taiwan and China Thursday to quickly begin talks on exchanging flights between Taipei Songshan Airport and Shanghai's Hongqiao International Airport as the Shanghai World Expo 2010 approaches.

Lee said he was happy to find out that the Taiwan Affairs Office under China's State Coucil had responded positively to a Taiwanese request for negotiations and called for a swift start in view of the rising demand with the approach of the expo, which will kick off in May.
"The two sides should hold the talks and set up game rules as soon as possible to allow carriers on both sides to make preparations and arrange their operations," Lee said.

"It is necessary to quickly add flights and provide more seats on the Taipei- Shanghai route to satisfy the strong market demand, " Lee said. "Otherwise, the fare cuts recently offered by Taiwanese carriers will serve no-one," he added.
"Flying charters between the two popular destinations is only an interim measure, and both sides should also soon negotiate a scheme for regular flights," he went on.
"Songshan-Hongqiao flights should also continue after the Shanghai World Expo 2010 ends," he added.
According to Lee, the CAA has repeatedly sought two-way talks on increasing the number of Taipei-Shanghai flights, but the Chinese side has always turned down Taiwan's requests.
The Taipei-Shanghai route is the busiest flight route across the Taiwan Strait and tickets tend to sell like hot cakes, requiring travelers to book tickets at least two months in advance.
Apart from Songshan Airport, seven other airports around Taiwan should also establish direct flights with Shanghai earlier, Lee said.

DOC.HEADLINE: AIT chief optimistic about Taiwan's economic prospects
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, April 15 (CNA) 04/15/10 23:16:43 (By Tseng Yi-hsuan and Bear Lee)

TEXT.P: The director of the Taipei Office of the American Institute in Taiwan (AIT) , which represents U.S. interests in the absence of bilateral diplomatic relations, said Thursday that he is optimistic about Taiwan's economic recovery and that he welcomes closer economic cooperation between the two sides of the Taiwan Strait.
William A. Stanton made the remarks while addressing a party hosted by AmCham- Kaohsiung in the southern city of Kaohsiung earlier that day.

A Southern Taiwan White paper, which assesses the business environment in the region and offers suggestions on the development of industry and education, was released by AmCham-Kaohsiung at the party.
AmCham-Kaohsiung President Brian Aiello said the paper was written after visits to Kaohsiung city and county officials and a survey of 1,737 businesses in the area.

On Taiwan's proposed economic cooperation framework agreement with China, Aiello said that if signed, it will be an important step forward for Taiwan, just as when the country joined the World Trade Organization (WTO), and will eventually benefit Taiwan.

The white paper says the ECFA will allow Taiwan to further consolidate its business base and reduce the trade barriers worldwide, but suggests that the country's central and local governments should take good care of the areas and sectors that will be adversely impacted by the pact.

Predicting that southern Taiwan will see more focus on the development of green energy and tourism, the white paper urges the government to speed up the modernization of airports and seaports in the region, and to improve tourism and transport facilities.
Chris Castro, chief of the AIT's Kaohsiung branch, also said in an interview with CNA that day that the ECFA will also be beneficial for Taiwan-U.S. trade relations.

He said AIT will also encourage American architecture firms to seek participation in many of the important construction projects under way in Kaohsiung, such as a maritime cultural and pop music center, a passenger terminal at Kaohsiung Harbor, a trade exhibition and convention center, and a planned marina.

DOC.HEADLINE: Electric motorbikes dominate trade show in Taipei
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, April 15 (CNA) 04/15/10 21:33:19 (By Alex Jiang)

TEXT.P: A motorcycle show highlighting the latest electrical models kicked off in Taipei Thursday as Taiwan's government is promoting the production and use of eco-friendly scooters in a country with the highest scooter density in Asia.

"The Ministry of Economic Affairs allocated NT$1.6 billion (US$51 million) for a four-year subsidy plan in 2009 to encourage the public to buy electrical scooters or motorcycles, " said Hsu Chun-fang, deputy director-general of the ministry's Bureau of Foreign Trade.
"That is part of the government's goal to promote the use of eco-friendly products," she told the opening ceremony of the four-day Motorcycle Taiwan show.
The target of the show is to see sales of 100,000 such scooters or motorcycles over the next four years, Hsu added.
Earlier this month, however, leaders of local major business groups urged the government to raise the target for electrical motorbike sales to one million over the four-year period.
They also asked the government to set up lanes especially for electrical motorbikes and recharging stations for the bikes in cities throughout Taiwan.

Taiwan has the highest scooter density in Asia, with every 1.6 person owning a scooter on average, according to government figures. There are some 14.55 million scooters or motorcycles on the island of 23 million people.

As Taiwan's domestic market for motorbikes is reaching maturation, local companies have begun shifting their focus to overseas markets in the United States and Europe in recent years, Hsu said at the ceremony.
The ratio of the country's motorbike exports to total bikes produced rose from 32.94 percent in 1999 to 41.23 percent in 2009, Hsu noted.

Taiwan's motorbike companies are now facing low-price competition from counterparts in China and Southeast Asian countries, but their quality has helped them play a leading role in the industry, Hsu said.
Outside the Taiwan International Motorcycle Show, there is a small area to allow people to experience a ride on new models of motorbikes. Stunt performances will also take place in the area.
In its fifth year, the show also features sand beach motorbikes, heavy bikes and motorcycle parts.
The show will run until April 18 at the Taipei World Trade Center's Exhibition Hall, with the first two days open to buyers and the final two days open to the general public.
Some 17,000 people are expected to visit the event, with 195 companies from the U.S., Germany, Italy, Spain, Russia, Hong Kong and Malaysia displaying their products in 429 booths.

DOC.HEADLINE: Poor roads drag number of visitors to Alishan to 27-year low
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, April 15 (CNA) 04/15/10 21:39:56 (By Chiang Chun-liang and Sofia Wu)

TEXT.P: Road damage has taken a heavy toll on travel services in the Alishan area, one of Taiwan's most iconic tourist destinations, causing the number of visitors to the mountain resort during this year's spring flower season to drop to a 27-year low, sources said Thursday.

According to statistics released by the Alishan Highway Toll Station, only 102,853 people visited the Alishan National Scenic Area between March 15 and April 15, the lowest number for the period since the inauguration of the Alishan Highway in 1983.
The Taiwan Forest Bureau designates the month-long period as the Alishan's flower season to coincide with the blossoming of various species of the many flowering cherry trees grown there.
A toll station official said this year's visitor number was even lower than that recorded in the flower season immediately following the deadly Sept. 21, 1999 earthquake.
In its 2000 flower season, Alishan still managed to attract 136,000-plus visitors, the official said.
"Normally, the number can be expected to exceed 200,000 or even hit 300,000 during the season," said the official.

He attributed this year's record low number mainly to the suspension of services of the well-known Alishan alpine railway in the wake of Typhoon Morakot, which wreaked havoc in the region and several other parts of southern Taiwan last August.
Two branch railway lines, including one that leads to Chushan, the traditional destination for watching the sunrise, have also been closed since the typhoon.

Worse still, the Alishan Highway, the region's main traffic link, has been closed to large tour buses since the typhoon. Some sections of the highway are still being repaired and are only open to small buses and cars.
Local tour operators said they hope highway and railway repair work can be completed as soon as possible to give a much-needed shot in the arm to the region's tourism industry.

DOC.HEADLINE: Ex-president's cash to be handed over as soon as possible
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, April 15 (CNA) 04/15/10 21:50:54 (By Neil Lu, Lin Chung-sen and Fanny Liu)

TEXT.P: Swiss judicial authorities said Thursday that they expect to hand over the assets of former President Chen Shui-bian's relatives frozen in Swiss bank accounts to the Taiwanese authorities as early as possible, but gave no specific timetable as to when the money would be forthcoming.
It was the first time the Office of the Attorney General (OAG) of Switzerland had commented publicly on the ex-first family's case.
"There is an excellent collaboration between the Taiwanese authorities and the OAG, " Jeannette Balmer, spokeswoman of the OAG, wrote in a statement to CNA.
"The objective target of this collaboration is the handover of the assets to the Taiwanese authorities as early as possible (i.e. practicable)," she went on.
The Swiss authorities' attitude and their handling of the case are seen as key in deciding whether Chen will be released on bail.

On April 2, the High Court gave an ultimatum to Chen's relatives, demanding that they return the money, and said Chen will have a good chance of being released on bail if the money is returned and little chance if it is not.

The former president, indicted on corruption and embezzlement charges, has been in custody at the Taipei Detention Center in Taipei County since Dec. 30, 2008. He was given a life sentence and a fine of NT$200 million last September. He is presently appealing against the sentence and the High Court is expected to hand down a ruling on it June 11.
However, it is uncertain whether the Swiss handover of the assets can be completed by that time.
Balmer said that measures for such a procedure take time and that no further information would be given at this stage.

According to sources familiar with the case, after Taiwan's Special Investigation Division under the Supreme Prosecutors Office, which is responsible for the former president's case, sent an agreement signed by Chen's family to the OAG at the end of March, the Zurich-based RBS Coutts Bank AG and Merrill Lynch Bank (Suisse) S.A. started account-closing procedures.

With Chen's current detention period slated to expire April 23, his family are hopeful that the money held in Switzerland -- roughly NT$700 million (US$21 million) -- can be transferred to a bank account designated by prosecutors, increasing the chances that Chen can be released on bail.

DOC.HEADLINE: Taiwanese businessman indicted for spying for China
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, April 15 (CNA) 04/15/10 21:55:09 (By Lin Chang-shun and Bear Lee)

TEXT.P: A Taiwanese businessman with operations in China was indicted by the Shihlin Prosecutors Office Thursday for spying for China, according to the indictment released that day.

Ho Chih-chiang, a China-based Taiwanese businessman, had been recruited by China's national security authorities since 2007 to collect Taiwanese national security secrets in return for financial subsidies and other privileges, the indictment said.

Acting under the instructions of Chinese officials, Ho returned to Taiwan and tried to recruit a Taiwan National Security Bureau (NSB) officer, surnamed Chao, to serve as a Chinese spy by collecting information related to the government's policies on Falun Gong, Tibetan independence, Japan and diplomacy, between December 2008 and February this year.

Ho also offered Chao US$20,000, liquor and additional pay several times that of Chao's retirement pension in exchange for information on NSB overseas deployments and its satellite communication routings, but this was rejected by Chao.
Ho was indicted on charges of bribery and of violating laws on national security and on protection of national secrets.

DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, April 15 (CNA) 04/15/10 23:09:35 (By S.F. Wang and Flor Wang)

DOC.HEADLINE: Today in history
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, April 16 (CNA) 04/16/10 08:57:51
DOC.TEXT:
Today is Friday, April 16, or the third day of the third month of the Year of the Tiger according to the lunar calendar. Following is a list of important events that have occurred on this date in the past:
1828: Francisco Jose de Goya, Spanish artist whose paintings and etchings reflected the political and social turmoil of his time, dies at the age of 82.
1850: Madame Marie Tussaud, Swiss founder of the famous waxworks museum in London, dies at the age of 89.
1889: Sir Charles Spencer Chaplin, known as "Charlie," film actor and comedian much loved for his portrayal of a tramp in baggy pants and bowler hat, is born in Britain. His productions include "The Kid," "The Gold Rush," and "The Great Dictator."
1912: American pilot Harriet Quimby becomes the first woman to fly the English Channel.
1917: Vladimir Ilyich Lenin returns to Russia after three years of exile in Zurich.
1923: Japanese Crown Prince Hirohito arrives in Keelung for an inspection tour of Taiwan, which is under Japanese rule.
1925: In honor of Dr. Sun Yat-sen, who died in Peking on March 12, 1925 at the age of 59, the Kwangtung Provincial Government changes the name of Hsiangshan County, the place of birth of Dr. Sun, to Chungshan County.
1941: German troops enter Sarajevo, Yugoslavia, and the main synagogue is destroyed.
1948: The Organization for European Economic Co-operation (OEEC) is established in Paris by Western European nations in accordance with the Marshall Plan.
1960: The Taiwan Provincial Government begins the implementation of labor insurance regulations by establishing the Labor Insurance Bureau.
1972: Yasunari Kawabata, Japanese writer who won the 1968 Nobel Prize for literature, commits suicide at the age of 73. His novels, including "Thousand Cranes," often concern alienated, lonely individuals in search of beauty and purity.
1972: The Apollo 16 mission is launched from Cape Kennedy, Florida, to make the fifth manned moon landing.
1975: The communist Khmer Rouge seize Phnom Penh, capital of Cambodia.
1978: A tornado strikes the eastern state of Orissa in India, killing some 180 people.
1981: The Kaohsiung C.K.S. Cultural Center is inaugurated.
1982: Queen Elizabeth proclaims Canada's new constitution, severing the colonial links with Britain.
1985: The first test tube baby in the Republic of China is born at the Veterans General Hospital in Taipei.
1990: In London, Freed African National Congress leader Nelson Mandela publicly thanks the world for its support during his 26-year imprisonment by the South African government.
1998: Khmer Rouge leader Pol Pot is reported dead of a heart attack in his Cambodian jungle stronghold at the age of 73. During his four-year reign of terror some two million Cambodians died.
1999: Former opposition Democratic Progressive Party Chairman Hsu Hsin-liang is blasted by other DPP members for his recent remarks on plebiscites and Taiwan independence.
1999: A field hospital donated by Taiwan opens at the Stenkovee refugee camp outside Skopje, Macedonia.
2000: Republic of China President-elect Chen Shui-bian says that "maintaining peace and stability and safeguarding the interests of Taiwan are the highest goals and moral obligations" for him as president.
Confucius' lesson of the day: "Men in old times educated themselves for their own sakes. Men now educate themselves to impress others."
