DOC.HEADLINE: United Daily News: Fiscal gatekeeping needed

TEXT.P: The latest reversal of the industrial innovation policy highlights a serious flaw in President Ma Ying-jeou and his staff with regard to financial policy research and analysis.

The finance minister and chief budgeter of a country are required to have clear thinking and a strong professional background, and should not subject themselves too much to restrictions by the premier and the president.

However, our present finance minister and chief budgeter obviously are more submissive than professional. Their silence with regard to the industrial innovation bill reflects their negligence in supervising Taiwan's fiscal situation.

Even after a whole year of arbitrary tax cuts in 2009, the Ma administration has still not realized the seriousness of the country's fiscal deficit and is now allowing lawmakers to haggle over the corporate income tax rate -- which could be dropped to 17 percent as a result. The populist, obsequious manner demonstrated by the administration is very worrisome.

This serious lack of basic fiscal and financial concepts by our nation's leader is responsible for the country's worsening fiscal situation. This is the number one foul-up the Ma administrion badly needs to fix. (April 16, 2010)

DOC.HEADLINE: China Times: Stop disgracing the medical sector
DOC.DATELINE: 04/16/10 11:36:26 (By Elizabeth Hsu)

TEXT.P: It was the most malignant and darkest event involving the medical sector in Taiwan when 10 hospitals, seven physicians and 20 "phony patients" were found to be working with a fraud ring to claim health insurance reimbursement and payouts from insurance companies.

Facing a punitive fine of NT$150 million (US$4.75 million) , one of the hospitals involved -- Kaohsiung Medical University Chung-Ho Memorial Hospital in southern Taiwan -- contended that the punishment is too heavy since it was not the hospital that committed the fraud.

However, as a medical center, can the hospital actually even say it is not responsible for the conduct of its medical personnel? There are obviously glitches in the hospital's management if its director of the Department of Obstetrics and Gynecology was able to switch cancer patient specimens and let "phony" patients undergo chemotherapy treatment, as well as surgery, in order to claim reimbursement from the National Health Insurance system and insurance companies.
It is one thing to question the punishment's justice. The hospital should apologize for its mistakes before trying to defend itself. It should be facing the accusations in a more humble manner.
The scandal exposes the fact that Taiwan still needs to make great efforts to promote medical ethics education and self-discipline in the medical sector.

DOC.HEADLINE: Death suspected to be caused by toxic dried bean curd
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, April 16 (CNA) 04/16/10 11:52:50 (By Chen Ching-fang and Deborah Kuo)

TEXT.P: A 45-year-old woman living in Miaoli County who died two days ago is suspected of having died from botulism growing on dried bean curd or preserved oysters that she had eaten, Department of Health (DOH) officials said Friday.

The woman's 72-year-old mother-in-law, who had also eaten the two suspicious items, was on intubation in the Taichung Veterans General Hospital intensive care unit, said Feng Jun-lan, an official with the Food and Drug Administration (FDA) under the DOH.
The suspect dried bean curd was bought from a store in their neighborhood in Miaoli, while the oysters were bought recently in Yunlin, Feng said.

No symptoms were reported among the other members of the family, including a grandfather and son, who did not eat the dried bean curd at all, and a grandson who only consumed a little of the food, according to Feng.

Lin Ting, deputy director of the DOH's Centers for Disease Control (CDC), said that although it would take two days to find out the results of tests, their symptoms suggested serious paralytic illness caused by a nerve toxin produced by the bacterium clostridium botulinum.
The CDC has rushed antiviral agents to the hospital in the hope that the 72 -year-old's life can be saved, Lin said.
Samples of the dried bean curd and salted oyster were also retrieved by the FDA, but lab reports are not expected to be available for two weeks, Feng said.

She described the bacteria as anaerobic, gram-positive, spore- forming rods that produce a potent neurotoxin and grow best in low oxygen conditions. She suggested that all home-canned foods, vegetables and meats should be boiled for at last 10 minutes before consumption.
According to DOH tallies, Taiwan's botulism mortality rate averages between 5 percent-10 percent. The illness was declared by the CDC as a notifiable disease in 2007.
A total of 12 botulism cases were reported in 2007-2008, with one 67-year-old man dying of the disease.
The two Miaoli women were the third and fourth cases this year following a mother and daughter in Taoyuan County who were diagnosed as victims of botulism in early April, the CDC said.

DOC.HEADLINE: Taiwan, Canada ink working holiday MOU
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, April 16 (CNA) 04/16/10 12:11:25 (CTOT) and the Taipei Economic and Cultural Office in Canada (TECO) (By Chris Wang)

TEXT.P: Canada has become the fourth country to sign a working holiday agreement with Taiwan, allowing young people to travel and work in each other's country, the Ministry of Foreign Affairs (MOFA) announced at a press conference Friday.

A Memorandum of Understanding (MOU) on youth mobility, which aims to simplify the administrative process for young people aged 18-35 from Canada and Taiwan who wish to travel and work in each other's territory for up to one year, was signed in the Canadian capital of Ottawa earlier in the day by the Canadian Trade Office in Taipei early Friday, said MOFA spokesman Henry Chen.
CTOT represents Canadian interests in Taiwan in the absence of bilateral diplomatic ties, while TECO functions as Taiwan's representative office in Ottawa.

"Through this arrangement, Canadian and Taiwanese youth can gain a unique travel, work and life experience abroad, enriching their understanding of each other's culture, " said CTOT Executive Director Scott Fraser in a press release. "Such exchanges will also further strengthen the longstanding people-to-people ties between Canada and Taiwan," he added.

Taiwan signed similar agreements with Australia and New Zealand in 2004 and with Japan in 2009. It is the fourth country in the Asia-Pacific region to have made such arrangements with Canada, following Japan, South Korea and Hong Kong, according to Chen.

He said the MOU is expected to come into effect July 1. Each side will offer a quota of 200 of multiple entry visas in the first year of the program, increasing the number over the next few years depending on the popularity of the program.

The program is expected to boost bilateral tourism. According to statistics provided by Taiwan's Tourism Bureau, the number of Taiwanese nationals traveling to Canada plummeted from 112,413 in 2004 to 61,893 in 2009.
The existing working holiday programs are going smoothly, Chen went on, with more than 12,000 applicants -- 600 for New Zealand, 2,000 to Japan and more than 10,000 to Australia -- last year.

Meanwhile, Winston Chen, deputy director-general of MOFA's Department of North American Affairs, said the ministry has been working hard toward Canada's granting of visa-free privileges for Taiwanese nationals and will continue to do so.

In terms of Taiwan's potential filing of a complaint with the World Trade Organization (WTO) against Canada over its refusal to allow generalized preferential tariffs on Taiwan-made textile products, he said this will not have a negative impact on the visa negotiations.

"Bilateral relations between Taiwan and Canada are on the right track and are too good to be damaged by a trade dispute, " he said, adding that Taiwan will still do its best to protect its own interests once the case is in the WTO.

DOC.HEADLINE: Two Taiwanese carriers cancel flights to Europe over ash fallout
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, April 16 (CNA) 04/16/10 12:19:51 (By Wang Shu-fen and Sofia Wu)

TEXT.P: Taiwan's two largest carriers -- China Airlines (CAL) and EVA Airways -- canceled several of its Europe-bound flights Friday as some European airports remained closed due to clouds of ash spewed from an erupting volcano in Iceland.
The clouds of volcanic ash, which can wreak havoc on jet engines, were drifting across the Atlantic and over large swathes of Europe, making flying hazardous.
CAL canceled the Bangkok-Amsterdam leg of its CI165 and CI166 flights between Taipei and Amsterdam.
Meanwhile, EVA dropped its Taipei-Paris round-trip flights and was scheduled to announce later in the day whether it would also cancel its Taipei-Vienna flights.

DOC.HEADLINE: Commercial Times: Widening gap between rich and poor

TEXT.P: The phenomenon of "one Taiwan, two worlds" is typical of the increasingly uneven distribution of wealth in this country. Unless the vanishing middle class is rejuvenated, this phenomenon of wealth polarization will place Taiwan in a precarious situation.
On the part of the government, providing assistance to the financially disadvantaged will be of greatest help to producing a "multiplier effect."

We are not advocating "robbing the rich to give to the poor" to provide social equality. However, we understand that it is the wage and salary earners rather than those high net worth individuals on the tip of the social pyramid that contribute the largest share of the country's tax revenue. The government should launch extensive reforms and impose a tax on personal property.

As for the business sector, it should fulfill its social responsibility and spend more on public interest efforts than ostentatious, impractical items. Furthermore, "employees are corporate assets" should not be a mere slogan but should be put into practice.

The middle class will only thrive in a society where businesses view their employees as assets and provide their workers with reasonable pay and due respect. Without a steady and strong middle class, the wealth disparity in society will continue to widen, which will in turn intensify labor-capital conflicts.

The phenomenon should be taken seriously by the nation. In particular, the country's two major political parties should get election considerations out of their brains and stop passing laws that could further widen the divide between the poor and the rich.

DOC.HEADLINE: Legislature begins screening contentious innovation bill
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, April 16 (CNA) 04/16/10 12:57:02 (By Su Lung-chi and Sofia Wu)

TEXT.P: The Legislative Yuan began a second reading of a contentious draft statute on encouraging industrial innovation Friday, with the opposition Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) caucus calling for showdown votes on 17 of its clauses.

The bill should have been passed last year to fill the void left by the expiration of a statute on encouraging industrial upgrading at the end of 2009, but its passage was delayed as several of its provisions met strong criticism from some social quarters.

The most controversial of these concerns tax incentives to be offered to the business and industrial sectors, including an across-the-board corporate income tax cut and tax privileges for corporate R&D spending, as well as employment subsidies.
After many rounds of difficult negotiations between the ruling and opposition legislative caucuses, both sides finally agreed to deal with the bill at Friday's session.
Legislative Speaker Wang Jin-pyng said the legislature would finalize screening of the bill on that day, even if it had to extend its session into the night.
As the ruling Kuomintang controls a majority of the legislative seats, it was widely expected that the bill would clear the legislative floor by the end of the day.

DOC.HEADLINE: Water rationing expected in Kaohsiung
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, April 16 (CNA) 04/16/10 13:32:13 (By Yang Sz-ruei and Y.F. Low)

TEXT.P: Water rationing measures might be implemented in Kaohsiung from late May due to a serious drought in the southern part of the country, an official said Friday.

The Water Resources Agency (WRA) had expected normal water supplies to continue into mid-June in the Kaohsiung and Pingtung areas and late June in the Tainan area, according to WRA Director-General Yang Wei-fu.
However, water reserves in the south are going down faster than expected, with almost no rainfall in the Kaohsiung and Pingtung areas in recent months, Yang said.
If the drought continues, water rationing measures will have to be enforced in Kaohsiung beginning in late May, he said, urging residents to conserve water in preparation for the crisis.

DOC.HEADLINE: Talk of the day -- Is New Taiwan dollar undervalued?

TEXT.P: With foreign money flowing into Asian currency markets in anticipation of the Chinese yuan appreciation, the New Taiwan dollar has been rising against the U.S. greenback in recent days.
The local unit climbed NT$0.121, or 0.38 percent, to reach NT$31.339 at one point in Thursday's trading session, but edged down as of the 4 p.m. close following central bank intervention.
According to a Goldman Sachs assessment, the NT dollar was undervalued by about 20 percent.

Judging from Thursday's currency market development, banking sources said, the central bank would not want the NT dollar to appreciate too fast, although the general trend is for the local currency to continue to strengthen, they added.
The following are excerpts from local media coverage of the issue: Commercial Times:
The NT dollar will continue to rise at a moderate pace after it surged past the NT$31.5 level.
According to a Goldman Sachs report, the local currency is undervalued by at least 20 percent and it forecast that the NT dollar might rise to NT$30 against the greenback over the next 12 months.

Sakthi Siva, Credit Suisse's Asia-Pacific and emerging markets equity strategist, said that even though Asian currencies have appreciated significantly recently, most of them have not yet returned to the levels recorded before the 2008-2009 global financial crisis. Therefore, he predicted that their upward streaks will not end any time soon.

Credit Suisse also forecast that the currencies of South Korea, Brazil, Taiwan, Israel and China will have great room for appreciation this year. It gave an even more optimistic forecast than Goldman Sachs, saying that the NT dollar has the potential to rise to NT$29.5 against the greenback by the end of this year. (April 16, 2010). China Times:
Liu Kuo-chao, head of the Importers and Exporters Association of Taipei, said the continued rise in the local currency's value has affected local manufacturers' competitiveness.

He said that if the NT dollar rises to 30 to the US dollar, many local exporters will face enormous pressure. As a lot of hot money is flowing to Asia, central banks in most Asian countries, including Singapore and South Korea, have been forced to let their currencies to rise.

In the face of this trend, Liu said he cannot expect Taiwan's central bank to do otherwise. "We can only hope that our central bank will do its utmost to have our currency rise at a moderate pace," Liu said.

Market analysts shared Liu's view that the local currency cannot buck the general market trend and will appreciate steadily. But they said whether the NT dollar will rise to 31 will hinge on the international currency market trend. (April 16, 2010).

DOC.HEADLINE: Vice premier could boost KMT in elections: secretary-general
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, April 16 (CNA) 04/16/10 14:49:24 (By Garfie Lee and Deborah Kuo)

TEXT.P: Vice Premier Eric Liluan Chu's willingness to run for the Kuomintang (KMT) in Xinbei City is a shot in the arm for the ruling party in the mayoral elections for the five special municipalities, KMT Secretary-General King Pu-tsung said Friday.

The bid for Xinbei City -- to be upgraded from Taipei County -- marks a challenge in Chu's political career but is a crucial and positive move for the KMT, King said in an interview broadcast Friday on local television channel TTV.
Chu's announcement of the bid has calmed the party's edginess concerning the election in Xinbei, a major battlefield for the KMT and the opposition Democratic Progressive Party (DPP), King said.

On the prospects of incumbent KMT Taipei Mayor Hau Lung-bin's taking on strong DPP rival Su Tseng-chang, King said it would be a formidable task for Hau, but added that the mayor is well-prepared and in high spirits.

On the election in Kaohsiung City, which will be a merger of the southern port city and Kaohsiung County, King said it would be a "decisive battle" that could see a complete reversal for the ruling party in that crucial area.
King said that six KMT members have made known their intentions to vie for the Kaohsiung nomination.
"The final nominee will be selected on principles of openness, fairness and justice," the secretary-general said.
Turning to his relationship with President Ma Ying-jeou, who doubles as KMT chairman, King described it as a "relationship of trust."
King said he will endeavor to do his best for the president and the country while working as a top aide to Ma.
On criticism that Ma was too weak as a president, King said that Ma is a mild man who upholds democratic rationality and makes decisions based on democratic consensus.
He added that a democratic nation should avoid "politics of hate," referring to criticism of President Ma by DPP members.

According to King, the DPP distorted the president's hard-earned achievements in improving the cross-Taiwan Strait relations -- lauded by the international community -- as a plot to "sell out Taiwan" borne of Taiwan-centric ideology.
On Ma's low approval ratings, King appealed to the country to give the president "a little more time" for the results of his administrative efforts to show.

DOC.HEADLINE: Taiwanese private bank to organize venture capital fund with China
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, April 16 (CNA) 04/16/10 15:19:30 (By Tien Yu-pin and Elizabeth Hsu)

TEXT.P: Taiwan's privately owned Fubon Financial Holding Co. (FHC) is planning to cooperate with the investment fund of China's state-run China Development Bank, as well as the Fujian provincial government, to set up an industrial venture capital fund, the general manager of FHC said Friday.

Under the plan, Victor Kung elaborated that the three organizations will inject a total of 5 billion Chinese yuan (NT$24.75 billion or US$732.36 million) into the fund, with Fubon putting in the largest portion of the investment at 40 percent while the other two investors each contribute 30 percent.
The planned fund will exist in the form of a private equity fund that will target all cross-Taiwan Strait industrial businesses without limitation on the category of industrial sectors, Kung noted.

Fubon is regarded as a Taiwanese financial holding company with a comprehensive business deployment in China. Apart from the planned investment fund, it is also working to form a fund management company with the Zhejiang Province-based Founder Securities, according to the company.

Meanwhile, FHC Chairman Daniel M. Tsai expressed hope for the financial services sector to be included in the first list of goods and services subject to immediate tariff concessions or exemptions under the "early harvest" program of the proposed economic cooperation framework agreement (ECFA) between Taiwan and China.
The early harvest lists are seen as the backbone of the trade pact Taiwan hopes to be sealed as early as June.

The financial sector was not placed on the agenda of the second round of ECFA talks held March 31-April 1. The arrangement drew concern from Taiwanese investors in China who have been calling for the two sides of the strait to open their doors to the banking sectors of each side.

While urging the government to proceed with the ECFA talks at a faster pace, Tsai also called for the authorities in charge of financial affairs to relax restrictions that restrain Taiwan's banking operators from investing in China.

DOC.HEADLINE: Process for U.K. passport applications to change: BTCO
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, April 16 (CNA) 04/16/10 15:32:07 (By Chris Wang)

TEXT.P: From May 17, United Kingdom passport applications for British nationals will no longer be handled by the British Trade and Cultural Office (BTCO) and will need to be sent directly by the applicant to a regional passport processing center in Hong Kong, the UK's representative office in Taiwan announced Friday in a press release.
The office will no longer accept passport applications from British nationals, said the BTCO, Britain's official authority in Taiwan in the absence of bilateral diplomatic ties.

Previously, the BTCO acted as a middleman for British passport applications in Taipei, accepting the applications, sending them to the issuing authorities in Hong Kong, and then issuing the passport to the applicant.
According to the BTCO, the changes are part of a global initiative to streamline the issuance of passports overseas.
The Passport Processing Center in Hong Kong, which will produce and return passports directly to applicants in Taiwan, aims to issue all new passports within 10 working days, the office said.
If British nationals need to travel urgently, however, the BTCO will still be able to issue emergency travel documents.

DOC.HEADLINE: Taiwan share prices close lower
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, April 16(CNA) 04/16/10 15:35:29 (by Olivia Wang)

TEXT.P: Taiwan's share prices closed lower Friday, with the weighted index -- the market's key barometer-- falling 60.37 points, or 0.73 percent, to close at 8,111.57.
The local bourse opened at 8,161.85 and fluctuated between 8,090.68 and 8,162.85 during the day's trading. Market turnover totaled NT$121.17 billion (US$3.86 billion).

Six of eight major stock categories lost ground, with cement issues dropping the most at 1.1 percent. Financial and banking stocks lost 0.96 percent, machinery and electronics issues moved down 0.87 percent and foodstuffs were down 0.67 percent. Textile issues fell 0.43 percent and plastics and chemicals shares lost 0.21 percent.
Two major stock categories gained ground, with construction shares gaining 0.84 percent and paper and pulp issues moving up 0.65 percent.
Losers outnumbered gainers 2,003 to 1,118, with 279 remaining unchanged.
Foreign investors and Chinese QDIIs were net sellers of NT$1.71 billion in shares.

DOC.HEADLINE: President wants heritage status for traditional Chinese characters
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, April 16 (CNA) 04/16/10 15:50:52 (By Cheng Ching-wen and Y.F. Low)

TEXT.P: President Ma Ying-jeou expressed hope Friday that traditional Chinese characters can be designated as a world cultural heritage item by the United Nations.

Ma also instructed government agencies to use traditional, also known as standard, Chinese characters, instead of the simplified form of characters used in China, when receiving visitors from there, so as to promote the use of the traditional writing form.

The president made the remarks when addressing the opening of a cross-Taiwan Strait conference on Chinese literature held in Taipei. Other participants included National Cultural Association (NCA) President Liu Chao-shiuan, the 2000 Nobel laureate in literature Gao Xingjian, poet Ya Hsien, and writers Lee Ou-fan and Liu Zaifu.
According to Liu Chao-shiuan, literature could be the only available resolution to cross-strait differences because the two sides share a common cultural and historical memory.

In light of the situation in which there are terms that carry different meanings in China and Taiwan, the NCA is seeking to compile a database of Chinese terms in cooperation with China to expedite cross-strait cultural exchanges, he said.
Commenting on the issue, Gao, however, said it is not necessary to standardize the terms used by the two sides because "literature knows no borders."

DOC.HEADLINE: Eight localities refuse to support ECFA campaign
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, April 16 (CNA) 04/16/10 16:44:07 (By C. L. Chiang and Flor Wang)

TEXT.P: Eight local governments under the opposition Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) signed a pledge Friday to refuse to cooperate with the central government's call to promote across-Taiwan Strait trade pact.

"A proposed Taiwan-China economic cooperation framework agreement (ECFA) is a significant matter and should be decided by the Taiwan people, " Chiayi County Magistrate Chang Hwa-kuan said at a news conference.

Chang also displayed a statement signed by Kaohsiung Mayor Chen Chu, Kaohsiung County Magistrate Yang Chiu-hsing, Pingtung County Magistrate Tsao Chi-hung, Tainan Mayor Hsu Tain-tsair, Tainan County Magistrate Su Huan-jhih, Yunlin County Magistrate Su Chih-fen and Yilan County Magistrate Lin Tsung-hsien.

"Until the government comes up with a good explanation of the pacts's pros and cons, we refuse to serve as messengers for the administration of President Ma Ying-jeou, " Chang said, arguing that the government has not fully disclosed the information.
According to Chang, the government has only bothered to tout the good side of the ECFA, but it has not told the people about the disadvantages.
She criticized Ma's administration, saying it was damaging Taiwan's democracy and economy by insisting on pushing through the trade deal without the people's consent.
The ECFA with China would allow hundreds of products from either side to enter the other with low tariffs or duty free.

DOC.HEADLINE: U.S. dollar up on Taipei Forex
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, April 16 (CNA) 04/16/10 16:53:12 (By Olivia Wang)

TEXT.P: The U.S. dollar gained ground against the New Taiwan dollar on the Taipei Foreign Exchange Friday, rising NT$0.015 to close at NT$31.390.
A total of US$807 million changed hands during the trading session.
The U.S. dollar opened at the day's high of NT$31.436 and dropped to a low of NT$31.340 before rebounding.

DOC.HEADLINE: MOI expands denture-fitting subsidy program for elderly
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, April 16 (CNA) 04/16/10 17:27:05 (By Lee Ming-chung and Y.F. Low)

TEXT.P: The eligibility for the government's denture-fitting subsidies has been expanded to cover a larger number of elderly individuals, Minister of the Interior Jiang Yi-huah announced Friday.
More than 10,000 are expected to benefit from the program this year, Jiang said.

The new beneficiaries of the programs are disabled individuals aged 65 or older. They are eligible if they are recipients of a living subsidy issued by the government, or if 50 percent or higher of their care and support expenses are being subsidized by the government, Jiang said.
The program targeted only senior citizens from low-income and lower-middle income households when it was launched in January 2009.
A total of 4,823 people benefited from the program that year, the minister said.
According to the Bureau of Health Promotion, 21.5 percent of Taiwan's elderly population have lost all their teeth, which is a common cause of malnutrition among this demographic.
Under the subsidy program, those who are eligible can receive subsidies of up to NT$40,000 based on the type of dentures fitted.

DOC.HEADLINE: Air links between eastern Taiwan, China to be opened in May
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, April 16 (CNA) 04/16/10 17:39:36 (By Wang Shu-fen, Tyson Lu and Elizabeth Hsu)

TEXT.P: Three Taiwanese air carriers are to begin providing chartered flight services from eastern Taiwan's Hualien and Taitung cities to Chinese cities and Hong Kong, the Tourism Bureau under the Ministry of Transportation and Communications announced Friday.

The services, scheduled to kick off in May, were established amid a steadily increasing number of visits by tourists from China and Hong Kong after the two sides of the Taiwan Strait launched direct chartered flights in July 2008.

The planned chartered flight services, which will allow Chinese tourists to travel direct by air to scenic eastern Taiwan instead of arriving on the west coast and traveling overland, are expected to increase the choices and freshness of tours of Taiwan, bureau officials said.
According to the bureau, Taipei-based Mandarin Airlines will launch its maiden chartered flight from Nanjing to Hualien May 7, and its first flight from Nanjing to Taitung May 14.
Uni Airways will offer its first chartered flight from Xiamen to Taitung May 5, and Trans Asia Airways will fly for the first time from Hangzhou to Hualien May 14, the bureau said.

In terms of the Hong Kong-eastern Taiwan chartered flight services, the bureau said Mandarin Airlines will launch a flight between Hong Kong and Taitung on May 15 and another on May 18, and a flight between Hong Kong and Hualien on May 21 and another on May 25.
Taitung Magistrate Justin Huang expressed hope, meanwhile, that "there will not only be maiden flights but that regular flights will follow."

DOC.HEADLINE: Dried bean curd makers' operations suspended
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, April 16 (CNA) 04/16/10 18:02:41 (By Chen Ching-fang and Deborah Kuo)

TEXT.P: The Taoyuan County Public Health Bureau on Friday ordered two dried bean curd makers to suspend operations for two weeks after two women were reportedly poisoned by food that may have come from the two companies.

The bureau notified Cheng Hsiang Foods Co. and Richang Bean Curd Plant in the northern Taiwan county to temporarily suspend business after their products were found in the refrigerator of the two women's home in Miaoli County.

Of the two, the 45-year-old daughter-in-law died two days ago. Doctors suspect she contracted botulism from either dried bean curd or preserved oysters she had eaten, the Cabinet-level Department of Health (DOH) said earlier that day.

The woman's 72-year-old mother-in-law, who had also eaten the two food items, was on intubation in Taichung Veterans General Hospital's intensive care unit, according to Feng Jun-lan, an official with the Food and Drug Administration (FDA) under the DOH.

Lin Ting, deputy director of the DOH's Centers for Disease Control (CDC) , said that although it would be two days before test results are available, the women's symptoms suggested serious paralytic illness caused by a nerve toxin produced by the bacterium clostridium botulinum, which causes botulism.
The CDC had rushed several doses of botulismus-antitoxin to the hospital in a bid to save the 72-year-old's life, Lin said.
The Taoyuan health officials have also notified major grocery chain stores in the county to pull products from the two companies off shelves.
The companies' owners, however, complained of mistreatment. They said their products were safe and produced in line with government standards.
They complained that the two-week suspension will cost them hundreds of thousands of New Taiwan dollars.
"I hope the relevant tests will be completed soon so that my company's name can be cleared, " said Tseng Fan-Hsiang, owner of Cheng Hsiang Foods Co.

In related news, Lin said around noon that the CDC's inventory of botulismus- antitoxin doses now totals only around 15 after 10 were sent to National Taiwan University Hospital and Taichung Veterans General Hospital.
"We have already placed new orders for the medicine to beef up our supplies," Lin said.
According to Lin, the antitoxin costs NT$149,000 per dose of 250cc and is distributed to botulism patients free of charge because the illness was declared by the CDC as a notifiable disease in 2007.
Samples of the dried bean curd and salted oysters that the two women consumed were also retrieved by the FDA, but lab reports are not expected to be available for two weeks.

The two Miaoli women were the third and fourth cases this year following a mother and daughter in Taoyuan County who were diagnosed with botulism in early April, the CDC said. The Taoyuan mother and daughter have been treated with botulismus-antitoxin.

DOC.HEADLINE: Interns get low job ratings but remain in demand by employers: poll
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, April 16 (CNA) 04/16/10 18:23:54 (By Yang Su-min and Y.L. Kao)

TEXT.P: Domestic enterprises expressed widespread dissatisfaction with the performance of interns hired under a special government subsidy program, but more than 90 percent said they were willing to keep at least some of the interns on for a second year, a poll conducted by the 1111 job bank has found.

In a survey of 458 companies conducted by the job bank between March 31 and April 13, the respondents gave the interns an average score of 41 on a scale of 100 for their job performance, with 34.62 percent of respondents giving their interns scores between 21 and 40.
The main causes of dissatisfaction were the interns' attitude toward their jobs and early termination of their contracts, according to the survey, the results of which were released Friday.

At the same time, however, 92 percent of the companies said they were willing to keep the interns on after their one-year contracts expired, and 52.32 percent were willing to offer them formal positions.
A spokeswoman for 1111 Job Bank explained that the apparent contradiction between the high disapproval rate and the high willingness to retain the interns was related to two factors.

Companies involved in the program hired five interns on average, so even if they were willing to rehire only some of their interns, they would have been included among the 92 percent willing to retain the interns.

Also, because many companies had already invested in training and familiarizing the interns with their operations, the employers were more willing to rehire the experienced interns than new recruits, the spokeswoman said.

Under the internship program launched in mid-2009 to curb unemployment among young adults, the government provides subsidies to businesses that offer one- year internships to individuals who graduated from a university or college within the previous three years.
Businesses receive NT$26,000 per month for each new graduate hired (including subsidies for health and labor insurance) , and the interns are paid NT$22,000 per month.
Open to 34,000 people, the program is still employing 29,265 interns. Most of the jobs are related to planning and design, marketing and trade, and business management, according to the survey.
Up to 68.75 percent of the companies responding to the poll have raised their interns' salaries, with an average monthly salary of NT$23,651 paid to each intern, the survey found.

Just over half, or 57 percent, of the companies said that if they rehired the interns, they would raise their salaries by an average of NT$1,280, while 13 percent said they had already raised their salaries, and 30 percent said they would maintain the salary level at NT$22,000.

Meanwhile, 64 percent of respondents expressed the belief that the program would help address unemployment among new university graduates, who faced a particularly difficult job market after graduating in 2009 because of the global economic downturn.

DOC.HEADLINE: Institute revises Taiwan's 2010 GDP growth rate upwards
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, April 16 (CNA) 04/16/10 19:24:33 (By C. W. Hsieh and Flor Wang)

TEXT.P: Chung-Hua Institution for Economic Research (CIER) on Friday revised its forecast for Taiwan's GDP growth in 2010 upwards to 4.99 percent, 0.33 percentage points higher than its previous projection made last December.
Wang Lee-rong, director of the CIER's Center for Economic Forecasting, attributed the revision to growing private-sector investment and increased exports amid a recovering economy.

She warned, however, that if the government decides to wind down the economic stimulus measures it has used to combat the global economic slump or lower public investment to curb its budget deficit, Taiwan's growth rate could fall to 4.08 percent in 2010.

The economic research body also forecast that Taiwan's GDP should grow 6.55 percent in the second quarter of the year, 4.01 percent in Q3, and 1.08 in Q4, while unemployment for the year should average 5.5 percent.
Weaker growth experienced in Q4 could continue into 2011, Wang said, with the CIER revising its growth forecast for next year downwards to 4.09 percent from 4.30 percent.
Wang said inflationary pressures should be moderate in 2010, with consumer prices expected to rise 1.71 percent and wholesale prices projected to increase by 5.76 percent.

She stressed, however, that the CIER's projections were on the conservative side and had not taken into account the impact of a planned economic cooperation framework agreement (ECFA) with China and a possible appreciation of the Chinese yuan.

Wang predicted that the yuan will gain in value in June when the G20 holds a summit of finance ministers and central bankers, and she expected that if China's currency become stronger, the Taiwan dollar would also appreciate.
She did not believe, though, that the yuan would appreciate too rapidly in a short period of time.
The CIER forecast that the Taiwan dollar will average 31.299 against the greenback in 2010 and that it will continue rising in 2011.

Meanwhile, Wang warned that the government's finances would worsen if an industrial innovation bill, which slashes the corporate income tax rate to 17 percent (from the current 20 percent) , passes the Legislative Yuan, an outcome that could affect public investment in the future.

DOC.HEADLINE: Time right to sign trade pact with China: president
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, April 16 (CNA) 04/16/10 20:23:54 (By lee Hsi-chang and Y.L. Kao)

TEXT.P: President Ma Ying-jeou said Friday that it is the right time to sign a proposed economic cooperation framework agreement (ECFA) with China and that the government will do what it can to prevent disadvantaged industries from being affected by the pact.
Ma made the remarks in response to a call by several precision machinery companies in Taichung City to sign the proposed ECFA as soon as possible.

Victor Taichung Machinery Works Co. President Huang Ming-ho said that Taiwan's machinery exports to China face strong competition from South Korea now and that the competition will become even stiffer if China signs a free trade agreement with South Korea allowing South Korean exports to China to enjoy lower tariffs.

The signing of the proposed ECFA might pose a risk to Taiwan, but it could also be an opportunity for the country, Huang said, adding that if Taiwan does not sign the cross-Taiwan Strait trade pact, the machinery sector could be left with nowhere to go.
But if an ECFA is signed, there would be room for the industry to develop and create a peak period of about 5 to 10 years, or even more than 20 years, according to Huang.

Echoing Huang, Ma said the machinery sector is a major source of Taiwan's soft power, and that if the ECFA is not signed, the competitiveness of Taiwan's machinery industry would lag behind its Japanese and South Korean rivals in the Chinese market.
Ma cited experts as saying that due to the global economic recovery, it is the right time to sign the pact and it could help stimulate the revival of domestic industries.

The president said that in the initial stage, the scope of products and services on an early harvest list for immediate concessions under the trade accord will be small, but include the necessary items.
To mitigate potential negative impact the accord could bring to vulnerable local industries, the government will provide funds to help affected sectors, he said.

DOC.HEADLINE: Israeli conductor to make his Taiwan debut
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei April 16 (CNA) 04/16/10 20:25:10 (By Sunnie Chen)

TEXT.P: Israeli conductor Amos Talmon will present music from Israel's past and present when he makes his debut in Taipei this weekend.

In the concert, called "Voice of Israel -- Now and Then, " Talmon will collaborate with local cellist Ku Mei-yu to present Max Bruch's "Kol Nidrei" and conduct the Moment Musical Youth Orchestra in performances of Jewish composer Marc Lavri's "Emek" and Tchaikovsky's Symphony No. 6 in B minor, "Pathetique."
"Lavri's symphonic poem 'Emek' depicts Israel's landscape and spirit through music. The other piece by Max Bruch, 'Kol Nidrei, ' is the most Jewish piece I can think of, " said Talmon Friday.

Invited to Taipei by Chiang Ching-po, the music director of the Philharmonia Moment Musical, Talmon is excited about his first appearance in Taiwan's capital, and he hopes to promote communication between young musicians in the two countries in the future.

Chiang and Talmon are both committed to promoting talented young musicians, so after they met in Israel, where Chiang was invited to conduct the Israel Symphony Orchestra Rishon LeZion last Christmas, they became good friends, and Chiang invited Talmon to Taiwan.
"It's a good start for our future cooperation to introduce talented young musicians to come to Taipei or to go to Israel to present their music," Chiang said.
The 47-year-old Talmon is regarded as unique among conductors internationally because of the unusual path he's taken to making a name for himself in his profession.
He had been a businessman for much of his young adult life but could not shake an interest in music that had been with him since childhood.
"So I decided to take action on music 13 years ago, and now when I look back, I feel great about my choice," he said.
Talmon launched his career by conducting orchestras in his home country, such as the Israel Philharmonic, Israel Symphony Rishon LeZion and Jerusalem Radio Symphony.

As he gained fame, he later collaborated with famous orchestras outside of the country, including the Polish Radio Symphony Warsaw, Zurich Symphony Orchestra, Beijing Symphony, and the Mexico State Symphony.

He also founded the Music Angels Herzliya Foundation in 2000 and was also the music director of the Grand Symphonic Series, produced by the Music Angels Herzliya Center for Performing Arts, to support and provide opportunities for young Israeli soloists.
"I would love to do the same thing here in Taiwan, " the conductor said.

DOC.HEADLINE: Ex-president to remain jailed two more months
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, April 16 (CNA) 04/16/10 20:28:32 (By Y. C. Lai and Flor Wang)

TEXT.P: A Taiwan High Court panel ruled Friday that former President Chen Shui-bian will remain at the Taipei Detention Center for another two months.
Friday's ruling means that Chen will not be released before June 11, when the Taiwan High Court hands down its verdict on the appeal of his conviction.
Chen was first arrested Nov. 12, 2008 after being charged with corruption and money laundering. He was set free a month later following his indictment.
Chen was detained again December 30, 2008 by the Taipei District Court on a request by prosecutors and has never been released since that time.
The high court panel took charge of Chen's case on Sept. 24, 2009, after he appealed his life sentence.

Both Chen and his wife were sentenced to life in prison on Sept. 11, 2009 by the Taipei District Court and fined NT$200 million (US$6.13 million) and NT$300 million, respectively, on counts of corruption, embezzlement and taking bribes.
