DOC.HEADLINE: Taiwan charity raising funds for Qinghai orphans
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, April 16 (CNA) 04/16/10 21:03:40 (By Chen Li-ting and Elizabeth Hsu)

TEXT.P: The Taipei-based Eden Social Welfare Foundation launched a campaign Friday to help children from an orphanage school in China's Qinghai province after the school was destroyed in a 7.1 magnitude earthquake April 14.

The foundation announced that it will first donate NT$1 million (US$31,800) to the school in Qinghai's Tibetan Autonomous Prefecture of Yushu before sending volunteers from Taiwan in May to help with relief work.

At a news conference Friday, Eden called Nyima Renzin, the principal of the school, to ask about the aftermath of the earthquake. The principal cried as he said that the school's 220 orphans and more than 10 teachers have been forced to camp at a horse-racing course since the quake destroyed the school, killing one teacher and injuring six students.
"They need winter clothes very much now to keep them warm," Nyima Renzin said, noting that the temperature dropped to low as to minus 4 or 5 degrees Celsius at night.

Eden Chief Executive Huang Cho-sung said it is difficult to enter Yushu at the moment because the Chinese government has blocked roads leading to quake-hit areas. Moreover, sandstorms had reportedly caused trouble for road traffic between Xining, the capital of Qinghai province, and Yushu, he added.
Volunteers from Eden currently posted in Sichuan province were expected to arrive in Qinghai Friday, where they will work along with Handicap International to provide aid, Huang said.
The earthquake left 760 people dead, according to China's state-run Xinhua News Agency.

Since 2004, the Eden foundation has sent volunteers annually to remote, impoverished areas in foreign countries including the Philippines, Thailand, India and China to help less-privileged children and families.

DOC.HEADLINE: Taiwanese scientist makes breakthrough in biotracer research
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, April 16 (CNA) 04/16/10 21:10:57 (By Lin Hui-chun and Sofia Wu)

TEXT.P: A Taiwan-trained biomedical engineer has gained international renown with a breakthrough in creating a new generation of biotracer, the National Science Council (NSC) said Friday.

Lin Cheng-an, an assistant professor in Chung Yuan Christian University's Department of Biomedical Engineering, received the 2010 Young Investigator Award from the International Society for Optical Engineering (SPIE) in January for his achievements in using nanotechnology in developing new materials for biotracer production, the council said.

His paper, which described a novel method of synthesizing fluorescent gold nanoclusters for molecular imaging inside the human body, was carried in the 2009 ACS Nano, a peer-reviewed scientific journal published by the American Chemical Society.
It ranked third in terms of the click through rate among the journal's nanotechnology-related papers in 2009.
The paper even attracted the attention of "Nature, " one of the world's most prestigious science journals, which published an interview with him in its March 25 issue.

"It marked the first time that the world's top science journal has carried an exclusive interview with a young Taiwanese scientist," NSC Deputy Minister Chen Cheng-hong said at a news conference. "It is an honor for our academic sector."

Speaking on the same occasion, Lin said biotracers are an important tool to track and mark cells in biomedical research. At present, quantum dots are the preferred material for cellular imaging because of their stability and brightness relative to organic dyes.
But they still have major drawbacks. They cannot be used in humans because they contain toxic ions, such as cadmium.

In comparison, Lin said, the biotracer he developed using fluorescent gold nanoclusters are more suitable for molecular imaging inside the human body because nanoparticles are smaller, and gold is a bioinert and biocompatible material.

"It will allow us to track cells -- for example, an antibody that is a marker for cancer -- over a long period of time, " Lin said, adding that the material can be used in biophotonics, biomedicine and molecular biotechnology.

Lin acknowledged that his new material still needs to undergo more biosafety and biocompatibility, and other issues, such as how to flush it out of one's system, also need to be resolved before it can be used in humans on a clinical basis.

Lin said that at present, he is collaborating with Yeh Hung-yi, a cardiologist at Mackay Memorial Hospital in Taipei, to use the nano-biotracer to mark stem cells taken from the human body and inject them into the deformed rear limbs in mice to help them recover.
The 33-year-old is a locally trained scientist who obtained his bachelor, master's and doctoral degrees in biomedical engineering from Chun Yuan Christian University.

In his interview with Nature, Lin said he originally studied the biological effects of ultrasound stimulation. Under his mentor Walter Chang's encouragement, he decided to focus his efforts on nanobiotechnology in 2002 when the NSC began promoting a national nanotechnology program.
He received a scholarship co-sponsored by the NSC and Germany's DAAD (Deutscher Akademischer Austausch Dienst) to do post-doctor research on nanobiophotonics.
The research project allowed him to receive tutoring from both Taiwan and German collaborators, which Lin said gave him plenty of inspiration.

"Nanobiophotonics -- generating photons to image or manipulate biological materials at the nanoscale -- was quite new in Taiwan at that time, " Lin recalled in the interview, adding that he and his mentor's initial efforts to synthesize fluorescent nanocrystals failed.
"Collaborators in Germany helped us gain the necessary skills, " Lin said.

In 2005, Lin said, Professor Chang arranged for him to visit Wolfgang Parak's group, then at Ludwig Maximilian University of Munich, for two months to learn the skills needed to synthesize quantum dots.
On his future career plans, Lin said he hoped to develop some promising nano- related products, especially for clinical use, and patent them.
"Once they are on the market, the benefit of the technology transfer will come back to our university for research and education efforts," he added. CNA Photo 19, 21

DOC.HEADLINE: Lower trade barriers beneficial to U.S.-Taiwan trade: AIT official
DOC.DATELINE: Kaohsiung, April 16 (CNA) 04/16/10 21:33:02 (by Emmanuelle Tseng and Lillian Lin)

TEXT.P: If there are cross-Strait initiatives that help Taiwan lower trade barriers and reduce protectionism, it would be beneficial to U.S.-Taiwan trade, Chris Castro, chief of the American Institute in Taiwan (AIT) Kaohsiung Branch Office, said Friday.

Asked to comment on the proposed economic cooperation framework agreement (ECFA) between Taiwan and China, Castro stressed that "ECFA is an issue for Taiwan and the PRC to decide, and AIT won't interfere.
"We support any cross-Strait initiative which improves peaceful cross-Strait exchange," he said.

Some local politicians in southern Taiwan have expressed concern over the possible negative impact the framework agreement will have on certain industries after it is signed and Taiwan's market is more open to Chinese products.
But Castro said that if an ECFA is signed, "I hope leaders in the south will find the best means possible to pursue new economic opportunities while protecting vulnerable groups."

DOC.HEADLINE: National Academy of Civil Service opens with president's blessing
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, April 16 (CNA) 04/16/10 21:55:09 (By Sophia Yeh and Sofia Wu)

TEXT.P: President Ma Ying-jeou gave his full support Friday to proposed amendments to the country's civil service performance evaluation system, saying it's time for the existing system to be modified to upgrade the quality of the country's civil service.
"The purpose of the Civil Service Performance Evaluation Act is to encourage civil servants rather than punish them, " Ma said at the inauguration ceremony of the National Academy of Civil Service.
"Therefore, we should place our focus on whether the proposed reform can realize the goal of rewarding outstanding civil servants while retiring underperforming ones."
It was the first time that Ma has publicly thrown his weight behind the controversial Examination Yuan-initiatied amendments to the civil service evaluation act.

The amendments have sparked a backlash among some public functionaries because they would require all government agencies to give at least 3 percent of their staffers a "C" grade in their annual evaluations.
The draft package, which also proposes that civil servants be retired or fired if they get three "Cs" over 10 years, is now pending legislative approval.

Ma said critics need not focus their concern on the "3 percent C-grade" proposal and should instead determine whether the new system can effectively boost the morale of civil servants and upgrade service quality.

The president said the package's inclusion of objective evaluation standards and a mechanism for underperforming civil servants to offset poor evaluations, as well as guidelines to establish an efficient and independent channel of appeal, are very important to reforming the system.
He therefore hoped the reform package could clear the Legislature in the not- too-distant future.
He also lauded Examination Yuan President John Kuan for his broad-mindedness and modesty shown in the process of formulating the reform package.
Speaking on the same occasion, Kuan said the National Academy of Civil Service is an upgrade of the Examination Yuan's original body responsible for civil service training.
The new academy is expected to play a greater role in training and cultivating competent civil servants in order to better contribute to good governance, Kuan said.
"Reform of the civil service evaluation system and reinforcement of manpower training are like two wings to help uplift our civil service quality," he added.

DOC.HEADLINE: Innovation bill passes legislature after marathon session
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, April 16 (CNA) 04/16/10 22:39:29 (by Kelven Huang and Lillian Lin)

TEXT.P: The Legislative Yuan approved the draft Statute to Encourage Industrial Innovation Friday night, after a marathon debate between legislators of the ruling Kuomintang (KMT) and the opposition Democratic Progressive Party (DPP).
The Legislative Yuan began showdown votes on various controversial clauses of the draft bill Friday afternoon, with dozens of legislators offering arguments for and against.
The caucuses of the KMT and the DPP agreed in the morning that the screening of the draft bill had to be finalized during Friday's session.
At a consultation initiated by Legislative Speaker Wang Jin-pyng, the two caucuses agreed to set aside 17 controversial clauses and concluded the second reading of the draft bill in the morning.

The deadlocked clauses mainly concerned tax incentives and non-project related subsidies to business and industry for innovation that the DPP caucus has said will only benefit big businesses. Most of the DPP arguments failed to be adopted as the bill was undergoing its final review, or third reading.

A KMT version of the draft bill was approved by the Cabinet in May 2009 as a means to stimulate industrial innovation and research and development, since a previous investment-stimulating measure -- the Statute for Upgrading Industry -- was to expire at the end of 2009.

During the last legislative session, however, the proposal met strong resistance from the DPP, which said that several of the draft's provisions overlooked the requirements of small- and medium-sized industries.
Although the ruling KMT controlled a majority of the legislative seats, the draft bill failed to pass the legislature before the Statute for Industrial Upgrading expired.
The hotly debated business income tax rate is not included in the draft bill, despite the fact the tax break is meant to be a major incentive measure to encourage research and development.

A closely related draft bill on business taxes will be screened by legislators next week after the KMT caucus submits a proposal to cut the business income tax rate from 20 percent to 17 percent. A DPP proposal to reduce the business income tax rate from 20 percent to 17.5 percent already passed the second reading at the Legislative Yuan.
Since tax incentives remain at the core of the innovative incentive bill, a bill on tax breaks is required for tax authorities to make necessary adjustments to the taxation system.

DOC.HEADLINE: Local bank urges allowing Chinese banks to invest in Taiwan
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, April 16 (CNA) 04/16/10 23:14:22 (By Tien Yu-pin and Y.L. Kao)

TEXT.P: A local financial holding company called on the government Friday to lift a ban on Chinese banks from holding stakes in Taiwan's banks and financial holding companies, saying local banks would not necessarily be at a disadvantage at the negotiating table.

Victor Kung, president of Fubon Financial Holding Co., Taiwan's second largest listed financial services company, said the attempts by some Taiwanese banks to sell stakes to Chinese banks has raised concerns that an major influx of funds from China could undermine Taiwan's banking system.
Kung dismissed the concerns, however, arguing that if local banks can sell their stakes at 3-5 times their value, they could be the winners in the transactions.

Noting that the banking and financial sector in Taiwan now operates in an extremely competitive environment, Kung said that if Chinese investors took over Taiwanese banks, he doubted whether they could survive the market.

Also, Chinese authorities would also not necessarily be willing to allow their banks to invest in Taiwan, the Fubon Financial executive said, adding that with China's banks enjoying an interest rate spread of at least 3 percent, Taiwan's financial sector might not be very attractive to them to begin with.
Kung said, however, that Chinese banks are welcome to take a stake in Fubon and that the company is keen to forge strategic alliances with Chinese partners.
But he indicated that if their offers are not attractive enough, Fubon is not likely to be interested in working with them.

Fubon Financial was Taiwan's first financial services company to buy a stake in a Chinese bank, when it bought a 19.99 percent share in Xiamen City Commercial Bank through Fubon Bank (Hong Kong) in 2008.
It now plans to launch insurance and fund-management ventures in China in the hope of building a business conglomerate in Fujian Province on a scale similar to the company in Taiwan.

DOC.HEADLINE: Military to relocate ammunition depot
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, April 16 (CNA) 04/16/10 23:18:35 (By Tyson Lu and Lilian Wu)

TEXT.P: National Defense Minister Kao Hua-chu gave his word Friday that an ammunition depot located in an aboriginal community in Taitung County will be removed in three to five years, after residents voiced their opposition to having the depot so close to them.

Kao made the promise during a visit to Hsinwu community in the eastern county's Haiduan Township to listen to the voice of the Bunun people who live there. He was there at the invitation of Legislator Kung Wen-chi of the ruling Kuomintang.

In 1972, the MND chose the mountainous community, which is about 70 kilometers from downtown Taitung City, as the site for an ammunition depot where the guns and cannons for the Army and the Air Force in the Taitung area could be stockpiled.

With the ammunition depot near their homes, the residents have lived "in constant fear, " Kung said. They also believe it hampers the tourism development of the community, which is part of the Southern Cross-Island Highway linking Kaohsiung and Tainan counties in the west to Taitung County in the east.

For Haiduan Township's years of accommodating the depot, the Ministry of National Defense said it would reciprocate by providing NT$2 million annually to the community starting in 2011, as long as the depot remained in the area.
It stipulated, however, that 90 percent of the funds were to be used on local development, which residents of the area claimed would not be in line with local needs.
They hoped the funds could be allocated to other areas, such as culture and health insurance, or as subsidies for low-income households.
But even with the promise of money, community residents agreed it was best "if the depot were removed."

DOC.HEADLINE: Taiwan firm vows to grow 'Regent' brand worldwide
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, April 16 (CNA) 04/16/10 23:32:10 (By S. H. Hsu and Flor Wang)

TEXT.P: Taipei-based Formosa International Hotels Corporation (FIHC) announced Friday that it has purchased the Regent luxury hotel business and its development rights.
FIHC Chairman S. Steven Pan confirmed that his group has bought the global brand name for US$56 million from Carlson, a privately-held, global hospitality and travel company.
"Our mission is to build Regent into the most admired luxury hotel brand in the world, one that exceeds even the high expectations of Regent owners and guests," Pan said.
"We are confident that Regent will thrive under the direction of Formosa, " said Hubert Joly, president and chief executive officer of Carlson, in a statement.
The transaction made FIHC the first business group in Taiwan's history to acquire an international brand that it had introduced into the country.

FIHC owns the Grand Formosa Regent hotel in Taipei, which is rated one of the world's best operated hotels. Pan said that was the major reason why FIHC was picked by Carlson to manage the brand from among 20 bidders.

The acquisition includes the sale of the global Regent brand and all associated intellectual property, the hotel management and lease contracts for properties in operation and under development, and the Regent Seven Seas Cruises license, FIHC said in a statement.

Pan said he is determined to develop "Regent" into a diverse business that encompasses the finest hotels, upscale residential property and exquisite shopping malls in prime urban and resort locations.
To further polish the image of "Regent," Pan said he plans to set up a global business operations hub in Taipei and recruit the brightest talent to join his group.
He vowed to return the brand to the world's leading cities, including Tokyo, Shanghai, New York, London, Paris and Sydney.
Regent currently owns 17 hotels in Europe, Asia, America and the Middle East, some of which are still under construction.

DOC.HEADLINE: Taiwan sees first indigenous German measles case this year
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, April 16 (CNA) 04/16/10 23:34:32 (By Chen Li-ting and Lilian Wu)

TEXT.P: A 21-year-old foreign worker from Vietnam has become Taiwan's first patient with an indigenous case of German measles this year, the Department of Health announced Friday.
The individual, who currently works in Gueishan Township in Taoyuan County, came down with a fever, rashes, a runny nose and red eyes on April 4, the DOH's Centers for Disease Control (CDC) said.

The victim, who has not traveled overseas recently, was admitted to the hospital for treatment and later released. The 28 people he had contact with have not shown any suspicious symptoms so far, but the CDC said it will continue to keep track of them.

The CDC reported the first imported measles cases this year on April 7 -- a 26 -year-old woman and her 15-month-old daughter in Kaohsiung County. They developed the disease after visiting relatives in Vietnam from January 26 to March 23.
Taiwan has had 110 German measles cases over the past three years, of which 19 were imported (six from Vietnam) and the balance originated in Taiwan.

DOC.HEADLINE: Children susceptible to household infection of H1N1: NTU
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, April 16 (CNA) 04/16/10 23:41:21 (By Chen Li-ting and Sofia Wu)

TEXT.P: Young children are highly susceptible to influenza A (H1N1) if any family member is infected with the virus, a pediatrician at National Taiwan University (NTU) Hospital said Friday.

Speaking at the annual conference of the Asian Society for Pediatric Research (ASPR) , Chang Luan-ying said the average H1N1 infection rate within households was 27 percent, but the ratio reached an average of 61 percent among children.
Chang said her report was based on the findings of a study on 87 local families with a total of 310 members.
Citing the findings, Chang said that if an H1N1 patient was living with four family members, one was likely to come down with the virus.
While the within-family infection rate was 15 percent among adults, the percentage for children was more than four times that figure, Chang said.

"Children were not only more vulnerable to H1N1 infection than adults but also more susceptible to complications, " said Chang, who argued that children, particularly pre-schoolers, should be put on the priority list for immunization.

According to Chang, NTU Hospital's pediatrics department accepted 61 patients with severe H1N1 symptoms who needed hospitalization and 47 of them were discharged after recovery. The remaining 14 had to stay at intensive care wards or died.
"Our statistics show that 21 percent of H1N1 child patients needed to be hospitalized and their average mortality rate was about 5 percent," she added.

DOC.HEADLINE: Meiji University looks to Taiwan for top students
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, April 16 (CNA) 04/16/10 23:48:11 (By Lin Szu-yu and Y.L. Kao)

TEXT.P: Representatives from Japan's Meiji University visited the College Entrance Examination Center last month to ask about the feasibility of using local proficiency test scores as the basis for admitting Taiwanese students, a spokesman for the center said Friday.

Taiwan was the third stop of the Japanese delegation's trip, which also took them to South Korea and China, aimed at recruiting senior high school students with outstanding academic performances, according to the spokesman.

The university representatives tried to gain a better understanding of whether the proficiency test scores can adequately reflect students' true proficiency and can be used to simplify the Japanese university's admissions process for Taiwanese students, the spokesman said.

The scholastic aptitude test only covers the first two years of Taiwan's high school curriculum and courses. They had hoped that there was a test in Taiwan covering all the courses offered at senior high schools, the spokesman noted.
Japan, Hong Kong and China are all planning to open their universities to recruit top Taiwanese high school graduates.
Approximately 1,000 Taiwanese obtain visas to study in Japan every year, with 60 percent of them studying for a bachelor's degree there, according to statistics compiled by the Ministry of Education.
Japan presently hosts about 120,000 foreign students and launched a program last year that hopes to increase the number of foreign students in Japan to 300,000 by 2020.
Meiji University ranks among the top six universities in Tokyo, trailing only behind Tokyo University, Waseda University and Keio University.

DOC.HEADLINE: Today in history
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, April 17 (CNA) 04/17/10 10:08:51
DOC.TEXT:
Today is Saturday, April 17, 2010, or the fourth day of the third month of the Year of the Tiger according to the lunar calendar. Following is a list of important events that have occurred on this date in the past:
1421: More than 100,000 people drown when the sea breaks through a dike in Dort, Holland.
1790: American public official, writer, scientist, and printer Benjamin Franklin dies at the age of 84. He played a major part in the American Revolution, negotiated French support for the colonies, signed the Treaty of Paris and helped draft the US Constitution.
1824: The United States and Russia define respective rights in the Pacific Ocean and on the northwest coast of America.
1894: Nikita S. Krushchev, Soviet politician, is born. As Soviet leader he denounced Stalin and thwarted the Hungarian Revolution of 1956. He was deposed in 1964 for his failure to improve the Soviet economy.
1895: The Treaty of Shimonoseki is signed, compelling the Ching court to pay a huge indemnity, open its seaports, recognize the independence of Korea, and cede the Liaoning Peninsula, Taiwan and the Pescadores to Japan.
1897: During a revolt in Ottoman-held Crete, war breaks out between Greece and the Ottoman Empire.
1906: A Pacific cable between China and the United States is completed.
1938: Chang Kuo-dao, governor of the Chinese communist government that controls the region comprising Shensi, Kansu and Ningsia issues a statement in Hankou distancing himself from the Chinese Communist Party.
1941: U.S. President Franklin D. Roosevelt approves initial military aid US$45 million for China.
1946: Communist troops enter Changchun, Kirin Province, in northeastern China.
1950: The Chinese Women's Anti-Aggression League is formally inaugurated.
1964: The ROC Ministry of Foreign Affairs issues a statement severing diplomatic relations with The Congo.
1968: U.S. President Lyndon B. Johnson meets with South Korean President Park Chung Hee in Honolulu, pledging U.S. protection for noncommunist Asia.
1971: Egypt, Syria and Libya sign an agreement to form a confederation.
1971: East Pakistanis declare their homeland an independent nation which they rename Bangladesh. Sheik Mujibur Rahman serves as the nation's first prime minister.
1973: President Lon Nol of Cambodia announces the resignation of his Cabinet.
1980: The International Monetary Fund (IMF) accepts mainland China as a member, and the Republic of China is forced to pull out of the organization.
1989: The Mainland Affairs Council passes a proposal to allow teachers and staff of public schools to travel to the Chinese mainland for family visits.
1992: Legislative proceedings are completed for the National Employment Act, which is to serve as the basis for employment of foreign nationals in the Republic of China.
1994: Mainland China's public security unit announces it has solved a criminal case in which 24 Taiwan tourists were killed at Qiandao Lake on March 31, 1994.
1995: Fire breaks out at a KTV on Hankou Street in Taipei, killing 12 people and seriously injuring 14 others.
1996: U.S. President Bill Clinton signs a joint declaration on security cooperation with Japanese Prime Minister Ryutaro Hashimoto pledging to maintain American military levels in Japan and elsewhere in Asia.
1999: An ROC humanitarian relief delegation returns to Taipei after a visit to Macedonia to express concern and offer assistance to ethnic Albanian refugees from neighboring war-torn Yugoslav province of Kosovo.
2000: The Year 2000 Trend Setting & Technology Conference is held in Taipei with more than 100 experts and industrialists from home and abroad participating.
2000: The Republic of China Finance Ministry allows two local insurance companies to set up offices in mainland China, marking the first mainland foray for the island's insurance industry.
2001: The Taipei Bank is chosen over four other hopefuls by the Ministry of Finance (MOF) to issue both traditional and computerized charity lotteries.
Confucius' lesson of the day: "A wise man is ashamed to say much; he prefers to do more."

DOC.HEADLINE: Taiwan headline news
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, April 17 (CNA) 04/17/10 12:11:13

DOC.HEADLINE: United Daily News: Ma risks alienating finance staff

TEXT.P: Wavering policies and disrespect for professionalism by the administration of President Ma Ying-jeou, as demonstrated in its dealing with the industrial innovation bill, will alienate and hollow out his economic and finance talent pool.

When the bill was being discussed by the Cabinet's Tax Reform Committee last October, the committee members agreed on a version that would lower the corporate income tax rate to 20 percent and keep four types of tax breaks. However, after the bill reached the Legislative Yuan, this version was discarded amid noise by lawmakers and business representatives.

Of all the finance and economic officials in the Cabinet, there are probably none who would brace up and defend their own policies. These officials lack any core ideas and policy directions and comply with whatever instructions come from above. This is where the Ma administration's crisis lies.
The president's financial and economic advisory council is also to blame for Taiwan's present financial and economic problems, because there are serious flaws in both its composition and operation.

Around one-third of the members in the council are linked to the business sector, with the result that almost all economic and financial policies lean toward the sector. In meetings, the members often come to conclusions after only brief discussion. How reckless the policy-making method is. (April 17, 2010)

DOC.HEADLINE: MOEA to expand distribution of distinctive local products
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, April 17 (CNA) 04/17/10 14:51:04 (By Lin Huei-chun and Lilian Wu)

TEXT.P: The Ministry of Economic Affairs (MOEA) will push to expand the distribution network for products specific to localities in the latter half of the year, an economics official said Saturday.

Lin Mei-hsueh, deputy director general of the Small and Medium Enterprise Administration (SMEA) under the ministry, said that adopting the local marketing concept of "One Town One Product" (OTOP) from Japan, the SMEA started from 1989 to help stimulate distinctive local industry by integrating local resources and their specialties.
The government wants to develop industries that have rich historical, cultural and distinctive features that local people are proud of, Lin said.

But currently the display and distribution network for these types of products is limited to places such as the Taiwan High Speed Rail's Chiayi Station, Nantou's scenic Sun Moon Lake resort and the Dream Mall in Kaohsiung.
Lin noted that 70 percent of the products are agriculture produce or area specialities, with the local governments deciding on the display and distribution network.
"To expand the distribution, the SMEA is planning to push for its own distribution networks in the latter half of the year," Lin said.

DOC.HEADLINE: Cell phone shipments to reach nearly 1.6 billion units: TRI
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, April 17 (CNA) 04/17/10 14:52:15 (By Tsai Su-jung and Fanny Liu)

TEXT.P: The shipment of global mobile phones in 2010 is expected to grow by about 12 percent to nearly 1.59 billion units due to increased demand in emerging markets, the Taiwan-based Topology Research Institute (TRI) forecast Saturday.
According to the private think tank, handset shipment growth will be driven largely by key emerging markets such as India and China.

The number of mobile phone users in India is expected to increase from 400 million at present to over 700 million in 2012 -- boosted by telecom tax changes and liberalization measures, the TRI said. China's effort to promote 3G services is also expected to substantially increase its mobile phone shipments.
Hsieh Yu-shan, an analyst at the TRI, said that 2010 will be the year of the smartphone, adding that a sharp growth in sales is expected to begin from Q2.
The global smartphone penetration rate, which was 13 to 15 percent in 2009, is expected to reach 18 to 20 percent this year, and 25 to 28 percent next year, Hsieh said.

Although global cell phone shipments have continued to increase, shipments and market percentage of mobile phones from Taiwanese manufacturers have been decreasing over the past few years, the TRI said.
The shipment of Taiwanese mobile phones is expected to drop to 56 million units this year, compared to 59.7 million units in 2009 and 89 million in 2008, it said.
The percentage of Taiwanese mobile phones among global shipments is expected to decrease to 3.5 percent this year, compared to 4.2 percent in 2009 and 6.6 percent in 2008, it added.

Hsieh said, however, that shrinking shipments of Taiwanese mobile phones may not be necessarily negative, because most Taiwanese manufacturers were trying to reposition themselves and move toward producing more high-end mobile phones.
If Taiwanese cell phone manufacturers only focus on shipment and revenue numbers, their gross profit margins will continue to drop, she added.

DOC.HEADLINE: Taiwan players dream of hitting the hardwood in China
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, April 17 (CNA) 04/17/10 16:03:27 (By Chris Wang)

TEXT.P: Despite limited success, most Taiwanese basketball players who opted to play in China said they didn't regret the decision, which may have alienated them from local basketball but is symbolic and meaningful for their careers.

An all-time high of five players left their teams in the local professional Super Basketball League (SBL) last year to play in the Chinese Basketball Association (CBA) . They said the CBA, a growing league of 17 teams, offers higher salaries and better competition.

Local players wouldn't have left if the basketball environment was better in Taiwan, said Lin Chih-chieh, formerly one of the most popular players in Taiwan and a national team regular who spent last season with the China's Zhejiang Lions.
Despite its spot as the second most popular sport after baseball, professional basketball in Taiwan is still said to lack the planning, organization and vision necessary for the game to develop.

In its seventh year, the average attendance at SBL games is under 1,000. Lacking sponsors and advertisers, the majority of team revenues comes from television broadcast fees. The league didn't allow foreign players until its fifth year and at one point considered a monthly salary maximum of NT$120,000 (US$3,826) per player so that teams could keep their budgets down.
Discontented with the current status and unknown future of the league, players started to look for a way out.

Playing in China was an easy and natural answer because of the common language and culture, as well as the fact the Chinese league blossomed in recent years as the country's economic power rose, Lin said. The CBA is now capable of hiring active National Basketball Association (NBA) players, such as former New York Knicks guard Stephon Marbury.

And there are other Taiwanese players in China. Chen Hsin-an played for the Dongguan Leopards in Guangdong province and Yen Hsin-shu played for the Shanghai Sharks last season, and Hsu Hao-cheng and Lin Kwan-lun both joined Shanxi Zhongyu this year.

It was not the first time domestic basketball lost talent to China. Cheng Chih- lung was the first Taiwanese player in the CBA when he signed with the Shanghai Sharks in 1999, joining current Houston Rockets center Yao Ming in 1999. The Sina Lions became the first Taiwanese team to play in the Chinese league in 2002-2003.

While thousands of American players earn a living by playing overseas, it's unusual for foreign teams to show interest in Taiwanese players. Playing overseas is seen as proof of a local player's skill and talent.

Lin was reportedly paid US$15,000 monthly plus incentives -- about four times what he made in Taiwan. Chen Hsin-an signed a two-year contract for an annual salary of US$340,000, and even second-string player Lin Kuan-lun was signed for US$8,000 a month.

However, part of the Taiwanese players' "China Dream" was not what they had imagined. Although Lin played an important role in Zhejiang, cracking the starting lineup and averaging 11.7 points and four rebounds per game, as well as leading the team to the semifinal, none of the other four played more than 10 minutes per game.
It's disappointing to get big paychecks but sit on the bench, media quoted Chen as saying.

For Lin, he said the training and playing style in Taiwan and China are very different and that he had learned a lot. Most of all, he said, the facilities and treatment of players are much better in China. Every team hires a weightlifting coach, he said.
"You have to do everything yourself in Taiwan, " he said, adding that he will play in China again next season and encouraging aspiring Taiwanese players to do the same.
Lin said that players have to learn to take care of themselves because their careers are short and the local league is not going anywhere.
One staff member from a local team agreed that when it came to money, Taiwan just couldn't compete.

"Of course we would like to keep our players on the team, but the salary the Chinese league is offering is just crazy and we couldn't possibly match that, " said a team representative who declined to be identified.
"I really don't think these players help their careers or skills with such miserable playing time in the games, but they sure make a lot more money," he said.

DOC.HEADLINE: Talk of the day -- Legislature passes innovation bill

TEXT.P: The Legislative Yuan passed a controversial draft Statute to Encourage Industrial Innovation late Friday after a marathon debate between lawmakers of the ruling Kuomintang (KMT) and opposition Democratic Progressive Party (DPP).

The bill was designed to pave the way for Taiwan to become a global innovation hub, in keeping with President Ma Ying-jeou's goals and Premier Wu Den-yih's directive for more attention to be given to small- and medium-sized enterprises (SMEs) and to job creation.
Wu thanked Legislative Yuan President Wang Jin-pyng later Friday for the legislature's support of the bill that aims to benefit both large and small businesses.

Although the bill passed in the legislature is different from the original version submitted by the Executive Yuan, Wu said he is quite satisfied with the new law that will replace the decades-old Statute for Industrial Upgrading and help reinvigorate Taiwan's industrial sector.
The following are excerpts from local media coverage of the issue:
China Times:
President Ma hailed the passage of the bill, saying the government is sticking firmly to its central idea of opening Taiwan to the world.

According to Ma, the industrial innovation law and a planned Taiwan-China economic cooperation framework agreement (ECFA) will be the two key strategic tools to help enhance Taiwan's innovation and competitiveness.

The law will allow the government to create a fund to provide capital and technology assistance to companies. But of the four tax incentive proposals originally put forth, only one concerning a 10-year tax deduction for business innovation was retained in the bill.
The legislature will vote next Tuesday on the KMT's proposed 17 percent corporate income tax rate, which will require an amendment to the Income Tax Act.
However, some critics have said that lowering the corporate income tax from 20 percent to 17 percent will hurt the government's finances.

Wang Lee-rong, director of the Center for Economic Forecasting of the Chung-Hua Institute for Economic Research (CIER), warned that the tax cut will lead to a shortfall of NT$34.3 billion (US$1.1 billion) in government revenue.
In response, KMT Legislator Lai Shyh-bao said the KMT caucus has proposed raising the tax rate on companies' undistributed earnings from 10 percent to 15 percent. (April 17, 2010)
United Daily News:

Acer Inc. Chairman C. T. Wang on Friday expressed support for the proposal to lower the corporate income tax to 17 percent. "This would help boost Taiwan's economic development over the next 10 years, " he said.

Lin Ping-pin, chairman of the National Association of Small and Medium Enterprises, called for a speedy revision of the Income Tax Act to drop the corporate income tax to 17 percent, or to 17.5 percent as proposed by the opposition Democratic Progressive Party.

Huang Ming-ho, general manager of Victor Taichung Machinery, called the proposal "belated justice, " saying that traditional businesses have always been taxed 25 percent, in contrast to the almost zero income tax rate for high-tech firms. "This would help us to significantly improve our profits," he said. (April 17, 2010)
The Liberty Times:
Some academics have criticized the clause in the innovation bill that allows small companies to receive government subsidies for hiring additional workers.
The bill is meant to help companies sharpen their competitiveness and create jobs for the public, not to increase jobs by offering government subsidies, Taiwan Thinktank Chairman Chen Po-chih said.

Economics Minister Shih Yen-shiang stressed Friday that the revisions to 27 sub- legislations related to the innovation bill will be completed within three months of the bill's promulgation, which he said will help spur the upgrade and transformation of Taiwan businesses.
KMT caucus whip Lin Hung-chih predicted that the bill will help to expand Taiwan's GDP by NT$69 billion. (April 17, 2010)

DOC.HEADLINE: Apple Daily: Hospital disgraces memory of its founder

TEXT.P: It is extremely shameful that Kaohsiung Medical University Hospital became involved in a case of National Health Insurance (NHI) fraud, which resulted in the hospital being fined NT$150 million.
We cannot help but feel sorrow on behalf of the hospital's late founder, Tu Tsung-ming, a stickler for integrity and ethics, whose memory has now been tarnished by those who suceeded him.

According a biography of Tu written by Yang Yu-ling, Tu (1893-1986) devoted his entire life to upgrading the quality of the medical profession in Taiwan. He was the first Taiwan citizen to hold a PhD, which he earned at the University of Tokyo.

In 1954, he established the Kaohsiung Medical College -- the forerunner of the university -- and introduced an honor system under which students who cheated in exams were flunked. Tu said he was profoundly influenced by the moral education he received from his elementary school principal, who thought the value of an individual was determined by his or her moral character, not erudition.

Despite having such a great founder, the university has turned out skilled doctors who nonetheless lack any sense of shame. Regardless of whether the problem lies in the NHI system or the university's education system, the fact remains that the university has betrayed the purpose of Tu's establishment of the school in the first place. (April 17, 2010)

DOC.HEADLINE: Taiwan students need to study abroad: official
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, April 17 (CNA) 04/17/10 16:52:56 (By Lin Huei-chun and Elizabeth Hsu)

TEXT.P: The number of Taiwanese students applying for visas to study abroad remained between 32,000 and 37,000 annually from 2004 to 2008, despite a growing number of graduates, an official at the Cabinet-level National Science Council (NSC) said Saturday.
According to Ministry of Education statistics, the accumulated number of graduates with a bachelor's or master's degree in Taiwan rose from around 253,000 people in 2004 to more than 285,000 in 2008.
The figures suggest a drop in the percentage of graduates seeking advanced education abroad, said Chang Ching-ray, director general of the NSC'S Department of International Cooperation.
Moreover, department researchers found that in recent years, more and more graduates went abroad for short-term language courses only, instead of acquiring an academic degree, Chang noted.
Most graduates stayed in Taiwan for higher education, he said.
Amid globalization, Taiwan needs a pool of talent with international vision, Chang said, adding that local young people need to be encouraged to study abroad.

To achieve that goal, the NSC has prepared various subsidy programs, including an academic exchange plan with the German Academic Exchange Service, under which Taiwan sends up to 30 Ph.D. candidates to Germany every year for research visits, Chang said.

DOC.HEADLINE: China Times: Torturing students is not 'education'

TEXT.P: Over the past month, there have been two reported incidents of school children being given heavy slaps in the face by their teachers. In both cases, some parents sided with the teachers, indirectly condoning that type of torture as punishment.

In the process of educating children, there certainly must be a system of reward and punishment. However, punishment must be for the purpose of protecting children and stimulating their mental growth.

Therefore, we can hardly agree that a teacher who hit a 10-year-old girl should be awarded a medal for "excellence" in the performance of duty. We cannot comprehend why a teacher has to give a student more than 10 slaps in the face to help the student learn.

The pressure of competition is gradually distorting education in our schools, turning them into simulated battlegrounds where students are not allowed to get a single answer wrong because every point counts. And a minority of parents are encouraging this trend.

If education authorities do not work toward education quality control, we are afraid this will become a contentious issue in the year-end mayoral elections in the five special municipalities. (April 17, 2010)

DOC.HEADLINE: ECFA helps Taiwan reach out to world: president
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, April 16 (CNA) 04/17/10 17:11:25 (By Sunrise Huang, Lee Ming-chung and Lilian Wu)

TEXT.P: President Ma Ying-jeou said Saturday that a trade pact with China is a global economic strategy to help Taiwan reach out to the world.

"The signing of the cross-strait economic cooperation framework agreement (ECFA) is only the first step, " the president said. "The deal will help Taiwan sign trade pacts with other countries and further reduce cross-strait tension."
Ma said that all Taiwan's regional rivals have signed major free trade agreements over the past decade, resulting in the marginalization of Taiwan.
Taiwan, whose lifeline depends on exports, has seen its global market share gradually decline, he said. If it fails to do something, exports will face a grave situation, he added.
"If we close the door, we will wither. We can only have hope if we open up," the president said.

The ECFA is a steppingstone for Taiwan to take part in the economic activities of East Asia, he continued, adding that closer economic cooperation with China will help Taiwan promote its relations with Japan and keep other countries from having to "take sides."
The president made the remarks at Xiulang Elementary School in Yonghe City, Taipei County, as part of his island-wide tour to drum up support for the trade pact.

Accompanying the president were Vice Premier Eric Liluan Chu, Minister of Economic Affairs Shih Yen-hsiang, and officials from the Council of Labor Affairs, Council of Agriculture and Mainland Affairs Council.

The president and other officials reaffirmed the principles for signing the ECFA: Help local people do business and allow no more than the current 1,000-plus Chinese agricultural products to enter Taiwan from China.

The government will also not allow Chinese laborers to enter the Taiwanese market, they said. It will solicit tariff concessions for Taiwan exports, protect the investment rights of Taiwan businesspeople and protect intellectual property rights.
Meanwhile, Vice President Vincent Siew said at a forum in Taipei Saturday that Taiwan cannot shut its door and allow its rivals to jockey for position in the Chinese market.
Siew echoed Ma's remarks, saying Taiwan could use the trade deal with China as a "steppingstone" to signing free trade agreements with other countries to avoid being marginalized.

DOC.HEADLINE: Taiwan 'chamber of commerce' in China elects new chair
DOC.DATELINE: Beijing, April 17 (CNA) 04/17/10 17:21:48 (By Chou Huei-ying and Elizabeth Hsu)

TEXT.P: Kuo Shan-huei, a former chairman of the Taiwan Businessmen Association Dongguan, was narrowly elected Saturday to head the Association of Taiwan Investment Enterprises on the Mainland -- seen as Taiwan's chamber of commerce in China.
Kuo defeated incumbent Chairman Chang Han-wen 101-100 after two rounds of voting. A total of 203 members were present.

Many voters described the three-candidate election as "intense." The third candidate, Lin Po-feng, lost in the first round of voting with 17 votes, while Chang received 96 and Kuo 89. A second round of voting was held because none of the competitors won more than half of the votes.

Kuo is the founder of the Lacquer Craft group, one of the world's largest wooden furniture makers. He was a vice chairman of the association of Taiwanese enterprises in China when it was established on April 16, 2007.
On Saturday, Kuo won a three-year term as chairman of the business group.

DOC.HEADLINE: President urges public to remain alert against influenza HIN1
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, April 17 (CNA) 04/17/10 17:51:44 (By Carfie Lee and Flor Wang)

TEXT.P: President Ma Ying-jeou called Saturday for the Taiwan public to remain alert against influenza HINI and he praised the Department of Health (DOH) for its work since the outbreak of the virus last year.
In conversation with Health Minsiter Yaung Chih-liang in the president's weekly online journal, Ma urged the public to stay on guard against the potentially fatal disease.
Yaung described the DOH's immunization efforts as the most important battle in Taiwan's public health history since the eruption of SARS in 2003.

"Among the 32 members (and observers) of the Organization for Economic Cooperation (OECD), Taiwan has the third-lowest H1N1-related mortality rate, which indicates that the country's medical treatment of the virus is one of the best in the world, " Yaung said.
This can be attributed to the fast flow of information in Taiwan and to a sound public health network facilitated by the National Health Insurance system, Yaung added.
According to Yaung, Taiwan's 70 percent H1N1 immunization rate among school children is also the highest in the world.

Although an H1N1 command center was temporarily dismantled by the DOH in late February after 303 days of operation, the president said, the public should not let down its guard against the virus as it might stage a comeback this year.

DOC.HEADLINE: Government finances face serious shortfall: experts
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, April 17 (CNA) 04/17/10 18:03:13 (By Hsieh Chun-wei and Fanny Liu)

TEXT.P: After the disputed Statute to Encourage Industrial Innovation passed the Legislative Yuan late Friday, the government needs to propose supplementary measures to improve its financial shortfall, experts said Saturday.

The hotly debated corporate income tax rate was not included in the statute, but will be screened by legislators April 20 after the ruling Kuomintang (KMT) caucus submits a proposal to cut the rate from 20 percent to 17 percent.

According to the Ministry of Finance, if the corporate income tax rate is slashed to 17 percent under the new law -- which aims to provide subsidies to business and industry for innovation -- it could create a shortfall of NT$34.3 billion in government revenue.
Wu Chung-shu, the dean of National Dong Hwa University's College of Management in Hualien, said that in the long run, the government needs to raise some tax rates to make up for the shortfall.
Wu pointed out that Taiwan's existing value-added tax rate is 5 percent, substantially lower than the more than 10 percent tax rate in most other countries.
While tax breaks will hurt the government's revenue, the aging population and the high dependency ratio will continue to increase government debt, Wu said.
Wang Lee-rong, director of the Chung-Hua Institute for Economic Research's (CIER's) Center for Economic Forecasting, also warned that the tax cut would make the government's financial burden heavier.

The CIER estimated that Taiwan's economic growth this year will contract by 0.91 percentage points, falling from a projected growth rate of 4.99 percent to 4.08 percent, if the government were to slash public investment to balance its finances.

However, Wang said that the forecast appeared to be conservative as it did not calculate potential impact from a planned Taiwan-China economic cooperation framework agreement (ECFA) and the appreciation of the Chinese yuan.
Meanwhile, opposition Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) Chairperson Tsai Ing-wen said Saturday that the innovation law would only increase -- instead of reduce -- the government's financial burden.

DOC.HEADLINE: Taiwan-based diplomats help turn 'trash' to 'gold'
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, April 17 (CNA) 04/17/10 18:28:00 (By Alex Jiang & Fanny Liu)

TEXT.P: A dozen foreign diplomats and their family members volunteered at a recycling activity organized by the Buddhist Compassion Relief Tzu Chi Foundation in Taipei Saturday.

At a recycling station in a suburban area in Neihu, the eco-friendly envoys from Taiwan's diplomatic allies in Central America and elsewhere were shown how to use plastic bottles to make blankets, scarves or polo shirts. They then helped with packaging or giving the products a final touch, like ironing labels onto the blankets.
The event, organized by the foundation, was held to celebrate the upcoming Earth Day on April 22.
The diplomats later spent an hour separating used plastic bags and taking apart discarded VHS tapes to pick out valuable components.
"We don't call this 'trash.' We call it 'gold' that will turn into 'love,'" said Wang Ming-li, a foundation member.
However, she said, it is a pity that because people think plastic bottles are easily recyclable, they use too many of them.
Wang said several senior citizens help out at the station regularly just to do a good turn. "One man who had a stroke comes here every day for rehabilitation," she added.
Njabuliso Gwebu, the Taipei-based ambassador of Swaziland, described the activity as "educational."
Touching one of the blankets, Ruby Caines, a relative of the ambassador from St. Kitts and Nevis, said, "It's so soft. I couldn't believe this."
"What Tzu Chi is doing is recycling and at the same time, they are helping the needy and poor people in the world, " said Efrain Novelo, Belize's ambassador in Taiwan.
"Today is the time to save the Earth, not tomorrow," he said.
Tzu Chi has given away more than 250,000 such blankets to homeless people, poor people or disaster victims in 20 countries since the foundation unveiled the blanket in 2006.
It takes 70 to 80 600cc plastic bottles to make a blanket that is 230 centimeters by 180 centimeters.
The foundation has 4,500 recycling stations around the country and 70,000 volunteers.
Around 200 groups from Spain, the United States, Thailand, Indonesia, Singapore, the Philippines and other countries visited the recycling station in Neihu in 2009.
"They don't just come from different countries, but also from different religions to learn about Tzu Chi's recycling efforts, " foundation member Lin Cheng-yuan said.

DOC.HEADLINE: Ash from Iceland volcano unlikely to reach Taiwan: meteorologist
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, April 17 (CNA) 04/17/10 18:34:47 (By Wang Shu-fen and Elizabeth Hsu)

TEXT.P: The clouds of ash from a volcano in Iceland, which have drifted into the skies over northern Europe and caused the grounding of many flights in that area, are unlikely to reach Taiwan, an official of Taiwan's Central Weather Bureau said Saturday.
Chen Ming-tien, director of the bureau's Weather Forecast Center, said the plume of ash thrown up by a volcanic eruption in Iceland was six kilometers high, but "it was not huge in terms of volume."
Most of the ash would remain in the troposphere and the grit would decrease as the plume of ash spreads out, he said.
Chen also predicted that the volcanic ash will not affect the global weather. To cause such a big impact, an eruption would have to send ash more than 10 km into the air, he said.

In 1991, the ash cloud from the eruption of Mount Pinatubo in the Philippines rose 15 km. Citing research results, Chen said thick drifts of ash from that eruption were found to have blocked the sun's rays, causing an average 0.5 degrees Celsius drop in global temperatures.

DOC.HEADLINE: Former DPP chair releases book on Kaohsiung Incident trials
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, April 17 (CNA) 04/17/10 18:50:05 (By Hung huang-chun and Y.F. Low)

TEXT.P: Shih Ming-teh, a former chairman of the opposition Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) , released a book Saturday that recalls the trials of opposition activists following the 1979 Kaohsiung Incident.

The book is intended to mark the 30th anniversary of the nine-day military-court trial, in which he was one of the defendants. Shih held the book-launching event at the Jing-Mei Human Rights Memorial and Cultural Park in Sindian, Taipei County -- the original site of the "first tribunal" where the trials took place.
"I never thought that I would revisit the trial scene alive, " said Shih, who was jailed for 10 years after being convicted of sedition for the Kaohsiung Incident.

Shih said the purpose of the book is to clarify the historical truth regarding the trials. He said he feels very sad about the current situation in Taiwan, which he described as "having no sense of right and wrong, no truth and no justice."

He called on politicians in the country to show ideals, a sense of mission and an ability to self-reflect, adding that they should tell their supporters exactly what they are leading the country toward.

Also known as the Formosa Incident, the Kaohsiung Incident took place on Dec. 10, 1979, when a group of opposition activists held a demonstration on Human Rights Day in the southern port city to demand democracy in Taiwan.
The Kuomintang (KMT) government cracked down on the protest and arrested many of the participants.

In the years following the incident, pressure grew on the KMT government to lift martial law and bans on the establishment of new political parties and newspapers, leading to the country's democratization.

DOC.HEADLINE: President sells innovation bill, cross-strait trade pact
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, April 17 (CNA) 04/17/10 19:45:45 (By S. P. Yeh and Flor Wang)

TEXT.P: The new industrial innovation bill and a planned cross-Taiwan Strait trade pact are "injections" needed to transform Taiwan into a regional commercial hub, President Ma Ying-jeou said Saturday.

Stressing that "opening Taiwan to the world" is the focus of the government's economic policy, the president said the bill and the Taiwan-China economic cooperation framework agreement (ECFA) are strategic tools to upgrade Taiwan's economy.
"Taiwan companies can make big money if they reach out, like the Won Won and Master Kang groups," he said.
He pledged to allow the Legislative Yuan to closely scrutinize the ECFA before it is signed.
Ma made the remarks in a meeting with Taipei County residents to explain the importance of the newly passed Statute to Encourage Industrial Innovation and the proposed ECFA with China.
However, the president said, local companies also need to go international as part of the globalization effort. "We must not rely solely on the China market," he stressed.
Meanwhile, Vice President Vicente Siew said Taiwan products need to be innovative and to be sold with added value in more markets.

"The passage of the industrial innovation bill means that Taiwan's economic development will enter a new era over the next 10 to 20 years, " he said. "The ECFA will be next, as Taiwan-made products will need an institutionalized mechanism to avoid risks in the Chinese market."
With other countries striving to seize a greater share of the Chinese market, Taiwan cannot continue with its closed door policy, he said.
"The ECFA will serve as a steppingstone to Taiwan signing free trade agreements with other countries and will help to prevent its marginalization," he added.
But Tsai Ing-wen, chairwoman of the opposition Democratic Progressive Party which has been critical of the ECFA, panned the innovation bill, calling it a poor piece of legislation.
"It will not help to reduce the government's financial burden nor will it help companies to gain fair treatment by the government," she said.

The controversial Statute to Encourage Industrial Innovation was passed in the Legislative Yuan Friday. The law, along with the amendments to corporate tax statute to be scrutinized next week, will lower the corporate income tax rate from 20 percent to 17 percent for both traditional and hi-tech businesses. According to aresearch institute, the tax cut will result in a shortfall of NT$34.3 billion in government revenue.

DOC.HEADLINE: Taiwan seeks Indonesia's help to search for fishing boat
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, April 17 (CNA) 04/17/10 19:52:09 (By Lee Ming-chung and Fanny Liu)

TEXT.P: Taiwan has asked the Indonesian government to help search for a Taiwanese fishing boat that went missing Friday, an official of the Ministry of Foreign Affairs (MOFA) said Saturday.

The ministry has submitted a request, via the Indonesian Economic and Trade Office in Taipei, to help find the fishing vessel, and the MOFA will do its best to provide assistance, said MOFA spokesman Henry Chen.

According to the Liuchiu Fishermen's Association in southern Taiwan's Pingtung County, the Liuchiu-registered Chen Fu Hsiang 16 lost contact with Taiwan Friday afternoon while it heading toward eastern Malaysia and Indonesia.
The fishing vessel, which left Taiwan last September, has been operating in an area south of Sri Lanka in the Indian Ocean, the association said.

DOC.HEADLINE: Taiwan's Chan Yung-jan through to ITF finals
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, April 17 (CNA) 04/17/10 19:58:05 (By Oscar Wu and Elizabeth Hsu)

TEXT.P: Taiwanese professional tennis player Chan Yung-jan beat Junri Namigata of Japan 6-2 and 7-5 Saturday at the International Tennis Federation (ITF) women's tournament in Gimhae, South Korea to reach the finals.
It was the second time Chan and Namigata were facing off. Their first encounter was in Seoul in 2009 when Chan also defeated Namigata.
With her victory over the fourth-seeded Namigata at the ITF tournament, Chan has gone through to the finals.

Chan, ranked 91th in the world, is the top-seeded player in the ITF tournament that was opened on April 12 and will run through April 18. She is also the only player in the tournament who is on the world's top-100 list.

DOC.HEADLINE: U.S. beef tongues will be subject to rigorous checks: DOH
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, April 17 (CNA) 04/17/10 20:45:51 (By Chen Ching-fang, Yang Shu-min and Lilian Wu)

TEXT.P: The Department of Health (DOH) said Saturday that of all new U.S. beef products to be imported into Taiwan, tongues will be subject to the most rigorous inspections.
Kang Jaw-Jou, director general of the DOH's Food and Drug Administration, said that because of the higher risks associated with beef tongues, every carton of that product will be examined.

Kang made the remarks in response to an announcement Friday by the U.S. Department of Agriculture (USDA) that exports of beef products to Taiwan will include bones with meat, hanging tenders, tongues, penises, testicles, tails, tendons, and skirts (diaphragm) derived from cattle less than 30 months of age slaughtered on or after April 1.
Kang said that except for tongues, all other beef parts will be subject to 5 percent examination -- the same level as for U.S. bone-in beef that was allowed in earlier.
He said that the new beef parts meet Taiwan's law on food safety, and that Taiwan still maintains its ban on U.S. beef skulls, brains, eyes, spinal chords, ground beef, offal and related products.

The importers of U.S. beef parts, other than tongues, on the new list will be required to apply to the Ministry of Economic Affairs' Bureau of Foreign Trade for import permission, and the DOH will conduct the checks on the products.
The Consumers' Foundation demanded Saturday that the DOH and the Ministry of Foreign Affairs clearly explain whether allowing importation of the new U.S. beef products means offal will be included.
Chairman of the foundation Hsieh Tien-jen said he has reminded the DOH that the U.S. and Taiwan can review the beef protocol 180 days after it was signed.
Hsieh said that the USDA's latest announcement proves that the foundation's worries are not unwarranted.

Taiwan and the United States signed a protocol last October to allow the entry of bone-in beef and other beef products, including ground beef and offal, that had previously been banned out of concern over bovine spongiform encephalopathy (BSE), or mad cow disease.

But due to public outcry, the legislature amended the food safety law to effectively bar U.S.ground beef, beef offal and other beef parts such as the skull, eyes and intestines from access to Taiwan's markets.
Hsieh said that consumers should not let down their guard despite the legislature's action.
"In order to protect their own health, consumers should actively join a signature drive for a national referendum on reopening beef talks with the United States," Hsieh said.

DOC.HEADLINE: Largest-ever Hakka Tung flower festival kicks off
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, April 17 (CNA) 04/17/10 20:53:10 (By Chen Shu-feng and Lilian Wu)

TEXT.P: The largest ever Hakka Tung Blossom Festival kicked off in Miaoli, northern Taiwan Saturday, and is expected to attract one million visitors over the next month, according to its sponsor, the Council for Hakka Affairs.
Minister of the council Huang Yu-cheng officiated at a prayer ceremony at the start of the festival, using agricultural products such as ginger and sweet potatoes as offerings.
"With 36 Hakka townships in 11 cities and counties coming together to stage the Hakka Tung Blossom Festival this year, it will be the biggest ever," Huang said.

The month-long festival, featuring more than 800 Hakka cultural events and industrial activities, is expected to attract one million visitors and create business opportunities worth about NT$1 billion, Huang said.
The beauty of Hakka culture and the dynamism of the Hakka people will be portrayed through music and dance, according to Huang.

The Tung tree was one of the cash economic crops in Taiwan in earlier years, he noted, adding that because he grew up picking up the seeds under the trees, he has a special attachment to the Tung tree and the festival.

DOC.HEADLINE: Plans of 2,000 Taiwanese travelers affected by volcanic ash in Europe
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, April 17 (CNA) 04/17/10 21:17:22 (By Wang Shu-fen and Elizabeth Hsu)

TEXT.P: The travel plans of some 2,000 Taiwanese were affected as a hazardous cloud of volcanic ash from Iceland forced the closure of airports and the delay or cancellation of many flights in Europe, Taiwan tourism authorities said Saturday.

According to the Tourism Bureau under the Ministry of Transportation and Communications, 12 local travel agencies were affected by the chaos, while a total of 70 tour groups organized by the agencies were either stranded in Europe or could not proceed with their travel plans.

According to local travel agencies, tours to Europe have been popular since the beginning of the year, with a 30 percent increase in the number of tour groups recorded in the first few months compared to the same period last year. The tourists were mostly retired people and newly wedded couples, they added.
Most of the travel agencies affected by the volcanic eruption in Iceland said they could do nothing but face their losses because it was an unpredictable natural disaster.
Chen Shu-chuang of the Travel Quality Assurance Association acknowledged that although the tour packages were all insured, the payments would not be enough to cover the losses.

The insurance companies will pay only NT$2,000 a day for each traveler stranded in Europe, but the cost of food and accommodation there is more than NT$4,000 per person per day, he said. This means the travel agencies will have to meet the difference, he added.

DOC.HEADLINE: Taiwan seeks Indonesia's help to search for fishing boat
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, April 17 (CNA) 04/17/10 19:52:09 (By Lee Ming-chung and Fanny Liu)
