DOC.HEADLINE: Largest-ever Hakka Tung flower festival kicks off
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, April 17 (CNA) 04/17/10 20:53:10 (By Chen Shu-feng and Lilian Wu)

TEXT.P: The largest ever Hakka Tung Blossom Festival kicked off in Miaoli, northern Taiwan Saturday, and is expected to attract one million visitors over the next month, according to its sponsor, the Council for Hakka Affairs.
Minister of the council Huang Yu-cheng officiated at a prayer ceremony at the start of the festival, using agricultural products such as ginger and sweet potatoes as offerings.
"With 36 Hakka townships in 11 cities and counties coming together to stage the Hakka Tung Blossom Festival this year, it will be the biggest ever," Huang said.

The month-long festival, featuring more than 800 Hakka cultural events and industrial activities, is expected to attract one million visitors and create business opportunities worth about NT$1 billion, Huang said.
The beauty of Hakka culture and the dynamism of the Hakka people will be portrayed through music and dance, according to Huang.

The Tung tree was one of the cash economic crops in Taiwan in earlier years, he noted, adding that because he grew up picking up the seeds under the trees, he has a special attachment to the Tung tree and the festival.

DOC.HEADLINE: Plans of 2,000 Taiwanese travelers affected by volcanic ash in Europe
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, April 17 (CNA) 04/17/10 21:17:22 (By Wang Shu-fen and Elizabeth Hsu)

TEXT.P: The travel plans of some 2,000 Taiwanese were affected as a hazardous cloud of volcanic ash from Iceland forced the closure of airports and the delay or cancellation of many flights in Europe, Taiwan tourism authorities said Saturday.

According to the Tourism Bureau under the Ministry of Transportation and Communications, 12 local travel agencies were affected by the chaos, while a total of 70 tour groups organized by the agencies were either stranded in Europe or could not proceed with their travel plans.

According to local travel agencies, tours to Europe have been popular since the beginning of the year, with a 30 percent increase in the number of tour groups recorded in the first few months compared to the same period last year. The tourists were mostly retired people and newly wedded couples, they added.
Most of the travel agencies affected by the volcanic eruption in Iceland said they could do nothing but face their losses because it was an unpredictable natural disaster.
Chen Shu-chuang of the Travel Quality Assurance Association acknowledged that although the tour packages were all insured, the payments would not be enough to cover the losses.

The insurance companies will pay only NT$2,000 a day for each traveler stranded in Europe, but the cost of food and accommodation there is more than NT$4,000 per person per day, he said. This means the travel agencies will have to meet the difference, he added.

DOC.HEADLINE: Today in history
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, April 18 (CNA) 04/18/10 12:19:28
DOC.TEXT:
Today is Sunday, April 18, or the fifth day of the third month of the Year of the Tiger according to the lunar calendar. Following is a list of important events that have occurred on this date in the past:
1480: Lucrezia Borgia, the illegitimate daughter of Pope Alexander VI, is born in Italy. She was married three times by the age of 18 to further her father's political ambitions.
1906: An earthquake devastates San Francisco, killing more than 1,000 people and making 300,000 others homeless.
1925: The first world women's exposition is opened in Chicago.
1927: The national government is established in Nanking by the Kuomintang.
1933: Fighting spreads in northern China as several strategic passes along the Great Wall fall to the Japanese.
1942: Planes from a U.S. aircraft carrier bomb Tokyo for the first time. They were commanded by Lt. Gen. James Doolittle.
1943: Isoroku Yamamoto, a Japanese naval officer, is killed when his plane is shot down by U.S. warplanes over the Solomon Islands. He planned Japan's naval strategies during World War II, including the attack on Pearl Harbor in 1941.
1946: The League of Nations is formally dissolved.
1948: By a two-thirds majority, the first National Assembly approves temporary provisions granting emergency powers to the president during the ongoing anti- Communist campaign.
1949: The Republic of Ireland is formally proclaimed in Dublin.
1954: Gamal Abdel Nasser becomes prime minister of Egypt.
1955: Albert Einstein, the German-born American theoretical physicist who won a Nobel Prize in 1921 for his explanation of the photoelectric effect, dies at the age of 76. His specific and general theories of relativity revolutionized modern thought on the nature of space and time and formed a theoretical basis for the exploitation of atomic energy.
1968: Army officers in western Africa's Sierra Leone take over the government, dissolve the Legislature and suspend the constitution.
1977: A boat capsizes near Suao Port in eastern Taiwan, killing 32 college students and teachers on board and injuring 16 others.
1980: The former Rhodesia becomes independent Zimbabwe under President Canaan Banana.
1982: Monaco's Prince Rainier III and his wife, Princess Grace Kelly, arrive in Taipei for a visit.
1988: The Republic of China Red Cross Society begins forwarding mail from Taiwan residents to mainland China.
1989: The Mainland Affairs Council under the Executive Yuan decides to permit Taiwan citizens to gather news and make films in mainland China.
1998: Official talks between South and North Korea end with the two sides failing to resolve a dispute over aid to the starving North and the reunion of separated families.
1999: A GIO-produced documentary featuring the relationship between the year of one's birth and the 12 animals in the 12-year cycle of the Chinese calendar wins a gold medal at the Houston International Film Festival.
2000: Tainan-based National Cheng Kung University signs an academic cooperation contract with Japan's Kanazawa Industrial University.
2000: President Lee Teng-hui confers the Order of Brilliant Star with Grand Cordon on U.S. Senator Frank Murkowski (R-Alaska) for his contributions to promoting bilateral relations between the ROC and the United States.
2001: The Tainan District Court approves a prosecution request to hold Tainan City Mayor George Chang incommunicado over his alleged involvement in a governmental land-requisition scam.
Confucius' lesson of the day: "A wise and good man may be known in three ways which I am not able to show in my own person. As a moral man he is free from anxiety; as a man of understanding he is free from doubt; and as a man of courage he is free from fear."

DOC.HEADLINE: Taiwan headline news
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, April 18 (CNA) 04/18/10 14:47:23

DOC.HEADLINE: China Times: Gov't policy tested as '22K' nears expiry date
DOC.DATELINE: 04/18/10 15:27:03 (By Deborah Kuo)

TEXT.P: A government program, under which new university graduates working as interns at local companies are paid NT$22,000 a month, will expire soon after one year in operation. The expiration of the program, commonly known as the 22K program, will test the graduates' readiness to formally enter the job market and the success of the government's efforts to rev up employment.

Since last summer, a total of 46,000 university and college graduate have entered the internship program. Currently, 29,000 of them are still in the program, while the others have either found better jobs or quit for assorted reasons.

The government plans to launch a new 22K program on June 1 for another 30,000 new graduates. However, this time around, employers of the interns will be required to pay NT$12,000 of the NT$22,000 monthly salary and the government the other NT$10,000.

By offering immediate job opportunities to new graduates, the 22K program may have helped to reduce the country's unemployment rate, but we see it as more of an effort to delay the explosion of the unemployment rate, rather than a solution to the problem.

However, it would be unfair to deny the value of the program. At a time when most private companies were reluctant to hire new employees because of the global economic slump last year, the program served a three-pronged purpose -- benefiting the business sector, helping to reduce unemployment and allowing fresh graduates to acquire some work experience before embarking on their careers.
Nonetheless, before launching the new program, the government should assess whether it would be cost-efficient and not a waste of taxpayers' money and the graduates' time. (April 18, 2010).

DOC.HEADLINE: Taiwan medical team departs for China to help quake victims
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, April 18 (CNA) 04/18/10 16:16:31 (By Maubo Chang)

TEXT.P: A 20-member medical team assembled by the Red Cross Society of the Republic of China, departed for Xining, western China Sunday, to provide assistance to survivors of a deadly 7.1-magnitude earthquake that struck there April 14.

Chang Huan-chin, leader of the team and superintendent of Lishin Hospital in Pingzhen, Taoyuan County, said before his departure that his team consists of medical personnel from Taipei City Hospital, National Cheng Kung University Hospital in Taiwan City, and Lishin Hospital.

Chang, whose experience includes relief work in the wake of the Sept. 21, 1999 quake in central Taiwan, the earthquake of May 12, 2008 in Sichuan, western China and other disasters, said that his team is carrying 1,000 kg of medicines, which is the maximum allowed because of the limited airlift capacity in the disaster area.
Most of the medicine would be used for preliminary surgery, according to Chang.

Given that the disaster area is located at an altitude of 4,000 meters, Chang said, the weather will be a severe challenge for his team, although each member is equipped with up to 15 kg of gear that includes heavy coats and medicine for altitude sickness.
The medical team is expected to arrive in Xining, the capital of Qinghai Province, Sunday night, via Hong Kong and Beijing.
Meanwhile Cheng Zongliang, a spokesman for China's Red Cross Society in Beijing, expressed gratitude for the assistance offered by its Taiwan counterpart.
Cheng told China's Xinhua news agency that the Taiwan medical team will work in the disaster area for one week.

The 7.1-magnitude temblor that struck western China on April 14 has left 1,484 dead and more than 12,088 injured, according to Chinese authorities. The death toll is expected to climb, as 312 people are still unaccounted for and hopes of finding any more survivors are fading three days after the disaster.

DOC.HEADLINE: Talk of the day--Goldman Sachs case could slightly affect Taiex

TEXT.P: Following the accusations of fraud against Goldman Sachs by the U.S. Securities and Exchange Commission (SEC) which sent global stock markets plunging last Friday, financial shares on the local bourse are expected to lead the local stock market lower Monday, analysts predicted Sunday.

In addition, because foreign investors began selling Friday after the Taiex set a new high last week, the market is expected to correct itself on the first two days of the coming week, the analysts said.
However, a rebound is possible in the next few days because the fraud case is an isolated one and will have limited impact on the local bourse, according to the analysts.

The market could be boosted on the last few trading days of next week by bargain buying and by a legislative vote Tuesday on an amendment to the Corporate Income Tax Act designed to lower the corporate income tax rate to 17 percent, the analysts added.
The following are excerpts from local media coverage of the issue:
United Daily News:

The Taiwan stock market is expected to open lower Monday, reflecting the effects of fraud accusations against Wall Street giant Goldman Sachs, with financial shares likely to drop the most, analysts said.
U.S. stocks have plunged the steepest since February, as the SEC's accusations against Goldman Sachs Group Inc. have given rise to concern that the fallout from the financial crisis is not over.
Goldman Sachs shares plummeted 13 percent, the biggest drop in 15 months, after the SEC sued the company for misstating and omitting facts about collateralized debt obligations.
The charges have badly shaken global financial markets, even hitting the price of gold, oil and the currency markets.
If the fraud suit spurs selling, particularly among foreign institutional investors, it could be quite a challenge for Taiwan's stock market to remain above the 8,000-point mark, analysts said.

However, Chen Kuan-rong, chief of an asset management company, predicted that if the Goldman Sachs's fraud case is an isolated one, the local bourse would open lower Monday but there would be no long-term impact on the fundamentals of the market.
With the Taiex already reaching this year's high of around 8,100, if no new energy is brought into the market, the Taiex could pull back to between 7,600 and 7,800, he added. (April 18, 2010).
Economic Daily News:

Wu Zu-wang, a fund manager at Shin Kong Investment Trust Co., said while he does not expect the fraud case to heavily affect the Taiwan stock market, he thinks the fallout from a recent volcanic eruption in Iceland could expand.
The eruption has disrupted flights throughout Europe and sent shares in China Airlines and EVA air plummeting last Friday, Wu noted.
On the other hand, Wu said, China's bright economic outlook for the year could help bolster the local bourse.
World Expo 2010 Shanghai, the three-day Labor Day holiday and an appreciation of the Chinese yuan are factors that could affect the local market, Wu added.
Liu Kuan-hsi, general manager of Masterlink Securities Investment Advisory Corp., said that if the Taiex cannot remain above its monthly moving average of 7,992, that could spur selling pressure.
Because the volcano situation is uncertain, it is especially difficult to estimate its effects, which casts a shadow on stock markets around the world, he added. (April 18, 2010).

DOC.HEADLINE: Botulism infection confirmed as cause of woman's death
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, April 18 (CNA) 04/18/10 17:20:35 (By Chen Li-ting, Chiu Chun-chin and Deborah Kuo)

TEXT.P: The Centers for Disease Control (CDC) under the Department of Health confirmed Sunday that a woman who died April 14 after eating dried beancurd and preserved oysters had a botulism infection.

CDC Deputy Director Lin Ting said lab tests confirmed that the 44-year-old woman from Miaoli County had a botulism infection, which is usually caused by a nerve toxin produced by clostridium botulinum bacteria.
Several mice were injected with the woman's blood serum and they died within 24 hours, Lin added.
However, further lab tests will be required to determine what type of botulism caused the woman's death, he said.
It was also still not known whether it was the dried beancurd or the preserved oysters which the woman and her mother-in-law ate that caused the fatal botulism infection, Lin said.

The woman's 71-year-old mother-in-law has been on intubation at Taichung Veterans General Hospital in central Taiwan since she fell ill after eating the beancurd and oysters. Lab tests have confirmed that she also has a botulism infection. She has received two doses of botulismus-antitoxin that were rushed to the hospital by the CDC and which saved her life, according to Lin.

However, the daughter-in-law was not that lucky, as she was rushed to a different hospital in Taoyuan County, northern Taiwan which was not alert enough to seek emergency assistance from the CDC for the treatment of botulism, Lin said.

Samples of two packs of dried beancurd and a can of salted oysters that were found in the women's home in Miaoli were retrieved by the Food and Drug Administration for testing, but the lab reports will not be available for two weeks, the CDC said.

The two Miaoli women were the third and fourth botulism cases this year, following a mother and daughter in Taoyuan County who were diagnosed in early April, the CDC said. The Taoyuan mother and daughter were treated with botulismus-antitoxin.

Meanwhile, the Taoyuan County Public Health Bureau on Friday closed operations for two weeks at the two companies where the dried beancurd was made and ordered that the products be pulled from the shelves of major grocery stores.

However, the companies have complained of mistreatment, saying that their products were safe and were made in line with government standards. They complained that the two-week suspension will cost them hundreds of thousands of New Taiwan dollars.
"I hope the relevant tests will be completed soon so that my company's name can be cleared, " said Tseng Fan-Hsiang, owner of Cheng Hsiang Foods Co.
The latest incident has also resulted in declining business in Taoyuan County's Dasi township -- the center of dried beancurd production in Taiwan.
Huang Chien-chia, president of Tafang Foods, a well-established manufacturer of dried beancurd and related products in Dasi, said his store's business has shrunk by one-third this weekend.

Chiang Chiu-yun, the owner of another company known as Wan Li Hsiang which was established in 1921, said business at her store has also been affected by the incident, but added that her faithful customers were not at all fazed.

DOC.HEADLINE: Outstanding golfer looks forward to Taiwanese corporate sponsorship
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, April 18 (CNA) 04/18/10 18:52:13 (By Oscar Wu and Sofia Wu)

TEXT.P: The father of one of the world's top-ranking golfers, Yani Tseng of Taiwan, said Sunday his daughter is eager to gain the sponsorship of local companies.

Tseng Mao-hsin made the remarks while confirming that the Huabin Group in china has offered to sign a long-term sponsorship contract with his daughter, who vaulted into second place in the women's world golf rankings after she won the Kraft Nabisco Championship earlier this month.
The local Chinese-language daily China Times reported Sunday that the Huabin Group intends to sign a five-year, US$25 million sponsorship contract with the 21-year-old Taiwanese golfer.

Responding to the report, Tseng Mao-hsin said that as a Taiwanese citizen, his daughter would prefer to collaborate with Taiwanese business groups, but regrettably none of them have stepped forward so far.
Regarding the Huabin offer, Tseng Mao-hsin said the two sides are still discussing the details of the contract.
"We are not sure whether a sponsorship contract will eventually be signed, as we have not yet come to terms on certain details, " he said.
To be honest, Tseng Mao-shin, said the Huabin Group's offer is far from attractive because the contract will not cover Tseng Yani's travel costs to participate in LPGA tournaments.
"As a matter of fact, LPGA tours comprise the largest chunk of Yani's annual expenses... therefore, the Huabin offer is less than attractive in real terms," he said.

Another aspect that has to be considered is Huabin's demand that Yani Tseng terminate all other contracts with her existing sponsors of golf clubs, sunglasses, sportswear and relevant sports gear once she signs a deal with Huabin, her father said.
Apart from Huabin, he said, several brokerage agencies are also negotiating sponsorship contracts with his daughter.

Yani Tseng is scheduled to return to Taiwan April 25 when various sponsorship contract issues will be further discussed, he said. Aside from soaring up the world rankings, Yani Tseng catapulted to the top of other major lists by winning the April 4 Kraft Nabisco Championship in Rancho Mirage, California, the first major tournament of the season. Her US$300,000 first prize made her the leading prize money winner on the LPGA Tour after its first four events of the year.

The Huabin Group was founded by Yen Bin, a Thai-Chinese businessman. Over the past decades, the group has grown into a multinational enterprise in four major sectors, including consumer goods, modern service industries, sports, arts and culture and financial services and investments. The group has offices in many countries around the world.
Yen Bin ranks 10th on the Hurun Rich List, an annual list of the 100 wealthiest people in China.

DOC.HEADLINE: Taiwan composer breathes new life into traditional music

TEXT.P: In the musical world of Huang Chen-ming there are no limitations or boundaries. He sees no problem combining traditional Taiwanese and Chinese music with elements of Western rock, African music or Scottish folk songs.

Wang, the founder of the Chai Found Music Workshop, has set himself the goal of broadening the scope of traditional music and creating more opportunities for Taiwan musicians to play all over the world.
Since his return from the 2010 Winter Olympics in Vancouver, Canada earlier this year and a tour of several United States cities, Huang thinks he has been moving closer to this goal.
His life mission is to promote traditional music, he told the Central News Agency.
"I want to create limitless possibilities for traditional music and I hope more composers worldwide would join us," he said.
Since he established the music workshop 19 years ago, Huang has brought together a group of musicians that include pipa player Lin Hui-Kuan and di player Wu Chung-Hsien.

As the group's artistic director and composer, Huang uses traditional Chinese instruments as a central thematic element and has created a unique musical space that not only facilitates the performance of Sizhu music -- Chinese chamber music -- but also provides other composers with an inspirational platform for experimentation.

The group preserves traditional elements by fully exploiting the distinctive sounds of Eastern instruments, while also introducing light innovation into the genre of folk and world music. The aim is to create a groundbreaking expression of the diversity, vitality and richness of Taiwanese contemporary music, according to Huang.
He thinks that traditional music could encompass all kinds of experimentation. One of his latest concepts is that music should not only be heard, but also be seen.
With this in mind, he plans to incorporate tai-chi into his group's musical performances.
"All of our musicians will begin to learn tai-chi in May so that they can express that art form through music and with their bodies," he said.

As part of his efforts to expand the expression of traditional music, Huang last year held a composers' competition based on the theme of the ancient Chinese "five movements" philosophy which describes the interactions and relationships among five elements -- wood, water, earth, fire and metal.
The competition attracted many composers from the West and the East, eight of whom were chosen to present their works at a concert.
Huang is holding a similar competition this year, this time under the theme of yin-yang, which describes the interconnectedness and interdependency of seeming polar forces in the natural world.

"In this competition, we could see quite different and very creative works from Western and Eastern composers, which could also open another window for the enrichment of traditional music," Huang said.
The winning compositions will be presented at a concert in October, he added.

Over the years, Huang 's group has been invited to several international festivals such as the Barcelona Arts Festival in Spain in 1992, the Costa Rica Culture Festival in 1998, the Hoergaenge Contemporary Music Festival in Austria in 2000, the Cologne Music Festival in Germany 2001, the Huddersfield Contemporary Music Festival in England in 2004; and the Festival Dimension in Seoul, Korea in 2009.
"This year, we will have more opportunities to go abroad, to connect with other countries, including France where we will perform with musicians in Paris at the end of the year" Huang said.
"But this is also the year for training for a great future, " he added. CNA Photo 57 By Sunnie Chen CNA Staff reporter

DOC.HEADLINE: ECFA early harvest list to be drafted soon: official
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, April 18 (CNA) 04/18/10 19:41:57 (By Lin Su-yuan and Y.L. Kao)

TEXT.P: The third round of talks between Taiwan and China later this month on a proposed trade pact is expected to produce a clear draft of an early harvest list of products and services for tariff concessions, an economics official said Sunday.
During the second round of technical talks, Taiwan and China reached consensus on several aspects of the proposed Economic Cooperation Framework Agreement (ECFA), the official added.
Negotiations on financial services between the two sides will be held ahead of the third round of ECFA talks, the official said.

A panel of experts, commissioned by the Ministry of Finance's Department of Customs Administration, has been in consultation with their Chinese counterparts on the details of place-of-origin regulations for imported products, he noted.
The issue includes rules on "substantial transformation" of a product, added value tax rates and changes in the customs tariff codes, according to the official.
"Substantial transformation" refers to the extent to which a product is substantially changed after being imported for a specific manufacturing or processing purpose.

At present, the added value rate in Taiwan is 35 percent, but under the ECFA a different rate will be applied to imported goods that are included in the early harvest lists, based on the characteristics of the products.

Taiwan and China will also discuss imposing new regulations on imported textile products in an effort to stop illegal transshipments of textiles which involves the falsification of the country-of-origin information to avoid duties.

During the second round of ECFA talks in March, Chinese negotiators requested that 700 items be put on the early harvest list, according to the official, added in the next round of negotiations, "China is unlikely to propose that many items."

"The list will be acceptable to Taiwan, " because China has promised to make concessions so that Taiwan's small and medium-sized enterprises (SMEs) would benefit, therefore, it is likely that China would make requests that could negatively affect SMEs, the official added.

DOC.HEADLINE: All imports of U.S. beef tongues to be inspected: official
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, April 18 (CNA) 04/18/10 19:46:17 (By Lin Shu-yuan and Maubo Chang)

TEXT.P: The importation of beef tongues from the United States will require permission from Taiwan and the product should be inspected batch-by-batch, an economic official said Sunday.

The official, speaking on condition of anonymity, said beef tongues, cattle penises, testicles and tails are not classified as offal, which is not allowed into Taiwan according to a protocol signed with Washington last November.

Therefore, the importation of the other beef parts mentioned are technically allowed under the category of bone-in beef, which does not require special permission and is subject only to random checks, the official said.
However, the official added, Taiwan is insisting on special permission and batch-by-batch inspection for the importation of those products because of safety concerns among local consumers.
Washington's announcement on April 16 regarding the export of U.S. beef tongues to Taiwan was made only after it agreed to Taiwan's terms, the official said.

In other words, the official said, importers will be required first to obtain a U.S. phytosanitary certificate and health certificate before bringing beef tongues into Taiwan, he said. Then they would have to apply for import permission in Taiwan and agree to batch-by-batch inspection of the products by Taiwan inspectors before the beef tongues could be put on the local market, the official added.

A health official confirmed that every case of imported U.S. beef tongues will be opened and inspected. The first batch of the other beef parts will also be inspected in the same way, but if they pass the checks, only 5 percent of the cases in subsequent shipments will be inspected, the official added.

According to a local beef importer, U.S. beef tongues and tails are unlikely to see good sales because they are not that popular among local consumers, and the same products from Australia and New Zealand cost much less.
The U.S. announced Friday that all the beef parts mentioned above should come from cattle younger than 30 months and slaughtered on or after April 1, which would reduce the risk of mad cow disease.
Last September, Taiwan lifted its ban on imports of U.S. bone-in beef, which had been imposed out of fear of mad cow disease.

DOC.HEADLINE: Man faces fine for destroying endangered wetland grass
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, April 18 (CNA) 04/18/10 20:25:11 (By Chao Hung-chin and Deborah Kuo)

TEXT.P: A man who destroyed a patch of endangered beach grass by driving a dune buggy across a wetlands area in Taichung County recently, may face a fine of up to NT$250,000 (US$7,937), a Taichung police source said Sunday.

The man, identified as Chen Sung-ming, was temporarily detained and questioned several days ago after he drove a dune buggy across the Kaumei Wetlands near the estuary of the southern bank of the Dajia River, said Lee Tsai-an, head of the Chingshuei Police Department in Taichung County.

The all terrain vehicle (ATV) damaged several hundred square meters of endangered Guan grass (Bolboschoenus planiculmis) that was growing on the Kaumei Wetlands, which has seven different kinds of environments and hosts many wild animals and plants, Lee said.

The Chingshuei Police Department referred the case to the Taichung County government Sunday for penalty advice. The man could be fined up to NT$250,000 for violating the Wildlife Conservation Law, Lee added.
The Guan grass, which grows naturally in the wetlands salty soil, is an important aspect of the area's diverse ecology.
According to the police, Chen had injured his leg recently before the ATV incident, when a light plane he was flying crashed into the sea near the Dajia River estuary on March 20.
On that occasion, he was a given a ticket for violating the Law of Civil Aviation, according to the Chingshuei Police Department.

DOC.HEADLINE: Applications for cross-strait banking to be accepted soon
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, April 18 (CNA) 04/18/10 20:45:42 (By Chen Yun-hsuan and Maubo Chang)

TEXT.P: The Financial Supervisory Commission (FSC) is preparing to accept applications from local and Chinese banks this week for cross-strait banking operations, as the legislature is scheduled to hear the commission's report on revisions to three financial regulations Monday.
Technically, the revisions, which were designed to allow cross-strait banking operations, will take effect as soon as the commission had finished its report, according to a financial official.
Under the revised regulations, local banks will be permitted to apply to set up branch offices in China and vise versa.

However, Chinese banking institutions will only be permitted to invest in Taiwan banks if a trade pact being negotiated by Taiwan and China allows them to do so, and even then, Taiwan's Ministry of Economic Affairs will have to make revisions to another set of regulations, the official said.

DOC.HEADLINE: KMT to reinstate Sun Yat-sen scholarships
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, April 18 (CNA) 04/18/10 21:11:22 (By Lee Shu-hua and Deborah Kuo)

TEXT.P: After a hiatus of nearly 10 years, the ruling Kuomintang (KMT) leadership may decide to reinstate soon the Sun Yat-sen scholarships that were previously awarded to many of its promising young members, a party source said Sunday.

President Ma Ying-jeou, who is also chairman of the KMT, and the party's secretary general King Pu-tsung may be invited soon to give the oral tests to candidates, as both men were recipients of the scholarship and have a good command of the English language, said Lin Yung-juei, a KMT official in charge of administrative management.

President Ma will meet with KMT heavyweights April 22 for discussions on the reinstatement of the scholarship, which was established in 1960 by the KMT to send talented young people abroad for advanced studies in different disciplines, Lin said.

The preliminarily plan is for 10 young men and women, under 40 years of age, will be selected by the party this year to receive the Sun Yat-sen scholarships, and NT$15 million will be allocated this year for that purpose, according to Lin.
The scholarships will be open only to candidates who have been KMT members for more than two years, he added.

Besides Ma and King, other prominent figures who were awarded the scholarships for advanced studies overseas include Examination Yuan President John Kuan, KMT Vice Chairman Chan Chuen-po, retired veteran diplomat Eugene Yi-cheng Lok, Taichung City Mayor Jason Hu, Government Information Office Minister Johnny Chi- chen Chiang, and KMT Legislator Chou Shou-hsun.

DOC.HEADLINE: First public hearing on death penalty scheduled for April 21
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, April 18 (CNA) 04/18/10 21:16:25 (By Huang Hsu-sheng and Sofia Wu)

TEXT.P: The first in a series of public hearings on the question of whether the death penalty should be abolished will be held April 21 in Taipei County, the Ministry of Justice (MOJ) said Sunday.

The public hearing, which is expected to draw the participation of people on both sides of the death penalty issue, will focus on two main questions -- whether the 44 convicts currently on death row should be executed and what should be the government's policy on capital punishment, the ministry said in a statement.

While it is Taiwan's ultimate goal to abolish the death penalty, there is no timetable for doing so, the ministry said. The priorities at the moment are to forge a national consensus on the issue, reduce the use of death penalty and give better protection to crime victims, it added.

As part of the government's efforts to strengthen communication with the public, the ministry will join with district prosecutors offices to hold four public hearings on topics related to the death penalty.
The first hearing will be held April 21 at a Lunshan Temple-owned culture hall Banciao City, and the other three will be held later in Taichung, Kaohsiung and Hualien, respectively.
Members of the public are invited to attend the hearings to voice their views, the ministry said.

The discussions will examine factors that should be considered in evaluating whether the death penalty should be phased out, the purpose and social significance of such a move, the effects of correctional education, and whether government finances and the country's image should be taken into account in making a decision on capital punishment.
Other issues to be discussed will include what complementary measures should be adopted if death penalty will remain in place and how to improve the death penalty-related judicial process.

DOC.HEADLINE: Government not opposed to referendum on ECFA: premier
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, April 18 (CNA) 04/18/10 21:55:59 (By Hsieh Chia-chen and Y.L. Kao)

TEXT.P: Premier Wu Den-yih said Sunday that he and President Ma Ying-jeou both support rule of law and that if a referendum proposal on a trade pact with China is presented in accordance with the law, no one would have the right to block or oppose it.

Wu said in a TV interview that the ruling Kuomintang is not opposed to a referendum on the proposed cross-Taiwan Strait economic cooperation framework agreement (ECFA) and that everyone should respect the right of referendum, once the proposal adheres to the Constitution and the law.

Wu's comments came days after the China Times reported that he was "not opposed to an ECFA referendum." DOC.HEADLINE: Low-income housing areas not to be seen as slums: speaker
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, April 18 (CNA) 04/18/10 21:57:56 (by Huang Min-hsi and Lillian Lin)

TEXT.P: Legislative Speaker Wang Jin-pyng said Sunday that the government should take into consideration all factors pertaining to urban development when planning affordable housing units and must avoid giving the impression that residential areas for low-income families are "slums."
Wang made the remarks at a presentation ceremony for the Top Manager awards sponsored by the Institute of Taiwan Project Management.

Commenting on the government's plan to build thousands of affordable homes near planned metro stations in Linkou, Taipei County, Wang said that basic infrastructure, including schools and hospitals, should be built in the neighborhood to meet the needs of the new low-income communities.
Noting that affordable housing is meant to accommodate families of comparably lower income, Wang warned against the prospect of the new communities being viewed as "slums".
He suggested that the government assign project managers to plan and manage real estate development.

DOC.HEADLINE: Botulism infection confirmed as cause of woman's death
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, April 18 (CNA) 04/18/10 17:20:35 (By Chen Li-ting, Chiu Chun-chin and Deborah Kuo)

TEXT.P: The Centers for Disease Control (CDC) under the Department of Health confirmed Sunday that a woman who died April 14 after eating dried beancurd and preserved oysters had a botulism infection.

CDC Deputy Director Lin Ting said lab tests confirmed that the 44-year-old woman from Miaoli County had a botulism infection, which is usually caused by a nerve toxin produced by clostridium botulinum bacteria.
Several mice were injected with the woman's blood serum and they died within 24 hours, Lin added.
However, further lab tests will be required to determine what type of botulism caused the woman's death, he said.
It was also still not known whether it was the dried beancurd or the preserved oysters which the woman and her mother-in-law ate that caused the fatal botulism infection, Lin said.

The woman's 71-year-old mother-in-law has been on intubation at Taichung Veterans General Hospital in central Taiwan since she fell ill after eating the beancurd and oysters. Lab tests have confirmed that she also has a botulism infection. She has received two doses of botulismus-antitoxin that were rushed to the hospital by the CDC and which saved her life, according to Lin.

However, the daughter-in-law was not that lucky, as she was rushed to a different hospital in Taoyuan County, northern Taiwan which was not alert enough to seek emergency assistance from the CDC for the treatment of botulism, Lin said.

Samples of two packs of dried beancurd and a can of salted oysters that were found in the women's home in Miaoli were retrieved by the Food and Drug Administration for testing, but the lab reports will not be available for two weeks, the CDC said.

The two Miaoli women were the third and fourth botulism cases this year, following a mother and daughter in Taoyuan County who were diagnosed in early April, the CDC said. The Taoyuan mother and daughter were treated with botulismus-antitoxin.

Meanwhile, the Taoyuan County Public Health Bureau on Friday closed operations for two weeks at the two companies where the dried beancurd was made and ordered that the products be pulled from the shelves of major grocery stores.

However, the companies have complained of mistreatment, saying that their products were safe and were made in line with government standards. They complained that the two-week suspension will cost them hundreds of thousands of New Taiwan dollars.
"I hope the relevant tests will be completed soon so that my company's name can be cleared, " said Tseng Fan-Hsiang, owner of Cheng Hsiang Foods Co.
The latest incident has also resulted in declining business in Taoyuan County's Dasi township -- the center of dried beancurd production in Taiwan.
Huang Chien-chia, president of Tafang Foods, a well-established manufacturer of dried beancurd and related products in Dasi, said his store's business has shrunk by one-third this weekend.

Chiang Chiu-yun, the owner of another company known as Wan Li Hsiang which was established in 1921, said business at her store has also been affected by the incident, but added that her faithful customers were not at all fazed.

DOC.HEADLINE: Outstanding golfer looks forward to Taiwanese corporate sponsorship
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, April 18 (CNA) 04/18/10 18:52:13 (By Oscar Wu and Sofia Wu)

TEXT.P: The father of one of the world's top-ranking golfers, Yani Tseng of Taiwan, said Sunday his daughter is eager to gain the sponsorship of local companies.

Tseng Mao-hsin made the remarks while confirming that the Huabin Group in china has offered to sign a long-term sponsorship contract with his daughter, who vaulted into second place in the women's world golf rankings after she won the Kraft Nabisco Championship earlier this month.
The local Chinese-language daily China Times reported Sunday that the Huabin Group intends to sign a five-year, US$25 million sponsorship contract with the 21-year-old Taiwanese golfer.

Responding to the report, Tseng Mao-hsin said that as a Taiwanese citizen, his daughter would prefer to collaborate with Taiwanese business groups, but regrettably none of them have stepped forward so far.
Regarding the Huabin offer, Tseng Mao-hsin said the two sides are still discussing the details of the contract.
"We are not sure whether a sponsorship contract will eventually be signed, as we have not yet come to terms on certain details, " he said.
To be honest, Tseng Mao-shin, said the Huabin Group's offer is far from attractive because the contract will not cover Tseng Yani's travel costs to participate in LPGA tournaments.
"As a matter of fact, LPGA tours comprise the largest chunk of Yani's annual expenses... therefore, the Huabin offer is less than attractive in real terms," he said.

Another aspect that has to be considered is Huabin's demand that Yani Tseng terminate all other contracts with her existing sponsors of golf clubs, sunglasses, sportswear and relevant sports gear once she signs a deal with Huabin, her father said.
Apart from Huabin, he said, several brokerage agencies are also negotiating sponsorship contracts with his daughter.

Yani Tseng is scheduled to return to Taiwan April 25 when various sponsorship contract issues will be further discussed, he said. Aside from soaring up the world rankings, Yani Tseng catapulted to the top of other major lists by winning the April 4 Kraft Nabisco Championship in Rancho Mirage, California, the first major tournament of the season. Her US$300,000 first prize made her the leading prize money winner on the LPGA Tour after its first four events of the year.

The Huabin Group was founded by Yen Bin, a Thai-Chinese businessman. Over the past decades, the group has grown into a multinational enterprise in four major sectors, including consumer goods, modern service industries, sports, arts and culture and financial services and investments. The group has offices in many countries around the world.
Yen Bin ranks 10th on the Hurun Rich List, an annual list of the 100 wealthiest people in China.

DOC.HEADLINE: Taiwan composer breathes new life into traditional music

TEXT.P: In the musical world of Huang Chen-ming there are no limitations or boundaries. He sees no problem combining traditional Taiwanese and Chinese music with elements of Western rock, African music or Scottish folk songs.

Wang, the founder of the Chai Found Music Workshop, has set himself the goal of broadening the scope of traditional music and creating more opportunities for Taiwan musicians to play all over the world.
Since his return from the 2010 Winter Olympics in Vancouver, Canada earlier this year and a tour of several United States cities, Huang thinks he has been moving closer to this goal.
His life mission is to promote traditional music, he told the Central News Agency.
"I want to create limitless possibilities for traditional music and I hope more composers worldwide would join us," he said.
Since he established the music workshop 19 years ago, Huang has brought together a group of musicians that include pipa player Lin Hui-Kuan and di player Wu Chung-Hsien.

As the group's artistic director and composer, Huang uses traditional Chinese instruments as a central thematic element and has created a unique musical space that not only facilitates the performance of Sizhu music -- Chinese chamber music -- but also provides other composers with an inspirational platform for experimentation.

The group preserves traditional elements by fully exploiting the distinctive sounds of Eastern instruments, while also introducing light innovation into the genre of folk and world music. The aim is to create a groundbreaking expression of the diversity, vitality and richness of Taiwanese contemporary music, according to Huang.
He thinks that traditional music could encompass all kinds of experimentation. One of his latest concepts is that music should not only be heard, but also be seen.
With this in mind, he plans to incorporate tai-chi into his group's musical performances.
"All of our musicians will begin to learn tai-chi in May so that they can express that art form through music and with their bodies," he said.

As part of his efforts to expand the expression of traditional music, Huang last year held a composers' competition based on the theme of the ancient Chinese "five movements" philosophy which describes the interactions and relationships among five elements -- wood, water, earth, fire and metal.
The competition attracted many composers from the West and the East, eight of whom were chosen to present their works at a concert.
Huang is holding a similar competition this year, this time under the theme of yin-yang, which describes the interconnectedness and interdependency of seeming polar forces in the natural world.

"In this competition, we could see quite different and very creative works from Western and Eastern composers, which could also open another window for the enrichment of traditional music," Huang said.
The winning compositions will be presented at a concert in October, he added.

Over the years, Huang 's group has been invited to several international festivals such as the Barcelona Arts Festival in Spain in 1992, the Costa Rica Culture Festival in 1998, the Hoergaenge Contemporary Music Festival in Austria in 2000, the Cologne Music Festival in Germany 2001, the Huddersfield Contemporary Music Festival in England in 2004; and the Festival Dimension in Seoul, Korea in 2009.
"This year, we will have more opportunities to go abroad, to connect with other countries, including France where we will perform with musicians in Paris at the end of the year" Huang said.
"But this is also the year for training for a great future, " he added. CNA Photo 57 By Sunnie Chen CNA Staff reporter

DOC.HEADLINE: ECFA early harvest list to be drafted soon: official
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, April 18 (CNA) 04/18/10 19:41:57 (By Lin Su-yuan and Y.L. Kao)

TEXT.P: The third round of talks between Taiwan and China later this month on a proposed trade pact is expected to produce a clear draft of an early harvest list of products and services for tariff concessions, an economics official said Sunday.
During the second round of technical talks, Taiwan and China reached consensus on several aspects of the proposed Economic Cooperation Framework Agreement (ECFA), the official added.
Negotiations on financial services between the two sides will be held ahead of the third round of ECFA talks, the official said.

A panel of experts, commissioned by the Ministry of Finance's Department of Customs Administration, has been in consultation with their Chinese counterparts on the details of place-of-origin regulations for imported products, he noted.
The issue includes rules on "substantial transformation" of a product, added value tax rates and changes in the customs tariff codes, according to the official.
"Substantial transformation" refers to the extent to which a product is substantially changed after being imported for a specific manufacturing or processing purpose.

At present, the added value rate in Taiwan is 35 percent, but under the ECFA a different rate will be applied to imported goods that are included in the early harvest lists, based on the characteristics of the products.

Taiwan and China will also discuss imposing new regulations on imported textile products in an effort to stop illegal transshipments of textiles which involves the falsification of the country-of-origin information to avoid duties.

During the second round of ECFA talks in March, Chinese negotiators requested that 700 items be put on the early harvest list, according to the official, added in the next round of negotiations, "China is unlikely to propose that many items."

"The list will be acceptable to Taiwan, " because China has promised to make concessions so that Taiwan's small and medium-sized enterprises (SMEs) would benefit, therefore, it is likely that China would make requests that could negatively affect SMEs, the official added.

DOC.HEADLINE: All imports of U.S. beef tongues to be inspected: official
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, April 18 (CNA) 04/18/10 19:46:17 (By Lin Shu-yuan and Maubo Chang)

TEXT.P: The importation of beef tongues from the United States will require permission from Taiwan and the product should be inspected batch-by-batch, an economic official said Sunday.

The official, speaking on condition of anonymity, said beef tongues, cattle penises, testicles and tails are not classified as offal, which is not allowed into Taiwan according to a protocol signed with Washington last November.

Therefore, the importation of the other beef parts mentioned are technically allowed under the category of bone-in beef, which does not require special permission and is subject only to random checks, the official said.
However, the official added, Taiwan is insisting on special permission and batch-by-batch inspection for the importation of those products because of safety concerns among local consumers.
Washington's announcement on April 16 regarding the export of U.S. beef tongues to Taiwan was made only after it agreed to Taiwan's terms, the official said.

In other words, the official said, importers will be required first to obtain a U.S. phytosanitary certificate and health certificate before bringing beef tongues into Taiwan, he said. Then they would have to apply for import permission in Taiwan and agree to batch-by-batch inspection of the products by Taiwan inspectors before the beef tongues could be put on the local market, the official added.

A health official confirmed that every case of imported U.S. beef tongues will be opened and inspected. The first batch of the other beef parts will also be inspected in the same way, but if they pass the checks, only 5 percent of the cases in subsequent shipments will be inspected, the official added.

According to a local beef importer, U.S. beef tongues and tails are unlikely to see good sales because they are not that popular among local consumers, and the same products from Australia and New Zealand cost much less.
The U.S. announced Friday that all the beef parts mentioned above should come from cattle younger than 30 months and slaughtered on or after April 1, which would reduce the risk of mad cow disease.
Last September, Taiwan lifted its ban on imports of U.S. bone-in beef, which had been imposed out of fear of mad cow disease.

DOC.HEADLINE: Man faces fine for destroying endangered wetland grass
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, April 18 (CNA) 04/18/10 20:25:11 (By Chao Hung-chin and Deborah Kuo)

TEXT.P: A man who destroyed a patch of endangered beach grass by driving a dune buggy across a wetlands area in Taichung County recently, may face a fine of up to NT$250,000 (US$7,937), a Taichung police source said Sunday.

The man, identified as Chen Sung-ming, was temporarily detained and questioned several days ago after he drove a dune buggy across the Kaumei Wetlands near the estuary of the southern bank of the Dajia River, said Lee Tsai-an, head of the Chingshuei Police Department in Taichung County.

The all terrain vehicle (ATV) damaged several hundred square meters of endangered Guan grass (Bolboschoenus planiculmis) that was growing on the Kaumei Wetlands, which has seven different kinds of environments and hosts many wild animals and plants, Lee said.

The Chingshuei Police Department referred the case to the Taichung County government Sunday for penalty advice. The man could be fined up to NT$250,000 for violating the Wildlife Conservation Law, Lee added.
The Guan grass, which grows naturally in the wetlands salty soil, is an important aspect of the area's diverse ecology.
According to the police, Chen had injured his leg recently before the ATV incident, when a light plane he was flying crashed into the sea near the Dajia River estuary on March 20.
On that occasion, he was a given a ticket for violating the Law of Civil Aviation, according to the Chingshuei Police Department.

DOC.HEADLINE: Applications for cross-strait banking to be accepted soon
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, April 18 (CNA) 04/18/10 20:45:42 (By Chen Yun-hsuan and Maubo Chang)

TEXT.P: The Financial Supervisory Commission (FSC) is preparing to accept applications from local and Chinese banks this week for cross-strait banking operations, as the legislature is scheduled to hear the commission's report on revisions to three financial regulations Monday.
Technically, the revisions, which were designed to allow cross-strait banking operations, will take effect as soon as the commission had finished its report, according to a financial official.
Under the revised regulations, local banks will be permitted to apply to set up branch offices in China and vise versa.

However, Chinese banking institutions will only be permitted to invest in Taiwan banks if a trade pact being negotiated by Taiwan and China allows them to do so, and even then, Taiwan's Ministry of Economic Affairs will have to make revisions to another set of regulations, the official said.

DOC.HEADLINE: KMT to reinstate Sun Yat-sen scholarships
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, April 18 (CNA) 04/18/10 21:11:22 (By Lee Shu-hua and Deborah Kuo)

TEXT.P: After a hiatus of nearly 10 years, the ruling Kuomintang (KMT) leadership may decide to reinstate soon the Sun Yat-sen scholarships that were previously awarded to many of its promising young members, a party source said Sunday.

President Ma Ying-jeou, who is also chairman of the KMT, and the party's secretary general King Pu-tsung may be invited soon to give the oral tests to candidates, as both men were recipients of the scholarship and have a good command of the English language, said Lin Yung-juei, a KMT official in charge of administrative management.

President Ma will meet with KMT heavyweights April 22 for discussions on the reinstatement of the scholarship, which was established in 1960 by the KMT to send talented young people abroad for advanced studies in different disciplines, Lin said.

The preliminarily plan is for 10 young men and women, under 40 years of age, will be selected by the party this year to receive the Sun Yat-sen scholarships, and NT$15 million will be allocated this year for that purpose, according to Lin.
The scholarships will be open only to candidates who have been KMT members for more than two years, he added.

Besides Ma and King, other prominent figures who were awarded the scholarships for advanced studies overseas include Examination Yuan President John Kuan, KMT Vice Chairman Chan Chuen-po, retired veteran diplomat Eugene Yi-cheng Lok, Taichung City Mayor Jason Hu, Government Information Office Minister Johnny Chi- chen Chiang, and KMT Legislator Chou Shou-hsun.

DOC.HEADLINE: First public hearing on death penalty scheduled for April 21
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, April 18 (CNA) 04/18/10 21:16:25 (By Huang Hsu-sheng and Sofia Wu)

TEXT.P: The first in a series of public hearings on the question of whether the death penalty should be abolished will be held April 21 in Taipei County, the Ministry of Justice (MOJ) said Sunday.

The public hearing, which is expected to draw the participation of people on both sides of the death penalty issue, will focus on two main questions -- whether the 44 convicts currently on death row should be executed and what should be the government's policy on capital punishment, the ministry said in a statement.

While it is Taiwan's ultimate goal to abolish the death penalty, there is no timetable for doing so, the ministry said. The priorities at the moment are to forge a national consensus on the issue, reduce the use of death penalty and give better protection to crime victims, it added.

As part of the government's efforts to strengthen communication with the public, the ministry will join with district prosecutors offices to hold four public hearings on topics related to the death penalty.
The first hearing will be held April 21 at a Lunshan Temple-owned culture hall Banciao City, and the other three will be held later in Taichung, Kaohsiung and Hualien, respectively.
Members of the public are invited to attend the hearings to voice their views, the ministry said.

The discussions will examine factors that should be considered in evaluating whether the death penalty should be phased out, the purpose and social significance of such a move, the effects of correctional education, and whether government finances and the country's image should be taken into account in making a decision on capital punishment.
Other issues to be discussed will include what complementary measures should be adopted if death penalty will remain in place and how to improve the death penalty-related judicial process.

DOC.HEADLINE: Today in history
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, April 19 (CNA) 04/19/10 08:45:52
DOC.TEXT:
Today is Monday, April 19, or the sixth day of the third month of the Year of Tiger according to the lunar calendar. Following is a list of important events that have occurred on this date in the past:
1832: Jose Echegaray y Eizaguirre, Spanish dramatist, mathematician, statesman and Nobel laureate, is born.
1853: Russia claims to be the protectorate of Turkey in a prelude to the Crimean War.
1882: British naturalist Charles Darwin dies at the age of 73. He revolutionized the study of biology with his theory of evolution based on natural selection. His most famous works include "Origin of Species" and "The Descent of Man."
1906: French chemist and physicist Pierre Curie is run over and killed in Paris at the age of 47. He and his wife Marie shared the 1903 Nobel Prize for fundamental research into radioactivity.
1928: Japanese troops occupy Shantung Province in northern China.
1942: Chinese Expeditionary Forces led by Gen. Sun Li-jen capture Yenangyuang in northern Burma, rescuing more than 7,000 British and Burmese troops from Japanese encirclement.
1948: The first National Assembly elects Chiang Kai-shek as the Republic of China's first president under the new ROC Constitution, garnering 2,430 out of 2,704 votes.
1956: Prince Rainier of Monaco marries American screen actress Grace Kelly in Monte Carlo. Over 1,200 guests attend the televised Catholic wedding ceremony.
1959: The Dalai Lama, the Tibetan leader fleeing a Communist Chinese invasion of his country, finds sanctuary in India.
1960: South Korean President Syngman Rhee is toppled in a nationwide pro- democracy student uprising that was protesting election fraud.
1966: Australian troops leave Sydney to join American forces in Vietnam.
1974: The Blood Donation Association of the Republic of China is inaugurated.
1975: India's first satellite is launched by a Soviet rocket.
1977: ROC Education Minister Tsiang Yien-si resigns to take responsibility for an incident in which 32 college students and teachers were killed when their boat capsized near Suao Port in eastern Taiwan. Tsiang was succeeded by Li Yuan- zu.
1992: Dutch Minister of Foreign Trade Yvonne van Rooy visits Taipei to seek stronger bilateral relations.
1993: A total of 87 Branch Davidian cult members, including their leader David Koresh, are killed when federal agents storm their compound in Waco, Texas, after a 51-day standoff. Nine other members are freed.
1995: A huge truck bomb destroys the Alfred P. Murrah government building in Oklahoma City, killing 168 people and injuring more than 400 others.
1995: Malawi President Bakili Muluzi pays a state visit to Taipei.
1997: The S.S. Sheng Da, a mainland China container freighter, steams into Kaohsiung Port on its maiden voyage, becoming the first ship to sail directly to Taiwan from the mainland in 48 years, and completing a historic crossing of one of the world's great political divides.
1999: Tsai Shun-fa, 52, known as "Bean Curd Papa," is honored by Premier Vincent Siew for donating blood 495 times over 20 years.
1999: The Republic of China-Swaziland Conference on Economical and Technological Cooperation opens in Taipei.
2000: Jeffrey Koo, chairman of the Taipei-based Chinese National Association of Industry & Commerce, says that if Beijing bullies Taiwanese doing business in mainland China, it will hurt both sides of the Taiwan Strait.
2000: President-elect Chen Shui-bian promises that his administration will help the Ministry of Justice Investigation Bureau transform itself into a "National Bureau of Investigation."
2001: Former ROC Premier Vincent Siew says that he will file an application with the government for a visit to mainland China to pitch for the formation of a "common market" across the Taiwan Strait.
Confucius' lesson of the day: "Be not concerned that men do not know you; be concerned that you have no ability."
