DOC.HEADLINE: Taiwan players win second place at Badminton Asia Championships
DOC.DATELINE: New Delhi, April 19 (CNA) 04/19/10 10:32:22 (By He Hung-rui and Maubo Chang)

TEXT.P: Taiwan players lost their bid to win the first title for their country in the Badminton Asia Championships after being defeated by their South Korea rivals in the men's doubles final Sunday.
Chen Hung-ling and Lim Yu-lang, who were seeded first, lost 12-19, 12-21, 21-17 to fifth-seeded Cho Gun-woo and Yoo Yeon-seong.
Another Taiwan pair, Lee Sheng-mu and Fang Chieh-min, won third place in the men's doubles.
Taiwan players Chien Yu-chin and Chen Wen-hsin also won third place in the women's doubles.

DOC.HEADLINE: Suicide prevention measures to be strengthened: minister
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, April 19 (CNA) 04/19/10 11:48:44 (By Chou Yung-chieh and Elizabeth Hsu)

TEXT.P: After learning of a mother who killed herself and her teenage daughter by burning charcoal indoors, Minister of the Interior Jiang Yi-huah said Monday that the ministry will take measures to strengthen its suicide prevention mechanism.

The National Police Agency will also be told to train police officers to be alert when receiving reports of similar cases, after the 13 year-old victim had attempted to find help upon learning her mother wanted to kill them both, Jiang said.
In response to media inquiries, Jiang admitted there were defects in the existing suicide prevention reporting system.

The girl, identified only by her surname Tsao, and her mother were both found dead at their home in Taichung County's Taiping City April 17, with police saying they had killed themselves by burning charcoal.

The tragedy was publicized by a local newspaper, the United Daily News, on its front page Monday, saying that despite the girl having attempted to find help at school, her mother was still able to take the girl home and carry out her suicide plan.
The girl left two letters for classmates and one thank-you note for her teacher to bid farewell, the report said.

Citing the director of student affairs -- surnamed Chen -- at a private boarding school in Nantou County where Tsao was enrolled, the report said: "I begged the mother to leave the child here, but was rejected."
"After learning of the death of the mother and girl, the image of the child, who could not stop weeping out of fear for her mother's anger, kept emerging in my head," Chen said.

According to the report, Tsao told the school on April 1 of her mother's plan to commit suicide during the Tomb Sweeping Day holiday April 3-5. On that same day, Tsao's mother picked the girl up from school despite Chen's request that Tsao stay with her.
Chen said she had informed the police and county social workers of the alleged suicide attempt. But "both of them failed to show up" before the mother and daughter left, she said.
"Despite the fact I tried not to let her go, I could only watch them leave," Chen said.

The report said that Nantou County social workers transferred the case to their counterparts in Taichung County where the mother lived, and that Taichung County police and social workers did not handle the case until April 6, when they visited the mother's home in Taiping City but found that no one answered the door.

After that, police and social workers visited the house three days in a row but found no one until April 17, when police broke in and discovered the mother and daughter had been dead for days, the report said.
"It was a serious mistake by social working units, " the daily cited Peng Huai- chen, an assistant professor at Tunghai University's Department of Social Work, as saying.
Peng blamed social workers' lack of alertness for the tragedy, saying they shouldn't give up when they fail to reach someone involved in such a case.

DOC.HEADLINE: Talk of the day -- Taiwanese on spree for Chinese yuan
DOC.DATELINE: 04/19/10 12:19:39 (By Deborah Kuo)

TEXT.P: Taiwanese people, who were first allowed to purchase the Chinese yuan only months ago, have been on a shopping spree for the currency in anticipation of an appreciation this year.

The new "fad of renminbi shopping" has caused shortages of the Chinese yuan banknotes in Taiwan, a development which in turn led local banks to become reluctant to sell the renminbi, with some even implementing a "buying only, no selling" strategy.

However, a banker reminds people wishing to profit from the price differences that "hoarding" of the Chinese yuan will not necessarily yield any profits if the yuan appreciates no higher than 5.1 percent.
The following are excerpts on the issue carried in Monday's China Times and United Daily News.
China Times:

A Mega Bank official said that with its store of Chinese yuan decreasing drastically as a result of rising demand for the currency in Taiwan, the bank was forced to acquire yuan from Bank of America and HSBC based in Hong Kong.
The anticipation of the yuan's rise was so strong that even HSBC stopped offering quotes on the currency.
"Over the past month, we have either sourced renminbi cash at higher prices or obtained none at all," the Mega banker said.

That is why Mega Bank has implemented a "buying only, no selling" measure in all its branches islandwide, the banker said, except for at Kaohsiung International Airport, where the Chinese yuan is still available for exchange. (April 19, 2010).
United Daily News:
"Hoarding" renminbi will not necessarily be profitable for Taiwanese people.

The recent visit to Beijing by U.S. Treasury Secretary Timothy Geithner has stirred up forex speculators' expectations of the Chinese yuan's imminent appreciation. China's Vice Minister of Commerce Zhong Shan, however, said last week that China and the U.S. have reached a preliminary agreement that the value of the yuan will not be adjusted and the currency will remain stable in both China's forex exchange market and its foreign trade market.
Chinese President Hu Jintao has also declared that "the renminbi exchange reform will not begin because of any outside pressure."
China's export traders, however, speculated that the renminbi will rise between 2-3 percent this year, despite the government's denial.
Liu Enyuan, a vice president at Panpan Security Industries, said the renminbi's appreciation is irreversible, given the fact that costs for all raw materials have risen.
"Even if the renminbi does not rise in a lump sum shortly, the currency is forecast to grow stronger gradually, " Liu said. (April 19, 2010).

DOC.HEADLINE: China Times -- President Ma on watch list
DOC.DATELINE: Kuomintang (KMT) 04/19/10 13:38:15 (By Maubo Chang)

TEXT.P: Secretary-General King Pu-tsung told Singapore-based Lianhe Zaobao that President Ma Ying-jeou's disapproval rating declined by 18 percent in the KMT's latest survey, which he branded as a positive development.

However, we have to point out that according to another survey conducted by the Global Views Monthly, Ma's approval rating remained at about 30 percent, compared to the 60 percent polled who disapprove of his performance.
So at best, Ma is still on the public's watch list.
How could he fall from grace with the people so rapidly?
Whether Ma will admit it or not, his ruling team doesn't have any central goals for leading the country.
Shortly after taking office, the president gathered a group of scholars and experts with an eye to streamlining the country's
taxation system, only to see their efforts fall flat because Ma's ruling team was more than willing to overrule their suggestions for political reasons.
In an attempt to outbid the opposition party, the business income tax provided in the government's industrial innovation bill was cut, by the ruling team itself, from 20 percent to 17 percent.
There is no reason to cut it except to woo voters.
The bill was crafted to replace two expired statutes that promoted investment in and the upgrading of industry, and is supposed to eliminate tax breaks included in its forerunners.
However, it not only renews this outdated practice but expands it to cover traditional economic sectors and small- and medium-sized enterprises, even though they have nothing to do with innovation.

Another example is the establishment of five municipalities, which includes two more than President Ma's initial plan and run contrary to his goal of balancing the development of northern, central and southern Taiwan.

If the only thing the head of the state is concerned about is how to win elections in the newly formed municipalities, rather than a long-range vision for the country, the country's democracy will not be able to develop healthily.
A leader who is too accommodating to voters at the cost of his policies can hardly earn people's respect. (April 19, 2010)

DOC.HEADLINE: Talk of the day -- New military complex taking shape

TEXT.P: A special military district will take shape in the Taipei suburb of Dazhe next year when the Ministry of National Defense (MND) and the Air Force General Headquarters move into new buildings in the area next year.

The ministry reportedly has formed a task force to oversee relevant construction projects to ensure they are completed in time for inauguration next October as part of the country's centenary celebrations.

Meanwhile, the ministry has also completed a review of its 50-plus barracks in metropolitan Taipei and has tentatively decided to release more than 200 hectares of land under its control for redevelopment.

In line with the government's "lean and mean" military streamlining project, the MND is scheduled to disband its military forces entertainment corps in 2014 as part of its efforts to meet the goal of trimming the number of armed forces to 215,000.
The following are excerpts from local media coverage of the topic: China Times:

Construction of the new MND building began in 2005 and was originally scheduled for completion in 2008, but completion was delayed due to a redesign of its interior to cope with new demand arising from military restructuring.
The budget was also increased from NT$13.3 billion to more than NT$15 billion (US$476.19 million) because of the redesign.
Defense Minister Kao Hua-chu has been pushing for acceleration of construction in order to finalize the ministry's relocation next year in time for the country's centenary celebrations.
The new MND headquarters is being built on the site of the old National Defense University and will also house the new Air Force headquarters.

The new MND and Air Force headquarters, and the adjacent Navy headquarters, will form a new special military complex. Moreover, the new MND building is close to the tightly guarded Heng Shan Military Command Center, an emergency command center.
The new location will allow for seamless integration of peacetime and wartime operations, according to military sources.

According to the sources, the new MND building can withstand a magnitude-7 earthquake and Chinese EMP (electromagnetic pulse) attacks. Its blastproofing and bombproofing capacity is on par with that of the U.S. Pentagon, the sources said.

The complex will have two large helipads. As the new MND headquarters has a mountain at its back, it is better protected from missile and fighter jet attacks, the sources went on, adding that anti-air attack missiles and ground troops will be deployed at the complex to cope with possible enemy attacks. (April 19, 2010). Commercial Times:

The 200 hectares of land to be released by the military for redevelopment will include a 185-hectare plot that will be left vacant following the downsizing of the military's No. 202 artillery and ammunition factory in Nangang district, and a 7-hectare plot to be vacated following the relocation of the Air Force headquarters next year.
The Air Force headquarters plot will be most lucrative, as it sits on the city's tree-lined Renai Road, which boasts many luxury houses and beautiful scenery.
The plot, worth NT$16.2 billion in terms of officially assessed price, has been listed by the Executive Yuan as one of the areas to be subject to rejuvenation and redevelopment.
Local construction companies cannot wait to bid for cooperation with the military to develop the plot, as they believe that housing built in the area will fetch exorbitant prices. (April 19, 2010).

DOC.HEADLINE: Strict controls on U.S. beef imports: economics minister
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, April 19 (CNA) 04/19/10 14:13:01 (By Justin Su and Elizabeth Hsu)

TEXT.P: Taiwan will adopt strict measures based on the existing law to ensure that imports of U.S. beef products such as tongues and testicles are safe for consumption, Minister of Economic Affairs Shih Yen-shiang said Monday.
In response to lawmakers' questions at the Legislative Yuan, Shih said the measures will be implemented based on the principles of "three controls and five certifications."

The measures set controls on beef imports at the source, at borders and in markets, while the five certifications refer to verifying certification documents, checking that shipments are marked with detailed product information, opening a high percentage of cartons of imported beef to check the product, conducting food safety tests and being able to get information on suspected problem products immediately.

Asked about the U.S. government's announcement that beef exports to Taiwan will include tongues, testicles and tails, Shih cited Department of Health data as explaining that these products are not categorized as "internal organs" that are not allowed to be exported to Taiwan according to a Taiwan-U.S. protocol signed last year.
The Bureau of Foreign Trade will decide whether or not to allow the import of such U.S. beef products based on the existing standard, Shih said.

The U.S. Department of Agriculture announced Aril 16 that exports of beef products to Taiwan will include bone-in meat, hanging tenders, tongues, penises, testicles, tails, tendons, and diaphragms derived from cattle less than 30 months of age slaughtered on or after April 1.

The beef parts are technically allowed to be exported into Taiwan under the category of bone-in beef, which does not require special permission and is subject only to random checks, according to ministry officials.
Legislator Ting Shou-chung of the ruling Kuomintang (KMT) suggested that the government take immediate action to prohibit the beef parts from entering Taiwan to prevent public outrage.
Taiwan's agreement last year to lift its ban on U.S. bone-in beef and certain other beef products, including ground beef and offal, sparked a huge public outcry.
The ban was imposed in 2003 due to fears of bovine spongiform encephalopathy (BSE), or mad cow disease.

Under public pressure, the KMT-controlled Legislative Yuan amended the Act Governing Good Sanitation Jan. 5 to deny access to Taiwan of beef products -- including ground beef, offal and other beef parts such as skulls, brains, eyes and spines -- from countries with documented BSE cases over the past decades.

DOC.HEADLINE: CBC advises banks to acquire renminbi directly from China
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, April 19 (CNA) 04/19/10 14:23:56 (By Kao Chao-fen and Deborah Kuo)

TEXT.P: The Central Bank of the Republic of China (CBC) advised the two major foreign banks in Taiwan that are authorized suppliers of Chinese currency to acquire banknotes directly from China to beef up their supplies, a CBC official said Monday.
Taiwanese people, who were first allowed to purchase the Chinese yuan only months ago, have been snapping up the Chinese currency in anticipation of an appreciation this year.

The "renminbi shopping fad" has caused shortages of Chinese yuan banknotes in Taiwan, a development that prompted local banks to become reluctant to sell the currency renminbi, with some even implementing a "buying only, no selling" strategy.
Fielding questions at the Legislative Yuan, CBC Deputy Governor Chou A-ting said renminbi supplies in Taiwan had declined substantially over the past two weeks.

The amount of Chinese banknotes made available by HSBC and Bank of America in Asia has dropped noticeably over the past several weeks, and their acquisition of renminbi from financial markets around Asia has diminished by half, Chou said.

Chou made the remarks in response to questions from ruling Kuomintang Legislator Lai Shyh-bao, who inquired about the New Taiwan dollar-yuan exchange rate and limits on how much Chinese currency Taiwan citizens are allowed to buy from banks.
Chou said the NT dollar-yuan exchange rate is about 4.8: 1 and that people are allowed to purchase 20,000 yuan per transaction from local banks.
Lai suggested people could just go to the bank several times a day and acquire as much Chinese as they wished.
"People are hoarding the yuan," Lai told Chou.

A Mega Bank official said earlier that with its store of Chinese yuan decreasing drastically as a result of rising demand, the bank was forced to acquire yuan from branches of HSBC and Bank of America based in Hong Kong.
The anticipation of the yuan's rise was so strong that HSBC even stopped offering quotes on the currency.
"Over the past month, we have either sourced renminbi cash at higher prices or obtained none at all," the Mega banker said.

DOC.HEADLINE: Economic Daily News: Issues to be clarified by party head debate
DOC.DATELINE: 04/19/10 15:34:23 (By Maubo Chang)

TEXT.P: President Ma Ying-jeou and opposition Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) Chairperson Tsai Ying-wen are slated to have a debate April 25 on whether the country should conclude an economic cooperation framework agreement (ECFA) trade pact with China.

Although the debate will neither change Ma's determination to clinch the pact nor stop Tsai from going all out to stop it, we still hope it will clarify certain issues surrounding the ECFA and will not simply be a case of trading criticisms.
Given the rise of China and the rapid economic integration in Southeast Asia, Taiwan must adjust its economic development policy to accommodate this trend.

Ma has opted to clinch the ECFA with China to break the bottleneck Taiwan faces, but this has nothing to do with Ma's personal political preference, so the DPP should not brand his option as "a plot to betray Taiwan" or to "knit Taiwan together with China."
On the other hand, the ruling party should not describe the DPP's opposition to the pact as trying to seclude the island further from international society.
Ma has characterized the ECFA as the first step toward a free trade pact with China.
In theory, a free trade pact will promote the efficient use of resources, but in reality, the process of economic integration will come at a price for various industries.

The debate should disclose the extent of the pact's coverage and the timetable for it to evolve into a full free trade pact so the public can estimate its positive and negative effects on individual industries.
The government should also reveal the complementary measures it will adopt to ensure that the ECFA realizes its intended purposes and that its benefits will be shared by the public.

On behalf of the DPP, Tsai should tell the people how the DPP thinks the country should enhance its international profile, promote ties with China, strengthen its competitiveness and improve the welfare of the general public in the absence of such a pact.

Whether the debate will degenerate into a war of words, or become an actual dialogue between the ruling and opposition leaders, depends greatly on the participants' wisdom and vision. (April 19, 2010)

DOC.HEADLINE: Share prices plunge on local bourse
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, April 19 (CNA) 04/19/10 15:35:47 (By Olivia Wang)

TEXT.P: Taiwan's share prices plunged Monday, with the weighted index, the market's key barometer, falling 257.35 points, or 3.17 percent, to close at 7,854.22.
The local bourse opened at 8,003.02 and fluctuated between 7,845.77 and 8,042.05 during the day's trading. Market turnover totaled NT$138.03 billion (US$4.38 billion).

All eight major stock categories lost ground, with paper and pulp issues dropping the most at 5.2 percent, followed by construction shares at 5 percent. Textile issues lost 4.9 percent, cement shares moved down 4.8 percent and foodstuff shares were down 4.4 percent.
Financial and banking stocks dropped 4.1 percent, plastics and chemicals shares were down 3.4 percent and machinery and electronics issues lost 2.8 percent.
Losers outnumbered gainers 3,105 to 375, with 73 remaining unchanged.
Foreign investors and Chinese QDIIs were net sellers of NT$3.52 billion-worth of shares.

DOC.HEADLINE: Taiwanese banks apply to venture into China
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, April 19 (CNA) 04/19/10 15:37:01 (By Cheng Yun-hsuan and Deborah Kuo)

TEXT.P: The amendments to the three revised statutes governing the operations of banks, insurance companies and securities houses were enacted Monday, paving the way for Taiwan banks to file applications to break into China.
The Financial Supervisory Commission (FSC) was to start accepting applications Monday afternoon.

FSC Chairman Sean Chen said that it would take about two months for the FSC's Banking Bureau to screen applications filed by local banks to invest in China and that it would take another four to six months for Chinese authorities to process the applications before granting licenses.
"I'm afraid that Taiwanese banks will be able to formally venture into China by the end of the year at the earliest, " Chen said at a meeting at the Executive Yuan Finance Committee.

All local public banks, including Taiwan Cooperative Bank, First Commercial Bank, Land Bank of Taiwan, Chang Hwa Bank, the Medium Business Bank of Taiwan and Hua Nan Commercial Bank, said they will submit applications as soon as possible.

Meanwhile, Banking Bureau Director Kuei Hsien-nung said the screening and supervising of Chinese banks making inroads into Taiwan will be a "dual track" mechanism, with the FSC and the Investment Commission under the Ministry of Economic Affairs being in charge.

DOC.HEADLINE: U.S. dollar up on Taipei Forex
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, April 19 (CNA) 04/19/10 16:32:40 (By Olivia Wang)

TEXT.P: The U.S. dollar gained ground against the New Taiwan dollar on the Taipei Foreign Exchange Monday, rising NT$0.102 to close at NT$31.492.
A total of US$979 million changed hands during the trading session.
The U.S. dollar opened at NT$31.460 and fluctuated between NT$31.345 and NT$31.480.

DOC.HEADLINE: Chinese delegation from Hubei visits Taiwan
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, April 19 (CNA) 04/19/10 17:21:03 (By Feng Chao and Y.L. Kao)

TEXT.P: A 1,000-strong delegation from central China's Hubei Province led by one of the province's top officials arrived in Taiwan Monday to enhance exchanges between Hubei and Taiwan.

The delegation, led by Luo Qingquan, secretary of the Hubei Provincial Committee of the Communist Party of China and divided into 32 subgroups, is expected to purchase over 30 types of products worth more than US$500 million during the visit.

The main purpose of the visit is to gain more information about investing in Taiwan and to invite Taiwanese businessmen to invest in Hubei, said Yang Jun, a Hubei official in charge of Taiwan affairs.
As of 2009, some 2,080 Taiwanese businessmen had invested a total of US$5.8 billion in the province, according to Yang.

Ruling Kuomintang (KMT) Honorary Chairman Wu Poh-hsiung was to host a banquet in the evening in honor of the delegation, which is made up of representatives from various business groups in the provincial capital of Wuhan.
At the invitation of the KMT, the delegation will attend a series of activities, including four forums and industry briefings, as part of the "Taiwan-Hubei Wuhan Week" program that will open Tuesday.
On April 21, several consultations for those visitors intending to purchase products and a seminar on information technology will be held.
"Taiwan-Hubei Wuhan Week, " which started in 2004, has been held in Wuhan for the past six years and this is the first time Taiwan has hosted the large-scale event.

During his one-week visit, Luo will also meet another KMT honorary chairman Lien Chan, Taiwan's semi-official Straits Exchange Foundation Chairman, Chiang Pin- kung, Taichung Mayor Jason Hu, Chinese National Federation of Industries President Chen Wu-hsiung, Hon Hai Group Chairman Terry Gou and Uni-President Group CEO Lin Chang-sheng.
The delegation is also scheduled to visit the National Palace Museum in Taipei, Taichung Harbor, Sun Moon Lake in Nantou County, and Yunlin County, before leaving April 26.

DOC.HEADLINE: Vice premier promotes public transit to cut carbon emissions
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, April 19 (CNA) 04/19/10 17:27:55 (By Maubo Chang)

TEXT.P: Instead of imposing a carbon tax to cut carbon emissions, the government should put greater emphasis on improving the energy efficiency of vehicles and encouraging the use of public transportation, Vice Premier Eric Liluan Chu said Monday.

In an interview with a local cable TV station, the vice premier, who heads a carbon emissions reduction committee under the Executive Yuan, said a carbon tax is one option to curb the consumption of fossil fuels, but the government's overall strategy remains the most important factor in the effort.

"Limiting the emissions of vehicles, encouraging the use of electric vehicles, enhancing the efficiency of public transportation, and extending rapid transit systems" would be more effective than imposing carbon taxes or congestion pricing, according to Chu.

The government is also pushing 10 other carbon reduction measures, Chu said, that focus in part on the development of clean and renewable energy and carbon- reduction technologies, and the spread of green buildings, green factories and green communities.
Saving energy is part of modern ethics and should be a habit instilled in students at school so they "can serve as energy-saving inspectors at home," the vice premier added.

Rapid transit systems are considered highly effective in cutting carbon emissions, but Chu said the pace of infrastructure development has been too slow, including in Taipei, where to date the MRT system covers 92.9 kilometers and serves 1.38 million passengers daily.
The system will cover 120 km when it is completed in 2015.

Although Taiwan is not a signatory of the 1997 Kyoto Protocol on Climate Change, it has promised to cut its carbon emissions to the level of 2008 by between 2016 and 2020, and to 50 percent of the level of emissions seen in 2000 by 2050.
The government formed a committee led by Chu on Dec. 28, 2009 to come up with strategies to achieve the goals.

Meanwhile, Chu, who is considered the ruling Kuomintang's likely nominee in the Xinbei City mayoral race in late 2010, said in the interview that he was not certain when he will be formally tapped by the party as its candidate in the race.
"I will concentrate my energy on my job at the Executive Yuan before I am nominated and will do my best to win the election after being nominated," Chu said.

DOC.HEADLINE: Commercial Times: Investment promotion strategy needs revamp

TEXT.P: The Executive Yuan recently formed a special task force to help remove investment barriers and boost employment. We welcome government action to promote private investment.
Nevertheless, we should remind the government that a conventional technology- centered investment strategy won't be enough to resolve Taiwan's unemployment plight.

Taiwan's private investment has steadily declined in recent years, but the amount still ranges between NT$1.6 trillion and NT$2 trillion per year, higher than the NT$1 trillion to NT$1.7 trillion per year recorded in the 1990s.

Despite the relatively high level of investment, Taiwan's unemployment rate regularly exceeded 4 percent even before the 2008-2009 global financial crisis, far higher than the 1990s average of 2 percent.

Why was limited private investment in the past been able to create jobs to help keep unemployment at bay? And why has the higher investment seen in recent years been unable to drive down the jobless rate?
A major reason is that the biggest portion of private investment has been pumped into the semiconductor, flat panel display and other electronics industries.

It is widely known that these capital- and technology-intensive industries create few jobs. According to a 2006 industrial census, every NT$100 million invested in the high-tech sector created only 6.4 jobs, compared to 16 jobs that the same amount of investment could create in non-electronics or high-tech sectors.

These figures indicate that the government should not indulge in promoting large investment projects in the high-tech sector. It should focus instead on stimulating investment in conventional manufacturing sectors, services, and small- and medium-sized enterprises, which have been shown to be more effective in generating new jobs. (April 19, 2010).

DOC.HEADLINE: Groups launch campaign to herald new era of reading
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, April 19 (CNA) 04/19/10 17:45:57 (By Lee Hsien-feng and Deborah Kuo)

TEXT.P: Delegates of 100-odd Taiwanese non-profit organizations (NPO) gathered Monday to declare the establishment of the Taiwan NPO Reading Alliance, to herald a new era of reading in Taiwan.

The delegates, led by the alliance's convener, Peter Mau-hsiu Yang, an associate professor of children's literature at National Taitung University, announced a "reading declaration" authored by writer Chien Chen.
According to the declaration, reading is the bedrock of a civil society. Reading enriches people's imagination, broadens their views and spurs their courage, it says.

In line with the purposes of the alliance's establishment, the members will share resources and render support to each other to help build reading habits and facilitate the alliance's further development, the declaration says.
Addressing the gathering, Education Minister Wu Ching-chi said he sees new hope for the country with Taiwan's NPOs stepping forward to promote reading.
He said reading is not an exclusive right reserved only for students. "Parents and adults should also read," he noted.
"People who read can see the whole world. Through reading, a man can see higher and farther, as if he is standing on the shoulders of a giant," Wu said.

Also speaking on the occasion, Lonnie Lin, a veteran NPO organizer, quoted a 2007 survey conducted by the Global View magazine as finding that the Taiwanese spend an average of 16.94 hours per week watching television and 7.41 hours on the Internet, but only 2.72 hours reading.
This means that the public spend less than 23 minutes a day reading, Lin said, adding that over half of Taiwan's adults are not in the habit of reading.
According to another survey, only 24 percent of Taiwan's 10-year-olds read for fun every day, a rate that was the lowest of its kind in a survey of 45 countries.

Noting that parents' attitudes toward reading have a direct impact on their children, Lin suggested that the alliance should regularly organize a series of activities every year to bolster reading habits in Taiwan.

DOC.HEADLINE: Taipei mayor, lawmaker emerge as KMT hopefuls in Taipei, Kaohsiung
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, April 19 (CNA) 04/19/10 18:21:00 (By Lee Su-hua and Y.L. Kao)

TEXT.P: Taipei Mayor Hau Lung-bin and Legislator Huang Chao-shun of the ruling Kuomintang (KMT) have beaten their rivals in public opinion surveys as to who should represent the party to run in the year-end elections for mayor of Taipei and Kaohsiung, respectively, KMT spokesman Su Jun-pin said Monday.

In Tainan City, two potential contenders -- former KMT lawmakers Lee Chuan-chiao and Kuo Tien-Tsai -- are within the statistical margin of error and either of them could emerge as the KMT's candidate in the mayoral race there, Su cited the results of another poll conducted by the KMT as saying.
The KMT held three opinion polls last week to gauge support for potential contenders seeking to run for the Taipei, Kaohsiung and Tainan mayoral seats.

As incumbent Taichung Mayor Jason Hu and Vice Premier Eric Liluan Chu are likely to be directly drafted by the KMT for the elections in Taichung City and Xinbei City, the KMT did not hold polls in those two cities.
Su said that KMT Secretary-General King Pu-tsung informed the potential contenders of the results of the polls but that the details will not be released to the public.

The survey results will be used by the party as references in its nominee selection procedure for candidates in the five special municipalities -- Taipei City, Xinbei City, Taichung City, Tainan City and Kaohsiung City -- in the Nov. 27 elections.
After the polls, KMT headquarters will coordinate among those party members who enjoy similar amounts of public support, in an effort to ensure that the best candidate is selected, according to Su.

DOC.HEADLINE: Imports of U.S. beef offal allowed if no internal organs included
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, April 19 (CNA) 04/19/10 18:26:23 (By Chen Ching-fang and Fanny Liu)

TEXT.P: After a local beef importer applied to import 453 kilograms of U.S. beef offal on April 15, health authorities said Monday that the applications will be approved as long as high-risk internal organs are not included.
It was the first application for importing U.S. beef offal since last November, according to the Web site of the Bureau of Foreign Trade under the Ministry of Economic Affairs (MOEA).

To help ease any lingering public doubt about U.S. beef products, the Department of Health (DOH) , the MOEA and the Council of Agriculture (COA) held a joint press conference earlier Monday to explain the existing standards.

Six types of beef offal such as beef tongues, penises, testicles, tails, tendons and skirt (diaphragm) are not classified as internal organs, so imports of those non-high-risk beef products will be accepted, they said.
The foreign trade bureau's Web site, however, does not provide details of beef offal products that the local business applied to import.
Legislators from the opposition Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) argued that the beef tongues and penises should be classified as internal organs, which would make them illegal to import.

The DOH said it decided last May that beef tongues are not classified as internal organs -- unlike thoracic, abdominal, and pelvic organs, which are not allowed into Taiwan under a protocol signed with Washington last October.
However, as the public appears to have doubts about beef tongues, imports require special permission and must also pass batch-by-batch inspection, DOH Deputy Minister Hsiao Mei-ling said.

Hsu Tien-lai, director general of the Bureau of Animal and Plant Health Inspection and Quarantine under the COA, said that high- risk circumvallate papillae, toward the base of the tongue, are required to be removed from beef tongues before entering Taiwan.
The first batch of the other beef parts will also be inspected batch- by-batch, but if they pass the checks, only 5 percent of the cases in subsequent shipments will be inspected, officials said.
According to MOEA statistics, over 210,000 kg of U.S. bone-in beef products have been imported since last November.

The U.S. announced last Friday that exports of beef products to Taiwan will include bone-in meat, hanging tenders, tongues, penises, testicles, tails, tendons and diaphragms from cattle younger than 30 months and slaughtered on or after April 1, seen as having a lower risk of carrying mad cow disease.

DOC.HEADLINE: Social workers blamed for not being active in saving lives
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, April 19 (CNA) 04/19/10 18:27:17 (By Hao Hsueh-chin, Chao Hung-chin and Elizabeth Hsu)

TEXT.P: Taichung Mayor Jason Hu instructed city officials and social workers Monday to be more active in handling reports of suicide attempts and to try harder to prevent tragedies.

Hu issued the directive after learning about a mother who took her own life and the life of her 13-year-old daughter by burning charcoal indoors, even though the daughter had attempted to find help upon learning that her mother wanted to kill them both.
The victims -- identified only by the surname Tsao -- lived in Taichung County's Taiping City, although their household registration was in Taichung City, central Taiwan.
The girl, who studied at a private boarding school in Nantou County, told teachers April 1 that her mother was preparing to commit suicide by burning charcoal.

Although the school attempted the following day to keep the girl at school, and contacted both the police and social workers to seek their assistance. Neither the police nor the social workers bothered to attend, however, and the school was forced to hand over the girl to her mother. Afterward, even when the child did not show up at school, social workers of both Nantou County and Taichung County made no contact with them until April 17, when police discovered their bodies at their home in Taiping City.

Hu expressed his regret and remorse, and questioned why the social workers and policemen responsible for the case did not break into the victims' home much sooner, since they were well aware of the mother's intention to commit suicide.
"A strong hand must be used in handling matters regarding human lives, " Hu said, criticizing those involved for "not being active enough" to prevent the loss of life.

Although the case occurred outside Taichung City, Hu said he had instructed the city's Bureau of Social Affairs to review its measures based on the tragedy. Social workers should not follow "regular rules when it is a possible matter of life and death," he pointed out.

Meanwhile, describing the case as a significant warning and reminder for social workers, Taichung City Department of Social Affairs Deputy Director Li Kun-ming said that if the girl had been forcibly taken from her mother, the tragedy would have been prevented.

However, he also acknowledged that in Taichung City, every social worker is tasked with handling an average of 100 cases or more at a time. " They are not omnipotent and it is a heavy burden to ask them to take full responsibility, " Li said.
A similar review and self-examination also began in the Taichung County Department of Social Affairs.

During a review meeting, department Director Wang Hsiu-yen acknowledged that the Tsaos' death reflects the fact that their social workers lack experience and professional judgment, and that defects exist in the reporting and communication system.

DOC.HEADLINE: St.Kitts upgrades representative's post to resident ambassador

TEXT.P: Taipei, April 19 (CNA The Republic of St. Christopher and Nevis, also known as St. Kitts, has upgraded the post of its representative to Taiwan from charge d'affaires to resident ambassador.
Jasmine Huggins, St. Kitts's first ambassador to Taiwan, presented her letters of credence to President Ma Ying-jeou Monday in Taipei.

Huggins said at a reception later in the day that her new appointment as ambassador extraordinary and plenipotentiary signals a deepening of the friendship between St. Kitts and Taiwan and is a significant milestone in her diplomatic career.

"When I was asked to come to Taiwan to establish the (St. Kitts) embassy in December 2007, I could not have imagined that my acceptance of that grave responsibility would have taken me on this remarkable journey that would grant me such enormous professional and personal satisfaction," she said.
"The beauty of this country, the richness of its culture and the warmth of its people quickly eroded any doubts that assailed me, and made a difficult task manageable."

The St. Kitts embassy in Taiwan was established 24 years after the two countries sealed diplomatic relations. The office was set up amid a growing trend of students from the Caribbean country coming to Taiwan to study.

Even so, there are only about 15 students from St. Kitts studying at universities in Taiwan at the moment. But Huggins said one of her aims is to expand this area of cooperation between Taiwan and St. Kitts.
"I shall endeavor to vigorously pursue the educational opportunities that exist in the Republic of China for the youths of the federation wishing to further their studies, " she pledged.

"Our people-to-people exchanges, whether political, cultural or educational, can only serve to foster understanding, engender respect and build lasting relationships that would serve us in good stead in years to come."

Another of the ambassador's stated priorities is to promote her country as a competitive market for investment opportunities in areas such as tourism, light manufacturing, information technology and agriculture.

"I will assiduously work to create partnerships that would bind our countries ever closer as we pursue the collective purpose of improving the quality of life for our citizens. So potential investors from Taiwan whose ideas and energies are in sync with those of our federation would find a welcoming and attractive business climate," she said.

At the reception, Hou Ping-fu, the director-general of the 3rd Bureau of the Presidential Office, described Huggins as a highly experienced diplomat who understands where the priorities lie in the relations between Taiwan and St. Kitts.
He said the frequent visits by high level officials between the two countries are an indication of the importance the two sides attach to the ties that they share.

St. Kitts and Taiwan established diplomatic relations in 1983, immediately after the Caribbean nation gained independence from Britain. The island country is one of Taiwan's five allies in the Caribbean region.

DOC.HEADLINE: Overseas offices gear up to help stranded Taiwanese in Europe
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, April 19 (CNA) 04/19/10 19:56:07 (By Lin Chang-shun and Sofia Wu)

TEXT.P: Taiwan's representative offices in Europe have geared up to help Taiwanese travelers stranded there due to the closure of many European airports over hazardous clouds of volcanic ash sweeping across the area from Iceland, an official said Monday.

Noting that many Taiwanese tour groups are stranded in Europe due to the grounding of so many flights there, Deputy Minister of Foreign Affairs Shen Lu- hsun said at a Legislative Yuan meeting that the Ministry of Foreign Affairs (MOFA) had stepped in to help with the situation.

"All of our representative offices in affected European areas, including Frankfurt, Brussels, Amsterdam and Edinburgh have mustered all of their staff to help our stranded compatriots, " Shen told lawmakers from the legislature's Committee on Foreign Affairs and National Defense.

For instance, Shen went on, all staff at the Frankfurt office have been working at the Frankfurt airport to help Taiwanese passport holders apply for provisional visas or entry permits, or to help those who need healthcare services to get treatment or medication.
Shen said the overseas offices will also offer maximum loans of US$500 to every passenger in need of financial aid.

Although there are fewer Taiwanese stuck in Edinburgh, Shen went on, staff at Taiwan's representative office there have also visited the airport to see whether any Taiwanese travelers are stranded and need help.

Shen said the MOFA issued a yellow travel alert immediately after becoming aware April 16 that clouds of volcanic ash spewing from an erupting volcano in Iceland had affected flight safety across a large swath of Europe.

According to the latest statistics released by the Tourism Bureau, 61 tour groups comprising 1,589 travelers assembled by 14 local travel agencies were still stranded in Europe as of noon Monday, some of which had been stranded for up to five days, travel sources said.

An executive with the Travel Quality Assurance Association advised people intending to visit Europe to postpone their travel plans until the summer, as flight services were not expected to return to normal any time soon.

DOC.HEADLINE: 21 whales beached in Kaohsiung; 17 rescued
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, April 19 (CNA) 04/19/10 20:05:42 (By Lin Shu-yuan and Fanny Liu)

TEXT.P: Rescuers from a whale rescue center said Monday that among a group of 21 pygmy killer whales found stranded at a harbor in southern Taiwan late the previous day, 17 had been rescued while four had died after a rescue operation lasting several hours.

According to the Forestry Bureau under the Council of Agriculture (COA) , which sponsors the rescue team from the Taijiang Cetacean Rescue Center, the whales were found at around 11 p.m. Sunday at Hsinda Harbor in Kaohsiung County.

The rescue team, which included about 80 people from the Coast Guard Administration, first tried to use speedboats to lead all 21 whales away from the coast, but only six of them made their way to the ocean.
Fifteen of the animals were later washed back onto the beach at around 3 a.m., by which time four had died. The remaining 11 whales were finally herded back out into the open ocean by the rescuers.

The causes for mass whale strandings of pygmy killer whales, which weigh between 110 kg and 170 kg and mostly live in tropical oceans, are still unknown, although scientists have cited climate change, seismic activity, or infestation by parasites, according to Forestry Bureau officials.

DOC.HEADLINE: 60,000 people awaiting rescue in China's quake-hit villages
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, April 19 (CNA) 04/19/10 20:10:59 (By Alex Jiang)

TEXT.P: A Taiwan-based Tibetan said Monday that many of the roughly 60,000 people in villages in China's quake-hit Yushu County had not received help in the past few days, even though Beijing had reportedly begun expanding the scope of rescue operations to cover the affected rural areas.

"The rescuers have been focusing on institutions, schools and markets in central Jiegu Township, but not the neighboring rural villages, " said Dawa Tsering, a representative of the Tibetan government-in-exile, in a telephone interview with CNA.

Yushu County has a total population of 100,000, 40,000 of whom live in the town with the remainder living in surrounding villages, noted Dawa, who is also the chairman of the Tibet Religious Foundation of His Holiness the Dalai Lama.
Jiegu is the area of the county that was hardest hit by a 7.1 magnitude earthquake April 14.
Hours after he made the remarks, however, China's Chinese-language Yangcheng Evening News reported that over 10,000 rescuers had moved from the city to surrounding rural areas.

Dawa, who has been in contact since the quake occurred with members of his family and friends in Yushu, which he left in 1992 at the age of 29, said his aunt's entire family of eight people were killed in the disaster.
He also said he learned from the people with whom he was in contact that the number of dead was far higher than official figures were suggesting.
The earthquake command headquarters in Yushu had updated the death toll to 1,944 as of 8 a.m. Monday.

DOC.HEADLINE: Libya eyes investment from Taiwan SMEs
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, April 19 (CNA) 04/19/10 20:45:05 (By Chris Wang)

TEXT.P: Libya is hoping for direct investment from Taiwan's small- and medium-sized enterprises (SMEs) as the North African country seeks to become the region's technology hub, visiting Libyan officials said at a seminar Monday.

Officials from the Libyan Economic Development Board (EDB) briefed dozens of Taiwanese businessmen on potential trade and investment opportunities in Libya, which has maintained warm relations with Taiwan in recent years despite the lack of official bilateral diplomatic ties.

EDB Director-General Mahmoud Gebril said the Libyan government launched a series of ambitious programs in 2007, many of which were designed by the EDB, to develop the country's modern infrastructure and "soft power," including education and technology.

Taiwan's SMEs, especially in the information and communication technology (ICT) sector, are welcome to invest in Libya and will play an important role in its national development if they do, Gebril said.

Mike Hung, chairman of the Taiwan-Africa Industry Development Association, said trade with Libya is more viable now that the United Nations (U.N.) has lifted its trade sanctions and bans on aircraft movements, oil exports and arm sales that were originally imposed over Libya's suspected terror links.
But he noted that Taiwanese businesses never stopped doing business with Tripoli during the time sanctions were in force because Libyan businessmen enjoyed good reputations.

Gebril, who insisted that the trip was private because of the sensitivity of Taiwan-China-Libya relations, encouraged Taiwan's SMEs to take advantage of the country's strategic geographic location, connecting the European Union (EU) , Africa and the Arab world and serving as a gateway to the African market.
He added that Tripoli would provide foreign investors with a wide range of incentives, such as tax exemptions in a special economic zone, to create a win- win situation for both parties.

Meanwhile, Taiwan is also hoping to strengthen its exchanges with Libya. Bilateral trade volume between the two countries grew by 2.7 percent last year, one of Taiwan's few trade relationships to show positive growth during the global economic slump, said Chang Shih-chang, Europe and Africa Section manager of the Taiwan External Trade Development Council (TAITRA), Taiwan's trade promotion agency.
In May 2006, then-Taiwan president Chen Shui-bian made a surprise visit to Tripoli, where he was greeted by Libyan leader Muammar Al-Gaddafi.

Saif Gaddafi, son of the leader, reportedly visited Taiwan prior to Chen's meeting with his father, who has ruled the country since 1969. The visit was dubbed as a "diplomatic breakthrough" by the Chen administration.

In addition to the ICT sector, Taiwan SMEs which specialize in the water purification, solar energy, machinery, infrastructure, hotel, and petrochemical sectors are also encouraged to invest, Hung said.
He also suggested that Taiwan's yacht manufacturers could take advantage of Libya's 1,770-kilometer coastline.

Libya has been keen to diversify its economy away from its traditionally heavy reliance on oil exports, Hung said, which is why Libya has announced plans to privatize more than 100 state-owned companies and encourage more foreign direct investment (FDI).

There are dozens of Taiwanese businessmen in Libya at present, Hung said. Taiwan's state-owned petrochemical giant CPC Corp. has just launched an oil exploration project this month after winning tenders on oil exploration rights in southern Libya, he said.

DOC.HEADLINE: Taiwanese carriers estimate small losses from canceled flights
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, April 19 (CNA) 04/19/10 21:14:10 (By Chao Hsiao-huei and Y.L. Kao)

TEXT.P: Though a massive cloud of volcanic ash hovering over northern Europe has disrupted global air travel, Taiwan's two major airlines said Monday that it would not have a major financial impact on their businesses.

Shares of China Airlines (CAL) and EVA Airways have plummeted over the past two trading days because of the air travel chaos. But spokesmen for the two carriers said that because Europe-bound air routes only constituted a small part of their operations, the suspension of flights to the region would not prove too costly.

CAL Director of Finance John Chang said that although the company has canceled 20 flights to and from Europe, leaving about 1,300 passengers stranded in Europe over the past few days, the continent accounts for only 7 percent of the company's flights.

A spokesman for EVA said that between April 15 and April 19, the company canceled 11 passenger flights and 5 cargo flights to and from Europe, affecting about 4,000-5,000 passengers, but the number is small compared to the 5 million passengers it serves every year.
The International Air Transport Association (IATA) estimated Friday that airlines around the world were suffering losses of more than US$200 million a day because of the volcanic eruption.
CAL said it had canceled flights from Frankfurt and Amsterdam to Taipei, as well as flights between Bangkok and Amsterdam through Monday but had resumed its flights between Bangkok and Taipei.
The carrier also canceled its Tuesday flights from Amsterdam to Bangkok and Taipei and between London and Taipei, but will resume its Taipei-Delhi-Rome and Rome-Delhi-Taipei flights.

EVA's flights between Bangkok and Vienna, London and Taipei and Paris and Taipei on Monday were all canceled, and all flights to and from Amsterdam and London through Bangkok scheduled for Tuesday have also been canceled.
EVA also called off its late night Bangkok-Taipei flight on April 21.
CAL reported later Monday that it would mobilize three passenger aircraft, including one from Taipei to Rome via Delhi, Tuesday, to take more than 850 passengers stranded in Europe home.
EVA will also apply to fly a Taipei-Bangkok-Vienna flight to help bring home its stranded passengers.

DOC.HEADLINE: Consumers' Foundation disagrees with beef diaphragm definition
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, April 19 (CNA) 04/19/10 21:48:39 (By Lin Hui-chun, Justin Su and Fanny Liu)

TEXT.P: The Consumers' Foundation criticized the government Monday for not classifying beef diaphragms as a high-risk internal organ and said the decision to allow the imports of the beef part was "unbelievable."

Foundation Chairman Hsieh Tien-jen said in an interview with the Central News Agency that the government's classification of diaphragms as something other than an internal organ was different from the perception of most people.

The U.S. announced last Friday that exports of beef products to Taiwan will include bone-in meat, hanging tenders, tongues, penises, testicles, tails, tendons and diaphragms from cattle younger than 30 months and slaughtered on or after April 1, which are seen as having a lower risk of carrying mad cow disease.

The announcement sparked controversy because some, including Hsieh, saw it as running counter to a measure passed by the Legislative Yuan in January that banned the import of U.S. ground beef and internal organs.

Hsieh said that aside from diaphragms, beef tongue and beef penis should also be classified as high-risk products. The World Organization for Animal Health (OIE) has considered designating the latter as a high-risk material, he added.
The foundation will continue to promote its petition drive to launch a referendum on rejecting high-risk beef products from the United States, Hsieh said.

While some legislators argued earlier on Monday that beef tongue and penis should be classified as internal organs, the Ministry of Economic Affairs (MOEA) explained in a written statement that the two were not classified as such.

The ministry cited a decision by the Department of Health (DOH) last May that beef tongue was not classified as an internal organ, unlike thoracic, abdominal, and pelvic organs, which are not allowed into Taiwan under a protocol signed with Washington last October.
To help ease any lingering public doubts about U.S. beef products, the DOH, the MOEA and the Council of Agriculture held a joint press conference earlier Monday.

They explained that six types of beef offal announced by the U.S. last Friday (tongues, penises, testicles, tails, tendons and diaphragms) are not classified as internal organs and imports of those non-high-risk beef parts would therefore be accepted.

DOC.HEADLINE: New top prosecutor vows to stave off political interference
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, April 19 (CNA) 04/19/10 22:01:10 (By Lin Chang-shun and Sofia Wu)

TEXT.P: Taiwan's new top prosecutor pledged Monday not to yield to political pressure or interference in criminal investigations and prosecution.
Huang Shih-ming made the vow as he was sworn in as the state public prosecutor general in a ceremony overseen by Minister of Justice Tseng Yung-fu.
With the judicial system's credibility under fire, Huang said the country's prosecutorial system is encountering far harsher challenges than before.
"But I will not be daunted by any tribulation that may lie ahead and will go all out to fulfill my mission as the country's top prosecutor and the public's top prosecutor, " Huang said.

The new chief prosecutor said his top priority will be to forge a new image of prosecutorial personnel by defending the rule of law, ensuring respect for due process, being impartial in exercising judicial power, and getting rid of political interference in criminal investigations and indictment.
Under his leadership, Huang said, prosecutors will not waver under political pressure.

He also promised to initiate reforms in a number of areas, including improving prosecutors' attitudes toward criminal suspects, respecting the interests of the accused, and preserving confidentiality during investigations.

Huang said he will also push prosecutors to exercise greater prudence in initiating searches, confiscations and seizures, encourage speedy conclusions of criminal investigation, and work to improve the conviction rate.

He further said that he will insist that chief prosecutors closely monitor and supervise criminal investigations and that they will be held accountable if there is any dereliction of duty or malfeasance involving prosecutors under their oversight.
Huang succeeds Chen Tsung-ming, who resigned Jan. 19 after being impeached by the watchdog Control Yuan over dereliction of official duty and lack of moral integrity.

Some prosecutors of the Special Investigation Division (SID) , which headed the investigation into corruption allegations against former President Chen Shui- bian, applied to return to their original work units after Chen Tsung-ming's resignation.

Asked about whether the SID will undergo a partial or an overall personnel reshuffle, Huang said he will come to a decision only after talking to SID prosecutors on Tuesday about personnel issues and major cases under investigation.

On the corruption cases involving the former president, Huang said he will see to it that prosecutors make every possible effort to seek foreign assistance in having the Chen family's overseas slush funds returned back to Taiwan's national coffers.

DOC.HEADLINE: Microsoft to launch cloud computing center in Taiwan in June
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, April 19 (CNA) 04/19/10 22:08:20 (By Alex Jiang)

TEXT.P: Software giant Microsoft Corp. is due to launch a cloud computing services research center in collaboration with Taiwan's economic ministry sometime around June, a visiting Microsoft executive said Monday.

"We've been having several meetings with the MOEA (Ministry of Economic Affairs) and I guess what I could announce here is we are well underway with launching something called the Microsoft Software and Services Excellence Center," said John Kalkman, vice president of OEM Engineering and Services at Microsoft.
At the moment, the project is under review, he said at a press meet in Taipei.
"We look to launch this around the Computex timeframe, " he said, referring to the world's second largest information and communications technology (ICT) trade show annually held in Taipei.

Microsoft seeks to provide software and service support to Taiwanese companies, which excel at designing and making hardware in the field of cloud computing, the Taiwan branch of the U.S. company said in a press release.
Cloud computing means that users entrust technology companies with online data storage and applications.

Microsoft launched a cloud computing service in Taiwan with the country's largest telecom operator Chunghwa Telecom Co. April 1, which is targeting 400,000 small- and medium-sized companies in Taiwan, the statement said.
Microsoft is also eyeing local schools. Kalkman revealed that details on projects with a couple of major universities related to their administrative systems will be made public later this spring.

DOC.HEADLINE: Government plans to invest NT$17 billion on cloud computing by 2014
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, April 19 (CNA) 04/19/10 22:32:48 (By Hsieh Chun-wei and Fanny Liu)

TEXT.P: The government is planning to increase its budget for supporting the development of cloud computing by nearly 70 percent to NT$17 billion (US$540 million) by 2014, an Industrial Development Bureau (IDB) official said Monday.

Addressing a seminar on cloud computing, IDB section chief Lu Cheng-hua said the government would like to spend NT$17 billion within four years -- instead of the NT$10.1 billion planned in February -- to encourage the growth of the cloud computing sector, mostly by investing in infrastructure.

If cloud computing, which refers to outsourcing online data storage and applications, becomes a trend and lowers the demand for hardware, it will adversely impact Taiwan's manufacturing industry, which has a high concentration of OEM and ODM contractors, Lu acknowledged.

The challenge, however, may also bring opportunities, Lu said. The government is trying to develop cloud computing services and devices by targeting six emerging industries -- tourism, medicine and health care, biotechnology, green energy, cultural and creative enterprises, and specialty agriculture.

Chen Yu-te, a manager of the Industrial Economics & Knowledge Center under the Industrial Technology Research Institute (ITRI) , also suggested at the seminar that the medical, financial and manufacturing sectors in Taiwan should put more effort into developing cloud computing.

In a bid to grab a share of the growing cloud computing market, more than 50 companies in Taiwan's information and communications technology (ICT) and service industries launched an alliance early this month.

DOC.HEADLINE: Cabinet reverses plan for Hsinchu biomedical park
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, April 19 (CNA) 04/19/10 23:02:29 (By Lin Juei-yi and Y.L. Kao)

TEXT.P: The Executive Yuan decided Monday to suspend a plan to set up an anti-epidemic center and develop international medical services at a planned biomedical science park in Hsinchu County, after the plan drew opposition from local residents.

The decision was made at a meeting to discuss the plan hosted by Premier Wu Den- yih and attended by representatives from the county government, county council, universities and academic institutions, according to ruling Kuomintang Legislator Chao Li-yun, who was present at the meeting.

Local representatives expressed strong opposition to the initiative, under which the Department of Health was to set up an anti-epidemic center and give priority to developing medical tourism at the park.

They argued it ran counter to a county government initiative to establish a national-level hospital in the park to provide care to patients with acute diseases in the Miaoli and Hsinchu area, according to Chao.
Hsinchu County Magistrate Chiu Ching-chun told Wu that a medical center should be established at the park to protect the lives of the 2 million residents in the Greater Hsinchu area.

Hsinchu County Councilor Chen Chien-hsien added that the quality of medical care received by residents in the county ranks second to last in the country, and stressed that it has an immediate need for a large medical center with more than 500 beds.
The Executive Yuan decided to suspend the plan at the meeting even though the contract for the center's design had already been tendered out, Chao said.
Planning for the park has been under way since 2001.

DOC.HEADLINE: Cabinet regrets DPP's brush-off of ECFA information
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, April 19 (CNA) 04/19/10 23:13:34 (By Wen Kuei-hsiang, Lee Shu-hua and Lilian Wu)

TEXT.P: The Executive Yuan said Monday that it regretted the opposition Democratic Progressive Party's (DPP's) rejection of information on a cross-strait trade pact provided by the Cabinet ahead of a debate on the issue.

The Cabinet was responding to a DPP statement in which the party reacted with disdain to information it received from the government on the cross-strait economic cooperation framework agreement (ECFA).
"We asked for an apple, but we got a guava," the DPP said.
The DPP also said the documents would be thrown into the recycling bin rather than relayed to DPP Chairwoman Tsai Eng-wen to avoid wasting her time.
Executive Yuan spokesman Johnny Chiang said the DPP's statement was regrettable, and indicated that if Tsai was not satisfied, she could return the documents rather than throw them away.
"Is this how an opposition party should act? " Chiang asked.

Tsai will debate President Ma Ying-jeou on the merits of the ECFA on April 25. To prepare for the showdown, the DPP requested access to a number of documents, including the early harvest list proposed by the government, the draft of the agreement, and any government- commissioned ECFA assessment reports.
At Ma's request, the Cabinet provided the information on the proposed trade pact, but said it withheld the details on Taiwan's early harvest list.
Chen Ching-tsai, deputy secretary-general of the Executive Yuan, carried the more than 500 pages of information to the DPP in the afternoon.

DPP spokesman Tsai Chi-chang said the documents included reports given by the Mainland Affairs Council (MAC) and the Ministry of Economic Affairs at the legislature, the information posted on the MAC Web site, the news releases and public opinion polls.

Tsai said the government has vowed to sign the ECFA in June, but the public does not have any access to the content of the pact, and "the party wants to know on what basis both sides are negotiating the deal."

Microsoft launched a cloud computing service in Taiwan with the country's largest telecom operator Chunghwa Telecom Co. April 1, which is targeting 400,000 small- and medium-sized companies in Taiwan, the statement said.
Microsoft is also eyeing local schools. Kalkman revealed that details on projects with a couple of major universities related to their administrative systems will be made public later this spring.

DOC.HEADLINE: Government plans to invest NT$17 billion on cloud computing by 2014
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, April 19 (CNA) 04/19/10 22:32:48 (By Hsieh Chun-wei and Fanny Liu)

TEXT.P: The government is planning to increase its budget for supporting the development of cloud computing by nearly 70 percent to NT$17 billion (US$540 million) by 2014, an Industrial Development Bureau (IDB) official said Monday.

Addressing a seminar on cloud computing, IDB section chief Lu Cheng-hua said the government would like to spend NT$17 billion within four years -- instead of the NT$10.1 billion planned in February -- to encourage the growth of the cloud computing sector, mostly by investing in infrastructure.

If cloud computing, which refers to outsourcing online data storage and applications, becomes a trend and lowers the demand for hardware, it will adversely impact Taiwan's manufacturing industry, which has a high concentration of OEM and ODM contractors, Lu acknowledged.

The challenge, however, may also bring opportunities, Lu said. The government is trying to develop cloud computing services and devices by targeting six emerging industries -- tourism, medicine and health care, biotechnology, green energy, cultural and creative enterprises, and specialty agriculture.

Chen Yu-te, a manager of the Industrial Economics & Knowledge Center under the Industrial Technology Research Institute (ITRI) , also suggested at the seminar that the medical, financial and manufacturing sectors in Taiwan should put more effort into developing cloud computing.

In a bid to grab a share of the growing cloud computing market, more than 50 companies in Taiwan's information and communications technology (ICT) and service industries launched an alliance early this month.

DOC.HEADLINE: Cabinet reverses plan for Hsinchu biomedical park
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, April 19 (CNA) 04/19/10 23:02:29 (By Lin Juei-yi and Y.L. Kao)

TEXT.P: The Executive Yuan decided Monday to suspend a plan to set up an anti-epidemic center and develop international medical services at a planned biomedical science park in Hsinchu County, after the plan drew opposition from local residents.

The decision was made at a meeting to discuss the plan hosted by Premier Wu Den- yih and attended by representatives from the county government, county council, universities and academic institutions, according to ruling Kuomintang Legislator Chao Li-yun, who was present at the meeting.

Local representatives expressed strong opposition to the initiative, under which the Department of Health was to set up an anti-epidemic center and give priority to developing medical tourism at the park.

They argued it ran counter to a county government initiative to establish a national-level hospital in the park to provide care to patients with acute diseases in the Miaoli and Hsinchu area, according to Chao.
Hsinchu County Magistrate Chiu Ching-chun told Wu that a medical center should be established at the park to protect the lives of the 2 million residents in the Greater Hsinchu area.

Hsinchu County Councilor Chen Chien-hsien added that the quality of medical care received by residents in the county ranks second to last in the country, and stressed that it has an immediate need for a large medical center with more than 500 beds.
The Executive Yuan decided to suspend the plan at the meeting even though the contract for the center's design had already been tendered out, Chao said.
Planning for the park has been under way since 2001.

DOC.HEADLINE: Cabinet regrets DPP's brush-off of ECFA information
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, April 19 (CNA) 04/19/10 23:13:34 (By Wen Kuei-hsiang, Lee Shu-hua and Lilian Wu)

TEXT.P: The Executive Yuan said Monday that it regretted the opposition Democratic Progressive Party's (DPP's) rejection of information on a cross-strait trade pact provided by the Cabinet ahead of a debate on the issue.

The Cabinet was responding to a DPP statement in which the party reacted with disdain to information it received from the government on the cross-strait economic cooperation framework agreement (ECFA).
"We asked for an apple, but we got a guava," the DPP said.
The DPP also said the documents would be thrown into the recycling bin rather than relayed to DPP Chairwoman Tsai Eng-wen to avoid wasting her time.
Executive Yuan spokesman Johnny Chiang said the DPP's statement was regrettable, and indicated that if Tsai was not satisfied, she could return the documents rather than throw them away.
"Is this how an opposition party should act? " Chiang asked.

Tsai will debate President Ma Ying-jeou on the merits of the ECFA on April 25. To prepare for the showdown, the DPP requested access to a number of documents, including the early harvest list proposed by the government, the draft of the agreement, and any government- commissioned ECFA assessment reports.
At Ma's request, the Cabinet provided the information on the proposed trade pact, but said it withheld the details on Taiwan's early harvest list.
Chen Ching-tsai, deputy secretary-general of the Executive Yuan, carried the more than 500 pages of information to the DPP in the afternoon.

DPP spokesman Tsai Chi-chang said the documents included reports given by the Mainland Affairs Council (MAC) and the Ministry of Economic Affairs at the legislature, the information posted on the MAC Web site, the news releases and public opinion polls.

Tsai said the government has vowed to sign the ECFA in June, but the public does not have any access to the content of the pact, and "the party wants to know on what basis both sides are negotiating the deal."

DOC.HEADLINE: Today in history
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, April 20 (CNA) 04/20/10 08:59:33
DOC.TEXT:
Today is Tuesday, April 20, 2010, or the 7th day of the third month of the Year of the Tiger according to the lunar calendar. Following is a list of important events that have occurred on this date in the past:
1526: Baber, or Zahir ud-Din Mohammed, leads 2,000 Moguls to victory over 10,000 Muslims and 100 elephants under Ibrahim at the battle of Panipat. The conqueror of India later captured Delhi and Agra and founded the Mogul dynasty.
1657: Jews in New Amsterdam (now New York City) are granted equal rights and privileges as citizens.
1836: The U.S. Congress officially separates the western part of the Michigan Territory, creating a new zone known as the Wisconsin Territory.
1859: Holland concludes a treaty granting Portugal the right to govern the eastern part of Timor as well as Atauro Island and Oecussi.
1889: Adolf Hitler, house painter and subsequently German dictator who founded the National Socialist (Nazi) Party and was the architect of World War II, is born in Austria.
1908: Taiwan's West Coast Railway Trunk Line from Keelung to Kaohsiung, with a total length of 405 kilometers, is opened to traffic.
1916: The Taipei Yuanshan Zoo is inaugurated.
1933: President Franklin D. Roosevelt removes the United States from the gold standard.
1944: Britain's Royal Air Force drops a record 4,500 tons of bombs on Germany in a single raid.
1945: Soviet troops penetrate Berlin defenses.
1950: The Taiwan Garrison Command Headquarters is established, with Gen. Sun Li-jen serving at its first commander.
1957: Japan protests against nuclear testing by the Soviet Union.
1968: Pierre Elliot Trudeau of the Liberal Party becomes the 15th prime minister of Canada.
1970: President Richard M. Nixon announces the withdrawal of 150,000 U.S. military personnel from South Vietnam.
1974: The Republic of China announces the termination of Taiwan-Japan flights by China Airlines and Japan Airlines after Japan and mainland China sign an air pact in Beijing.
1978: Soviet warplanes force an off-course South Korean airliner down in the Soviet Union near the Arctic Circle, killing two passengers aboard and injuring 13 others.
1984: Britain announces that its administration of Hong Kong will cease in 1997 when the colony is returned to mainland China.
1986: A reservoir bursts and floods a Sri Lankan town, killing 100 people and making some 20,000 families homeless.
1990: Soviet troops storm Lithuania's state printing works after Mikhail Gorbachev cuts off 85 percent of gas supplies to the rebellious republic.
1996: World leaders meeting in Moscow agree to cooperate on increasing nuclear safety.
1999: Taiwan's Council of Agriculture rejects a call from South Korea for a resumption of reciprocal trade in fruit between the two countries.
1999: Defense Minister Tang Fei denies a U.S. media report that the Republic of China plans to develop medium range missiles.
2000: Central News Agency President Bill Wang says that CNA will shortly add a commercial information databank to its Internet services.
2000: National Yang Ming University President Tseng Chih-lang announces that he has decided to accept President-elect Chen Shui-bian's offer of the post of education minister in the new administration.
2001: Japanese Foreign Minister Yohei Kono announces that Japan will issue a visa to former ROC President Lee Teng-hui to seek medical treatment for his heart condition.
Confucius' lesson of the day: "A man who does not anticipate deceit nor imagine untrustworthiness, but who can readily detect their presence, must be a very superior man."
