DOC.HEADLINE: Taiwan to host int'l conference on health promotion
DOC.DATELINE: London, April 19 (CNA) 04/20/10 11:25:36 (By Jennifer Huang and Deborah Kuo)

TEXT.P: Taiwan has been awarded the right to host the 2012 conference of the International Network of Health Promoting Hospitals and Health Services (HPH), a network initiated by the World Health Organization, a Taiwan health official said Monday.

The International HPH Network -- established based on the health promotion philosophy of the WHO as outlined in the WHO Ottawa Charter for Health Promotion -- recently held its 2010 conference in Manchester, England. Its next conference, in 2011, will be held in Finland.

The network, of which Taiwan has been a member since 2006, decided at the Manchester conference that its 2012 conference will be held in Taipei, the first time its annual meeting will be held outside Europe, said Shu-ti Chiou, director-general of the Bureau of Health Promotion under the Cabinet-level Department of Health.
Chiou led a Taiwan delegation to the April 14-16 Manchester conference, which brought together more than 600 health officials and medical professionals from 39 countries.

Citing the Ottawa Charter, Chiou said the role of the health sector should go beyond its responsibility to provide clinical and curative services and embrace an expanded mandate that is sensitive and respects cultural needs.

This mandate should support the needs of individuals and communities for a healthier life and open channels between the health sector and broader social, political, economic and physical environmental components, Chiou said.
"The mandate is coincidentally in line with that of Taiwan's health culture," she told the Central News Agency.
Chiou initiated Taiwan's HPH Network in 2006 and has since headed the organization that now comprises 61 hospitals.
The Taiwan HPH Network was the first of its kind in Asia and is one of the three largest networks in the world, according to Chiou.
Member hospitals of the Taiwan HPH Network submitted 74 papers to this year's international conference, the most of any member country, she said.

Chiou, who holds a Ph.D. in epidemiology from National Taiwan University and formerly served as director of Taipei City's Department of Health, was elected to the supervisory board of the International HPH Network in 2008 and is responsible for promoting the network's influence and operations in Asia.

DOC.HEADLINE: U.S. criticizes Taiwan for tighter inspection of beef tongue
DOC.DATELINE: Washington, April 19 (CNA) 04/20/10 11:56:29 (By Zep Hu and Elizabeth Hsu)

TEXT.P: The Office of the United States Trade Representative (USTR) said Monday that it was "deeply disappointed" with Taiwan's decision to require much stricter inspection procedures for beef tongue imported from the U.S.

Taiwan's actions are not consistent with a bilateral protocol signed last Oct. 22, under which Taiwan agreed to lift its ban on U.S. bone-in beef and certain other beef products, the USTR told the Central News Agency in response to an e-mail request for comment on the issue.

Last Friday, the U.S. Food Safety and Inspection Service announced that exports of beef products to Taiwan will include bone-in meat, hanging tenders, tongues, penises, testicles, tails, tendons and diaphragms from cattle younger than 30 months and slaughtered on or after April 1, which are seen as having a lower risk of carrying mad cow disease.

The announcement came after a Taiwanese beef importer applied to import 453 kilograms of U.S. beef offal on April 15, the first application to import such products since last November when Taiwan opened its market wider to U.S. beef producers.
The application triggered controversy in Taiwan over how beef offal should be defined and what parts should be considered as high risk and barred from entry into Taiwan.

The Legislative Yuan passed a measure in January that bars imports of U.S. beef products classified as "internal organs, " but the term was not clearly defined, and some believed the items listed in the USTR announcement should be included as part of the "internal organ" ban.

Taiwan's government argued Monday, however, that the six types of beef offal on the USTR list (tongues, penises, testicles, tails, tendons and diaphragms) are not classified as internal organs, so imports of those non-high-risk beef products will be accepted.

But acknowledging that public doubts linger over beef tongue, the government said imports of the product would require a special import permit and would have to pass batch-by-batch inspections, a decision not welcomed in Washington.

"We are pleased that Taiwan authorities have clarified that beef tongues and a number of other beef products are not considered internal organs, and are eligible for export to Taiwan, " the USTR told CNA.

But "we remain deeply disappointed that Taiwan has taken action that are not consistent with our bilateral protocol, " which the USTR said "was negotiated in good faith with Taiwan and is consistent with science and the guidelines laid out by the World Organization for Animal Health and Taiwan's own risk assessment that found that all U.S. beef and beef products are safe."
USTR stated that Taiwan's actions will be reviewed carefully, and that it will utilize all appropriate tools to resolve the issue.
Deputy Minister of Foreign Affairs Shen Lyu-shun had said on Monday that the U.S. "acted unilaterally" in opening beef tongue for export, but the USTR said that was not the case.

The U.S. Department of Agriculture "has merely updated the export library on its website based on information received from Taiwan authorities as to which beef products are permitted for export, " the U.S. trade office said.

In answering a question on whether it has requested or will request consultations to review the implementation of the U.S.-Taiwan protocol on beef, the office replied that the U.S. and Taiwan have had regular consultations on the workings of the protocol.
"Both sides have agreed to continue to consult as needed to discuss the operation of the protocol and inspection and quarantine issues relating to U.S beef exports to Taiwan." it said.

DOC.HEADLINE: Talk of the day: Standardized house sale contracts to be launched
DOC.DATELINE: 04/20/10 12:25:29 (By Maubo Chang)

TEXT.P: A standardized contract aimed at enhancing transparency in residential property transactions will be launched on May 1.
The following are excerpts of the Liberty Times coverage of the story. Liberty Times:

A standardized contract that assigns separate prices to an apartment's main living area, its attached balconies and terraces, and its share of common space for presold residential units is set to be launched on May 1.
Interior Minister Jiang Yi-huah warned real estate developers to abide by the decree, because his ministry is determined to enforce it.

The standardized contract, which obliges the sellers to list the price for an apartment's main living area and attached structures separately, is meant primarily to protect home buyers rather than to check rising real estate prices, the minister said.
"It is vital to buyers of houses that have not yet been finished," he said.
Developers who fail to abide by the directive will be referred to Taiwan's consumer regulatory agency for possible punishment, Jiang said.
He added that the Consumer Protection Commission is drafting a revision to the Consumer Protection Act to impose a fine of up to NT$200,000 on developers who flaunt the rules.
"Don't test our determination to protect the consumers." the minister warned.

Ministry of the Interior official Wang Ching-hsiu said the next step is to require the sellers of existing houses to follow suit by listing the price of the main living area and attached structures separately.

At the same time, the ministry is also considering excluding contentious parts of the house often priced as part of the main living area, such as balconies and terraces, from an apartment's formally registered floor space, she said.

Under the standardized contract for presold units, the seller and buyer will be required to pay or return the difference in price when the main living area of the house is more than 1 percent smaller or bigger, respectively, than the floor space listed in the contract.

For presold houses sold through installment payments, the payment of each installment should be at least 20 days apart, and buyers may cancel the contract within five days after taking delivery of the apartment. (April 20, 2010)

DOC.HEADLINE: China Times: Don't make a farce of Formosa movement
DOC.DATELINE: Former Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) 04/20/10 12:47:47 (By Y.F. Low)

TEXT.P: Chairman Shih Ming-teh -- one of the victims of the political trials following the 1979 Formosa Incident that pushed for Taiwan's democratization -- alleged recently that the lawyers who defended the political defendents might have been "secret agents" serving the then-authoritarian Kuomintang government.

Some of the former Formosa Incident lawyers might have betrayed their ideals after making a career switch to politics, but this cannot be interpreted as evidence that the Formosa democratic movement was sold out from the beginning.

Those who are accused by Shih of being "stool pigeons" should take positive action to restore history, such as making public how the legal team was formed and operated and compiling an oral history on the incident.

Following Taiwan's democratization, Taiwanese voters rapidly did justice to Formosa movement participants by electing them to public office. Therefore, many of the Formosa Incident victims have to some extent become beneficiaries. On the contrary, this chapter of history could become a victim itself, and the DPP should not take Shih's accusation lightly. (April 20, 2010)

DOC.HEADLINE: Taiwan Railways Administration to offer low-carbon library
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, April 20 (CNA) 04/20/10 13:06:28 (By Wang Shu-fen and Deborah Kuo)

TEXT.P: A low-emission public library that will enable passengers to check out books before getting on the train will be launched April 22 on Earth Day 2010, the Taiwan Railways Administration (TRA) said Tuesday.

The environmentally friendly library, located in the lobby of Banciao Railway Station, will be open from 7 a.m. to 10 p.m. year round to all members of the public, the TRA said. A Taipei MRT EasyCard will be needed for admission.

Established and run jointly by the Taipei County government and Taipei County Public Library, the library will be the first in Taiwan to be located in a transportation hub that serves the traditional railway, an MRT system and Taiwan's high-speed railway, the TRA said.
The library will be fully automated, featuring a digital round-the-clock monitoring system. Books will be able to checked out and returned automatically, without the help of a library clerk.
The facility itself is also a low-carbon environment, with its lighting and air conditioning systems designed to limit carbon emissions and optimize efficiency, according to the TRA.
The railway administration suggested that passengers can borrow books before boarding trains and return the books when they arrive back at the station later in the day after school or work.

Taiwan's train network is not the only group eager to promote reading throughout the country. Delegates of more than 100 nonprofit organizations gathered Monday to declare the establishment of the Taiwan NPO Reading Alliance.
The campaign, aimed at driving up Taiwan's low reading rate, was also launched to coincide with World Book and Copyright Day on April 23.
Addressing the gathering, Education Minister Wu Ching-ji said he sees new hope for the country with Taiwan's NPOs stepping forward to promote reading.
He said reading is not an exclusive right reserved only for students, but one that parents and adults should also take advantage of.
"People who read can see the whole world. Through reading, a man can see higher and farther, as if he is standing on the shoulders of a giant," Wu said.
A 2007 survey conducted by Global Views magazine found that Taiwanese spend an average of 16.94 hours per week watching television and 7.41 hours on the Internet, but only 2.72 hours reading.
This translates to less than 23 minutes a day reading, which is not surprising since over half of Taiwan's adults are not in the habit of reading, said Lonnie Lin, a veteran NPO organizer.

DOC.HEADLINE: Taiwan not violating protocol on U.S. beef import: health official
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, April 20 (CNA) 04/20/10 13:54:08 (By Chen Ching-fang and Elizabeth Hsu)

TEXT.P: Taiwan did not violate its bilateral protocol on beef imports with the United States by tightening inspection procedures, as Washington has charged, the deputy minister of the Department of Health (DOH) said Tuesday.

The Office of U.S Trade Representative said Monday that Taiwan's decision to inspect imported U.S. beef tongue batch-by-batch was inconsistent with the protocol, but the DOH's Hsiao Mei-ling disagreed, saying that the protocol allows Taiwan to impose measures to control U.S. beef at borders.

Hsiao explained that in the second article of the protocol -- which opened Taiwan's market to imports of U.S. bone-in-beef and other beef parts -- the U.S. side promised that Taiwan's inspection and quarantine procedures would be respected.

The article authorizes Taiwan's control measures of "three controls" and "five certifications, " as well as the provisions of the Act Governing Food Sanitation Act, Hsiao said, reiterating that Taiwan has done nothing to violate the terms of the protocol.

The measures set controls on beef imports at the source, at borders and in markets. The five certifications include verifying certification documents and checking that shipments are marked with detailed product information.
They also involve opening a high percentage of cartons of imported beef to check the product, conducting food safety tests and being able to get information on suspected problem products immediately.

Both the DOH and the Ministry of Economic Affairs (MOEA) said at a joint press conference the previous day that certain beef offal items allowed to be imported to Taiwan -- including tongues, penises, testicles, tails, tendons and diaphragms -- should come from among 40 U.S. government-certified butchers.

Once tongue imports arrive, they will be subject to batch-by-batch inspections. The same complete check will also be used for other imported beef cuts, but if they pass the checks, only 5 percent of the cartons in subsequent shipments will be inspected, officials said.
The DOH and the MOEA's Bureau of Foreign Trade held another press conference Tuesday, adding diaphragms and testicles to beef tongue as items that will undergo strict batch-by-batch checks.

Bureau Director-General Huang Chih-peng said the importer who applied on April 15 to import 453 kilograms of beef tongue and diaphragms -- which started the controversy -- had called the bureau to withdraw an application for an import permit, saying the goods had yet to be shipped by the supplier.

DOC.HEADLINE: AIT reaffirms safety of U.S. beef imports
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, April 20 (CNA) 04/20/10 14:32:00 (By Chris Wang)

TEXT.P: The safety of U.S. beef, especially new items that were added to the import list this month, is guaranteed, the top U.S. official in Taiwan said Tuesday as he tried to diffuse a new controversy over U.S. beef that he contended was created by local politicians.

"What's now being talked about being imported were not part of the 13 items that were excluded specifically by the amendment that was passed by the Legislature Yuan, " said William Stanton, the director of the American Institute in Taiwan (AIT) Taipei Office.

The controversy arose after the U.S. Department of Agriculture's Food Safety and Inspection Service (FSIS) announced last Friday that exports of beef products to Taiwan will include bone-in meat, hanging tenders, tongues, penises, testicles, tails, tendons and diaphragms from cattle younger than 30 months and slaughtered on or after April 1, which are seen as having a lower risk of carrying mad cow disease.

Local politicians and the Consumers' Foundation chairman criticized Taiwan's government Monday for not classifying beef diaphragms as a high-risk internal organ and said the decision to allow the imports of the beef part was "unbelievable."

They argued that the new announcement runs counter to a measure passed by the Legislative Yuan in January that banned the import of U.S. ground beef and internal organs and insisted that beef tongue and testicles should also be listed as "internal organs."
Stanton said that in English, all of the items are referred to as offal, while a distinction exists in Chinese between "offal" and "internal organ."
Beef tongue, he said, "meets the definition as defined by Taiwan law, by its amendment, and by our agreement, so there really shouldn't be any problem."
"It's unfortunate that I think that some people for political reasons are making this into an issue again, and it should not be, " he added.

Stanton said that he himself eats beef tongue, the most talked about item in the controversy, and noted that beef tongue has never being excluded by anyone nor was it excluded by the U.S.-Taiwan agreement.

Taiwan's inspection process is a matter for Taiwan to decide, he said, so long as it is not inconsistent with its agreement with the U.S. Meanwhile, the U.S. is confident that all its beef is safe and passed inspection in the U.S., he said.
Shen Lyushun, Taiwan's deputy minister of foreign affairs, told legislators Monday that the new measure was "a unilateral action implemented by the U.S."
In response, Stanton said he "didn't think the particular statement accurately reflected the foreign ministry's point of view."

DOC.HEADLINE: AIT announces Taiwan finalists for 2010 democracy video challenge
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, April 20 (CNA) 04/20/10 14:38:06 (By Chris Wang)

TEXT.P: Three short films were chosen as Taiwan's finalists for the 2010 Democracy Video Challenge, the American Institute in Taiwan (AIT) announced at an awards ceremony Tuesday.

The Democracy Video Challenge, a worldwide U.S. Department of State competition, asks filmmakers, democracy advocates, and the general public to create three- minute videos that complete the phrase, "Democracy is..."

"We thank these young filmmakers for taking part in the Democracy Video Challenge, and for sharing their talents and perspectives with us, " said William Stanton, the director of the American Institute in Taiwan (AIT) Taipei office.
"Democracy is but one of many key fundamental values shared by the United States and Taiwan, and I am pleased by the level of dialogue on this issue that the Challenge attracted," he added.
Stanton and Taiwan Foundation for Democracy President Huang Teh-Fu presented certificates and awarded prizes of NT$10,000 each to Ho Sen-yi, Lin Yu-sheng and Lai Yu-yao for their films.

According to the AIT, the competition received 17 submissions this year in Taiwan. One of the Taiwan finalists was chosen through voting by AIT's Facebook fans, while the other two were chosen by a panel.
A total of 470 entries from 88 countries were received by the American government this year.
The three films from Taiwan are now being evaluated by a panel of judges in the U.S., the AIT said, and are eligible to be chosen as among the finalists for the East Asia and Pacific region.
The winning videos will be selected by global online voting between May 15 to June 15. The video platform will be provided by YouTube.

The Challenge will honor seven winning videos worldwide, with one winner each from Sub-Saharan Africa, East Asia and the Pacific, Europe, the Near East and North Africa, South and Central Asia, and the Western Hemisphere, and one anonymous video winner.

DOC.HEADLINE: 'Taiwan's Susan Boyle' in L.A. for TV talk show appearances
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, April 20 (CNA) 04/20/10 14:57:47 (By Huang Hui-min and Deborah Kuo)

TEXT.P: Lin Yu-chun, a local talent show contestant who has been described as "Taiwan's Susan Boyle, " is now in Los Angeles where he will appear on two major talk shows, an entertainment source said Tuesday.

Lin, 24, will be interviewed on The Ellen DeGeneres Show and the Lopez Tonight show hosted by George Lopez April 20 U.S. time, according to A-List Entertainment, a company that produces top singers, stars, models and entertainers in Taiwan.
Lin became an overnight Internet hit, capturing the attention of Internet viewers worldwide with his rendition of Whitney Houston's "I Will Always Love You."
The video of his performance on the Taiwan talent show "Million Star" went viral shortly after it was posted on YouTube on April 6. The video has since had close to 2 million hits.
According to an article on Yahoo! TV Blog, Lin's rendition was "a near-perfect sound-alike of Whitney Houston's original, with barely a hint of an accent."
A-List said that Lin's voice is also ideal for the songs of Ella Fitzgerald, one of greatest jazz singers of all time.
Lin has received a flood of invitations from Japan, the United States and South Korea, according to A-List.

While in Los Angeles, Lin, who has been called "Little Fatty" since he was small, will tour the Kodak Theatre in Hollywood, the new home of the Academy Awards, and other tourist attractions in the south California city, A-List said.

DOC.HEADLINE: Commercial Times: Stunned by the so-called tax reform
DOC.DATELINE: 04/20/10 15:38:37 (By Maubo Chang)

TEXT.P: The government's bill on industrial innovation, which was railroaded through the legislature, slashes the corporate income tax rate from the 20 percent originally envisioned to 17 percent, in a bid to pre-empt opposition from the Democratic Progressive Party.
We are stunned by the result, which will seriously damage the country's finances and runs contrary to the country's long-term goal of developing a healthy tax system.

"Lower tax rate, broader tax base" is a fundamental principle followed by all tax planners around the world in mapping out taxation systems. Businesses in Taiwan currently face a nominal income tax rate of 25 percent, but those favored under a previous industrial innovation statute were actually paying a marginal tax rate of 5-10 percent on average, which gave them undue advantages.
To address this unfair tax system, a tax reform panel assembled by the government in 2008 worked out a plan to wipe out targeted tax breaks while lowering the overall corporate income tax rate.

Wiping out most of the tax incentives was expected to raise revenues and compensate for shortfalls expected from cutting the general corporate income tax rate to 20 percent, increasing deductions and lowering marginal tax rates for individual taxpayers, and cutting the maximum inheritance tax rate from 50 percent to 10 percent.
This blueprint was not perfect, but it was organized and took into consideration the country's overall interests and the benefits of various sectors.
The panel's efforts were undone, however, by the administration and ruling Kuomintang (KMT) lawmakers who considered the plan nothing more than a series of unrelated tax breaks.
Those who decided to lower the corporate income tax rate further than previously envisioned failed to realize that any cut in taxes for one economic sector will affect other sectors.
They also mistook the country's finances as a means to improve enterprises' finances, without acknowledging that a fair tax system is vital to the country's sustainable development.
Also, the finance minister didn't lift a finger to remind them of this, let alone pull his weight in defending tax fairness.

President Ma Ying-jeou rammed the bill through the legislature in adesperate effort to shed the image that he has failed to provide leadership to the country, but the reckless process use to decide the issue was nothing short of astounding. (April 20, 2010)

DOC.HEADLINE: Taiwan share prices close higher
DOC.DATELINE: 04/20/10 15:39:09 (By Olivia Wang)

TEXT.P: The local bourse opened at 7,908.11 and fluctuated between a low of 7,842.07 and a high of 7,923.27 during the day's trading. Market turnover totaled NT$106.26 billion (US$3.38 billion).

Five of the eight major stock categories gained ground, with foodstuff issues gaining the most at 1.64 percent, followed by machinery and electronics shares at 1.01 percent. Textile issues rose 0.73 percent, financial and banking stocks moved up 0.46 percent and cement issues were up 0.11 percent.
The three other major stock categories lost ground, with construction issues moving down 0.78 percent. Paper and pulp issues were down 0.5 percent and plastics and chemicals lost 0.04 percent.
Gainers outnumbered losers 1,676 to 1,486, with 244 remaining unchanged.
Foreign investors and Chinese QDIIs were net sellers of NT$ 4.81 billion-worth of shares.

DOC.HEADLINE: MOFA helps Taiwanese couple's round-world cycle trip
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, April 20 (CNA) 04/20/10 15:44:33 (By Wen Kuei-hsiang and Fanny Liu)

TEXT.P: A Taiwanese couple who started a round-the-world bicycle trip has obtained assistance from the Ministry of Foreign Affairs (MOFA) in receiving supplies and visa applications, a MOFA official said Tuesday.

The MOFA has asked 11 overseas representative offices to help the couple get supplies and obtain visas for Kazakhstan, Russia, Belarus and the European Union, according to Chen Po-hsiu, executive secretary of the Non-Government Organization (NGO) Affairs Committee under the MOFA.
Lin Hsiao-kai, 37, and his girlfriend Yen Yi-hui, 27, began their 55,000-km trip April 7 by flying to Bangkok, Thailand, where the cycle trip began.

Lin and Yen plan to travel the world on bicycles from April 2010 to October 2012. During the 30-month sojourn, they will cycle across more than 30 countries in Southeast Asia, Oceania, Central Asia and Europe before flying across the Atlantic Ocean to the United States and then across the Pacific to Japan, the final leg.
Lin and Yen are scheduled to complete the 2,100-km first leg of the trip -- from Thailand to Malaysia and Singapore -- by April 28.

They will then fly to Australia and New Zealand, as well as crossing China, Kazakhstan, Russia, and Belarus before entering eastern and central Europe in the second half of 2011. They will then cross the United States and finish their Japan leg by the end of September 2012.

DOC.HEADLINE: Long-distance bike buses to make debut May 1
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, April 20 (CNA) 04/20/10 16:07:34 (By Chen Shun-hsieh and Lilian Wu)

TEXT.P: Kuo Kuang Motor Transport, one of Taiwan's major long-distance bus operators, announced Tuesday that a first group of five buses catering to cyclists will depart from Taipei to scenic Sun Moon Lake May 1.

Wu Chang-hsi, president of the bus company, said the exclusive "ibb life" (I bike bus life) buses have been converted from passenger coaches, with about half the seats pulled out to make room for two-wheeled vehicles.

Only 20 seats for passengers remain, with the rest of the space occupied by bicycle racks. Up to 23 bicycles can be stored in the bus if luggage locker space, which can hold four bikes, is included, he said.

Wu said that cars and bicycles have become vehicles of leisure for many people, but current transportation trends have either separated the transport of people and bicycles or forced people to carry them in or on their cars.

Some motorists, however, are reluctant to load their bicycles onto their cars out of fear of scratches or concerns over the bikes' ability to withstand the sun and the wind, Wu said, a problem the ibb life buses will eliminate.
"Our buses will serve the bikes as if they were humans," he said.
Bicycles stored in the ibb life buses will be insured against damage along the way.
The first five buses to depart for Sun Moon Lake in Nantou County are fully booked. Passengers will pay a discounted price of NT$3,200 for bus fare, a one- night hotel stay, and two meals.
The same package for individuals in the future will be NT$4,200 on weekdays and NT$5,200 on weekends. Separate group tour deals will also be available.
Wu said there will be five ibb life buses in service initially, but if the response is good, he would not rule out the possibility of increasing his fleet to 30 bike buses by the end of the year.
"In the long run, the goal is 50 such buses, " he said, adding that once the service reaches a certain scale, the bus company will begin regular and backpack tours.

DOC.HEADLINE: Apple Daily: Girl's death exposes social worker shortage

TEXT.P: The most disappointing aspect of a government is not corruption, but when it allows a child to die because of government negligence.

Early this month, a 13-year-old girl told her teachers that her mother intended to kill her and commit suicide. The mother took the girl away from school the next day, despite efforts by school officials to keep the girl away from the mother. When social workers finally reported the case to police -- more than 10 days later -- the pair had already been dead since probably April 4.

There were three opportunities to save the girl, all of which were missed. Had the school authorities insisted on not allowing the girl to leave, she might still be alive. If police and social workers had arrived immediately upon receiving a report from the school, she might not have died. Had social workers and police visited the girl and her mother April 3, the mother might have been prevented from killing her child.

We cannot rebuke the social workers, because there are too few of them. Their workloads are far heavier than their U.S. and European counterparts, and negligence is inevitable as a result of their exhaustion.

We advocate decreasing the number of superfluous civil servants and increasing the number of social workers. The shortage of social workers is the government's fault and is yet another example of a system that is killing people. (April 20, 2010)

DOC.HEADLINE: U.S. dollar down on Taipei Forex
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, April 20 (CNA) 04/20/10 16:18:51 (By Olivia Wang)

TEXT.P: The U.S. dollar lost ground against the New Taiwan dollar on the Taipei Foreign Exchange Tuesday, dropping NT$0.045 to close at NT$31.447.
A total of US$792 million changed hands during the trading session.
The U.S. dollar opened at the day's high of NT$31.492 and fell to a low of NT$31.417 before rebounding.

DOC.HEADLINE: Environmentalists seek support for ban on seal oil
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, April 20 (CNA) 04/20/10 16:29:41 (By Yang Shu-ming and Maubo Chang)

TEXT.P: An environmental protection group invited the public Tuesday to visit its Web site to sign an appeal asking the government to ban the import of seal oil.

Chen Yu-ming of the Environment & Animal Society of Taiwan said 4,480 people had already signed the appeal, and she said it will be handed to the Council of Agriculture when 10,000 signatures are collected.
Since the campaign was launched a week ago, two brands of seal oil on the local market have already been removed from the shelves of two retail chains, she said.
The group drew attention to its seal oil ban initiative by posting a film shot by environmentalists showing the brutal culling of seals in Canada on its Web site.
Chen told a news conference last Tuesday that Canada allows its fishermen to cull 380,000 seals a year, even though the seals account for only 5 percent of the fishermen's annual income.

According to Chen, the culling process is brutal. Canadian fishermen kill these seals by knocking them on head with a cudgel and skinning them while they lie helplessly in a pool of blood struggling to stay alive.
"All this was recorded in a film shot by the Humane Society International and posted on our Web site," Chen said at the time.

"Many of the seal cubs, which are only one month old, are killed while lying on the ice and waiting for their mothers to feed them, " Chen said, adding that it was the world's largest massacre of marine mammals every year.

Although seals are not listed as an endangered species by the United Nations Convention on International Trade in Endangered Species of Wild Fauna and Flora, products using seal ingredients are widely banned in the West, Chen said, and she urged Taiwan to follow suit.
Taiwan has become the fourth leading market for Canadian seal products. From 2003 to 2009, it imported 431,364 kilograms of seal oil, an amount requiring the killing of 120,000 seals, Chen said.

Seal oil is rich in omega-3 fatty acids, but its proponents contend that it provides a higher concentration of the essential fatty acids that reduce the risk of cardiovascular disease than other fish oils, driving demand for the product.
Chen argued, however, that seals need not be killed because every nutrient found in the seal oil can be obtained from other natural sources.
An official from the Council of Agriculture said on the condition of anonymity that the council will not impose the ban until there is a consensus to do so.

DOC.HEADLINE: Taiwan set to join Antigua Convention
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, April 20 (CNA) 04/20/10 16:34:29 (By Y.C. Chou and Flor Wang)

TEXT.P: The Legislative Yuan approved Tuesday Taiwan's participation in the Antigua Convention of the Inter American Tropical Tuna Commission (IATTC) , upgrading the country's status from a cooperating fishing entity to a full member of the body, the Ministry of Foreign Affairs (MOFA) announced that same day.

This means that Taiwan will enjoy the same treatment as other IATTC member states and will retain the title "Chinese Taipei," which will better ensure Taiwan's deep-sea fishing rights in the eastern Pacific and will be of great help in Taiwan's efforts to take part in more international activities, MOFA officials said.
Taiwan first joined the IATTC in 1973 as an observer and became a cooperating fishing entity under the "Chinese Taipei" name in 2003.
The IATTC, established by international convention in 1950, is responsible for the conservation and management of tuna and other species taken by tuna-fishing vessels in the eastern Pacific.

DOC.HEADLINE: Water rationing might begin if drought persists: Taiwater
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, April 20 (CNA) 04/20/10 16:40:14 (By Chang Jung-hsiang, Chou Yung-chieh and Deborah Kuo)

TEXT.P: Taiwan's only running water supplier said Tuesday that water rationing might be imposed in the greater Tainan area by mid-June if the ongoing drought in the region persists.

Taiwan Water Corp. (Taiwater) said that although water reserves in major reservoirs in the area have continued to decline due to the drought, water supplies have remained normal at about 840,000 cubic meters per day.

Water reserves in the Nanhua Reservoir have fallen to some 24.37 million cubic meters, representing about 25 percent of the reservoir's maximum capacity, while the Zengwen Reservoir has fallen to some 20 percent of capacity, or 68.31 million cubic meters, and the Wushantou Reservoir is at about 55.83 million cubic meters, which is roughly 50 percent of its full capacity, according to Taiwater.

An official of Taiwater's Sixth District Administration said that according to hydrologic statistics compiled by Taipower over the past decade or so, May 20 is a crucial date, as it usually rains after that day, ending the annual dry season in the greater Tainan area.
"If it doesn't rain after May this year, it will be necessary for Taiwater to limit water supplies," the official warned.

Meanwhile that day, the Executive Yuan passed a bill allowing the Ministry of Economic Affairs to invest NT$54 billion (US$1.72 billion) over a period of six years to dredge silt from the three main reservoirs in the greater Tainan area and streamline the reservoirs' upstream catchment areas.

DOC.HEADLINE: Taiwan-Hubei (Wuhan) Week inaugurated in Taipei City
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, April 20 (CNA) 04/20/10 17:05:29 (By Kuo Mei-lan, Feng Chao and Elizabeth Hsu)

TEXT.P: The seventh Taiwan-Hubei (Wuhan) Week opened at the Grand Hotel in Taipei City Tuesday, where participants hope to expand commercial, technological, cultural and agricultural exchanges between Taiwan and central western China.

A big delegation from Hubei Province, headed by Communist Party of China Hubei Provincial Committee Secretary Luo Qingquan, is attending the annual event organized by Hubei, which is being held in Taiwan for the first time.

At the opening ceremony, Lien Chan, honorary chairman of Taiwan's ruling Kuomintang (KMT), described Hubei as a significant province in central China that has attracted over 2,000 Taiwanese investors and is home to between 70 and 80 Taiwan-invested agricultural enterprises.
He said he anticipated that the event will further help boost industrial and commercial cooperation.

Preston Chen, chairman of the Taipei-based Chinese National Federation of Industries, said he expected Luo's plan to visit local farms and make direct contact with local people would be beneficial to mutual exchanges in the future.
Those ties are also expected to be "closer" after the two sides ink an economic cooperation framework agreement, he said.
As of the end of 2010, there were 2,080 Taiwanese businesses operating in Hubei, with total investment of US$5.8 billion, according to Chen.
Luo's 1,000-member delegation is comprised of officials of the Hubei provincial government, 17 provincial city governments, leaders of state-run and private enterprises, and performing artists.

In his address, Luo pinpointed cultural exchanges as one of the most important segments of cross-strait exchanges, and he suggested that Taiwan encourage more Taiwanese students to study in Hubei while pledging that Hubei would encourage its students to study in Taiwan.
Luo also suggested that the two sides expand cooperation in the areas of agriculture, technology, green energy, low-carbon commerce, information technology and herbal medicine.

Hubei has begun developing an industrial park for Taiwanese businesses and a Taiwan farmers' park, new facilities that Luo touted as providing considerable space for future cooperation between the industrial sectors from the two sides.

The opening was attended by many influential entrepreneurs in Taiwan, including Uni-President Enterprises Corp. CEO Jason C.S. Lin, Compal Group Chairman Rock Hsu, Taiwan Glass Group Chairman P.F. Lin, Hon Hai Group Chairman Terry Gou, and Far Eastern Group Chairman Douglas Hsu.

DOC.HEADLINE: Taiwan's medical team in Qinghai praised by health official
DOC.DATELINE: Xining, Qinghai, April 20 (CNA) 04/20/10 17:34:48

TEXT.P: China's Vice Minister of Health Yin Li on Tuesday praised the expertise and experience of Taiwan Red Cross Society's medical team when he visited quake- affected victims at a hospital in Qinghai, northwestern where the team was serving.

The 20-member Taiwan medical team with about 1,000 kg of medicines and relief goods, left Taiwan Sunday for Qinghai to provide medical assistances to the victims of the magnitude-7.1 quake that hit the Yushu county April 14.

Yin viisted the Xining First People's Hospital intensive care units to see the victims seriously injured in the quake, and said that that with the best medical equipment in the hospital and assistance from Taiwan's medical team, they will recover soon.
Yin said the arrival of Taiwan's medical team is a demonstration of the freiendship between the two sides of the Taiwan Strait, as well as the spirit of "blood running thicker than water."

Noting that half of the memders of Taiwan's medical team had taken part in the rescue mission in the Sichuan earthquake on May 12, 2008, he said this also shows the close interaction between the two sides.

Yin said that after the big temblor in Yushu County area, Taiwan's Red Cross Society had asked to send a medical team there, but because the affected area is on a plateau with no convenient transportation, and most of the victims had been transported outside, China arranged for Taiwan's team to serve in Xining's hospital instead. (By Chou Kuang-hung and Lilian Wu)

DOC.HEADLINE: 10 Chinese tourists injured in Alishan bus accident
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, April 20 (CNA) 04/20/10 17:50:27

TEXT.P: Ten Chinese tourists were hurt Tuesday in a road accident which occurred on Alishan mountain in southern Taiwan's Chiayi County, with five seriously injured, according to local sources.

The 10 tourists on two separate small buses were wounded when one of the buses collided with a sport utility vehicle (SUV) while coming down from the mountain -- one of the top tourist destinations in Taiwan for Chinese visitors, the county's firemen said.

The first tour bus crashed against the SUV at the 83.5 kilometer spot of the Alishan Freeway. Eight female Chinese tourists on that bus were wounded. Two other Chinese tourists in the second bus got hurt when the vehicle they were in, which was traveling behind the first tour bus, suddenly braked.
The 10 Chinese tourists, part of a 27-member tour group from Beijing which visited Alishan in three small buses, were rushed to a local medical station for treatment.
Five of the more seriously injured were later transferred to St. Martin De Porres Hospital in Chiayi City. None of them were in life- threatening danger.
Police have launched an investigation into the cause of the traffic accident.
The tourists arrived in Taiwan Sunday for a week-long visit.

The Alishan Freeway, which was severely damaged last August by Typhoon Morakot, remains closed to large tour buses. Until roads are fully repaired, tourists hoping to visit the mountain must travel in small buses. (By C. L. Chiang and Flor Wang)

DOC.HEADLINE: KMT to begin mediation efforts among mayoral aspirants
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, April 20 (CNA) 04/20/10 18:03:10 (By Lee Shu-hua and Y.F. Low)

TEXT.P: The ruling Kuomintang (KMT) is expected to soon begin mediation efforts among would-be candidates as part of the nomination process for the year-end mayoral elections in the five special municipalities, party officials said Tuesday.
Instead of holding a primary, the KMT will determine its nominees for the elections by conscription.

While it is almost certain that Vice Premier Eric Liluan Chu will run in Xinbei City and Taichung Mayor Jason Hu will run in the greater Taichung area, the candidates for Taipei City, greater Kaohsiung and greater Tainan have yet to be finalized.

Following the recent completion of opinion polls on the aspirants in these three municipalities, KMT Secretary-General King Pu-tsung will mediate among them to single out the best candidate for each city and try to win the losers' support for the selected candidate, according to party officials.

The results of the surveys show that incumbent Taipei Mayor Hau Lung-bin and Legislator Huang Chao-shun are leading the popularity stakes in Taipei City and greater Kaohsiung, respectively. In greater Tainan, former Legislator Kuo Tien- Tsai is in the lead, but his support rating and that of former Legislator Lee Chuan-chiao, who is in second place, fall within the statistical margin of error.
According to KMT spokesman Su Jun-pin, opinion surveys are an important reference tool during the selection process.

However, he went on, just because they win the highest support ratings in the surveys does not mean that the aspirants will be drafted by the party. It only means that they stand a higher chance of being drafted, he said.

DOC.HEADLINE: Taiwan carrier resumes Rome flights
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, April 20 (CNA) 04/20/10 18:40:05 (By Wang Shu-fen, Bien Chin-feng and Elizabeth Hsu)

TEXT.P: Taipei-based China Airlines (CAL) resumed its flights to Rome Tuesday amid signs that a cloud of ash spewed out by an erupting volcano in Iceland that emptied the skies over Europe of planes had started to shrink.
The CAL flight from Taipei to Rome via Delhi took off at 8: 40 a.m. and was scheduled to make the return flight at 8: 30 p.m. Wednesday, according to the company.

Meanwhile, Taiwan's other main airline, EVA Airways, canceled a flight destined for Vienna via Bangkok that had been scheduled to take off at 10: 45 p.m. that day, following reports of new clouds of drifting ash.
EVA Airways said the canceled flight will be grounded until April 22.

The two carriers meanwhile continued their suspension of flights to London, Amsterdam and Frankfurt. These flights will immediately resume as soon as the airports there are re-opened, according to airline officials.
Tuesday morning saw crowds of people planning to fly to Rome packed the CAL check-in counters at the Taiwan Taoyuan International Airport.
A guide for one tour group said his agency had confirmed their return flight and expressed confidence that "there will be no problem" for them to return home on schedule.

However, one group of German travelers were not so happy, having made for Taipei on their way home from the Indonesian resort island of Bali in a desperate attempt to avoid the flight chaos, only to find themselves stranded at the airport hoping for a flight to Europe.

DOC.HEADLINE: Taiwan should open doors to Chinese students: university presidents
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, April 20 (CNA) 04/20/10 18:58:43 (By Kelvin Huang and Fanny Liu)

TEXT.P: Several university presidents said Tuesday that Taiwan should open its doors to Chinese students as soon as possible, insisting that there will be more pros than cons.

Taiwan's government late last year decided to allow Chinese students to study in Taiwan, but it will limit the number of mainland Chinese students to under 2,000 a year in the initial stage of the program.

The presidents of Taiwan's universities said during a press conference Tuesday that opening Taiwanese universities to Chinese students will not threaten Taiwanese students in any way, be it in the college entrance slots or job opportunities.

National Taiwan University President Lee Si-chen said that more than 80 percent of university presidents in Taiwan support opening Taiwanese universities to Chinese students, citing a survey conducted while he was serving as the head of the Association of National Universities.

It is a global trend to allow the free flow of students, and Taiwan should not selectively open its doors to students from other countries but not those from China, Lee said, adding that he expects local students will be greatly inspired by Chinese students' attitude toward learning.
The press conference was held by the legislative caucus of Taiwan's ruling party Kuomintang (KMT), which supports the move.

With a legislative committee scheduled to review law amendments regarding this issue on Wednesday, the opposition Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) 's legislative caucus said earlier Tuesday that they strongly opposed the government's plan to allow Chinese students to study in Taiwan.
However, the university presidents said the policy the government plans to carry out along with the opening, will protect Taiwanese students' interests.

Michael J.K. Chen, president of Ling Tung University in Taichung City, said that the government's decision to attach the "three restrictions and six noes" policy in allowing Chinese students to study in Taiwan will suit local circumstances.

The three restrictions on Chinese students include restrictions on universities to be enrolled in the program, the number of students to be admitted, and the professional areas in which the Chinese students' educational credentials will be recognized.

Under the "six noes, " Chinese students will not be given preferential scores. They will not affect the number of local students to be enrolled, they will not be eligible for scholarships, and they will not be allowed to moonlight, seek jobs or take tests for civil service examinations in Taiwan after graduation.

Chen said the number of Taiwanese students aiming to obtain degrees in China was 1,888 in 2010, and the number has never exceeded 2,000 since 1987; therefore, Taiwan's move to impose an upper limit of 2,000 on the number of Chinese students in Taiwan will create a natural balance.

Chen, who is also the head of the Association of Private Universities and Colleges of Technology, also pointed out that around 60 percent of the foreign students in Japan's universities were from China last year, and about 70 percent of foreign students in South Korea were Chinese.

Last week, a Ministry of Education official said that at present there is an imbalance because China permits Taiwanese students to enter its universities, but as yet there are no reciprocal regulations in Taiwan.

DOC.HEADLINE: Premier defends trade pact with China
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, April 20 (CNA) 04/20/10 19:19:30 (By Hsieh Chia-chen and Lilian Wu)

TEXT.P: Premier Wu Deng-yih rebutted Tuesday former President Lee Teng-hui's criticism of a proposed trade pact with China, pointing out that many of the things Lee has said in the past were later proved wrong.

Wu was responding to remarks made by Lee April 17 when he blasted the administration of President Ma Ying-jeou for insisting on signing the cross- strait economic cooperation framework agreement (ECFA) despite public misgivings that it would make Taiwan even more dependent on China and would cost the country jobs.
Lee also said the inking of the ECFA will be China's first step toward swallowing Taiwan.

Asked during a TV interview about two ruling Kuomintang (KMT) legislators, Shyu Jong-shyong and Lo Shu-lei, who accused the government of having failed to effectively carry out risk control on the negative impact of the ECFA, Wu said the government will do its best to mitigate any such impact.
He noted that there are 75 KMT lawmakers in the 113-member legislature and said the views of just two of them do not represent those of the whole party.
"Their views represent more of a reflective voice to remind the government to remain on guard," he added.

Wu said he respects the voice of the opposition and will listen to its views, adding that as long as it is willing to monitor and come up with better ideas than those of the government, he is willing to adopt them.

Asked why Taiwan should not sign a cross-strait peace agreement and demand that China withdraw the more-than 1,000 missiles targeting Taiwan, Wu said he would not agree to sign such a pact if all China had to do was withdraw its missiles.
Wu said the time for the signing of a peace accord is still "far off. "

Withdrawing that missiles would not be enough, Wu went on, adding that more should be done to persuade China to stop squeezing Taiwan's maneuvering space in the international community, that more cross-strait trade, economic and cultural exchanges could foster more mutual trust, and that China's freedom, democracy and rule of law should grow.
"When enough goodwill is accumulated over the long term, we can talk about signing a peace accord," Wu said.

DOC.HEADLINE: No third party help in inviting Bush to Taiwan: foreign ministry
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, April 20 (CNA) 04/20/10 19:50:12 (By Alex Jiang)

TEXT.P: Taiwan's foreign ministry said Tuesday that it did not ask a third party to help invite the former U.S. President George W. Bush to visit Taiwan.
The Ministry of Foreign Affairs said Tuesday that it directly contacted Bush's office to arrange the visit and that a third party was never involved in the process.

In a statement, the ministry said Foreign Minister Timothy C.T. Yang has made it clear that he represented President Ma Ying-jeou in inviting Bush to visit Taiwan during his trip to Dallas in early December 2009.

The foreign ministry issued the statement days after the China Times Weekly reported that Jack Hu, a 25-year-old Chinese American, said in an exclusive interview with the local Chinese-language magazine that he was asked by the ministry to deal with the invitation.

Hu added in the interview that he began helping arrange the visit after Harry Tseng, director-general of the ministry's Department of North American Affairs, asked him about the possibility of inviting a former head of state from the United States to Taiwan during a telephone conversation in October last year.

Bush, who left office in 2009, was reported to make the visit in late April. But the ministry said earlier this month that the visit was not possible because of Bush's tight schedule during his tour of Asia.
Taiwan sees the U.S. as one of its major allies despite the lack of diplomatic ties between the two.
The foreign ministry said it will ask Taiwan's representative to the U.S. -- Jason Yuan - to continue to invite Bush as part of the ministry's efforts to promote bilateral relations.

DOC.HEADLINE: Taiwan butterflies and fireflies on display in Germany
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, April 20 (CNA) 04/20/10 20:09:52 (By Ku Lan-ying and Fanny Liu)

TEXT.P: Several species of butterflies and fireflies from Taiwan are being displayed in Europe for the first time, at a butterfly farm in Germany that is that largest on the continent, the organizers said Tuesday.

Taiwan's aquatic firefly species, Luciola ficta Olivier and Luciola cerata Olivier, also known as the black-winged firefly, made their debut in Europe at Schemetterlingsfarm Trassenheide, according to the Information Division of the Taipei Economic and Cultural Office (TECO) in Hamburg, which organized the exhibit.

Chang Hsiao-nee, head of the Hamburg office, said that Taiwan is known as the "Butterfly Kingdom" because of its 410 species of butterflies. In comparison, Japan has 225 species and Germany 150, Chang noted.

The butterfly farm in Trassenheide, which is collaborating with Taiwan for the first time, has created a proper living environment for the Taiwan butterflies and fireflies during the six-month exhibition period, the office said.
The farm, located on Usedom, a Baltic Sea island on the border between Germany and Poland, attracts about 200,000 tourists a year.

DOC.HEADLINE: Record export order value, recovery in sight: MOEA
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, April 20 (CNA) 04/20/10 20:30:36 (By S.Y. Lin and Flor Wang)

TEXT.P: The combined value of export orders placed with Taiwanese firms in March set a new high of US$34.39 billion, with orders from the country's three major trading partners all hitting single-month highs, the Ministry of Economic Affairs (MOEA) reported Tuesday.

Huang Chi-shih, director-general of the MOEA's Department of Statistics, said the figure, which shows a rebound to the levels before the financial tsunami that began in 2008, represents an annual growth rate of 43.66 percent.

"I am optimistic that the figure for export orders received by Taiwanese companies in April will also be good, " Huang said, predicting that "the figure for May will also set a new record, buoyed by strong demand from the Labor Day holiday" in the China.
Orders placed with Taiwanese companies in October 2007 were worth US$32.2 billion, MOEA statistics show.

In March, the value of orders from China (including Hong Kong) , Japan and Association of Southeast Asian Nations (ASEAN) countries all reached new monthly highs, "which is a sign that an economic recovery is taking shape," Huang added.

China placed US$9.81 billion worth of orders with local businesses last month, marking an increase rate of 59.67 percent year on year, according to the MOEA. March orders from Japan hit US$3.993 billion, a year-on-year growth rate of 93.55 percent. Orders from ASEAN member states, meanwhile, totaled US$3.237 billion, a growth of 61.77 percent compared to the year-earlier level.

Flat panel displays were the main product ordered by foreign companies in March. Orders for medium- and large -sized panels hit US$3.244 billion, registering an annual expansion rate of 87.84 percent, while the figure for small panels reached US$2.025 billion, up by 66.94 percent from a year ago, MOEA tallies show.

DOC.HEADLINE: Construction experts to discuss disaster prevention in Taipei
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, April 20 (CNA) 04/20/10 21:10:15 (By Alex Jiang)

TEXT.P: Some 1,000 construction experts from 16 countries in the Asian Pacific region will gather in Taipei Wednesday to discuss how to use innovative technologies to cope with natural disasters, one of the organizers said Tuesday.

"It's been 22 years since the International Federation of Asian and Western Pacific Contractors' Associations (IFAWPCA) held a member congress in Taipei, " said Pan Chun-jung, the head of the Taiwan General Contractors Association.

"In addition to exchanges on construction technologies and culture, there will be a seminar on how the industry could cope with earthquakes, floods, mudslides and other natural disasters," he said at a press conference.
The congress is now in its 38th year. Taiwan is a founding member of the IFAWPCA, which was established in 1956 in the Philippines.

DOC.HEADLINE: MOI approves former premier's visit to China
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, April 20 (CNA) 04/20/10 21:15:42 (By Bear Lee)

TEXT.P: The Ministry of the Interior approved Tuesday an application by former Premier Liu Chao-shiuan to visit China May 10-18 to preside over a lighting ceremony at the inauguration of the Taiwan pavilion at the 2010 World Expo in Shanghai, ministry officials said later that day.

The ministry give its green light to Liu's application on the grounds that the planned visit is a cross-Taiwan Strait cultural exchange only, and involves no national security issues, the officials said.

The former premier will visit Shanghai to officially open the Taiwan pavilion at the expo in his capacity as chairman of the National Cultural Association, a non-profit organization set up by the government in 1966 to help re- energize Chinese culture.
Under the law, political appointees and high-ranking officials seeking to visit China within three years of their resignations must apply for prior government approval.

Liu, who began serving as premier when President Ma Ying-jeou took office May 20, 2008, resigned Sept. 10 last year to shoulder responsibility for the government's bungled rescue and relief operations after Typhoon Morakot devastated parts of southern and eastern Taiwan last August.

DOC.HEADLINE: Stock stabilization fund may fully withdraw from market in May
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, April 20 (CNA) 04/20/10 22:25:50 (By Hsieh Chia-chen and Fanny Liu)

TEXT.P: Vice Premier Eric Liluan Chu said Tuesday that the National Stabilization Fund (NSF) might completely withdraw from Taiwan's stock market next month and that the government will set a strict standard for the fund to enter the local stock market in the future.

Chu said in a televised interview that he is optimistic about the outlook for the stock market, citing the fact that the Chung-Hua Institution for Economic Research recently revised upward its forecast for economic growth this year to 4.99 percent, compared to the government's growth forecast of at least 4.8 percent.

In addition, the ample funds in the market, the signing of a proposed economic cooperation framework agreement (ECFA) with China, and an expected cut in corporate tax are all positive factors for the stock market, Chu added.
He expressed confidence that the NSF will no longer be needed to stabilize the stock market as it did in late 2008 and early 2009.
According to statistics, the NSF bought about NT$59.9 billion-worth of shares between late 2008 and early 2009, and has been gradually selling its holdings since the beginning of the year, he said.
The pace of selling has been very slow, Chu went on, denying media reports that the government-run fund has sold NT$10 billion to NT$20 billion in a single day.
The fund earned a profit of about NT$27 billion by selling more than two-thirds of the shares it bought during the 2008-2009 period, with the rate of returns estimated at over 60 percent, he said.

He continued, however, that the fund was not aimed at making profits or long term investments and was required to withdraw from the stock market following a decision by the fund's management committee in January.

Chu also pointed out that stricter standards will be applied for the fund to enter the stock market in the future and that it will not be allowed to buy shares when the TAIEX drops only 200 to 300 points, or to sell shares when it surges just 400 or 500 points.

DOC.HEADLINE: FPG's Jenwu plant could face record pollution fine
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, April 20 (CNA) 04/20/10 22:43:20 (By Lee Hsien-feng and Lilian Wu)

TEXT.P: The Environmental Protection Agency (EPA) asked the Kaohsiung county government Tuesday to fine Formosa Plastics Group (FPG) for serious pollution of soil and underground water at its Jenwu plant in southern Taiwan.

The plant in Kaohsiung County could be fined up to NT$150 million (US$4.76 million) , surpassing a NT$130 million administrative fine meted out to the Kuanyin Industrial Park last year that is the highest of its kind ever levied in Taiwan.
Chen Hsien-heng, director of the EPA's Department of Water Protection, said the exact amount of the fine will be decided after a remedial plan put forth by the Jenwu plant is approved.

He noted that the Jenwu plant has known since December 2003 that the underground water was seriously polluted in its plant complex, but has failed to alert the authorities and has not adopted emergency contingency measures.
It was not until 2009, when the EPA entered the plant to conduct an investigation, that the plant installed recycling wells to stem the spread of the pollutants.

Chen said that during the inspection, the EPA also discovered that the plant had applied for a refund of nearly NT$40 million in the name of new investment for anti-pollution facilities. The fund has yet to be approved.

Chen said that if the Jenwu plant is fined under the Water Pollution Control Act, it can be fined just NT$600,000 at most, but if the regulation of "improper gains" under the Administrative Penalty Act is cited, the fine will be much higher.
The EPA has tentatively mapped out eight options, with fines ranging from NT$39 million to NT$150 million.

Amid calls by environmental groups that the plant's operations should be suspended, Chen said that if the pollution spreads, the plant might be shut down, but if the pollution does not get worse, it will be permitted to continue operating.

Amid public concern about the safety of drinking water in the vicinity of the plant, Kaohsiung county government environmental protection officials said that 96 percent of the people use tap water for drinking, while only a small number use underground water, mostly for washing.

County government officials have started collecting samples from the wells within the plant as well as wells in six villages surrounding the plant and test information is expected to be available April 29.

DOC.HEADLINE: Foreign-based manufacturing hurts jobs at home: MOEA
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, April 20 (CNA) 04/20/10 22:48:17 (By S.Y. Lin and Flor Wang)

TEXT.P: Increased foreign-based manufacturing by Taiwanese firms is set to seriously hurt the local job market and drag down private-sector consumption, the Ministry of Economic Affairs (MOEA) said Tuesday.
Although overseas manufacturing is beneficial to local enterprises' globalization, MOEA officials warned that it will also result in more local job losses and will impact private-sector consumption.

The percentage of products made by Taiwanese firms abroad rose above the 50 percent level to 50.69 percent in March for the first time in history, thanks mainly to a sound supply chain they have built in other countries such as China, the officials noted.

In the past, the ratio stood always below 50 percent, they went on, voicing deep concern that the trend will severely impact the local employment market and deal a heavy blow to consumption in the private sector, despite news of a noticeable economic recovery.

In terms of sector, the information technology industry has the highest percentage of overseas manufacturing at 84.96 percent -- which means that the vast majority of Taiwan-branded notebook computers are produced outside the country, the officials pointed out.

According to the latest statistics published earlier in the day by the MOEA, the value of export orders local companies received in March recorded a new high of US$34.39 billion -- rebounding to the levels of before the financial tsunami that began in 2008 and representing an annual growth rate of 43.66 percent.
Foreign orders placed with Taiwanese companies in October 2007 were worth US$32.2 billion, MOEA statistics show.

DOC.HEADLINE: 2009 wealth gap narrows 1.69 times: CEPD
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, April 20 (CNA) 04/20/10 22:58:38 (By Hsieh Chun-wei and Bear Lee)

TEXT.P: The gap between the rich and the poor in Taiwan was narrowed 1.69 times last year as a result of comprehensive efforts by the government, the Council of Economic Planning and Development (CEPD) said Tuesday.

CEPD Vice Chairman Hu Chung-ying made the remarks in response to a report by the Apple Daily newspaper that wealth gap is higher than in either Japan or South Korea and that it will worsen further in the next two or three years if the government fails to properly address the adverse impact likely to arise from a proposed cross-Taiwan Strait trade pact.
"The difference would have widened to 7.74 times last year from 6.05 times a year earlier if the government had not put in place tax and social welfare measures," Hu said in a press conference.

However, he did acknowledge that the economic cooperation framework agreement (ECFA) that Taiwan and China are expected to sign in June will pound some weaker sectors, increase unemployment and worsen wealth distribution in spite of its far greater benefit to the country's economy as a whole.

Hu cited research by the Chung-Hua Institution for Economic Research (CIER) as forecasting that the ECFA will create more than 257,000 additional jobs and increase Taiwan's GDP by between 1.65 percent and 1.72 percent.

For those industries that will bear the brunt of the ECFA, the government has prepared a comprehensive program to help them weather their difficulties, earmarking NT$95 billion to be distributed as subsidies, Hu added.

He further pointed out that the Industrial Innovation Law that passed the legislature last week will also help contribute to a fairer distribution of wealth, as under the law, small- and medium-sized enterprises are entitled a corporate tax break, unlike its forerunner, the Statute for Upgrading Industry that expired at the end of 2009 and which offered tax incentives mostly to hi- tech conglomerates.

DOC.HEADLINE: MOFA maintains efforts to assist Taiwanese stranded in Europe
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, April 20 (CNA) 04/20/10 23:04:20 (By Chris Wang)

TEXT.P: The Ministry of Foreign Affairs (MOFA) said Tuesday that it is still trying to offer help to Taiwanese travelers stranded in Europe five days after air traffic over Europe came to a standstill.
Giant clouds of ash spewing from an erupting volcano in Iceland has drifted over large swathes of Europe, rendering flying hazardous.

European Union transport ministers have held an extraordinary meeting via video conference and have agreed on a "progressive and coordinated" reopening of European airspace with full guarantees of safety.

According to a MOFA press release, staff of its 26 representative offices based in European countries have been assisting stranded Taiwanese round the clock over the last five days and have offered help to more than 900 people.

Those who run out of money in Europe as a result of the chaos will be granted an emergency loan of US$500, the press release said, adding that the MOFA is also coordinating an emergency evacuation plan that will arrange flights to transport elderly citizens, children and those in need of medical services back to Taiwan once flights resume.
According to the EU website, the European Organization for the Safety of Air Navigation (Eurocontrol) has divided the airspace into three zones based on the volcanic ash content.

Eurocontrol explained that the first of these zones is the region beneath the volcanic plume, where there is still a strict no-fly zone, such as London and Amsterdam. The second zone, which includes Vienna, covers an area where ash might be present but in which operations will be coordinated by the authorities of member states. The third zone is the area unaffected by the ash and in which there are no flight restrictions, such as Rome.
Eurocontrol was expecting 40 percent to 45 percent of flights in European airspace to resume Wednesday compared to 30 percent Tuesday.

DOC.HEADLINE: Record export order value, recovery in sight: MOEA
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, April 20 (CNA) 04/20/10 20:30:36 (By S.Y. Lin and Flor Wang)

TEXT.P: The combined value of export orders placed with Taiwanese firms in March set a new high of US$34.39 billion, with orders from the country's three major trading partners all hitting single-month highs, the Ministry of Economic Affairs (MOEA) reported Tuesday.

Huang Chi-shih, director-general of the MOEA's Department of Statistics, said the figure, which shows a rebound to the levels before the financial tsunami that began in 2008, represents an annual growth rate of 43.66 percent.

"I am optimistic that the figure for export orders received by Taiwanese companies in April will also be good, " Huang said, predicting that "the figure for May will also set a new record, buoyed by strong demand from the Labor Day holiday" in the China.
Orders placed with Taiwanese companies in October 2007 were worth US$32.2 billion, MOEA statistics show.

In March, the value of orders from China (including Hong Kong) , Japan and Association of Southeast Asian Nations (ASEAN) countries all reached new monthly highs, "which is a sign that an economic recovery is taking shape," Huang added.

China placed US$9.81 billion worth of orders with local businesses last month, marking an increase rate of 59.67 percent year on year, according to the MOEA. March orders from Japan hit US$3.993 billion, a year-on-year growth rate of 93.55 percent. Orders from ASEAN member states, meanwhile, totaled US$3.237 billion, a growth of 61.77 percent compared to the year-earlier level.

Flat panel displays were the main product ordered by foreign companies in March. Orders for medium- and large -sized panels hit US$3.244 billion, registering an annual expansion rate of 87.84 percent, while the figure for small panels reached US$2.025 billion, up by 66.94 percent from a year ago, MOEA tallies show.

DOC.HEADLINE: Construction experts to discuss disaster prevention in Taipei
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, April 20 (CNA) 04/20/10 21:10:15 (By Alex Jiang)

TEXT.P: Some 1,000 construction experts from 16 countries in the Asian Pacific region will gather in Taipei Wednesday to discuss how to use innovative technologies to cope with natural disasters, one of the organizers said Tuesday.

"It's been 22 years since the International Federation of Asian and Western Pacific Contractors' Associations (IFAWPCA) held a member congress in Taipei, " said Pan Chun-jung, the head of the Taiwan General Contractors Association.

"In addition to exchanges on construction technologies and culture, there will be a seminar on how the industry could cope with earthquakes, floods, mudslides and other natural disasters," he said at a press conference.
The congress is now in its 38th year. Taiwan is a founding member of the IFAWPCA, which was established in 1956 in the Philippines.

DOC.HEADLINE: MOI approves former premier's visit to China
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, April 20 (CNA) 04/20/10 21:15:42 (By Bear Lee)

TEXT.P: The Ministry of the Interior approved Tuesday an application by former Premier Liu Chao-shiuan to visit China May 10-18 to preside over a lighting ceremony at the inauguration of the Taiwan pavilion at the 2010 World Expo in Shanghai, ministry officials said later that day.

The ministry give its green light to Liu's application on the grounds that the planned visit is a cross-Taiwan Strait cultural exchange only, and involves no national security issues, the officials said.

The former premier will visit Shanghai to officially open the Taiwan pavilion at the expo in his capacity as chairman of the National Cultural Association, a non-profit organization set up by the government in 1966 to help re- energize Chinese culture.
Under the law, political appointees and high-ranking officials seeking to visit China within three years of their resignations must apply for prior government approval.

Liu, who began serving as premier when President Ma Ying-jeou took office May 20, 2008, resigned Sept. 10 last year to shoulder responsibility for the government's bungled rescue and relief operations after Typhoon Morakot devastated parts of southern and eastern Taiwan last August.

DOC.HEADLINE: Today in history
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, April 21 (CNA) 04/21/10 08:35:33
DOC.TEXT:
Today is Wednesday, April 21, or the eighth day of the third month of the Year of Tiger according to the lunar calendar. Following is a list of important events that have occurred on this date in the past:
1634: Jan van Riebeeck, Dutch naval surgeon and founder of Cape Town, South Africa, is born.
1898: The United States declares war on Spain.
1910: Mark Twain, pen name of Samuel Langhorne Clemens, American author and humorist, dies at the age of 74. He drew on his childhood along the Mississippi River to create masterpieces of humor and sarcasm, including "Tom Sawyer" and "The Adventures of Huckleberry Finn."
1926: Elizabeth II, Queen of England since 1952, is born.
1930: Fire breaks out at the Ohio state penitentiary, killing 355 people.
1935: An earthquake hits central and northern Taiwan, killing some 3,000 people.
1937: Steamships formally begin plying a regular weekly route between Shanghai and San Francisco.
1946: British economist John Maynard Keynes dies at the age of 63. He proposed that high unemployment, being a result of insufficient consumer spending, can be relieved by government-sponsored programs.
1948: Republic of China troops evacuate Yenan.
1949: The Chinese communists resume an all-out offensive and cross the Yangtze River.
1954: The United States flies a French battalion to Indochina to defend Dien Bien Phu, which is overrun by Vietnamese forces three weeks later.
1957: Taiwan voters go to the polls for the third time to elect county magistrates, city mayors and provincial assemblymen.
1958: The Taiwan Provincial Assembly building in Wufeng, Taichung County, is inaugurated.
1960: Brazil moves its capital from Rio de Janeiro to Brazilia, the brain-child of President Juselino Kubitschek.
1966: The ROC and Dahomey resume diplomatic relations.
1971: Haitian dictator Francois Duvalier, known as "Papa Doc," dies at the age of 64. Elected president in 1957, he declared himself president for life in 1964 and ruled in an authoritarian manner until his death. He was succeeded by his son Jean-Claude, who fled the country in 1986 after widespread civil unrest.
1975: South Vietnamese President Nguyen Van Thieu resigns after denouncing the United States as untrustworthy.
1987: Terrorists detonate a bomb near the main bus station in Colombo, Sri Lanka, killing and injuring more than 400 people.
1989: More than 10,000 workers and students clamoring for democracy and human rights march from campuses to converge on Tiananmen Square in Beijing in defiance of official warnings against anti-government protests.
1997: An advance contingent of communist Chinese troops enter Hong Kong in preparation for the July 1 handover of the British crown colony to communist China.
1998: Seoul drops efforts to receive Japanese compensation for women held as sex slaves during World War II and says it will pay the surviving women.
1999: A survey conducted by the Switzerland-based Business Environment Risk Intelligence ranks Taiwan as the least risky area for investment in the world.
1999: Renowned local writer Su Hsueh-lin, winner of the Chungshan Literature Prize and the National Literature Prize, dies at the age of 104.
2000: Taiwanese "Go" player Wang Li-cheng wins the title of "Go Sage," the highest title and honor for any Go professional in Japan.
2000: Tsai Ying-wen, an advisor to the National Security Council and a professor at National Chengchi University, is confirmed chairman of the Cabinet-level Mainland Affairs Council.
2001: A pro-unification organization urges Taiwan's three main opposition parties to monitor the Democratic Progressive Party-led government to prevent Taiwan from "marching toward independence."
Confucius lesson of the day: "A good horse is considered so not because of its mere brute strength but because of its moral qualities."
