DOC.HEADLINE: United Daily News: 'Asia-Pacific platform' revived?

TEXT.P: President Ma Ying-jeou's recent decision to push for a second-generation National Health Insurance system marks a rare show of broad-mindedness since his inauguration.
A similar show of decisiveness was seen in Ma's rapid decision to lower the corporate income tax rate to 17 percent in the wrangling over the industrial innovation bill.

It appeared that cutting the tax rate in a big way was one of Ma's plans in the first place, but he dared not put it forward for fear that the opposition Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) might go against it. However, after the DPP proposed dropping the tax rate to 17.5 percent, the Ma administration took the opportunity to show its cards.

More surprising still, Ma announced at the same time that in certain economic and trade zones, the wages for foreign laborers do not have to comply with the nation's minimum wage. The moves were like removing two big mountains standing in the way of the government's efforts to push for the special economic and trade zones.

It is not clear whether Ma has come to this string of prompt policies by chance or with well-devised considerations. It requires further observation to see if they will help launch long-anticipated projects to develop Taiwan into an economic and trade platform in the Asia-Pacific region and set up special economic and trade zones in the country. They would be means by which Taiwan could face up to the severe challenges ahead. (April 21, 2010)

DOC.HEADLINE: Talk of the day -- Record export orders draw mixed views

TEXT.P: Export orders placed with Taiwanese companies posted 43.66 percent year-on-year growth in March to set a new single-month record of US$34.39 billion, according to statistics released by the Ministry of Economic Affairs (MOEA) Tuesday.
The higher-than-expected growth was yet another indication that the local economy has emerged from a year-long recession amid a global financial crunch.
But some analysts are worried that the increased export orders will not contribute to domestic consumption and employment because more than half of the export orders will be produced abroad.
The high ratio of overseas production highlights the exodus of local manufacturers, which could exacerbate Taiwan's structural unemployment problem.
The following are excerpts from local media coverage of the issue: Economic Daily News:
The combined value of export orders placed with local suppliers in March beat the previous record of US$32.2 billion set in October 2007.
"The March amount indicated that our export orders have returned to the pre- global financial tsunami levels, " said Huang Chi-shih, director-general of the MOEA's Department of Statistics.
As orders are an indication of Taiwan's shipments in the next one to three months to foreign countries, Huang said the March number signals robust export trade for the second quarter of this year.
According to Huang, export orders from China, Japan and six major ASEAN nations all set new single-month records in March.
As to the effects of the recent closures of major European airports over volcanic ash from Iceland, Huang said the impact on Taiwan's export orders and outbound shipments will be limited.

Nevertheless, he added, local companies may face a short-term shortage of parts and components if they do not have adequate inventories in their overseas warehouses. (April 21, 2010). Commercial Times:

While Taiwan's export orders surged to a single-month high of US$34.39 billion in March, it may not help much to boost domestic consumption and reduce unemployment as 50.69 percent of the orders will be produced abroad.

It marked the first time that the overseas production ratio has exceeded 50 percent. In the past, the percentage hovered around 40 percent, but the figure began to rise steadily last October when export orders gradually regained momentum amid a global economic recovery.

MOEA officials said the percentage rose because the ratio of overseas production in the information technology and electronics sectors shot up from 45.32 percent in February to 50.36 percent in March.
As a result, the officials said, the overall overseas production percentage reached 50.69 percent in March from February's 49.42 percent.
While local companies' efforts to relocate production lines abroad will facilitate their global expansion plans, the official admitted that such moves could adversely affect the domestic job market.
They further predicted that if the domestic industrial structure is not overhauled, the ratio of overseas production will continue to rise. (April 21, 2010) Liberty Times:

Kenneth Lin, an economics professor at National Taiwan University, said the high ratio of overseas production will not only worsen structural unemployment but will also affect domestic wage levels and consumption.

He reminded the government that the exodus of local IT and electronics companies will further accelerate once the proposed cross-Taiwan Strait economic cooperation framework agreement (ECFA) is signed. (April 21, 2010)

DOC.HEADLINE: Commercial Times: Think twice before downsizing statistics units

TEXT.P: In line with ongoing government restructuring efforts, the Cabinet recently came to a preliminary decision to merge the accounting and statistics units under various government agencies.
This raises concerns that the government's statistics function -- an essential element of credible governance -- could be undermined.

We think there are two possible ways to fix the situation. First, the government could use new technology to make up for decreased manpower. Second, the Directorate-General of Budget, Accounting and Statistics will have to assume heavier responsibilities, collecting accurate information for timely and efficient statistical analysis to provide a basis for policy-making and resource distribution.

We call on the authorities to pay attention to the profound impact that the reform is likely to have. The government must be cautious about the matter and must not act simply for the sake of expediency. (April 21, 2010)

DOC.HEADLINE: Slovakian couple get married in Taiwan due to volcanic ash delay
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, April 21 (CNA) 04/21/10 12:15:06 (By Chiu Chun-chin and Elizabeth Hsu)

TEXT.P: Love has proved more powerful than a volcanic eruption as a central European couple have gotten married in Taiwan after being unable to return to Europe for their wedding that had been planned for April 24.
The 32-year-old Juraj Hegyi married Zuzana Marcekova, whom he has been in love with for 13 years, Tuesday at the Orchard Park Hotel in northern Taiwan's Taoyuan County.

The hotel is not far from Taiwan's main international gateway, Taiwan Taoyuan International Airport, where many passengers have been stranded after their flights to Europe were canceled because of a volcanic eruption in Iceland.

None of the couple's family members were present at wedding, but many local residents, hotel staffers and other European travelers like Hegyi and Marcekova stranded in Taiwan were on hand to help the couple celebrate their marriage.

Hegyi, a physician from Slovakia, and Marcekova, 31, a radiology technician from the Czech Republic, were taking a trip through Asia and had planned to return home for their wedding in Slovakia on April 24.

They had visited Thailand, Singapore and Hong Kong before flying to Taiwan for a transit stop before heading on to Europe, but by that time, the ash drift spread by the volcano had already shut down air travel over the continent.

Marcekova said they had to cancel the wedding they had planned for more than a year after learning their flight home would be postponed indefinitely. That realization sent Marcekova into tears, according to hotel staff.
After learning of the couple's story, hotel founder and chairman Li San-lian decided to organize a wedding ceremony for them within a day.
Dozens of hotel staffers and workers were summoned to assist the couple in purchasing wedding rings, arranging a ceremony and selecting a wedding gown.
With all of the couple's new Taiwanese friends and her love for her husband, the "volcanic eruption was nothing, " said the bride after the ceremony.

The wedding was based on a traditional Christian ceremony -- singing Christian songs, reading bible passages, and exchanging rings -- and was witnessed by Christian minister Kao Tien-yuan from Chung Yuan Christian University.

Family members of the couple watched the ceremony via video conference. Expressing his gratitude, Hegyi said the passion of the Taiwanese people and the hotel's assistance saved them from feeling regret for the rest of their lives.
"Life is full of surprises. Taiwan will be a memory that we will never forget, " he said.

DOC.HEADLINE: Clashes erupt in legislature over opening to Chinese students
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, April 21 (CNA) 04/21/10 14:36:04 (By Huang Ming-hsi and Sofia Wu)

TEXT.P: Violent clashes broke out in the Legislative Yuan Wednesday as lawmakers fought over draft amendments to two education laws that would pave the way for local universities and colleges to recruit Chinese students.

Ruling Kuomintang (KMT) Legislator Chao Li-yun, who was chairing the meeting of the Education and Culture Committee, fainted during the commotion and was rushed to nearby National Taiwan University (NTU) Hospital for treatment.
Chao quickly regained consciousness and is recuperating at NTU Hospital, KMT legislative caucus sources said.
Two opposition Democratic Progressive Party legislators, Kuan Bi-ling and Chen Ting-fei, were also sent to the hospital after sustaining injuries in the brawl.
The clashes broke out at 9 a.m. immediately after Chao announced the start of a hearing on draft amendments to the University Act and the Junior College Act.

DPP lawmakers tried to block Education Minister Wu Ching-ji from delivering a briefing on the amendment proposals, which would lead to the opening of local universities and colleges to Chinese students.
They surrounded Wu and asked him to suspend the proposals, but Wu managed to deliver a brief report on the MOE-drafted amendments under the protection of KMT lawmakers.

Kuan fueled the flames when she displayed an e-mail from the secretariat of a college association that suggested that nine university presidents who voiced public support for the amendments a day earlier felt pressured to do so by the Ministry of Education (MOE) because they receive MOE subsidies.
More scuffles broke out after the KMT legislative caucus announced the start of the question-and-answer stage of the committee's review of the two bills.
Chao fainted after she announced that the two bills had completed their first review and were to be referred to the full legislature for further deliberation.
The brawl came to an abrupt end at 9:55 a.m. when Chao was rushed to NTU Hospital and Minister Wu left the building.
Legislator Lin Yi-shih, who concurrently serves as the head of the KMT's policy coordination committee, said the two bills completed their first review in accordance with legal procedures.

The DPP's legislative caucus thought otherwise, however, saying that the procedures have yet to be finalized. DPP caucus members warned that if the KMT sticks to its guns, they will do their utmost to block the bills at the full legislative session.

DOC.HEADLINE: New Taiwan-U.S. beef row can be handled well with trust: MOFA
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, April 21 (CNA) 04/21/10 14:44:22 (By Lee Ming-chung and Y.F. Low)

TEXT.P: The Ministry of Foreign Affairs (MOFA) expressed confidence Wednesday that the latest controversy on the Taiwan-U.S. beef trade can be handled properly with mutual trust between the two sides.
Taiwan has been maintaining fluid dialogue and consultation with the U.S. on the issue and will make sure the communication continues, said Vice Minister of Foreign Affairs David Y.L. Lin.

Lin said Taiwan's decision to strengthen inspections of U.S. beef parts, including tongues, diaphragms and testicles, should be understandable to the U.S. government because it is an internal and domestic administrative measure.
The controversy was triggered by a recent application by a Taiwanese firm to import 453 kg of beef tongues and diaphragms from the United States.

In response to the application, the Department of Health (DOH) and the Ministry of Economic Affairs said beef offal items allowed to be imported to Taiwan should come from just 40 butchers certified by the U.S. government.
Once the products arrive, they will be subject to batch-by-batch inspections.

However, the Office of the United States Trade Representative said Monday that Taiwan's actions "are not consistent" with a bilateral protocol signed last October, under which Taiwan agreed to lift its ban on U.S. bone-in beef and certain other beef products.
The DOH issued a rebuttal Tuesday, saying that the protocol allows Taiwan to impose measures to control U.S. beef at borders.
The Bureau of Foreign Trade said the same day that the importer had withdrawn its application.

DOC.HEADLINE: Flights to European destinations gradually returning to normal
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, April 21 (CNA) 04/21/10 15:09:11 (By Chen Shun-hsieh and Lilian Wu)

TEXT.P: With most of Europe opening up its skies in the wake of the diminishing effect of a volcanic ash cloud drifting from Iceland, Europe-bound flights were gradually returning to normal Wednesday.
EVA Airways, one of Taiwan's two major carriers, said its three regular flights -- Taipei-Paris, Taipei-Bangkok-Vienna and Taipei-Bangkok-London -- would depart on time.

EVA had originally canceled its Bangkok-London flight, but after the plane had taken off from Taipei bound for Bangkok, it learned that London's Heathrow Airport had re-opened and decided in mid-flight that it would continue on to London after transiting in Bangkok.
Meanwhile that same day, the country's other major airline, China Airlines, was operating five flights to and from Europe.
Two of CAL's passenger flights that had been stranded at Frankfurt Airport left for Taipei, while another passenger flight stuck in Amsterdam also returned home.

In addition, regular flights from Taipei to Vienna and Frankfurt scheduled for the previous day were set to leave later Wednesday after getting consent from Vienna and Frankfurt airports for delayed departure.
Both EVA and CAL said they were planning and applying for additional flights, hoping to get around 2,000 Taiwanese passengers still stranded in Europe back home to Taiwan as soon as possible.

Meanwhile, Hong Kong-based Cathay Pacific had flights to Paris, London, Frankfurt, Amsterdam, Rome and Milan, while Singapore Airlines had flights to Paris, Amsterdam, Rome, Zurich and Barcelona Wednesday.

DOC.HEADLINE: Stranded Taiwanese travelers finally fly home
DOC.DATELINE: Rome and London, April 21 (CNA) 04/21/10 15:24:20 (By Huang Ya-shih, Jennifer Huang and Elizabeth Hsu)

TEXT.P: Hundreds of Taiwanese travelers who had been stranded in Europe for nearly a week were finally able to return home Tuesday night when China Airlines (CAL) resumed service on its Rome-Delhi-Taipei route.
"We're finally going home! , " was the refrain of many relieved passengers after receiving their boarding pass for the Rome-Taipei flight.
A Taiwanese businessman said he had tried to seek a way to return home for a week before getting on the flight in Rome.
"You feel helpless when your heart is in Taiwan, but you can't fly back," he said.

Nearly 2,000 Taiwanese passengers were stranded in Europe when a volcanic eruption in Iceland spewed massive amounts of ash into the atmosphere on April 14, forcing the cancellation of flights around the continent.

With Rome the most likely of European destinations serviced by Taiwanese carriers to be reopened first, some Taiwanese travelers made their way to the Italian airport, hoping to catch an early flight home.

Two Taiwanese businessmen recalled their ordeal after they could not get a flight home from Milan. Unable to book seats on the Eurostar train between Milan and Rome, they were forced to take local trains to the Italian capital, said one of the businessmen, surnamed Huang.

"We had to change trains four or five times to get here, " he said. 'We both suffer from high blood pressure and we had to return to Taiwan as soon as possible because we were running out of medicine."

They had originally bought tickets for a flight on Beijing-based Air China in Milan destined for China and thought they could then catch a connection to Taiwan. But Air China later told them that there would be no flights until May 1, Huang said.
Meanwhile, Taiwan's de facto ambassador to the United Kingdom, Katharine Chang, said Tuesday that there were currently nearly 1,000 Taiwanese people left stranded in London.
Her office has been trying to help Taiwanese citizens in any way possible, including assisting them in obtaining visas for travel to the European continent to catch flights home, Chang said.
The office has also helped travelers find cheaper hotels, hostels or restaurants and assisted a diabetes patient get medicine, she said.

After the British government announced that all airports in the U.K. would open at 10 p.m. Tuesday, Taiwan's two major carriers, CAL and EVA Airways, said they expected flights from London to Taipei to resume on April 22.

DOC.HEADLINE: Premier to resign if jobless rate remains higher than 5%
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, April 21 (CNA) 04/21/10 15:34:26 (By Lee Shu-hua and Sofia Wu)

TEXT.P: Premier Wu Den-yih reiterated Wednesday that he will resign if Taiwan's unemployment rate remains above 5 percent by the end of this year.
In an interview with a cable TV station, Wu said he was serious when he pledged earlier this year that he would step down if the jobless rate remains higher than 5 percent at the end of 2010.

Asked how the Cabinet would achieve the goal after the unemployment rate rose to 5.67 percent in February, Wu said the increase mainly resulted from seasonal factors, because many people change jobs around the Lunar New Year holiday.
The premier indicated that one factor that could bring down the jobless rate is the replacement of civil servants as they retire from government service.
He also pointed to job openings that would be created as the global economy continues to recover, and Taiwan's manufacturers receive more export orders.

On the possibility that the jobless rate will surge to new highs this summer as new university graduates enter the job market for the first time, Wu said the Cabinet will make every possible effort to create new employment opportunities and help new graduates land jobs.

DOC.HEADLINE: Taiwan share prices close higher
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, April 21 (CNA) 04/21/10 15:35:03 (by Olivia Wang)

TEXT.P: Taiwan's share prices closed higher Wednesday with the weighted index, the market's key barometer, moving up 90.11 points, or 1.14 percent, to close at 7,990.53.
The local bourse opened at 7,949.96 and fluctuated between a low of 7,947.90 and a high of 7,998.76 during the day's trading. Market turnover totaled NT$117.94 billion (US$3.76 billion).

All eight major stock categories gained ground, with paper and pulp issues gaining the most at 1.88 percent. Machinery and electronics issues rose 1.51 percent and construction shares moved up 1.21 percent.

Plastics and chemicals issues and financial and banking stocks were up 0.7 percent, and cement issues advanced 0.49 percent. Foodstuff shares edged up 0.3 percent and textile issues were up 0.19 percent.
Gainers outnumbered losers 2,409 to 806, with 250 remaining unchanged.
Foreign investors and Chinese QDIIs were net buyers of NT$6.49 billion in shares.

DOC.HEADLINE: U.S. dollar down on Taipei Forex
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, April 21 (CNA) 04/21/10 16:25:24 (By Olivia Wang)

TEXT.P: The U.S. dollar lost ground against the New Taiwan dollar on the Taipei Foreign Exchange Wednesday, dropping NT$0.059 to close at NT$31.388.
A total of US$908 million changed hands during the trading session.
The U.S. dollar opened at the day's high of NT$31.447 and fell to a low of NT$31.334 before rebounding.

DOC.HEADLINE: U.S. continues support for Taiwan's WHA participation
DOC.DATELINE: Washington, April 20 (CNA) 04/21/10 17:33:30 (By Jorge Liu and Y.L. Kao)

TEXT.P: The U.S. Department of State (DOS) has notified Congress of Washington's continued support for Taiwan's observer status at the 63rd World Health Assembly (WHA) next month.

The DOS submitted a report to Congress last week in accordance with a congressional resolution that required the department to make clear the U.S. position regarding Taiwan's participation ahead of the annual WHA.
The report said: "Last year our efforts bore fruit: Taiwan was invited to participate as an observer at the 62nd World Health Assembly in May 2009."

For the first time since Taiwan began seeking observer status at the WHA in 1996, a delegation from Taiwan under the name "Chinese Taipei" was invited by World Health Organization (WHO) Director-General Margaret Chan to participate in the 2009 WHA as an observer.

The report said that Washington would welcome the WHA extending another invitation to Taiwan and that the U.S. will seek confirmation from the WHO director general that Taiwan is invited to this year's assembly.
"Our goal will be for the WHO to regularly invite Taiwan every year to attend the WHA as an observer," the DOS said in the report.

At last year's WHA, Health and Human Services Secretary Kathleen Sebelius said the WHA welcomed Chinese Taipei's participation as an observer and expressed her hope that "experts from Taiwan will be able to participate consistently and meaningfully in technical meetings of the WHO, for the benefit of global public health, " the report said.
Taiwan's participation in the WHA was a positive development and could provide a model for its participation as an observer in other U.N. bodies, it said.

"In addition to WHA observer status in 2009, at the urging of the United States and other like-minded WHO Member States, the WHO made progress toward providing Taiwan greater access to the work of the organization," it noted.
For example, it said the WHO secretariat helped allow Taiwan to participate directly in the implementation of the world health body's International Health Regulations (IHRs), according to the DOS.

"The United States will continue to work with the WHO and its Member States to advance the universal application of the IHRs and to involve Taiwan's experts in relevant technical meetings of the WHO consistent with our 'one China' policy," it said.

The report went on to say that outbreaks such as severe acute respiratory syndrome (SARS) , avian influenza, and H1N1 influenza underlined the "need to involve Taiwan in a meaningful, pragmatic way in the work of the WHO."

DOC.HEADLINE: Foreign contractors urged to bid for Taiwan infrastructure projects
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, April 21 (CNA) 04/21/10 17:37:41 (By Wei Shu and Sofia Wu)

TEXT.P: President Ma Ying-jeou on Wednesday invited joint bids by foreign and local construction companies for major infrastructure projects in Taiwan, saying it would be a win-win situation for them.

Addressing the opening of the 38th Conference of the International Federation of Asia and Western Pacific Contractors' Association (IFAWPCA) , Ma said his administration has launched many large infrastructure construction projects in recent years as part of its efforts to help boost domestic economic development amid a global financial crisis.
In 2009, Ma said, public infrastructure investment posted a 20 percent annual growth, which has helped stimulate domestic demand and contributed to job creation.

Noting that Taiwan has become a signatory to the Government Procurement Agreement (GPA) under the World Trade Organization, Ma said his administration has helped open up US$900 billion worth of business opportunities at home and abroad for local contractors.
Taiwan is now about to launch a number of critical infrastructure projects, such as the Taoyuan aviation city development plan and the Kaohsiung shipping- aviation hub program, he noted.
"We are inviting foreign contractors to join forces with their Taiwanese counterparts to bid for these ambitious projects for mutual benefits," Ma added.
In the face of the threat of global warming, Ma also encourage contractors around the world to build more green buildings to help conserve energy and reduce carbon emissions.

The three-day IFAWPCA conference has brought together senior executives of major contractors' associations in 16 Asia-Pacific countries to discuss feasible strategies for sustainable development in the 21st century, including the use of new technologies to make buildings safer.
Taiwan last hosted an IFAWPCA annual conference 22 years ago.

DOC.HEADLINE: Office workers dream of changing jobs to make more money
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, April 21 (CNA) 04/21/10 17:39:13 (By I. S. Cheng and Flor Wang)

TEXT.P: Close to 58 percent of Taiwan's office workers dream of finding better-paying jobs to improve their financial means, according to the results of a survey published Wednesday.

In the survey conducted by online manpower agency 104 Job Bank asking white- collar workers what they dreamed about, nearly three-fifths (57.86 percent) said their most common dream was to change jobs and have a better salary.
They needed annual incomes of NT$870,000 (US$27,620) on average to make their dreams come true, the poll found.
The other top dreams cited, in order, were saving NT$1 million, buying a home, mastering a foreign language, and starting one's own business.
They were followed by successfully losing weight, traveling independently, falling in love, passing national examinations, and getting married, according to the survey.
Men and women's dreams varied significantly. Losing weight was the fourth most popular dream among female respondents but did not figure in the top 10 among men.
Conversely, getting married and buying cars were the No. 6 and No. 8 dreams for male respondents, respectively, but they were not high among women's choices.
For those born after the 1980s, studying overseas was one of their top 10 dreams, according to the poll.
Some 80 percent of office workers believe they do not make enough to meet their needs and feel compelled to find other ways to make money, the survey found.
They said the best methods to make more money were to get high-paid jobs, better manage their finances, save money and take on part-time jobs.

About 66 percent of the female respondents said they were trying to get extra work at home, while 54 percent of their male peers preferred to have a part-time job related to their full-time employment.

Generally speaking, Taiwan's salaried workers take "time schedule flexibility, " "the need not to disrupt their full-time work, " and "salary" into account when considering whether or not to work part-time.

According to the poll, those who already have a part-time job earn an additional NT$7,875 per month on average, far below the NT$13,040 individuals who have yet to find a part-time job are hoping for.
The job bank carried out the survey from April 1-7, collecting 2,755 valid questionnaires. It has a margin of error of plus or minus 1.86 percentage points.

DOC.HEADLINE: Premier explains policy on U.S. beef tongue imports
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, April 21 (CNA) 04/21/10 18:23:23 (By Lee Shu-hua and Elizabeth Hsu)

TEXT.P: Premier Wu Den-yih defended Wednesday a government decision to hold back on approval for imports of controversial U.S. beef tongues, saying that no changes had been made to the administration's beef policy and that experts will be invited again to provide a clear definition of exactly which items constitute beef internal organs.

Praising the Department of Health's (DOH's) strategy for handling the controversy surrounding certain U.S. beef offal items, Wu explained that the decision to hold back import approval and invite experts to provide an unambiguous definition were made to ensure public safety and calm public doubts.

The DOH, the Ministry of Economic Affairs and the Council of Agriculture announced at a joint press conference the previous day that imported U.S. beef tongues, testicles and diaphragms will all undergo the most strict inspection upon arrival in Taiwan.
Checks will be performed "case by case" rather than "batch by batch" the government had said a few days previously.
Meanwhile, Bureau of Foreign Trade (BOFT) Director-General Huang Chih-peng suggested that traders refrain from importing the controversial beef cuts until the public doubts have been assuaged.

The changes, however, drew criticism from Hsien Tien-jen, chairman of the non- profit Consumers Foundation, who denounced the government for not prohibiting imports of high-risk beef products on one hand and for advising importers not to import the products on the other.
The government's measures "contradict each other, " he blasted. Eventually, whole cows, regardless of how old they are, will be allowed to enter Taiwan's markets, he predicted.

Taiwan agreed in a protocol with Washington last Oct. 22 to lift a ban on U.S. bone-in beef and certain other beef products from cattles younger than 30 months. Amid public concerns over the import of high-risk beef products, the Legislative Yuan passed a measure in January that barred imports of U.S. beef products classified as "internal organs."

Wu pointed out that the DOH had invited experts last May 18 to define what "internal organs" are in terms of U.S. beef cuts. At that time, tongues, diaphragms and testicles were not included in the category, he said, noting that it was this definition that allowed the BOFT to begin April 1 to accept applications for imports of these beef cuts.

However, since consumers and scholars began to question the safety of beef tongues for consumption and why the item is not categorized as an internal organ, the government believes it is necessary to gather experts for a review of the definition, Wu said.

The government announced Monday that six types of offal on the U.S. Trade Representative list -- tongues, penises, testicles, tails, tendons and diaphragms -- are not classified as internal organs and that imports of those beef products will be permitted.
But acknowledging the lingering public doubts over beef tongue, it said imports of the product would require a special import permit and would have to pass batch-by-batch inspections.

Meanwhile, amid the controversy that has inflamed debate among politicians and consumer rights activists, Chung Cheng-wei, a chef at a Yakiniku restaurant in Taichung City, was quoted by the United Daily News as saying that beef tongues are covered with nerve tissue. Even if the part close to the tonsils are removed, they can still be a threat if they come from a place affected by mad cow disease, he said.
Beef tongue is a popular menu item at Yakiniku restaurants in Taiwan, and even beef testicles are seen as gourmet food, the report said.

DOC.HEADLINE: Taiwanese fishing boat missing off Indonesia found
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, April 21 (CNA) 04/21/10 18:34:57 (By Kuo Chu-chen and Y.L. Kao)

TEXT.P: A Taiwanese fishing vessel that went missing off Indonesia last week has been found and is being kept under surveillance by the Indonesian Navy, the head of a fishermen's association in Liuchiu, Taiwan's southern county of Pingtung said Wednesday.

The Liuchiu-registered Chen Fu Hsiang 16 was found Tuesday, nearly a week after it lost contact with Taiwan last Wednesday while it was operating in an area south of Sri Lanka in the Indian Ocean, according to Tsai Pao-hsing, the head of the Liuchiu Fishermen's Association.
Due to high waves and strong winds at the sea off Indonesia Tuesday, the Indonesian Navy was unable to approach the missing vessel and was only able to keep a close watch on it.
So it was still unknown what happened on the boat, Tsai said, citing information from the Ministry of Foreign Affairs.
The association and family members of the Taiwanese captain of the fishing vessel suspect that the captain might have been hijacked by the eight Indonesian crew members on the boat, Tsai said.

DOC.HEADLINE: 'Taiwan's Susan Boyle' interviewed by U.S. talk shows
DOC.DATELINE: Los Angeles, April 20 (CNA) 04/21/10 18:44:10 (By Chiang Chin-yeh and Y.F. Low)

TEXT.P: Taiwanese singer and Internet sensation Lin Yu-chun -- dubbed "Taiwan's Susan Boyle" -- was interviewed by two major U.S. talk shows Tuesday.
Lin used a translator during the interviews on the Ellen DeGeneres Show and Lopez Tonight, scheduled for broadcast the next day.
Lin told Taiwanese journalists after the recordings that his feelings were "indescribable" after appearing on the shows as the first-ever Taiwanese guest.
"I'm very happy because I'm drawing the world's attention to Taiwan," Lin said.

The 24-year-old shot to fame after a video showing him singing Whitney Houston's version of "I Will Always Love You" was posted on YouTube April 6. The clip, from his performance on Taiwan talent show "Million Star," has tallied over 12 million hits to date.
On the Ellen Show, Lin said, he presented a live rendition of the song and received a standing ovation from the audience.
On Lopez Tonight, he sang "Saving All My Love For You, " another of Houston's hits, and Bonnie Tyler's "Total Eclipse of the Heart."

Lin said that it was the first time he sang "Total Eclipse of the Heart" publicly and that his performance deeply impressed the accompanying musicians, who encouraged him to seek a career in show business in the United States.
Asked by George Lopez about what he would like to do the most, the food-lover said he wanted to hold a hamburger in one hand and a bowl of Haagen-Dazs ice cream in the other.

Lin said that Lopez, who was aware of his love for ice cream, had arranged for ice cream to be sent to his hotel and prepared more than 10 bowls of chocolate ice cream for him in the studio, as well as giving him a gift certificate from a prominent U.S. hamburger chain.

Also on the show, Lin, who weighs 110 kg and is nicknamed "fatty, " recalled his childhood experience of being bullied because of his size. He advised those who are having the same problem not to worry and to have confidence in themselves.
"The best way to get back at your bullies is to excel them, " he said.

Speaking about the rest of his itinerary in Los Angeles, Lin said he will attend an American Idol Gives Back concert with tickets presented to him by DeGeneres and shop for large-sized clothing in Hollywood before returning to Taiwan.

DOC.HEADLINE: Hubei businessmen sign 35 purchase agreements
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, April 21 (CNA) 04/21/10 19:17:02 (By Feng Chao, Kuo Mei-lan, Cheng Chin-wen and Lilian Wu)

TEXT.P: Representatives of major businesses, including Wuhan Bluestar Computer and Wushang Bulksale, from central China's Hubei Province, signed 35 procurement agreements with local businessmen Wednesday.
With Hubei Province aiming to become "China's optics valley," the purchases mainly involved electronic parts such as flat panels and LEDs.

Representatives from the Jointown Pharmaceutical Group, one of the top 500 businesses in China, noted that Taiwan excels in biotech medicine and medical equipment, and the group signed a purchase deal worth US$15 million with a local biotech firm.
Jointown also expressed hope that it will be able to sell Chinese herbal medicines to Taiwan.
Delphi Hubei, meanwhile, purchased nearly US$10 million-worth of automotive electronic diodes from Taiwan's Actron Technology Corp.
Hubei buyers also included the Wuhan Zhongbai Group and the Wuhan Zhongnan Commercial Group, whose purchases were focused on agricultural products and daily necessities.

Taiwanese businessmen attending the purchase meetings recognized the importance of Hubei's geographic location and expressed hope that they will be able to use the province as a stepping stone into China's domestic market.
A total of 36 manufacturers from Hubei Province took part in the procurement meetings.

Yang Fang, an official of the Wuhan Hanshang Group, said there are not many Taiwanese products available in Wuhan City, the provincial capital, and that what is available is mainly sold in supermarkets.

Yang said it was her first procurement visit to Taiwan, and she expressed particular interest in beauty care products such as red cypress essential oil, red cypress shampoo and facial masks, because such products are uncommon in Wuhan and people generally have to go to beauty parlors to buy them.
She suggested that Taiwanese businesses should establish agents in China to help Chinese buyers who want to discuss business with them.

The procurement meetings were part of the seventh Taiwan-Hubei (Wuhan) week that opened in Taipei a day earlier, in which participants were hoping to expand commercial, technological, cultural and agriculture exchanges between Taiwan and central western China.
In a related development, meanwhile, a Taiwan-Hubei (Wuhan) Week Cultural Exhibition opened in Taipei Wednesday.

Luo Qingquan, secretary of the Hubei Provincial Committee of the Communist Party of China, Taiwan's opposition New Party Chairman Yok Mu-ming, former Straits Exchange Foundation Vice Chairman Chiao Jen-ho, as well as Chinese painter Zhou Shaohua and Taiwanese artist Li Chi-mao, attended the opening ceremony.

Luo was leading a 1,000-strong delegation from Hubei that arrived April 19 to enhance exchanges between Hubei and Taiwan. The delegation is expected to make purchases worth more than US$500 million during the visit.

DOC.HEADLINE: Local firms urged to sponsor world climate event
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, April 21 (CNA) 04/21/10 19:19:10 (By Alex Jiang)

TEXT.P: Environmental activists held a press briefing Wednesday to urge local firms, especially those in electronics and green energy industries, to sponsor an upcoming conference on climate change.
More than 100 eco-friendly activists from abroad will attend the meeting, said Pan Han-shen, the convener of the Green Party Taiwan.

Major companies in Taiwan's petrochemical, steel and financial industries have agreed to sponsor the second Conference of the Asia Pacific Greens Network, which is slated to take place in Taipei April 30-May 2, Pan said.
"We, however, have met setbacks in raising funds from local electronics and green energy companies," he said.

"The event is one of the major climate change conferences in the Asia Pacific region... It is also the first time for Taiwan to host an event on international cooperation on climate change, " Pan added.

Tuvalu's Prime Minister Apisai Ielemia, who received much attention after warning that rising sea levels might submerge his homeland at last year's Copenhagen climate change summit, originally could not attend the conference in Taiwan due to the organizer's lack of financial support.
"But after Taiwan's foreign ministry decided to lend a hand, the prime minister will be able to give a keynote speech at the conference," Pan said.

The organizer is now seeking sponsorship from 20 local companies, each of which is expected to offer NT$48,000 (US$1,500) . The organizer explained that they want to diversify the sources of donations to avoid the dominance of any single company.

"NT$48,000 will allow 10 Taiwanese non-profit organization members to take part in the event. We will also allow one person from each sponsor to join the event for free to learn more about green issues," Pan said.
The event offers Taiwanese activists an opportunity to have a dialogue with delegates from over 20 countries in the Asia Pacific region, the organizer said in a statement.

"I believe the great significance of the conference is to help us learn from other countries that environmental protection means protecting the social and economic environments as well, which is a world trend," said Robin Winkler, a local environmentalist.
"If the natural environment goes wrong, so does the social environment and the economic environment," he told reporters.

Miriam Solomon, international secretary of Australian Greens, said: "When people come together from these different countries, very commonly, they are surprised at how similar they are and how the struggles we have and difficulties we face are very similar."

"We found that normally across the world, if you are speaking the truth, a lot of people don't like you, " she said. "So we come together to encourage each other to keep speaking the truth and not to be discouraged."

DOC.HEADLINE: Chiayi County launching `save Alishan' tourism campaign
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, April 21 (CNA) 04/21/10 19:39:37 (By Chiang Chun-liang and Elizabeth Hsu)

TEXT.P: The government of southern Taiwan's Chiayi County launched a "Save Alishan Driv " Wednesday with the aim of increasing the number of tourists to Alishan -- once Taiwan's most popular tourist destination but presently suffering a decline -- to 1 million people per year.

Chiayi Magistrate Chang Hwa-kuan pointed out that since the Alishan area was severely damaged by massive flooding and landslides caused by Typhoon Morakot last August, the number of visitors has decreased dramatically.

So far this year, only 94,780 people have visited Alishan for cherry blossom season March 15-April 15, just 33 percent of the number who came last year for the area's most popular annual event, Chang said.
The figure was even smaller than the number who came for cherry blossom season in 2004, the year following the outbreaks of Severe Acute Respiratory Syndrome (SARS), she went on.

Citing Tourism Bureau statistics, Chang said Alishan attracted 175,571 sightseeing visits in the first three months of this year, representing a decline of 422,046 visits -- or 71 percent -- compared with the same period of 2009. This reflects the fact that tourism in the Alishan area is in recession, she pointed out.

In an effort to revive tourism, Chang invited all tour and hotel operators in the mountain resort area to join the drive. She also urged the central government to help by opening the Alishan National Forest Recreation Area for free visits and repairing the forest railway that has been closed due to severe damage by Morakot.
She expressed hope that the number of tourists to Alishan will recover to an average annual level of 800,000 people within a year, and rise further to 1 million within two years.

DOC.HEADLINE: Yo-Yo Ma, Silk Road Ensemble arrive in Taiwan for 3-city tour
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei April 21 (CNA) 04/21/10 19:50:03 (By Sunnie Chen)

TEXT.P: Renowned cellist Yo-Yo Ma and the Silk Road Ensemble arrived in Taipei Wednesday for a performance tour of three cities from April 22-25.
They will also hold two workshops at which they will share their experience and expertise with local musicians. One of the workshops is geared specifically toward young people in the 12-18 age group.

The concerts, to be held in Taipei, Taichung and Kaohsiung, will feature a repertoire that includes Ahmet Adnan Saygun: Partita, Opus 31, Allegretto; Persian Traditional: Ascending Bird; and Chinese Traditional: White Snow in the Sunny Spring.
Ma started The Silk Road Project, a non-profit artistic, cultural and educational organization, 10 years ago.
"During this time, we have been to Taiwan, Korean, Egypt and many other countries. In these travels, we feel more part of the world and more human," Ma said at a press conference Wednesday.
The aim of the project is to promote innovation and learning through the arts, he said.
"The best students are teachers, the best teachers are students, and I think that the best thing is to share our passions, " Ma said.

The Silk Road Ensemble was established with the participation of internationally renowned performers and composers from more than 20 countries. The instrumental voices include piano, violin, pipa, erhu and many others.
According to the ensemble, the goals of its virtuoso musicians are to nurture global connections while maintaining the integrity of art rooted in an authentic tradition.
One of the ensemble members, Chinese musician Wu Tong who plays the sheng and bawu, said the experience of working with Ma since 2000 has changed his life.
According to Wu, he was rock singer but after he met Ma he started to try different genres of music. In the process, he learned about tolerance and understanding, he said.
Wu also thanked Taiwan for sending medical and relief aid to the quake-affected area of Qinghai in China. He promised to bring the best quality music to the people of Taiwan.
The concerts will be held at National Concert Hall, Taipei April 22; Fulfill Amphitheatre, Taichung April 24; and at Jhihde Hall, Kaohsiung April 25.

DOC.HEADLINE: Taiwan ready to embrace trade pact with China: president
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, April 21 (CNA) 04/21/10 20:03:28 (By S. H. Lee and Flor Wang)

TEXT.P: President and ruling Kuomintang (KMT) Chairman Ma Ying-jeou said Wednesday that the government has readied itself to deal with the impact of a planned trade pact with China on local industry and workers.

To mitigate the possible negative effects of the cross-Taiwan Strait economic cooperation framework agreement (ECFA) on some local industries and their workers, the government is planning to earmark a budget of NT$95 billion (US$3.03 billion) over a 10-year period to serve that end, Ma told reporters after a weekly meeting of the KMT's policy-making Central Standing Committee.

Citing a study by the Chung-Hua Institution for Economic Research, Ma said the tariff-concession trade pact would help create 260,000 jobs for Taiwanese workers although it would also affect some 80,000 people.
"This does not mean that 80,000 workers would lose their jobs, rather, it means that their salaries or benefits might contract," he explained.

According to an assessment made by the Ministry of Economic Affairs (MOEA) , 17 traditional sectors, such as towels, garments, bedding, and Chinese herbal medicine, would become vulnerable if the two sides ink the trade agreement, which aim to eliminate tariffs, he pointed out.
But Ma stressed: "There will be more advantages than disadvantages if the trade deal is put in place."
"Should we fail to sign the ECFA with China, a lot more companies would be forced to relocate to other countries and more workers would lose their jobs," Ma said.
Taiwan and China are slated to hold the next round of ECFA talks in May or June in China. Both sides have reiterated their resolve to clinch the agreement the sooner the better.
The two sides have tried hard to arrive at an "early harvest list" which will contain items of trade that will enjoy immediate tariff reduction or elimination after the agreement is signed.

Ma said signing a trade agreement with China is particularly significant to Taiwan as it will make Taiwanese goods more competitive in the vast Chinese market amid fierce competition from countries in the region after China forms a zero-tariff "ASEAN plus one" free trade area with countries in Southeast Asia this year.

DOC.HEADLINE: Taiwan boys advance to second round of Junior Davis Cup
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, April 21 (CNA) 04/21/10 20:03:40 (By Chris Wang)

TEXT.P: The Taiwan boys' team lost to India 2-1 in the 2010 Junior Davis Cup tennis tournament Wednesday in Kuching, Malaysia, but still managed to advance to the second round.

Taiwan finished the round with a 2-1 record and advanced with Group 4 leader India to the final eight of the 16-team Asia/Oceania Final Qualifying tournament. Taiwan beat both the Philippines and Pakistan 3-0 in previous competition.
Taiwan's Lee Li-lun and Ho Chih-jen lost in singles Wednesday before winning the doubles match.
According to the Chinese Taipei Tennis Association, Japan has won Group 1 while junior tennis powerhouse Australia is expected to win Group 2. China and South Korea are battling to lead Group 3.
Eight teams in the second round will vie for the three seats for the Asia/Oceania zone in the world finals.

Around 90 nations and 170 teams compete in regional qualifying events around the world every year to reach the Junior Davis Cup and Junior Fed Cup Finals, to be played from Sept. 28-Oct. 3 this year in San Luis Potosi, Mexico.

DOC.HEADLINE: Taiwan medical mission on 10-day trip to Nepal
DOC.DATELINE: New Delhi, April 21 (CNA) 04/21/10 20:09:04 (By Ho Hung-ju and Y.L. Kao)

TEXT.P: A 12-member Taiwanese mobile medical mission left New Delhi Wednesday for Nepal's capital, Kathmandu, to provide 10-day free medical services to outlying villages there.
The team was led by Chen Chih-fu, leader of the Taiwan International Cooperation and Development Fund (TaiwanICDF) Mobile Medical Mission.
All the volunteers taking part in the mission paid NT$50,000 (US$1,593) each for air tickets, food and accommodation, as well as helping to raise US$6,000 to buy medical supplies, Chen told the CNA.

With the assistance of a Chinese language school in Kathmandu, the mission was planning to buy the medical supplies there, Chen went on, adding that only about US$4,000 had been collected so far and the members would have to pay the remaining amount out of their own pockets if no more funds were raised.
The Indian branch of Fo Guang Shan, the largest Buddhist monastery in Taiwan, was to help manage transport and itineraries for the volunteers during the mission.
The mission was scheduled to provide medical services in six to seven villages around Kathmandu, Chen went on.

Continuity of care should be integral to offering effective and efficient health care overseas, Chen continued, adding that his team will gather more information about endemic diseases in Nepal to improve the continuity of medical care there.
The team includes physicians in various disciplines, as well as two pharmacists and four nurses from four hospitals in southern Taiwan.

DOC.HEADLINE: Taiwanese cosmetics artist wins top award in Vancouver
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, April 21 (CNA) 04/21/10 21:13:24 (By Chou Yung-chieh and Sofia Wu)

TEXT.P: A young Taiwanese cosmetics artist won the coveted top prize at the International Make-Up Artist Trade Show (IMAT) in Vancouver, Canada last Sunday.
"It came as a big surprise to me," a jubilant Cheng Wei-ying said in a telephone interview with the Central News Agency Wednesday.

Cheng, an information and mass communications graduate of Yuan Ze University in northern Taiwan's Taoyuan County, is studying makeup design at the Vancouver Film School. She was the school's first student of Chinese descent to receive the top award in an IMAT contest. The award carried a cash prize of 1,000 Canadian dollars.
The IMAT is held five times per year -- in London, Toronto, Vancouver, Los Angeles and Sydney -- and the contest is open to students and those who have graduated for less than a year.

In the final event in the contest, Cheng said that each participant was required to demonstrate their creativity and make-up skills on a selected model using themes from the Brothers Grimm fairy tales. Each contestant had three hours to perform complete makevoers on the model's body, hair and face.
The 24-year-old cosmetics artist said her entry was based on the tale of "The Frog Prince" and infused with a sense of modernity.
"I tried to convey a sense of solitude by styling the model into a cursed prince who projected an ugly image but possessed a kind heart," Cheng explained.
Finalists only had three weeks to prepare and assemble materials needed for their creation, Cheng said.
"I spent one week sewing a special jacket to be worn by the model and I spent more than 1,000 Canadian dollars purchasing cosmetics materials, " she recalled.

She only learned about patches to be pasted on the model's face 10 minutes before the start of the contest. "Such an arrangement was aimed at testing the contestant's sensitivity," she said, adding that she had to dye the hair on the patches before pasting them on the model during the contest.

Cheng has only studied cosmetics in Canada for a year. "I take great interest in cosmetics as the human body is the most fascinating canvas for painting and the feel of painting on the human body is beyond imagination," she added.
After winning the first international prize of her career, Cheng said she still has a long way to go to realize her dream of becoming an outstanding make-up artist.

"I would not hesitate to travel far to do makeup for somebody and to help realize his or her dream, " Cheng said, adding that she hopes her creativity and cosmetics work can help draw world attention to Taiwan.

DOC.HEADLINE: First public hearing on capital punishment held
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, April 21 (CNA) 04/21/10 21:28:16 (By Sunrise Huang and Lilian Wu)

TEXT.P: Participants expressed their views on whether Taiwan should continue or abolish the death penalty as they pitted themselves against each other in the first of four public hearings on the controversial issue Wednesday.
National Taiwan University Professor Lee Mao-sheng, who supports the abolishment of capital punishment, said the execution of death row inmates has not achieved the purpose of deterring crime.
Lee argued that as it is impossible to avoid miscarriages of justice, once a death penalty inmate is executed, the dead cannot be revived.

However, Lin Chih-chieh, assistant professor of National Chiao Tung University, who is opposed to abolishing or conditional scrapping of the death penalty, said the quality of judicial judgment should be upgraded to deal with the problem of wrongful convictions.
Also, Lin said capital punishment should not be carried out in "closed-door operations," but that legal proceedings and execution proceedings should be made public.

Meanwhile, a group concerned about crime victims' rights asked whether anyone who supports abolishing the death penalty have family members who have been murdered, and have had experience dealing with that excruciating pain.
Sociologist Chu Hai-yuan said that the government's protection of crime victims is not enough, and that effective protection should be a good policy.
Chu said the public should be educated on the cause of crime and the purpose of punishment so as to effectively prevent crimes and increase protection and care for the victims and their families.

The issue of whether Taiwan should abolish the death penalty came to the fore recently when Taiwan's former Minister of Justice Wang Ching-feng openly stated her objections to the death penalty and her refusal to approve any executions as minister. Her statements led to public criticism, especially by victims' families and opposition legislators. Wang later resigned.
New Justice Minister Tseng Yung-fu has said he will approve the executions of prisoners on death row if they exhaust the appeals process.

In view of the controversial issue, the Ministry of Justice recently decided to sponsor four public hearings to hear the public's opinion on the matter. The hearing Wednesday was held in Banciao, Taipei County. Three others will be held in Taichung, Kaohsiung and Hualien later.

Justice Minister Tseng said Wednesday at the hearing that the ministry will read through all the cases of the 44 inmates now on death row, and exhaust all relief measures before carrying out capital punishment on them.
"The execution of the death sentence will not drag to the end of this year," Tseng said.
The Ministry of Justice has not approved an execution since December 2005.

DOC.HEADLINE: ECFA will not drive down wages to level in China: labor council
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, April 21 (CNA) 04/21/10 21:33:50 (By M. C. Lee and Flor Wang)

TEXT.P: Council of Labor Affairs (CLA) Chairwoman Wang Ju-hsuan rebutted rumors Wednesday that a planned cross-Taiwan Strait economic cooperation framework agreement (ECFA) will drive down wages in Taiwan to the same level as in China.

Reporting at the weekly meeting of the policy-making Central Standing Committee of the ruling Kuomintang (KMT) , Wang said this will not happen because Taiwan has a higher quality workforce than China.
Wang pointed out that wages have not dropped in Hong Kong, Singapore, Australia or New Zealand, all of which have signed trade agreements with China.

As matter of fact, in Hong Kong, the average monthly wage of workers in the industry and service sectors rose from US$1,591 in 2003, when it signed a closer economic partnership arrangement (CEPA) with China, to US$1,765 in 2008, she said.

In addition, during that five-year period, Hong Kong's jobless rate dropped from 7.9 percent to 3.6 percent, with the number of employed workers increasing from 3.19 million to 3.52 million, she noted.

Yiin Chii-ming, a former economics minister and now a minister without portfolio, said at a news conference Wednesday that the ECFA is meant to help Taiwan companies maintain their operations at home and attract more multinationals to set up hubs in Taiwan.
He urged southern Taiwan local government chiefs affiliated with the opposition Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) to cooperate with the central government in selling the ECFA to the public.
"They should hold sessions to help local residents gain a better understanding of the agreement and its benefits, " Yiin said.

Eight local government chiefs last week signed a joint pledge, denouncing the ECFA and arguing that it will cause job losses in Taiwan and lead to an influx of Chinese agricultural products and laborers in Taiwan.
However, the government is promoting the ECFA as means by which Taiwan could avoid marginalization in the region and obtain preferential tariff treatment for its exports to China.

DOC.HEADLINE: Cloud Gate 2 presents new work by three choreographers
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei April 21 (CNA) 04/21/10 22:39:38 (by Sunnie Chen)

TEXT.P: Three choreographers of Cloud Gate 2, a sister group of Taiwan's world famous Cloud Gate Dance Theatre, will present their latest pieces at Novel Hall in Taipei Wednesday night.
The presentation entitled "Spring Riot" will be staged in Taipei until April 25 and will later tour Hsinchu, Kaohsiung and other cities around the country.

Huang Yi, one of the young choreographers who took second place in the Cross Connection Ballet 3rd International Choreography Competition (CCBC) in Denmark earlier this month, will present "Floating Domain" based on his award-winning piece "Whisper".
"The 20-minute piece is actually a reflection of my own feelings," he said.

The piece depicts an imagined relationship between people's emotions and the space around them. When the dancers are sad, the space around them expands, but the dancers can feel themselves getting smaller and more lonely, Huang said..
Another choreographer, Cheng Tsung-lung, will present a 30-minute piece called "Crack."
"It is called 'Crack', but actually I want to show cohesion, " Cheng said. "It is a search for a solution to close and seal all the cracks."
The third choreographer Ku Ming-shen said her piece "Endless Shore "challenges the dancers." In addition to displaying their skills, the dancers are encouraged to transmit overtones", Ku said.
Huang and Cheng this year received support from the Lo Man Fei Dance Fund, a program that is designed to foster young talent in dance related fields.

DOC.HEADLINE: Taipei Culture Center opens in Tokyo
DOC.DATELINE: Tokyo, April 21 (CNA) 04/21/10 22:43:47 (By Mike Chang and Flor Wang)

TEXT.P: The Taipei Culture Center in Tokyo opened Wednesday, becoming the third of its kind after similar facilities in New York and Paris.

Council for Cultural Affairs Minister Emile Sheng and John C. T. Feng, Taiwan's top envoy to Japan, presided over the opening at the the Tokyo-based Taipei Economic and Cultural Representative Office. More than 100 guests from the two countries attended the ceremony, including professional Go player Cho U from Taiwan, Japanese Dietman Takeo Hiranuma and Reijiro Hattori, president of Japan's Interchange Association.
Addressing the ceremony, Feng said one of his office's top tasks this year is inaugurating the culture center to boost bilateral cultural exchanges.
"Next I'll work to organize an exhibition of treasures from the Taipei-based National Palace Museum in Japan," he said.
Noting that the Tokyo culture center was one of President Ma Ying-jeou's campaign promises, Sheng said he was happy to witness its opening prior to the second anniversary of Ma taking office.
Sheng said he expects Japanese friends to better understand Taiwan through the center -- the first of its kind in Asia.

Hiranuma, a long-time supporter of Taiwan and the leader of a group friendly to Taiwan in Japan's parliament, said he is planning to propose legislation in early May to secure the safety of Taiwan's national treasures if they are displayed in Japan.

DOC.HEADLINE: Government taking steps to curb housing prices
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, April 21 (CNA) 04/21/10 23:02:13 (By Cheng Yun-hsuan and Y.L. Kao)

TEXT.P: The Cabinet-level Council for Economic Planning and Development (CEPD) announced Wednesday that it will set up a Web site in few weeks time to make real estate information more transparent, as part of the government's efforts to curb rising housing prices.

Within three months of the Web site's launch, information on real estate appraisals and property transactions will be posted to prevent inflated valuations by private institutions and consequently higher market prices, the CEPD said.

The CEPD plan was announced after the Financial Supervisory Commission and the Central Bank of the Republic of China (Taiwan) unveiled various measures to tamp down on exorbitant housing prices by strengthening financial supervision of loans for property purchase.
The FSC earlier this year stepped up checks on financial institutions and banks that approve an excessively high percentage of housing and construction loans.

The action was taken to ensure that the lending institutions comply with regulations on internal control and risk management. The FSC is also asking banks to provide more information on their home loans and interest rates.
In keeping with the government's policy to tighten loan risk management, the central bank said Wednesday that it will conduct a full-scale investigation into banks' home loan policies.
The central bank will ask lending institutions to show data such as loan-to- value ratios, loan-to-income ratios, interest rates, and grace periods in real estate loans to investors.
The government's efforts to cool down the housing market were welcomed in the construction sector.
Pan Chun-jung, chairman of the Taiwan Regional Engineering Contractors' Association, said high housing prices are not in the interest of businesses or the general public.
"How many people can afford to buy a house that costs as much as NT$2 million per ping (3.31 square meters)?" he asked.
Houses should be sold at prices that most people can afford because the economy does not rest on just a few rich people but on the majority of the population, Pan added.

DOC.HEADLINE: President visits injured lawmaker, condemns violence
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, April 21 (CNA) 04/21/10 23:10:20 (By Wen Kui-hsiang and Lilian Wu)

TEXT.P: President Ma Ying-jeou on Wednesday visited a ruling party legislator at a hospital and condemned the opposition Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) for resorting to violence to disrupt legislative proceedings Wednesday.

Chao Li-yun, who earlier in the day presided over a meeting to screen two education bills that would pave the way for local universities and colleges to accept Chinese students, fainted and was rushed to National Taiwan University Hospital after a brawl broke out between ruling Kuomintang and DPP lawmakers.
President Ma urged DPP Chairperson Tsai Ying-wen not to condone her party's disruption of legislative proceedings.
Ma said the lawmakers could certainly express their opinions, but should do so rationally.
KMT Policy Committee Director Lin Yi-shih said Chao suffered multiple bruises and that she is weak and would have to stay in the hospital.
The Presidential Office on Wednesday also urged Tsai to restrain DPP members.
Presidential Office spokesman Lo Chih-chiang said that Tsai has touted rationality and respect for democracy, and that she should practice what she preaches.
On her part, Tsai said the KMT was acting "rashly."

She said that if the acceptance of Chinese academic credentials was not involved, then it would be good to exchange students or open school courses to Chinese so that students could have more contact with their counterparts across the Taiwan Strait.
But if accreditation is involved, Taiwan should conduct a "cautious assessment," Tsai said.

DOC.HEADLINE: Premier vows to drive home benefits of ECFA to win public support
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, April 21 (CNA) 04/21/10 23:30:22 (By Lee Shu-hua and Sofia Wu)

TEXT.P: Premier Wu Den-yih said Wednesday the Executive Yuan will step up efforts to drive home the essence of a proposed trade pact with China in order to win wider public support for the initiative.

In an interview with a cable TV station, Wu discounted speculations that the government's plan to sign a cross-Taiwan Strait economic cooperation framework agreement (ECFA) may adversely affect the ruling party's performance in the year-end mayoral elections in two southern Taiwan municipalities.
"There is no direct link between the ECFA and the mayoral elections," Wu contended in the interview.

He admitted that the government could do more to gain wider public support for the ECFA initiative, as the results of a series of public opinion polls show that the majority of people in the three southern counties of Yunlin, Chiayi and Tainan are opposed to the trade pact.

In comparison, public support for the ECFA in the northern and central parts of the country is high, but in the southern counties of Kaohsiung and Pingtung public opinion on the issue is evenly split, he said.

According to Wu, this is due to three main reasons -- insufficient effort by the government to promote the ECFA, misleading of the grassroots people by opposition groups, and comparatively slow infrastructure development in southern Taiwan.

On the opposition Democratic Progressive Party's demand for the Presidential Office to provide information about the "early harvest" list for tariff waivers that will form the backbone of the ECFA, Wu said no such a document is available at the moment because the ECFA negotiations are still in progress.
Describing the ECFA as a rose bush, Wu said the government has been working hard to prevent the thorns from hurting Taiwan.
"We will make every possible effort to minimize the adverse effects of the ECFA, " Wu said.
However, an estimated 80,000 local people may suffer as a result of the "early harvest" list of items proposed by China for concessionary tariff treatment, he added.
"We are still working hard to keep that number as low as possible," he said.

DOC.HEADLINE: Health minister asked to showcase H1N1 efforts
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, April 21 (CNA) 04/21/10 23:42:44 (By Chen Li-ting & Bear Lee)

TEXT.P: Vice Premier Eric Liluan Chu asked Health Minister Yaung Chih-liang Wednesday to showcase Taiwan's successful fight against the outbreak of influenza A (H1N1) to the international community.
Chu gave the instructions at a press conference at which he described Taiwan's anti-H1N1 drive as one of the most successful in the world.

"Taiwan has been on par with advanced countries in terms of fighting the epidemic, judging from its high inoculation rate and low fatality rate," Chu said, adding that "the health minister should use the coming World Health Assembly (WHA) and other international occasions to showcase the country's achievement."
Yaung is scheduled to represent Taiwan as an observer at May's WHA.

Chu said that the fatality rate for H1N1 in Taiwan was only one-third the average of Organization for Economic Co-operation and Development (OECD) countries, and was the third lowest among all OECD members and observers.

The percent of Taiwanese people vaccinated against the virus was the fifth highest in the world, and its immunization rates for medical and disease prevention personnel, and elementary and junior high school students ranked first and second, respectively, highlighting the success of the drive that began last November, Chu said.

In terms of the safety of the vaccines, the ratio of those vaccinated who have had undesired side effects was lower than the global average; and 39 of the 46 post-vaccination death cases have been proven unrelated to the vaccines, Chu said.

Meanwhile, Centers for Disease Control and Prevention (CDC) Director-General Steve H. S. Kuo reiterated that the controversial death of a seven-year-old boy in Taichung City was because of hemophagocytic syndrome, a blood disorder, caused by B19 parvovirus.
At a press conference, Kuo was responding to yet another question raised by the boy's father, a genealogist surnamed Liu, on an opinion page in a local newspaper that same day.
Liu has frequently questioned whether his son's death was closely related to a locally produced H1N1 vaccine he received weeks before he died.

Kuo said that results of pathological tests by several institutes, including the Ministry of Justice's Institute of Forensic Medicine (IFM) and the U.S. CDC all pointed to parvovirus as the cause of the boy's death.

Yaung said that the national anti-H1N1 drive cost the government NT$8.6 billion (US$276 million), compared to NT$25 billion that was earmarked for the outbreak of SARS (severe acute respiratory syndrome) in 2003, not to mention the surplus 8 billion doses of H1N1 vaccines and other anti-influenza medicines that could be used in case of another outbreak of the disease.
