DOC.HEADLINE: Taiwan boys advance to second round of Junior Davis Cup
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, April 21 (CNA) 04/21/10 20:03:40 (By Chris Wang)

TEXT.P: The Taiwan boys' team lost to India 2-1 in the 2010 Junior Davis Cup tennis tournament Wednesday in Kuching, Malaysia, but still managed to advance to the second round.

Taiwan finished the round with a 2-1 record and advanced with Group 4 leader India to the final eight of the 16-team Asia/Oceania Final Qualifying tournament. Taiwan beat both the Philippines and Pakistan 3-0 in previous competition.
Taiwan's Lee Li-lun and Ho Chih-jen lost in singles Wednesday before winning the doubles match.
According to the Chinese Taipei Tennis Association, Japan has won Group 1 while junior tennis powerhouse Australia is expected to win Group 2. China and South Korea are battling to lead Group 3.
Eight teams in the second round will vie for the three seats for the Asia/Oceania zone in the world finals.

Around 90 nations and 170 teams compete in regional qualifying events around the world every year to reach the Junior Davis Cup and Junior Fed Cup Finals, to be played from Sept. 28-Oct. 3 this year in San Luis Potosi, Mexico.

DOC.HEADLINE: Taiwan medical mission on 10-day trip to Nepal
DOC.DATELINE: New Delhi, April 21 (CNA) 04/21/10 20:09:04 (By Ho Hung-ju and Y.L. Kao)

TEXT.P: A 12-member Taiwanese mobile medical mission left New Delhi Wednesday for Nepal's capital, Kathmandu, to provide 10-day free medical services to outlying villages there.
The team was led by Chen Chih-fu, leader of the Taiwan International Cooperation and Development Fund (TaiwanICDF) Mobile Medical Mission.
All the volunteers taking part in the mission paid NT$50,000 (US$1,593) each for air tickets, food and accommodation, as well as helping to raise US$6,000 to buy medical supplies, Chen told the CNA.

With the assistance of a Chinese language school in Kathmandu, the mission was planning to buy the medical supplies there, Chen went on, adding that only about US$4,000 had been collected so far and the members would have to pay the remaining amount out of their own pockets if no more funds were raised.
The Indian branch of Fo Guang Shan, the largest Buddhist monastery in Taiwan, was to help manage transport and itineraries for the volunteers during the mission.
The mission was scheduled to provide medical services in six to seven villages around Kathmandu, Chen went on.

Continuity of care should be integral to offering effective and efficient health care overseas, Chen continued, adding that his team will gather more information about endemic diseases in Nepal to improve the continuity of medical care there.
The team includes physicians in various disciplines, as well as two pharmacists and four nurses from four hospitals in southern Taiwan.

DOC.HEADLINE: Taiwanese cosmetics artist wins top award in Vancouver
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, April 21 (CNA) 04/21/10 21:13:24 (By Chou Yung-chieh and Sofia Wu)

TEXT.P: A young Taiwanese cosmetics artist won the coveted top prize at the International Make-Up Artist Trade Show (IMAT) in Vancouver, Canada last Sunday.
"It came as a big surprise to me," a jubilant Cheng Wei-ying said in a telephone interview with the Central News Agency Wednesday.

Cheng, an information and mass communications graduate of Yuan Ze University in northern Taiwan's Taoyuan County, is studying makeup design at the Vancouver Film School. She was the school's first student of Chinese descent to receive the top award in an IMAT contest. The award carried a cash prize of 1,000 Canadian dollars.
The IMAT is held five times per year -- in London, Toronto, Vancouver, Los Angeles and Sydney -- and the contest is open to students and those who have graduated for less than a year.

In the final event in the contest, Cheng said that each participant was required to demonstrate their creativity and make-up skills on a selected model using themes from the Brothers Grimm fairy tales. Each contestant had three hours to perform complete makevoers on the model's body, hair and face.
The 24-year-old cosmetics artist said her entry was based on the tale of "The Frog Prince" and infused with a sense of modernity.
"I tried to convey a sense of solitude by styling the model into a cursed prince who projected an ugly image but possessed a kind heart," Cheng explained.
Finalists only had three weeks to prepare and assemble materials needed for their creation, Cheng said.
"I spent one week sewing a special jacket to be worn by the model and I spent more than 1,000 Canadian dollars purchasing cosmetics materials, " she recalled.

She only learned about patches to be pasted on the model's face 10 minutes before the start of the contest. "Such an arrangement was aimed at testing the contestant's sensitivity," she said, adding that she had to dye the hair on the patches before pasting them on the model during the contest.

Cheng has only studied cosmetics in Canada for a year. "I take great interest in cosmetics as the human body is the most fascinating canvas for painting and the feel of painting on the human body is beyond imagination," she added.
After winning the first international prize of her career, Cheng said she still has a long way to go to realize her dream of becoming an outstanding make-up artist.

"I would not hesitate to travel far to do makeup for somebody and to help realize his or her dream, " Cheng said, adding that she hopes her creativity and cosmetics work can help draw world attention to Taiwan.

DOC.HEADLINE: First public hearing on capital punishment held
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, April 21 (CNA) 04/21/10 21:28:16 (By Sunrise Huang and Lilian Wu)

TEXT.P: Participants expressed their views on whether Taiwan should continue or abolish the death penalty as they pitted themselves against each other in the first of four public hearings on the controversial issue Wednesday.
National Taiwan University Professor Lee Mao-sheng, who supports the abolishment of capital punishment, said the execution of death row inmates has not achieved the purpose of deterring crime.
Lee argued that as it is impossible to avoid miscarriages of justice, once a death penalty inmate is executed, the dead cannot be revived.

However, Lin Chih-chieh, assistant professor of National Chiao Tung University, who is opposed to abolishing or conditional scrapping of the death penalty, said the quality of judicial judgment should be upgraded to deal with the problem of wrongful convictions.
Also, Lin said capital punishment should not be carried out in "closed-door operations," but that legal proceedings and execution proceedings should be made public.

Meanwhile, a group concerned about crime victims' rights asked whether anyone who supports abolishing the death penalty have family members who have been murdered, and have had experience dealing with that excruciating pain.
Sociologist Chu Hai-yuan said that the government's protection of crime victims is not enough, and that effective protection should be a good policy.
Chu said the public should be educated on the cause of crime and the purpose of punishment so as to effectively prevent crimes and increase protection and care for the victims and their families.

The issue of whether Taiwan should abolish the death penalty came to the fore recently when Taiwan's former Minister of Justice Wang Ching-feng openly stated her objections to the death penalty and her refusal to approve any executions as minister. Her statements led to public criticism, especially by victims' families and opposition legislators. Wang later resigned.
New Justice Minister Tseng Yung-fu has said he will approve the executions of prisoners on death row if they exhaust the appeals process.

In view of the controversial issue, the Ministry of Justice recently decided to sponsor four public hearings to hear the public's opinion on the matter. The hearing Wednesday was held in Banciao, Taipei County. Three others will be held in Taichung, Kaohsiung and Hualien later.

Justice Minister Tseng said Wednesday at the hearing that the ministry will read through all the cases of the 44 inmates now on death row, and exhaust all relief measures before carrying out capital punishment on them.
"The execution of the death sentence will not drag to the end of this year," Tseng said.
The Ministry of Justice has not approved an execution since December 2005.

DOC.HEADLINE: ECFA will not drive down wages to level in China: labor council
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, April 21 (CNA) 04/21/10 21:33:50 (By M. C. Lee and Flor Wang)

TEXT.P: Council of Labor Affairs (CLA) Chairwoman Wang Ju-hsuan rebutted rumors Wednesday that a planned cross-Taiwan Strait economic cooperation framework agreement (ECFA) will drive down wages in Taiwan to the same level as in China.

Reporting at the weekly meeting of the policy-making Central Standing Committee of the ruling Kuomintang (KMT) , Wang said this will not happen because Taiwan has a higher quality workforce than China.
Wang pointed out that wages have not dropped in Hong Kong, Singapore, Australia or New Zealand, all of which have signed trade agreements with China.

As matter of fact, in Hong Kong, the average monthly wage of workers in the industry and service sectors rose from US$1,591 in 2003, when it signed a closer economic partnership arrangement (CEPA) with China, to US$1,765 in 2008, she said.

In addition, during that five-year period, Hong Kong's jobless rate dropped from 7.9 percent to 3.6 percent, with the number of employed workers increasing from 3.19 million to 3.52 million, she noted.

Yiin Chii-ming, a former economics minister and now a minister without portfolio, said at a news conference Wednesday that the ECFA is meant to help Taiwan companies maintain their operations at home and attract more multinationals to set up hubs in Taiwan.
He urged southern Taiwan local government chiefs affiliated with the opposition Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) to cooperate with the central government in selling the ECFA to the public.
"They should hold sessions to help local residents gain a better understanding of the agreement and its benefits, " Yiin said.

Eight local government chiefs last week signed a joint pledge, denouncing the ECFA and arguing that it will cause job losses in Taiwan and lead to an influx of Chinese agricultural products and laborers in Taiwan.
However, the government is promoting the ECFA as means by which Taiwan could avoid marginalization in the region and obtain preferential tariff treatment for its exports to China.

DOC.HEADLINE: Cloud Gate 2 presents new work by three choreographers
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei April 21 (CNA) 04/21/10 22:39:38 (by Sunnie Chen)

TEXT.P: Three choreographers of Cloud Gate 2, a sister group of Taiwan's world famous Cloud Gate Dance Theatre, will present their latest pieces at Novel Hall in Taipei Wednesday night.
The presentation entitled "Spring Riot" will be staged in Taipei until April 25 and will later tour Hsinchu, Kaohsiung and other cities around the country.

Huang Yi, one of the young choreographers who took second place in the Cross Connection Ballet 3rd International Choreography Competition (CCBC) in Denmark earlier this month, will present "Floating Domain" based on his award-winning piece "Whisper".
"The 20-minute piece is actually a reflection of my own feelings," he said.

The piece depicts an imagined relationship between people's emotions and the space around them. When the dancers are sad, the space around them expands, but the dancers can feel themselves getting smaller and more lonely, Huang said..
Another choreographer, Cheng Tsung-lung, will present a 30-minute piece called "Crack."
"It is called 'Crack', but actually I want to show cohesion, " Cheng said. "It is a search for a solution to close and seal all the cracks."
The third choreographer Ku Ming-shen said her piece "Endless Shore "challenges the dancers." In addition to displaying their skills, the dancers are encouraged to transmit overtones", Ku said.
Huang and Cheng this year received support from the Lo Man Fei Dance Fund, a program that is designed to foster young talent in dance related fields.

DOC.HEADLINE: Taipei Culture Center opens in Tokyo
DOC.DATELINE: Tokyo, April 21 (CNA) 04/21/10 22:43:47 (By Mike Chang and Flor Wang)

TEXT.P: The Taipei Culture Center in Tokyo opened Wednesday, becoming the third of its kind after similar facilities in New York and Paris.

Council for Cultural Affairs Minister Emile Sheng and John C. T. Feng, Taiwan's top envoy to Japan, presided over the opening at the the Tokyo-based Taipei Economic and Cultural Representative Office. More than 100 guests from the two countries attended the ceremony, including professional Go player Cho U from Taiwan, Japanese Dietman Takeo Hiranuma and Reijiro Hattori, president of Japan's Interchange Association.
Addressing the ceremony, Feng said one of his office's top tasks this year is inaugurating the culture center to boost bilateral cultural exchanges.
"Next I'll work to organize an exhibition of treasures from the Taipei-based National Palace Museum in Japan," he said.
Noting that the Tokyo culture center was one of President Ma Ying-jeou's campaign promises, Sheng said he was happy to witness its opening prior to the second anniversary of Ma taking office.
Sheng said he expects Japanese friends to better understand Taiwan through the center -- the first of its kind in Asia.

Hiranuma, a long-time supporter of Taiwan and the leader of a group friendly to Taiwan in Japan's parliament, said he is planning to propose legislation in early May to secure the safety of Taiwan's national treasures if they are displayed in Japan.

DOC.HEADLINE: Government taking steps to curb housing prices
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, April 21 (CNA) 04/21/10 23:02:13 (By Cheng Yun-hsuan and Y.L. Kao)

TEXT.P: The Cabinet-level Council for Economic Planning and Development (CEPD) announced Wednesday that it will set up a Web site in few weeks time to make real estate information more transparent, as part of the government's efforts to curb rising housing prices.

Within three months of the Web site's launch, information on real estate appraisals and property transactions will be posted to prevent inflated valuations by private institutions and consequently higher market prices, the CEPD said.

The CEPD plan was announced after the Financial Supervisory Commission and the Central Bank of the Republic of China (Taiwan) unveiled various measures to tamp down on exorbitant housing prices by strengthening financial supervision of loans for property purchase.
The FSC earlier this year stepped up checks on financial institutions and banks that approve an excessively high percentage of housing and construction loans.

The action was taken to ensure that the lending institutions comply with regulations on internal control and risk management. The FSC is also asking banks to provide more information on their home loans and interest rates.
In keeping with the government's policy to tighten loan risk management, the central bank said Wednesday that it will conduct a full-scale investigation into banks' home loan policies.
The central bank will ask lending institutions to show data such as loan-to- value ratios, loan-to-income ratios, interest rates, and grace periods in real estate loans to investors.
The government's efforts to cool down the housing market were welcomed in the construction sector.
Pan Chun-jung, chairman of the Taiwan Regional Engineering Contractors' Association, said high housing prices are not in the interest of businesses or the general public.
"How many people can afford to buy a house that costs as much as NT$2 million per ping (3.31 square meters)?" he asked.
Houses should be sold at prices that most people can afford because the economy does not rest on just a few rich people but on the majority of the population, Pan added.

DOC.HEADLINE: President visits injured lawmaker, condemns violence
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, April 21 (CNA) 04/21/10 23:10:20 (By Wen Kui-hsiang and Lilian Wu)

TEXT.P: President Ma Ying-jeou on Wednesday visited a ruling party legislator at a hospital and condemned the opposition Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) for resorting to violence to disrupt legislative proceedings Wednesday.

Chao Li-yun, who earlier in the day presided over a meeting to screen two education bills that would pave the way for local universities and colleges to accept Chinese students, fainted and was rushed to National Taiwan University Hospital after a brawl broke out between ruling Kuomintang and DPP lawmakers.
President Ma urged DPP Chairperson Tsai Ying-wen not to condone her party's disruption of legislative proceedings.
Ma said the lawmakers could certainly express their opinions, but should do so rationally.
KMT Policy Committee Director Lin Yi-shih said Chao suffered multiple bruises and that she is weak and would have to stay in the hospital.
The Presidential Office on Wednesday also urged Tsai to restrain DPP members.
Presidential Office spokesman Lo Chih-chiang said that Tsai has touted rationality and respect for democracy, and that she should practice what she preaches.
On her part, Tsai said the KMT was acting "rashly."

She said that if the acceptance of Chinese academic credentials was not involved, then it would be good to exchange students or open school courses to Chinese so that students could have more contact with their counterparts across the Taiwan Strait.
But if accreditation is involved, Taiwan should conduct a "cautious assessment," Tsai said.

DOC.HEADLINE: Premier vows to drive home benefits of ECFA to win public support
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, April 21 (CNA) 04/21/10 23:30:22 (By Lee Shu-hua and Sofia Wu)

TEXT.P: Premier Wu Den-yih said Wednesday the Executive Yuan will step up efforts to drive home the essence of a proposed trade pact with China in order to win wider public support for the initiative.

In an interview with a cable TV station, Wu discounted speculations that the government's plan to sign a cross-Taiwan Strait economic cooperation framework agreement (ECFA) may adversely affect the ruling party's performance in the year-end mayoral elections in two southern Taiwan municipalities.
"There is no direct link between the ECFA and the mayoral elections," Wu contended in the interview.

He admitted that the government could do more to gain wider public support for the ECFA initiative, as the results of a series of public opinion polls show that the majority of people in the three southern counties of Yunlin, Chiayi and Tainan are opposed to the trade pact.

In comparison, public support for the ECFA in the northern and central parts of the country is high, but in the southern counties of Kaohsiung and Pingtung public opinion on the issue is evenly split, he said.

According to Wu, this is due to three main reasons -- insufficient effort by the government to promote the ECFA, misleading of the grassroots people by opposition groups, and comparatively slow infrastructure development in southern Taiwan.

On the opposition Democratic Progressive Party's demand for the Presidential Office to provide information about the "early harvest" list for tariff waivers that will form the backbone of the ECFA, Wu said no such a document is available at the moment because the ECFA negotiations are still in progress.
Describing the ECFA as a rose bush, Wu said the government has been working hard to prevent the thorns from hurting Taiwan.
"We will make every possible effort to minimize the adverse effects of the ECFA, " Wu said.
However, an estimated 80,000 local people may suffer as a result of the "early harvest" list of items proposed by China for concessionary tariff treatment, he added.
"We are still working hard to keep that number as low as possible," he said.

DOC.HEADLINE: Health minister asked to showcase H1N1 efforts
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, April 21 (CNA) 04/21/10 23:42:44 (By Chen Li-ting & Bear Lee)

TEXT.P: Vice Premier Eric Liluan Chu asked Health Minister Yaung Chih-liang Wednesday to showcase Taiwan's successful fight against the outbreak of influenza A (H1N1) to the international community.
Chu gave the instructions at a press conference at which he described Taiwan's anti-H1N1 drive as one of the most successful in the world.

"Taiwan has been on par with advanced countries in terms of fighting the epidemic, judging from its high inoculation rate and low fatality rate," Chu said, adding that "the health minister should use the coming World Health Assembly (WHA) and other international occasions to showcase the country's achievement."
Yaung is scheduled to represent Taiwan as an observer at May's WHA.

Chu said that the fatality rate for H1N1 in Taiwan was only one-third the average of Organization for Economic Co-operation and Development (OECD) countries, and was the third lowest among all OECD members and observers.

The percent of Taiwanese people vaccinated against the virus was the fifth highest in the world, and its immunization rates for medical and disease prevention personnel, and elementary and junior high school students ranked first and second, respectively, highlighting the success of the drive that began last November, Chu said.

In terms of the safety of the vaccines, the ratio of those vaccinated who have had undesired side effects was lower than the global average; and 39 of the 46 post-vaccination death cases have been proven unrelated to the vaccines, Chu said.

Meanwhile, Centers for Disease Control and Prevention (CDC) Director-General Steve H. S. Kuo reiterated that the controversial death of a seven-year-old boy in Taichung City was because of hemophagocytic syndrome, a blood disorder, caused by B19 parvovirus.
At a press conference, Kuo was responding to yet another question raised by the boy's father, a genealogist surnamed Liu, on an opinion page in a local newspaper that same day.
Liu has frequently questioned whether his son's death was closely related to a locally produced H1N1 vaccine he received weeks before he died.

Kuo said that results of pathological tests by several institutes, including the Ministry of Justice's Institute of Forensic Medicine (IFM) and the U.S. CDC all pointed to parvovirus as the cause of the boy's death.

Yaung said that the national anti-H1N1 drive cost the government NT$8.6 billion (US$276 million), compared to NT$25 billion that was earmarked for the outbreak of SARS (severe acute respiratory syndrome) in 2003, not to mention the surplus 8 billion doses of H1N1 vaccines and other anti-influenza medicines that could be used in case of another outbreak of the disease.

DOC.HEADLINE: Today in history
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, April 22 (CNA) 04/22/10 09:04:29
DOC.TEXT:
Today is Thursday, April 22, or the ninth day of the third month of the Year of the Tiger according to the lunar calendar. Following is a list of important events that have occurred on this date in the past:
1500: On his way to India with 13 ships, Portuguese navigator Pedro Alvarez Cabral discovers Brazil and claims it for Portugal.
1724: Immanuel Kant, German idealist philosopher and one of history's greatest thinkers, is born. He argued that reason is the means by which the phenomena of experience is translated into understanding. His classic works include "Critique of Pure Reason" and "Critique of Practical Reason."
1870: Vladimir Ilich Lenin, Russian leader of the Bolshevik Revolution and first leader of Communist Russia, is born.
1904: Robert Oppenheimer, American nuclear scientist who developed the atom bomb, is born.
1915: The Germans use poison gas for the first time on British troops on the Western Front during World War I.
1944: Allied forces land on Dutch New Guinea.
1947: Wei Tao-ming becomes governor of the newly established Taiwan Provincial Government.
1951: The first contingent of officers from the U.S. Military Assistance Advisory Group (MAAG) in Taiwan, arrives in Taipei. Maj. Gen. William C. Chase, the first MAAG chief, would arrive in Taipei later.
1956: Beijing appoints the Dalai Lama as chairman of a committee to prepare Tibet for regional autonomy within Communist China.
1961: The construction of the Taipei Chunghua Bazaar is completed with Gov. Chow Chih-jou of Taiwan Provincial Government presiding over the inauguration ceremony.
1969: American surgeons conduct the first human eye transplant.
1973: President Hammer de Roburt of the Republic of Nauru and his wife arrive in Taipei for a visit.
1974: A Pan American Airlines passenger plane crashes in Bali, Indonesia, killing 107 people.
1975: The first batch of Vietnamese refugees arrive on the western coast of the United States, as South Vietnam falls to the communists.
1980: S.S. Don Juan, a vehicle ferry, collides with a car float and sinks near Mindoro Island in the Philippines, killing some 1,000 people.
1984: Medical researchers working in the United States and France identify a type of human cancer virus that may be the causative agent in the killer disease Acquired Immune Deficiency Syndrome (AIDS).
1991: The second extraordinary session of the First National Assembly passes, at its sixth plenary meeting, the Additional Articles of the Constitution of the Republic of China and approves the abolishment of the Temporary Provisions Effective During the Period of Communist Rebellion.
1992: Gasoline that leaked from a nearby refinery explodes in the sewer system of Guadalajara, Mexico, killing more than 200 people and injuring over 600 others.
1993: The Legislative Yuan ratifies a 1989 ROC-U.S. copyright agreement and passes amendments to the ROC's copyright law that go into effect April 26.
1993: Tongan Prime Minister Baron Vaea and Madame Vaea visit the Republic of China.
1994: Former U.S. President Richard M. Nixon dies of a stroke at the age of 81. He visited mainland China in 1972 and established detente with the USSR. When Congress recommended three articles of impeachment for Nixon's involvement in the Watergate scandal, he resigned from office Aug. 9, 1974.
1999: Visiting President Kirsan Nikolayevich Ilyumzhinov of the Kalmykia Republic meets with Taipei Mayor Ma Ying-jeou and expresses interest in creating sisterhood ties between the Russian state and Taipei.
2000: The newly founded People First Party calls for a halt in revamping the ROC Constitution by the National Assembly, branding the draft amendments unconstitutional.
2000: The ROC Foreign Ministry formally approves the appointment of Chen Kuo- huang, director of the Foreign Ministry's Western Asian Affairs Department, as ambassador to Palau.
2001: Nobel laureate Yang Chen-ning is honored as the outstanding alumnus of the century in Hsinchu, northern Taiwan, by his alma mater National Tsinghua University.
Confucius' lesson of the day: "When the rulers encourage education and good manner, the people are easily amenable to government."

DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, April 22 (CNA) 04/22/10 09:12:36 (By Sofia Wu)

DOC.HEADLINE: China Times: Freedom of speech at risk

TEXT.P: A proposed amendment to the Personal Data Protection Act recently passed its second reading in the Legislative Yuan. The most controversial aspect of the bill is a clause requiring the media and elected public officials to obtain the consent of individuals before publicizing any information about them.
We urge the legislature to drop this bill before the third reading. If it is passed, it would be an unconstitutional law that could destroy Taiwan's hard-won freedom of speech and of the press.

According to the bill, the media will not be allowed to seek by any means information about the private or social lives of individuals. This would leave the media with very little to report. Even worse, the bill does not specify whether the individuals it is seeking to protect are ordinary people or government officials.
Under the controversial clause, all information about individuals is designated as private. However, it overlooks the fact that privacy is not an infinite or absolute right.
It is evident that the architects of the bill have no idea that there are different rights pertaining to people's privacy and reputations.

In media reporting, a person's privacy can only be violated if the information is accurate. Therefore, if all information about individuals is considered private and off limits to the media, there can be no accurate news stories, in which case all the media outlets will have to shut down.

We could not believe our eyes when we saw the bill and we wished that our interpretation of it was incorrect. Can the Ministry of Justice and the Legislative Yuan please tell us if we have read the bill correctly? (April 22, 2010)
