DOC.HEADLINE: United Daily News: Reform and opening needed in Taiwan

TEXT.P: "Reform and opening" was one of the late Chinese leader Deng Xiaoping's trademark slogans. We must say that Taiwan needs reform and opening now. In particular, we are saying this to the opposition Democratic Progressive Party (DPP).

At a time when it has become totally impossible to bar people and capital from flowing outward, the country has been throwing up various blockades to the inflow of external resources. This is the true crisis in Taiwan.

A case in point is the dispute over whether to open Taiwan to Chinese students. It is impossible to bar Taiwanese students from going to China, but the DPP is trying to block Chinese students from coming to Taiwan.

The DPP's objection to the signing of an economic cooperation framework agreement (ECFA) with China is another example. Even as Taiwanese resources continue to flow outward, there are fewer incentives for Taiwanese and foreign businesses to keep their roots in Taiwan. But Taiwan has been shutting out Chinese capital.
Opening up will inevitably cause pain. However, unless Taiwan does so, it will have no means of sharpening its competitiveness or continuing to attract global resources.

A closed-door policy is unfeasible. This is especially true when its comes to a policy that shuts off the entry of resources, but not the exit. The DPP's closed-door policy will serve only to increase the flow of Taiwanese students and capital to China. (April 22, 2010)

DOC.HEADLINE: Taichung mayor rules out possibility of presidential bid
DOC.DATELINE: Singapore, April 22 (CNA) 04/22/10 12:58:09 (By Charles Kang and Maubo Chang)

TEXT.P: Jason Hu, mayor of the central Taiwan city of Taichung who once served as Taiwan's foreign minister, has ruled out the possibility of running for president either in 2012 or 2016.
"It is out of the question." he said in an interview published in Thursday's Chinese-language Lianhe Zaobao.

"The Kuomintang should focus on rallying behind President Ma Ying-jeou to secure his reelection in 2012." said the mayor, who is widely seen as a possible KMT presidential candidate should Ma's low popularity preclude a second term.

Obviously irritated by the interviewer's repeated questions on the possibility of him making a presidential bid, Hu snapped, "I have already told you three times that it is out of the question, how can I get this across to you."

According to the paper, Hu is considered as one of the KMT's most prominent leaders, along with President Ma and Vice Premier Eric Li-luan Chu, but the mayor prefers to remain in his current post than to serve in the central government.

Lianhe Zaobao said that Hu's popularity is hard to explain because while he doesn't bungle his job, his performance is not exactly brilliant. The level of support he enjoys in southern Taiwan, which is a traditional stronghold of the opposition Democratic Progressive Party (DPP), is quite unusual, it noted.
Hu's popularity has raised hopes among KMT supporters that he might run instead of Ma on the KMT ticket in the 2012 presidential election, given Ma's poor showing in various public opinion surveys.
The mayor's supporters have maintained high expectations of him, even after he suffered a mild stroke a few years ago.
In February, they erected a huge billboard in Taichung City that reads "Support to the hilt for Jason Hu as the 2012 presidential candidate."
It forced Hu to scramble to nip the idea in the bud by stating his position publicly.
In the interview with Lianhe Zaobao, he praised Ma and downplayed his own popularity.

"You can hardly find anyone who is more honest and diligent in his work than Ma, " the mayor said. "There are many factors that have contributed to his low approval ratings at the moment, but there is no guarantee that I would be more popular than him in a presidential election."

"The KMT cannot afford divisions at this time, nor can it field a better candidate than Ma Ying-jeou, so I am throwing my weight behind him with all my heart and I urge all party members to do the same, " Hu said.
He also entreated the KMT to stop flirting with the dangerous idea of swapping horses in midstream.
"The KMT's only option is to pull out all the stops to boost Ma's popularity and win the (2012) election," he said.
"There is no question of anyone within the KMT challenging Ma for the presidential candidacy in 2012," he said.

Hu, who will run for the first mayor of a new municipality that will be created later this year by merging Taichung city and county, said the KMT is likely to retain control in three of five such new municipalities and hopefully will win another one or two.
"We expect to win in the cities of Taipei, Xinbei and Taichung, and are not ruling out victories in the cities of Tainan and Kaohsiung."
Lianhe Zaobao said Hu is a shoo-in for Taichung mayor but the KMT candidates in Taipei and Xinbei will face a stiffer challenge from the DPP candidates.
In the interview, which was conducted in Taichung on April 19, the mayor emphasized that Taiwan's power lies not in its armed forces but in its well- developed democracy and economy.
"Democracy has earned the country credit while its economy gives it the power to engage other states."
Hu, who served as foreign minister between 1997 and 1999, said Taiwan's relations with China and the United States are the best ever at the moment, and Taiwan is mending fences with Singapore.

DOC.HEADLINE: 'Taiwan's Susan Boyle' performs on popular U.S. talk show
DOC.DATELINE: Los Angeles, April 21 (CNA) 04/22/10 13:52:08 (By Leaf Jiang and Sofia Wu)

TEXT.P: Taiwanese singer and Internet sensation Lin Yu-chun wowed audiences Wednesday with his impeccable rendition of Whitney Houston's version of "I Will Always Love You" on the Ellen DeGeneres Show.

The talk show host exclaimed "unbelievable" several times as she expressed her admiration for what was called Lin's amazingly beautiful rendition of the song that was written by Dolly Parton and made famous by Whitney Houston.
At the end of his performance, during which he sang also "Amazing Grace," the studio audience gave Lin a standing ovation.
Wearing his trademark shirt, vest and a bow tie, Lin performed a short dance piece at the start of his appearance on the Ellen DeGeneres Show.

The 24-year-old told DeGeneres that he was inspired by the success story of Susan Boyle, a Scottish singer who came to international attention when she appeared as a contestant on the TV show Britain's Got Talent in April 2009, singing "I Dreamed a Dream" from Les Miserables.

Lin vaulted to fame after a video showing him singing "I Will Always Love You" was posted on YouTube April 6. The clip, from his performance on a Taiwan talent show "Million Star, " immediately went viral, propelling him to worldwide stardom.
Lin, who weighs 110 kg and is nicknamed "fatty, " admitted on the talk show that he had been bullied during his childhood because of his weight.

Prompted to offer some advice to other children who may be facing the same problem, Lin said, "There is a reason for everyone's existence. Be confident. The best way to get back at them (bullies) is to be more successful than they are".
DeGeneres endorsed Lin's advice, putting her arm around his shoulders and saying, "that's the best revenge."

Lin's popularity is such that he was recognized by some tourists in the famous Hollywood shopping center "The Grove." Some of them approached him and asked to take photos with him, while others asked whether he was the person who sang "I Will Always Love You" in the YouTube video.
TMZ, a popular celebrity news Web site, posted an article Wednesday introducing Lin as "the Taiwanese, male Whitney Houston."

Lin has also been interviewed for the Wednesday edition of the Lopez Tonight talk show. On the show, he sang "Saving All My Love For You, " another of Houston's hits, and performed Bonnie Tyler's "Total Eclipse of the Heart" in a duet with Canadian actor, recording artist, and author William Shatner.

DOC.HEADLINE: Commercial Times: Credibility of national statistics in crisis

TEXT.P: The Cabinet recently decided to merge the government's statistics and accounting units in more than 20 government agencies as part of a government restructuring project. With the long existing shortage of resources in the country's statistics department, this decision is tantamount to declaring that Taiwan will soon have no trustworthy national statistics.

Once the statistics and accounting units are merged, the compilation of macroeconomics data such as export orders, industrial production, and retail surveys is bound to stop. Even if the work does continue, the quality of the statistics will be worrisome.
Inaccurate figures will result in miscalculations of the economic situation, which can steer the economy toward disaster.
It is inconceivable that our government restructuring efforts are now trying to put accounting and statistics, widely known to be two totally different disciplines, under one roof.

In countries such as the United States, Japan, South Korea and China, an increasing level of importance is being placed on departments of statistics. In comparison, is Taiwan making the right decision on this issue? We urge President Ma Ying-jeou and Premier Wu Den-yih to pay special attention to this matter. (April 22, 2010)

DOC.HEADLINE: Talk of the day -- Scuffles over opening to Chinese students
DOC.DATELINE: 04/22/10 13:59:59 (By Deborah Kuo)

TEXT.P: Legislators brawled Wednesday over draft amendments to two education laws that would pave the way for local universities and colleges to recruit Chinese students.

Clashes broke out when opposition Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) lawmakers stormed the podium to prevent two clerks from announcing the agenda of a committee hearing on draft amendments to the University Act and the College Act. DPP lawmakers also attempted to block Education Minister Wu Ching-ji from delivering a briefing on the amendment proposals.
The scuffles turned into a free-for-all, with DPP legislators pushing KMT Legislator Chao Li-yun, who was chairing the session of the Legislative Yuan's Education and Culture Committee.

Chao, who was sweating and having difficulty breathing, fainted after she announced that the two bills had completed their first review and were to be referred to the full legislature for further deliberation.
The following are excerpts from local media coverage of the issue:
United Daily News:

Presidents and vice presidents of more than 100 local colleges and universities witnessed the fracas at the legislature over an issue that is of crucial importance to the development of Taiwan's institutes of higher education.
Chen Tai-jan, a deputy president at National Taiwan University, said the fight did not solve problems, but only deepened rifts. "It served as a bad example," he said.

During the scuffles, DPP Legislator Kuan Bi-ling displayed an e-mail from the secretariat of a college association that suggested nine university presidents who voiced public support for the amendments a day earlier felt pressured to do so by the Ministry of Education (MOE) because they receive subsidies from the ministry.

Dismissing Kuan's allegation, Chen said university executives do not need to be "mobilized" because opening to Chinese students involves the globalization of Taiwan's system of higher education and will increase its international competitiveness.

On DPP legislator complaints that Wu was "sacrificing Taiwan's next generation only to kiss Beijing's ass, " Chen Chen-kuei, president of Ling Tung University, said: "Our democratization is what they (the Chinese people) crave. We are influencing them, not falling victim to any 'united front' scheme." (April 22, 2010).
The Liberty Times:

The amendment proposals, which appear only to lead to the opening of Taiwan's universities and colleges to some 2,000 Chinese students a year, will probably end up infringing on Taiwan students' rights to education and Taiwan people's opportunities for work.
"Tilting toward China" -- reflected in the MOE's pushing for the amendment proposals -- is the real motive behind this and it is something Taiwan society should worry about.

Taking Hong Kong as an example, Martin Oei, a Hong Kong-based news commentator, has warned that allowing Chinese students to enter Taiwan to study is tantamount to surrendering to China. He said the opening would not just trigger problems such as work opportunities for Taiwan's people and controversies over fake academic credentials, but would also involve Taiwan's national security. (April 22, 2010).
China Times:
A survey by this daily on Wednesday found that 47 percent of respondents agreed with the government conditionally opening Taiwan's doors to Chinese students, while 39 percent opposed it.
Forty percent of the respondents said "yes" to a question asking whether Taiwan should recognize academic credentials issued by Chinese institutes, and 43 percent said "no."

The poll results also showed that 44 percent of the respondents think Taiwan universities are better than their Chinese counterparts academically. Only 15 percent consider China's higher education of a higher standard than Taiwan's.
A total of 787 adults were randomly selected for the survey. (April 22, 2010).

DOC.HEADLINE: Share prices close lower on local bourse
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, April 22 (CNA) 04/22/10 15:08:13 (By Y.L. Kao)

TEXT.P: Taiwan's share prices closed slightly lower Thursday, with the weighted index, the market's key barometer, falling 11.84 points, or 0.14 percent, to close at 7,978.69.
The local bourse opened at 7,948.89 and fluctuated between 7,985.49 and 7,897.14 during the day's trading. Market turnover totaled NT$113.47 billion (US$3.61 billion).
Only two of the eight major stock categories gained ground, with paper and pulp issues advancing the most at 0.65 percent and construction shares gaining 0.26 percent.

The six other major stock categories lost ground, with construction shares falling the most at 1.7 percent, followed by cement stocks at 1.21 percent, financial and banking shares at 1.16 percent, plastics and chemical issues at 0.65 percent, textile stocks at 0.14 percent and foodstuff shares at 0.05 percent.
Losers outnumbered gainers 1,862 to 1,209, with 308 stocks remaining unchanged.
Foreign investors and Chinese QDIIs were net sellers of NT$2.87 billion-worth of shares.

DOC.HEADLINE: Higher education no guarantee of good job: poll
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, April 22 (CNA) 04/22/10 15:44:50 (By Cheng Yun-hsuan and Deborah Kuo)

TEXT.P: Higher education does not guarantee a good job and vocational school graduates are the "favorite" candidates in job interviews and in Taiwan's job market, according to a survey by the 1111 Job Bank.

Some 70 percent of business executives responding to the survey said they attach importance to job seekers' educational backgrounds, saying the backgrounds reflect the candidates' common sense, work attitude and professional capability, the survey found.

The executives were from the education sector, government agencies, non- governmental organizations, the medical, agricultural and husbandry sectors as well as high-technology companies, in that order.
Most companies in the service sector, however, said they don't care much about a job seeker's educational background, according to the poll.
Meanwhile, 75 percent of companies responding to the poll said they had hired people whose educational backgrounds were not in line with requirements but had great potential and work experience.
The 1111 Job Bank conducted the poll online from April 4 to April 20 and collected 340 valid responses from companies and organizations.

Seventy-three percent of respondents said that when conducting interviews, they do not necessarily hire applicants with the highest education backgrounds. Respondents said they did not do so because people with high educational backgrounds tend to think highly of themselves and give themselves airs and graces, according to the poll.

On statistics suggesting that the more education people have, the more likely they are to be unemployed, respondents attributed the phenomenon to several factors, with the most common being: They have grandiose aims but little ability.
It was also found that business companies were most satisfied with staff members holding diplomas from vocational colleges, followed by university graduates.
The vocational school graduates were the "favorite" workers because their professional capabilities conform to their job requirements and they don't put on airs, according to the survey.

DOC.HEADLINE: Bilingual emergency cards placed at airports for local travelers
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, April 22 (CNA) 04/22/10 16:02:29 (By Garfie Li and Fanny Liu)

TEXT.P: To help Taiwanese people overcome the language barrier during possible emergencies while traveling abroad, bilingual cards have been made available at Taoyuan and Kaohsiung international airports for travelers, the Ministry of Foreign Affairs (MOFA) said Thursday.
Passengers can obtain the emergency aid cards free of cost at the airports' information desks and at the check-in counters of China Airlines and Eva Air, according to a MOFA press release.

The phrases on the cards, in both Chinese and English, request help or information. Some of them are "I am from Taiwan (ROC) , and cannot speak English, I wonder if I could have a Chinese (Mandarin) interpreter;" and "If no one is available, please contact the Taiwan Mission in your country, I need their assistance."
The MOFA said that if Taiwanese travelers encounter problems at customs or immigration in other countries or find themselves in emergency situations abroad they can use the cards to seek assistance.

At present, the Chinese-English cards are available in four versions for travel in Asia, to North America, Europe and Trans-Atlantic regions. The MOFA said is planning to add other language versions for use in Central and South America and Africa.
The information on the cards includes a MOFA emergency contact number, 886-800-085-095, and the emergency contact numbers of several Taiwanese missions abroad.

DOC.HEADLINE: President stresses importance of disaster prevention
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, April 22 (CNA) 04/22/10 16:10:13 (By Chen Shou-gow and Y.F. Low)

TEXT.P: President Ma Ying-jeou stressed the importance of disaster prevention as he reviewed a rescue exercise in Kaohsiung County Thursday.

Approximately 500 members of the military, police and firefighting forces cooperated with staff from public and private agencies in the exercise, which took place in a riverside park under the Wanda Bridge in the county's Daliao Township.

According to Ma, the importance of disaster prevention and rescue has become evident following severe devastation caused by Typhoon Morakot that left more than 700 people dead or missing in southern Taiwan last August.

Ma noted that natural disasters usually cannot be foreseen or resisted. Earthquakes are unpredictable, he said, and preventive measures such as raising the quake-resistance level of buildings should be in place to minimize the impact of disasters.
Forecasts are helpful when it comes to typhoons, however, and residents should be properly evacuated before disaster occurs, the president said.
He pointed out that more than 9,000 people were evacuated before Typhoon Morakot hit Taiwan. Had these people not left their homes, at least 1,000 more could have been killed, he said.

Ma admitted that if the evacuation had been conducted earlier and more quickly, the Morakot death toll could have been lower. He urged government agencies to strengthen their coordination in preparation for disasters.

DOC.HEADLINE: U.S. dollar up on Taipei Forex
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, April 22 (CNA) 04/22/10 16:31:52 (By Y.L. Kao)

TEXT.P: The U.S. dollar gained ground against the New Taiwan dollar on the Taipei Foreign Exchange Thursday, rising NT$0.010 to close at NT$31.398.
A total of US$890 million changed hands during the trading session.
The U.S. dollar opened at NT$31.388 and fluctuated between NT$31.350 and NT$31.400.

DOC.HEADLINE: Ex-U.S. minor leaguer Keng sidelined for unusual injury
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, April 22 (CNA) 04/22/10 16:41:31 (By Chris Wang)

TEXT.P: The La New Bears placed relief pitcher Keng Po-hsuan on the injured list after he burned his crotch in an accident at home, the team said in a press release Thursday.

Keng, who played Major League Baseball for a Toronto Blue Jays farm team from 2005 to 2008, suffered injury to his private parts "from boiling water, " the team said without elaborating. He is expected to return in one to two weeks.

The right-handed reliever, who returned to Taiwan and was selected by La New in a Chinese Professional Baseball League (CPBL) special draft in 2009, appeared in seven games this season and registered one win and two saves with a 1.00 earned run average (ERA).

Keng was not the first La New player to suffer such an injury. On Oct. 19, 2007, one day before La New opened the best-of-seven Taiwan Series against the Uni- President Lions, American pitcher Andrew Lorraine had a similar experience.
Lorraine was watching a scouting DVD with a cup of coffee in his hands when he was bumped by a teammate and spilled the scalding hot beverage on his lap.
The former major leaguer, who was later released in 2008, still managed to play in Game 2 as a reliever and started Game 4. La New eventually lost 4-3 in the series.

DOC.HEADLINE: Taiwan-educated student awarded Fulbright Ph.D scholarship
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, April 22 (CNA) 04/22/10 16:42:48 (By Chris Wang)

TEXT.P: A Taiwan-educated student has been awarded a U.S. State Department-funded international Fulbright science and technology Ph.D scholarship and will enroll in Stanford University this fall to study nanotechnology.

Hsu Po-chun, 25, is the third Taiwan student to have won the scholarship, a flagship international educational exchange program sponsored by the U.S. government that is granted to 45 international students every year in the science and technology category.

This scholarship is regarded as special because Hsu, who graduated from National Tsing Hua University (NTHU) in 2007, was educated only in Taiwan and is one of the few Taiwanese students to study for a Ph.D after earning only a bachelor's degree, said Chen Tung-jung, executive officer of The Foundation for Scholarly Exchange (Fulbright Taiwan) , one of some 50 bilateral organizations in the world established specifically to administer the program outside the U.S.
Hsu told CNA he was surprised to find out that he had been granted the three- year, US$240,000 scholarship last October because he had failed his first bid in 2009.

Hsu plans to focus on nanotechnology and would like to apply the results of his research to the development of solar energy, especially solar cells. He expressed hope that he will be able to use what he learns in the U.S. to help Taiwan's scientific development.

Hsu, a researcher at Academia Sinica, Taiwan's top research institute, does not fit the traditional perception of a "good student" in Taiwan as he does not want to be a "nerd" who does nothing but study and conduct scientific experiments.

As well as taking classes in psychology and journalism, he was also vice president of the Student Association, chief executive of the organizing committee of the locally renowned intercollegiate athletic games between NTHU and National Chiao Tung University and volunteered to work in the emergency room at Mackay Memorial Hospital in Hsinchu City.
Just as he has taken the road less traveled in his research, Hsu's favorite sport -- soccer -- is not popular in Taiwan.
"I appreciate my parents for always respecting me and letting me make decisions for myself. They let me find the uniqueness of myself, rather than just following the herd," he said.

Hsu, who describes himself as a hard worker rather than a genius, said he has only been to the U.S. once, when he was a small child, but added that the experience of being an exchange student at China's Tsing Hua University in 2006 helped broaden his perspective.

Most university students in China work very hard because of fierce peer competition and a strong desire to succeed, he observed. Taiwan's college students, on the other hand, tend to be more animated and creative, to be good at integrating cross-disciplinary knowledge and are better at teamwork, according to Hsu.
"We should leverage these characteristics to gain advantages in cross-Taiwan Strait competition, " he said.

The Fulbright Program was established in 1946 under legislation introduced by then-Senator J. William Fulbright of Arkansas. It is sponsored by the U.S. Department of State's Bureau of Educational and Cultural Affairs.

Approximately 294,000 "Fulbrighters " -- 111,000 from the U.S. and 183,000 from other countries -- have participated in the program since its inception. The program awards around 7,500 new grants annually and presently operates in over 155 countries.
Over the past 50 years, Fulbright Taiwan has financed over 1,400 Taiwan Fulbright grantees to the U.S. and more than 1,000 U.S. Fulbright grantees coming to Taiwan.

DOC.HEADLINE: Taiwan's priority list more comprehensive than China's: MOEA
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, April 22 (CNA) 04/22/10 16:48:58 (By S.Y. Lin and Flor Wang)

TEXT.P: A priority "early harvest" list prepared by Taiwan as part of negotiations on an economic cooperation framework agreement (ECFA) with China is more comprehensive than China's, Minister of Economic Affairs Shih Yen-shiang said Thursday.

Fielding questions from ruling Kuomintang (KMT) Legislator Lee Ching-hua at a legislative committee meeting, Shih said the number of items and their total export value to be put forward by the Ministry of Economic Affairs (MOEA) at the negotiating table will certainly be higher than China's, based on a proportional principle due to the difference in size of the two markets.

Commenting on a local media report that Taiwan will present a list containing 300 to 500 items, far short of China's list of more than 700 items, Shih described it as sheer speculation, while also pointing out that China has repeatedly said that it will make more concessions concerning the "early harvest lists" in the ECFA talks.
Taiwan and China are slated to hold the next round of ECFA talks in May or June in China. Both sides have reiterated their resolve to clinch the agreement the sooner the better.
The two sides have tried hard to arrive at an "early harvest list, " which will contain items of trade that will enjoy immediate tariff reduction or elimination after the agreement is signed.

Turning to a proposal by the opposition Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) that a referendum should be held to allow the public to decide the fate of the cross- Taiwan Strait trade pact, Shih contended that it will not be necessary, as most democratic governments around the world sign free trade agreements without the need for referendums.
"But whether or not a referendum should be called to serve that end must be handled in line with the Referendum Law," he added.
"The Executive Yuan is responsible for the ECFA, and will submit the accord to the Legislative Yuan for screening once the deal is signed," Shih said.

DOC.HEADLINE: Changhua County promotes fruit, vegetables in Singapore
DOC.DATELINE: Singapore, April 22 (CNA) 04/22/10 16:58:09 (By Charles Kang and Fanny Liu)

TEXT.P: Vegetables and fruit from central Taiwan's Changhua County attracted a lot of attention at a promotional event in Singapore Thursday, and organizers of the event said they are planning to introduce more Taiwanese fruit and vegetables to Singapore.

About NT$8 million (US$253,968) -worth of mushrooms, grapes, guavas, carrots and star fruit from the county -- one of Taiwan's main agricultural areas -- will be sold by NTUC Fairprice, a leading Singapore supermarket chain and one of the event organizers.

NTUC Fairprice Managing Director Seah Kian Peng said most Singaporeans have a very good impression of Taiwan's agriculture products, so the company decided to expand the size of the promotional event this year and to continue to cooperate with Taiwan in introducing more Taiwanese vegetables and fruit.

Addressing the opening ceremony of the promotional campaign, Changhua Magistrate Cho Po-yuan expressed hope that other agriculture products from his county such as flowers and seedlings can also be exported to Singapore now that the county's grapes and mushrooms have gained praise after being sold in Singapore since last year.

Vanessa Shih, Taiwan's Representative to Singapore, noted that the promotional event was the third of its kind and said the Taiwanese representative office in Singapore will continue to promote Taiwanese products such as organic foods.

DOC.HEADLINE: Taiwanese yacht builders to make Kaohsiung production stronghold
DOC.DATELINE: Kaohsiung, April 22 (CNA) 04/22/10 17:11:48 (By Emma Tseng and Deborah Kuo)

TEXT.P: Taiwanese yacht builders signed a letter of intent with the Kaohsiung city government Thursday to increase their investment in Kaohsiung and take advantage of plans that the city government has mapped out to facilitate their development.

John Lu, founder and CEO of Horizon Yachts -- the largest yacht builder in Asia and sixth-largest in the world -- and chairman of the Taiwan Yacht Industry Association, signed the letter of intent on behalf of association members with Kaohsiung Mayor Chen Chu.

Lu said that although many Chinese cities, including Shanghai, Qingdao and Shenzhen, have beckoned Taiwanese yacht builders with investment incentives, he prefers keeping his company home in Kaohsiung.
"The Kaohsiung sail boat industry has its competitiveness as a cluster of builders has been forming here," Lu said.

Addressing the signing ceremony, Chen said the development of a yacht building hub, to be named the Asia Luxury Sail Boat Development District, will be one of the pivotal projects under the port city's endeavor to speed up its industrial transition.
The sail boat building district will be located on a 105-hectare tidal land area to which the city government will allocate NT$5 billion (US$160 million) for development, Chen said.
She added that the yacht building district has also been included in a project approved by the Executive Yuan to develop a new "ocean-and-air" town in Kaohsiung.

Lu said that despite China's beckoning, he and other Taiwanese yacht builders preferred to keep their roots in Kaohsiung because of the high-caliber manpower in Taiwan and a well-established research, production, marketing and delivery chain.
"The Asia Luxury Sail Boat Development District to be developed in Kaohsiung could become the most complete and competitive yacht building area in the world," a confident Lu forecast.
Taiwan's yacht industry is a 40-year veteran in the yacht building world, even though yachting is non-existent in Taiwan due to restrictive regulations.

He said Taiwan is the only country in the world in which yacht builders build yachts on land, and the only yacht building country in the world in which yachting has until recent years not been permitted.
It is not impossible for Taiwan to turn into a yachting country if the government lifts a ban on the development of marinas and yachting, and adds new statutes governing yachting, Lu said.

DOC.HEADLINE: KMT puts brakes on controversial personal data act
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, April 22 (CNA) 04/22/10 17:31:05 (By Maubo Chang)

TEXT.P: The legislative caucus of the ruling Kuomintang (KMT) decided Thursday to postpone the third reading of amendments to the Personal Data Protection Act amid fierce criticism from the local mass media.

Legislator Lin Yi-shih, who is head of the KMT's policy committee, said the leading members of the caucus, after consultation with Cabinet officials, decided Friday to ask the plenary session of the legislature to postpone the third reading of the bill.
However, the legislature is expected to make a firm decision on the revisions at its next plenary session on April 27, Lin said.

The KMT lawmakers stalled the bill amid complaints in the media about a clause that would require news organizations to obtain the consent of an individual before they could publicize his or her personal information. This is seen likely to cramp the operations of many publications and TV talk shows that have built their business on sensational expose's.

The controversy flared up Tuesday after the legislature's Organic Laws and Statutes Committee decided to strike out a clause in the amendments that would have exempted the media from the consent requirement.

The mass-circulated China Times said in its editorial Thursday that the revised bill is unconstitutional, and if it is passed it will ruin the country's hard- earned freedom of the press and undermine President Ma's promise to protect human rights.

The editorial blasted the Ministry of Justice, which crafted the original version of the amendments, and the legislature, which struck out the media exemption clause, as the chief culprits in what it said was a bungled attempt to protect pesonal data.

Meanwhile Tan Cheng-hsiang, director of the Legal Affairs Department under the Ministry of the Justice said the revisions were aimed at protecting people's personal information rather than limiting freedom of the press.
The original intention was to exclude the mass media from the stipulation, but this idea was opposed by the majority of people with whom the ministry consulted, he added.

DOC.HEADLINE: Economic growth could hit 5 percent: economic affairs minister
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, April 22 (CNA) 04/22/10 17:31:50 (By Maubo Chang)

TEXT.P: Taiwan's economic growth could hit 5 percent this year judging from its performance in the first quarter, Minister of Economic Affairs Shih Yen-shiang said Thursday.

"The better-than-expected growth of course has something to do with the proposed economic cooperation framework agreement with China, " Shih said while fielding questions from Kuomintang Legislator Lee Ching-hua at the Legislative Yuan.
The agreement, which is still under negotiation between Taipei and Beijing, is expected by the Taiwanese side to be concluded in June.

Citing Taiwan's boosted international trade and export orders, Shih said there are increasing signs that the growth rate could hit 5 percent this year, although the Directorate General of Budget, Accounting and Statistics has forecast only a 4.72 percent growth.

Shih also declined to rule out the possibility of a 6.5 percent growth -- forecast by the International Monetary Fund -- saying that "it is not absolutely impossible, but 5 percent is a very reasonable forecast for the time being."

DOC.HEADLINE: Taiwan records year's fifth severe enterovirus case
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, April 22 (CNA) 04/22/10 17:39:21 (By Chen Ching-fang and Y.F. Low)

TEXT.P: Taiwan's health authorities reported Thursday the country's fifth case of severe enterovirus infection for this year, which involved a 9-month-old boy in Kaohsiung County.

The infant has been hospitalized since April 11 after coming down with a fever, drowsiness, seizures and acute flaccid paralysis, according to Lin Ting, director-general of the Centers for Disease Control (CDC).
The patient, who is now in stable condition, was later diagnosed as having contracted enterovirus type 71 (EV71) -- the deadliest type of the virus, Lin said.
Investigations show that the boy could have contracted the virus from his 34 -month-old brother, who was diagnosed with a minor enterovirus infection on April 7 and has since recovered, Lin said.

According to the official, severe complications can easily occur among children under 3 years old who get infected by an older child in the family. This is because younger children have weaker immunity and they are exposed to higher levels of the virus than the first victims.

CDC monitoring data show that 4.09 people out of every 1,000 patients seeking emergency medical attention last week were suffering from enterovirus. The ratio has reached the alert level, which falls within a range between 2.73 percent and 5.24 percent, the CDC said.

DOC.HEADLINE: March unemployment rate drops slightly to 5.67%
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, April 22 (CNA) 04/22/10 18:09:38 (By Fanny Liu)

TEXT.P: Taiwan's unemployment rate dropped in March to 5.67 percent, down 0.09 percentage points from the previous month, according to statistics released by the Directorate General of Budget, Accounting and Statistics (DGBAS) Thursday.
The jobless population in March was 624,000, down 10,000 from February.
The seasonally adjusted unemployment rate in March fell for the seventh consecutive month to 5.64 percent, according to the DGBAS.
The number of long-term unemployed, defined as those out of a job for at least one year, decreased by 3,000 in March to 115,000 -- the indicator's first monthly decrease in the past 11 months.
The number of employed people in Taiwan totaled 10.38 million in March.
At the same time, the number of unemployed people that lost their jobs to company closures or layoffs shrank by 14,000 in March, the ninth straight month in which the figure fell.
Meanwhile, there were 139,000 unemployed people between 45 and 64 years old in March, down 5,000 from February.

DOC.HEADLINE: Taiwan marks Earth Day with pledge to build low-carbon society
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, April 22 (CNA) 04/22/10 18:14:59 (By Lee Hsien-feng and Sofia Wu)

TEXT.P: Premier Wu Den-yih announced the launch of a low-carbon homeland program Thursday as part of activities to mark the 40th anniversary of World Earth Day.

"The program, under which two low-carbon model communities in each city and county around the country will be built by 2011, epitomizes our determination to march toward a low-carbon society, " Wu said at the launching ceremony held by the Cabinet-level Environmental Protection Administration (EPA).
Highlights of the program also include developing six low-carbon cities by 2014 and completing four low-carbon living areas in northern, central, southern and eastern Taiwan by 2020, Wu said.

"The Earth we live on requires protection from each of us... I hope each government agency, school and private corporation will fulfill its obligation as a member of the global village by contributing to global environmental protection," the premier added.

Since World Earth Day was launched on April 22, 1970 to raise public awareness of the importance of environmental protection, Wu noted, the pursuit of a healthy and sustainable living environment has never ceased.

Countries around the world are now working on measures to reduce carbon emissions, in accordance with the resolutions reached at the United Nations Framework Convention on Climate Change, in order to mitigate the impact of global warming on living creatures on the Earth.
In the face of this global trend, Wu said, the local population should step up its environmental protection efforts.

In response to the Earthday Network's A Billion Acts of Green campaign, the EPA has launched a series of green programs aimed at urging local people to conserve water resources, reduce carbon emissions and practice recycling, wildlife conservation, environmental cleanup and sustainable development of the land.
"We hope business groups and individual citizens will join forces with the government in carrying out these programs," the premier urged.

He also pointed out that the government's energy conservation campaign has generated encouraging results, saving 7 billion kilwatt hours of electricity last year and over the past few months, a volume of water equivalent to Taipei City's total consumption for 29 days.

DOC.HEADLINE: Teresa Teng museum opens in Kaohsiung
DOC.DATELINE: Kaohsiung, April 22 (CNA) 04/22/10 19:45:35 (By Chang Che-fon and Fanny Liu)

TEXT.P: Late Taiwanese superstar Teresa Teng's memorial museum attracted hundreds of visitors on its opening day in the southern port city of Kaohsiung Thursday, the museum administration said.

The nearly 800-square-meter museum, located by the Love River, showcases Teng's posters, pictures, dresses, accessories, personal collections, the bed in which Teng slept in Hong Kong and a Mercedes Benz she used in France, it said.

Addressing the opening ceremony, Kaohsiung Mayor Chen Chu said that the city's Tourism Bureau will help improve the environment around the museum and include it in the city's sightseeing information to attract more visitors.
Chen also thanked Teng's family for choosing Kaohsiung to establish the only museum devoted to Teng in Taiwan.
Admission to the museum is free and the administration said it expects to attract many Chinese tourists.
Teng's grave near the north coast of Taiwan is already one of the most popular scenic spots for Chinese tourists.
Teng, who died in May 1995 at 43 years old, is said to be the most famous female singer ever in Chinese communities around the world.

DOC.HEADLINE: ASUS optimistic about Q2 business prospects
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, April 22 (CNA) 04/22/10 20:20:47 (By T.C. Yeh and Flor Wang)

TEXT.P: ASUSTeK Computer Inc., one of Taiwan's prime computer producers, is optimistic about its business prospects in the second quarter due to better-than-expected performance in Q1, company executives said Thursday.

Q1 revenue of ASUS totaled NT$74.807 billion (US$2.38 billion) , only a 6.24 percent drop from its Q4 revenue -- better than the previous forecast of a 10 percent - 20 percent contraction, ASUS ECO Jerry Shen said at a shareholder meeting.
The company's March revenue hit NT$31.715 billion, an increase of 56 percent from February and a 71 percent year-on-year growth.
Shen also forecast that the company's revenue will expand from quarter to quarter this year, thanks to rebounding business around the world, particularly in eastern Europe.

Brushing aside speculation that an ash cloud from an erupting volcano in Iceland might have affected its business in Europe, ASUS Chairman Stan Shih said the impact of suspended European flights on the company's deliveries will be limited as the company has raised its ratio of marine transport. Europe is the main market for the computer firm.
Shih also reiterated his resolve to make ASUS the world's third-largest computer firm next year.
ASUS is currently the world's No. 1 maker of motherboards, enjoying a 37 percent stake in the global market. It aims to be putting out more than 50 percent of the world's motherboards by 2014.
Meanwhile, both China Airlines and EVA Airways, Taiwan's two largest carriers, announced that all their European flights had returned to normal.

DOC.HEADLINE: French philharmonic to perform in Taiwan
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei April 22 (CNA) 04/22/10 20:29:46 (by Sunnie Chen)

TEXT.P: The Orchestre Philharmonique de Radio France, one of the top orchestras in Europe, will bring their distinctive sounds to Taiwan in May.

The philharmonic, led by Korean-born conductor Myung-Whun Chung, will give two concerts at the National Music Hall on May 7-8, according to an official of the National Theater and Concert Hall (NTCH) Thursday.

The 104-member group will tour Shanghai for Shanghai's World Expo at the end of this month, and then come to Taipei to present the group's best repertoire -- French composer Joseph-Maurice Ravel's works.
The orchestra is the first philharmonic created by French Radio in the 1930s, and since May 2000 has been led by Chung, who has successfully raised the performance of the group to a new level.

The changes are reflected in the latest music reviews: one music critic had indicated that he thought France did not currently have an orchestra which was capable of playing consistently at the level of those in Berlin, Amsterdam or Vienna. But after listening to one of the philharmonic's concerts last month conducted by Chung, he felt that they had demonstrated that such comparisons were no longer true.
The philharmonic has performed "with just about as much precision as one would think humanly possible, " the critic Steven Kruger wrote in the Berkshire Review for the arts.

Chung is one of the most influential Asian musicians in the world. He has received many honors, such as the Premio Abbiati award and the Arturo Toscanni award in Italy. He has also been named "Artist of the Year" by the Association of French Theatres and Music Critics in 1991.
In addition, he received the Legion d'honneur in 1992, and three times the "Victoire de la Musique" in 1995, a French music award.

This time he is leading the group to Taiwan's capital to present works by French impressionist composer Maurice Ravel, and has also invited French pianist Roger Muraro, winner of the International Franz Liszt Piano Competition, to play Ravel's piano concerto in G Major.

The piece is one of the only two concertos that Ravel has ever composed. It is unrestrained in rhythm and elegant in melody. In fact, some regard it as the most beautiful movement in all Ravel's compositions, the organizer of the NTCH said.

DOC.HEADLINE: President vows to find win-win solution to economy, carbon dilemma
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, April 22 (CNA) 04/22/10 20:35:15 (By Garfie Li, Wang Shu-fen and Sofia Wu)

TEXT.P: President Ma Ying-jeou said Thursday his administration will do its best to find a win-win solution to the dilemma of balancing economic development with reducing greenhouse gas emissions.
Ma made the remarks while meeting with representatives of major domestic environmental advocacy groups to mark the 40th World Earth Day.

Noting that the government has designated 2010 as the year for promoting energy conservation and carbon reduction, Ma said various public agencies are carrying out 30-plus programs to realize those goals.

Through the concerted efforts of the government, business groups and individual citizens, Ma said, Taiwan managed to lower its annual carbon emissions to the 2005 level last year, far ahead of the original target of reducing carbon emissions to the 2008 level by 2020.
In related developments that day, Premier Wu Den-yi announced the launch of a low-carbon homeland program to mark Earth Day.

Under the program, two low-carbon model communities in every city and county will be built by 2011, while six low-carbon cities will be developed by 2014 and four "low-carbon living circles" will take shape in northern, central, southern and eastern Taiwan by 2020.

Addressing the launch ceremony held by the Environmental Protection Administration, Wu also urged major carbon emitters such as state-owned Taiwan Power Co, Formosa Plastics Corp. and CPC Corp., Taiwan, to step up carbon reduction efforts to contribute to the campaign against global warming.
Meanwhile, Vice Premier Eric Liluan Chu attended a "save the Earth through carbon reduction" event organized by the Taiwan Institute for Sustainable Energy (TISE).
Chu walked from the Executive Yuan to the site of the activity at a square in front of Taipei Main Station to signify his support for a low-carbon green lifestyle.

Noting that the government has mapped out a 10-year carbon reduction plan, Chu said 10 strategies will be adopted to realize the goal of cutting carbon reduction by 210 million tons by 2020 through an industrial policy overhaul, power generation and transportation reforms, and environmental education.

TISE Chairman Eugene Chien said Taiwan accounted for about 1 percent of the world's total carbon emissions of 28.9 billion tons last year, making it the world's 22nd-largest source of carbon emissions. Taiwan's ranking was even higher at 17th in terms of per capita carbon emissions.

To avoid possible sanctions from the rest of the world, Chien said, Taiwan must intensify its energy conservation and carbon reduction campaign. He suggested that the government take the lead in this regard by pushing state-run enterprises to cut carbon emissions and adjusting development policies for high- carbon-emitting and energy-consuming industries.

Vice Minister of Foreign Affairs David Y.L. Lin and representatives of Britain, Australia, Japan, Singapore, Haiti and Belize stationed in Taipei also attended the event to witness Taiwan's declaration that it will work with the world in saving Earth.

DOC.HEADLINE: Taiwan copes with shortage of Norwegian salmon sushi
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, April 22 (CNA) 04/22/10 21:02:41 (By Alex Jiang)

TEXT.P: Local hotels and restaurants offering Norwegian salmon sushi faced rising costs and sought alternatives after grounded European flights over the past week slashed shipments of the popular fish.
"We still have salmon shipped from Norway, but the number of shipments has significantly dropped, " said Huang Lien-fa, vice president of PTC Nakajima Suisan (Taiwan) Co.
The company sells sushi at various up-market supermarkets around Taiwan.
The price of Norwegian salmon shipped by plane has gone up 10 percent to 20 percent, he told CNA Thursday in a telephone interview.
Grand Formosa Regent Taipei, one of Taiwan's international five- star hotels, has also had its Norwegian salmon supplies reduced.
"Our supplier told us that there will be supplies on Thursday, but they are not sure about Friday, " said Ellen Chang, the hotel's public relations director.
If the supplies are cut off, she said, the hotel will have to replace raw Norwegian salmon with other dishes in its restaurants.
The hotel might also use salmon from Canada for other salmon dishes on its menus, she added.
Chang said the hotel is not facing a price increase, as the hotel signs long- term contracts with its suppliers to ensure stable supplies and prices.

Sushi Express Co., Taiwan's largest sushi chain group, said the sharp decrease in Norwegian salmon air shipments due to the volcanic ash cloud from Iceland has caused an impact on its 137 stores around the country.
"The cost has surged 20 percent and we have been switching to salmon from Canada and Australia," a company executive said.
Sushi Express, which imports 3 to 5 tons of salmon per day, is expected to have its Norwegian salmon supplies returned to normal next week, the executive noted.
Meanwhile, the Carrefour supermarket chain was due to feature Norwegian salmon shipped by plane at a promotional event Thursday, but was forced to use frozen stocks instead.

Although flights were resuming in Europe, a local dealer providing raw Norwegian salmon to northern Taiwan said that whether the supply and price of the fish will return to normal in the following week will rely on how fast airports in Europe resolve their flight backlogs. CNA Photo 119

DOC.HEADLINE: Yang Ming Marine expects to turn profit in Q2
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, April 22 (CNA) 04/22/10 22:10:18 (By Chiao Hsiao-hui and Fanny Liu)

TEXT.P: Helped by growing business on its European routes, Yang Ming Marine Transport Corp. is expected to turn a profit in the second quarter of this year, the company's president said Thursday.

Yang Ming Marine President Robert Ho explained that the freight rates on the company's European routes had gone up since Q4 last year, with the percentage of European lines business also increasing from 35 percent to 40 percent.
"Spring has arrived for container services, " said Ho, who is also director- general of the Chinese Shipowner's Association of Taipei.
The company made a huge net loss of NT$15.84 billion (US$500 million) in 2009 -- the first annual loss for nearly 10 years.
However, the losses in Q1 decreased by between 70 percent and 80 percent from the same period of last year, Ho said.

Ho pointed out that the recovery of the global economy and rising freight rates have decreased the number of idle container ships worldwide to 400 -- resulting in the ratio of container ships sitting idle at 7.5 percent compared to 600, or 11.7 percent, in Q3 last year.
A proposed freight rate hike is expected to help the company also earn a profit on its American routes by June or July, he went on.
The company is also planning new routes, in addition to a recently launched Australian route, Ho added.
European routes account for about 40 percent of the company's business, American routes make up 35 percent, and the Middle East and Asian routes comprise 25 percent, Ho noted.

DOC.HEADLINE: President reaffirms commitment to press freedom
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, April 22 (CNA) 04/22/10 22:32:48 (By Garfie Li and Sofia Wu)

TEXT.P: President Ma Ying-jeou expects the legislative and executive branches to work together to allay suspicion that recent legal amendments might lead to excessive restrictions on press freedom, the Presidential Office said Thursday.

The office issued the statement amid mounting media criticism of a package of amendments to the Personal Data Protection Act that, if enacted, would require news organizations to obtain the consent of an individual before publishing his or her personal information.

The requirement is seen as likely to undermine press freedom and even stymie the operations of some local media organizations, particularly gossip tabloids and TV talks shows that thrive on sensationalist exposes.
Noting that freedom of the press is not only a constitutionally protected basic human right but also the bedrock of democracy, the statement said Ma is adamant that press freedom should be protected.

On the controversy surrounding the proposed amendments to the Personal Data Protection Act, the statement said the contention mainly results from the conflict between two basic human rights -- freedom of the press and the right to personal privacy.

Describing the proposed amendments as being aimed at better protecting the personal privacy of ordinary people, the statement said the move should actually be seen as a step forward for Taiwan's human rights protection.

Nevertheless, the statement said, the draft amendments might indeed cause improper restrictions on press freedom. In this regard, the statement said, the president hopes the legislative and executive branches will take steps to make necessary improvements and alleviate misgivings.
The ruling Kuomintang-controlled Legislative Yuan originally planned to complete a third reading of the contentious package Friday, but made a reversal Thursday following a media outcry.

After consulting with Cabinet officials, leading members of the KMT legislative caucus said they will ask the legislature Friday to postpone the third reading of the bill until April 27 to allow for more extensive discussion on the contentious points.

DOC.HEADLINE: Today in history
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, April 23 (CNA) 04/23/10 08:55:44
DOC.TEXT:
Today is Friday, April 23, or the 10th day of the third month of the Year of the Tiger according to the lunar calendar. Following is a list of important events that have occurred on this date in the past:
1616: William Shakespeare, English playwright and poet whose body of works is considered by most as the greatest in English literature, dies at New Place at the age of 52.
1616: Miguel de Cervantes, Spanish writer best known for his classic satirical novel "Don Quixote," dies at the age of 69.
1873: The Dutch war against the Sultan of Achin begins in northwest Sumatra, Indonesia.
1895: Russia, Germany and France protest the ceding of Chinese territory to Japan.
1897: Lester Pearson, Canadian prime minister from 1963-1968, is born. He won the 1957 Nobel Peace Prize for his part in settling the Suez crisis.
1919: Peking Teachers High School for Girls is formally established.
1928: Shirley Temple Black, American child star who went on to become the U.S. ambassador to Ghana, is born. As Shirley Temple, she was an immensely popular child actress of the 1930s, starring in films such as "Wee Willie Winkie" and "Bright Eyes."
1935: Joseph Stalin officially opens the Moscow underground rail system.
1945: U.S. and Soviet forces meet at Torgau in eastern Germany.
1946: Hsia Kai-chun, noted writer of modern Chinese literature, dies in Shanghai at the age of 63.
1949: Government forces of the Republic of China evacuate Nanking.
1962: In the biggest-ever "ban the bomb" demonstration, some 150,000 people rally in London's Hyde Park.
1965: The Soviet Union launches its first communications satellite.
1965: President Charles de Gaulle of France emphasizes his opposition to the United States' Asian policies by withdrawing French units from naval maneuvers of the Southeast Asia Treaty Organization.
1969: A Los Angeles jury decides that Sirhan B. Sirhan should be sent to the gas chamber for the murder of Sen. Robert Kennedy in June 1968.
1975: U.S. President Gerald Ford declares the Vietnam War is over as panic grips Saigon after the South Vietnamese regime's Cabinet resigns.
1985: The Industrial Technology Research Institute successfully develops an amorphous-silicon solar battery of high commercial value.
1986: National Taiwan University Hospital separates a pair of 14-day-old Siamese twins, saving the life of one of the girls. The twins set a record for being the youngest to be separated.
1990: Li Peng, premier of mainland China, arrives in Moscow for a visit, becoming the most senior Beijing leader to tour the Soviet Union in 26 years.
1991: Tens of thousands of striking Soviet workers fill the streets in Minsk on the eve of the Communist Party plenum.
1997: After 26 days of occupation by rebels, Peru's government launches a sudden attack on the Japanese ambassador's residence in Lima, freeing 71 hostages. Three soldiers, one hostage and all 14 guerrillas die in the attack.
1999: State-run Taiwan Sugar Corp. inaugurates a phalaenopsis plant in Costa Rica, with scores of ranking Costa Rican government officials attending the ceremony.
2000: Former U.S. Assistant Secretary for East Asia and Pacific Affairs Winston Lord visits People First Party Chairman James Soong to exchange opinions on the Taiwan Strait situation.
2000: President-elect Chen Shui-bian and Vice President-elect Annette Lu kick off an island-wide tour to express thanks to their supporters in the March 18 presidential election.
2001: Computer chip giant Intel signs a memorandum of cooperation with the Industrial Development Bureau and the Technology Department under the Ministry of Economic Affairs.
Confucius' lesson of the day: "A wise and good man is one who sets himself seriously to order his conversation aright."

DOC.HEADLINE: Bottle from Taiwan found on U.S. beach after 8 years at sea
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, April 23 (CNA) 04/23/10 10:26:34 (By Chris Wang)

TEXT.P: A bottle thrown into the sea by a Dutch couple in Taiwan has traveled across the Pacific Ocean to be found on the coast of the United States eight years later, a Seattle TV station reported Friday.
According to the report, local resident Catherine Shaw found the bottle, which contained a message from the couple, on a beach near Ocean Shores, a city in Washington State, a few weeks ago.

"We opened it and it was from 2002 and was thrown in the ocean in Taiwan... A couple from Holland were on a cruise ship. He was an officer on a cruise ship and they had gone to Hong Kong. They thought it would be fun to throw a couple of bottles into the ocean, " Shaw was quoted as saying.

"Every time we sail together we throw a few bottles into the sea and hope someone will find it and write to us, " the couple said in the letter, which had been laminated so that it would survive longer in the ocean.

Shaw emailed them and found out that they are Niels and Marije Dekker, who have married and now have an 11-month-old son. She said she plans to keep corresponding with the couple and hopes to meet them in the future.

DOC.HEADLINE: Economic Daily News: Fixing housing prices is a piece of cake

TEXT.P: The government has recently been trying to cool housing prices in response to wide-ranging public outrage over the skyrocketing market.

However, the measures taken, such as imposing credit controls on housing projects in restricted areas and stopping the auctioning off of state-owned property, will only push housing prices even higher. By suppressing supply when demand keeps soaring, the government is unlikely to succeed in lowering prices.

The fundamental method of stabilizing housing prices is to maintain a balance between demand and supply. A good example is Singapore, where the government has been building public housing communities, known as new towns, for rent to citizens. If several such new towns were built in the greater Taipei area so that residents could easily find a home, housing prices would stabilize immediately.

Hoisting the banner of "grassroots economy, " the government is now moving in the right direction by planning to build a large number of cheap residential units in the suburban Linkou area. But this is still not enough. More new towns should be established in other habitable areas for rent to people who do not own a home.

Targeting those rich people who can spend big money on luxury residences, the government should gradually work to improve the transparency of housing trading prices and significantly raise housing and land tax rates to the levels of advanced countries. This would fix the housing headache for good. (April 23, 2010)

DOC.HEADLINE: Talk of the day -- Job market shows signs of rebound
DOC.DATELINE: 04/23/10 12:41:29 (By Deborah Kuo)

TEXT.P: Taiwan's unemployment rate stood at 5.67 percent in March, down 0.09 percent from the month-earlier level, and the number of those on the jobless list also declined by 10,000 to 624,000.

Good news in March also included that the numbers of jobless people aged over 45 and those who have been unemployed for over one year have both fallen, while the average regular salary for office workers rose by 2.64 percent in the January- February period to NT$35,912, marking the greatest growth for same period in 10 years.
Premier Wu Den-yih reiterated recently that he will resign if Taiwan's unemployment rate remains higher than 5 percent by the end of this year.

Wu said the Cabinet will make every possible effort to boost employment, including speeding up the replacement of civil servants as they retire from government service, creating jobs for new graduates in the hope that the global economy will continue to recover.
The following are excerpts from local media coverage of the issue:
China Times:

Liu Tien-tsu, an official with the Directorate General of Budget, Accounting and Statistics, attributed the rise in average regular salaries in January and February mainly to a steadily recovering global economy and a relatively lower comparison base from 2009.
However, Liu stressed that the overall condition of the local workforce market has not yet returned to the levels prior to the 2008-2009 global economic meltdown.

This fact is indicated in declining average irregular salaries, including performance awards, year-end bonuses and dividend payments, that office workers received between December 2009 and February 2010 -- totaling NT$51,620, which was down by NT$8,268 year on year, Liu said. (April 23, 2010).
The Liberty Times:

The latest International Monetary fund (IMF) report adjusted upward its forecast for global economic growth to 4.2 percent for 2010, with Taiwan's GDP rising by 6.5 percent, the highest among the four Asian dragons -- Taiwan, Hong Kong, South Korea and Singapore.
However, the IMF also forecast that Taiwan's unemployment rate will top 5.4 percent for the year, the highest among the dragons.

For 2011, the IMF forecast that Taiwan's GDP will grow a little bit slower by 4.8 percent to rank third among the dragons, while its unemployment rate will top 4.9 percent, still the highest among the four. (April 23, 2010).
United Daily News:

JPMorgan Chase edged GE out to become the world's largest company in terms of revenue this year, while Taiwan's Hon Hai Precision topped all 39 Taiwanese companies that made the Global 2000 list published by Forbes recently.

China's ICBC ranked fifth and Hon Hai was 176th. Other Taiwanese companies that made the Forbes Global 2000 list included Taiwan Semiconductor Manufacturing Co., Formosa Plastics Corp., China Steel Corp., Chunghwa Telecom, AU Optronics, Quanta Computer Inc. and ASUSTek Computer Inc.

These companies are major providers of new job openings in Taiwan. According to the 104 Job Bank, 326,000 job openings were available around Taiwan in April, up a whopping 66 percent year on year. (April 23, 2010).

DOC.HEADLINE: China Times: Why should Taiwan shut out Chinese students?
DOC.DATELINE: 04/23/10 12:48:25 (By Maubo Chang)

TEXT.P: Fear makes people retreat, which leads to restraint and eventually self- inflicted isolation. Facing the rise of China, Taiwan should not be frightened and should not back down, because the island has nothing to fall back on.
Based on this view, instead of rejecting Chinese students, Taiwan should attract them to study here in the hope that Taiwan's shine and warmth will rub off on China through these students.

But while all the colleges in the country are ready to take in Chinese students, a bill aimed at lifting the restrictions on them has prompted a fracas at a Legislative Yuan committee meeting, and more violent conflict is expected when the bill is referred to the whole floor for passage.

Why are the Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) lawmakers going out of their way to block the bill? They claim that Chinese students would strain the country's educational resources, compete with local young people for job opportunities and crowd local students out of schools.

These worries are groundless, as the Education Ministry has said that Chinese students will not affect local student intakes and will not receive a penny in grants from the government, while the Examination Yuan has reiterated many times that Chinese students will not be allowed to take civil service examinations and as far as local colleges can maintain their competitiveness, Taiwan should not be afraid of allowing its students to study abroad, including in China.
The movement of talent is a worldwide trend and Taiwan should ride the wave by adapting itself to it rather than bucking it. Taiwan should harness worldwide talent to enhance its competitiveness.

After undergoing peaceful democratic development and creating the economic miracle, what can scare Taiwan? China is following the path Taiwan trod so many years ago toward democracy and a market economy. Taiwan could help China to move ahead on the road without deviation or retreat. The DPP is worried that Chinese students in Taiwan will serve as Chinese agents to influence Taiwan, but on the other hand, Taiwan could win over these students and make them side with Taiwan.

The DPP shut the country's doors on China for eight years during its rule of Taiwan, at the cost of Taiwan's economic growth. Should it continue to hold the country hostage? Taiwan welcomes talent from all over the world, so why should it reject talent from China? Exchanges across the Taiwan Strait are an irresistible tide, and education exchanges are an inevitable part of this. Failing to realize this will undermine the DPP's bid to return to power. (April 23, 2010)

DOC.HEADLINE: Customs official accused in Japanese beef smuggling scandal
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, April 23 (CNA) 04/23/10 13:15:30 (By Chiu Chun-chin and Elizabeth Hsu)

TEXT.P: Amid a months-long dispute over U.S. beef imports that appear set to continue, prosecutors in Taoyuan County, which houses Taiwan's largest international airport, have discovered that a local trader has been smuggling in banned beef from Japan for at least a year.

Taoyuan district prosecutors and police raided a trading company in Taipei City Thursday, seizing 95 kg of frozen Matsuzaka beef, a Japanese product that has been barred from entering Taiwan since 2001 after Japan reported mad cow disease outbreaks.
The prosecution took in the firm's owner, identified as Chang Shih-chun, 52, and two of his staff later that day for interrogation.

During the probe, it was discovered that Chang had been sending two-to-six employees every week to Japan since 2009, who smuggled the beef into Taiwan on their return, according to the Taoyuan District Prosecutors Office.

Each trip they brought back scores of kilograms of Matsuzaka beef -- one of the most famous kinds of beef in Japan and internationally known for its perfectly balanced fat-to-meat ratio. In Japan, Matsuzaka is considered one of the generally recognized three most famous beef brands along with Kobe beef and Yonezawa beef.

The prosecution pointed out that the traders had colluded with an inspector at the Taipei Customs Office (TCO) , who shielded the smugglers from customs clearance checks at the Taiwan Taoyuan International Airport.
The company is suspected of having smuggled at least one ton of Matsuzaka beef from Japan over the past year, the prosecutors said.

The case was not exposed until Wednesday, when a Taoyuan district prosecutor, Ministry of Justice inspectors and TCO personnel detained three passengers upon their arrival at the airport from Japan and discovered a total of 95 kg of frozen Matsuzaka beef in their luggage.
Upon learning about the TCO inspector's involvement of the smuggling, the Director-General of Customs pledged to bring the suspect to justice.
On Friday, local newspapers reports said Chang had sold the beef to local high- end steak houses and teppanyaki restaurants at an average price of NT$9,000 (US$287) per kilo.
The United Daily News quoted Chang as saying that "the beef is very popular" and that it "sells out as soon as it arrives" in Taiwan.

DOC.HEADLINE: Taiwanese singing sensation causes commotion in Hollywood
DOC.DATELINE: Los Angeles, April 22 (CNA) 04/23/10 13:27:30 (By Chiang Chin-yeh and Y.F. Low)

TEXT.P: Taiwanese singing sensation Lin Yu-chun drew a large crowd of fans as he made a visit to the Hollywood Walk of Fame Thursday, a day after his appearances on two popular U.S. talk shows.

Walking down the famous sidewalk in search of the names of his favorite stars, Lin was recognized by many visitors, who requested to have their photos taken with him, leaving the street nearly impassable.
Among the crowd was a man who immediately telephoned his wife and mother-in-law, both of whom are Lin's fans, so that they could have a conversation with the singer.
There was also a group of women from Canada who knew of Lin from YouTube. They praised him for singing "like an angel."
Lin said he was extremely happy to have become so recognizable.

He described his visit to America as "fantastic, " because besides having the opportunity to meet American TV audiences, he has been able to attend an American Idol show and get a close look at many superstars.

Another of his gains from the trip is large-sized clothing, which is not so easily available in Taiwan, as well as a large-sized cap bearing the Los Angeles Dodgers logo, which was presented to him by a media representative from Taiwan.
Lin was scheduled to depart Los Angeles early Friday to return to Taiwan.
The main purpose of the visit was to perform and do interviews on the Ellen DeGeneres Show and Lopez Tonight.
He again conquered his audience when he sang Whitney Houston's version of "I Will Always Love You" on the Ellen DeGeneres Show.

Lin shot to fame after a video showing him singing the song on Taiwanese talent show "Million Star" was posted on YouTube April 6 and immediately went viral, with comparisons between Lin and British singing sensation Susan Boyle, who rose to stardom after auditioning for "Britain's Got Talent" last year.

DOC.HEADLINE: Job market picking up steam
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, April 23 (CNA) 04/23/10 13:42:00 (By Cheng Yun-hsuan and Deborah Kuo)

TEXT.P: The number of job openings in Taiwan surged in April following an improvement in the employment climate the previous month, two major job banks said Friday.
A total of 326,000 job openings were available around Taiwan in April, up 66 percent, or 130,000, over the year-earlier level, according to data compiled by online manpower agency 104 Job Bank.
It was the greatest growth of its kind since the global financial meltdown that started in the latter part of 2008, said Fang Guang-wei, a public relations manager for the 104 Job Bank.

The rising manpower demand came mainly from the computer and consumer electronics manufacturing, semiconductor manufacturing, optoelectronic and solar energy, financial services and electronic component manufacturing sectors, in that order, Fang said.
"Demand in all these areas increased by over 150 percent year on year, " he added.
Meanwhile, the 1111 Job Bank noted that many people change their jobs in February after the Chinese New Year, contributing in part to the rise in job openings in March.

Henry Ho, public relations director of the 1111 Job Bank, said the number of jobs listed with the job broker website in March totaled over 200,000, representing a month-on-month increase of 46 percent.
Most of the openings were available in the hi-tech manufacturing sector, the financial services sector and the real estate and housing brokerage sector, Ho said.

The unemployment rate stood at 5.67 percent in March, down 0.09 percent over the month-earlier level and the number of those on the jobless list also declined by 10,000 to 624,000 people, according to the Directorate General of Budget, Accounting and Statistics.

DOC.HEADLINE: Liberty Times: Taiwan's workers must brace for fewer jobs, lower pay
DOC.DATELINE: 04/23/10 13:50:16 (By Maubo Chang)

TEXT.P: President Ma Ying-jeou said at a meeting of the Kuomintang's (KMT's) Central Standing Committee that about 80,000 local workers could be affected by the proposed trade pact with China. They will not necessarily lose their jobs, but probably will have to accept lower pay or fewer perquisites.

Wages dropping because of the country's trade pact with China is not what is anticipated, but that is what is going on. It will not be necessary to bring wages down to China's level, but they will gradually move in that direction.
Owing to its close economic ties with China, Taiwan's wage level has apparently been dragged down in recent years and has declined to the level of 13 years ago, while unemployment is surging.
This trend is set to accelerate after the conclusion of the trade pact with China.

In order to avoid this, Taiwan should seek to boost domestic investment by inking free trade pacts with developed countries that boast higher wage levels rather than with developing states that have lower wage levels.

Under those circumstances, local wages would be driven up toward the levels of the developed countries. It would be a win-win situation for both management and the workers. However, a trade pact with China will only cost the country the chance of upgrading its industry and lay Taiwan open to China's political manipulation.
At the same time, local workers will face the risk of losing their jobs and the prospects of declining wages. This is a lose-lose case for management and workers alike.

Furthermore, the increasing exchanges with China evoked by the trade pact will help China gain Taiwan's technology and make it easier for it to compete with Taiwan. This means that the pact will benefit China more than Taiwan.

Fortunately, Taiwan is a democracy and people do not have to resign themselves to the government's decision on the trade pact with China. Now that the people are overwhelmingly calling for a referendum on the pact, the Ma administration will be swept away if it dares to try to crush it. (April 23, 2010)

DOC.HEADLINE: President to be honored by U.S. congressional group
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, April 23 (CNA) 04/23/10 15:13:51 (By Chiachen Hsieh and Y.F. Low)

TEXT.P: President Ma Ying-jeou is to be honored by a U.S. congressional organization for his leadership in international affairs, the Ministry of Foreign Affairs (MOFA) said Friday.

The Congressional Hispanic Leadership Institute (CHLI) is scheduled to present the Leadership in International Relations Award to Ma in a ceremony to be held in Washington, D.C. May 20, according to Harry Tseng, director-general of the Department of North American Affairs under the MOFA.

As objections from China would preclude Ma from attending the ceremony in person, the award will be accepted on Ma's behalf by Taiwan's representative to the United States, Jason Yuan, said Tseng, adding that Ma will film a thank-you speech in Taipei that will be screened at the ceremony.
The CHLI is a non-profit organization founded by members of Congress to promote the interests of Americans of Hispanic and Portuguese descent.
Approximately 400 guests are expected to attend the May 20 ceremony, including U.S government officials, congressmen, foreign emissaries and businessmen, according to the MOFA.

DOC.HEADLINE: Over 74% of Taiwan people satisfied with living conditions
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, April 23 (CNA) 04/23/10 15:38:19 (By Lee Ming-tsung and Deborah Kuo)

TEXT.P: The people of Taiwan are more satisfied with their living conditions than they were a year ago, according to the results of a survey released Friday by the Directorate General of Budget, Accounting and Statistics (DGBAS).
The survey results show that 74.1 percent of the respondents said they are satisfied with their living conditions, up 4.2 percentage points from March 2009.

About 83.7 percent of those polled cited garbage collection and handling as the most satisfactory element in their lives, followed by sewerage and flood prevention facilities in their neighborhoods (78 percent) , transport convenience (77.3 percent) , quality of health care (73.2 percent) and social order (71.2 percent), according to the DGBAS.

On quality of life, 84.3 percent of the respondents said they are most satisfied with their family life, followed by their working conditions (61.5 percent) , their family finances (59.5 percent) , leisure (56.5 percent) and performance at work (50.5 percent).

On education and safety, 71.1 percent said they are satisfied with the safety and security in public places, followed by consumer protection (70.7 percent) and public transport safety (65.2 percent), according to the survey.

Of particular note to the DGBAS officials was that 67.1 percent of the respondents said they have not taken part in any lifelong learning activity, indicating that there is room for improvement in this aspect of Taiwan life.

A total of 1,084 adults selected randomly nationwide were interviewed for the survey conducted March 22-23, which had a confidence level of 95 percent and a margin of error of plus or minus 2.98 percentage points.

DOC.HEADLINE: Taiwan share prices close higher
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, April 23 (CNA) 04/23/10 15:40:16 (By Olivia Wang)

TEXT.P: Taiwan's share prices closed higher Friday with the weighted index, the market's key barometer, moving up 26.2 points, or 0.32 percent, to close at 8,004.89.
The local bourse opened at 8,021.71 and fluctuated between a low of 7,996.77 and a high of 8,030.11 during the day's trading. Market turnover totaled NT$124.49 billion (US$3.97 billion).

Four of the eight major stock categories gained ground, with paper and pulp issues gaining the most at 1.04 percent. Foodstuff shares rose 0.58 percent, machinery and electronics issues advanced 0.54 percent and financial and banking stocks moved up 0.13 percent.

The other four major stock categories lost ground, with cement issues dropping the most at 0.49 percent, followed by textile issues, which moved down 0.4 percent. Construction shares fell 0.34 percent and plastics and chemicals were down 0.27 percent.
Gainers outnumbered losers 1,794 to 1,282, with 353 remaining unchanged.
