Foreign investors and Chinese QDIIs were net buyers of NT$3.99 billion-worth of shares.

DOC.HEADLINE: Cross-strait telecom MOUs signed
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, April 23 (CNA) 04/23/10 15:41:21 (By Carol Yeh and Fanny Liu)

TEXT.P: The Taiwan Telecommunication Industry Development Association (TTIDA) signed five memorandums of understanding (MOUs) with China's Association of Communications Across the Taiwan Strait (ACATS) Friday, with the aim of enhancing cross-strait exchanges and cooperation in the industry.

The MOUs are designed to establish a platform for cross-strait cooperation and exchanges, to foster such exchanges and cooperation, to push both sides toward collaboration on laying a submarine optical fiber cable, to jointly develop markets and to cooperate in the field of investment.
The two sides also agreed to cooperate in developing telecommunications technologies and services, enhancing service quality and seeking more global business opportunities.

The TTIDA, set up in 2004, is an industry platform operated by Taiwan's telecommunication service providers. In addition to pushing for the local industry's development, enhancing cross-strait exchanges in the industry is also one of its main missions.

The ACATS was established last August to promote cross-strait development and exchanges in the industry. Its members include China Telecom, China Unicom, China Mobile and various telecommunication research institutes.

DOC.HEADLINE: Tourism Bureau sees promotion drive paying off as arrivals surge
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, April 23 (CNA) 04/23/10 16:10:12 (By Sofia Wu)

TEXT.P: Taiwan's efforts to promote tourism are paying off as the number of visitors in March hit a new single-month high of 516,512, Tourism Bureau Director-General Janice Lai said Friday.
The number marked a steep 30.7 percent year-on-year growth and beat the previous single-month record of 450,000 set last December, Lai said.
"Most encouraging was the fact that there was an increase in the number of visitors from every major tourist source in March, "she noted.

Moreover, the number of arrivals in every individual category also all increased from the year-earlier level, she added. For example, the number of sightseers, which formed 60 percent of the total arrivals, rose 46 percent in March, she said.

Even more impressive was the 85 percent year-on-year increase in the number of visitors who came to Taiwan for study purposes, said Lai. In other categories, the number of conference-goers rose by 60 percent, the number of visitors attending family reunions by 30 percent, and the number of business visitors by 21 percent.
"All these figures indicate that not only the Tourism Bureau but also various government agencies have contributed to the drive to attract more visitors to Taiwan," Lai said.

Amid improved relations across the Taiwan Strait, China emerged as Taiwan's main source of tourism in March, with 149,617 Chinese citizens visiting the island, up 71.97 percent year-on-year. Incentive trips offered by major China-based companies contributed significantly to the surge in the number of Chinese tourist arrivals, Lai said.

Altogether, Chinese travelers made 344,136 visits to Taiwan in the first quarter of this year -- an increase of 98.64 percent year-on-year. Travel industry sources predicted that the total number of Chinese visitors will break the 1 million mark this year.
Japan ranked second in terms of the number of visitors to Taiwan in March, totaling 112,231 and up 6.5 percent year-on-year.
Hong Kong and Macau combined were the third largest source, with 61,024 arrivals, which represented an annual growth rate of 6.9 percent.
The number of visits by American citizens in March was 37,696, which marked a 26.86 percent year-on-year increase and put the U.S. in fourth place as a tourism source.

The Tourism Bureau's promotional blitz in Times Square and on New York subways, coupled with its invitations to U.S. media professionals and travel executives to explore Taiwan's tourist attractions, has helped to boost the market, Lai said.

She noted that the annual number of arrivals from Malaysia rose by a whopping 106.96 percent to 26,698, which put Malaysia in fifth place as a tourism source market. She attributed the steep growth in visitor arrivals from that country to the increase in the number of Taiwan-Malaysia flights and the launch of budget travel between the two countries.
The number of visitors from Europe, Singapore and South Korea increased in March by 17.37 percent, 14.75 percent and 28.67 percent, respectively.
The increase in the number of tourist arrivals has benefited the local travel and hospitality industries and even street vendors, market sources said.

Moreover, the tourism boom has helped hotel operators in the eastern counties of Taitung and Hualien tide over the effects of Typhoon Morakot, which wreaked havoc in southern and southeastern Taiwan last August, according to industry sources.

Following Taiwan's wider opening to Chinese tourists nearly two years ago, 10 tourist hotels with a total of 2,602 rooms have been under construction, Tourism Bureau statistics show. In addition, 137 new general hotels have opened and 805 others have had facelifts, in anticipation of an increasing number of visitors from China.
Five new tourist hotels are scheduled to open this year and four international hotel chains, including Okura and Le Meridien, are expected to come on line in Taiwan next year.

DOC.HEADLINE: Former Taipei mayor named Grand Hotel chairman
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, April 23 (CNA) 04/23/10 16:22:14 (By Chen Shun-hsieh and Deborah Kuo)

TEXT.P: Former Taipei Mayor Huang Ta-chou assumed his new post Friday as chairman of the Grand Hotel, a distinctive Taipei landmark built in 1952 reportedly under Madame Chiang Kai-shek's directive and operated as a non-profit organization.
Huang, who served as mayor of Taipei between 1990 and 1994, received the official seal of the Grand Hotel from acting Chairman Chen Tien-kuei, making him the 12th chairman of the prestigious hotel.
Addressing the handover ceremony, which was organized by the Ministry of Transportation and Communications, Huang vowed to recover and represent the hotel's former grandeur.
"With the Grand Hotel's great tradition, it is essential for us to retain its grandeur, even though we need to face new challenges in running it," Huang said.

He said the hotel has contributed significantly over the past six decades in improving Taiwan's international image, cementing relations with other countries and nurturing talent in tourism for the country.

Built to a Chinese architectural design with curving tiled roofs and red pillars, the hotel was built to impress foreign diplomats and the like in the absence of any five-star accommodations in the capital at that time.
Situated on a hill overlooking Taipei City, the hotel is seen as an exemplar of modern Chinese architecture and iconography.

DOC.HEADLINE: Taiwan to help manufacturers expand sales to emerging markets
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, April 23 (CNA) 04/23/10 16:23:57 (By Lee Ming-chung and Elizabeth Hsu)

TEXT.P: The Ministry of Economic Affairs (MOEA) has prepared a plan under which nearly NT$5.5 billion (US$175 million) will be spent assisting local factories in making high-quality, reasonably priced consumer products for sales to emerging markets, a trade official said Friday.

The ministry briefed the Executive Yuan about the plan at a weekly meeting a day earlier, saying that the plan was initiated as part of an effort to explore the vast middle-class markets in emerging countries such as China, India and Indonesia.

The rise of middle-class consumers in these emerging markets has stirred up a trend of consumption of premium and easily affordable products in the post- financial storm era, said Bureau of Foreign Trade chief secretary Chiang Wen- juo.
She pointed out that in the first three months of this year, "our general exports grew by 52.2 percent on average, but exports to most emerging countries showed a rise of over 60 percent."
"This shows that demand is very high in these countries, " Chiang said in an interview with Radio Taiwan International.

The official explained that the middle class in emerging countries is now a group of strong consumers who, although unable to afford such high-priced products that some European and American customers can, nevertheless desire consumer items that give the impression of luxury but at more modest prices.
Premier Wu Den-yih said in Thursday's Cabinet meeting that emerging economic entities have become an important power that is pushing global economic growth.

As an export-reliant country, Taiwan should target these markets in efforts to boost overseas sales with its premium yet fairly priced information communication products, he said after the MOEA briefing.

Under the three-year plan, budget will be allocated to help local businesses create 40 innovative products that are internationally competitive in terms of quality and price, establishing five new international or regional brands and increasing Taiwan's exports to emerging countries by 30 percent before the end of 2012, according to the MOEA.

Efforts will also be made to promote Taiwan's high-quality consumer products overseas through strategies that include building an international online shopping mall, organizing trade fairs in emerging markets including China, India and Vietnam, and opening special zones at various business exhibitions held in Taipei to allow foreign buyers to get in touch with Taiwan's creative products, the ministry said.

DOC.HEADLINE: U.S. dollar up on Taipei Forex
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, April 23 (CNA) 04/23/10 16:26:35 (By Olivia Wang)

TEXT.P: The U.S. dollar gained ground against the New Taiwan dollar on the Taipei Foreign Exchange Friday, rising NT$0.062 to close at NT$31.460.
A total of US$655 million changed hands during the trading session.
The U.S. dollar opened at NT$31.398 and fluctuated between NT$31.325 and NT$31.460.

DOC.HEADLINE: Commercial Times: About the debate on trade pact with China
DOC.DATELINE: 04/23/10 17:22:43 (By Maubo Chang)

TEXT.P: President Ma Ying-jeou is set to debate with opposition Democratic Progressive Party Chairperson Tsai Ing-wen on Taiwan's proposed economic cooperation framework agreement (ECFA) with China on Sunday.
We hope their discussion will be based on substance rather than ideology.

The first point that should be made clear is that this pact is nothing unique to Taiwan and China. It is an agreement designed by the World Trade Organization (WTO) as a transitional step toward a free trade pact. China inked such a pact with ASEAN in 2003 before moving on to a free trade agreement in 2010.

WTO members sign ECFAs to eliminate barriers between them. Anyone who claims that Taiwan is downgrading itself by choosing an ECFA with China instead of a free trade agreement is misleading the public.

As a member of the WTO, Taiwan should follow the organization's rules in making such deals -- not only with China, but with all members. Any debate on whether Taiwan should strike such a deal with China is totally pointless.

Then we have to ask: Is there any option other than ECFA to wipe out the trade barriers between Taiwan and China? The answer is "no." Taiwan has only been reaching out to China for two years, and therefore it is impossible to sign a free trade agreement immediately.

Although the elimination of trade barriers will bring benefits to both sides in the long term, in the meantime the transformation will help industries that benefit from competition and undermine those which aren't competitive.
So the only issues worth debating are which industries will be negatively and positively affected by an ECFA, to what extent they will be influenced, and whether the gains will outweigh the losses.
We hope the two debaters will focus on these points and inform the public of the pros and cons of the deal. (April 23, 20100)

DOC.HEADLINE: Presidential Office rebuts DPP head's accusation
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, April 23 (CNA) 04/23/10 18:04:51 (By Lee Shu-hua and Elizabeth Hsu)

TEXT.P: President Ma Ying-jeou's spokesman rebutted Friday an accusation by opposition Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) Chairperson Tsai Ing-wen that the ruling Kuomintang (KMT) was the instigator of the latest brawl in the Legislative Yuan.
Lo Chih-chiang said the remarks appeared to clash with the image Tsai works to maintain of being a woman of integrity.

Lo made the comment in response to a report carried that day in the Liberty Times newspaper that cited Tasi as saying that the tension between the ruling and opposition parties was deliberately fomented by the KMT.

Amid the approach of a widely anticipated debate between Ma and Tsai slated for April 25 on the proposed economic cooperation framework agreement with China, "it is bad to deliberately stir up confrontation and conflict," Tsai was quoted as saying.

Lo noted that Tsai has a reputation for maintaining an image of being rational and honest, but appears now to be describing "herself as the victim of a crime she herself committed" -- a reference to the recent violent scuffles in the Legislative Yuan blamed by the KMT on the DPP.

The incident, which occurred April 21, ended with KMT Legislator Chao Li-yun, who had been presiding over a meeting to screen two controversial education bills that would pave the way for local universities to admit students from China, being taken to hospital after briefly fainting after the brawl broke out.
Ma later urged Tsai not to condone her party's disruption of legislative proceedings. Regrettably, Lo said, Tsai was unrepentant and in fact accused the KMT of being the side that started the fracas.

DOC.HEADLINE: Bill aimed at expediting trial of criminal cases passed
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, April 23 (CNA) 04/23/10 18:17:53 (By Maubo Chang)

TEXT.P: A bill aimed at expediting the prosecution of criminal cases passed the Legislative Yuan Friday, a measure legislators hope will prevent trials and appeals from dragging on for more than a decade as occurs at present.

Legislator Hsieh Kuo-liang, convener of the Judiciary and Organic Laws and Statutes Committee, said he hoped the new statute would prevent the Supreme Court from repeatedly remanding cases back to lower courts because of indecision or minor flaws or stop prosecutors from filing endless appeals of not guilty verdicts.

The new law, which was passed with the support of both the ruling and opposition parties, limits the period in which criminal cases -- including the initial trial and all subsequent re-trials or appeals -- must be resolved to eight years.
The impetus for the bill has been a number of cases in Taiwan that have lasted for a decade -- and even decades -- in some cases outlasting the criminals or defendants involved.

Under the new statute, if a case spends eight years in the courts without a final resolution, the defendant will be released if he or she was found not guilty in the most recent court ruling and be allowed to file for commutation of the sentence if found guilty at that point in the process.
By the same token, the defendant cannot be detained for more than eight years prior to a final conviction.

The new statute will also prohibit prosecutors from appealing a case if the defendant is found not guilty at both the district court and high court level, unless the ruling has serious technical flaws.
The law will become binding two years after it is promulgated by the president, to give the judiciary system time to prepare for it.
Judiciary Yuan official Lin Chun-yi said there are currently 30 defendants who have been detained for more than five years as their cases make their way through the court system.
He said the judiciary system will try to close their cases within the next two years before the new statute takes effect.

DOC.HEADLINE: No farm products on ECFA 'early harvest list': COA
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, April 23 (CNA) 04/23/10 19:01:09 (By Yang Su-ming and Y.L. Kao)

TEXT.P: To protect Taiwanese farmers, agricultural products from China will not be included in a planned cross-strait economic cooperation framework agreement's (ECFA) "early harvest list," a Council of Agriculture official (COA) said Friday.

Hsiau Dong-chong, deputy director-general of the COA's International Cooperation Division, said that at the second round of ECFA negotiations, which concluded April 1, China agreed not to demand further opening of Taiwan's market for Chinese agricultural products or to include its farm products on the "early harvest" list.
The "early harvest list" refers to goods and services that will enjoy lower or no tariffs if the ECFA is signed.

Taiwan has maintained bans on the importation of 830 agricultural products from China that were in effect when President Ma Ying-jeou took office on May 20, 2008, and will not reduce tariffs on the 1,415 agricultural items already allowed, Hsiao said.
She was responding to remarks by former National Policy Adviser Huang Yueh-sui that Taiwan's agriculture and fishery sectors could suffer a heavy blow if an ECFA is signed.
Hsiau added that at the first round of ECFA talks in Beijing on Jan. 26, Taiwan refused to discuss issues related to further opening Taiwan to Chinese agricultural products.
Costs are the main reason behind the government's decision to allow imports of some types of agricultural products, Hsiao said.

For example, Taiwan began allowing the importation of watermelon seeds from China in 1989 because local farmers didn't show interest in the product due to high production costs, Hsiao said. Statistics from 2007 show 7.97 hectares were devoted to the plants, a figure that decreased to 1.06 hectares in 2008. There was almost no production in 2009, she said.
However, Taiwan still bans the import of Chinese watermelons, she pointed out.

The opening to imports of Chinese Pu-erh tea leaves and garlic from China was due to the fact they are not produced locally, or because of high transport costs for imports from other countries, Hsiao added.

DOC.HEADLINE: Kaohsiung dry spell eases slightly
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, April 23 (CNA) 04/23/10 19:06:58 (By S. Y. Lin and Flor Wang)

TEXT.P: A dry spell that threatens Kaohsiung water supplies eased slightly as the area saw rains Friday morning.
However, government officials said the rainfall was far from enough to help reservoirs take in sufficient water to maintain a normal supply beyond June.

Wu Yueh-si, the deputy director-general of the Water Resources Agency, said that although the rain did not solve shortages, it helped provide some relief for daily water use. "We are still waiting for more precipitation to come," Wu said.

The rain started at around 6: 00 a.m. and fell mainly on the flatlands. As of 8: 00 a.m., it had rained the most in Gangshan City in Kaohsiung County, which saw 40 millimeters, local weathermen said. Kaohsiung City only received 3-4 mm and mountainous areas only saw a drizzle.
Taking advantage of the rainfall brought about by weather fronts that approached Taiwan, WRA personnel produced some 10 mm of artificial rain.

Meanwhile, the season's first crop of rice paddies benefited from the rainfall, Wu said. However, it had little effect on the Kaoping River, a major river in southern Taiwan's Kaohsiung and Pingtung counties.
"We took about 930,000 tons of water from the Kaoping River on Friday, " Wu said, adding that water supplies may only last several months.

No rain has fallen in parts of southern Taiwan since Typhoon Morakot lashed that part of the country last August. Spring rice planting in some areas of central and southern Taiwan has been suspended to save water.

DOC.HEADLINE: SEF chairman stresses urgency of cross-strait trade deal

TEXT.P: "Taiwan must not delay the signing of a mutual tariff concession agreement with China, as it is much easier to reach consensus on a limited list of items for tariffs reduction or exemption than to conclude a comprehensive economic cooperation pact," according to the chairman of the Straits Exchange Foundation (SEF).
In an interview with focustaiwan.tw, Chiang Pin-kung spoke of the urgency of Taiwan signing the proposed economic cooperation framework agreement (ECFA) with mainland China.
"Taiwan's move to negotiate and sign an ECFA with the mainland is, first of all, due to the current trend of fast-moving economic integration, " said Chiang.
He stressed the need for an export-oriented economy to ensure that Taiwan can compete on a fair footing in export markets and avoid being economically marginalized.

"To date, both sides of the Taiwan Strait have held two rounds of formal negotiations on the ECFA and have achieved consensus on matters such as the basic structure of clauses in the agreement and rules and positions pertaining to the 'early harvest list' of goods and services," he added.

Chiang, a former minister of economic affairs (1993-1996) , explained that the "early harvest list" will cover only about 500 items. It will not include products in sensitive sectors that may become vulnerable to competition when more tariff-free imports are allowed into the domestic market.
"The much misunderstood 'early harvest list' is designed to ease the impact of tariff concessions on domestic industries and allow time for the economy to adjust to a new trade policy,"he explained.

Over the years, Taiwan has opened its market to 8,612 products from the Chinese mainland, including 7,200 industrial items and 1,412 agricultural products. In the ECFA negotiations on the "early harvest list", Taiwan has insisted that only about 500 of the 1,378 industrial items still under import control will be listed for tariff concessions and that none of the 830 restricted Chinese agricultural items will be included, Chiang said.

Chiang forecast that Taiwan industries will benefit from cross-strait economic cooperation in areas such as investment protection, intellectual rights protection and tariff concessions, under the ECFA with China.

According to an SEF report, China was the largest market for Taiwan products in 2008, absorbing US$74 billion worth of exports at an average tariff rate of 9 percent. Meanwhile, Taiwan imported US$31.4 billion worth of goods from China in 2008 at an average tariff rate of 4 percent, the figures show.
Since the average import tariff rate in China was relatively higher, a cross- strait trade agreement that includes tariff concessions would be in Taiwan's favor, the report states.
Stressing the urgency of the ECFA, Chiang said it could lead to bilateral trade agreements with other Asian economies and that Taiwan may face fewer obstacles in its pursuit of such pacts.

"With the establishment of a free trade zone involving six members of the Association of Southeast Asian Nations (ASEAN) and mainland China on Jan. 1 this year, products are flowing within that zone tariff-free, which puts Taiwan at a disadvantage, " Chiang said.

The Global Trade Analysis Project (GTAP) 7.0 data base has forecast that with the formation of the ASEAN plus China tariff free zone, Taiwan may see a 0.176 percent drop in its gross domestic product, a 0.412 percent decline in exports and a 0.601 percent fall in imports.
As a matter of fact, since a free trade agreement between ASEAN and China took effect in 2005, Taiwan products in the China market have been lagging behind those of the 10 ASEAN member states.

In 2004, China imported US$64.7 billion worth of products from Taiwan, while imports from ASEAN amounted to US$62.9 billion. Last year, China's imports from Taiwan amounted to US$85.7 billion, while those from ASEAN totaled US$106.2 billion.

Statistics compiled by Taiwan and China's customs offices indicate that in 2009, China's import tariffs on Taiwan petrochemical products averaged 6.49 percent, on machinery 8.23 percent, and on automobiles and auto parts 14.92 percent.

Meanwhile, petrochemical products from the ASEAN countries were subject to an average 0.98 percent import tariffs at China's customs in 2009 and the rate has been reduced further to an average 0.25 percent this year.

China has also dropped the average tariff rate on machinery imports from the ASEAN countries from 2.08 percent in 2009 to 0.07 percent in 2010, and on automobiles and auto parts from 7.04 percent to 4.31 percent.

The Taiwan government is hoping that the ECFA will help Taiwan products to remain competitive in the Chinese market, according to Chiang. It is also pushing for the service sector to be included on the ECFA "early harvest list" so that it can maintain its competitive edge, he added.

The SEF chairman noted that Taiwan and China last year signed three memorandums of understanding (MOUs) on financial supervision, which allows banking, insurance, and securities and futures firms to conduct business in each others territory. However, there are issues related to a difference in market access thresholds, as defined by the World Trade Organization (WTO) , that need to be resolved, he added.

According to WTO regulations, Taiwan as a developed economy has lower market access threshold compared to developing economies, including China. But Chiang said the market access issue can also be resolved in the negotiation of the trade agreement between Taiwan and China.

Admitting that certain local industries would encounter unprecedented competition from Chinese products with the signing of the ECFA, Chiang said that the Taiwan government has worked out a series of remedial measures in line with WTO regulations in order to protect the vulnerable sectors.
These include anti-dumping duties, countervailing duties, compensatory duties, and subsidies to certain disadvantaged sectors, he added.

While the government has been trying to find ways for Taiwan's industries to maintain their competitiveness, discussions by politicians, in the media, and in various economic sectors reflect the general concerns that persist over the negative impact of the proposed ECFA.
But Chiang thinks that some of the arguments are colored by ideological orientations.

"It is possible that there is some confusion over 'technical terms' such as 'early harvest list', but regrettably some of the negative responses to the proposed trade pact are spurred by ideologically oriented arguments," Chiang said.
by Lillian Lin, CNA Staff Writer

DOC.HEADLINE: Green camp files new ECFA referendum petition
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, April 23 (CNA) 04/23/10 19:59:43 (By Wen Kuei-hsiang, Chiachen Hsieh and Y.F. Low)

TEXT.P: Taiwan's pro-independence camp filed a new petition Friday for a referendum on the proposed economic cooperation framework agreement (ECFA) with China, eight months after their previous bid was rejected.
The latest petition, initiated by the Taiwan Solidarity Union (TSU) and other groups, was submitted to the Central Election Commission (CEC) with signatures of 110,000 supporters.
TSU officials said in a news conference earlier in the day that a second-phase signature drive will be launched next week, with the goal of collecting 1 million signatures.
Former President Lee Teng-hui, the TSU's spiritual leader, set the goal even higher at 2 million signatures.

Lee argued that the ECFA would be disastrous for Taiwan because it is not an agreement between sovereign states, but one that is similar to the Closer Economic Partnership Arrangement between China and the special administrative regions of Hong Kong and Macau.
According to Lee, the ECFA is part of China's plot to annex Taiwan under the pretense of economic cooperation.
Taiwanese people should be given a say on the ECFA issue so that they can decide their own fate, he added.

Meanwhile, Su Jia-chuan, secretary-general of the opposition Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) , threatened to launch extensive protests against the administration of President Ma Ying-jeou if it again blocks the referendum bid and insists on going ahead with its plan to sign the agreement with China in June.

The previous initiative for a referendum on the ECFA was filed by the DPP in July last year, with the proposed question: "Do you agree that the government should hold a referendum to allow the people to decide on the signing of a Taiwan-China ECFA?"

The initiative, however, was rejected by the Cabinet's Referendum Screening Committee one month later. The committee said it was based on a hypothetical situation and did not meet the criteria of the Referendum Law.
In the latest petition, the proposed question has been rephrased to: "Do you agree with the government's plan to sign an ECFA with China?"
Upon receiving the TSU's referendum petition, CEC Spokesman Teng Tien-yu said the CEC will meet May 4 to determine if the new proposal meets legal requirements.

Under the Referendum Law, a referendum proposal must pass two thresholds to be accepted. In the initial stage, signatures from 0.5 percent, or 86,608, of the 17,321,622 eligible voters in the last presidential election must be collected.

If a referendum screening committee finds that the proposed referendum conforms to legal guidelines, the referendum's initiators then need to collect signatures from 5 percent, or 866,081 eligible voters, for the question to be put to referendum.

DOC.HEADLINE: MOI promises to address shortage of social workers in Taiwan
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, April 23 (CNA) 04/23/10 20:07:04 (By Hsieh Chia-cheng and Lee Ming-tsung and Lilian Wu)

TEXT.P: The Ministry of the Interior (MOI) plans to subsidize the hiring of more social workers by local governments after controversy over a recent mother and daughter murder-suicide brought to light the severe shortage of such workers in Taiwan.

The MOI said Friday that there are currently 1,688 social workers on government payrolls, far from the number needed, and before their ranks can be replenished, the ministry will continue to provide subsidies to help local governments recruit new people.

Local governments are responsible for hiring social workers, but because many of them are currently facing serious financial constraints, they cannot afford to hire more people to meet actual needs, causing the quality of social services to suffer, the ministry noted.
That decline in quality and the difficulties social workers face gained public exposure recently when a mother killed herself and her daughter despite the daughter's attempt to seek assistance.

Social workers generally were blamed for the tragedy, but amid mounting criticism, more than 100 social workers mobilized by a group trying to form a union staged protests outside the MOI and the Executive Yuan Friday.

The group complained that the government "took the lead" in blaming them for the incident by describing them as not being proactive enough, lacking experience, showing poor judgment, and acting negligently.

The protesters countered that the government was unaware of the inadequacies and flaws in its policies and demanded that a long-term and stable hiring system for social workers be established as soon as possible.

The MOI said that to strengthen the ranks of social workers at the local government level, the central government has subsidized the hiring of an additional 320 social workers to protect children and teenagers and 190 social workers to attend to domestic violence and sexual offense cases since 2006.

Since 2008, it has used part of the proceeds from the public welfare lottery to help local governments increase their staffing of social workers to strengthen services for children, teenagers, women, the elderly and the physically and mentally challenged, the MOI said.

DOC.HEADLINE: KMT unveils four likely nominees for municipal elections
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, April 23 (CNA) 04/23/10 20:12:03 (By Lee Su-hua and Y.L. Kao)

TEXT.P: Taipei Mayor Hau Lung-bin, Vice Premier Eric Liluan Chu, Taichung Mayor Jason Hu and Legislator Huang Chao-shun are likely Kuomintang (KMT) candidates for year- end special municipality elections, a KMT official told reporters in Taipei Friday.

KMT Secretary-General King Pu-tsung also said that the nominee for the Tainan special municipality -- a merger of Tainan City and Tainan County -- will be finalized after the KMT confirms results of a second public opinion poll.
Former KMT legislators Lee Chuan-chiao and Kuo Tien-tsai were neck-and-neck in the first poll, he said.

The nominations -- Hau for Taipei City mayor, Chu for Xinbei City (an upgraded Taipei County) , Hu for the expanded Taichung City (a merger of Taichung City and Taichung County) and Huang for Greater Kaohsiung (a merger of Kaohsiung City and Kaohsiung County) -- will be passed on to a KMT task force charged with consulting candidates.
The final nomination list will be decided by May 19 at the latest, a KMT source disclosed.

According to the KMT's nomination procedure, the candidates will be screened by the task force and a nomination review committee before being submitted to the KMT Central Standing Committee for final approval.

DOC.HEADLINE: President prepares for TV debate with DPP chairperson
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, April 23 (CNA) 04/23/10 20:24:45 (By Lee Shu-hua and Fanny Liu)

TEXT.P: Over the past few days, President Ma Ying-jeou has been in sessions with teams of advisors, led by Vice President Vincent Shaw, in preparation for a debate Sunday with the leader of the opposition Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) , a presidential aide said Friday.
A group of experts drawn from various fields and a debate prep team have been working with the president to get him ready for the live TV debate with Tsai Ing-wen, the aide said.
The experts, from the government, business and academic sectors, have been serving as a large database, providing the president with statistics, documentation and arguments, according to the aide.

The debate team, which comprises Presidential Office spokesman Lo Chih-chiang, former presidential spokesman Wang Yu-chi, Kuomintang spokesman Su Jun-pin, young scholars, financial scholars and civil servants, has been helping Ma to prepare his statements and arguments based on the information provided by the team of experts, the aide said.
Using military analogy, the aide said the group of experts is like a policy ammunition depot, while the debate team is like a simulation exercise command.

According to Presidential Office spokesman Lo, Tsai is not responsible for the formulation or implementation of policy so she could change her arguments whenever she wants, but Ma may have less flexibility because he has to be consistent.

"Even if President Ma does not gain the upper hand in terms of debating skills, strategies or presentation, he has to convey his views with clarity and show that he has command of the subject, " Lo said.

Su said that Ma will frankly state the pros and cons of the proposed economic cooperation framework agreement (ECFA) with China and will also make concrete proposals for dealing with the adverse effects of the trade pact.
The debate will be broadcast live on Taiwan Public Television Service (Channel 13) from 2:00 p.m. Sunday.

DOC.HEADLINE: Holland envoy plans to make Taiwan his home after retirement
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, April 23 (CNA) 04/23/10 20:38:52 (By Chang Jung-hsiang & Bear Lee)

TEXT.P: Holland's envoy to Taiwan, Menno Goedhart, said Friday that he and his wife have decided to make Taiwan their home after he retires.

At the launch of his new book "The Real Taiwan and the Dutch" at Fort Provintia in Tainan City, Goedhart said he and his wife will resettle in the southern township of Sinhua in Tainan County when his tenure as the Netherlands' top envoy to Taiwan ends later this year.

Over the past eight years, Goedhart has visited almost every corner of the Taiwan -- including some areas that are unfamiliar to many Taiwanese -- to trace the footprints of his ancestors who ruled Taiwan between 1524 and 1662.
During that period, some citizens of Holland married local aborigines, mostly from the Rukai tribe that is one the 10-odd recognized indigenous groups in Taiwan.

Goedhart, who has built a close friendship with the Rukai people, was given an "elder" title by the tribe in Shantimen township in Pingtung. He is one of two foreign citizens on whom the Rukai bestowed the title, the first being also a Hollander who was given the honor in the early 20th century.

Goedhart's book, published in Chinese and English, features many of Taiwan's most attractive destinations, including the counties of Hualien and Taitung in eastern Taiwan, the cities and counties of Tainan and Chiayi in the central part and the offshore Penghu County. It also focuses on the indigenous tribes around the country.

According to Goedhart, he plans to make his home in Tainan when he retires and to travel around Taiwan promoting his book. All proceeds from the book will to be donated to the victims of Typhoon Morakot which devastated parts of eastern and southern Taiwan last August, he added.
At the book launch, Tainan Mayor Hsu Tain-tsair dubbed Goedhart as "the Marco Polo of Taiwan, " citing the envoy's ambitious plan to sell Taiwan to the rest of the world.

Marco Polo was a Venetian merchant and adventurer who visited China in the 13th century and wrote a book called "Il Milione di Marco Polo, " which gave Europeans some of their earliest information about China.

DOC.HEADLINE: CNA News Budget for April 23

TEXT.P: social workers 9. Taiwan's telecom association signs MOU with China's counterpart 10. Former Taipei mayor heads Grand Hotel 11. Taiwan to help manufacturers expand sale to emerging markets 12. Installation arts exhibition at Yunlin wetland opens

DOC.HEADLINE: Government helps 220,000 on unpaid leave return to jobs: premier
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, April 23 (CNA) 04/23/10 20:59:28 (By Lin Yi-feng and Lilian Wu)

TEXT.P: Premier Wu Den-yih said Friday that the government has helped reduce the jobless rate and allowed as many as 220,000 people on unpaid leave to return to their jobs over the past year.

The premier noted that the unemployment rate hit an all-time high of 6.13 percent in August 2009, the highest on record since the government began compiling unemployment statistics in 1978. The figure dropped to 5.64 percent last month.
The government is pushing for a "velvet revolution" to quickly drive down unemployment rates, he said.
Public efforts over the past year have reversed and changed many figures, the premier continued.

He cited the jobless rate in industrial zones as an example, saying that between February and March in 2009, there were nearly 230,000 on unpaid leave, but that the number has since dropped to less than 3,000, and would continue to drop.
In the science-based parks, the number on unpaid leaves peaked at 126,000, but now stands at under 100, he said.
The premier said earlier in the week that he will resign if Taiwan's unemployment rate remains above 5 percent by the end of this year.
He said Friday it would be "a daunting task, " although it would not be unreachable if everyone works toward it.

DOC.HEADLINE: Japan finally opens market to Taiwan-grown dragon fruit: COA
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, April 23 (CNA) 04/23/10 21:19:02 (By Yang Shu-min and Sofia Wu)

TEXT.P: Japan has decided to allow imports of Taiwan dragon fruit, after more than nine years of effort on Taiwan's part to gain access to that market, the Council of Agriculture (COA) announced Friday.

"The Japanese Ministry of Agriculture, Forestry and Fisheries issued an official notice April 16 on its decision to allow the entry of Taiwan-grown dragon fruit, " said Ko Wen-chun, a section chief at the COA's Bureau of Animal and Plant Health Inspection and Quarantine (BAPHIQ).

Over the past 10 years, Ko said, dragon fruit (Hylocereus undatus) has emerged as one of most popular fruit species in Taiwan. It is grown throughout the country on a total acreage of 800 hectares, with the central and southern parts of the country being the main areas of production.
An annual output is 15,158 tons and is valued about NT$420 million (US$13.38 million), Ko said.

Given Taiwan's outstanding breeding, cultivation and management technologies, its dragon fruit variety is superior to those grown in southeast Asian countries, in terms of color, taste and texture, he added.
"Our dragon fruit has great market potential, but it has to pass rigorous quarantine checks before it can be exported to Japan, " Ko said.
Because the Oriental fruit fly and melon fly are found in Taiwan, it has been difficult for Taiwan to obtain permission to export its dragon fruit, which hosts those pests, to Japan, Ko said.
In 2001, the quarantine bureau managed to develop a special dragon fruit disinfection technology and in 2003 developed a high-temperature steaming technology to kill fruit flies on dragon fruit.

"We then filed an application with Japan in 2004 for dragon fruit exports and finally passed Japan's stringent quarantine examinations this year, " Ko said, adding that shipments to Japan are expected to hit 100 tons in the first year.

Noting that the types of Taiwan-grown fruit exported to Japan has continued to expand in recent years, Ko said Taiwan now exports about 11,000 tons of fresh fruits to Japan annually, worth about NT$670 million. The different types of fruits include mangoes, grapes, papayas, mandarin orange, pomelo, lychees, bananas and pineapples.

Taiwan has also applied to Japan for permission to export star fruit, cantaloupe, guava, pears and Indian dates. However, Japan has not yet completed screening of those applications, he said, adding that the bureau is now developing disinfection technologies for bell fruit and pineapple-custard apple.

DOC.HEADLINE: Lu into semifinals of Athens ATP Challenger
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, April 23 (CNA) 04/23/10 21:59:48 (By H. C. Wu and Flor Wang)

TEXT.P: Lu Yen-hsun, Taiwan's top-ranked tennis player, advanced to the semifinals of the Status Athens Open Friday with a flawless 6-4, 6-1 victory over Japan's Yuichi Sugita.

The eighth-seeded Lu has yet to lose a set in his first three matches at the 85,000 euro ATP Challenger event and remained sharp against his Japanese quarterfinal opponent, winning the match without ever facing a break point.
Lu, ranked 102nd in the world, got in an uncharacteristically high 77 percent of first serves and broke Sugita four times to coast to victory in just over an hour.

He will now meet world No. 257 Gilles Muller of Luxembourg in Saturday's semifinals, as he pursues his first tournament title since winning another Challenger event (second-tier events on the men's tennis tour) in South Korea last November.

Lu reached a career best ranking of 55 last June, but it has since tumbled to around 100 because he has played more main ATP Tour events against the world's best players since the middle of last year, with mixed results.

Teamed with Rik de Voest of South Africa, the 26-year-old Taiwanese has also reached the semifinals of the doubles event in Athens, after defeating top seeds Leos Friedl and David Skoch of the Czech Republic 6-1, 6-0 on Thursday.

DOC.HEADLINE: French Institute in Taipei unveils new Web site version
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, April 23 (CNA) 04/23/10 22:17:35 (By Chris Wang)

TEXT.P: The French Institute in Taipei unveiled the new version of its official Web site in a ceremony Friday, hoping the new-and-improved portal will serve as a better channel of communication for its French and Taiwanese users.

Patrick Bonneville, director of the French representative office, introduced the new Web layout of www.fi-taipei.org, which showcases the streamlined content and Web design in Chinese and French versions.
"We hope that the new Web site will serve the needs of all users, including French nationals living in Taiwan or Taiwan nationals, " Bonneville said.

The new design allows users to find anything they are looking for on the Web site within three clicks, The content, divided into five major categories, is focused on bilateral exchanges between France and Taiwan and "the French perspective on global affairs, " said Patrick Mansier, chief officer of the Analysis and Information Services.

An RSS (Really Simple Syndication) service has been added to keep users posted about the latest news related the office and French-related news, Mansier said, adding that the Web site hopes to be more user-friendly by adding various services.
Alliance Francaise Taiwan, devoted to promoting French language and culture outside France, also announced the launch of its official Web site (www.alliancefrancaise.org.tw) at the ceremony.

DOC.HEADLINE: March industrial production reaches new high: MOEA
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, April 23 (CNA) 04/23/10 22:25:55 (By Fanny Liu)

TEXT.P: Taiwan's industrial production index reached a record high in March and grew at a double-digit clip for the fifth consecutive month, the Ministry of Economic Affairs (MOEA) reported Friday.
The index rose 39.2 percent year-on-year in March to a record 120.30. It also registered 47.1 percent annual growth in the first quarter, the MOEA said in a statement.
The MOEA attributed the continuing rise in industrial production to the global economy's steady recovery and growing cross-Taiwan Strait trade activity.
The improving economy was also reflected in the 42 percent rise in the manufacturing production index in March.

Among individual product categories, the production index for electronic parts and components increased by 77.3 percent, leading all categories, while the indexes for motor vehicles and parts, and machinery climbed 63.8 percent and 58.5 percent, respectively, according to MOEA figures.
The electronic parts and components production index also increased by 100.6 percent in the first quarter from the same period last year.
The robust growth received a major boost from the recent launches of products featuring new technology and the need to replenish parts inventories, the MOEA noted.

Because electronic industry inventories have remained low, recently, with some components in short supply, the production of semiconductors, flat panels and optoelectronic materials rose considerably to meet heavy demand, it added.

DOC.HEADLINE: KMT official pans DPP for politicizing ECFA issue
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, April 23 (CNA) 04/23/10 22:42:46 (By Lee Shu-hua and Y.L. Kao)

TEXT.P: A top Kuomintang official criticized the opposition Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) Friday for avoiding any mention of possible benefits that a proposed trade pact with China might bring to Taiwan, as a debate on the issue between the leaders of the two parties looms.
KMT Secretary-General King Pu-tsung accused the DPP for overly politicizing a planned economic cooperation framework agreement (ECFA) between Taiwan and China.

He said that in Sunday's debate on the ECFA between President Ma Ying-jeou, who doubles as the KMT's chairman, and DPP Chairwoman Tsai Ing-wen, Ma will explain how the government is trying to push the trade accord to give Taiwan a path of sustainable development.
On the other hand, the DPP's anti-ECFA proposals are aimed at pressuring Ma to step down, King argued.
The DPP should keep in mind that in a democracy, the minority must follow the majority, and the DPP should therefore work to seek more mainstream support, King said.

He also criticized Tsai for attempting to obfuscate the issue by using "political language, " saying that calling on DPP supporters to boycott the proposed trade accord is related to politics rather than to the policy.
While the KMT is taking the ECFA seriously as a policy issue for debate, it is regretful that Tsai, who usually acts rationally, is attempting to turn it into a political issue, King contended.

The upcoming debate between Ma and Tsai on the trade pact has already drawn media attention from around the world because in many countries, the head of state rarely participates in a debate with the opposition, according to King.

Because the trade pact will be beneficial to Taiwan and a critical element in its economic development in the coming decade, the president felt he has the responsibility to expound on the issue personally, King reiterated.

DOC.HEADLINE: Public urged not to travel to Thailand over fear of further clashes
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, April 23 (CNA) 04/23/10 22:53:30 (By Hsieh Chia-chen & Bear Lee)

TEXT.P: The Ministry of Foreign Affairs urged members of the public Friday to avoid traveling to Thailand as clashes between pro-government military and anti- government protesters could break out at any time.

The ministry meanwhile upgraded its travel alert to a "red" level for would-be travelers to the Thai capital of Bangkok and neighboring provinces of Nonthaburi, Samut Prakan, Nakhon Pathom, Pathum Thani and Ayutthaya. It maintained an "orange" alert for travelers planning to visit four provinces in southern Thailand.

A red alert -- the highest in Taiwan's four-tier travel advisory system -- advises that no one should visit the affected destination under any circumstances, while an "orange" alert advises would-be travelers to think of their personal safety when deciding whether to visit.
The ministry said it came to the decision based on a report on the situation issued by Taiwan's representative office in Thailand.

The Thai government has turned tougher against the "red-shirt" protesters -- mostly supporters of exiled Prime Minister Thaksin Shinawatra -- who have economically paralyzed Bangkok and neighboring areas with their six-week long demonstrations, the report said.

Adding to the political uncertainty is that groups of people -- be they are called "yellow-shirt, " "non-color" or "colorful" shirts -- are also taking to the streets, and the Thai military has asked the protesters to disband or face a second wave of "suppression," the report said.

A wire service report indicated, however, that the Thai army may have changed its strategy, with its commander-in-chief saying Friday that he does not plan to use force to quell the demonstrations, because military action would result in more disadvantages than advantages.
Twenty-one demonstrators were killed and some 800 injured in a failed attempt by the military on April 10 to disperse the protesters.

DOC.HEADLINE: Taiwan to respect high seas fishing ban
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, April 23 (CNA) 04/23/10 23:02:15 (By Yang Shu-min and Lilian Wu)

TEXT.P: The Fisheries Administration said Friday that it will respect the decision by a group of eight Pacific island countries to ban fishing in 4.5 million square kilometers of high seas in a bid to save rapidly depleting tuna stocks.

Officials from the group known as the Parties to the Nauru Agreement (PNA) , which controls areas responsible for a quarter of the world's tuna supply, agreed to extend the ban to new areas earlier in the day.

Huang Hung-yen, a section chief at the Fisheries Administration, said Taiwan's annual haul of tuna and similar fish in the Pacific is about 200,000 tons. The figure constitutes one-sixth of the country's total coastal, deep-sea and aquacultural fishing haul of 1.3 million tons.

Huang said there are already two high sea areas in the Pacific that prohibit fishing. In addition, large groups of fish often migrate into economic zones of the island nations, where Taiwan's vessels have to pay for fishing rights.
But if the vessels only fish in open sea areas, the fishing haul will be greatly reduced, he said.
"Taiwan will respect the decision by the Pacific island nations and operate in the areas with a spirit of cooperation and coordination as in the past, " he added.

DOC.HEADLINE: Scholars debate ECFA's pros and cons
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, April 23 (CNA) 04/23/10 23:25:03 (By Chris Wang)

TEXT.P: Scholars debated the possible benefits and disadvantages of a proposed cross- Taiwan Strait trade agreement at a seminar Friday in a possible preview of Sunday's showdown on the issue between President Ma Ying-jeou and the head of the main opposition party.

The seminar gathered university professors and researchers who both support and oppose the signing of an economic cooperation framework agreement (ECFA) between Taiwan and China, which Ma said he hopes to sign in June to prevent Taiwan from being economically marginalized in the region.
The 150-minute debate appeared to be a warm-up before Ma and opposition Democratic Progressive Party Chairwoman Tsai Ing-wen meet in a much-anticipated nationally televised debate on the ECFA.

If Taiwan does not take advantage of the China market, the world's biggest market, it will be hard to make up for the "lost decade, " said Daniel Liu, a senior researcher at the Chung-Hua Institution for Economic Research (CIER).
He was referring to the period between 2000-2010 during which Taiwan failed to participate in Asian economic integration, especially in East Asia.

Liu, who supports the trade pact, addressed at length objections raised by the opposition to the deal, such as the possible influx of cheap Chinese labor, its negative impact on agriculture and the pact's potential triggering of lower wages in Taiwan based on factor-price equalization theory.

The ECFA will be able to improve stability across the strait and be the starting point of the institutionalization of cross-strait relations, he said, arguing that the agreement "may not be the only way, but it will be an effective way to improve Taiwan's economy."

Wang To-far, a professor of economics at National Taipei University who opposes the ECFA, described it as China's first step toward enticing Taiwan to move toward an eventual "one-China market" and economic integration before reaching its ultimate goal of political integration.

Wang argued that the government had exaggerated the benefits of the deal without mentioning its possible adverse impact on employment and specific sectors, and voiced concerns that the excessive reliance of Taiwan's investment and exports on China's market would compromise the country's "economic sovereignty" in the future.
Lin Chu-chia, a professor of economics at National Chengchi University, was more concerned, however, about the political tone of the arguments on the issue.
"It seems to me that most people who support the agreement support it for economic reasons, and people who are against the pact oppose it for political reasons, " he said.

"As an economist, I think we have to be rational and we have a responsibility to tell the people what they're facing, " Lin said. "Unfortunately, the discussion of this important agreement hasn't been rational in Taiwan."

DOC.HEADLINE: Installation art on display at wetlands to deliver eco-lesson
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, April 23 (CNA) 04/23/10 23:35:09 (By Yang Shu-min and Sofia Wu)

TEXT.P: Five landscape sculptures created through an international environmental art project were formally put on display Friday at the Cheng Long wetlands in central-south Taiwan's Yunlin County to raise the public's environmental awareness.

All five installation sculptures were created by artists from home and abroad with natural materials available from the wetlands, said Lin Hua-ching, an ecological habitat management specialist with the Taiwan Forestry Bureau under the Council of Agriculture.
In the process, Lin said, local children and residents have been invited to work together with domestic and foreign artists to find new possibilities for development of their homeland.
The 100-hectare Cheng Long wetland park was formed as a result of land subsidence due to long years of excessive extraction of groundwater, Lin said.
Owners of 41 hectares of the land agreed to join the international environmental art project organized by the Kuan Shu Educational Foundation with a subsidy from the forestry bureau, Lin said.
The project attracted submissions from 81 artists in 33 countries and five entries were finally selected to be installed at the park.
Wang Chao-mei, a Kuan Shu executive, said it was very interesting to see how concepts changed and were developed after the artists came to the wetlands and began their work.

One of the works was sketched by American artist Roy Staab, Wang said. He worked with local schoolchildren to make use of abundant oyster shells from the nearby village and created a sort of drawing in the water with shells placed on bamboo poles posted in the water.
"The artwork is interesting to view at different times of day and from different viewpoints," she said.
The works will be displayed until July 25, Wang said, and then will return to nature through weathering.
"We hope the exhibition will help local residents find a new path for community development in this sinking wetland," Wang said.

Over the past year, Wang said the foundation has also sponsored a series of ecological exploration programs attended by local schoolchildren and residents to help them better understand the importance of environmental protection.
The activities also included making wooden bird models to attract migrant birds to the wetlands and environmental cleanup.
"Our efforts have helped infuse new life into the wetland park, which now attracts at least 86 migrating bird species annually, " Wang added.

DOC.HEADLINE: U.S. dollar up on Taipei Forex
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, April 23 (CNA) 04/23/10 16:26:35 (By Olivia Wang)

TEXT.P: The U.S. dollar gained ground against the New Taiwan dollar on the Taipei Foreign Exchange Friday, rising NT$0.062 to close at NT$31.460.
A total of US$655 million changed hands during the trading session.
The U.S. dollar opened at NT$31.398 and fluctuated between NT$31.325 and NT$31.460.

DOC.HEADLINE: Commercial Times: About the debate on trade pact with China
DOC.DATELINE: 04/23/10 17:22:43 (By Maubo Chang)

TEXT.P: President Ma Ying-jeou is set to debate with opposition Democratic Progressive Party Chairperson Tsai Ing-wen on Taiwan's proposed economic cooperation framework agreement (ECFA) with China on Sunday.
We hope their discussion will be based on substance rather than ideology.

The first point that should be made clear is that this pact is nothing unique to Taiwan and China. It is an agreement designed by the World Trade Organization (WTO) as a transitional step toward a free trade pact. China inked such a pact with ASEAN in 2003 before moving on to a free trade agreement in 2010.

WTO members sign ECFAs to eliminate barriers between them. Anyone who claims that Taiwan is downgrading itself by choosing an ECFA with China instead of a free trade agreement is misleading the public.

As a member of the WTO, Taiwan should follow the organization's rules in making such deals -- not only with China, but with all members. Any debate on whether Taiwan should strike such a deal with China is totally pointless.

Then we have to ask: Is there any option other than ECFA to wipe out the trade barriers between Taiwan and China? The answer is "no." Taiwan has only been reaching out to China for two years, and therefore it is impossible to sign a free trade agreement immediately.

Although the elimination of trade barriers will bring benefits to both sides in the long term, in the meantime the transformation will help industries that benefit from competition and undermine those which aren't competitive.
So the only issues worth debating are which industries will be negatively and positively affected by an ECFA, to what extent they will be influenced, and whether the gains will outweigh the losses.
We hope the two debaters will focus on these points and inform the public of the pros and cons of the deal. (April 23, 20100)

DOC.HEADLINE: Presidential Office rebuts DPP head's accusation
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, April 23 (CNA) 04/23/10 18:04:51 (By Lee Shu-hua and Elizabeth Hsu)

TEXT.P: President Ma Ying-jeou's spokesman rebutted Friday an accusation by opposition Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) Chairperson Tsai Ing-wen that the ruling Kuomintang (KMT) was the instigator of the latest brawl in the Legislative Yuan.
Lo Chih-chiang said the remarks appeared to clash with the image Tsai works to maintain of being a woman of integrity.

Lo made the comment in response to a report carried that day in the Liberty Times newspaper that cited Tasi as saying that the tension between the ruling and opposition parties was deliberately fomented by the KMT.

Amid the approach of a widely anticipated debate between Ma and Tsai slated for April 25 on the proposed economic cooperation framework agreement with China, "it is bad to deliberately stir up confrontation and conflict," Tsai was quoted as saying.

Lo noted that Tsai has a reputation for maintaining an image of being rational and honest, but appears now to be describing "herself as the victim of a crime she herself committed" -- a reference to the recent violent scuffles in the Legislative Yuan blamed by the KMT on the DPP.

The incident, which occurred April 21, ended with KMT Legislator Chao Li-yun, who had been presiding over a meeting to screen two controversial education bills that would pave the way for local universities to admit students from China, being taken to hospital after briefly fainting after the brawl broke out.
Ma later urged Tsai not to condone her party's disruption of legislative proceedings. Regrettably, Lo said, Tsai was unrepentant and in fact accused the KMT of being the side that started the fracas.

DOC.HEADLINE: Bill aimed at expediting trial of criminal cases passed
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, April 23 (CNA) 04/23/10 18:17:53 (By Maubo Chang)

TEXT.P: A bill aimed at expediting the prosecution of criminal cases passed the Legislative Yuan Friday, a measure legislators hope will prevent trials and appeals from dragging on for more than a decade as occurs at present.

Legislator Hsieh Kuo-liang, convener of the Judiciary and Organic Laws and Statutes Committee, said he hoped the new statute would prevent the Supreme Court from repeatedly remanding cases back to lower courts because of indecision or minor flaws or stop prosecutors from filing endless appeals of not guilty verdicts.

The new law, which was passed with the support of both the ruling and opposition parties, limits the period in which criminal cases -- including the initial trial and all subsequent re-trials or appeals -- must be resolved to eight years.
The impetus for the bill has been a number of cases in Taiwan that have lasted for a decade -- and even decades -- in some cases outlasting the criminals or defendants involved.

Under the new statute, if a case spends eight years in the courts without a final resolution, the defendant will be released if he or she was found not guilty in the most recent court ruling and be allowed to file for commutation of the sentence if found guilty at that point in the process.
By the same token, the defendant cannot be detained for more than eight years prior to a final conviction.

The new statute will also prohibit prosecutors from appealing a case if the defendant is found not guilty at both the district court and high court level, unless the ruling has serious technical flaws.
The law will become binding two years after it is promulgated by the president, to give the judiciary system time to prepare for it.
Judiciary Yuan official Lin Chun-yi said there are currently 30 defendants who have been detained for more than five years as their cases make their way through the court system.
He said the judiciary system will try to close their cases within the next two years before the new statute takes effect.

DOC.HEADLINE: No farm products on ECFA 'early harvest list': COA
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, April 23 (CNA) 04/23/10 19:01:09 (By Yang Su-ming and Y.L. Kao)

TEXT.P: To protect Taiwanese farmers, agricultural products from China will not be included in a planned cross-strait economic cooperation framework agreement's (ECFA) "early harvest list," a Council of Agriculture official (COA) said Friday.

Hsiau Dong-chong, deputy director-general of the COA's International Cooperation Division, said that at the second round of ECFA negotiations, which concluded April 1, China agreed not to demand further opening of Taiwan's market for Chinese agricultural products or to include its farm products on the "early harvest" list.
The "early harvest list" refers to goods and services that will enjoy lower or no tariffs if the ECFA is signed.

Taiwan has maintained bans on the importation of 830 agricultural products from China that were in effect when President Ma Ying-jeou took office on May 20, 2008, and will not reduce tariffs on the 1,415 agricultural items already allowed, Hsiao said.
She was responding to remarks by former National Policy Adviser Huang Yueh-sui that Taiwan's agriculture and fishery sectors could suffer a heavy blow if an ECFA is signed.
Hsiau added that at the first round of ECFA talks in Beijing on Jan. 26, Taiwan refused to discuss issues related to further opening Taiwan to Chinese agricultural products.
Costs are the main reason behind the government's decision to allow imports of some types of agricultural products, Hsiao said.

For example, Taiwan began allowing the importation of watermelon seeds from China in 1989 because local farmers didn't show interest in the product due to high production costs, Hsiao said. Statistics from 2007 show 7.97 hectares were devoted to the plants, a figure that decreased to 1.06 hectares in 2008. There was almost no production in 2009, she said.
However, Taiwan still bans the import of Chinese watermelons, she pointed out.

The opening to imports of Chinese Pu-erh tea leaves and garlic from China was due to the fact they are not produced locally, or because of high transport costs for imports from other countries, Hsiao added.

DOC.HEADLINE: Kaohsiung dry spell eases slightly
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, April 23 (CNA) 04/23/10 19:06:58 (By S. Y. Lin and Flor Wang)

TEXT.P: A dry spell that threatens Kaohsiung water supplies eased slightly as the area saw rains Friday morning.
However, government officials said the rainfall was far from enough to help reservoirs take in sufficient water to maintain a normal supply beyond June.

Wu Yueh-si, the deputy director-general of the Water Resources Agency, said that although the rain did not solve shortages, it helped provide some relief for daily water use. "We are still waiting for more precipitation to come," Wu said.

The rain started at around 6: 00 a.m. and fell mainly on the flatlands. As of 8: 00 a.m., it had rained the most in Gangshan City in Kaohsiung County, which saw 40 millimeters, local weathermen said. Kaohsiung City only received 3-4 mm and mountainous areas only saw a drizzle.
Taking advantage of the rainfall brought about by weather fronts that approached Taiwan, WRA personnel produced some 10 mm of artificial rain.

Meanwhile, the season's first crop of rice paddies benefited from the rainfall, Wu said. However, it had little effect on the Kaoping River, a major river in southern Taiwan's Kaohsiung and Pingtung counties.
"We took about 930,000 tons of water from the Kaoping River on Friday, " Wu said, adding that water supplies may only last several months.

No rain has fallen in parts of southern Taiwan since Typhoon Morakot lashed that part of the country last August. Spring rice planting in some areas of central and southern Taiwan has been suspended to save water.

DOC.HEADLINE: SEF chairman stresses urgency of cross-strait trade deal

TEXT.P: "Taiwan must not delay the signing of a mutual tariff concession agreement with China, as it is much easier to reach consensus on a limited list of items for tariffs reduction or exemption than to conclude a comprehensive economic cooperation pact," according to the chairman of the Straits Exchange Foundation (SEF).
In an interview with focustaiwan.tw, Chiang Pin-kung spoke of the urgency of Taiwan signing the proposed economic cooperation framework agreement (ECFA) with mainland China.
"Taiwan's move to negotiate and sign an ECFA with the mainland is, first of all, due to the current trend of fast-moving economic integration, " said Chiang.
He stressed the need for an export-oriented economy to ensure that Taiwan can compete on a fair footing in export markets and avoid being economically marginalized.

"To date, both sides of the Taiwan Strait have held two rounds of formal negotiations on the ECFA and have achieved consensus on matters such as the basic structure of clauses in the agreement and rules and positions pertaining to the 'early harvest list' of goods and services," he added.

Chiang, a former minister of economic affairs (1993-1996) , explained that the "early harvest list" will cover only about 500 items. It will not include products in sensitive sectors that may become vulnerable to competition when more tariff-free imports are allowed into the domestic market.
"The much misunderstood 'early harvest list' is designed to ease the impact of tariff concessions on domestic industries and allow time for the economy to adjust to a new trade policy,"he explained.

Over the years, Taiwan has opened its market to 8,612 products from the Chinese mainland, including 7,200 industrial items and 1,412 agricultural products. In the ECFA negotiations on the "early harvest list", Taiwan has insisted that only about 500 of the 1,378 industrial items still under import control will be listed for tariff concessions and that none of the 830 restricted Chinese agricultural items will be included, Chiang said.

Chiang forecast that Taiwan industries will benefit from cross-strait economic cooperation in areas such as investment protection, intellectual rights protection and tariff concessions, under the ECFA with China.

According to an SEF report, China was the largest market for Taiwan products in 2008, absorbing US$74 billion worth of exports at an average tariff rate of 9 percent. Meanwhile, Taiwan imported US$31.4 billion worth of goods from China in 2008 at an average tariff rate of 4 percent, the figures show.
Since the average import tariff rate in China was relatively higher, a cross- strait trade agreement that includes tariff concessions would be in Taiwan's favor, the report states.
Stressing the urgency of the ECFA, Chiang said it could lead to bilateral trade agreements with other Asian economies and that Taiwan may face fewer obstacles in its pursuit of such pacts.

"With the establishment of a free trade zone involving six members of the Association of Southeast Asian Nations (ASEAN) and mainland China on Jan. 1 this year, products are flowing within that zone tariff-free, which puts Taiwan at a disadvantage, " Chiang said.

The Global Trade Analysis Project (GTAP) 7.0 data base has forecast that with the formation of the ASEAN plus China tariff free zone, Taiwan may see a 0.176 percent drop in its gross domestic product, a 0.412 percent decline in exports and a 0.601 percent fall in imports.
As a matter of fact, since a free trade agreement between ASEAN and China took effect in 2005, Taiwan products in the China market have been lagging behind those of the 10 ASEAN member states.

In 2004, China imported US$64.7 billion worth of products from Taiwan, while imports from ASEAN amounted to US$62.9 billion. Last year, China's imports from Taiwan amounted to US$85.7 billion, while those from ASEAN totaled US$106.2 billion.

Statistics compiled by Taiwan and China's customs offices indicate that in 2009, China's import tariffs on Taiwan petrochemical products averaged 6.49 percent, on machinery 8.23 percent, and on automobiles and auto parts 14.92 percent.

Meanwhile, petrochemical products from the ASEAN countries were subject to an average 0.98 percent import tariffs at China's customs in 2009 and the rate has been reduced further to an average 0.25 percent this year.

China has also dropped the average tariff rate on machinery imports from the ASEAN countries from 2.08 percent in 2009 to 0.07 percent in 2010, and on automobiles and auto parts from 7.04 percent to 4.31 percent.

The Taiwan government is hoping that the ECFA will help Taiwan products to remain competitive in the Chinese market, according to Chiang. It is also pushing for the service sector to be included on the ECFA "early harvest list" so that it can maintain its competitive edge, he added.

The SEF chairman noted that Taiwan and China last year signed three memorandums of understanding (MOUs) on financial supervision, which allows banking, insurance, and securities and futures firms to conduct business in each others territory. However, there are issues related to a difference in market access thresholds, as defined by the World Trade Organization (WTO) , that need to be resolved, he added.

According to WTO regulations, Taiwan as a developed economy has lower market access threshold compared to developing economies, including China. But Chiang said the market access issue can also be resolved in the negotiation of the trade agreement between Taiwan and China.

Admitting that certain local industries would encounter unprecedented competition from Chinese products with the signing of the ECFA, Chiang said that the Taiwan government has worked out a series of remedial measures in line with WTO regulations in order to protect the vulnerable sectors.
These include anti-dumping duties, countervailing duties, compensatory duties, and subsidies to certain disadvantaged sectors, he added.

While the government has been trying to find ways for Taiwan's industries to maintain their competitiveness, discussions by politicians, in the media, and in various economic sectors reflect the general concerns that persist over the negative impact of the proposed ECFA.
But Chiang thinks that some of the arguments are colored by ideological orientations.

"It is possible that there is some confusion over 'technical terms' such as 'early harvest list', but regrettably some of the negative responses to the proposed trade pact are spurred by ideologically oriented arguments," Chiang said.
by Lillian Lin, CNA Staff Writer

DOC.HEADLINE: Green camp files new ECFA referendum petition
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, April 23 (CNA) 04/23/10 19:59:43 (By Wen Kuei-hsiang, Chiachen Hsieh and Y.F. Low)

TEXT.P: Taiwan's pro-independence camp filed a new petition Friday for a referendum on the proposed economic cooperation framework agreement (ECFA) with China, eight months after their previous bid was rejected.
The latest petition, initiated by the Taiwan Solidarity Union (TSU) and other groups, was submitted to the Central Election Commission (CEC) with signatures of 110,000 supporters.
TSU officials said in a news conference earlier in the day that a second-phase signature drive will be launched next week, with the goal of collecting 1 million signatures.
Former President Lee Teng-hui, the TSU's spiritual leader, set the goal even higher at 2 million signatures.

Lee argued that the ECFA would be disastrous for Taiwan because it is not an agreement between sovereign states, but one that is similar to the Closer Economic Partnership Arrangement between China and the special administrative regions of Hong Kong and Macau.
According to Lee, the ECFA is part of China's plot to annex Taiwan under the pretense of economic cooperation.
Taiwanese people should be given a say on the ECFA issue so that they can decide their own fate, he added.

Meanwhile, Su Jia-chuan, secretary-general of the opposition Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) , threatened to launch extensive protests against the administration of President Ma Ying-jeou if it again blocks the referendum bid and insists on going ahead with its plan to sign the agreement with China in June.

The previous initiative for a referendum on the ECFA was filed by the DPP in July last year, with the proposed question: "Do you agree that the government should hold a referendum to allow the people to decide on the signing of a Taiwan-China ECFA?"

The initiative, however, was rejected by the Cabinet's Referendum Screening Committee one month later. The committee said it was based on a hypothetical situation and did not meet the criteria of the Referendum Law.
In the latest petition, the proposed question has been rephrased to: "Do you agree with the government's plan to sign an ECFA with China?"
Upon receiving the TSU's referendum petition, CEC Spokesman Teng Tien-yu said the CEC will meet May 4 to determine if the new proposal meets legal requirements.

Under the Referendum Law, a referendum proposal must pass two thresholds to be accepted. In the initial stage, signatures from 0.5 percent, or 86,608, of the 17,321,622 eligible voters in the last presidential election must be collected.

If a referendum screening committee finds that the proposed referendum conforms to legal guidelines, the referendum's initiators then need to collect signatures from 5 percent, or 866,081 eligible voters, for the question to be put to referendum.

DOC.HEADLINE: MOI promises to address shortage of social workers in Taiwan
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, April 23 (CNA) 04/23/10 20:07:04 (By Hsieh Chia-cheng and Lee Ming-tsung and Lilian Wu)

TEXT.P: The Ministry of the Interior (MOI) plans to subsidize the hiring of more social workers by local governments after controversy over a recent mother and daughter murder-suicide brought to light the severe shortage of such workers in Taiwan.

The MOI said Friday that there are currently 1,688 social workers on government payrolls, far from the number needed, and before their ranks can be replenished, the ministry will continue to provide subsidies to help local governments recruit new people.

Local governments are responsible for hiring social workers, but because many of them are currently facing serious financial constraints, they cannot afford to hire more people to meet actual needs, causing the quality of social services to suffer, the ministry noted.
That decline in quality and the difficulties social workers face gained public exposure recently when a mother killed herself and her daughter despite the daughter's attempt to seek assistance.

Social workers generally were blamed for the tragedy, but amid mounting criticism, more than 100 social workers mobilized by a group trying to form a union staged protests outside the MOI and the Executive Yuan Friday.

The group complained that the government "took the lead" in blaming them for the incident by describing them as not being proactive enough, lacking experience, showing poor judgment, and acting negligently.

The protesters countered that the government was unaware of the inadequacies and flaws in its policies and demanded that a long-term and stable hiring system for social workers be established as soon as possible.

The MOI said that to strengthen the ranks of social workers at the local government level, the central government has subsidized the hiring of an additional 320 social workers to protect children and teenagers and 190 social workers to attend to domestic violence and sexual offense cases since 2006.

Since 2008, it has used part of the proceeds from the public welfare lottery to help local governments increase their staffing of social workers to strengthen services for children, teenagers, women, the elderly and the physically and mentally challenged, the MOI said.

DOC.HEADLINE: KMT unveils four likely nominees for municipal elections
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, April 23 (CNA) 04/23/10 20:12:03 (By Lee Su-hua and Y.L. Kao)

TEXT.P: Taipei Mayor Hau Lung-bin, Vice Premier Eric Liluan Chu, Taichung Mayor Jason Hu and Legislator Huang Chao-shun are likely Kuomintang (KMT) candidates for year- end special municipality elections, a KMT official told reporters in Taipei Friday.

KMT Secretary-General King Pu-tsung also said that the nominee for the Tainan special municipality -- a merger of Tainan City and Tainan County -- will be finalized after the KMT confirms results of a second public opinion poll.
