Former KMT legislators Lee Chuan-chiao and Kuo Tien-tsai were neck-and-neck in the first poll, he said.

The nominations -- Hau for Taipei City mayor, Chu for Xinbei City (an upgraded Taipei County) , Hu for the expanded Taichung City (a merger of Taichung City and Taichung County) and Huang for Greater Kaohsiung (a merger of Kaohsiung City and Kaohsiung County) -- will be passed on to a KMT task force charged with consulting candidates.
The final nomination list will be decided by May 19 at the latest, a KMT source disclosed.

According to the KMT's nomination procedure, the candidates will be screened by the task force and a nomination review committee before being submitted to the KMT Central Standing Committee for final approval.

DOC.HEADLINE: President prepares for TV debate with DPP chairperson
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, April 23 (CNA) 04/23/10 20:24:45 (By Lee Shu-hua and Fanny Liu)

TEXT.P: Over the past few days, President Ma Ying-jeou has been in sessions with teams of advisors, led by Vice President Vincent Shaw, in preparation for a debate Sunday with the leader of the opposition Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) , a presidential aide said Friday.
A group of experts drawn from various fields and a debate prep team have been working with the president to get him ready for the live TV debate with Tsai Ing-wen, the aide said.
The experts, from the government, business and academic sectors, have been serving as a large database, providing the president with statistics, documentation and arguments, according to the aide.

The debate team, which comprises Presidential Office spokesman Lo Chih-chiang, former presidential spokesman Wang Yu-chi, Kuomintang spokesman Su Jun-pin, young scholars, financial scholars and civil servants, has been helping Ma to prepare his statements and arguments based on the information provided by the team of experts, the aide said.
Using military analogy, the aide said the group of experts is like a policy ammunition depot, while the debate team is like a simulation exercise command.

According to Presidential Office spokesman Lo, Tsai is not responsible for the formulation or implementation of policy so she could change her arguments whenever she wants, but Ma may have less flexibility because he has to be consistent.

"Even if President Ma does not gain the upper hand in terms of debating skills, strategies or presentation, he has to convey his views with clarity and show that he has command of the subject, " Lo said.

Su said that Ma will frankly state the pros and cons of the proposed economic cooperation framework agreement (ECFA) with China and will also make concrete proposals for dealing with the adverse effects of the trade pact.
The debate will be broadcast live on Taiwan Public Television Service (Channel 13) from 2:00 p.m. Sunday.

DOC.HEADLINE: Holland envoy plans to make Taiwan his home after retirement
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, April 23 (CNA) 04/23/10 20:38:52 (By Chang Jung-hsiang & Bear Lee)

TEXT.P: Holland's envoy to Taiwan, Menno Goedhart, said Friday that he and his wife have decided to make Taiwan their home after he retires.

At the launch of his new book "The Real Taiwan and the Dutch" at Fort Provintia in Tainan City, Goedhart said he and his wife will resettle in the southern township of Sinhua in Tainan County when his tenure as the Netherlands' top envoy to Taiwan ends later this year.

Over the past eight years, Goedhart has visited almost every corner of the Taiwan -- including some areas that are unfamiliar to many Taiwanese -- to trace the footprints of his ancestors who ruled Taiwan between 1524 and 1662.
During that period, some citizens of Holland married local aborigines, mostly from the Rukai tribe that is one the 10-odd recognized indigenous groups in Taiwan.

Goedhart, who has built a close friendship with the Rukai people, was given an "elder" title by the tribe in Shantimen township in Pingtung. He is one of two foreign citizens on whom the Rukai bestowed the title, the first being also a Hollander who was given the honor in the early 20th century.

Goedhart's book, published in Chinese and English, features many of Taiwan's most attractive destinations, including the counties of Hualien and Taitung in eastern Taiwan, the cities and counties of Tainan and Chiayi in the central part and the offshore Penghu County. It also focuses on the indigenous tribes around the country.

According to Goedhart, he plans to make his home in Tainan when he retires and to travel around Taiwan promoting his book. All proceeds from the book will to be donated to the victims of Typhoon Morakot which devastated parts of eastern and southern Taiwan last August, he added.
At the book launch, Tainan Mayor Hsu Tain-tsair dubbed Goedhart as "the Marco Polo of Taiwan, " citing the envoy's ambitious plan to sell Taiwan to the rest of the world.

Marco Polo was a Venetian merchant and adventurer who visited China in the 13th century and wrote a book called "Il Milione di Marco Polo, " which gave Europeans some of their earliest information about China.

DOC.HEADLINE: CNA News Budget for April 23

TEXT.P: social workers 9. Taiwan's telecom association signs MOU with China's counterpart 10. Former Taipei mayor heads Grand Hotel 11. Taiwan to help manufacturers expand sale to emerging markets 12. Installation arts exhibition at Yunlin wetland opens

DOC.HEADLINE: Government helps 220,000 on unpaid leave return to jobs: premier
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, April 23 (CNA) 04/23/10 20:59:28 (By Lin Yi-feng and Lilian Wu)

TEXT.P: Premier Wu Den-yih said Friday that the government has helped reduce the jobless rate and allowed as many as 220,000 people on unpaid leave to return to their jobs over the past year.

The premier noted that the unemployment rate hit an all-time high of 6.13 percent in August 2009, the highest on record since the government began compiling unemployment statistics in 1978. The figure dropped to 5.64 percent last month.
The government is pushing for a "velvet revolution" to quickly drive down unemployment rates, he said.
Public efforts over the past year have reversed and changed many figures, the premier continued.

He cited the jobless rate in industrial zones as an example, saying that between February and March in 2009, there were nearly 230,000 on unpaid leave, but that the number has since dropped to less than 3,000, and would continue to drop.
In the science-based parks, the number on unpaid leaves peaked at 126,000, but now stands at under 100, he said.
The premier said earlier in the week that he will resign if Taiwan's unemployment rate remains above 5 percent by the end of this year.
He said Friday it would be "a daunting task, " although it would not be unreachable if everyone works toward it.

DOC.HEADLINE: Japan finally opens market to Taiwan-grown dragon fruit: COA
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, April 23 (CNA) 04/23/10 21:19:02 (By Yang Shu-min and Sofia Wu)

TEXT.P: Japan has decided to allow imports of Taiwan dragon fruit, after more than nine years of effort on Taiwan's part to gain access to that market, the Council of Agriculture (COA) announced Friday.

"The Japanese Ministry of Agriculture, Forestry and Fisheries issued an official notice April 16 on its decision to allow the entry of Taiwan-grown dragon fruit, " said Ko Wen-chun, a section chief at the COA's Bureau of Animal and Plant Health Inspection and Quarantine (BAPHIQ).

Over the past 10 years, Ko said, dragon fruit (Hylocereus undatus) has emerged as one of most popular fruit species in Taiwan. It is grown throughout the country on a total acreage of 800 hectares, with the central and southern parts of the country being the main areas of production.
An annual output is 15,158 tons and is valued about NT$420 million (US$13.38 million), Ko said.

Given Taiwan's outstanding breeding, cultivation and management technologies, its dragon fruit variety is superior to those grown in southeast Asian countries, in terms of color, taste and texture, he added.
"Our dragon fruit has great market potential, but it has to pass rigorous quarantine checks before it can be exported to Japan, " Ko said.
Because the Oriental fruit fly and melon fly are found in Taiwan, it has been difficult for Taiwan to obtain permission to export its dragon fruit, which hosts those pests, to Japan, Ko said.
In 2001, the quarantine bureau managed to develop a special dragon fruit disinfection technology and in 2003 developed a high-temperature steaming technology to kill fruit flies on dragon fruit.

"We then filed an application with Japan in 2004 for dragon fruit exports and finally passed Japan's stringent quarantine examinations this year, " Ko said, adding that shipments to Japan are expected to hit 100 tons in the first year.

Noting that the types of Taiwan-grown fruit exported to Japan has continued to expand in recent years, Ko said Taiwan now exports about 11,000 tons of fresh fruits to Japan annually, worth about NT$670 million. The different types of fruits include mangoes, grapes, papayas, mandarin orange, pomelo, lychees, bananas and pineapples.

Taiwan has also applied to Japan for permission to export star fruit, cantaloupe, guava, pears and Indian dates. However, Japan has not yet completed screening of those applications, he said, adding that the bureau is now developing disinfection technologies for bell fruit and pineapple-custard apple.

DOC.HEADLINE: Lu into semifinals of Athens ATP Challenger
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, April 23 (CNA) 04/23/10 21:59:48 (By H. C. Wu and Flor Wang)

TEXT.P: Lu Yen-hsun, Taiwan's top-ranked tennis player, advanced to the semifinals of the Status Athens Open Friday with a flawless 6-4, 6-1 victory over Japan's Yuichi Sugita.

The eighth-seeded Lu has yet to lose a set in his first three matches at the 85,000 euro ATP Challenger event and remained sharp against his Japanese quarterfinal opponent, winning the match without ever facing a break point.
Lu, ranked 102nd in the world, got in an uncharacteristically high 77 percent of first serves and broke Sugita four times to coast to victory in just over an hour.

He will now meet world No. 257 Gilles Muller of Luxembourg in Saturday's semifinals, as he pursues his first tournament title since winning another Challenger event (second-tier events on the men's tennis tour) in South Korea last November.

Lu reached a career best ranking of 55 last June, but it has since tumbled to around 100 because he has played more main ATP Tour events against the world's best players since the middle of last year, with mixed results.

Teamed with Rik de Voest of South Africa, the 26-year-old Taiwanese has also reached the semifinals of the doubles event in Athens, after defeating top seeds Leos Friedl and David Skoch of the Czech Republic 6-1, 6-0 on Thursday.

DOC.HEADLINE: French Institute in Taipei unveils new Web site version
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, April 23 (CNA) 04/23/10 22:17:35 (By Chris Wang)

TEXT.P: The French Institute in Taipei unveiled the new version of its official Web site in a ceremony Friday, hoping the new-and-improved portal will serve as a better channel of communication for its French and Taiwanese users.

Patrick Bonneville, director of the French representative office, introduced the new Web layout of www.fi-taipei.org, which showcases the streamlined content and Web design in Chinese and French versions.
"We hope that the new Web site will serve the needs of all users, including French nationals living in Taiwan or Taiwan nationals, " Bonneville said.

The new design allows users to find anything they are looking for on the Web site within three clicks, The content, divided into five major categories, is focused on bilateral exchanges between France and Taiwan and "the French perspective on global affairs, " said Patrick Mansier, chief officer of the Analysis and Information Services.

An RSS (Really Simple Syndication) service has been added to keep users posted about the latest news related the office and French-related news, Mansier said, adding that the Web site hopes to be more user-friendly by adding various services.
Alliance Francaise Taiwan, devoted to promoting French language and culture outside France, also announced the launch of its official Web site (www.alliancefrancaise.org.tw) at the ceremony.

DOC.HEADLINE: March industrial production reaches new high: MOEA
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, April 23 (CNA) 04/23/10 22:25:55 (By Fanny Liu)

TEXT.P: Taiwan's industrial production index reached a record high in March and grew at a double-digit clip for the fifth consecutive month, the Ministry of Economic Affairs (MOEA) reported Friday.
The index rose 39.2 percent year-on-year in March to a record 120.30. It also registered 47.1 percent annual growth in the first quarter, the MOEA said in a statement.
The MOEA attributed the continuing rise in industrial production to the global economy's steady recovery and growing cross-Taiwan Strait trade activity.
The improving economy was also reflected in the 42 percent rise in the manufacturing production index in March.

Among individual product categories, the production index for electronic parts and components increased by 77.3 percent, leading all categories, while the indexes for motor vehicles and parts, and machinery climbed 63.8 percent and 58.5 percent, respectively, according to MOEA figures.
The electronic parts and components production index also increased by 100.6 percent in the first quarter from the same period last year.
The robust growth received a major boost from the recent launches of products featuring new technology and the need to replenish parts inventories, the MOEA noted.

Because electronic industry inventories have remained low, recently, with some components in short supply, the production of semiconductors, flat panels and optoelectronic materials rose considerably to meet heavy demand, it added.

DOC.HEADLINE: KMT official pans DPP for politicizing ECFA issue
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, April 23 (CNA) 04/23/10 22:42:46 (By Lee Shu-hua and Y.L. Kao)

TEXT.P: A top Kuomintang official criticized the opposition Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) Friday for avoiding any mention of possible benefits that a proposed trade pact with China might bring to Taiwan, as a debate on the issue between the leaders of the two parties looms.
KMT Secretary-General King Pu-tsung accused the DPP for overly politicizing a planned economic cooperation framework agreement (ECFA) between Taiwan and China.

He said that in Sunday's debate on the ECFA between President Ma Ying-jeou, who doubles as the KMT's chairman, and DPP Chairwoman Tsai Ing-wen, Ma will explain how the government is trying to push the trade accord to give Taiwan a path of sustainable development.
On the other hand, the DPP's anti-ECFA proposals are aimed at pressuring Ma to step down, King argued.
The DPP should keep in mind that in a democracy, the minority must follow the majority, and the DPP should therefore work to seek more mainstream support, King said.

He also criticized Tsai for attempting to obfuscate the issue by using "political language, " saying that calling on DPP supporters to boycott the proposed trade accord is related to politics rather than to the policy.
While the KMT is taking the ECFA seriously as a policy issue for debate, it is regretful that Tsai, who usually acts rationally, is attempting to turn it into a political issue, King contended.

The upcoming debate between Ma and Tsai on the trade pact has already drawn media attention from around the world because in many countries, the head of state rarely participates in a debate with the opposition, according to King.

Because the trade pact will be beneficial to Taiwan and a critical element in its economic development in the coming decade, the president felt he has the responsibility to expound on the issue personally, King reiterated.

DOC.HEADLINE: Public urged not to travel to Thailand over fear of further clashes
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, April 23 (CNA) 04/23/10 22:53:30 (By Hsieh Chia-chen & Bear Lee)

TEXT.P: The Ministry of Foreign Affairs urged members of the public Friday to avoid traveling to Thailand as clashes between pro-government military and anti- government protesters could break out at any time.

The ministry meanwhile upgraded its travel alert to a "red" level for would-be travelers to the Thai capital of Bangkok and neighboring provinces of Nonthaburi, Samut Prakan, Nakhon Pathom, Pathum Thani and Ayutthaya. It maintained an "orange" alert for travelers planning to visit four provinces in southern Thailand.

A red alert -- the highest in Taiwan's four-tier travel advisory system -- advises that no one should visit the affected destination under any circumstances, while an "orange" alert advises would-be travelers to think of their personal safety when deciding whether to visit.
The ministry said it came to the decision based on a report on the situation issued by Taiwan's representative office in Thailand.

The Thai government has turned tougher against the "red-shirt" protesters -- mostly supporters of exiled Prime Minister Thaksin Shinawatra -- who have economically paralyzed Bangkok and neighboring areas with their six-week long demonstrations, the report said.

Adding to the political uncertainty is that groups of people -- be they are called "yellow-shirt, " "non-color" or "colorful" shirts -- are also taking to the streets, and the Thai military has asked the protesters to disband or face a second wave of "suppression," the report said.

A wire service report indicated, however, that the Thai army may have changed its strategy, with its commander-in-chief saying Friday that he does not plan to use force to quell the demonstrations, because military action would result in more disadvantages than advantages.
Twenty-one demonstrators were killed and some 800 injured in a failed attempt by the military on April 10 to disperse the protesters.

DOC.HEADLINE: Taiwan to respect high seas fishing ban
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, April 23 (CNA) 04/23/10 23:02:15 (By Yang Shu-min and Lilian Wu)

TEXT.P: The Fisheries Administration said Friday that it will respect the decision by a group of eight Pacific island countries to ban fishing in 4.5 million square kilometers of high seas in a bid to save rapidly depleting tuna stocks.

Officials from the group known as the Parties to the Nauru Agreement (PNA) , which controls areas responsible for a quarter of the world's tuna supply, agreed to extend the ban to new areas earlier in the day.

Huang Hung-yen, a section chief at the Fisheries Administration, said Taiwan's annual haul of tuna and similar fish in the Pacific is about 200,000 tons. The figure constitutes one-sixth of the country's total coastal, deep-sea and aquacultural fishing haul of 1.3 million tons.

Huang said there are already two high sea areas in the Pacific that prohibit fishing. In addition, large groups of fish often migrate into economic zones of the island nations, where Taiwan's vessels have to pay for fishing rights.
But if the vessels only fish in open sea areas, the fishing haul will be greatly reduced, he said.
"Taiwan will respect the decision by the Pacific island nations and operate in the areas with a spirit of cooperation and coordination as in the past, " he added.

DOC.HEADLINE: Scholars debate ECFA's pros and cons
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, April 23 (CNA) 04/23/10 23:25:03 (By Chris Wang)

TEXT.P: Scholars debated the possible benefits and disadvantages of a proposed cross- Taiwan Strait trade agreement at a seminar Friday in a possible preview of Sunday's showdown on the issue between President Ma Ying-jeou and the head of the main opposition party.

The seminar gathered university professors and researchers who both support and oppose the signing of an economic cooperation framework agreement (ECFA) between Taiwan and China, which Ma said he hopes to sign in June to prevent Taiwan from being economically marginalized in the region.
The 150-minute debate appeared to be a warm-up before Ma and opposition Democratic Progressive Party Chairwoman Tsai Ing-wen meet in a much-anticipated nationally televised debate on the ECFA.

If Taiwan does not take advantage of the China market, the world's biggest market, it will be hard to make up for the "lost decade, " said Daniel Liu, a senior researcher at the Chung-Hua Institution for Economic Research (CIER).
He was referring to the period between 2000-2010 during which Taiwan failed to participate in Asian economic integration, especially in East Asia.

Liu, who supports the trade pact, addressed at length objections raised by the opposition to the deal, such as the possible influx of cheap Chinese labor, its negative impact on agriculture and the pact's potential triggering of lower wages in Taiwan based on factor-price equalization theory.

The ECFA will be able to improve stability across the strait and be the starting point of the institutionalization of cross-strait relations, he said, arguing that the agreement "may not be the only way, but it will be an effective way to improve Taiwan's economy."

Wang To-far, a professor of economics at National Taipei University who opposes the ECFA, described it as China's first step toward enticing Taiwan to move toward an eventual "one-China market" and economic integration before reaching its ultimate goal of political integration.

Wang argued that the government had exaggerated the benefits of the deal without mentioning its possible adverse impact on employment and specific sectors, and voiced concerns that the excessive reliance of Taiwan's investment and exports on China's market would compromise the country's "economic sovereignty" in the future.
Lin Chu-chia, a professor of economics at National Chengchi University, was more concerned, however, about the political tone of the arguments on the issue.
"It seems to me that most people who support the agreement support it for economic reasons, and people who are against the pact oppose it for political reasons, " he said.

"As an economist, I think we have to be rational and we have a responsibility to tell the people what they're facing, " Lin said. "Unfortunately, the discussion of this important agreement hasn't been rational in Taiwan."

DOC.HEADLINE: Installation art on display at wetlands to deliver eco-lesson
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, April 23 (CNA) 04/23/10 23:35:09 (By Yang Shu-min and Sofia Wu)

TEXT.P: Five landscape sculptures created through an international environmental art project were formally put on display Friday at the Cheng Long wetlands in central-south Taiwan's Yunlin County to raise the public's environmental awareness.

All five installation sculptures were created by artists from home and abroad with natural materials available from the wetlands, said Lin Hua-ching, an ecological habitat management specialist with the Taiwan Forestry Bureau under the Council of Agriculture.
In the process, Lin said, local children and residents have been invited to work together with domestic and foreign artists to find new possibilities for development of their homeland.
The 100-hectare Cheng Long wetland park was formed as a result of land subsidence due to long years of excessive extraction of groundwater, Lin said.
Owners of 41 hectares of the land agreed to join the international environmental art project organized by the Kuan Shu Educational Foundation with a subsidy from the forestry bureau, Lin said.
The project attracted submissions from 81 artists in 33 countries and five entries were finally selected to be installed at the park.
Wang Chao-mei, a Kuan Shu executive, said it was very interesting to see how concepts changed and were developed after the artists came to the wetlands and began their work.

One of the works was sketched by American artist Roy Staab, Wang said. He worked with local schoolchildren to make use of abundant oyster shells from the nearby village and created a sort of drawing in the water with shells placed on bamboo poles posted in the water.
"The artwork is interesting to view at different times of day and from different viewpoints," she said.
The works will be displayed until July 25, Wang said, and then will return to nature through weathering.
"We hope the exhibition will help local residents find a new path for community development in this sinking wetland," Wang said.

Over the past year, Wang said the foundation has also sponsored a series of ecological exploration programs attended by local schoolchildren and residents to help them better understand the importance of environmental protection.
The activities also included making wooden bird models to attract migrant birds to the wetlands and environmental cleanup.
"Our efforts have helped infuse new life into the wetland park, which now attracts at least 86 migrating bird species annually, " Wang added.

DOC.HEADLINE: Chinese sparrow hawks fly over Kenting
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, April 23 (CNA) 04/24/10 00:02:40 (By T. H. Kuo and Flor Wang)

TEXT.P: Some 10,000 Chinese Goshawk (or Chinese sparrow hawk) passed over the Kenting area Thursday, allowing local and foreign visitors to gain a glance of the migratory birds as they fly northward after having wintered in the south.
Some Malaysian visitors shrieked in joy as they watched large flocks of the bird flying over the skies of Kenting -- a hot tourist destination in southern Taiwan.

The Chinese Goshawk breeds in Korea and southeast China, and winters in Indonesia and the Philippines, passing through the rest of Southeast Asia, including Taiwan. As many as 1000,000 and 200,000 sparrow hawks fly through the area in autumn.
"This was the first time in spring that large flocks of the birds were seen flying over the area, " Tsai I-jung, an official of the Kenting National Park Headquarters, said Friday.
"We now know that there are more Chinese Goshawk at the Lingshiao Pagoda within Sheding Park, which is the best vantage point in Kenting from which to watch the birds," Tsai said.
He explained that because it rained Friday in the Kaohsiung area, the flocks of Chinese Goshawk might fly to neighboring Pingtung County or Taitung County before they continue migrating north.

According to Tsai, local researchers have been unable to collect sufficient information to understand how many birds fly over Kenting on their way north during the spring, as they had seldom appeared in large numbers in Kenting during the season.
In contrast, researchers have collected a wealth of information about the bird when it flies over Kenting in autumn on its way southward to winter in some southeast Asian countries, he said.
The bird usually passes through Kenting before mid-September, with 20,000-30,000 potentially flying over Kenting in a single day.

DOC.HEADLINE: Today in history
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, April 24 (CNA) 04/24/10 10:41:56
DOC.TEXT:
Today is Saturday, April 24, 2010, or the 11th day of the third month of the Year of the Tiger according to the lunar calendar. Following is a list of important events that have occurred on this date in the past:
1731: Daniel Defoe, British journalist, novelist and economist, dies at the age of 71. His works include "Robinson Crusoe" and "Moll Flanders."
1800: The U.S. Congress votes to set up a congressional library.
1898: Spain declares war on the United States after receiving a U.S. ultimatum to pull out of Cuba.
1919: Chan Tien-yu, a railway pioneer in China, dies in Hankou at the age of 59.
1941: Hsieh Chin-yuan, a Chinese hero in the War of Resistance Against Japan, is assassinated at the age of 37. The ROC Army regimental commander led his "800 Brave Fighters" in a heroic battle against invading Japanese troops at a warehouse in Shanghai. Shanghai was captured by the Japanese on Nov. 11, 1937, after three months of fierce fighting.
1946: The ROC government postpones the convention of the National Assembly set for May 6, 1946.
1948: Lin Hsien-tang is appointed head of the Historical Research Commission of Taiwan Province.
1955: The Bandung Conference ends with five Asian states condemning colonialism by both the West and the Soviet Union.
1963: "Liang Shan-po and Chu Ying-tai," a movie directed by Lee Han-hsiang, premieres in Taipei and receives a warm welcome from a large audience.
1965: The Indonesian government formally takes control of all foreign companies in the country.
1967: Soviet cosmonaut Vladimir Komarov plunges to Earth and dies when parachute straps on his Soyuz craft get tangled.
1970: Vice Premier Chiang Ching-kuo arrives in New York for a visit and survives an assassination attempt in front of his hotel by a pro-Taiwan independence radical.
1970: Mainland China launches its first satellite, the Dong Fang Hong, into orbit.
1970: The Food and Fertilizer Technology Center of the Asian and Pacific Council is inaugurated in Taipei.
1974: A 16-member Orient Trade Mission of the U.S. Pacific Northwest International Trade Council, led by William Martin, president of the council, arrives in Taipei for a three-day business trip.
1975: Thousands of Vietnamese refugees are flown to Guam as communists move rapidly in their takeover of South Vietnam.
1976: The 1976 convention of 4-H Clubs opens in Taipei with more than 300 delegates taking part.
1981: A train encounters a landslide while on its way to Mt. Ali in Chiayi County, killing 10 passengers and injuring 19 others.
1986: Wallis Simpson, Duchess of Windsor, for whom a British king gave up his throne amid great controversy, dies in Paris at the age of 89.
1986: ROC Minister of Foreign Affairs Chu Fu-sung and Paraguayan Foreign Minister Carlos Augusto Saldivar sign an extradition treaty in Taipei on behalf of their respective governments.
1990: West and East Germany agree to set July 2 as the date for economic union, a prelude to full political unification.
1996: Russian President Boris Yeltsin meets with his mainland Chinese counterpart, Jiang Zemin, at the start of a visit to Beijing.
1997: The head of states of Russia, mainland China, Kazakhstan, Tajikistan and Kyrgyzstan sign a pact on troop reduction along the former Sino-Soviet border.
2000: The ROC National Assembly begins to fade into history after it downgrades itself to a virtual ceremonial organization without much power by passing a series of constitutional amendments during a third reading.
2001: Competition at the Second Asian Physics Olympiad kicks off in Taipei with 81 senior high school students from 12 countries participating.
Confucius' lesson of the day: "A wise and good man sometimes also meets with distress; but a fool, when in distress, becomes reckless."

DOC.HEADLINE: Taiwanese singing sensation returns from U.S. visit
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, April 24 (CNA) 04/24/10 12:27:41 (By Chiu Chun-chin and Y.F. Low)

TEXT.P: Taiwanese singing sensation Lin Yu-chun returned home early Saturday after concluding a high-profile visit to the United States during which he appeared on two popular talk shows.

Lin told reporters upon his arrival at the Taiwan Taoyuan International Airport that he was both happy and nervous about his TV debuts in the United States and was "flattered" by the courtesy he had received.
"The biggest gain of the visit was allowing more people to see Taiwan, " Lin said. "Many people greeted me by saying 'Hi, Taiwan boy!' when I walked on the streets."

The talent show contestant, who shot to fame when a video of him singing Whitney Houston's version of "I Will Always Love You" was posted on YouTube and received millions of views, said he will seek to sharpen his singing skills and improve his physical posture and strength to pave the way for his future career as a professional performer.
However, Lin said he does not have any plans to lose weight, adding that he was afraid people might not recognize him if he slimmed down.
Excited to be on the same flight with the celebrity, many passengers said they had had their photos taken with him while on the plane. There were also fans who greeted him at the airport lobby.
The main purpose of the U.S. visit, mainly in Los Angeles, was to perform and do interviews on the Ellen DeGeneres Show and Lopez Tonight.
Lin again impressed his audience when he sang "I Will Always Love You" on the Ellen DeGeneres Show.

The video showing him singing the song on a Taiwanese talent show "Million Star" went viral soon after it was posted on YouTube April 6, with immediate comparisons between Lin and British singing sensation Susan Boyle, who rose to stardom after auditioning for "Britain's Got Talent" last year.
Lin was also well-received on the Lopez Tonight show when he did a duet of Bonnie Tyler's "Total Eclipse of the Heart" with William Shatner of U.S. popular TV series Star Trek fame.
His performance of Houston's "Saving All My Love For You" on Lopez Tonight was also highly praised, with videos of his performances on the show widely shared on the Internet.
Sony Music Entertainment (Taiwan) has decided to sign a contract with Lin and release an album for him.

DOC.HEADLINE: Taiwan headline news
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, April 24 (CNA) 04/24/10 13:06:06

DOC.HEADLINE: Taiwan to donate US$1 million for Qinghai's post-quake reconstruction
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, April 24 (CNA) 04/24/10 13:48:33 (By Lee Ming-tsung and Lilian Wu)

TEXT.P: The Executive Yuan has decided to donate US$1 million to help with post-quake reconstruction in western China's Qinghai province.

The Executive Yuan on Friday decided that the post-quake operations in Qinghai have now moved from rescue to reconstruction, and the Executive Yuan would like to make the donation to help in the reconstruction effort.

Since a magnitude-7.1 temblor hit Yushu, Qinghai on April 14, killing more than 1,400 people and toppling homes, the government has several times expressed the wish to send rescue teams and to provide needed relief goods, the Executive Yuan said.
Taiwan's Red Cross Society has sent a medical team to Xining First People's Hospital, where quake victims of Yushu were sent, to provide medical care, shortly after the quake.

DOC.HEADLINE: Economic Daily News: New paradigm impossible in ECFA debate

TEXT.P: The upcoming debate between President Ma Ying-jeou and opposition Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) Chairperson Tsai Ing-wen originally stood a chance of building a new paradigm in Taiwan's democracy history. It is a pity that this has become impossible in reality.

Even before the debate on the proposed Taiwan-China economic cooperation framework agreement (ECFA) begins, the DPP has stated that regardless of its outcome, it will push for a demonstration and referendum against the trade pact. It appears that the DPP's sole purpose of taking part in the debate is to justify its further struggle against the Ma administration. In this case, is there still room for rational discussions?

The DPP has been manipulating the ECFA issue by accusing Ma of "leaning toward China and selling out Taiwan." However, can we deal with an issue that concerns Taiwan's future and survival in such a simple, emotional, populist, bellicose and ideological manner?

The debate should be more than just a debate and should allow for in-depth discussions on Taiwan's future and survival. Topics involved may include globalization, regional economic organizations and China's dominant status in the global manufacturing and global market. Others are the diminishing U.S. role in international affairs, a shift to "peaceful development" in China's Taiwan policy, and the collapse of the Taiwan independence course in the international context.
Only if Ma and Tsai bear these backdrops in mind would they be able to prevent the debate from becoming a superficial political struggle and find a way out for Taiwan. (April 24, 2010)

DOC.HEADLINE: Talk of the day -- Speedy criminal law

TEXT.P: The Legislative Yuan approved the Fair and Speedy Criminal Trials Act Friday, which will limit the prosecution of criminal cases in the courts to no more than eight years.

Also, in cases that have not been resolved after eight years, either the defendant will be freed if the most recent ruling was "not guilty" or be allowed to file for a commutation of the sentence if the most recent verdict was guilty.
The measure will take effect two years after being promulgated by President Ma Ying-jeou.

In a bid not to waste judicial resources, the law will also prohibit prosecutors from appealing a criminal case if a defendant is acquitted of the charges in both the district and high courts, or the case has been remanded to a lower court more than three times. This measure will take effect from September 1.
The following are excerpts of local media's coverage of the story:
The Liberty Times:
Supreme Court President Yang Yen-shou said Friday that the Supreme Court has started handling cases more quickly and estimates it could close about 4,500 cases in two years.

Presidential Office spokesman Lo Chih-chiang said President Ma Ying-jeou was glad to see that Taiwan's human rights have taken a big step forward and voiced hope that the judicial system could handle cases "adequately" and "rapidly."

The Ministry of Justice (MOJ) pointed out Friday that the law will strip prosecutors of their right to appeal. Although the ministry said it respects the Legislative Yuan's decision to pass the law, it worried that the law will also affect the right to appeal of those involved.

Some senior prosecutors ascribed Taiwan's much maligned lengthy trials to the Supreme Court, accusing it of frequently invalidating the rulings of lower courts simply based on minor technical details.
The Judicial Reform Foundation, however, was skeptical about the effectiveness of the impact of the new statute on judicial reform.
The law will not help lengthy cases be settled quickly unless the defendants plea guilty, said a spokesman for the association.
A lawyer contended that the law, without complementary measures, would more favorable to the defendants due to the time limit on trials. (April 24, 2010)
United Daily News:
The statute was established in line with international conventions and legislation by other countries to allow defendants to be treated and tried fairly.

Robert Tsao, the former UMC chairman who is still being pursued in court by prosecutors despite being found "not guilty" of illegally investing in China, said that while the law will impose greater restrictions on prosecutors, they still possess too much power.

Judicial Yuan President Lai In-jaw, however, hailed the law as a hallmark in the history of Taiwan's human rights. He urged the judges to accelerate the pace of handling cases based on the principle of "presumption of innocence" and "quick sentencing." (April 24, 2010)
China Times:

The Ministry of Justice (MOJ) expressed regret Friday over passage of the law that will restrict prosecutors' power to appeal. It asked the Judicial Yuan to swiftly come up with complementary measures to deal with widespread concern that the rights of victims could be hurt.

Civic groups advocating a judicial overhaul, meanwhile, contended that the law was only designed to clear up old cases while turning a blind eye to unworthy judges who ignore their official duties at the expense of the victims' human and appeal rights. (April 24, 2010)

DOC.HEADLINE: Taiwan's people conserved large amount of water last year
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, April 24 (CNA) 04/24/10 16:09:17 (By Lin Hui-chun and Lilian Wu)

TEXT.P: Taiwan's people consumed 271 kiloliters of water per person in 2009, three kiloliters less than the previous year, saving a larger amount of water compared to previous years, according to statistics released by the Water Resources Agency (WRA) Saturday.

The amount of water saved represented the best water conservation results over the past 19 years, the WRA said. Water consumption is calculated on water consumed at homes and in work places, or during commercial and leisure activities.
Water consumption by government agencies and schools last year was down by 2.4 percent from 2008, showing the government's campaign to conserve water has borne fruit, the WRA said.
Per capita water consumption in Taiwan surpassed 272 kiloliters a day in 1991, a time when Taiwan was experiencing rapid economic growth, and then grew by years to the peak of 291 kiloliter.
But due to a government policy to cut water use to under 250 kiloliters per people per day, water consumption has gradually decreased yearly.

This year, southern Taiwan is facing a drought. Taiwan Water Corp., announced earlier this week that water rationing might be imposed in the greater Tainan area by mid-June if the ongoing drought in the region persists.
With the specter of water rationing in southern Taiwan looming, the Ministry of Economic Affairs has provided preferential water fees to those who conserve water.

It is estimated that the amount of water conserved has surpassed 30 million tons in the first quarter, or one third of the effective accommodation of Nanhua Reservoir, a major reservoir in southern Taiwan.

DOC.HEADLINE: 'Chinese Taipei': Ex-Olympic head's controversial legacy

TEXT.P: The name "Chinese Taipei, " which allows Taiwan entry in many international events, is one of the most controversial achievements of late International Olympics Committee (IOC) head Juan Antonio Samaranch, who passed away Wednesday at the age of 89.

The former Spanish diplomat, who died of cardio-respiratory failure in Barcelona, Spain, was instrumental in devising the "Chinese Taipei" formula in 1981 that allowed Taiwan to participate in the Games, after the IOC decided in 1979 that China's Beijing Olympic Committee would become the "Chinese Olympic Committee."

"The clever technical arrangement by Samaranch made possible the co-existence of Taiwan and China in sporting competitions and set up Taiwan's return to the Olympics, " said Wu Ching-kuo, the only IOC member from Taiwan and chairman of the International Boxing Association, in a statement Thursday.

Taiwan first competed as Chinese Taipei under the Chinese Taipei Olympics Committee flag in the 1984 Summer Olympics in Los Angeles. Since then it has participated in almost all international sporting events and some international organizations under the name.
Huang Chih-hsiung, a ruling Kuomintang (KMT) legislator and silver medalist in taekwondo at the 2004 Athens Olympics, has said that Taiwan should keep politics out of sports.
But it's not always easy.

As China squeezes Taiwan's international maneuvering room, organizations increasingly refer to Taiwan as "Chinese Taipei, " including the Asia Pacific Economic Cooperation forum, the Organization for Economic Co-operation and Development, the International Monetary Fund, the World Bank and the World Health Organization, among others.
Taiwan has also been called "Chinese Taipei" at Lions Club International events, the Miss World and Miss Universe pageants, the World Baseball Classic and the Little League World Series.
Opposition Democratic Progressive Party Legislator Chai Trong-rong contends that the name "Chinese Taipei" sends an inaccurate message to the international community.
The name, he argues, suggests that Taiwan is happy and willing to accept the arrangement, which he compares to the status of "Hong Kong, China."

Samaranch's legacy has caused another problem: translating "Chinese Taipei" into Chinese. While China translated it as "Zhongguo Taipei," suggesting that Taiwan is a part of China, Taiwan translated it as "Zhonghua Taipei, " where the translation for "Chinese" refers to a cultural entity rather than a state.

Chinese President Hu Jintao first publicly referred to Taiwan as "Chinese Taipei" when he met then-KMT Chairman Wu Po-hsiung in May 2009. The unprecedented move signified important political implications in cross- Taiwan Strait relations, Beijing-based researcher Xiao Yongguo wrote in an analysis for China Review News agency.

Hu's remark implied the possibility of mutual non-denial between China and Taiwan and underlined a chance for Taiwan to participate in the international community under the name Chinese Taipei while handling domestic affairs under the ROC Constitution, he said.
Thus, the name "Chinese Taipei" has created a path for Taiwan and China to co- exist in the political arena, Xiao concluded.

IOC member Wu, who described his relationship with Samaranch as "like that of father and son, " said in the statement that the former diplomat left behind a lasting legacy as a mediator between China and Taiwan as well as between South Korea and North Korea.

But Samaranch was not seen by all as a friend of Taiwan, especially in 1995 when the southern city of Kaohsiung lost its bid to host the 2002 Asian Games to its bitter rival -- South Korean port city Busan.

At the time, local media reported that Samaranch interfered with the selection process -- which was changed from a secret ballot vote to a show of hands -- that led some Kaohsiung supporters to withdraw their backing in the final vote. By Chris Wang, CNA Staff Reporter

DOC.HEADLINE: Taiwan YWCA honors world YWCA president
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei April 24 (CNA) 04/24/10 17:10:41 (By Sunnie Chen)

TEXT.P: Susan Brennan, president of the World Young Women's Christian Association (World YWCA) was presented with a Lifetime Service award by the Taiwan YWCA Saturday while commending the local branch for its work with underprivileged female immigrants.

In Taiwan to celebrate "World YWCA Day" with over 200 local YWCA members at a breakfast meeting in Taipei, Brennan gave a talk on how women are creating a safe world and shared examples of the work of YWCAs around the world to end violence and bring peace, prosperity and security to society.

"On this day, we rejoice in the leadership of women in creating safe spaces: spaces which are free from violence and war, free from want and discrimination, spaces in which women and girls realize their full potential," she said.

Brennan also lauded the efforts of Taiwan's YWCA not only for helping female immigrants but also for touching countless lives through special activities and creating an opportunity for young women to participate in international affairs and events.

Brennan, in Taiwan for the second time, was elected president of the World YWCA in Nairobi, Kenya in 2007. The 40-year-old Australian is the youngest women ever and only the third woman from the Asia Pacific region to hold the office.
In painting her vision of "a safe world, " she said it included the personal, economic, political and environmental security of women and an unapologetic emphasis on women as agents of change.
"From the developing world, we have learned that a woman or girl reinvests 90 percent of her income in her family; a man reinvests 30-40 percent," Brennan said.

An extra year of primary school raises a girl's lifetime wages by 10-25 percent, an extra year of secondary school raises a girl's lifetime wages by 15-25 percent, and the children of educated women are healthier and more likely to be in school themselves, Brennan contended.
The YWCA president acknowledged that considerable progress had been made worldwide on women's human rights, but that more needed to be done.

Many countries have passed laws to prevent violence, and women have obtained greater levels of participation in political decision making, she said but violence and cultural attitudes toward violence and women's participation in education remained big problems.

When asked specifically about the current environment for women in Taiwan, Brennan told the Central News Agency that the current level of engagement with the government by women's organizations is a really positive development.

At the breakfast meeting, Brennan embraced a unique tradition practiced by the Taiwan YWCA branch -- ringing small bells at the end of a meeting to highlight their commitment and willingness to accept responsibility.
"It is a beautiful sound, so I got a bell to take home with me, and I will bring that custom with me and it will travel with me," she said.
Brennan, who arrived Saturday morning, will be in Taipei until April 27.

DOC.HEADLINE: Liberty Times: ECFA should pass debate and referendum tests

TEXT.P: The Taiwan Solidarity Union officially filed a petition for a referendum on the proposed Taiwan-China economic cooperation framework agreement (ECFA) Friday, two days before a debate is held on the issue between President Ma Ying-jeou and opposition Democratic Progressive Party Chairperson Tsai Ing-wen.
The widespread doubts and discontent in Taiwanese society toward the ECFA is exactly what Ma and Tsai must address in the debate.

Ma claimed that the agreement will be purely economic and that terminology concerning sovereignty and unification will not appear in the agreement. This aligns perfectly with China's obvious conspiracy to strip Taiwan of its sovereignty and government under the pretense of "putting aside differences" and "separating economics from politics."

Also, the Ma administration has failed to clear up concerns that China may continue to bar Taiwan's bids to sign free trade agreements with other countries even after the signing of the ECFA. More ridiculous still, the ECFA has been advertised in such a way that it appears as if it will only bring Taiwan benefits, but not disadvantages.
To this day, the vast majority of people still have no idea what the ECFA is all about, and even government officials have no knowledge of its details.

With the Ma administration continuing to lean toward China and the Legislative Yuan failing to fulfill its oversight duty, the public has lost its confidence in the government. Under these circumstances, the Taiwanese people have no other choice but to push for a referendum to express their voice directly. (April 24, 2010)

DOC.HEADLINE: In traditional world of Peking opera, diva embraces innovation

TEXT.P: Taiwan's Peking opera diva Wei Hai-ming loves to challenge herself by performing new creative works, and this year she will hold a vocal recital for the first time to showcase the extensive range of her talent.

"I've loved to sing since I was a kid, but the key factor in making my dream come true has been my training in recent years, which has made me believe that I can do it, " she told the Central News Agency recently.

The unprecedented concerts, to be held in Taichung, Taipei and Tainan on May 8, 16 and 29, respectively, will feature songs from the 1930s to the present, including three episodes called Fantasia, Nostalgia and Aria Variata.
Wei will share the stage with 12 musicians who either play Western musical instruments or Eastern instruments.
"I will present 20 songs that are adapted from different genres of Chinese music. Some of them will include elements of Peking opera songs," Wei said.
The Peking opera star will also go to Shanghai to perform her two favorite operas -- "The Story of the Golden Cangue" and "The Kingdom of Desire" -- at the World Expo in June, she said.

"The Story of the Golden Cangue" is an adaptation of a modern novel, while "The Kingdom of Desire" is a 1986 adaptation of Macbeth, with Wu Hsing-kuo, a traditionally trained performer, playing Macbeth and Wei as Lady Macbeth."
Wei is one of the most famous Chinese opera actresses of the Mei Lanfang school in Taiwan and China. In 1996, she received the Plum Flower Award, the highest honor for Peking opera actors.
"I love tradition, but beyond just following that path, I have always wanted to do more, " she said.
Because of that drive, she has collaborated with Wu to create new forms of theatrical expression such as "The Kingdom of Desire," which has received rave reviews.

She also cited the example of the play "Meng Xiaodong," presented earlier this year for the first time, in which she sang as a woman, an old man or a young man. Having trained for different roles in the past, she felt at that point in time that it was "time to try something different."

When Wei presented "The Kingdom of Desire" for the first time in China, some critics compared it to dropping a bomb in China's drama milieu, since actors there usually still strictly follow tradition.
But now, more people appreciate innovative performances, and the actress remains determined to constantly strive for improvement and give audiences something new.

"No matter how many times people see my performances, they can still see something different, something new, because I always try to refresh the role and reinterpret it," Wei said. By Sunnie Chen, CNA Staff Reporter

DOC.HEADLINE: Number of families in financial straits increases 55.4% in 2009
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, April 24 (CNA) 04/24/10 18:39:08 (By Elizabeth Hsu)

TEXT.P: The number of families receiving government assistance after meeting low-income criteria rose 55.4 percent in 2009, according to statistics released by the Ministry of the Interior (MOI) Saturday.

The big jump resulted mainly from an amendment to the Statute for Providing Aid to Families in Dire Straits in January 2009, which allows assistance to be granted to single-father and skipped-generation families, the MOI said in a statement.
A total of 18,776 households were defined as families in dire straits around Taiwan, with 1,202 led by men and the rest by women.

Of the male-led families, 59 percent were led by single divorced men, while 48 percent of the female-led families were run by women who were forced to raise children alone after their husband died, statistics showed.

Over two-fifths (41.81 percent) of the heads of households receiving financial assistance, or 7,850, were between the ages of 30 and 39, making it the age bracket with the most aid recipients under the program in 2009.
The second largest age group receiving aid were those in the 40-49 age bracket, with 5,619 people applying for government help, followed by the 20-29 age group, consisting of 3,957 people.

Under the revised law, families in "dire straits" are defined as those in which the average monthly income of each family member is less than 2.5 times the government-designated minimum cost of living for the year, and which suffer from extenuating circumstances, such as domestic violence or the absence of one of the parents.

Eligible households are entitled to various forms of aid, including emergency living aid, living allowances for children aged under 18 years of age, and subsidies for day care, education, health care, legal expenses, and business start-up loans.
The latest MOI statistics show that in 2009, the government distributed NT$491.3 million in different forms of aid to the families facing financial woes, 43 percent more than a year earlier.

DOC.HEADLINE: China Times: Remedies needed to fix financial crisis

TEXT.P: It is estimated that the government will lose at least NT$50 billion in tax revenue as a result of the recently passed Industrial Innovation Act, which will lower the corporate income tax rate to 17 percent and offer employment subsidies to small- and medium-sized enterprises and tax credits for R&D expenses.

We have four suggestions for President Ma Ying-jeou to fix the country's finances. First, Ma should state that he will not put forth further tax cut plans in the remainder of his term and in his possible second term, nor will he allow legislators from his Kuomintang to support any such plans.

Second, in the first quarter of 2011, his administration should calculate corporate income tax revenue for 2010 to see if the lower tax rate in fact increase revenues, as some interest groups have claimed. In the event of a decrease, the administration should seek to adjust the tax rate.
Third, the Ma administration should set a ceiling on the share of tax revenue to be distributed to Taipei City and four other special municipalities that will be created at the end of the year.

Fourth, Ma should request the Constitutional Court to issue an interpretation on Article 91 of the Budget Act, which requires that legislators consult the Executive Yuan and identify possible fiscal remedies when they initiate legislation that would significantly decrease the government's revenue.
To date, the article has not been observed, and Ma should ask the Constitutional Court to give him the power to review or adjust laws that have violated it. (April 24, 2010)

DOC.HEADLINE: Asia Physics Olympiad opens in Taipei
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, April 24 (CNA) 04/24/10 19:06:52 (By Lin Szu-yu and Lilian Wu)

TEXT.P: The 11th Asia Physics Olympiad (APhO) kicked off in Taipei Saturday, with 181 students and their teachers from 16 countries or regions participating.

Vice President Vincent Siew welcomed the young scientists from around Asia, saying that although not everyone will win the competition, they will get the rare experience of working as part of a team and make acquaintances with students from other countries.

Teams from Australia, Hong Kong, India, Indonesia, Israel, Kazakhstan, Kyrgyzstan, Macau, Malaysia, Mongolia, Singapore, Thailand, Sri Lanka, Turkmenistan, and Vietnam, along with host Taiwan, have entered the competition.
China is absent from the competition due to "political considerations, " said Lin Ming-juey, chairman of the Olympiad's organizing committee.
China had participated in all past Olympiads when the host was not Taiwan, which also held the competition in 2001.
Lin said that countries from Southeast Asian countries have in recent years dedicated themselves to scientific education, and China has also engaged in nurturing top scientific senior high schools.
Taiwan has entered two teams with a total of 16 students in this year's competition. They were chosen from more than 4,000 students around the country.

The youngest Taiwanese team member is Huang Hong-jui, a second-year student in a Taipei City junior high school. Inspired by his teacher to develop a passion for physics, he said he found it to be an interesting subject that helps you understand nature.
Taiwan won eight individual medals -- seven gold and one silver -- and a team silver at last year's APhO in Thailand.

DOC.HEADLINE: Taipei City to help owners of old houses renovate their buildings
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, April 24 (CNA) 04/24/10 20:03:06 (By Johnson Sun and Elizabeth Hsu)

TEXT.P: The Taipei City government will encourage the rebuilding of low-to-mid-rise residential buildings in the city that are 30 years old or above through financial and technical assistance programs, the city's Urban Redevelopment Office said in a statement Saturday.

The city hopes the campaign will restrain rising residential housing prices in the capital by increasing supply. There are 970,000 registered households in the city, but only 890,000 housing units, leaving a gap of 80,000 units, the office said.
Under the new plan, which will be launched on Aug. 1, old residential buildings of less than 10 stories will be torn down and rebuilt with more residential units than before, the statement said.

While the rebuilding of old houses is expected to add residential units, it could also "lower demand, " because some potential new buyers are individuals living in old apartments who are looking for an upgrade, the office said.

According to city figures, 30 percent of low-to-mid-rise residential buildings in Taipei City are more than 30 years old, and 80 percent (around 290,000 households) of the old units are in four- to five-story buildings that cannot be easily renovated without being torn down.
Based on an average of four people per household, 1.16 million people living in old buildings in Taipei could potentially benefit from the program, city officials said.

DOC.HEADLINE: Taiwan shines in Geneva innovations exhibition
DOC.DATELINE: Brussels, April 24 (CNA) 04/24/10 20:52:29 (By Y. F. Tsao and Flor Wang)

TEXT.P: Taiwan grabbed 28 gold, 21 silver and 10 bronze medals Friday at the 38th International Exhibition of Inventions of Geneva -- to lead the medals table at the annual high-profile event.
A total of 54 Taiwanese inventors showcased 63 cutting-edge items at this year's exhibition, ranging from small-sized devices to state-of-the-art electronic equipment.
Their performance was extensively covered by the media of many countries, and their gadgets drew considerable interest from potential commercial partners.

A team from the Technology and Science Institute of Northern Taiwan won three gold, six silver and four bronze medals. Their power-saving night light and a skylight that can improve air circulation and open up to give residents an escape route in an emergency both won gold medals.
The electricity-saving bulb, equipped with a smart chip, allows users to adjust its light by clapping and can save as much as 90 percent of the power of regular bulbs.
It is also equipped with a low frequency sleep inducer and a high frequency mosquito repeller to help users sleep soundly.
A multifunctional foldable bike displayed by a Taiwanese firm attracted a crowd for its ability to be converted into a shopping basket.

Another product that grabbed some of the limelight was an electric clothes dryer created by students from Kun Shan University. The machine can automatically switch off by using the exhaust temperature to determine when the clothes are dry, saving energy.

DOC.HEADLINE: Captain whose ship sank by Japanese boat launches new vessel
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, April 24 (CNA) 04/24/10 21:08:50 (By Wang Hung-kuo and Lilian Wu)

TEXT.P: The captain of a recreational fishing boat that sank after a collision with a Japanese patrol boat two years ago launched a new vessel Saturday that was partly paid for by the compensation he received from Japan.
Ho Hung-yi, accompanied by Taipei County Magistrate Chou Hsi-wei and Legislator Lee Ching-hua of the ruling Kuomintang, sailed out from a fishing harbor off northern Taiwan to celebrate his new ship.
On June 10, 2008, Ho's vessel, the Lienho, sank after it was rammed by a Japanese vessel near the disputed Tiaoyutai islands, which are claimed by Taiwan, China and Japan.
The 13 recreational fishermen and three crew members on board were rescued as the ship begin to sink, and they were later released, but Ho was held in detention.
Taipei County Magistrate Chou Hsi-wei helped make appeals to the Japanese government on Ho's behalf, and he demanded that Japan apologize and compensate the captain for his vessel.

Japan's representative office in Taiwan, the Interchange Association, later sent officials to visit Ho and deliver a letter of apology for the incident. They also expressed willingness to compensate him for his losses.
Ho was eventually given NT$10.5 million (US$333,330) in compensation and then borrowed about NT$8 million from his friends to buy the new boat.
The 49-ton vessel is 23.7 meters long and 4.84 meters wide, considerably larger than the 27-ton Lienho.
Ho expressed his appreciation for the support he has received since the incident occurred, saying it has given him the courage and opportunity to "sail the seas again."
But he said he would no longer be involved in recreational fishing, preferring to try his hand at squid fishing instead.

DOC.HEADLINE: Taiwan wins medals in world cheerleading championship
DOC.DATELINE: Washington, April 23 (CNA) 04/24/10 21:15:39 (By Jorge Liu and Elizabeth Hsu)

TEXT.P: Taiwan has won a silver and bronze medal at the 2010 International Cheer Union (ICU) World Championships taking place in Orlando, Florida, according to the head of the national team.

Chen Hsi-hung told the Central News Agency that the team grabbed the bronze medal in the coed premier division, the toughest challenge at the championships, and the silver medal in the partner stunt division.

Teams from 50 countries had applied to compete in the championships, taking place from April 22-26, but some European teams were forced to drop out after their travel plans were disrupted by the volcanic eruption over Iceland, according to Chen.
The United States won the gold medal in the coed premier division while Costa Rica took silver.
At the 2009 ICU world championships, Taiwan won a silver in the cheerdance freestyle division and a bronze in cheerdance jazz.

DOC.HEADLINE: University students form group to observe ECFA
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, April 24 (CNA) 04/24/10 21:26:49 (By Lee Shu-hua & Bear Lee)

TEXT.P: On the eve of a debate between President Ma Ying-jeou and opposition Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) Chairperson Tsai Ing-wen on a proposed cross-strait trade pact, students from local universities formed a group to "observe" the debate and the fate of the trade deal.

The group, consisting of students from National Taiwan University, National Normal University and Shih Chien University, said that both Ma, who doubles as the chairman of the ruling Kuomintang, and Tsai should give clear answers to three questions that have been of particular concern to them and the public.
The much anticipated televised debate on the economic cooperation framework agreement (ECFA) between Taiwan and China will take place Sunday at 2 p.m.
The two party heads should assess the impact that signing the ECFA will have on the local job market and offer solutions to any dislocations the pact might create, they urged.
Second, Ma and Tsai should clarify their positions on a proposed ECFA referendum, including reasons for and against the referendum initiative being launched by the opposition pan-green camp.

Third, the students hoped the debaters will explain how they would deal with the situation if China continues to prevent Taiwan from signing free trade agreements with other countries even if the ECFA is inked.

Group spokesman Chung Yi-ting said the students do not have a common view on the trade deal, with some seeing it as the right move for Taiwan while others considering it part of China's "united front operations" aimed at annexing Taiwan.

President Ma's administration has reiterated its hope to strike the deal by June to help Taiwan sharpen its competitiveness, but the DPP-led opposition has strongly opposed the pact, saying it might make Taiwan excessively dependent on China economically.

DOC.HEADLINE: MOEA promotes first MIT halls in Taiwan
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, April 24 (CNA) 04/24/10 21:35:38 (By Yang Shu-min and Lilian Wu)

TEXT.P: Minister of Economic Affairs Shih Yen-shiang said Saturday that the government wants to help local people do business and upgrade Taiwan's competitiveness, as he opened the first hall to sell certified made-in-Taiwan (MIT) products.

On the eve of a debate between President Ma Ying-jeou and opposition Democratic Progressive Party Chairwoman Tsai Ing-wen on the merits and disadvantages of a cross-strait trade pact, Shih took part in the inauguration of consulting group as well as the opening of an MIT hall in a hypermart operated by the Far Eastern Group in suburban Taipei.
Shih noted that the framework agreement will bring great benefits for Taiwan, but will also adversely impact some industries.

To help these industries upgrade their operations and remain competitive, 20 research and development institutes under the ministry have formed a consulting team to help local industries improve their competitiveness through R&D, design, production and marketing.
The group includes the Industrial Technology Research Institute and the Taiwan Textile Federation.
Shih also visited the first MIT hall and said that MIT products that are certified by the ministry represent safety and trustworthiness.
He said that a total of 4,400 items had been certified, and he hoped that the number could increase to 10,000 by the end of the year.
The economics minister bought a dozen socks and a jacket at the store and urged more local consumers to buy products with the MIT logo.
The MIT logo office said there will be five MIT halls by the end of this year.

DOC.HEADLINE: Ma-Tsai debate on cross-strait trade pact to take place Sunday
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, April 24 (CNA) 04/24/10 21:56:34 (By Lilian Wu)

TEXT.P: The debate on a proposed cross-strait trade pact between President Ma Ying-jeou and Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) Chairwoman Tsai Ing-wen will take place at 2 p.m. Sunday.
The 2-hour-30-minute debate will be aired live on Taiwan's Public Television Service, marking the first debate on policy between a president and an opposition party head in Taiwan's history.

Ma and Tsai will first give an eight-minute statement on the cross-strait economic cooperation framework agreement. Then there will be cross-examination period with each being able to ask the other person five questions related to the trade deal.
The two will each have six minutes to present concluding statements, and after the debate they are both expected to hold news conferences.

DOC.HEADLINE: Lu moves closer to ATP Challenger event title
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, April 24 (CNA) 04/24/10 22:05:15 (By Luke Sabatier)

TEXT.P: An opportunistic Lu Yen-hsun continued his hot run at the Status Athens Open Saturday, defeating Gilles Muller of Luxembourg in straight sets to advance to Sunday's final.
Lu, currently ranked 102nd in the world, overcame a game challenge from the lower-ranked Muller and a short rain delay early in the second set to book his ticket to the final with a 6-4, 6-4 victory.

He will face his occasional doubles partner, German Rainer Schuettler, in the final of the 85,000 euro ATP Challenger event. Schuettler is seeded seventh and has dropped two sets in his four wins leading to the final.

Though the eighth-seeded Lu was rarely in trouble on his serve, losing a total of only 13 points in 10 service games, he had trouble getting break opportunities against the hard-serving Muller, who had 11 aces on the day.
Lu had only six break points in the entire match, with four of them coming in the first game of the second set -- all of which were saved by Muller.
Fortunately for the 26-year-old Taiwanese, he converted the other two to earn a service break in each set and the victory.

Lu, whose ranking has dropped as he has played more top level ATP Tour events over the past 10 months, is hoping to rack up ranking points on the second tier Challenger tour during the main ATP Tour's claycourt season leading up to the French Open in late May.
Lu has never felt comfortable on clay and rarely plays on it, so he's hoping to use the time to perform well enough in hardcourt Challenger events to propel him back into the top 100.
A victory in Athens would send him back into the top 90, where he would be assured of gaining automatic entry to the main draw of grand slam events.

DOC.HEADLINE: Today in history
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, April 25 (CNA) 04/25/10 12:25:25
DOC.TEXT:
Today is Sunday, April 25, or the 12th day of the third month of the Year of the Tiger according to the lunar calendar. Following is a list of important events that have occurred on this date in the past:
1744: Anders Celsius, Swedish astronomer who devised the Celsius thermometer in 1742, dies at the age of 43.
1859: Under the direction of Ferdinand de Lesseps, the construction of the Suez Canal begins. It was opened 10 years later on Nov. 16, 1869.
1874: Gulielmo Marconi, Italian engineer and inventor who shared the 1909 Nobel Prize in physics, is born. He became the first person to transmit long-wave radio signals across the Atlantic Ocean, doing so in 1901.
1895: Lai Ho, a noted Chinese writer of anti-Japanese literature, is born in Changhua.
1898: The U.S. Congress passes a joint resolution declaring war on Spain over events in Cuba.
1912: The Chung Kuo Ke Ming Tung Meng Hui is reorganized as the Kuomintang.
1925: Field Marshal Paul von Hindenburg becomes the second president of Germany's postwar Weimar Republic.
1927: After the national government in Nanking announces a purification movement that will entail the expulsion of Chinese communists, the communists meet in Wuhan and decide to set up a Soviet-style regime.
1930: Construction of the Chianan irrigation canal is completed.
1941: The United States and the United Kingdom sign in Washington separate but parallel agreements with China for stabilizing China's national currency. The United States provides US$50 million and the United Kingdom provides five million pounds.
1942: An accident at a coal mine in Benxi, located within Japanese-occupied China, kills 1,549 workers in the world's worst mining disaster.
1945: Delegates of 45 nations, including the Republic of China, meet in San Francisco, Calif., to organize the United Nations.
1946: The foreign ministers of the United States, Soviet Union, Britain and France meet in Paris to discuss the signing of a peace treaty with Germany.
1956: The Republic of China Ministry of Foreign Affairs announces the establishment of diplomatic relations with Haiti.
1962: The United States successfully launches its Saturn rocket, the largest in the world at the time.
1965: President Lyndon B. Johnson sends U.S. troops to the Dominican Republic to maintain order after rebel followers of Juan Bosch try to seize power.
1971: T.V. Soong, former president of the Executive Yuan, dies in San Francisco at the age of 77.
1971: Some 200,000 anti-Vietnam War protesters march on Washington, D.C.
1973: The Chinese National Baseball Team leaves Taipei for Manila to take part in the 10th Asian Cup Tournament.
1974: Portugal's dictator Marcelo Caetano is overthrown in a bloodless military coup. He surrenders to Gen. Antonio de Spinola, who becomes president the following month.
1982: The last Israeli soldier leaves Sinai, ending 15 years of Israeli occupation of the peninsula.
1989: Japanese Prime Minister Noburu Takeshita announces plans to resign over the "Recruit Affair," the country's biggest political scandal in decades.
1994: Tsutomu Hata becomes Japan's 51st prime minister.
1995 Ginger Rogers, American dancer and actress, dies at the age of 83. She is particularly noted for her partnership with Fred Astaire in several motion pictures, including "Swing Time," "Flying Down to Rio" and "Roberta."
2000: President Lee Teng-hui bestows a medal on Steve Forbes, president and CEO of U.S.-based Forbes Magazine, in recognition of his long-term contribution to the promotion of exchanges and coorperation between the Republic of China and the United States.
2001: President Chen Shui-bian says that the ROC government will take steps to develop the island into a "competitive country with a knowledge-based economy" within five years.
Confucius' lesson of the day: "The ancient Emperor Shun was perhaps the one man who successfully carried out the principle of no-government. For what need is there really for what is called government? A ruler needs only to be earnest in his personal conduct, and to behave in a manner worthy of his position."

DOC.HEADLINE: President to debate opposition leader on ECFA
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, April 25 (CNA) 04/25/10 13:08:14 (By Garfie Lee and Y.F. Low)

TEXT.P: President Ma Ying-jeou will discuss his administration's plan to sign a trade pact with China in a televised debate with opposition Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) Chairperson Tsai Ing-wen Sunday afternoon.
The debate -- the first ever between a president and an opposition leader in Taiwan -- will run two-and-a-half hours starting at 2 p.m. and broadcast live on Public Television Service (PTS).
It will be hosted by PTS anchorwoman Huang Ming-ming, with simultaneous sign language translation by two interpreters.

Ma and Tsai will each give an eight-minute statement at the opening, followed by a cross-examination period when each can ask the other person five questions. Each will then have six minutes to present concluding statements.
They will hold news conferences separately after the debate.

Forging an economic cooperation framework agreement (ECFA) with China has been one of Ma's most important policies and is aimed at preventing Taiwan from being marginalized as the regional economy becomes increasingly integrated.

The DPP, however, is against the ECFA for fear that it could undermine Taiwan's sovereignty and lead to an influx of cheap Chinese products, which could threaten the survival of local industries and the livelihood of local workers.
The DPP and other pro-independence groups have been pushing for a referendum on the ECFA to allow the people a say on the issue.
