DOC.HEADLINE: Dengue fever infections may increase this year: doctor
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, April 25 (CNA) 04/25/10 13:42:17 (By Chen Li-ting and Fanny Liu)

TEXT.P: With three cases of dengue fever reported since March, a doctor warned that the early start of indigenous infections may signal that the number of local cases will increase this year.

According to the Centers for Disease Control (CDC) under the Department of Health, three dengue fever infections -- all indigenous -- have been found in southern Taiwan's Kaohsiung City since the beginning of March, compared with only one reported case during the same time last year.

Huang Kao-pin, director of pediatric infectious disease at Chang Gung Medical Foundation, Kaohsiung Branch, said that theoretically, indigenous infections shouldn't begin to appear until July or August and peak in October or November.

"It means that some mosquitoes even carried dengue virus during the winter, which would result in an early start of the dengue fever outbreak," said Huang, who is also the director-general of the Taiwan Society of Parasitology.

Huang also said that there may be more people infected by dengue fever illness this year, and that the possibilities of dengue hemorrhagic fever infection -- a severe, potentially fatal infection that is different from normal dengue fever -- will also become higher.

Lin Ting, deputy director of the CDC, said that the number of dengue fever infections will increase when the weather becomes hotter. Lin suggested the public spend more effort cleaning living environments to prevent the outbreak of the disease.
Dengue fever is an influenza-like viral disease spread by the bite of infected mosquitoes. Patients develop symptoms including fever, headache, nausea, fatigue and pain in the muscles and joints.

DOC.HEADLINE: Environmental activists mark Earth Day Sunday
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, April 25 (CNA) 04/25/10 14:27:00 (By S. F. Lee and Flor Wang)

TEXT.P: Around 1,000 activists from local environmental protection groups lined up to form a giant "CO2"at the Chiang Kai-shek Memorial Hall to mark Earth Day Sunday.
Taiwan Environmental Information Center (TEIC) sponsored the activities in line with events held in New York, London, Sydney, Barcelona, Tokyo and Beijing.
TEIC Chairman Chen Chien-chih said Taiwan first celebrated the international Earth Day 20 years ago at the same venue.
Attendees from both the private sector and government agencies took part in a run to show their commitment to protecting the earth.
Activities were also held in other parts of Taiwan, including a jogging event in Changhua County and other green activities in Nantou County and offshore Penghu County.
Hu Ya-mei, chairwoman of the Homemaker's Union and Foundation, urged the government to fully implement carbon-reduction measures instead of only paying lip service to the issue.

DOC.HEADLINE: Talk of the day -- High-profile ECFA debate in spotlight

TEXT.P: A first-ever policy debate between a president and an opposition leader in Taiwan's history will be held this afternoon. It is not only drawing wide attention at home but also from foreign observers concerned about the Asia Pacific region.

Neither President Ma Ying-jeou nor opposition Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) Chairwoman Tsai Ing-wen dares to overlook the debate on whether Taiwan should sign a wide-reaching trade pact with China as it could influence their leadership authority and political stature.

While the Ma administration is preaching the need to strike an economic cooperation framework agreement (ECFA) with China to protect Taiwan from being marginalized amid mounting regional economic integration, the DPP-led opposition camp strongly opposes the bid out of concern that Taiwan's sovereignty could be at stake.
The following are excerpts from local media coverage on the issue: China Times:
Public Television Service (PTS) , the host of the high-profile event, conducted a rehearsal for the debate Saturday. Aides from both sides showed up at the PTS studio to finalize the procedures.
Ma and Tsai were reportedly cautiously finalizing the lists of guests to be invited to Sunday's televised debate, as the invitations would hint at their positions on the ECFA deal.

Ma's spokesman Lo Chih-chiang said the Presidential Office will invite a wide range of representatives, such as farmers, laborers, white-collar workers and scholars to attend, because the ECFA is a matter concerning the entire country. Some Presidential Office staffers will also be present, but only Premier Wu Den- yih will attend the event, with all other Cabinet members absent on the guest list.

DPP spokesman Tsai Chi-chang said the party will invite representatives from underprivileged groups and conventional industries that are most likely to be affected by the trade pact. (April 25, 2010). United Daily News:
In his weekly video address Saturday, Ma vowed to forge ahead the ECFA, saying the administration will definitely sign the proposed trade accord because it is conducive to Taiwan and its people.

Presidential Office sources said Ma called off all other public activities for the weekend in preparation for the debate and that he has been coached by his team of advisers and aides, headed by Vice President Vincent Siew.

On the other hand, DPP spokesman Tsai Chi-chang said Tsai Ing-wen was maintaining her usual daily routine Saturday, except that she would go to bed early to get plenty of sleep ahead of Sunday's debate.
Given the emphasis both sides are putting on the event, political analysts said the debate seems to be an opener for the 2012 presidential election. (April 25, 2010). Liberty Times:

Ma will expound in detail in the debate the need for Taiwan to adopt an open- door policy and the possible grave consequences if Taiwan continued a closed- door policy implemented by the previous DPP administration.
For her part, Tsai will articluate DPP's strategies for Taiwan to connect with the world rather than putting Taiwan increasingly reliant on China.

DOC.HEADLINE: Media an unseen casualty of game-fixing culture in local baseball

TEXT.P: Hundreds of thousands of baseball fans, dozens of honest players, and the game's image have been seen as the main casualties of persistent game-fixing in Taiwan's professional baseball league over the past 15 years.

But they aren't the only ones. Local sportswriters have also been tormented by the continuing scandal, which has led them to question their love for the national pastime, the value of their work and careers in the media, and even their trust and belief in others.

"It is very difficult to accept the fact that those games you covered were fixed, and those stories you wrote were kind of a joke," says Lan Tsung-piao, a sportswriter who has been covering baseball since 1991, a year after the Chinese Professional Baseball League (CPBL) , Taiwan's only professional baseball organization, was established.
The game-fixing scandal last year was the sixth in a wave of scandals that has undermined pro baseball in Taiwan since 1996. Similar incidents followed in 2003, 2005, 2007, 2008 and 2009.
More than 100 Taiwanese and foreign players and coaches have been implicated in those scandals for allegedly taking bribes from local bookies to throw games.
Even big name players, such as former U.S. major leaguer Tsao Chin-hui, the first Taiwanese pitcher to make it to the big leagues, have not been spared, though Tsao was not indicted by prosecutors.

The scandals have generally sent attendance plummeting, with the league never regaining its popularity of the mid-1990s, when it drew more than 5,000 fans per game. The average has lingered between 1,000 and 2,000 in recent years.
According to Lan, media coverage has also been drastically cut back, and reporters are no longer assigned to cover games outside of Taipei.

Former baseball writer Kerry Wu, who decided to quit covering the game he loves in 2000 and now works as a securities analyst, says there were about 30-40 reporters at each game when the league was at its peak in the 1990s.
But as Lan says: "Now you're lucky if you can find more than four (reporters) in the press room."

The experienced baseball writer said he did not sense anything wrong until the scandal broke out in 1997, when he was shocked to learn that some players who were his close friends had been lying to him over the years.
"I still love baseball. I really do, but I'm having trouble figuring out who -- including players and coaches -- to believe, " he says.
Lan still vividly remembers the good times, making the repeated debacles even more difficult to fathom.
He recalls seeing a family of four, days before the 1996 scandal broke out, happily talking about the game in the parking lot of a ballpark with the father explaining baseball rules to his children.

"It was such a lovely and inspiring scene. And that's why I never imagined how deeply those players and scandals would hurt the feelings of these passionate and supporting fans in every corner of the country, " he says.
Wu also suffered through the duplicity, remembering a player who one morning blasted the ethical standards and integrity of those who had been arrested, only to be arrested himself in the afternoon.

Some sportswriters were suspicious of the integrity of the game from the beginning and published their observations, Lan says, but it was very difficult to tell who was throwing games and who was not.

"We could not pretend it was not happening. We had to depend on our instincts but we had no evidence. Some writers, me included, received letters from law firms threatening legal action. Some were even sued, " he laments.
The scandals and declining interest in the game was difficult for these writers to take, Lan's wife told the Central News Agency.

"You're talking about a group of guys who covered the game, went home to watch the replay, and played nothing but baseball video games together when they were on road trips, " she says. "Most of them are baseball junkies who are hopelessly passionate about the game to apathetic degree."
A baseball writer who helped a guilty player write his autobiography before he was implicated in game-fixing allegations, said she "felt cheated after the scandal broke out."

Wu says he turned his attention to the U.S. Major League baseball after quitting his job as a reporter and has not been following the domestic league lately. Others have decided to cover amateur competition.
Lan, who still covers baseball to this day, says he thinks the league should suspend operations for one or two years, change its name, and start fresh because the fans have endured too many scandals.
"Otherwise, every error, strikeout and fireworks in the outfield (a signal from bookies) will always be suspicious."
Kevin Hsiao, a younger reporter who has been covering the game for only a few years, feels differently.
"For younger reporters like me, we grew up with this league. It's hard to imagine that this league would vanish for even one day, " he says, and Lan acknowledges that Hsiao will probably get his way.
"The show will go on. All we can do is cover the game as well and as responsibly as we can. Hopefully there will be no more scandals. Just don't bet on it." By Chris Wang CNA Staff Reporter

DOC.HEADLINE: Economic Daily News: Learn from former lessons
DOC.DATELINE: 04/25/10 15:14:42 (By Deborah Kuo)

TEXT.P: While preparing to sign a trade pact with China that could have a profound and far-reaching impact on Taiwan's economy and the people's welfare, we need to remember the hard lessons the country has learned in the past, including tariff concessions we made to gain admission to the World Trade Organization (WTO) and the controversy over a pact on imports of U.S. beef.

More than 10 years ago, when Taiwan was bidding to enter the GATT, which was later superseded by the WTO, it promised to tax locally produced rice wine -- a staple ingredient in Taiwanese cooking -- at a rate that was equal to taxes on imported spirits such as Scotch whiskey.

The tax commitment hurt the daily lives of ordinary Taiwanese people and triggered smuggling and heavy protests, prompting the Legislature in recent years to think about reclassifying rice wine as a cooking ingredient so that it could be taxed at a lower rate.
The administration believes, however, that any adjustment would be difficult to defend because it would be seen as Taiwan reneging on the commitments it made to gain WTO membership.

Similar headaches occurred after Taiwan signed a pact with the United States late last year agreeing to import U.S. bone-in beef, ground beef and some safe bovine offal -- which triggered an outcry from critics who raised fears that the cuts would bring mad cow disease to Taiwan.
Signing international agreements is no trivial matter and once they are signed, it's hard to override them.

We suggest that before signing any pact with any foreign country, the government first research the issues carefully and then communicate well with the people, particularly those directly affected, on the issue.
By doing so, the government could discover possible problems or pitfalls that have been overlooked, and the public's opinions could be used as leverage by the country's negotiators.

DOC.HEADLINE: China Times: Grieving for a preventable tragedy
DOC.DATELINE: 04/25/10 15:16:52 (By Elizabeth Hsu)

TEXT.P: The public was shocked by an April 19 report that a mother took her own life and the life of her 13-year-old daughter by burning charcoal indoors, despite the fact the daughter had sought help after learning of her mother's plans.
Social services and the police were criticized for lacking the skills and system to prevent the tragedy.

We admit that no social service institution is capable of saving everyone who is determined to die. But it is unforgivable that the mother was able to take the daughter with her. We hope that social workers and resources would be able to help, and not just by breaking into the house when the mother began burning the charcoal. We hope the social support system would have been able to let the mother know death is not the only answer and that she had other options.

It was reported that the mother -- identified only by the surname Tsao -- had been tormented by the decision of the girl's father not to officially accept the child as a member of his family. Suicide was her revenge.

Sadly, we find most adults are selfish and often treat children like property, arbitrarily deciding whether they live or die. Both Tsao and the father made the wrong choices. While social workers are blamed for not being alert and causing the girl's death, we shouldn't forget that her parents are also culprits. (April 25, 2010).

DOC.HEADLINE: Social workers should act quickly to protect children: minister
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, April 25 (CNA) 04/25/10 15:59:55 (By Lee Ming-chung and Y.L. Kao)

TEXT.P: The Administrative Execution Law requires social workers to take timely, assertive measures if they find children's lives are in danger, Minister of the Interior Jiang Yi-huah said after a meeting Saturday.

Jiang was referring to a case in which social workers and police have drawn wide criticism for not preventing a mother in Taichung County from killing herself and her 13-year-old daughter by burning charcoal indoors, even after the daughter had learned of her mother's plans and tried to seek help.
Jiang said the ministry is very sad about the tragedy and will help local governments recruit more social workers and improve the system for handling reports of suspected child abuse.
A meeting on recruitment and training of additional social workers will be held in the coming week, he said.
He also said that social workers have to notify police and village chiefs within 24 hours of receiving a report of suspected abuse and must visit high-risk families within 10 days.

DOC.HEADLINE: Economics minister says economy will be strong this year
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, April 25 (CNA) 04/25/10 16:17:02 (By Lin Shu-yuan and Fanny Liu)

TEXT.P: Economics Minister Shih Yen-shiang said Sunday that recent movements in various indicators showed that Taiwan's economy will be strong this year.
Addressing the opening ceremony of a job fair in Taipei, Shih expressed confidence that Taiwan's economy has recovered and employment demand is growing stronger.
"Taiwan's economy should be strong this year, " Shih said, citing many economic indicators to support his viewpoint.

Shih said the International Monetary Fund (IMF) expected Taiwan's economy to achieve growth of 6.5 percent in 2010, and the Council for Economic Planning and Development (CEPD) also has forecast the economy to grow by at least 5 percent this year.
If those forecasts pan out, Taiwan's economic growth will outpace that of the other Asian Tigers -- Hong Kong, South Korea and Singapore -- Shih added.

In addition, Shih said the value of export orders and industrial production both set a new high in March, indicating that Taiwan's economy is growing at a fast and steady pace, which will contribute to increasing demand for talent in the private sector.
A total of 507 companies participated in the job fair organized by the Ministry of Economic Affairs for enterprises in northern Taiwan, offering more 35,000 job openings.
Taiwan's unemployment rate dropped in March to 5.67 percent, down 0.09 percentage points from the previous month, with the jobless population at 624,000, down 10,000.

DOC.HEADLINE: President pledges to uphold Taiwan's interests at all costs
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, April 25 (CNA) 04/25/10 17:07:17 (By Y.F. Low)

TEXT.P: President Ma Ying-jeou pledged Sunday to uphold Taiwan's interests at all costs in negotiating an economic cooperation framework agreement (ECFA) with China, an arrangement which he said is essential to reviving Taiwan's trade competitiveness.

"If the ECFA talks cannot secure Taiwan's overall economic benefits, I won't accept it (the agreement) and would rather let it fall apart, " Ma said in his opening statement when debating opposition Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) Chairperson Tsai Ing-wen on the trade pact.
According to Ma, the agreement will cover three main areas: tariff reductions and exemption, investment protection, and intellectual rights protection.

There is a consensus between Taipei and Beijing that Taiwan will not open its market to Chinese agricultural products and laborers, and that the two sides will make the best of their efforts to protect conventional industries in Taiwan, Ma said.
For the small minority of conventional industries that are likely to be impacted by the agreement, the government will set aside NT$95 billion over 10 years to assist them, he said.

After Taiwan's global trade ranking declined from 14th to 18th due to a closed- door policy adopted by the DPP during its eight years in power, the ECFA will boost Taiwan's exports and investment as well as employment, Ma argued.

He said Taiwan must not allow itself to be isolated and marginalized as the regional economy is becoming increasingly integrated, noting that the number of free trade agreements signed in Asia has increased from three in 2000 to 58 in 2009.
In the next 10 years, he continued, a super-large free trade area comprising 17 nations and regions with total population of 3.3 billion is expected to be established.
"We cannot wait any longer. I want to lead Taiwan to recover those eight lost years and open up 10 golden years ahead," he said.

In her opening statement, however, Tsai said Ma's emphasis on the importance of signing the ECFA with China has demonstrated the thinking that "Taiwan can only gain access to the world via China." She challenged the president to tell the public if this is Taiwan's "only choice" and if there is no other alternative available.
According to Tsai, the DPP insists that Taiwan should follow several principles in developing economic and trade ties with China.

These include that Taiwan must maintain its autonomy and that the relations should be allowed to progress gradually, she said. Also, the ties must comply with the World Trade Organization treaties, and Taiwan must maintain its trade balance and avoid overly leaning toward China, Tsai said.
She argued that signing the ECFA is not a mere economic issue, because Taiwan's move will tilt the strategic balance in East Asia and even the whole of Asia.

Also, Tsai expressed disappointment at Ma's failure to provide details of the ECFA talks and dismay at government publicity that outlines only the benefits of the ECFA, with no mention of its disadvantages.
Once the agreement is signed, Taiwan will be subject to a 10-year time frame in which it will be required to open its market fully, Tsai warned.
"But the president has never told us how large the impact will be," she said.

DOC.HEADLINE: Ma stresses integrity in debate on ECFA
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, April 25 (CNA) 04/25/10 17:08:15 (By Deborah Kuo)

TEXT.P: President Ma Ying-jeou appealed to the nation Sunday to report the situation if any official is found profiting from Taiwan's talks with China on signing an economic cooperation framework agreement (ECFA).

"I attach great importance to the integrity of officials and the country's ultimate interests in the long run," Ma said in response to a question from opposition Democratic Progressive Party Chairwoman Tsai Ing-wen, who suggested that some officials of the Ma administration have probably begun to benefit from the ECFA talks.
Tsai suggested that the Ma administration conduct an investigation into possible irregularities, and Ma said his government welcomes reports of any irregularities.
He also stressed the importance and necessity of signing the ECFA with China, the earlier the better.
"I will have let down the voters and future generations if the signing of the trade pact is delayed by my administration, " he asserted.
Tsai accused Ma's pro-China policy of having drained Taiwanese resources and deepened Taiwan's commercial and trade reliance on China.

Ma argued, however, that his government has pursued Taiwan's opening to China in a vigilant manner. He said that Taiwan's trade reliance on China stood at 23 percent in 2000, but the rate shot up to 40 percent in 2008 while the DPP was in power.
"Taiwan's trade reliance on China increased by a mere one percentage point to 41 percent by the end of 2009, after the year the Kuomintang has been in office," Ma said.

Meanwhile, he said more Taiwanese enterprises who had relocated their investment operations to China over the last decade, such as the Want Want Group and the Tinghsin Group, have moved back to Taiwan to take advantage of the government's liberalized cross-strait measures.

DOC.HEADLINE: DOH to complete long-term care insurance proposal this year
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, April 25 (CNA) 04/25/10 17:18:07 (By Chen Ching-fang and Lilian Wu)

TEXT.P: Department of Health (DOH) Minister Yaung Chih-liang said that the DOH is scheduled to send a draft long-term care service bill to the Executive Yuan in the second half of this year.

It is hoped that the draft bill can be legislated into law in 2012 to address the needs of Taiwan's graying society, Yaung said at a seminar sponsored by the Taiwan Long-term Care Professional Association.

Yaung said that the planning of long-term care will pose a great challenge that "could prove even more difficult" than the current drive for a second-generation health insurance program that calculates premiums based on total household income, rather than the current system based on individual income.

According to the long-term care insurance program envisioned by the Council for Economic Planning and Development, there are two options: national insurance for everyone or compulsory insurance for those over 40 years old, with the premium for the former set at one-seventh of the health insurance premium and the latter at two-sevenths of the health insurance premium.

Day Guey-ing, deputy convener of a DOH panel working on the long- term care program, said that private civic groups have asked the government to provide long-term care through tax revenues as in some Scandinavian countries.
She noted, however, that Taiwan's tax burden is only 13.4 percent, compared with 36 percent in Sweden and 48 percent in Denmark.
The tax burden of a nation is usually evaluated by the ratio of total tax revenue to GDP.
For this reason, the premiums of the long-term care program should still follow the payment pattern of the national health insurance program, she said.
Day said that the public cares most about if there are sufficient long-term care institutions and variations in the quality of service and prices charged.
"But we have to first serve before talking about how to pay the bill," she said.

She added that there is a growing number of mentally and physically challenged people, as well as those who suffer from Alzheimer's disease. It is estimated that by 2028, the number of such people will exceed 810,000.
Moreover, due to the declining birth rate and the structural changes of families, long-term care will no longer just be needed by a small number of people, she added.

DOC.HEADLINE: ECFA urgently needed: President Ma
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, April 25 (CNA) 04/25/10 17:27:32 (By Flor Wang)

TEXT.P: President Ma Ying-jeou highlighted Sunday the urgent need for a planned trade deal between Taiwan and China, stressing that as a responsible head of state, he had to quickly clinch the agreement to protect the livelihoods and interests of Taiwan's people.

In one of the question-and-answer exchanges between Ma and Democratic Progressive Party Chairwoman Tsai Ing-wen in a debate on the proposed economic cooperation framework agreement (ECFA) , Tsai challenged Ma's support for the pact by saying it would deal a heavy blow to small businesses if it is rashly inked in exchange for only limited benefit.

Tsai also wondered why the government was aggressively pursuing a deal to lower tariffs for goods exported to China when the machinery sector, for example, already enjoyed an import duty of 1.95 percent under the WTO's most favored nation treatment.

Ma replied, however, that he knew one owner of a machinery company in Taichung surnamed Lai who told him that goods exported by Taiwan-based machinery exporters to China are actually subject to an 8 percent tariff rate.

Noting that Lai's company is just one of over 200 small companies supplying parts to a big machinery producer and exporter, Ma stressed that "large business groups and small firms do not necessarily have contrary trade practices, " and he argued the ECFA will help complete industrial clusters in a number of sectors improve their profits.
"What the government should do for local businesses, particularly these brave and diligent small firms, is set a stage for them, and the ECFA is the right stage at this point of time," he explained.

To help Taiwan find a new lease on life and continue thriving amid fierce competition from ASEAN, Japan and South Korea, the president emphasized he is racing against time to achieve the goal. Otherwise, it will be too late after eight years of inaction under the previous DPP administration.
"The ECFA is urgent and necessary to Taiwan, and the government is poised to consolidate every step it takes, " the president stressed.
The Ma-Tsai debate was the first ever between the president and a major opposition party leader in Taiwan.

The DPP strongly objects to the ECFA out of fear that it might open Taiwan's doors to laborers and agricultural products from China, hurting the local economy and threatening the livelihoods of the country's citizens, particularly in southern Taiwan people.
The DPP enjoys widespread support in Taiwan's southern regions, which heavily relies in agriculture and conventional sectors.

DOC.HEADLINE: United Daily News: Comments on speedy trial act
DOC.DATELINE: 04/25/10 17:36:35 (By Maubo Chang)

TEXT.P: A bill aimed at expediting the trial of criminal cases was passed by the Legislative Yuan last Friday. The Judiciary Yuan should also push for the revamping of the Code of Criminal Procedure to ensure the quick and appropriate trial of criminal cases.

The bill entitles a defendant who has stood on trial for more than eight years to ask for a commutation of any sentence under certain conditions, limits the prosecutor's power to appeal, and prohibits the detention of the defendant before a case is adjudicated for more than eight years.

The bill has its problematic areas. For example, defendants who were charged with the same offense may be treated differently because of the differing lengths of time their cases have been in the court system.
Also the bill will open avenues for prosecutors and judges to help defendants by dragging their feet in trials.

Furthermore, the bill has usurped the role of the Code of Criminal Procedure by setting limitations on the detention of the defendant and the prosecutors' power to appeal, thus confusing criminal procedures.
The root cause of criminal trials becoming cumbersome is that the Supreme Court repeatedly remands cases to lower courts for retrials.

The remedy is to make sure that the evidence in a case is fully disclosed and clearly determined in the first trial and does not need to be investigated again in ensuing trials. The Supreme Count should be limited to examining whether the law applied in the case is appropriate.
There is no reason to stipulate the period of detention in the Code of Criminal Procedure for defendants charged with misdemeanors and in the bill on a speedy trial for those charged with felonies.
Stipulating the periods of detention in different laws will complicate the task of streamlining criminal procedures.

The bill prohibits prosecutors from filing appeals in cases where the defendant was found not guilty in both the first and second trials. However, Ministry of Justice statistics show that verdicts in 60 percent of such cases were thrown out by the Supreme Court on appeal by prosecutors.
The bill also failed to take into consideration how the victims in criminal cases would feel if no one were found responsible for their suffering.
The bill is more a way to silence public criticism than to fix the problem of procrastination in criminal trials. (April 25, 2010)

DOC.HEADLINE: President calls for legislative debate on ECFA
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, April 25 (CNA) 04/25/10 17:43:24 (By Sofia Wu)

TEXT.P: President Ma Ying-jeou urged the opposition Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) Sunday not to boycott discussion in the Legislative Yuan on the pros and cons of a proposed wide-reaching trade pact with China.

In a televised debate with DPP Chairperson Tsai Ing-wen, Ma expressed regret over what he called the opposition party's repeated obstructions of reports by government officials on the initiative to sign an economic cooperation framework agreement (ECFA) with China.

Stressing the importance of such a deal to Taiwan's future economic development, Ma said officials of his administration have been more than willing to brief DPP lawmakers on the ECFA's essence and draft content.
DPP lawmakers, however, had repeatedly boycotted such sessions in the legislature, he said.

In a mature democratic country, Ma said, the legislature should be a key venue for policy debate. Instead of blaming the government for keeping the opposition party in the dark on the pact, Ma urged Tsai to order DPP lawmakers not to hinder legislative hearings on ECFA issues anymore.
Ma, however, failed to respond to Tsai's question on whether his administration has any alternative plan if ECFA talks with China break down.

Accusing the Ma administration of creating a false sense of urgency in concluding such a critical agreement with China, Tsai said that China may have ulterior motives for making unilateral concessions to Taiwan in ECFA talks.

She also advised the Ma administration to prepare a detailed package of measures to cope with the situation if it fails to realize its goal of striking such a deal in the first half of this year as scheduled.

DOC.HEADLINE: DPP head says people's anxiety over ECFA is real
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, April 25 (CNA) 04/25/10 17:49:40 (By Lilian Wu)

TEXT.P: Opposition Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) Chairwoman Tsai Ing-wen said in a debate Sunday that the public's sense of insecurity over a proposed trade pact with China was not "something the DPP could create," after her party was accused of being only good at scaring the people over the deal.

In a highly anticipated debate on the economic cooperation framework agreement (ECFA) Sunday, President Ma Ying-jeou charged that the DPP was behind much of the negative impression people had of the controversial pact.

Citing a DPP estimate on the number of white-collar workers who would be adversely affected by the ECFA that went from 3.21 million on April 6 to 5.9 million five days later, Ma asked if Tsai wanted to use public sense of insecurity to intimidate people for political ends and election gains.

Moreover, as noted experts such as Michael Porter and Paul Krugman and foreign investors think that the merits of signing the ECFA are bigger than the disadvantages, Ma asked why the DPP has often had more pessimistic views.
"The DPP has always talked about going global, but why has it deliberately left out China?" Ma asked.
In response, Tsai said the public's insecurity does in fact exist and was not something that a party could create.
The DPP is a poor party and does not have the ample administrative resources of the KMT, so that it can only reflect and voice the deepest anxieties of the people.

"Not only the green camp led by the DPP, but between 40 and 50 percent of those in the pro-blue camp led by the KMT have had a sense of anxiety about Taiwan's future in public opinion polls conducted by the DPP," she said.
In fact, since President Ma assumed his office, he has never stood up for Taiwan's sovereignty, Tsai said.

Moreover, in negotiations with China and the United States, the Ma administration has never strongly defended its position, leaving the public feeling it does not have a "president they can trust, " Tsai said.

She said the public has not seen the ECFA's early harvest list, and the biggest issue is that the administration has never honestly addressed the issue, either by explaining the possible downside of the trade pact or releasing its internal assessments on the agreement.

Tsai said the DPP was by no means trying to intimidate the people by trying to inflate the number of white-collar workers impacted by the ECFA, saying that the party had to adjust the number because it had to include those whose salary will not increase.

Although Ma noted that scholars and foreign investors support the inking of the ECFA, Tsai said that as a president, Ma should consider himself as somebody of a different status and responsibility, not an economics master.

DOC.HEADLINE: Ma says Taiwan can handle ECFA impact
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, April 25 (CNA) 04/25/10 18:05:32 (By Fanny Liu)

TEXT.P: President Ma Ying-jeou expressed confidence that Taiwanese people have the ability to deal with any adverse impact from a proposed trade pact with China and said the government will take the bold move of signing to secure a better future for Taiwan.

In a live, televised debate with opposition Democratic Progressive Party Chairperson (DPP) Tsai Ing-wen on the economic cooperation framework agreement (ECFA) , Ma stressed that the government planned to take measures to help 17 weaker industries that could be affected adversely by the pact.

He said measures to be taken include helping those industries to revive or adjust their business nature, and offering subsidies of about NT$95 billion (US$3 billion) , of which about NT$36.5 billion will be used by the Council of Labor Affairs.

In early April, the Industrial Development Bureau added five industries -- Chinese medicines, pesticides, environmental agents, animal drugs and bamboo and wooden products -- to the list of industries to be eligible to receive subsidies. The previously planned 12 industries include garments, home appliances and stone materials.

"It will not be the first time Taiwan faced such a crisis. Taiwan survived a greater impact after joining the World Trade Organization (WTO) in 2002, " said Ma, adding that he believes Taiwan has the ability to get over the crisis this time as well.

Tsai argued that Taiwanese businessmen, attracted by the elimination of tariffs as proposed under the pact, would invest in China and use the lack of tariffs to sell their products back to Taiwan cheaply, which could force even more Taiwanese companies to move to China.
Ma said the government would take measures to enhance the checking of certificates of origin to prevent illegal imports of Chinese products from damaging local manufacturers.

The "no-hurry" attitude on Taiwan-China trade relations that the DPP took during its eight years in power hurt Taiwan's economy, Ma said, adding that as president he needs to have a vision and consider what may happen in five or 10 years.

DOC.HEADLINE: Landslides block No. 3 freeway; rescuers search rubble
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, April 25 (CNA) 04/25/10 18:09:40 (by Wang Hung-kuo and Lillian Lin)

TEXT.P: Serious landslides and a collapsed overpass Sunday afternoon buried more than 300 meters of the No. 3 National Freeway about 3 kilometers from the northern end of the 429 km Keelung-Pingtung freeway.
As the rescue team was still digging, it was not clear whether there were cars buried in the rocks and mud, firemen on the scene said.

Premier Wu Den-yih told reporters that immediately after receiving reports from the freeway administration at around 2: 35 p.m., he instructed Vice Premier Eric Liluan Chu and Minister of the Interior Jiang Yi-huah to rush to the scene and inspect the accident.
In addition to rescuers from the Keelung fire department, military engineers are also helping to clear the freeway, which usually has heavy traffic during weekdays.

DOC.HEADLINE: Taiwan's golf champion dismisses China report
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, April 25 (CNA) 04/25/10 18:13:17 (By Bien Chin-feng and Elizabeth Hsu)

TEXT.P: Taiwanese golfer Yani Tseng returned from the United States Sunday and dismissed speculation that she would move to China, saying she would remain in Taiwan and continue to fight for the glory of the country.
The leader on the 2010 LPGA money ist won her latest battle at the LPGA Kraft Nabisco Championship earlier this month.
Tseng, accompanied by her mother, was received at Taiwan Taoyuan International Airport by her father, grandmother and Taoyuan County Magistrate Wu Chih-yang.

At a press conference at the airport, the 21-year-old said she regretted hearing that the world's top-ranking golfer, Lorena Ochoa of Mexico, would retire after the 2010 Tres Marias Championship from April 29 to May 2.

Asked about reports that the Huabin Group in China had offered her a long-term sponsorship contract with big paychecks and a private airplane, Tseng smiled and said the only thing she knew about the supposed offer was what she'd learned from the media.
She dismissed reports that she planned to acquire Chinese citizenship, stressing that she "wasn't considering it at all."
Tseng said she would focus on "winning more championships" so that she can "become the world No. 1 and write a new page in Taiwan's history."

DOC.HEADLINE: Ma, Tsai argue over urgency of ECFA, impact of ASEAN plus one
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, April 25 (CNA) 04/25/10 18:30:00 (By Deborah Kuo)

TEXT.P: President Ma Ying-jeou stressed Sunday that Taiwan needed to quickly sign a trade pact with China to prevent Taiwan from being marginalized further at a time when regional trade blocs are forming at an increasing pace.

ASEAN plus One (China) took effect in January this year and that ASEAN plus Three and other trade blocs are already on drawing boards, Ma said in a debate with opposition Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) Chairwoman Tsai Ing-wen on the economic cooperation framework agreement (ECFA).

South Korea has signed free trade agreements (FTAs) with seven major trade partners, China has signed FTAs with nine major players in international trade and Singapore has signed FTAs with 14 major economies, but Taiwan has signed none in Asia, the president said.
"While other countries strived to tie trade knots, we are arguing among ourselves and losing time, " he argued.
Tsai disagreed, saying that signing an ECFA is not a pressing issue, arguing that ASEAN plus China has only cost Taiwan 0.035 percent of GDP, and the signing of ASEAN plus Three is a long way away.

She told Ma that signing an ECFA with China is not an issue that can be dealt with "romantically," arguing that China's desire to sign the ECFA with Taiwan or FTAs with other countries was based on strategic considerations, rather than pure economic purposes.
Citing Indonesia as an example, Tsai said Southeast Asian countries have begun to feel the heat after the ASEAN plus China trade zone came into being.
"Indonesia has asked for a delay in the implementation of the regional trade pact," she said.
Tsai warned that Taiwan's signing of the ECFA with China, reportedly in June, may result in the change of the strategic map of East Asia and further increase China's clout in the region.

Tsai said the ECFA is not a must for Taiwan, pointing out that Taiwan should seek to strengthen trade ties with other countries under the World Trade Organization (WTO) framework, such as the Trade and Investment Framework Agreement (TIFA) signed with the United States for example.

Ma responded that strengthening trade engagement with other countries beyond China is of course an option of his administration, but Taiwan has encountered difficulties doing so when those countries became reluctant to sign any agreement with Taiwan because "Taiwan maintains no connections with China."

Tsai accused the Ma administration of rushing to sign the pact without having not fully informed Taiwan's people about its contents, saying that three-fourths of the people were not familiar with the trade pact or an "early harvest" list covering products to receive immediate tariff concessions.

Concerned that terms of the agreement would not be reviewed by the Legislature before the deal was completed and signed, Tsai asked Ma what would happen if the ECFA was rejected by the Legislature. "Will you redo it all over again?"
Ma ignored the question but reasserted his administration's rationale for the pact.
"Our strategy is to not let Taiwan be left behind, " he said. "We would be unable to meet the challenges ahead or cope with the international situation if we do not sign the ECFA."

Contending that his government has consulted economic experts, scholars and the private sector and is well prepared for the signing of the ECFA, Ma asked Tsai what the DPP's plans were to meet future challenges, other than waiting, spreading fear and even intimidating the government and the people over the issue.

DOC.HEADLINE: Taiwan needs not worry about 'ASEAN plus One' trade bloc: Tsai
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, April 25 (CNA) 04/25/10 19:18:17 (By Elizabeth Hsu)

TEXT.P: Opposition Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) Chairwoman Tsai Ing-wen on Sunday rejected the government's argument that a trade pact with China is needed to counter the impact of the "ASEAN plus One" free trade zone, saying Southeast Asian countries are not Taiwan's main competitors in China.

In a debate on a proposed economic cooperation framework agreement (ECFA) between Taiwan and China, President Ma Ying-jeou said the new free trade zone, which took effect Jan. 1, has directly affected Taiwan's automobile, machinery, petrochemical and textile sectors.

Those sectors are now faced with higher tariffs than their ASEAN competitors in the Chinese market, Ma said, and added that the DPP think tank's suggestion to let industrial sectors facing high tariffs move to China rather than signing the ECFA would leave some 590,000 workers in Taiwan jobless.
In response, Tsai said that Japan and South Korea, and not ASEAN (Association of Southeast Asian Nations) countries, were Taiwan's main rivals in those sectors in China.

She accused the president of exaggerating and overstating the impact of the "ASEAN plus One" zone, and said that in a mature industrial sector, quality, innovation and value-added determined profitability more than tariffs on trade.
Also, once the value of the Chinese yuan rises, triggering the likely rise in the appreciation of Taiwan's currency, any gains from the tariff reductions will be offset, Tsai argued.
She also challenged Ma's belief that Taiwan will be further marginalized once Japan and South Korea join "ASEAN plus One" and make it "ASEAN plus Three," reportedly in 2012.
"ASEAN plus Three will not be formed within the foreseeable future, " she predicted, because of reluctance on the part of Japan and South Korea.

The two countries not only fear that their domestic industries cannot withstand competitors from China, but also that a "China-centric East Asian economic circle" will be formed, which they believe will change the strategic balance in the region, Tsai said.

DOC.HEADLINE: DPP head regrets Ma's failure to clarify concerns in ECFA debate
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, April 25 (CNA) 04/25/10 19:24:35 (By Sofia Wu)

TEXT.P: Opposition Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) Chairwoman Tsai Ing-wen said Sunday that President Ma Ying-jeou failed to give convincing responses to her questions about the impact of a proposed cross-Taiwan Strait trade pact on local industries.

Tsai also complained about Ma's criticism of the DPP in a 150-minute debate on an economic cooperation framework agreement (ECFA) currently being negotiated with China, saying he contradicted himself on the DPP's handling of cross-strait relations during its eight years in power from 2000-2008.

"On the one hand, Ma completely denied the DPP's efforts to promote cross-strait exchanges during its eight years in power, but he also recognized the DPP's contribution to promote cross-strait tourism and economic exchanges, " Tsai said at a post-debate news conference.
"His statements were contradictory."

In the debate, Ma repeatedly asked the public to trust him and have confidence in his guarantee of the trade pact's benefits, but he failed to allay public worries whether his assurance would be valid or not, Tsai said.
She also expressed regret that Ma failed to give convincing responses to many substantive issues she questioned him about in the televised debate.

They included contingency plans the government had if the ECFA talks with China broke down, the exact amount of tariff benefits Taiwan could reap under the ECFA deal, and measures to deal with the increasing gap between rich and poor caused by the deal.
"His failure in this regard further confirms our belief that the ECFA initiative was a hasty decision proposed by a few people, " Tsai argued at the news conference.

While Ma took advantage of the debate to advertise what he called the ECFA's advantages and make false accusations against the DPP, Tsai said Ma's performance highlighted the ruling Kuomintang's inability to examine itself and its treatment of dealings with the opposition party as political warfare.

In the debate, Ma attacked the DPP for what he called the party's "closed-door" policy toward China, characterizing the period as the "lost eight years" because it hindered progress in cross-strait ties and exacerbated Taiwan's diplomatic isolation and economic marginalization.
Tsai said Ma's accusation was unfair and reflected his lack of introspection.
Instead of discounting the DPP's criticism of his administration's ECFA initiative, Ma and his administrative team should take into account the DPP's proposals in policy formulation.
While the DPP supports the strategy of using the Chinese market to beef up Taiwan's economic strength, Tsai the DPP calls for developing relations with China in a gradual manner.

Tsai further said ECFA not only involves economic issues but will also affect the balance of power in entire Asia, warning that Taiwan's speedy economic integration with China may tilt strategic balance of power in Asia.

DOC.HEADLINE: Pact with China to benefit both sides: president
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, April 25 (CNA) 04/25/10 19:28:40 (By Maubo Chang)

TEXT.P: The proposed economic cooperation framework agreement with China will benefit both sides, President Ma Ying-jeou said in an indirect denial of Beijing's claims that it will concede benefits to Taiwan through the pact.

In his televised debate with Democratic Progressive Party Chairperson Tsai Ing- wen over whether the country should sign such a pact with China, Ma said Taiwanese have invested more than NT$200 billion (US$6.34 billion) in China, adding that Taiwan enjoyed a cross-strait trade surplus of more than NT$400 billion a year.
Much of these exports are materials shipped to China and processed there before being exported to foreign markets, a system that benefits both Taiwan and China, the president said.
As to the problem of redistributing wealth and reorganizing local industries after the pact is signed, Ma said this would be done through the social welfare system and taxation.
The president said that there are 17 kinds of local industries that will be negatively influenced by the pact, and that the government will help them ride out the crisis by upgrading themselves.

Noting that Taiwan succeeded in cushioning the impact brought about by its admission to the World Trade Organization in 2002, Ma said this experience gave the country confidence to cope with any fallout triggered by the proposed trade pact with China.

DOC.HEADLINE: Fourth-round talks could settle 'early harvest list': minister
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, April 25 (CNA) 04/25/10 19:41:21 (By S. Y. Lin and Flor Wang)

TEXT.P: Taiwan and China are likely to complete an "early harvest list" in the fourth round of bilateral talks on a cross-Taiwan Strait economic cooperation framework agreement (ECFA) , Minister of Economic Affairs Shih Yen-shiang said Sunday.
"Taiwan and China will be able to fix the major items to be included on the list in their third-round talks, which may take place in late April or early May," Shih told reporters.
"Therefore, the two sides are expected to settle the 'early harvest list' in the fourth talks, and it could be published if both sides agree to do so," he added.

The "early harvest list " refers to a list of items that will enjoy an immediate reduction or elimination of tariffs after the ECFA is signed. The priority tax cut list is the centerpiece of the agreement, which the government says will help Taiwan avoid marginalization amid increasingly integrated trade in the region.

According to Shih, the machinery, textile, petrochemical and transportation industries, as well as a few categories of information-related products, will be included on the "early harvest list" to be put forth by his ministry.

"One thing is for sure, Taiwan's 'early harvest list' will be more comprehensive than China's, " he added. This means that the number of items and their total export value will certainly be higher than China's due to the difference in the size of the two markets, he said.

DOC.HEADLINE: Transition from ECFA to FTA will be gradual: Ma
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, April 25 (CNA) 04/25/10 20:01:39 (By Maubo Chang)

TEXT.P: President Ma Ying-jeou said Sunday that the cross-strait proposed economic cooperation framework agreement (ECFA) is not a fully developed free trade pact but a start toward it, and that the country will have time to adapt during the transition.
The transition between the ECFA and a full-fledged free trade pact would be gradual and that Taiwan's people were up to the challenge, he added.

In a televised debate with Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) Chairperson Tsai Ing-wen over whether the country should sign an ECFA with China, Ma said that the DPP government opened the local market to 936 Chinese agricultural goods during its eight years in power, while his administration has approved none.
Still, Ma said, the DPP often accuses him of planning to allow more Chinese agricultural products to enter Taiwan.
In her response, Tsai said that the DPP approved the entry of Chinese produce to bring the country in line with the rules of the World Trade Organization (WTO).

Tsai, a former vice premier under the administration of former President Chen Shui-bian, said the ECFA is a step toward a free trade pact under the WTO framework, which she said required signatories to fully open their markets to each other's produce within 10 years, and Taiwan would be no exception.
"If the plan is to obtain China's consent to waive the requirement for Taiwan, why would China do this and how would other states allow it?" she asked.

Not all free trade pact signatories have to fully open their produce markets within 10 years, Ma said, adding that 23 out of the 272 free trade pacts under the WTO provided for 10 to 24 years for the opening to 50 percent to 90 percent of the counterpart's produce.

Tsai said Taiwan won't be allowed to follow the examples of these 23 pacts in light of its strong trading power, and is sure to be asked to open its market to 90 percent or more of Chinese agricultural products during negotiations with China.

She criticized the government for not making public the industries that will enjoy an early exemption of tariffs, which she said has caused a panic among businesses, adding that more than three-fourths of Taiwan's people don't understand what the ECFA is about.
Ma said his administration has been going out its way to explain the pact to the general public.

DOC.HEADLINE: ECFA crucial to petrochemical sector: industry association
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, April 25 (CNA) 04/25/10 20:05:20 (By Chao Hsiao-hui and Lilian Wu)

TEXT.P: Signing a cross-strait economic cooperation framework agreement (ECFA) is crucial to the petrochemical sector because it would make Taiwan's products more competitive, a local petrochemical association said Sunday.

The Petrochemical Industry Association of Taiwan said 70 percent of the petrochemical products produced in Taiwan are currently exported to China to meet demand that is not satisfied by the mainland's own production.

China has to rely on imports for 30 percent of its needs, of which 20 percent come from Taiwan, the association said, just hours after President Ma Ying-jeou and Democratic Progressive Party Chairwoman Tsai Ing-wen held a marathon debate on the merits of the proposed trade pact.

The ECFA, currently being negotiated, is strongly opposed by Tsai and her party because they fear it will undermine Taiwan's economy and because the potential benefits are not as ample as the government has suggested.

According to one association official, members of the Association of Southeast Asian Nations (ASEAN) receive duty-free treatment when shipping their petrochemical products to China, but Taiwan's products face tariffs of 6.5 percent, making them less competitive against those offered by ASEAN rivals.

The official noted that among the sectors to be given preferential tariff treatment under the ECFA's "early harvest list" -- machinery, mid- and upstream textiles, transportation vehicles and petrochemicals -- only the petrochemical sector involves one-way trade, from Taiwan to China, while the others involve two-way trade.
Based on these considerations, the official said the inking of the ECFA is crucial to the petrochemical industry.
The Formosa Plastics Group (FPG), the dominant private player in Taiwan's petrochemical sector, said signing the pact will help its products make further inroads into China's vast market.

The company said that Taiwan's petrochemical products are highly competitive, and that if Taiwan can sign free trade agreements with other countries after signing the ECFA, it will be able to strengthen its Taiwan base and export to the whole world.

DOC.HEADLINE: Living coral reef found in Dongsha
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, April 25 (CNA) 04/25/10 20:16:57 (By Fanny Liu)

TEXT.P: An isolated living coral reef was found in a Dongsha atoll lagoon area that contains mostly dead coral, showing the atoll will likely return to its original appearance, park administration said Sunday.

According to the National Park Administration under the Ministry of Internal Affairs' Construction and Planning Agency, the huge reef -- about 8 kilometers east of Dongsha Island -- has a diameter of over 100 meters, and its lifeless top looks like many other dead reefs in the area.

After noticing a group of fishes appearing near the reef flat, however, a group of researchers decided to dive into the water and found a lot more fish and invertebrates inhabiting the reef slope, where massive live corals -- such as porite or "finger" coral, acropora or "table" coral, and brain coral were also found.

The discovery of the massive live corals was encouraging, because corals in the Dongsha atoll have been recovering slower than those on the outside of the atoll since the destruction of coral from the effects of El Nino in 1998, the administration said.
The administration said it will spend more effort investigating and researching the atoll lagoon's ecology and seek effective ways to restore it.
Park administration increased its underwater investigation after it bought a research boat last year and started to explore the Dongsha atoll lagoon area this year, it added.
The Dongsha atoll, located about 444 kilometers southwest of Kaohsiung, was designated by the government as the country's first marine national park in 2007.

DOC.HEADLINE: Negotiating process, not content, should be transparent: president
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, April 25 (CNA) 04/25/10 20:38:10 (by Lillian Lin)

TEXT.P: President Ma Ying-jeou said Sunday that that the process of negotiating the "early harvest list" under a proposed economic cooperation framework agreement (ECFA) with China, should be transparent, but that its content should not be.

In a debate on a proposed cross-strait trade pact, the president said he agreed with his rival, Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) Chairwoman Tsai Ing-wen, that the negotiations in principle should be transparent.
"But what is currently under negotiation cannot be revealed at the moment, " he said.
Ma promised that his administration will make public the content of the "early harvest list" before submitting it to the Legislative Yuan.

Admitting that the government needs to do more to help the public understand the proposed trade pact with China and the urgency of signing such a deal, Ma said some non-high-tech sectors anticipate that they might be left at a disadvantage by the deal.

"The Ministry of Economic Affairs has listed 17 categories of disadvantaged industries and is making contact with companies in these sectors, trying to help them reduce the impact from such an agreement," the president said.

Tsai rejected Ma's argument that accepting the potential consequences of the ECFA was a challenge that Taiwan needed to accept in order to maintain the competitiveness of local industries before the formation of the ASEAN (Association of Southeast Asian Nations) plus Three (China, Japan and South Korea) trade bloc.
She suggested that such a bloc was still a long way away because both Japan and South Korea have strategic concerns to consider before entering into a trade pact with China.

The two countries are worried about the impact of free trade agreements with China on their domestic industries, and also fear the emergence of a China- centric East Asia economic zone, according to Tsai.
She also argued that Taiwan might pay a huge price in the long run for accepting minor tariff concessions from China.

Although the items listed in the "early harvest list" might be limited, Taiwan's partial lifting of import restrictions on Chinese products would eventually lead to the wide opening of the local market and hurt companies that rely primarily on domestic sales, she said.

DOC.HEADLINE: Taiwan hosiery association welcomes ECFA
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, April 25 (CNA) 04/25/10 20:48:53 (By Wei Shu and Deborah Kuo)

TEXT.P: The Taiwan Hosiery Manufacturers' Association (THMA) said Sunday that it welcomed the government's efforts to sign an economic cooperation framework agreement (ECFA) with China.

THMA Chairman Wei Ping-chi said socks, tights and stockings made in Taiwan are of much higher quality than those produced in China and once an the cross-strait trade pact is forged, made-in-Taiwan hosiery products will enjoy a fast-growing market in China.
"The opening of the market brought about by the ECFA will create a new business niche in China for Taiwanese hosiery manufacturers, " Wei forecast.
He made the remarks in response to a televised debate between President Ma Ying- jeou and opposition Democratic Progressive Party Chairperson Tsai Ing-wen on signing an ECFA.

Tsai said during the debate that Taiwanese manufacturers may benefit from ECFA- authorized tariff concessions temporarily, but that the international competitiveness of Taiwan's industrial sector would be compromised in the long run.

Wei is president of Fu Chu Knitting Co., producer of high-quality legwear under several brand names. Eighty percent of the company's products are exported to the United States and the remaining 20 percent are mainly exported to Europe, Asia and Latin America.

He predicted that after the ECFA is signed, the government will be obliged to strengthen inspection and control on imports from China and in turn stymie the smuggling of substandard hosiery products from China.
"The ECFA will allow Taiwan manufacturers an opportunity to compete with their Chinese rivals on a fair and legal platform, creating a niche for us," Wei said.

He said that from this year on, he plans for his company's business in China to increase by at least 20 percent per year.Fu Chu has also been working to set up some 200 retailing stores in major Chinese cities, he added.

Wei said that opposing an ECFA is tantamount to protecting dishonest players, suggesting that some Taiwanese traders have imported inexpensive hosiery from China via a third place and relabeled the smuggled goods so they appeared to be from Vietnam, Japan or South Korea.

He said that despite a high 17 percent import tariff, Chinese hosiery importers have increasingly placed orders with his company and other Taiwanese makers because they were impressed by the Taiwan products' high quality and designs.
"They (Chinese importers) paid before delivery was made, " Wei said.

He painted a rosy picture for his company and other Taiwanese hosiery manufacturers after Taiwan signs the ECFA with China, saying that a market of over one billion hosiery users is indeed a big draw for Taiwan makers.
"It would be too late for us to catch up once the ASEAN Plus Three (China, Japan and South Korea) is struck," Wei asserted.

DOC.HEADLINE: DPP to press ahead with ECFA referendum after debate
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, April 25 (CNA) 04/25/10 20:57:57 (By Y.F. Low)

TEXT.P: The opposition Democratic Progressive Party will continue to push for a referendum on the proposed economic cooperation framework agreement (ECFA) with China, the party's chairwoman, Tsai Ing-wen, said Sunday.

"Our position on the referendum is very clear. We will press on toward the goal together with our ally, the Taiwan Solidarity Union (TSU) , " Tsai said in a news conference held immediately after her debate on the trade pact with President Ma Ying-jeou.
As a responsible leader, Ma should help facilitate the referendum and even have legislators from his Kuomintang cooperate with the DPP in promoting the vote, Tsai said.
She also said she could not remember Ma "answering any substantive questions" throughout the entire debate. However, she said, the DPP will welcome any chance for further debate on the issue.

On whether to go ahead with a plan to hold a massive demonstration against the ECFA, Tsai said her party will watch if Ma will adjust its attitude and drop the thinking that the agreement "must be signed no matter what" in June.
In the debate, the opposition leader described the ECFA policy as an ill-advised one that is based on a miscalculation of Taiwan's international situation.
She warned that Taiwan's premature economic integration with China could tilt the strategic balance in East Asia and even the whole of Asia.
The agreement will also force Taiwan to fully open its market to China in the next 10 years, leaving many Taiwan people out of work, according to Tsai.

In a separate news conference, Ma said he looks forward to holding further discussions with Tsai on the issue and that he will see if there are other things his administration can do to clear up the doubts held by the public.
Ma said the public should not see the signing of the ECFA as Taiwan taking a risk.
"If the agreement is signed, Taiwan's economic and trade status in East Asia will be very different," the president said.
On the referendum issue, Ma reiterated that initiating a referendum is part of the people's rights and that the government will not interfere as long as such an initiative is consistent with the law.

However, the government will not launch a referendum on the ECFA, because under the Referendum Act, the government is forbidden from doing so unless there is a situation threatening national security.
On Thursday, the TSU filed a new petition with the Central Election Commission for a referendum on the ECFA, eight months after a previous petition filed by the DPP was rejected.
The CEC will meet May 4 to determine if the new proposal meets legal requirements.

DOC.HEADLINE: President to lead FTA promotion team
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, April 25 (CNA) 04/25/10 21:30:50 (By Y.L. Kao)

TEXT.P: President Ma Ying-jeou unveiled on Sunday a plan to assemble a task force that he will lead to facilitate Taiwan's efforts to negotiate free trade agreements with its major trade partners.

In his closing remarks in a debate with the opposition Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) Chairperson Tsai Ing-wen on the merits of a proposed economic cooperation framework agreement (ECFA) with China, Ma broached the plan as he defended the pact, which he said would help counter the formation of regional trade blocs.

Japan, South Korea and the Association of Southeast Asian Nations countries have forged or are seeking to form trade partnership relations with China to achieve mutual economic and trade benefits and enhance their competitiveness, Ma said.
But Taiwan did not make any progress in improving its economic status under the rule of the previous DPP government due to the closed mind-set of the party, he said.
"Others have already run four or five laps while we're still tying our shoelaces. How much longer can we wait? Do we want to win or not?" he said.

Key to the effort, Ma said, is signing the ECFA, which will give new life to Taiwan's economy and create jobs, and then making renewed efforts to sign free trade agreements (FTAs) with other major trading partners.
To expedite the process, Ma said he will lead the FTA task force on signing FTAs with other countries, and urged China not to block Taiwan's pursuit of free trade deals with them.
In her closing remarks, Tsai summarized the "unprecedented negative impact" the proposed ECFA would have on some local sectors, particularly low-end industries.

Questioning Ma's assurances that the government would safeguard the country's interests, Tsai asked how people could trust him after he has been unable to fulfill his campaign promise to raise economic growth to 6 percent, reduce unemployment to 3 percent, and raise per capita income to US$30,000.

The country's economic policy should also encompass the adjustment of Taiwan's economic structure, industrial development and financial policy, Tsai added.

Signing the ECFA, she said, is not only the option, suggesting that Taiwan can also seek to forge closer economic and trade relations with other countries under the frameworks of the World Trade Organization and the Asia Pacific Economic Cooperation, she noted.
