DOC.HEADLINE: Farmers take president at his word of no imports of Chinese produce
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, April 25 (CNA) 04/25/10 21:50:22 (By Maubo Chang)

TEXT.P: Two officials of farmers and fishermen's groups in central and southern Taiwan said Sunday they would take President Ma Ying-jeou at his word that currently banned Chinese agricultural products would not be brought into Taiwan under the country's proposed trade pact with China.

In a telephone interview with the Central News Agency, Liao Cheng-hsian, secretary-general of the Farmers' Association of Changhua County, said he believes the president will follow through on his promise, which has already been conveyed to the country's farmers through Council of Agriculture Minister Chen Wu-hsiung.
He said, however, that the government should come up with measures to help industries that are expected to bear the brunt of the negative impact of the proposed pact with China.

Chen Yu-ling, an official with the Fishermen's Association of Linbian Township in Pingtung County in southern Taiwan, told CNA by phone that Taiwan's agricultural products are more competitive than those from China, so she was not worried about potential competition from the mainland.
As long as the government can screen out inferior Chinese goods, competition will only stimulate local farmers and fishermen to improve the quality of their products to capture customers, Chen said.
Ma reiterated his promise Sunday in a televised debate with Democratic Progressive Party Chairwoman Tsai Ing-wen on the merits of the proposed pact with China.

Tsai argued that the pact, once inked, will obligate Taiwan to open its market to 90 percent of China's products under the rules of the World Trade Organization (WTO), meaning that Taiwan will have to open its market wider to Chinese agricultural products that are currently barred, to the detriment of the country's farmers.
But Ma said the obligation is not necessarily inherent to free trade pacts, citing a number of other free trade deals that have been signed around the world.

An agricultural official who spoke on condition of anonymity told CNA that Taiwan's free trade pact with Guatemala is a good example, because 15 percent of all products were not covered under the deal.
He also reiterated that Taiwan's pact with China will not cover agricultural products.

DOC.HEADLINE: ECFA to draw overseas machine tool makers back to Taiwan: businesses
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, April 25 (CNA) 04/25/10 22:00:46 (By Hsu Tsiang-hsin and Elizabeth Hsu)

TEXT.P: Local machine tool makers predicted Sunday that Taiwan's signing of an economic cooperation framework agreement (ECFA) with China will attract some Taiwanese businesses operating in China to relocate their factories back to the island.

The anticipated trend could cause a shortage of workers in the machine tool sector within three years after the planned trade pact is signed, predicted Kim Y.C. Tsai, chairman of the Taichung County-based Mobiletron Electronics Co.

Tsai explained machine tools are sophisticated products, and Taiwanese companies have refrained from using Chinese tools because they lack durability, he said in explaining why he did not think Chinese tools would pose a threat in the local market.

Also, taking increases of workers' wages and other benefits in China into account, there are no products in the machine tool sector that are cheaper than those made in Taiwan, said Mobiletron spokesperson Tsai Shu-chen.
Tool makers commented on the potential trade deal after President Ma Ying-jeou and opposition Democratic Progressive Party Chairwoman Tsai Ing-wen debated its merits in a 150-minute debate.

Tsai argued that although exports of Taiwan's machine tool and machinery products to China will enjoy lower duties thanks to the trade pact, it would harm the competitiveness of local industries in the long run.
She said under the World Trade Organization's most favored nation standard, duties on machinery were 1.95 percent.

But Hsieh Teng-tsai, an assistant manager at Kaohsiung County-based machine tool maker Tongtai Machine and Tool Co., said the sector's exports to China now face tariffs of between 5 percent and 8 percent.

DOC.HEADLINE: Taiwan's top shipmaker to deliver 3 ships to German firm
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, April 25 (CNA) 04/25/10 22:05:46 (By Alex Jiang)

TEXT.P: CSBC Corporation, Taiwan, the country's largest shipbuilder, will deliver three container ships to its biggest foreign customer Monday, the first time the company has made such a big delivery at once.
The large delivery made by CSBC, rare anywhere around the globe, indicates that the container shipping industry is recovering, the company said in a statement.
"You will see two container ships delivered at the same time, but not three, " said Sunny Yu, an executive of the company based in the southern port city of Kaohsiung.
CSBC will hand over two ships capable of carrying 6,600 20-foot containers and one ship with a capacity of 4,200 20-foot containers to Peter Doehle Schiffahrts-KG of Germany.

The Hamburg-based shipping fleet operator ordered the ships in 2006 and did not withdraw orders when the financial crisis broke out in 2008, though it did ask to put off delivery for four months, the statement said.

DOC.HEADLINE: President, DPP leader welcome more discussions on ECFA
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, April 25 (CNA) 04/25/10 22:10:20 (By Sofia Wu)

TEXT.P: Both President Ma Ying-jeou and opposition Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) Chairperson Tsai Ing-wen said after their historic debate Sunday that they welcomed more discussion on a proposed contentious trade pact with China.

The 150-minute televised debate on the Ma administration's plan to sign an economic cooperation framework agreement (ECFA) with China marked a new step in Taiwan's democracy. Never before had the country's head of state engaged an opposition leader in a public policy debate.
"The event will contribute to the deepening of Taiwan's democratization, " Ma, who concurrently heads the ruling Kuomintang, said at a post-debate news conference.
Although the debate featured biting dialogue, Ma praised Tsai for her professionalism, sincerity and open-mindedness during the showdown.
He further said the debate has helped him better understand the opposition camp's major concerns about the proposed trade pact with China.
"The government cannot afford to ignore public misgivings or fears, " Ma said, adding that he will see what the government can further do to alleviate public misgivings about the ECFA deal.

The debate began with Ma and Tsai each giving an eight-minute presentation on their stances on the deal, followed by a cross-examination period when each asked the other person five questions. Each then delivered a six-minute concluding statement.
In the debate, Ma said ECFA is essential to revive Taiwan's trade competitiveness and shield Taiwan from being marginalized amid mounting regional economic integration.
"If we don't do this deal, what else can we do? As the rest of Asia is building alliances, we and North Korea could be eliminated and become Asia's orphaned birds," Ma said.
According to Ma, the agreement will cover three main areas: tariff reductions and exemptions, investment protection, and intellectual rights protection.
However, Tsai warned that the deal would flood Taiwan with cheaper Chinese products and could fuel an increase in property prices.

She accused Ma of being too bullish on the agreement and of brushing aside what she described as widespread fears of Beijing's ulterior motives behind its promise of unilateral concessions in ECFA talks.
"President Ma, this is not a matter that can be dealt with romantically. It's something that's rife with many challenges, " she added.
Tsai expressed regret at a separate news conference that Ma failed to give convincing responses to many substantive issues she questioned him about in the debate.

They included contingency plans the government had if the ECFA talks with China broke down, the exact amount of tariff benefits Taiwan could reap under the ECFA deal, and measures to deal with the increasing gap between rich and poor caused by the deal.
While the DPP supports the strategy of using the Chinese market to beef up Taiwan's economic strength, Tsai the DPP calls for developing relations with China in a gradual manner.

She further said ECFA not only involves economic issues but will also affect the balance of power in entire Asia, warning that Taiwan's speedy economic integration with China may tilt strategic balance of power in Asia.

DOC.HEADLINE: Lu grabs ATP Challenger title in marathon three-setter
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, April 25 (CNA) 04/25/10 23:11:12 (By Luke Sabatier)

TEXT.P: Taiwan's Lu Yen-hsun denied Germany's Rainer Schuettler a joyful 34th birthday celebration Sunday by outlasting his occasional doubles partner 3-6, 7-6 (3) , 6-3 in the final of the 85,000-euro Status Athens Open.

The victory in the ATP Challenger event was the world No. 102 Lu's first title in 2010 and should move him back into the top 90, which will guarantee him automatic entry into the main draws of grand slam events.

The 26-year-old Taiwanese, seeded eighth in the tournament, had breezed through the first four rounds of the tournament without losing a set, while the seventh- seeded Schuettler had been stretched to three sets twice.

At the age of 34, considered ancient in men's tennis, Schuettler could have been forgiven if he showed signs of fatigue in the final, but he pushed his opponent all the way in the 2 hour, 26 minute battle.
Lu got off to a horrible start, spotting the German the first 12 points of the match to quickly fall behind 3-0.
He fought back and had two break points to keep the set alive with Schuettler serving at 5-4, but the former Australian Open finalist saved them and closed out the set.

In the second set, Lu ran off the final four points of the tiebreaker to pull even at a set apiece, and then moved clear of his German rival midway through the third set with only his second service break of the match.
The Taiwanese served out the final game at love to win his first tournament since taking an ATP Challenger event in South Korea last November, earning him 12,250 euros in prize money.
Opting to play more top-level ATP Tour events over the past 10 months, Lu has seen his ranking fall from a career high 55 in June 2009 after a string of mixed results against top-flight competition.
Twice this year, he has faced American Andy Roddick in the second rounds of the ATP Tour events, and lost in straight sets both times.

But rather than playing top-flight tourneys during the ATP's claycourt season leading up to the French Open in late May, Lu decided to enter second tier Challenger events, such as this week's 85,000-euro Athens event, on his preferred hardcourt surface to rack up ranking points, in part to ensure he will get free entry into the Wimbledon draw.

DOC.HEADLINE: DPP to press ahead with ECFA referendum after debate
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, April 25 (CNA) 04/25/10 20:57:57 (By Y.F. Low)

TEXT.P: The opposition Democratic Progressive Party will continue to push for a referendum on the proposed economic cooperation framework agreement (ECFA) with China, the party's chairwoman, Tsai Ing-wen, said Sunday.

"Our position on the referendum is very clear. We will press on toward the goal together with our ally, the Taiwan Solidarity Union (TSU) , " Tsai said in a news conference held immediately after her debate on the trade pact with President Ma Ying-jeou.
As a responsible leader, Ma should help facilitate the referendum and even have legislators from his Kuomintang cooperate with the DPP in promoting the vote, Tsai said.
She also said she could not remember Ma "answering any substantive questions" throughout the entire debate. However, she said, the DPP will welcome any chance for further debate on the issue.

On whether to go ahead with a plan to hold a massive demonstration against the ECFA, Tsai said her party will watch if Ma will adjust its attitude and drop the thinking that the agreement "must be signed no matter what" in June.
In the debate, the opposition leader described the ECFA policy as an ill-advised one that is based on a miscalculation of Taiwan's international situation.
She warned that Taiwan's premature economic integration with China could tilt the strategic balance in East Asia and even the whole of Asia.
The agreement will also force Taiwan to fully open its market to China in the next 10 years, leaving many Taiwan people out of work, according to Tsai.

In a separate news conference, Ma said he looks forward to holding further discussions with Tsai on the issue and that he will see if there are other things his administration can do to clear up the doubts held by the public.
Ma said the public should not see the signing of the ECFA as Taiwan taking a risk.
"If the agreement is signed, Taiwan's economic and trade status in East Asia will be very different," the president said.
On the referendum issue, Ma reiterated that initiating a referendum is part of the people's rights and that the government will not interfere as long as such an initiative is consistent with the law.

However, the government will not launch a referendum on the ECFA, because under the Referendum Act, the government is forbidden from doing so unless there is a situation threatening national security.
On Thursday, the TSU filed a new petition with the Central Election Commission for a referendum on the ECFA, eight months after a previous petition filed by the DPP was rejected.
The CEC will meet May 4 to determine if the new proposal meets legal requirements.

DOC.HEADLINE: Today in history
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, April 26 (CNA) 04/26/10 08:50:25
DOC.TEXT:
Today is Monday, April 26, or the 13th day of the third month of the Year of the Tiger according to the lunar calendar. Following is a list of important events that have occurred on this date in the past:
1452: Leonardo da Vinci, Italian painter, engineer, scientist and one of the most versatile artists of the Renaissance, is born. As a painter, he is best known for "The Last Supper" and "Mona Lisa."
1885: Britain occupies Port Hamilton, Korea.
1925: Paul von Hinderburg, German general and politician, is elected president of the Weimar Republic. He appointed Adolf Hitler as chancellor in 1933.
1946: Chinese communist troops take over Harbin and Tsitsihar as Soviet forces evacuate.
1954: The United Nations meets at Geneva and insists on free elections in Korea.
1960: The construction of the East-West Cross-Island Highway in Taiwan is completed.
1966: Mt. Kelud erupts in Java, Indonesia, killing some 1,000 people.
1971: A White House commission recommends that Communist China be brought into the United Nations, with the Republic of China on Taiwan retaining its membership.
1972: The eleven-member Chinese track and field team returns from Manila after winning 11 gold, 2 silver and 4 bronze medals in the three-day Philippine National Open Track and Field Championships.
1975: The Embassy of the Republic of China in Saigon suspends operations.
1975: Shortly before the fall of Saigon, former South Vietnamese President Nguyen Van Thieu and his wife arrive in Taipei for a temporary stay before going into exile in the United States.
1976: The Fourth Asian Writers Conference of International P.E.N. opens with some 90 leading writers in Asia, Europe and America attending.
1976: The government of the Republic of China and the government of the Republic of South Africa announce the elevation of their consulates general to embassy status.
1976: Brig. Gen. Dan A. Brooksher of the U.S. Air Force arrives to replace Brig. Gen. David O. Williams Jr. as chief of staff of the U.S. Taiwan Defense Command.
1983: Explosions occur in buildings occupied by the Central Daily News and the United Daily News in Taipei.
1984: U.S. President Ronald Reagan and his wife Nancy leave for a trip to mainland China.
1986: A nuclear reactor at the Chernobyl plant in the Ukraine explodes, spreading a radioactive cloud across Europe and causing grave pollution. It was the world's worst nuclear accident.
1989: Mainland students march to central Beijing to protest government statements condemning their campaign for democracy.
1994: A China Airlines A300-600 Airbus crashes at Nagoya airport in Japan, killing 264 aboard. There were only seven survivors.
1996: Communist China, Russia and three former Soviet republics sign a treaty aimed at reducing tensions along their common borders.
1997: Peng Zhen, a senior leader of Communist China, dies in Beijing at the age of 95.
1999: NATO planes destroy the Zezeljev railway bridge in Novi Sad during the Kosovo war.
2000: Rodolfo T. Reyes, the new defacto Philippine representative to the Republic of China in the absence of formal diplomatic ties between the two countries, arrives in Taipei to assume office.
2000: ROC President-elect Chen Shui-bian pays a visit to former Premier Hau Pei- tsun for talks on a wide range of issues.
2001: The ROC Ministry of Foreign Affairs congratulates Junichiro Koizumi on his election as Japanese prime minister.
Confucius' lesson of the day: "Be conscientious and sincere in what you say; be earnest and serious in what you do: in that way, although you might be in barbarous countries, you will get along well with men."

DOC.HEADLINE: Magnitude-6.6 earthquake hits Taiwan
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, April 26 (CNA) 04/26/10 11:52:38 (By Wang Shu-fen and Sofia Wu)

TEXT.P: An earthquake measuring 6.6 on the open-ended Richter scale struck Taiwan Monday, the Central Weather Bureau's Seismology Center said.
The earthquake hit at 10:59 a.m., with the epicenter located off the southeastern Taiwan coast, near the outlying island of Lanyu, also known as Orchid Island, the center said.
Buildings swayed in Taipei, but there were no immediate reports of casualties or damage.

DOC.HEADLINE: Liberty Times: Television propaganda on a big scale
DOC.DATELINE: 04/26/10 12:28:26 (By Elizabeth Hsu)

TEXT.P: The leaders of the ruling and largest opposition parties engaged in an unprecedented televised debate yesterday on a proposed economic cooperation framework agreement (ECFA) between Taiwan and China. Disappointingly, President Ma Ying-jeou, the force behind the ECFA initiative, failed to offer a clear and comprehensive policy statement. His presentation was nothing but large-scale TV propaganda.
In the debate, Ma avoided giving any direct responses to queries about the trade pact, including the question of what exactly is the ECFA.

The other questions asked were: What is the early harvest program? Why the reluctance to publicize that program? What are the monitoring mechanisms? How will the ECFA affect Taiwan's economy, particularly the employment market? How will the pact affect Taiwan's sovereignty? What is Taiwan's economic strategy?
It seems the Ma administration firmly believes that once it bombards the people with propaganda, it can fool them into thinking that the ECFA, a poisonous weed, is in fact a fragrant flower.

We hereby remind the Ma government that if it respects public opinion it should follow the rules of a democratic country and put the ECFA issue to referendum so that the country's 23 million people could decide whether or not Taiwan should sign the pact. (April 26. 2010).

DOC.HEADLINE: Talk of the day -- Is ECFA better understood after debate?
DOC.DATELINE: 04/26/10 12:30:55 (By Deborah Kuo)

TEXT.P: President Ma Ying-jeou's approval ratings surged after his Sunday debate with opposition Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) Chairperson Tsai Ing-wen on the signing of an economic cooperation framework agreement (ECFA) with China. The debate might be a boost to his re-election bid for 2012, but has it given the public a better understanding of the ECFA?

Ma said in the debate that he will guard Taiwan's sovereignty when signing the ECFA with China to bolster Taiwan's economy, while Tsai said the pact will put Taiwan's sovereignty at stake and be harmful to the country's economic standing.
The following are excerpts from local media coverage of the issue:
United Daily News:

A high of 67 percent of the respondents to a poll conducted immediately after the debate said they are concerned about the ECFA issue, but 59 percent of them said the debate did not help them find out more about the pros and cons of Taiwan's signing the ECFA with China.

Forty-two percent of the respondents to the United Daily News poll said they support the government's bid to forge the ECFA with China, while 30 percent were opposed and 28 percent offered no opinion.

Of the supporters of the ECFA, some 50 percent-60 percent were company owners or white-collar office workers. People from the agricultural, fishery and husbandry sectors showed the highest concern about the ECFA, with less than 20 percent supporting the bid and 49 percent opposed. (April 26, 2010).
China Times:
A total of 53 percent of the respondents to a survey conducted by the Want Want China Times Poll Center Sunday said they watched Sunday's televised debate and 47 percent said they did not watch it.
Of the respondents, 41 percent said Ma gave a better performance in the debate than Tsai, while 28 percent said Tsai performed better and 10 percent considered the two to be equally matched.

Sixty-three percent of the respondents said they had a clearer picture about the ECFA after watching the debate, while 26 percent said the debate did not help them better understand the cross-strait trade pact.
After the debate, public support for the ECFA rose to 48 percent, up 7 percentage points posted in a similar poll conducted in early April. (April 26, 2010).
The Liberty Times:

Thirty-six percent of the respondents to a poll conducted by the Liberty Times Sunday said they opposed the ECFA signing, 8 percentage points more than those who expressed support for it. Thirty-six percent offered no opinion.
After watching the debate, 80 percent of the respondents said their attitude toward the bid remained unchanged, and only 7 percent said their attitude had changed.

A total of 60 percent said that before Taiwan signs the ECFA with China, the people should be given a say via a nationwide referendum on the issue, while 23.7 percent said a referendum is not necessary.
Seventy-nine percent of the respondents said they still did not totally or even partially understand the trade pact with China, even after watching the Ma-Tsai debate. (April 26, 2010).

DOC.HEADLINE: President touts study in U.S.
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, April 26 (CNA) 04/26/10 12:42:46 (By Garfie Li and Deborah Kuo)

TEXT.P: President Ma Ying-jeou exhorted Taiwanese students Monday to pursue advanced studies in the United States as a means to broaden their views and build person-to-person relationships.

During a talk at the Presidential Office with William C. Kirby, a history professor at Harvard University and director of Harvard's Fairbank Center for Chinese Studies, Ma said the number of Taiwanese students going to the U.S. for advanced studies has declined over the past decade, while the number from China has steadily increased.
Ma, himself a Harvard alumnus, expressed hope that more students from Taiwan will attend first-class U.S. universities such as Harvard, for advanced studies.
"I hope Taiwan can maintain closer contact and cooperation with the academic sector in the United States," he said.

He said things have changed since he attended the Harvard Law School 30 years ago, in that the number of Taiwanese students in the U.S. at that time was much greater than that of Chinese students. He said the sliding number of Taiwanese students in the United States could be related to the fact that increasing numbers of Taiwanese students have been going to the United Kingdom or Australia to pursue advanced studies.

The president expressed his appreciation to Kirby for arranging a teleconference April 6 at the Fairbank Center that allowed him to address Harvard faculty members and students and take questions from the audience.

Ma delivered a 20-minute address at the conference, titled "The Quest for Modernity, " that covered a variety of issues, including Taiwan's experience in weathering the global economic downturn, the country's policy of pursuing cross- Taiwan Strait peace and flexible diplomacy, and the country's values of democracy and freedom.

DOC.HEADLINE: Magnitude-6.6 earthquake hits Taiwan (Update-1)
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, April 26 (CNA) 04/26/10 13:28:13 (By Wang Shu-fen and Sofia Wu)

TEXT.P: An earthquake measuring 6.6 on the open-ended Richter scale struck Taiwan Monday, the Central Weather Bureau's Seismology Center reported later that day.

The earthquake hit at 10: 59 a.m., with the epicenter located at sea 190.4 km northeast of the Lanyu seismic observation station on the outlying island of Lanyu, also known as Orchid Island, at a depth of 20 km, the center said.
The earthquake was felt throughout Taiwan, with buildings swaying in Taipei for up to 20 seconds, but there were no immediate reports of casualties or damage.
Seismologists said the earthquake was caused by the convergence of the Eurasian and Philippine Sea tectonic plates, and could be considered a normal release of energy.
Earthquakes frequently rattle Taiwan but most are minor and cause little or no damage. However, a magnitude-7.3 earthquake in central Taiwan on Sept. 21, 1999 killed more than 2,300 people.

DOC.HEADLINE: Economic Daily News: New chance brought about by debate
DOC.DATELINE: 04/26/10 14:13:21 (By Maubo Chang)

TEXT.P: The ruling and opposition parties outlined their different visions, policies and strategies toward China through the debate between President Ma Ying-jeou and opposition Democratic Progressive Party Chairperson Tsai Ing-wen Sunday.

The economy is Taiwan's lifeline, and Taiwan's economy depends largely on its trade with other states. In order to maintain its economic competitiveness, Taiwan has to integrate itself into regional trade blocks, but these efforts have always been blocked by China.
In the debate, Ma advocated his views of reconciling with China as a first step toward enhancing Taiwan's international role.

On the other hand, Tsai called for engaging with China under a multilateral framework, warning that a bilateral trade pact with China could contribute to China's dominance in Asia and paint Taiwan into a corner.

The advantages and disadvantages of the proposed pact were the focus of their debate, with Ma saying that the pact will allow Taiwan to make up for the eight years it lost during the DPP's time in office and usher in a golden decade in terms of the economy.

However, Tsai cast doubt on Ma's promise to not allow in any more Chinese agricultural products, saying that the pact will oblige Taiwan to open its market to 90 percent or more of Chinese goods tariff-free within 10 years.
Ma argued that this obligation is not necessarily part of a trade pact and that such obligations vary in time-frame and extent from deal to deal.

Tsai floated an alternative to the pact, suggesting negotiations with China on various issues separately, such as tariff exemptions, investment protection and intellectual property rights protection, rather than a single trade pact.
If Tsai's proposal were to be implemented in the next decade, it would not really be contrary to the government's plan.

The most noteworthy part of the debate is that although there was a trade of barbs, the two leaders did not find themselves stuck in the mire of partisan bickering that has been usual for past debates between the two sides.
We believe that the more such debates continue, the more clearly the facts will be exposed and the more likely the differences between the two sides will be ironed out. (April 26, 2010)

DOC.HEADLINE: American student to compete in Taiwanese talent show
DOC.DATELINE: Los Angeles, April 25 (CNA) 04/26/10 14:25:51 (By Leaf Jiang and Deborah Kuo)

TEXT.P: American university student Liz Williams beat 25 finalists Sunday to win first place in a talent competition organized by Taiwanese talent show Super Idol and a L.A.-based Chinese-language media outlet.

Williams came out in front with her rendition of a mandarin Chinese song titled "Ai Qing Wen Zen Mo Zou (Tell Me How Love Will Go On) , " winning her a spot on "Super Idol, " a talent show in Taiwan sponsored by a local TV channel that has drawn the participation of many talented young men and women, including Lin Yu- chun -- known as "Taiwan's Susan Boyle."
Williams and six other finalists will travel to Taipei in May to compete on the Super Idol show.
It was the first time that Super Idol had held its competition in North America and the show attracted more than 400 American competitors.
Williams, who began to learn Chinese soon after entering university, speaks fluent mandarin and filled in her contest application form in Chinese.
She disclosed that she heard the song "Ai Qing Wen Zen Mo Zou" only two weeks ago and found it appealing, and mastered singing it by going to a karaoke lounge to practice every day.

DOC.HEADLINE: Taiwan to enjoy 5.11% economic growth in 2010: think tank
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, April 26 (CNA) 04/26/10 14:39:56 (By Lin Huei-chun and Elizabeth Hsu)

TEXT.P: Taiwan will post a growth of 5.11 percent in real gross domestic product (GDP) in 2010 amid an overall economic recovery, the Taiwan Institute of Economic Research (TIER) forecast Monday, revising its previous prediction of 4.81 percent.
The latest figure represents a reversal from a 1.87 percent GDP contraction recorded in 2009, the TIER said in its monthly economic report released that day.
The institute also forecast that annual economic growth will reach 9.64 percent in the first quarter of the year, followed by 7.19 percent in Q2, 3.11 percent in Q3 and 1.52 percent in Q4.

TIER Macroeconomic Forecasting Center Director Chen Miao said the upward adjustment of the GDP growth in 2010 was made after researchers observed trends, including an increase in corporate intention and ability to launch investment projects.
Judging from that, TIER predicted that the investment growth rate will rise to 15.3 percent this year, while exports of both commodities and services will grow by 16.92 percent, Chen said.
In terms of private consumption, Chen said, TIER kept its previous forecast of 2.07 percent growth unchanged because the researchers did not see any factors that would affect the growth rate.
TIER President David S. Hong pointed out that the private consumption growth rate has rarely surpassed the 3 percent mark since 2000, restrained by unemployment and consumer prices.
In the TIER report, Taiwan's exports are projected to grow 26.83 percent and imports by 33.87 percent this year, which would translate into a trade surplus of US$24.879 billion.
TIER also forecast that wholesale prices will move higher by 5.27 percent due to increasing global demand and inflation caused by depreciation of the U.S. dollar.
Consumer prices are anticipated to grow 1.77 percent year-on-year, resulted from rising costs of raw materials and fuel, the report went on.

In terms of the local currency, the institute predicted that the New Taiwan dollar will see a trend of appreciation this year thanks to increasing demand for the major Asian currencies and a market situation that will put pressure on the U.S. dollar to depreciate.
In this regard, the institute forecast that the local unit will stand at an average of NT$31.35 against the greenback this year.

DOC.HEADLINE: China Times: Ma regains confidence through debate
DOC.DATELINE: 04/26/10 15:29:43 (By Maubo Chang)

TEXT.P: President Ma Ying-jeou demonstrated leadership in Sunday's debate and many political pundits said it brought out the best in him for the first time since 2008.

At the beginning of the debate, Ma pointed out the contradictions in the Democratic Progressive Party's criticism of the proposed trade pact with China, saying that when the DPP was in power it had approved the importation of 900 Chinese agricultural items, while his administration has approved none.

Also, the direct air links between Taiwan and China and Taiwan's wider opening to Chinese tourists began under the DPP administration, but were maintained only on a small scale throughout the DPP's eight years in power, he said.
Worst of all, Taiwan's global competitiveness ranking slid from 14th to 18th under the DPP administration, he added.

At the conclusion of the debate, the president foiled his rival's arguments by noting that the DPP's manifesto states Taiwan should develop comprehensive exchanges with China, including economic and trade cooperation, and seek long- term peace and stability across the Taiwan Strait.
Like a true leader, Ma said that he is well aware of Beijing political designs regarding Taiwan, but gave the assurance that he will not ink any pact with China unless it is beneficial to Taiwan.

He said he will personally lead a government task force that will be responsible for seeking free trade agreements with other countries, and he urged Beijing not to block Taiwan's efforts to achieve this goal.

Democratic Progressive Party Chairperson Tsai Ing-wen's performance paled in comparison to Ma's because she could not afford to offend her party base and was saddled with the DPP's poor record of governance.

She asked Ma why not forge free trade pacts with other states, but this is exactly what the DPP failed to do while in office. Then she expressed doubts that an "ASEAN plus three" economic grouping would ever materialize, ignoring the fact that the trade bloc was launched at the beginning of this year.

Her biggest accusation was that cross-strait trade is being dominated by relatives of top officials on both sides of the Taiwan Strait, but she was unable to provide any supporting facts and her charge was easily deflected by Ma. He promised to prosecute to the full extent of law anyone found guilty of Tsai's charge.
In the news conference after the debate, Tsai kept criticizing Ma, while Ma praised Tsai's performance and said he looked forward to other such exchanges with her.
The president gave voice to the people's views that Taiwanese are courageous and confident. We are pleased to see that the president is also confident. (April 26, 2010)

DOC.HEADLINE: Taiwan share prices close higher
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, April 26 (CNA) 04/26/10 15:41:57 (by Olivia Wang)

TEXT.P: Taiwan's share prices closed higher Monday with the weighted index, the market's key barometer, moving up 153.25 points, or 1.91 percent, to close at 8,158.14.
The local bourse opened at 8,107.22 and fluctuated between a low of 8,093.14 and a high of 8,168.47 during the day's trading. Market turnover totaled NT$135.7 billion (US$4.34 billion).

Seven of eight major stock categories gained ground, with financial and banking stocks and plastics and chemicals gaining the most at 2.6 percent, followed by textile issues at 2 percent. Machinery and electronics shares went up 1.7 percent, and foodstuff shares moved up 1.4 percent. Constructions issues were up 1 percent and cement issues gained 0.7 percent.
Paper and pulp issues fell 0.1 percent.
Gainers outnumbered losers 2,153 to 1,116, with 297 remaining unchanged.
Foreign investors and Chinese QDIIs were net buyers of NT$26.81 billion in shares.

DOC.HEADLINE: Premier breaks ground for housing project for typhoon victims
DOC.DATELINE: Kaohsiung, April 26 (CNA) 04/26/10 15:51:41 (By Chen Chao-fu and Deborah Kuo)

TEXT.P: Premier Wu Den-yih officiated at a groundbreaking ceremony Monday to kick off the construction of permanent housing in the southernmost county of Pingtung for people displaced by Typhoon Morakot last August.

The housing project, authorized by the Pingtung county government, will be carried out by non-profit charity organization the Buddhist Compassion Relief Tzu Chi Foundation in Pingtung's Changjhih Township.

The project, to be known as the Changjhih Tzu Chi Da Ai Community upon completion, will be located on a 30-hectare plot that used to house the Pingtung branch of the semi-official Central Broadcasting System of the Republic of China.
A total of 167 housing units will be built in the first phase of the project to accommodate Morakot victims from the county's Sandimen and Wutai townships.

Addressing the ceremony, Wu said Typhoon Morakot, one of the worst natural disasters to hit Taiwan that left more than 700 people dead or missing and more than 10,000 families homeless, has served to tap people's empathy for each other and to strengthen person-to-person ties.
He expressed appreciation to the Tzu Chi Foundation for its empathy and magnanimity toward the displaced Pingtung residents, most of whom are indigenous people.

One of the affected villagers also expressed his gratitude at the ceremony to the Pingtung county government and to the Tzu Chi Foundation for providing the housing, which he praised as having "a great design."

DOC.HEADLINE: MOI planning regulations to publicize housing transaction data
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, April 26 (CNA) 04/26/10 16:04:18 (By Chou Yung-chieh and Y.L. Kao)

TEXT.P: The Ministry of the Interior (MOI) will formulate a package of regulations within three months, requiring that information on real estate transactions be published regularly, as part of the government's efforts to curb rising housing prices, Interior Minister Jiang Yi-huah said Monday.
Jiang said at a legislative session that his ministry is mapping out complementary measures and enforcement rules and will submit the proposal to the Cabinet within three months.

The regulations will be put into force in six months time if there is no need to amend related laws, said Jiang in response to a call by ruling Kuomintang Legislator Lai Shyh-bao's call for the MOI to make housing transaction data more transparent.
The exorbitant price of housing units in urban areas was listed as one of the public's top 10 complaints last year in a poll, Lai noted.

The Legislative Yuan passed a resolution last year, requesting that the MOI and the Financial Supervisory Commission regularly publish the prices paid for housing units around the country, in order to prevent inflated valuations by private institutions and consequently higher market prices.

DOC.HEADLINE: Taiwan aquaculture facing stiff competition from China
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, April 26 (CNA) 04/26/10 16:18:55 (By Frances Huang)

TEXT.P: Tilapia growers in Liuchia in southern Taiwan's Tainan County threw a banquet Sunday to promote their product in the domestic market amid falling exports and strong competition from China.
With more and more Taiwan's tilapia farmers relocating their investments to China, the island's tilapia business has seen a steep decline in exports, while China's exports of the fish have jumped.

According to the United Evening News, China's frozen tilapia exports to the U.S. totalled 29,672 metric tons in 2009, while Taiwan's were 13,180 metric tons. China's frozen tilapia fillet sales to the U.S. last year hit 10,691 metric tons, far in excess of Taiwan's 2,333 metric tons.
China is now the largest tilapia exporter to the U.S., the newspaper said.

In an effort to mitigate the effects of weakening exports, local tilapia farmers are giving more attention to the domestic market. However, an increase in local supply has dragged down domestic prices by 29 percent to 34 percent.

About 90 percent of Taiwan's tilapia species are being grown in China as the industry is moving more and more of its capital there. In addition, Taiwan investors have taken Taiwan's advanced breeding technologies to China, which is now producing a better quality product than Taiwan.

Hung San-yi, secretary general of the Tainan fishery association, said China's strength in the aquaculture business cannot be ignored. The Taiwan government and the industry itself will have to figure out the best strategy to combat the stiff competition from China, he added.

Su Huan-chih, magistrate of Tainan County which is the center of tilapia breeding in Taiwan, said the government has to come up with concrete measures to enhance Taiwan's global distribution network and also has to establish a certification mechanism to differentiate between the products on the two sides of the Taiwan Strait.

Su said he is worried that Taiwan's tilapia growers will suffer even more once an economic cooperation framework agreement (ECFA) with China is signed as it will require Taiwan to eventually open its market wider to Chinese products.

In the next round of high-level cross-strait negotiations scheduled for the middle of this year, Taiwan will seek to include protective measures in relevant agreements to protect the local agriculture sector from the effects of a wider market opening, according to the Council of Agricu lture (COA).
In addition, local agricultural businesses are expected to be required to pay a significant sum for licenses to move their operations to China, the COA said.
Furthermore, the COA said, Taiwan will implement strict rules on place-of-origin identification of its fishery products.

DOC.HEADLINE: U.S. dollar down on Taipei Forex
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, April 26 (CNA) 04/26/10 17:10:17 (By Olivia Wang)

TEXT.P: The U.S. dollar lost ground against the New Taiwan dollar on the Taipei Foreign Exchange Monday, dropping NT$0.101 to close at NT$31.359.
A total of US$1.20 million changed hands during the trading session.
The U.S. dollar opened at the day's high of NT$31.460 and fell to NT$31.288 before rebounding.

DOC.HEADLINE: Taiwanese scholar receives electronics, photonics award
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, April 26 (CNA) 04/26/10 17:25:46 (By Sunnie Chen)

TEXT.P: Academia Sinica scholar Chen Lih-juann has been awarded the 2010 Electronics and Photonics Division Award by the Electrochemical Society (ECS) of Canada, Taiwan's top research institute announced Monday.
Chen is also president of National Tsing Hua University (NTHU) , where he is a distinguished chair professor.

The award is in recognition of his "long-term and outstanding research on metallization in integrated circuit devices, thin film reactions, atomic scale structures and dynamics of nanomaterials, " according to the institute.

The award ceremony took place Sunday, the first day of the 217th ECS Meeting in Vancouver, Canada, held between April 25 and April 30. Chen was presented with an award scroll, a cash prize and a lifetime membership of the ECS.
The ECS is a US-based non-profit organization founded in 1902. Today it has more than 8,000 individual members in over 70 countries worldwide, as well as roughly 100 corporate members.

Chen has conducted extensive research on advanced metallization in integrated circuits over the last 30 years. Recently, his focus has been on the investigation of low-dimensional nanostructured materials. He has published more than 420 papers in internationally recognized journals.

DOC.HEADLINE: Election Commission to redraw lawmakers' constituencies
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, April 26 (CNA) 04/26/10 17:32:07 (By Hsieh Jian-chen and Maubo Chang)

TEXT.P: A public hearing was held Monday by the Central Election Commission to sound out public opinion on the redrawing of lawmakers' constituencies in three of the four new special municipalities to be formed by the end of this year.

Teng Tien-you, secretary-general of the commission, said the redrawing of the constituencies is necessary for the municipalities of Taichung, which will be formed through a merger of the existing Taichung City and Taichung County; Tainan, which will consist of a merger of the existing Tainan City and Tainan County; and Kaohsiung, which will be a merger of the existing Kaohsiung County and Kaohsiung City.

In the three new municipalities, the number of lawmakers in Kaohsiung will total eight, one seat less than the combined number of the present Kaohsiung City and Kaohsiung County, and six in Tainan, one seat more than the combined number in Tainan County and Tainan City. The actual number of seats will remain unchanged in Taichung.

Redrawing the lawmaker's constituencies is not necessary in the two other municipalities -- the already existing Taipei City and the upgraded Taipei County, to be called Xinbei City -- because their administrative regions will not be changed.
Teng said the redrawing of the constituencies will be finished and presented to the Legislative Yuan for approval by May 31 as required by law.

Hsu Yang-ming, deputy mayor of Tainan City, opposed the redrawing at the hearing, saying that the constituencies were redrawn as recently as 2007 and are set to be divided yet again after the redrawing of administrative districts in the new municipalities that is set to take place after municipality chief elections at the end of this year.
He suggested leaving the existing constituencies unchanged until the redrawing of administrative districts in the new municipalities.

His opinion was supported by Legislator Huang Chao-shun, a ruling Kuomintang lawmaker from Kaohsiung. Huang said the commission's plan to cut the number of Kaohsiung lawmakers by one is certain to be rejected by the Legislative Yuan, along with its plan to drastically re-organize the municipality's constituencies.
Instead of changing the constituencies, she suggested, the commission should ask the Legislature Yuan to leave them unchanged.
However, Teng said the commission will carry out its duties according to the law.

DOC.HEADLINE: Premier boosts rescue efforts after freeway landslide
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, April 26 (CNA) 04/26/10 18:05:21 (By Bien Chin-feng, Chen Chin-ping and Elizabeth Hsu)

TEXT.P: Premier Wu Den-yih Monday ordered more manpower and machinery to be employed for rescue missions on the No. 3 Freeway between Taipei and Keelung in northern Taiwan.

"Saving lives is the current priority, " he said during a visit to southern Taiwan's Pingtung County. Meanwhile, he added, the Ministry of Transportation and Communications and the Keelung City government have outlined transportation alternatives for commuters on the national freeway.

Without an obvious cause like an earthquake or human activity, a slope slid the previous day from the eastern side of the freeway at the 3.1-kilometer mark from the northern end, just north of the Chitu toll station, burying more than 300 meters of road.

Earlier Monday, the Keelung City Fire Bureau said it had received nine phone calls for help to search for missing cars after the incident occurred. It contacted the owners of seven vehicles suspected of being buried in landslide, but there are still two cars missing, the bureau said.

As of noon Monday, no people or vehicles had been discovered in the dirt and rocks that buried the freeway. Taiwan Area National Freeway Bureau Director General Tseng Ta-jen said efforts to clear the road were proceeding faster than scheduled.
"The work is expected to be completed two weeks ahead of plans, " he said, noting that it is still unclear whether people are trapped in the rubble.
According to Tseng, nearly 120 vehicles, including 45 excavators, and over 900 personnel had been mobilized for the project.
It was estimated that 200,000 cubic meters of dirt and rocks poured onto the road in what was the worst landslide ever on a freeway in the country, the national freeway bureau said.
Lin Chao-chung, director of the Ministry of Economic Affairs' Central Geological Survey, attributed the landslide to rock anchors -- steel reinforcers -- in restraining walls along the freeways.
Faulty construction or wear on the anchors could have led to the slide, Lin said.
An investigation into the incident has been launched.
That section of the freeway was opened in 2000.

The 430.5 km-long No. 3 National Freeway was the second North-South freeway built in Taiwan. It begins at Jijin Interchange on Provincial Highway No. 2, or Jijin Road, in Keelung City and ends on Provincial Highway No. 17 in Pingtung County's Linbian. The construction began in 1987, and the first completed section was opened for traffic in 1993.

DOC.HEADLINE: Minister touts revision of law dividing government revenues
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, April 26 (CNA) 04/26/10 18:07:40 (By Chen Shu-fen and Maubo Chang)

TEXT.P: Minister of Finance Lee Sush-der said the revamping of a law governing how government revenues are allocated is meant to funnel more funds to local governments.

At a seminar with finance officials from the counties of Taoyuan, Hsinchu and Miaoli, the minister assured local governments that they will get a bigger share of revenues than before after the Law Governing the Allocation of Government Revenues and Expenditures is revised.
Under a proposed amendment, the central government will distribute NT$100 billion more to local governments according to a fixed formula.
The government will also provide incentives to help township governments under the counties, which currently raise an average of 40-70 percent of their revenues, become 65-70 percent self-sufficient.

DOC.HEADLINE: Growing service sector seen as improving Taiwan's job market
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, April 26 (CNA) 04/26/10 18:35:14 (By Feng Chao and Frances Huang)

TEXT.P: Taiwan's growing service sector, particularly tourism, has the potential to strengthen the local job market and mitigate the impact of structural unemployment, a think tank said Monday.

David Hong, president of the Taiwan Institute of Economic Research (TIER) , said the service sector accounts for 70 percent of Taiwan's gross domestic product (GDP) , and if it can sustain its growth, the domestic job market will improve accordingly.

He specifically cited the tourism, retail, and health care sectors as labor- intensive service industries that could offset unemployment caused by structural changes to the local economy, such as factories relocating offshore.

Tourism especially has been one of the bright spots in the domestic economy, fueled by a dramatic rise in the number of Chinese visitors in the first quarter of the year as cross-Taiwan Strait ties improve.

A total of 344,136 Chinese nationals visited Taiwan in the first three months of 2010, up 98.64 percent from a year earlier, making China the largest source of visitors to the island. More than 1 million Chinese arrivals are expected this year.

Hong cautioned, however, that as local businesses continue to move overseas, the country's jobless rate, which fell slightly in March to 5.67 percent, is unlikely to drop below 3 percent in the near future.

During his election campaign in early 2008, President Ma Ying-jeou pledged to bring unemployment down to 3 percent during his term, but that goal was derailed when the global financial crisis took its toll on Taiwan's economy.
Meanwhile, the think tank revised its forecast of Taiwan's 2010 GDP growth to 5.11 percent from a previous estimate of 4.81 percent on rising investment as the global economy recovers.
It also expected private consumption in 2010 to grow 2.07 percent, compared with 1.48 percent in 2009.

DOC.HEADLINE: CLA minister defends minimum wage policy for foreign workers
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, April 26 (CNA) 04/26/10 18:50:00 (By Chen Shun-hsieh and Y.L. Kao)

TEXT.P: Council of Labor Affairs (CLA) Minister Wang Ju-hsuan reiterated Monday that she will step down if wages for foreign workers are delinked from the nation's minimum wage.

After Premier Wu Den-yih floated the concept earlier in the month that the link should be removed within certain economic and trade zones to allow lower wages for foreign workers and thereby attract foreign investment, ruling Kuomintang Legislator Luo Shu-lei brought forward a proposal to amend the Labor Standards Act to abolish the regulation that applies the country's minimum wage of NT$17,280 to migrant workers.

The proposed amendments have sparked outrage and protests among labor and immigrant advocacy groups, some of which rallied in front of the Legislative Yuan Monday, demanding that Wang resign over the matter.

Pressured by opposition Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) Legislator Huang Sue-ying, Wang said at a legislative session that she remained consistent in her opposition to the delinkage and that she made it clear long before she assumed her post that she would resign if she failed to uphold the bottom line.
No other countries that have adopted a minimum wage policy have waived the minimum wage requirement for migrant workers, Wang argued.

According to Wang, there is no legal minimum wage in Singapore or Hong Kong, where salaries are usually negotiated between employers and employees based on what the job entails. Despite this, the wages paid to foreign workers in the two countries are similar to those in Taiwan, she added.

Wang said one employer told her that a U.S. human rights report ranking Taiwan as a place unfriendly to foreign workers once caused him to lose an order worth NT$50 million (US$1.59 million). If the link is removed, the situation will become even worse and create an even greater barrier for Taiwan to negotiate free trade agreements with other countries, she predicted.
Wang said she will fight until the very end to make sure the policy remains unchanged.

DOC.HEADLINE: Dust storm likely to hit Taiwan
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, April 26 (CNA) 04/26/10 19:41:22 (By Lin Szu-Yu and Hsin-Yin Lee)

TEXT.P: Taiwan is likely to be affected by a dust storm swept over from China as early as Tuesday afternoon, the Environmental Protection Administration (EPA) warned Monday.
According to the EPA, sand particles in the air could reach 350 micrograms per cubic meter, which is five to six times the normal amount.

However, with a cold front affecting Taiwan late Monday, showers were expected across the country, which could alleviate the effects of the pollution, the EPA said, adding that the extent of the impact will depend on the actual amount of rain, as well as the wind direction.

Chu Yu-chi, director-general of the EPA's environmental monitoring and information management unit, said that since the weather tends to be unstable in the spring, the routes and durations of dust storms are difficult to predict.
The EPA placed further information on the dust storm on its website at http://dust.epa.gov.tw/dust/zh-tw/b0301.aspx.

DOC.HEADLINE: Red dot signs design congress MOU with Taiwan
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, April 26 (CNA) 04/26/10 20:24:44 (By Sunnie Chen)

TEXT.P: The president of red dot award, Peter Zec, signed a memorandum of understanding (MOU) Monday with Michael T.L. Lin, deputy CEO of the Taiwan Design Center, to become one of the global partners of the 2011 International Design Alliance (IDA) Design Congress Taipei.

The red dot design award is a large and coveted international product design prize awarded by the Design Zentrum Nordrhein Westfalen in Essen, Germany. The aim of the prize is to honor outstanding design quality. It has been described as the "Oscars of the design field" and is one of the most important design awards in the world.

"Through cooperation with the organization, Taiwan can extend its connections with other countries in Europe, " said Connie Chang, a senior specialist of the knowledge services division of the Industrial Development Bureau under the Ministry of Economic Affairs.
The 2011 IDA Congress will be held Oct. 24-26 next year in Taipei, and will be the first congress since the establishment of the IDA in 2007, said Lin, who is one of the organizers.
Lin said the congress is expected to attract a lot of overseas designers, as the IDL has also signed MOUs with six associations from Thailand, Japan and several other countries.
"This year, Taiwan has 68 creative products that have won red dot awards," he added.
Zec lauded the achievements Taiwan has made in the awards, saying they are "the best results ever" and describing the quality of Taiwanese products as "really competitive."
Red dot has an extensive international network, Zec noted, and said it can make very good use of it to promote the 2011 event overseas..

DOC.HEADLINE: EasyCard launches service counter in Kaohsiung
DOC.DATELINE: Kaohsiung, April 26 (CNA) 04/26/10 20:30:42 (By Wang Shu-fen and Fanny Liu)

TEXT.P: Taipei-based EasyCard Corporation opened its first service counter in Kaohsiung Monday, a move aimed at helping boost the number of its stored value EasyCards in circulation by 10 percent before the end of the year, a company official said Monday.
Sean Lien, the company's chairman, said the average number of transactions with the card in the southern port city has already reached 10,000 per day and continues to rise.

The growth momentum is expected to continue with the addition of the service center and next year's planned integration of the EasyCard with the I Pass card system used by Kaohsiung City's Mass Rapid Transit (MRT).
The new service counter was set up near the Ubus ticket counter in front of the Kaohsiung Railway Station and provides sales, refund and add-value services.
There are currently 18 million EasyCards (including co-branded cards) in circulation, and the company wants to increase the number to 20 million by the end of 2010, Lien said.
The IC non-contact cards are widely used in Taipei's transportation network and can now also be used for transactions under NT$1,000 in designated convenience stores.

DOC.HEADLINE: Lawmakers stand by ban on foreign workers
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, April 26 (CNA) 04/26/10 20:45:00 (By Chen Shun-hsieh and Y.L. Kao)

TEXT.P: Legislators on Monday urged the Council of Labor Affairs (CLA) to strengthen checks on the hiring of foreign workers for construction projects as there are still nearly 1,000 foreign laborers despite a ban on foreign workers for new projects.

The Legislative Yuan last April approved a four-year, NT$500 billion (US$15.94 billion) special budget bill to expand investment in major public construction projects aimed at stimulating the economy, which was accompanied by a resolution to impose such a ban.

According to the results of checks on labor hiring, 963 foreign workers are working on projects commissioned by the Ministry of Transportation and Communications, while 32 others are working on those by the Ministry of the Interior's Construction and Planning Agency.
In view of the situation, the Legislative Yuan's Social Welfare and Environmental Hygiene Committee reiterated the ban Monday and asked the CLA to intensify on-spot checks.
However, the CLA reported that the above-mentioned foreign workers have been hired legally before the resolution and that the council can not ask their employers to dismiss those workers.

DOC.HEADLINE: President impressed by CSBC's delivery of three ships in one day
DOC.DATELINE: Kaohsiung, April 26 (CNA) 04/26/10 20:47:24 (By Alex Jiang and Sofia Wu)

TEXT.P: President Ma Ying-jeou on Monday hailed CSBC Corp., Taiwan's delivery of three container ships to a German customer in a single day, saying it was a feat rarely seen even in major shipbuilding countries such as Japan and South Korea.

Addressing a joint christening and delivery ceremony for the three ships at a CSBC shipyard in the southern port city of Kaohsiung, Ma also lauded German shipping company Peter Dohle Schiffahrts-KG for its decision not to cancel its orders with CSBC despite the 2008-2009 global financial crisis.
"I came here to especially express my gratefulness to Peter Dohle and other companies that decided not to cancel the orders. This is obviously a wise decision, " Ma said at the ceremony.

"I also want to stress it is our strategy for making Taiwan the innovation center of the world, the springboard for investment in Asia, and the global headquarters location for Taiwanese companies and regional headquarters location for multinational corporations, " the president said.

More than a year ago, Ma said, Taiwan's economy faced harsh challenges amid a global economic downturn. Through concerted public and private efforts, Taiwan has emerged from a year-long recession, with exports rebounding almost to pre- crisis levels, he added.

Citing a recent International Monetary Fund (IMF) forecast, Ma said Taiwan is expected to outpace the other Asian Tigers -- South Korea, Hong Kong and Singapore -- with a 6.5 percent growth rate, coupled with a 1.5 percent inflation rate.
Moreover, he said, the IMF report predicts Taiwan will lead the three other Asian Tigers for most of the next five years.

Ma further said he hopes the current export recovery will help fuel growth in various industrial sectors, including the shipbuilding industry, so that Taiwan can realize its ambitious goal of connecting with the Asia Pacific region and reaching out to the world.
The ships delivered Monday include two vessels that can accommodate 6,600 20-foot containers and one ship capable of carrying 4,200 20-foot containers.

DOC.HEADLINE: Guang Hua Digital Plaza doing stellar business
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, April 26 (CNA) 04/26/10 20:51:14 (By Hsin-Yin Lee)

TEXT.P: The Guang Hua Digital Plaza, one of Taiwan's most famous technological and electronic goods malls, has come a long way since its original incarnation as a grubby and dank market, and now attracts more than 15,000 customers on weekdays and around 23,000 on weekends.

The original Guang Hua market, which was a crowded warren of tiny aisles established in 1973 under the Guang Hua Bridge, formerly specialized in used books, athletic products and to a far lesser extent in computer hardware.
When the bridge was demolished as part of a road-widening project, the market moved to its present location, a purpose-built building at the corner of Jinshan North Road and Civic Boulevard.
The cluster effect of sellers has made the plaza a Mecca for 3C electronics customers and ensures that the merchandise remains competitive in terms of price and quality, market analysts said.
Lin Wen-wei, owner of De Tzung Computers in the plaza, applauded the city government's relocation of the market.

To make sure the plaza and the surrounding district continues to provide 3C goods, the Taipei city government is launching the second phase of a BOT project to develop the plot of land immediately to the west of the plaza into a digital theme park and an animation merchandise mall.

DOC.HEADLINE: Chinese delegation from Hubei leaves Taiwan
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, April 26 (CNA) 04/26/10 21:05:52 (By Fanny Liu)

TEXT.P: A 1,000-person delegation from central China's Hubei Province left Taiwan Monday after a visit that a top official from the province said enhanced exchanges and cooperation between Hubei and Taiwan.

Luo Qingquan, secretary of the Hubei Provincial Committee of the Communist Party of China, said that both sides agreed to enhance cooperation in the agriculture and fishery sectors and in the religious, cultural and educational fields.

As Hubei has a wealth of agricultural products, Taiwan's know-how in processing agricultural goods could have a promising outlook in Hubei, Luo said at the Taiwan Taoyuan International Airport after an eight-day visit.
The delegation placed more than US$500 million in orders for more than 30 types of products during the visit.
Luo said the delegation attended more than 40 activities during the visit, which helped enhance mutual understanding and exchanges.
The delegation also attended "Taiwan-Hubei Wuhan Week", which started in 2004 and has been held in Wuhan for the past six years. It was the first time Taiwan has hosted the large-scale event.

DOC.HEADLINE: KMT to finalize municipal election nominees by May 19
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, April 26 (CNA) 04/26/10 21:21:37 (By Garfie Li and Y.L. Kao)

TEXT.P: The ruling Kuomintang (KMT) plans to conduct nominations in two rounds for the year-end five special municipality mayoral elections, with all the five candidates to be finalized by May 19, KMT spokesman Su Jun-pin said Monday.

Taipei Mayor Hau Lung-bin, Vice Premier Eric Liluan Chu, Taichung Mayor Jason Hu and Legislator Huang Chao-shun are likely candidates to represent the KMT in the Nov. 27 elections in Taipei City, Xinbei City, Greater Taichung City and Greater Kaohsiung City.

In Greater Tainan City, two potential contenders -- former KMT lawmakers Lee Chuan-chiao and Kuo Tien-tsai -- are within the statistical margin of error after two polls and the party will begin mediation efforts between them to single out the best candidate, Su said.
Kuo had a slim lead over Lee in both of the polls, a KMT source disclosed.

The nominations will be passed on to a KMT task force charged with consulting candidates and screened by a nomination review committee before being submitted to the KMT Central Standing Committee for final approval.
Other than the nominee for Tainan, the candidates for the other four special municipalities will be finalized in the first round of nominations, Su said.
Asked about whether Chu will resign from the post of vice premier if he is nominated, Su said it would be decided by Chu and Premier Wu Den-yih.
Chu said a few days ago that he will go all out to win if he is nominated.

After the elections, Greater Kaohsiung City will be a merger of Kaohsiung City and Kaohsiung County; Greater Tainan City will be a merger of Tainan City and Tainan County; Greater Taichung City will be a merger of Taichung City and Taichung County; and Taipei County will be upgraded to Xinbei City.

DOC.HEADLINE: Party drug mephedrone found for the first time in Taiwan
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, April 26 (CNA) 04/26/10 22:06:39 (By Chen Li-ting and Fanny Liu)

TEXT.P: The Department of Health (DOH) announced Monday that the party drug mephedrone was found for the first time in Taiwan recently, and it warned the public of the serious effects it can have on people's health and lives.
According to the Food and Drug Administration under the DOH, some drugs containing mephedrone were found in a batch of illegal drugs seized by the Aviation Police Office recently.

Cheng Chin-feng, an official with the Division of Controlled Drugs, said that according to information obtained, mephedrone is a new substance produced in China that was exported to Europe as a chemical fertilizer beginning in 2008.
Because the substance is relatively new, all that's known about its composition is that it is similar to amphetamine, Cheng said.

As the drug only takes a short time to exert its effect, users may keep applying the drugs, and that may cause severe constriction of the blood vessels, heart attack, irregular pulse, anxiety, and even death, he said.
Mephedrone, also known as meow meow, Meow, or M-Cat, is now officially a Class B controlled drug in the U.K., and an illegal drug in Germany and Sweden.
Worried about the spread of the new drug, the DOH will recommend to the Ministry of Justice that it classify mephedrone as a controlled drug, Cheng said.
He indicated that mephedrone has caused many deaths in other countries, citing a girl in the U.K. who died just a few hours after taking a drug containing both ketamine and mephedrone.

DOC.HEADLINE: Banks should be allowed to offer loans to foreign shipowners: CSBC
DOC.DATELINE: Kaohsiung, April 26 (CNA) 04/26/10 22:20:51 (By Alex Jiang and Sofia Wu)

TEXT.P: Taiwan's government should create an environment favorable for local shipbuilding companies to compete with their foreign rivals, the head of the country's largest shipbuilder urged Monday.

CSBC Corporation, Taiwan Chairman Cheng Wen-lon made the appeal in an interview with the Central News Agency on the sidelines of a ceremony celebrating the delivery of three CSBC-built container vessels to German shipping company Peter Dohle Schiffahrts-KG.

One of the most effective steps the government could take to boost the competitiveness of local shipbuilders would be to permit Taiwanese banks to offer financing to potential foreign buyers, Cheng said.

Insisting that CSBC can compete technologically with Japanese, Korean and Chinese shipbuilders, Cheng said it would gain more leverage in pursuing foreign orders if local banks were allowed to provide financing to its potential customers.
China, Japan and South Korea jointly control 90 percent of the world's total commercial shipbuilding market, while Taiwan only has a 0.8 percent share, Cheng said.

"What we rely on in competing with foreign shipbuilders is our technical expertise and our fine workmanship and quality, " Cheng said proudly. But the company would do better if the government could create a business environment on a par with the major shipbuilding countries, he said.

Noting that China has done much to prop up its shipbuilding industry, Cheng said Japan, South Korea and other powers in the industry have all offered financing on attractive terms to help attract foreign customers for their shipbuilders.

As for its delivery of the three container vessels Monday, Cheng said it was fortunate that Peter Dohle only asked for a four-month delay in the delivery of its ships, considering that the global container shipping industry was hard hit by the 2008-2009 global financial crisis.
One of CSBC's customers, an Israeli company, actually canceled its orders because of the downturn, Cheng said.

The German company placed orders for 12 container vessels with CSBC in 2006. After Monday's delivery of two vessels capable of carrying 6,600 20-foot containers and a vessel that can accommodate 4,200 20-foot containers, six more vessels are still to be delivered.
"German shippers are known to be demanding of high quality. Our technology has helped us secure orders from Peter Dohle, " Cheng said.

DOC.HEADLINE: Four stations to be added to Taiwan high speed rail
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, April 26 (CNA) 04/26/10 22:34:10 (By Cheng Yun-hsuan and Y.L. Kao)

TEXT.P: The Council for Economic Planning and Development (CEPD) passed a construction proposal to add four stations to the Taiwan high speed rail system by 2015 to increase passengers by about 5 percent, a CEPD official said Monday.
Under the plan, Nangang Station in Taipei City is scheduled to be completed in October 2012, and Miaoli, Changhua and Yunlin stations are scheduled for June 2015, the official said.

In January 2010, the daily number of passengers using the rail system averaged 93,000, with an average seat use rate of about 46 percent. After the additional stations are completed, the passenger load is estimated to increase by 5 percent, the official added.

The project would cost NT$52 million (US$1.65 million) for construction of Miaoli, Changhua and Yunlin stations and related facilities, NT$191 million for compensation for requisition of land and resettlement for residents of demolished houses, and NT$289 million for construction supervision and management. The Taiwan High Speed Rail Corp. will provide NT$7.5 billion for the project, according to the official.

He also said that in 2002 the Executive Yuan approved plans to transform the Nangang preparatory station into an auxiliary operation station to ease traffic jams, adding that an additional NT$1.70 billion has been earmarked for construction of the station.

DOC.HEADLINE: NTU professor wins Nikkei Asia prize for research on hepatitis B
DOC.DATELINE: Tokyo, April 16 (CNA) 04/26/10 22:37:55 (By Yang Ming-chu and Lilian Wu)

TEXT.P: Chen Ding-shinn, a professor of National Taiwan University College of Medicine, has won the Nikkei Asia prize.
Chen was among three winners announced by the online version of Nihon Keizai Shimbun.
It said that Chen, 66, was awarded in honor of his accomplishment in discovering a link between the hepatitis B virus and liver cancer.

His prizeworthy contribution in creating a public health program in Taiwan more than 20 years ago that has vaccinated nearly all newborns in the country against hepatitis B drastically reduced the incidence of liver cancer, it added.

Launched by Nikkei Inc. in 1996, the awards program honors people in Asia who have made significant contributions in three areas: regional growth; science, technology and innovation; and culture. The prizes target individuals and groups in northeast, southeast, southern and central Asia, excluding Japan.
In addition to the honor, the winners receive 3 million yen (US$31,480). The award ceremony will be held May 19 in Tokyo.

Before Chen, three Taiwanese have been honored with the same award: Hsu Wen- lung, founder of the Chi Mei Group, and Taiwan Semiconductor Manufacturing Co. Chairman Morris Chang, both in the regional growth category; and Chang Chun-yen, former National Chiao Tung University president, in the science, technology and innovation category.

DOC.HEADLINE: Matsu parade returns home to Jenn Lann Temple
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, April 26 (CNA) 04/26/10 22:42:43 (By Lee Hsi-chang and James Lee)

TEXT.P: Matsu, the Chinese goddess of the sea and Taiwan's most worshipped deity, returned home to Jenn Lann Temple in central Taiwan's Dajia township Sunday after a 340-kilometer procession through central and southern Taiwan.
The annual Matsu pilgrimage, which is usually held in the third lunar month of the year, began on April 16 and stopped at 102 temples in Taichung, Changhua, Yunlin, and Chiayi counties.
The ritual, one of Taiwan's most prominent religious events, lasted nine days this year, one day longer than usual, and attracted more than 1 million followers, temple sources said Monday.
The palanquin carrying the likeness the goddess was greeted enthusiastically by worshippers when it arrived at Jenn Lann Temple shortly after 11 p.m. Sunday.
Yen Ching-piao, head of the temple who is also a legislator, helped seat the palanquin to conclude the pilgrimage.
