Before Chen, three Taiwanese have been honored with the same award: Hsu Wen- lung, founder of the Chi Mei Group, and Taiwan Semiconductor Manufacturing Co. Chairman Morris Chang, both in the regional growth category; and Chang Chun-yen, former National Chiao Tung University president, in the science, technology and innovation category.

DOC.HEADLINE: Matsu parade returns home to Jenn Lann Temple
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, April 26 (CNA) 04/26/10 22:42:43 (By Lee Hsi-chang and James Lee)

TEXT.P: Matsu, the Chinese goddess of the sea and Taiwan's most worshipped deity, returned home to Jenn Lann Temple in central Taiwan's Dajia township Sunday after a 340-kilometer procession through central and southern Taiwan.
The annual Matsu pilgrimage, which is usually held in the third lunar month of the year, began on April 16 and stopped at 102 temples in Taichung, Changhua, Yunlin, and Chiayi counties.
The ritual, one of Taiwan's most prominent religious events, lasted nine days this year, one day longer than usual, and attracted more than 1 million followers, temple sources said Monday.
The palanquin carrying the likeness the goddess was greeted enthusiastically by worshippers when it arrived at Jenn Lann Temple shortly after 11 p.m. Sunday.
Yen Ching-piao, head of the temple who is also a legislator, helped seat the palanquin to conclude the pilgrimage.

DOC.HEADLINE: US urges China take steps to encourage Taiwan engaging in dialogues
DOC.DATELINE: Hong Kong, April 26 (CNA) 04/27/10 00:08:07 (By Chris Wang)

TEXT.P: The United States would like to see China to take steps to make Taiwan comfortable in engaging in cross-Taiwan Strait dialogues, U.S. Assistant Secretary of State for East Asian and Pacific Affairs Kurt Campbell told the media Monday.

"We would very much like to see China to take steps and to encourage Taiwan and to make them feel comfortable (in cross-Strait dialogues) ... We believe that overall process of this dialogue is important, " Campbell responded to a reporter's question in a keynote speech, titled "American Engagement and Asia", in the 2010 International Media Conference.
Campbell acknowledged that there has been a security dimension in the cross- Strait relations and said that the U.S. have urged restraint on both sides.

Reviewing recent U.S.-Taiwan relations, the veteran diplomat said that one of the biggest source of concerns in the past several years was "unintended development" and "accidents, " but there has been an increase of confidence since then.

Campbell reiterated that the U.S. maintains a unofficial relationship with Taiwan, which has been maintained by succession of administrations, and the commitment is legally binding by the Taiwan Relations Act.
"We have confidence in our broad relationship and encourage dialogues between two sides. " he said.

Asked on what role the U.S. will play under the circumstances of the warming cross-Strait ties, Campbell did not give a direct answer but said that "I see no concerns (from the U.S.) of a warming relationship between Taiwan and China."
In terms of China, Campbell affirmed in the one-hour speech that the U.S. maintains a stable and constructive relationship with China.

However, he said that current U.S.-Sino relations are no longer a "monotone" and "something like black and white" during the Cold War era. The relations are now multi-layer and more diverse and complicated, containing a wide range of factors from currency to trade, and from Iran to North Korea, all of which make the relations "extraordinary complex".

The bilateral relations suffered certain degree of a setback during U.S. President Barack Obama's second year in office during which China was not happy with Obama's meeting with the Dalai Lama and the U.S. arm sales to Taiwan, he recognized.
But at the same time, the U.S. will keep up its cooperation with China on many issues. For example, China could play a role on Korean Peninsula, he said.

Campbell said that the U.S. presence in the Asia Pacific region is still strong and maintains good relationship with its traditional allies as well as several emerging countries, despite a widespread perception of a gradual U.S. power decline in the region over the years.
The U.S. will meet the challenge by increasing high-ranking official visits to the region and interactive with the Asian Pacific countries regularly, he said.

Almost 300 international politics experts and media members attended the three- day "2010 International Media Conference" from April 26-28, which was organized by the East-West Center, established by the U.S. Congress in 1960 to promote better understandings of nations of the U.S., Asia and the Pacific, and Media Studies Center at the University of Hong Kong.

DOC.HEADLINE: Today in history
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, April 27 (CNA) 04/27/10 08:24:41
DOC.TEXT:
Today is Monday, April 27, 2010, or the 14th day of the third month of the Year of the Tiger according to the lunar calendar. Following is a list of important events that have occurred on this date in the past:
1521: Portuguese navigator Ferdinand Magellan is killed by the inhabitants on the island of Mactan in the Philippines.
1791: American painter and inventor Samuel F.B. Morse is born. A portraitist whose subjects included Lafayette, he refined and patented the telegraph and developed the telegraphic code that bears his name.
1822: Ulysses S. Grant, the 18th president of the United States, is born. After his victorious Vicksburg campaign, he was made commander in chief of the Union Army and accepted the surrender of Confederate Gen. Robert E. Lee at Appomattox in 1865, thus ending the Civil War.
1882: Ralph Waldo Emerson, the American essayist, philosopher, and a central figure of American transcendentalism, dies at the age of 78. His poems, orations and essays are regarded as landmarks in the development of American thought and literary expression.
1887: The world's first surgical removal of an appendix, an operation known as an appendectomy, is performed by American surgeon Dr. Thomas Morton in Philadelphia.
1911: An uprising in Canton, China, is foiled when revolutionaries led by Huang Shing are defeated by the local garrison. The battle in Canton is the 10th uprising directed by Dr. Sun Yat-sen after he launched a revolutionary movement against the Ching court in the late 19th century.
1937: The new Golden Gate suspension bridge linking the city of San Francisco with Marin County reaches completion after four years.
1945: The Allies reject peace offers by German S.S. chief Heinrich Himmler, insisting on unconditional German surrender.
1949: Republic of China President Chiang Kai-shek arrives in Shanghai and reiterates his determination to suppress the communist rebellion.
1950: The British government officially recognizes the state of Israel.
1956: Rocco Marciano, known as "Rocky," the American boxer who won the world heavyweight championship in 1952 and defended it six times, retires as undefeated world heavyweight boxing champion.
1959: Liu Shao-chi is elected "state chairman" of Communist China.
1960: The ROC establishes diplomatic relations with the Republic of Togo.
1960: Syngman Rhee resigns as president of South Korea, ending his 12-year rule.
1962: Hsieh Chin wins the "best director" award in the first film festival to be held in mainland China.
1972: After a journey to the moon, U.S. Apollo 16 spacecraft carrying three astronauts makes a safe landing in the Pacific Ocean.
1972: Kwame Nkrumah, the Ghanaian president who was deposed in 1966 by a military coup while he was in mainland China, dies in Bucharest, Hungary.
1973: Jordanian Ambassador to the ROC Mutasim Bileisi returns to Amman after a two-year tour of duty in Taipei.
1974: The Academia Sinica Advisory Council votes on a list of candidates for academicians.
1974: The Taiwan Railway Administration and General Electric of the United States sign a contract for the electrification of Taiwan's western trunk line railway. GE will provide 74 locomotives and heavy trucks for the project.
1978: President Mohammed Daoud is killed in a bloody coup and replaced by Afghanistan's first communist ruler, Nur Mohammed Taraki, who proclaims the Democratic Republic of Afghanistan.
1992: The International Monetary Fund and World Bank approve the membership of Russia and 12 other former Soviet republics.
1993: Koo Chen-fu, chairman of the ROC Straits Exchange Foundation, and Wang Daohan, chairman of Beijing's Association for Relations Across the Taiwan Strait, meet in Singapore in what is the first official contact between Taipei and Beijing since 1949.
1997: The world's longest road-rail suspension bridge, linking Hong Kong to its new offshore airport, is formally opened.
1998: Nguyen Van Linh, former general secretary of the Vietnam Communist Party, dies.
1999: Verka Modanu, the Republic of Macedonia's first resident envoy to the Republic of China, arrives in Taipei to assume her post.
2000: President-elect Chen Shui-bian says that only mutual trust can bring real peace to the people of both sides of the Taiwan Strait.
2001: The first-ever civic group to promote private exchanges between Taiwan- controlled offshore island of Kinmen and mainland China' Xiamen is formally established following the implementation of the "mini three links" with mainland China at the beginning of the year.
Confucius' lesson of the day: "When you meet the proper person to speak to and do not speak out, you lose your opportunity; but when you meet one who is not a proper person to speak to and you speak to him, you waste your words. A man of intelligence never loses his opportunity, neither does he waste his words."

DOC.HEADLINE: DPP head to explain stance on ECFA to local, foreign media
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, April 27 (CNA) 04/27/10 10:32:00 (By Sophia Yeh and Lilian Wu)

TEXT.P: Opposition Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) Chairperson Tsai Ing-wen will explain the party's stance to local and foreign media on a proposed trade pact with China, a party task force said Monday.

The DPP will also push for a referendum on the economic cooperation framework agreement (ECFA), and assess the possibility of holding a demonstration on the issue before mid-May, said Julian Kuo, a spokesman for the task force.

Kuo said that after the high-profile debate between President Ma Ying-jeou and the DPP's chairwoman Sunday, the party felt that the president had not addressed or answered many questions raised by Tsai.
"The DPP will help the public find the real answers through the legislature and its campaign," Kuo said.
Tsai will also meet with major local and foreign media to explain why the party believes it would be rash to sign an agreement that it contends would leave Taiwan too economically dependent on China.

On the possibility of a referendum, the opposition Taiwan Solidarity Union (TSU) has completed the first stage of a petition drive to hold a referendum on the ECFA by sending 110,000 signatures to the Central Election Commission (CEC) , which the CEC will review in May.

If a referendum screening committee finds that the petition conforms with the Referendum Act, the DPP will push to collect the signatures needed -- about 850,000 or 5 percent of the nearly 17 million eligible votes in the last presidential election -- in the second stage of the campaign.
"The role of the DPP will be more clear and positive," Kuo said.

On suggestions by some DPP members that the party stage a large-scale rally prior to the signing of the ECFA, which the ruling Kuomintang hopes occurs in June, Kuo said it was a question of how much momentum could be built through a demonstration.
The DPP feels the issue for which it can gain the most support is holding a referendum on the trade pact, he said.

The party expects that the "early harvest list, " which allows early tariff concessions, will be unveiled before May 20, and the DPP will assess at that time what kind of demonstration would be held, he said.

DOC.HEADLINE: Chinese shipping company gets green light to operate in Taiwan
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, April 27 (CNA) 04/27/10 10:42:54 (By Lin Shu-yuan and Deborah Kuo)

TEXT.P: The Investment Commission gave the green light Monday to SITC Maritime Group, China's largest private shipping company, to set up a branch office in Taiwan.

The Shangdong-based SITC applied to initially remit NT$12 million (US$382,165) into Taiwan for the establishment of the office, according to the Investment Commission under the Ministry of Economic Affairs.
With the opening of the branch, SITC will be able to operate independently in Taiwan without relying on its Taiwan-based agents.
SITC was the first Chinese shipping company approved to establish an affiliate in Taiwan since the two countries signed a cross-strait shipping agreement over one year ago.

According to Investment Commission figures, Chinese companies have applied to invest a total of NT$2.225 billion in Taiwan since June 30, 2009, when Taiwan officially opened its doors to Chinese investment.

Meanwhile, Taiwanese companies that invested in China illegally filed 504 applications between Feb. 9 and April 12 for permits that would legalize their investment, according to the Investment Commission.
The total value of the investment covered by these applications is US$198.86 million.

DOC.HEADLINE: Talk of the day -- Debate, the beginning of communication
DOC.DATELINE: 04/27/10 11:39:38 (By Elizabeth Hsu)

TEXT.P: The historic debate between President Ma Ying-jeou and Tsai Ing-wen, chairperson of the opposition Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) , on a controversial trade pact with China was seen as having helped people learn more about what the so- called economic cooperation framework agreement (ECFA) is.

The popular Taichung Mayor Jason Hu commented that the two debaters had both demonstrated their best side to the public, with Ma regaining his public popularity and Tsai improving the DPP's image with her professional performance.
The following are excerpts from local media coverage of the issue:
China Times:

The debate may have changed Ma's resistance to the idea of holding a referendum on the ECFA. Although he still appears not to approve the idea, he is no longer opposed to the movement seeking such a referendum.

Meanwhile, former Minister without Portfolio Chu Yun-peng praised the debate for encouraging the leaders of ruling and opposition parties to engage in meaningful dialogue on a significant public policy.
Liberty Times:
Public survey results from the pro-DPP Taiwan Thinktank show that 66 percent of respondent thought that whether or not to sign the ECFA should be decided by popular referendum

Their analysis also found that nearly half of "pan-blue alliance" supporters support the idea of holding the referendum. It indicates that the idea of an ECFA referendum has crossed political party barriers to become a common opinion of "pan-green" and "pan-blue" supporters.
United Daily News:
Ma's spokesman Lo Chih-chiang cited Ma as saying that the president recognized the debate's function, which Ma said enabled him to listen to different voices on his ECFA policy.

Amid growing public popularity thanks to the debate, President Ma planned two meetings with foreign reporters Tuesday and Wednesday to convey his ideas on the cross-strait trade pact to the international community.

High ranking government officials and bigwigs in the ruling Kuomintang pointed out that Ma, who deeply believes the ECFA is the road Taiwan must take, will never accept any of the DPP's hundreds of political reasons for not signing the pact.

President Ma firmly believes he can allow people to understand the policy through a public explanation. The Presidential Office said that efforts to publicize the ECFA will continue. (April 27, 2010).

DOC.HEADLINE: United Daily News: Reconsideration the only remedy for evil bill
DOC.DATELINE: 04/27/10 11:52:23 (By Maubo Chang)

TEXT.P: Pressured by public opinion, the Legislative Yuan decided to delay passage of a personal data protection bill that was ready to be voted on last week, so that sections that limit press freedom can be revised. This is the last opportunity to remedy this evil bill.

If the lawmakers don't understand what a foolish bill it is and decide to enact it anyway, then the Executive Yuan will have no choice but to ask the Legislature to reconsider it. That would set an embarrassing precedent in which an administration would ask the Legislature controlled by the same party to reconsider an ill-conceived bill.

Unfortunately, many lawmakers from both the ruling and opposition parties do not understand even now what is wrong with the bill, and have to consult the executive branch for a remedy. This highlights the reckless attitude of the lawmakers in carrying out their job.

The controversial bill made it through a legislative committee along with 16 other bills last Tuesday, with none of the lawmakers bothering to study the ramifications of any of them. The lawmakers took pride in the idea that they were improving the protection of personal data by endorsing this controversial bill, without realizing they had strangled press freedom.

The Ministry of Justice shares the blame for crafting the bill recklessly. It invited only one correspondent from a newspaper which is friendly to the opposition Democratic Progressive Party to a public hearing on the bill.

Worst of all, at the urging of the Taiwan Association for Human Rights at the public hearings, it struck off an article offering the mass media exemption from the restrictions on revealing personal data. We are astounded by the deep-rooted hostility this human rights group has shown toward the mass media, which is considered the fourth estate and is respected around the world.

Because of the recklessness of the executive and legislative branches, the bill not only infringes on the freedom of the press but also restricts Internet surfers. We are not certain that, if passed, the law could prevent the leakage of personal data from the data bank of big enterprises as is its intention, but it will leave people who post photos of spring scream concert-goers in Facebook open to prosecution.
The lawmakers have to right the wrong they made by having the bill reconsidered. They are not only fixing the bill but also erasing their tarnished images. (April 27, 2010)

DOC.HEADLINE: Taiwan office workers crazy about group buying
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, April 27 (CNA) 04/27/10 12:45:14 (By Cheng Yun-hsung, Chou Ping-chun and Frances Huang)

TEXT.P: Group purchasing has become very popular among office workers in Taiwan, with more than four-fifths of them having tried it, a survey showed Tuesday.

Food products were the favorite target of group purchases, which harness the bargaining power of groups of online shoppers to negotiate discounts with vendors, the survey conducted by 360D Human Resources found.
About 82 percent of the polled office workers said they had joined with colleagues in group purchasing, while 67 percent said company executives had also become involved.
According to the survey, 41 percent of respondents said the e-commerce innovation was very trendy in offices, while almost half made purchases through group buying as often as three times a month.

Apart from food products, office workers also used group buying to purchase cosmetics, garments and accessories, according to the survey, which was conducted between April 15 and April 22 and collected 1,019 valid responses.

PayEasy, one of Taiwan's leading e-commerce retailers, said its business has felt the growing impact of office workers shopping online, though it did not specify whether the purchases were made by individuals or groups.
The company said the peak hours for online purchases were at around 9: 30 a.m. and 2: 30 p.m., when office workers had a moment to surf shopping Web sites before their bosses stepped into the office.
Buying volume during the peak hours was 14 times the volume seen during non-peak periods, it said.
PayEasy expected its online shopping business to grow significantly as Mother's Day approaches, with sales likely to exceed NT$200 million in week preceding the holiday.

DOC.HEADLINE: License plate excavated from buried freeway
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, April 27 (CNA) 04/27/10 13:12:57 (By Sunrise Huang, Chen Chin-ping and Deborah Kuo)

TEXT.P: Rescuers scrambling to dig out cars suspected of being buried Sunday in a landslide on the No. 3 National Freeway have found a license plate that corresponds to one of the vehicles said to be missing.

The license plate with the number VF4988, which was found at 11: 47 p.m. Tuesday, matches that of the Mercedes-Benz that was reported as missing on Monday by the father of one of the car's passengers, Kuo Wen-han, who was headed to Keelung with his girlfriend.

More than 1,000 rescue workers, manning 200 excavators and other heavy equipment, have been working non-stop for the past two days to rescue four cars and five people feared buried in the landslide, which covered 300 meters of the freeway's Keelung-Sijhih section with around 200,000 cubic meters of soil and rock.

Despite persistent rain and occasional downpours, the rescuers have worked relentlessly without a minute of rest, said Hsu Cheng-chang, the director of the National Freeway Bureau's Northern Region Engineering Office.
As of 10 a.m. Tuesday, the workers, including 930 soldiers, had removed some 33,000 cubic meters of earth and rocks, Hsu said.
The Freeway Bureau's command center has four life-detecting systems at the scene, hoping to detect spots where people buried under the rubble might have survived against the odds.
As of 11 a.m., no people or vehicles had been discovered, in the worst landslide ever on a freeway in Taiwan, Hsu said.
Lin Chao-tsung, director of the Central Geological Survey under the Ministry of Economic Affairs, attributed the landslide to damaged rock anchors in the restraining walls along the freeway.
Faulty construction or wear on the anchors may have precipitated the collapse of a hill hovering over the freeway's Keelung-Sijhih section, Lin said.
The side of the hill facing the freeway was a dip slope -- a geological formation particularly vulnerable to landslides -- composed largely of sandstone, Lin said.
An investigation into the incident has been launched.

DOC.HEADLINE: Two more cases of indigenous dengue fever reported
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, April 27 (CNA) 04/27/10 13:47:15 (By Chen Li-ting and Y.F. Low)

TEXT.P: Two more cases of indigenous dengue fever have been reported in the southern city of Kaohsiung, bringing to five the total number of such cases recorded since the start of the dengue epidemic season in March, the Centers for Disease Control (CDC) said Monday.

The latest cases, reported within a week, were classified as a cluster infection involving two people who live 15 meters away from each other in the city's Lingya district, according to CDC Director-General Ling Ting.
The three previous cases also occurred in the port city.
Lin said this year's dengue fever epidemic pattern is similar to that of 2002 in that the season started early, which raises concerns that the outbreak this year could be as bad as it was in 2002.

In 2002, a total of 5,336 cases of indigenous dengue fever were recorded. The number included 241 cases of hemorrhagic fever, a potentially fatal development of the mosquito-borne disease, and 21 deaths.

This year's epidemic season began in the 11th week -- three weeks earlier than in 2002, Lin noted. The interval between the start of the 2010 epidemic season and the end of the 2009 epidemic season was four weeks, which was two weeks shorter than that between 2002 and 2001, he added.

DOC.HEADLINE: Commercial Times: China should concede to Taiwan on vital interests
DOC.DATELINE: 04/27/10 14:01:51 (By Maubo Chang)

TEXT.P: With a debate on the planned economic cooperation framework agreement (ECFA) with China having drawn a positive reaction from Taiwan's people, the pact with China is almost certain to be wrapped up by the middle of this year.

But many local businessmen are concerned about whether their industries will be listed among the first group of businesses to enjoy lower tariffs under the pact, and what Beijing's promise of making concessions to Taiwan means.
Ever since Chinese Premier Wen Jiabao promised to "yield benefits" to Taiwan under the ECFA, many local businessmen have believed that the ECFA would give Taiwan's economy a shot in the arm.

And many people came around to supporting the pact because of Wen's promise. That belief was only natural given that China's economy is much bigger than Taiwan's, and that it would sweeten the pot to attract Taiwan to joining it in long-term economic cooperation.
Those people also believed that Wen could not back down on his promise in order to win over Taiwan's people for political purposes.

However, Beijing's promise seemed to be empty words during the most recent round of bilateral negotiations. Many sectors Taiwan hoped would be included in the "early harvest list" -- such as petrochemicals, machinery, flat panel, and automobile and components -- were rejected or scaled down by Beijing.
On the other hand, China's list of industries to be granted low tariffs was longer than Taiwan's. Many of the sectors covered would surely price out their Taiwanese competitors.

Why didn't China honor its promise of concessions? Probably because it conceives concessions differently from Taiwan. It thought that not pressing Taiwan to open its market wider to Chinese agricultural products and allowing in Chinese workers was a concession. Or it may be that China's many state-run business were reluctant to make concessions to their Taiwanese counterparts.

If that is the truth, then the differences between Beijing and Taipei are major, because not opening Taiwan's market to Chinese laborers or more widely open it to agricultural products are considered by Taiwan to be preconditions to any ECFA rather than topics for negotiation.

Anyway, we hope the Chinese authorities will redefine their promise of concessions to accommodate Taiwanese businessmen, and make concessions on vital interests to facilitate cooperation across the Taiwan Strait. China's concessions will not only earn credit for their leader but also be compensated for by the fruits of bilateral cooperation in the future. (April 27, 21010)
