DOC.HEADLINE: Taiwan concerned about Japan's Diaoyutais exploration
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, April 27 (CNA) 04/27/10 15:31:24 (By Chiachen Hsieh and Frances Huang)

TEXT.P: Taiwan expressed concern Tuesday over a Japanese plan to explore seabed resources around a disputed island group in the East China Sea.

Chen Tiao-ho, secretary-general of the East Asia Relations Commission, said Taiwan's representative office in Japan has voiced concern about the likelihood that Japan will explore the resources, including rare metals, in waters around the Diaoyutai Islands, known in Japan as the Senkaku Islands.

Taiwan's move came after Japan's Kyodo News Agency disclosed a day earlier a Japanese official document detailing the country's strategy to ensure undersea resources and energy through seabed exploration in its sovereign waters, including part of the East China Sea.

Taiwan, Japan and China all claim sovereignty over the island group, which offers the possibility of plentiful oil reserves under the continental shelf below the islands. Relations among the three become strained whenever disputes over the islands arise.
Chen said Taiwan will watch closely how the exploration plan develops and will employ necessary measures at an appropriate time to protect its interests.

He added that as Taiwan has never changed its stance on the Diaoyutai Islands sovereignty, while Japan still insists on its own viewpoint, the two sides should put aside the sovereignty issue and work together on marine resource exploration.

DOC.HEADLINE: Taiwan to develop offshore wind power generation
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, April 27 (CNA) 04/27/10 15:44:38 (By Lin Shu-yuan and Fanny Liu)

TEXT.P: The Ministry of Economic Affairs (MOEA) announced Tuesday that it will push a policy of establishing offshore wind power plants and propose incentives in July to encourage local firms to invest in offshore wind power generation.

Deputy Minister of Economic Affairs Huang Chung-chiou said it is not too late for Taiwan to develop offshore wind generation, citing Denmark, the U.K, and Holland, which are still in the initial stages of developing the energy resource.
"Offshore wind generation should be given top priority, " Huang said, adding that the Taiwan Strait has very good locations for developing offshore wind power generation.

The capacity of a wind power generation station located within 20 meters off the coast could reach 1,200 megawatts (MW) , which is larger than the capacity of a similar wind power plant on land, Huang said.
If the plant is set up around 20 meters to 50 meters off the coast, its capacity could increase to 5,000 MW -- almost equal to the combined capacity of two nuclear power plants, according to Huang.

Yeh Hui-chin, chief of the Bureau of Energy under the MOEA said that offshore areas near central Taiwan's Changhua and Yunlin counties are suitable sites for developing wind power generation, and the MOEA will propose a plan in July to specify wind farm areas and the capacity needed.

According to the MOEA, the production value of Taiwan's wind power generation equipment was NT$4 billion (US$128 million) in 2009, with investment from 20 companies. The value of investment is expected to increase by more than NT$1.5 billion per year from 2010.
Huang pointed out that the Teco Group, Formosa Heavy Industries Corp., Yuan Jun Fong, and Taiwan's China Steel are aggressively taking part in developing the wind power industry.

DOC.HEADLINE: Taiwan share prices close lower
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, April 27 (CNA) 04/27/10 15:48:55

TEXT.P: Taiwan's share prices lost ground Tuesday, with the weighted index -- the market's key barometer-- falling 11.7 points, or 0.14 percent, to close at 8,146.44.
The local bourse opened at the day's high of 8,174.85 and fell to 8,121.14 before rebounding. Market turnover totaled NT$108.52 billion (US$3.47 billion).

Five of the eight major stock categories lost ground, with cement issues dropping the most at 1.14 percent, followed by foodstuff shares at 0.96 percent, construction shares at 0.91 percent, financial and banking stocks at 0.32 percent and machinery and electronics issues at 0.12 percent.
The other three major stock categories gained ground, with textile issues gaining the most at 0.88 percent. Plastics and chemicals rose 0.42 percent and paper and pulp issues moved up 0.06 percent.
Losers outnumbered gainers 1,873 to 1,181, with 319 shares remaining unchanged.
Foreign investors and Chinese QDIIs were net sellers of NT$7.8 billion in shares. (by Olivia Wang)

DOC.HEADLINE: Civilian volunteers rush to provide food for rescuers
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, April 27 (CNA) 04/27/10 15:53:36 (By Sunrise Huang and Deborah Kuo)

TEXT.P: A number of civilian volunteers have been taking food and drink to the site of a landslide in northern Taiwan where rescue teams have been working around the clock since Sunday to unearth five people feared buried in vehicles under some 200,000 cubic meters of rubble.

In the small hours of Tuesday, Chen Yung-shen, owner of a porridge company based in Taipei County's Zhonghe City, drove his van loaded with porridge to the site where more than 1,000 rescue workers, manning 200 excavators and other heavy equipment, have been working non-stop in shifts in rainy weather.
Chen said he took the hot porridge, made with pork and thousand-year eggs, to help warm up the rescuers who must be tired and hungry.

The rescue workers have been racing against time over the past two days in rainy weather to clear the landslide that occurred Sunday, completely covering a 300-meter section of the Keelung-Sijhih No. 3 National Freeway and burying some four vehicles.
"I hope the porridge will help give the rescuers strength, " said Chen, who also took his porridge to victims of the deadly Typhoon Morakot in southern Taiwan last year.
Meanwhile, a group of volunteers from the Buddhist Compassion Relief Tzu Chi Foundation, Taiwan's largest charity organization, also took food to the rescue workers at the landslide site.

The Tzu Chi volunteers, who were meeting in Keelung City Sunday in preparation for the celebration of Sakyamuni's birthday, took buns and stuffed rice rolls to the scene immediately after they learned about the accident.
Other members of the public have also pitched in, driving to the site to distribute food and drinks to the rescue workers.

DOC.HEADLINE: Apple Daily: No-one wins by rubbing nature the wrong way
DOC.DATELINE: 04/27/10 16:02:50 (By Maubo Chang)

TEXT.P: A landslide that buried a section of the No. 3 freeway on Sunday was terrible. But the slope of the hill slid only after its foot was cut off by the freeway and the drainage for its underground water was blocked by a retaining wall built to protect the freeway.
When the earth of the slope became saturated with water, it slid, bursting the retaining wall and burying the freeway.

When man cuts open a hill with dynamite and machines to build a road, the hill will get its revenge by getting its space back violently. Man plunders nature for his own advantage, and nature retaliates with flooding, draughts, desertification, earthquakes, hurricanes, landslides, surges in sea levels and other disasters.
It is the government's obligation to engage in infrastructure construction, but it should do so in a way that does not damage the environment.
Since landslides are widespread in Taiwan, why not follow the lead of Western powers by installing on dangerous hillsides alarms that send out warnings whenever there are signs of landslides.
Landslides kill every year in Taiwan, but the country has never learned to come to terms with nature. (April 27, 2010)

DOC.HEADLINE: Hon Hai wins Taipei BOT contract to build information park
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, April 27 (CNA) 04/27/10 16:09:18 (By Elizabeth Hsu)

TEXT.P: The Hon Hai Group, the world's biggest contract electronics manufacturer, was named Tuesday as the preferred bidder for a build-operate-transfer (BOT) contract to build an information park next to Guang Hua Digital Plaza in Taipei City.

Hon Hai's distribution subsidiary, Cybermart Worldwide Co., beat out four other companies, including Clevo Co., which was named the alternate bidder, and Lemel, Taiwan's leading information product distributor, to gain the upper hand in clinching the project.

Taipei's Department of Finance said it chose Cybermart Worldwide because of its proposal that stressed Taipei could not be left out of the global technology network, and because of the backing provided by the Hon Hai Group's deep resources.
The operator of the BOT project will have the right to operate the park for 50 years.
The planned complex, to be situated on a 2,686-ping lot (8,864 square meters) , is expected to include a 3C shopping mall, brand product shop, and multi- functional exhibition hall.
Other planned facilities in the park, expected to be opened in March 2014, include a state-of-the-art technology exhibition center, digital entertainment zone, and business cultivation center.

Hon Hai Chairman Terry Gou also promised to set up a NT$200 million fund to encourage young people to participate in international information design contests and promote cooperation between Taiwan's universities and their foreign counterparts, the department added.

The city expects the BOT project will draw NT$3.7 billion in private investment and create 1,500 new jobs in the next few years, while contributing an estimated NT$7 billion in sales and income tax revenues to central government coffers during the 50-year concession period.

The BOT project is the second-phase of the local government's ambitious plan to build an "Akihabara electric town" in the capital city. Akihabara is an area of Toyko that is known for 3C electronics, animation, manga and video games.
Commenting on his company's runner-up finish, Clevo Chairman Kent Hsu said he was very disappointed.

After successfully opening the Buynow shopping mall chain in China, which retails 3C information-related products, Hsu said he wanted to use their know- how to build a successful shopping center along the same lines in Taiwan.

DOC.HEADLINE: People seldom hug their mothers: survey
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, April 27 (CNA) 04/27/10 16:43:21 (By Hao Hsueh-chin and Kay Liu)

TEXT.P: Nearly half of the people polled in a recent survey rarely hug their mothers, but acknowledge that their mothers mean a lot to them, according to the results of the survey published Tuesday in the central city of Taichung ahead of May 2 Mother's Day.

Among the 600 respondents aged between 20 and 40, 96 percent said they regard their mothers as very important. However, 48.66 percent said they rarely hug their mothers, while 25.5 percent said they do so only when their mothers are ill.
The survey was conducted by TC Reading, a Taichung-based civic group that promotes reading.

The results were released at a news conference held by the city's Department of Social Affairs to promote a Mother's Day event scheduled for this Sunday aimed at encouraging people to hug their mothers to show their gratitude.

Sharing his own experience of interacting with his parents-in-law and two daughters, Chang Kuo-hui, director of the department, said that for most parents, receiving a hug or a phone call from their children is all they want.

A group of kindergarten kids also attended the news conference to tell how they see their own mothers, with some describing her as a magician conjuring up delicious meals or working around the clock like a convenience store. Others likened their mothers to a whipping top and an alarm clock.

DOC.HEADLINE: Imported ribs destroyed after banned feed additive detected
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, April 27 (CNA) 04/27/10 16:56:43 (By Chen Ching-ping and Lilian Wu)

TEXT.P: A shipment of frozen pork ribs imported from the United States was destroyed after it was found to contain the banned substance ractopamine, a drug put in feed to make pigs raised for meat leaner.

The Keelung Customs Office said the 1,360-kilogram shipment of pork ribs was brokered through customs on March 29. The importer decided not to return the pork ribs to the shipper, because the value of the shipment, NT$47,790 (US$1,520) , was lower than the transportation costs US$2,000.

Opposition Democratic Progressive Party legislators Liu Chien-kuo, Huang Jen-shu and Chen Ying, along with officials from the Bureau of Animal and Plant Health Inspection and Quarantine, Bureau of Standards, Metrology and Inspection, and customs, were on hand to see the pork ribs taken out of their container and destroyed in an incinerator.
Chen said the frozen pork ribs were found to have contained 1.18 ppb of ractopamine, an additive allowed by only five countries and banned by Taiwan.

Liu said that recently, a customs official was found to have collaborated with a trading company in Taipei City to allow in frozen Matsuzaka beef from Japan, which has been barred from entering Taiwan since 2001 after Japan reported an outbreak of mad cow disease.

Because of such examples of customs corruption, Liu and Chen said that they will propose in the legislature that in the future, the process of destroying any seized commodities should be recorded for monitoring purposes.

DOC.HEADLINE: U.S. congressman favors inviting ROC president to regional forum
DOC.DATELINE: Washington, April 26 (CNA) 04/27/10 17:19:00 (By Jorge Liu and Maubo Chang)

TEXT.P: U.S. Representative David Wu said Monday that he supports the idea of inviting Republic of China President Ma Ying-jeou to attend the annual meeting of the Asia Pacific Economic Cooperation (APEC) forum this year.

At a tea party he hosted for correspondents of Chinese-language media in Washington, D.C., Wu said it would be a good idea to have U.S. President Barack Obama invite Ma to an unofficial summit of APEC leaders that the U.S. president will host in Hawaii later this year.
Taiwan's president has been blocked from the summit due to China's opposition ever since it was admitted to the forum in 1991. Taiwan usually sends a senior economic official instead.
Wu said the U.S. should cancel a self-imposed ban on visits to Washington by Taiwan's president.

Recalling that he took a five-hour flight from Washington to San Francisco in January for a 90-minute meeting with Ma, Wu said he "cannot understand" why it is so difficult to meet with the ROC president in the United States.
Ma arrived in San Francisco Jan. 26 on a transit stop en route to a visit to Honduras.
With regard to Taiwan's negotiations with China on a trade pact, Wu, who is originally from Taiwan, said it is good for Taiwan and China to promote bilateral exchanges.
He also lauded Ma's push for reconciliation with China, saying the president is moving at an appropriate pace.
However, he said the prospects for Taiwan clinching a free trade pact with the U.S. for the time being are dim. He did not elaborate.

He also said it is inevitable that the Chinese yuan will appreciate, but predicted that it will be a gradual process, so that both U.S. consumers and Chinese producers will be able to adapt to the situation.

DOC.HEADLINE: Child care facilities must purchase group insurance
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, April 27 (CNA) 04/27/10 17:23:39 (By Chou Yung-chieh and Elizabeth Hsu)

TEXT.P: The Legislative Yuan passed an amendment to the Children and Youth Welfare Act Tuesday that lays the basis for requiring child care facilities to purchase group insurance.

The amendment was proposed by ruling Kuomintang Legislator Wu Yu-sheng to add a provision that requires child care centers that offer day care services for children aged four or less to purchase group insurance for the children they look after.

Wu estimated that over 237,000 children will benefit from the amendment, which was formed after a revision of the Insurance Law in January that prohibits death payouts on insured children aged under 15. The revision meant that children at day care centers did not require to be insured.
The child welfare law at present does not cover group insurance for young children at day care centers, while kindergarten children, as well as elementary and middle school students, must be covered.
The death of a child insured under group insurance gets compensation payment of NT$1 million.

DOC.HEADLINE: Taiwan not economically over-dependent on China: president
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, April 27 (CNA) 04/27/10 17:49:40 (By Alex Jiang)

TEXT.P: President Ma Ying-jeou on Tuesday dismissed concerns that Taiwan might become too dependent on China economically, after the signing of a controversial trade pact with China.
"I will call that (Taiwan-China trade) mutual or interdependent, " Ma said when fielding a question from an audience of Taipei-based foreign reporters at a meeting in Taipei.

Taiwan's exports to China and Hong Kong in March reached an all-time high of US$10.26 billion, the highest amount in a single month ever. Taiwan's exports to the mainland and Hong Kong hit US$26.42 billion in the first quarter of this year, accounting for a record 42.8 percent of its total exports.

It's "because that more than 40 percent of our exports go to the mainland, we need a mechanism to administrate and to do something about this large volume of trade to make sure that will actually increase the benefits to Taiwan," Ma said.

In addition, Ma said that the signing of the trade liberalization agreement with China is not the first step toward unification with China, but a step toward helping Taiwan regain a prominent place in world trade and in East Asia, especially as a springboard for foreign investment in the region.
"We can handle diplomatic isolation, but economic isolation is fatal," Ma said.

He said Taiwan will move quickly to sign free-trade agreements with other countries, including Singapore and the United States, once it signs the agreement with China, and urged China not to bar Taiwan from signing such deals with its other trade partners.
"I demand mainland China not to obstruct our efforts to sign FTAs with major trading partners of Taiwan," Ma said.

However, Ma did not specify which country will be the first of his efforts to help Taiwan reach FTAs or the number of FTAs he expects to reach after inking the proposed economic cooperation framework agreement (ECFA) with China, possibly in June.
"We cannot say, at the moment, how many but certainly we will try our best. And we hope we could do it right after we have our ECFA passed by our Legislative Yuan (Taiwan's legislature)," Ma said.
"And then we will formalize our action to do that. So we hope as soon as possible," Ma said.

During a debate with opposition Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) Chairwoman Tsai Ing-wen days earlier, Ma said that he will lead a task force in signing FTAs with Taiwan's major trading partners to diversify the country's export markets.
China is now Taiwan's largest trade partner and export market. Besides the United States and Singapore, the European Union countries and Japan are said to be on Taiwan's future FTA list.

Ma, who is seen as more friendly toward China than his predecessor, Chen Shui- bian, also told the reporters that other countries had advised Taiwan to first sign an FTA with China, in order to reach deals with other countries, which Beijing had objected to.

"When we tried to approach other countries, well, it's a rejection everywhere, " he noted. "Many countries told us that if you want to have an FTA with us, well, maybe you should try mainland China first."

Questioned how he can prevent deeper economic reliance on China from eroding Taiwan's cherished democratic way of life, Ma expressed confidence and urged his audience to have faith in Taiwan's democracy.

"There are things that Taiwan can do to really strengthen our democracy and really solidify our sovereignty. I think our press freedom and other things will help... So I keep telling people you have to trust Taiwan's people and Taiwan's democracy. I think that will have a very very important power in making Taiwan free and democratic," Ma said.

He also stressed that Taiwan's pact with China will be different from that between Hong Kong and China as the ECFA text will not carry any political language, including "one China" or "one country, two systems, " which would downgrade Taiwan's sovereignty.

DOC.HEADLINE: Task force to check cause of freeway landslide
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, April 27 (CNA) 04/27/10 18:02:39 (By C.W. Sun and Flor Wang)

TEXT.P: The Ministry of Transportation and Communications (MOTC) is set to commission a task force within three days to explore the cause of a Sunday landslide that buried part of the No. 3 Freeway, including five people in four cars that were trapped under the rubble.

Chen Yen-po, deputy director of the MOTC's Department of Railways and Highways, said the team, to be made up of geological experts, will be tasked with finding out the cause of the disaster, the worst that has occurred on a national highway because of slope failure.
In addition, Chen said, the team will also conduct a detailed investigation into the design of the freeway in northern Taiwan, which is built along a dip slope.
Some academics have suggested that damaged rock anchors might be behind the landslide and warned that 32 dip slopes along the nation's freeways are potentially at risk.

In response to grave public concern that more landslides might take place in these disaster-prone areas, the MOTC's National Freeway Bureau said it will conduct an overall probe of all the dip slopes along the country's freeways within three days to check whether any of them are in dangerous shape.

Later that same day, the Taipei City Geotechnical Engineering Office urged residents living in houses near slopeland not to worry about their safety, as no signs of insecurity around their homes have been discovered in the wake of several days of rain.
According to Huang Lee-yuan, the office's chief engineer, 135 apartment complexes under the office's jurisdiction are built near side slopes.

Speaking at a news conference, Huang said the city government is considering installing free monitoring systems in these residential communities to help prevent disasters related to slope failures, so that the office can demand that the communities' management swiftly handles insecure situations if any problems are detected.
There are more than 20,000 artificial side slopes in Taipei City, according to the most recent investigation conducted April 1.

DOC.HEADLINE: Mexico to relax visa requirements for Taiwan citizens: envoy
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei April 27(CNA) 04/27/10 18:29:08 (by Sunnie Chen)

TEXT.P: Mexico will soon relax its visa requirements for Taiwan citizens in an effort to attract larger numbers of Taiwanese visitors, a Mexico envoy in Taiwan said Tuesday.

Martin Munoz Ledo Villegas, head of the Mexican Trade Services Documentation and Cultural Office in Taiwan, said that his office will implement simple and convenient procedures for Taiwan citizens to visit Mexico and will make a more detailed announcement on the matter this weekend.
The new policy is expected to take effect in May, according to Munoz Ledo.
"We have a long history, beautiful views, good food and rich culture, which make us an ideal country for people to visit for tourism," he said.

Statistics from the office show that in recent years, the number of Taiwanese tourists to Mexico has increased greatly, propelling Taiwan into second place after India in terms of Mexico's tourism sources in Asia, he said.

"In 2006, my office issued about 4,000 visas, of which business visas accounted for approximately 85 percent to 90 percent, " Munoz Ledo said. "But in 2009, we issued 6,000 visas, with business visas dropping to 60 percent of the total and the remainder being tourist visas."
Munoz Ledo said that he was encouraged by these numbers and has set a goal this year to persuade more Taiwanese people to go to Mexico.
"I hope that the number from Taiwan will surpass the number from India, " he said.

As part of Mundo Ledo's plan, an art gallery has been set up in the waiting area of the consulate section of his office and he has held many activities in Taiwan to introduce Mexican art, music, food and history.
Through cultural understanding, he said, more people in Taiwan will learn about Mexico and will become interested in visiting the country.

DOC.HEADLINE: Blood donors in central Taiwan honored
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, April 27 (CNA) 04/27/10 18:40:54

TEXT.P: Three people were honored in Taichung City Tuesday for making the highest number of blood donations in the central Taiwan area.

Liu Cheng-ting, 57, who was given an award for the most whole blood donations -- a total of 210, said that in his experience blood donations not only save lives but can also help the donor to maintain good health.
Lu vowed that as long as his health permits, he will continue to be a blood donor.
Blood donation "is a worthy lifetime cause, " he added.
Liu's sentiments were echoed by Tsai Min-yu and Tsai Fang-ching, the top male and female donors, respectively, in the category of plateletpheresis.
The pair, both in their 40s, pledged to continue to donate blood and teach children the advantages of this action.
Tsai Min-yu has recorded nearly 1,000 plateletpheresis blood donations, and Tsai Fang-ching about 800.
The process of donating whole blood is relatively quick but such donations can only be made by an individual at three-month intervals, at the minimum, according to the Taichung Blood Donation Center.

The plateletpheresis donation process, in which only platelets are acquired, takes a longer time but individuals can make such donations every two weeks, the center said. (By Lee Hsi-chang and Elizabeth Hsu)

DOC.HEADLINE: Personal Data Protection Act amendments passed into law
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, April 27 (CNA) 04/27/10 18:58:51 (By Kelven Huang, Justin Su and Deborah Kuo)

TEXT.P: A package of amendments to the Personal Data Protection Act were passed into law Tuesday after concerns over its potential restrictions on press freedom were smoothed out.

Before the amendments cleared the legislative floor, ruling and opposition lawmakers reached a consensus on exempting mass media from the legislation's requirement that the consent of an individual has to be obtained before personal information about that person is released publicly.

Based on the principle of protecting public interests, mass media outlets will now be allowed by the amendments to obtain personal information on parties involved in news reports without obtaining their consent in advance, according to the newly enacted law.
Legislators, however, were not exempted from the stipulation.

Controversy has brewed over the bill since last week after the Legislature's Organic Laws and Statutes Committee decided to remove a clause in the amendments that would have exempted the media from the consent requirement.

The passage of the law comes after the Presidential Office issued a statement on April 22 that said freedom of the press is not only a constitutionally protected basic human right but also the bedrock of democracy.
It stressed that President Ma Ying-jeou is adamant that press freedom should be protected.
The newly enacted law also excludes personal blogs from the consent requirement.

Nevertheless, Chin Cheng-hsiang, director of the Ministry of Justice's Department of Legal Affairs, said bloggers will be dealt with under the Civil Code if their posts damage others' reputations or use their personal pictures without obtaining prior consent.

As there has been controversy over the definition of "public interests, " a sub- resolution was also passed Tuesday, demanding that the Executive Yuan engage in further discussion with experts and civic groups on the definition of "public interests."

DOC.HEADLINE: ECFA not fully-fledged FTA: MAC head
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, April 27 (CNA) 04/27/10 21:16:58 (By Liu Cheng-ching and Bear Lee)

TEXT.P: The proposed economic cooperation framework agreement (ECFA) between Taiwan and China is a "lean and necessary" trade deal for Taiwan rather than a fully fledged free trade agreement (FTA), Mainland Affairs Council (MAC) Chairwoman Lai Shin-yuan said Tuesday.
In an interview with a local radio station, Lai said the Taiwan-China ECFA is "special economic deal" in line with the spirit of the World Trade Organization (WTO) , of which both sides are members.

Lai lamented that the opposition Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) has misconstrued the ECFA as an FTA and has claimed that Taiwan will be obliged to open its market fully to China within 10 years of signing.

As a matter of fact, Lai went on, the WTO has never asked any signatories of the 272 FTAs that exist around the world to complete mutual market opening within a period of 10 years, adding that marketing openings among some FTA partners have even been less than 50 percent.
In addition, the WTO is unlikely to punish FTA partners whose market opening lags behind schedule, she added.

President Ma Ying-jeou's administration hopes that the ECFA can be signed in June as a means of sharpening Taiwan's international competitiveness, but has met strong opposition from the DPP, which is concerned that it will make Taiwan over-dependent on China economically and result in a massive influx of Chinese farm goods and laborers.
Lai said that in its ECFA talks with China, government will uphold the principle that there will be no all-out market opening under the trade deal.

DOC.HEADLINE: China's 'most dangerous woman' reenters media world
DOC.DATELINE: Hong Kong, April 27 (CNA) 04/27/10 21:51:19 (By Chris Wang)

TEXT.P: Dubbed by Business magazine as "the most dangerous woman in China," prominent Chinese journalist Hu Shuli told the international media Tuesday that she is back in Chinese media circles and hopes, through a new venture, to achieve the goal of independent news reporting in China.
Less than six months Hu left "Caijing, " an influential and profitable business magazine founded by her in China in 1998, she has established "Caixin Media."

The new enterprise will be as "outspoken, critical and professional" as before, she told around 300 media workers and international politics experts in a keynote speech at the 2010 International Media Conference organized by the U.S. East-West Center.

"Our future should be in our own hands, " said Hu, 56, who was forced to resign from Caijing last fall amid government anger over the magazine's exposure of a series of scandals in China's stock market and its criticism of the Chinese administration as incompetent.
Her insistence on holding the authorities accountable and on sticking to recognized journalistic standards was supported by almost 200 journalists and employees at Caijing who resigned when she did.
With the establishment of Caixin Media, Hu said, she now envisions a bigger future.
"Political influence and commercial interests should and will be kept out of Caixin Media," she stressed.
The enterprise publishes two Chinese-language magazines, Century Weekly and China Reform, as well as the English-language Caixin Digest.

It also hosts a Web site (www.caing.com) and offers mobile content and electronic magazine subscriptions. It links to online social networks such as Facebook and Twitter for better communication with its readers, according to Hu.
In an era when the media world has changed because of TV, the Internet and mobile devices, Hu said, she is seeking to pursue independent journalism in China via a multimedia platform.

She said that although the traditional media in China, especially newspapers and magazines, is still on the rise, she has decided that her new business should take on the bigger challenge of competing with well-known international media.
"I hope we can find a new business model to catch up with the times before it's too late, " she said.
Asked about her relationship with the Chinese government, Hu described it as "up and down, back and forth." However, she has not given up hope, she said.
She noted that among China's 400 million Internet users, 80 percent of them listed reading news as their favorite online activity as opposed to 20 percent in the Western world.
"All we need to do is grasp the opportunities and never give up," she said. "I don't worry much about difficulties. I always prefer to look for opportunities."
Responded to reporters' questions on tight governmental control of the Chinese media, Hu said she doesn't think the media in China is still an instrument of the state.
The Chinese media is now more diversified, especially in the Internet-dominated news market, she said.
"You cannot say there is only one voice (in China), " she added.
Hu's choice of career was in the footsteps of her mother who was a senior editor at Workers' Daily in China. Her father worked in a trade union.

She was awarded the 2003 International Editor of the Year by the World Press Review, and the 2007 Louis Lyons Award for Conscience and Integrity in Journalism by the Nieman Foundation at Harvard University. In May 2008, the U.S. magazine Foreign Policy named her as one of the top 100 public intellectuals in the world.

DOC.HEADLINE: Taiwan enters era of producing excellent products
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, April 27 (CNA) 04/27/10 21:58:08 (By Lin Shu-yuan and Lilian Wu)

TEXT.P: Vice President Vincent Siew said Tuesday that Taiwan has entered an era in which it is producing excellent products at premium prices.
Siew said that the time when Taiwan produced massive volumes of cheaply priced products is long gone and that now is a very good opportunity to further upgrade the country's industry.
He made the remarks when he attended the 18th Taiwan Excellence Awards ceremony sponsored by the Bureau of Foreign Trade.

He noted that foreign investors used to complain about Taiwan not doing enough in terms of intellectual property rights (IPR) protection, but with Taiwan putting more efforts into R&D, design, marketing and branding over the years, it has turned the tables and is now asking other nations to provide IPR protection for Taiwanese products.
He noted that Taiwan has specifically asked to have IPR protection clauses included in the proposed cross-strait economic cooperation framework agreement with China.
Siew and Minister of Economic Affairs Shih Yen-hsiang also presented Taiwan Excellence awards to 30 winning products, including BenQ's e-book reader and ASUSTeK's Eee keyboard PC.

Shih noted that many of the products entered in the competition have become hot products recently, such as Luxgen7 MPV car, e-books and mini motors used in information and communications sectors, and electric motorcycles.

DOC.HEADLINE: Officials upbeat about 5 percent growth in 2010 GDP
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, April 27 (CNA) 04/27/10 22:05:59 (By C.W. Hsieh and Flor Wang)

TEXT.P: Taiwan will secure a 5 percent economic growth this year as signs are clear that the economy is growing steadily, a government official forecast Tuesday.
Hu Chung-ying, vice chairman of the Cabinet-level Council for Economic Planning and Development (CEPD) , issued the forecast, but expressed reservations about the local job market.

"Although the economy is steadily picking up, we still need some time to judge whether the employment market has improved, " Hu said, adding that "manufacturing, exports and private-sector investment have regained momentum, but no substantial improvements have been observed in the job market."

According to CEPD statistics, the combined amount of every private investment project worth over NT$50 million in the January-February period totaled NT$291.1 billion (US$9.3 billion) , accounting for 28 percent of the full-year target set by the government. The ratio was the highest on record for the first two months of the year.

Meanwhile, the March industrial production index set a fresh new high of 120.3, an increase of 39.2 percent year on year, while the value of March export orders also recorded a historic single-month high of US$34.39 billion.
"These are signs that Taiwan's macro-economy has advanced strongly," Hu explained.

Meanwhile, the economy flashed a red light for March, according to the five- color monitoring system for the country's economic performance, the CEPD announced earlier the same day. The March composite score stood at 39 points, up one point from February.
The council said improvements among consumer, wholesale, retail and restaurant/beverage indicators were the primary reason for the third month of a red light.
The March leading indicator index reached 109.3 points, up by 0.3 percent over February.

Hong Ruei-bin, director of the CEPD's Economic Research Department, said the government is poised to launch more public construction works to help attract more private-sector investment and create jobs.
"Taiwan's economic prospects are optimistic, " he said.

DOC.HEADLINE: Taiwan, Philippines to push for joint typhoon center
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, April 27 (CNA) 04/27/10 22:21:02 (By Garfie Li and Lilian Wu)

TEXT.P: President Ma Ying-jeou said Tuesday that Taiwan and the Philippines have continued to cooperate in pushing for the establishment of a typhoon center under the framework of the Asia-Pacific Economic Cooperation (APEC) forum.

Ma noted that since National Science Council (NSC) Minister Lee Lou-chuang visited Manila last year to attend the second Taiwan-Philippine ministerial- level science and technology conference and both sides reached a consensus during the meeting, bilateral exchanges have been close.
He said the Philippines is planning to send eight meteorologists to Taiwan's Central Weather Bureau to help nurture the Southeast Asian country's meteorological talent.
He also noted that NSC Deputy Minister Chen Cheng-hong led a delegation to Manila to attend a Taiwan-Philippines forum on climate change earlier this month.

At present, the bilateral cooperation includes a feasibility assessment on installing a meteorological radar station in the northern Philippines, in addition to the proposed typhoon center under the APEC framework, Ma said.

He pointed out that all nations attach great importance to regional cooperation when studying climate change and that Taiwan and the Philippines, each of which face the threat of natural disasters, should strengthen their cooperation.
Ma also said the Philippines will hold a general election in two weeks, and expressed hope that the two sides can maintain good science and technology exchanges after the polling.

DOC.HEADLINE: Media challenges discussed at international conference
DOC.DATELINE: Hong Kong, April 27 (CNA) 04/27/10 22:46:41 (By Chris Wang)

TEXT.P: Media members taking part in an international conference Tuesday discussed possible new models for the media business, which is facing enormous challenges in the Internet age.

Items such as "free vs. subscription, " the fierce competition for readership and advertising dollars and the "rethinking of the media" were discussed by participants in a debate titled "Sustainable Media Models in the Internet Age" on the second day of the 2010 International Media Conference, organized by the U.S. Congress-funded East-West Center.
Joshua Benton, Director of Nieman Journalism Lab at Harvard University, noted that it is difficult for traditional media to be profitable in an age in which fewer people read print news.
Since 2006, one-third of newsroom jobs in the U.S. have been cut, he said.
While the average time spent on a news website per user averages between 2-8 minutes per month, Benton said, the same stats for the social website Facebook is 7 hours per month.
According to Benton, most news organizations lack technical expertise and their newsrooms tend to insist on sticking with traditions, which hampers much-needed adjustment.

Benton said that a good model for increasing revenues would be to publish newspapers only two or three times per week, charging NT$315 (US$10) per paper. That way, he said, readers would be interested in news content because there would be increasing segregation between printed material and web content.

Thomas Crampton, a former New York Times journalist, said the emergence of social media such as blogs, and services such as Facebook and Twitter, have caused a structural impact, as the barrier of entry has become extremely low, while some advertisers no longer deal with the print media at all.
Charging readers does not sound like a good idea because "a lot of people will be happy with the free alternatives, " he said.
In terms of the negative impact suffered by the emergence of the Internet, the media business is a lot like the music industry, Crampton went on.

He advised the media to pay attention to the three pillars of "print, online and in-person, " which means media companies should provide their news stories online and in print, and should probably organize real-life events to create closer bonds and better communication with readers.

Reginald Chua, editor-in-chief of the Hong Kong-based South China Morning Post, said the media suffers because the revenue it receives from advertisements and subscriptions and the costs of news production do not match.

Chua urged the media to think hard about how to generate revenue, how to change its way of telling stories, how the newsroom can help with reporting and how to restructure the newsroom, which according to him has not changed much since the 1950s.

DOC.HEADLINE: Government embarking on `golden decade' for Taiwan: CEPD
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, April 27 (CNA) 04/27/10 22:52:02 (By C. Wei Hsieh and Flor Wang)

TEXT.P: To help Taiwan cope with a fast-changing global economy, the Council for Economic Planning and Development (CEPD) has started working on a program with the aim of creating a "golden decade" for the country, CEPD Vice Chairman Hu Chung-ying said Tuesday.

In addition to crafting an economic strategy to sharpen Taiwan's competitiveness, the "2020 national visionary program" will outline projects for the country's development on a broad range of fronts over the next decade, Hu told a news conference.
"The CEPD will iron out a development blueprint for the major challenges that Taiwan is likely to encounter in the coming 10 years, ranging from an aging society to green industry," he said.

As Taiwan and China are expected to soon ink an economic cooperation framework agreement (ECFA) that might lead to a fundamental change in Taiwan's economic structure, Hu said it is vital that Taiwan explores its niche in long-term development at a time when most countries have already begun to do so.

Hu's remarks came after President Ma Ying-jeou revealed the "golden decade" vision Sunday in a debate with opposition Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) Chairperson Tsai Ing-wen on whether or not Taiwan should sign the ECFA with China.
In contrast to Tsai's fear that the proposed ECFA will hurt Taiwan's economy and sovereignty, Ma said the agreement is vital to Taiwan's survival after eight years of inaction under the DPP.

DOC.HEADLINE: Taiwan top choice for tennis player, despite outside offers
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, April 27 (CNA) 04/27/10 23:09:33 (By Hung Huang-chun and Lilian Wu)

TEXT.P: Although several countries have approached Taiwanese ace tennis player Chang Kai-chen with a view to having her represent them in competition, her father remained adamant Tuesday that Taiwan is still her priority choice.
Chang Chin-lai said at a news conference during which his daughter signed a sponsorship contract with a local real estate developer that Taiwan's support for players is limited.
Two years ago, other countries approached Chang, hoping that Kai-chen would play for them, but Chang said he turned down the offers.

"Two years ago, I placed Taiwan as the top priority. But the playing career of a professional athlete is short and I and her coach will make the best choice for her next year at the latest, " Chang said.
Kai-chen signed a sponsorship contract with the real estate developer Tuesday that will provide her with NT$1 million (US$31,741) over three years.

Chang said his daughter has received only paltry government subsidies over the years and that the NT$1 million is not sufficient to meet her expenses, pointing out that hiring a professional coach alone costs more than NT$4 million per year.
Kai-chen, who placed 88th in the ATP rankings as of April 12, said she will remain focused on her on-court performance and will leave other things to her father and her coach.
Asked if she will compete in the Asian Games in Guangzhou, China, at the end of the year, she said that "I'll do my best if time permits."
Kai-chen was scheduled to leave for Portugal later in the evening to play in the Estoril Open, scheduled to take place May 1-9.
Earlier this month, local outstanding golfer Yani Tseng was also reportedly turned down an approach by a Chinese group seeking to sign a long-term sponsorship contract with her.
Tseng's father said his daughter would prefer to collaborate with Taiwanese business groups, but regrettably, none have expressed any interest.

DOC.HEADLINE: Officials upbeat about 5 percent growth in 2010 GDP
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, April 27 (CNA) 04/27/10 22:05:59 (By C.W. Hsieh and Flor Wang)

TEXT.P: Taiwan will secure a 5 percent economic growth this year as signs are clear that the economy is growing steadily, a government official forecast Tuesday.
Hu Chung-ying, vice chairman of the Cabinet-level Council for Economic Planning and Development (CEPD) , issued the forecast, but expressed reservations about the local job market.

"Although the economy is steadily picking up, we still need some time to judge whether the employment market has improved, " Hu said, adding that "manufacturing, exports and private-sector investment have regained momentum, but no substantial improvements have been observed in the job market."

According to CEPD statistics, the combined amount of every private investment project worth over NT$50 million in the January-February period totaled NT$291.1 billion (US$9.3 billion) , accounting for 28 percent of the full-year target set by the government. The ratio was the highest on record for the first two months of the year.

Meanwhile, the March industrial production index set a fresh new high of 120.3, an increase of 39.2 percent year on year, while the value of March export orders also recorded a historic single-month high of US$34.39 billion.
"These are signs that Taiwan's macro-economy has advanced strongly," Hu explained.

Meanwhile, the economy flashed a red light for March, according to the five- color monitoring system for the country's economic performance, the CEPD announced earlier the same day. The March composite score stood at 39 points, up one point from February.
The council said improvements among consumer, wholesale, retail and restaurant/beverage indicators were the primary reason for the third month of a red light.
The March leading indicator index reached 109.3 points, up by 0.3 percent over February.

Hong Ruei-bin, director of the CEPD's Economic Research Department, said the government is poised to launch more public construction works to help attract more private-sector investment and create jobs.
"Taiwan's economic prospects are optimistic, " he said.

DOC.HEADLINE: Taiwan, Philippines to push for joint typhoon center
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, April 27 (CNA) 04/27/10 22:21:02 (By Garfie Li and Lilian Wu)

TEXT.P: President Ma Ying-jeou said Tuesday that Taiwan and the Philippines have continued to cooperate in pushing for the establishment of a typhoon center under the framework of the Asia-Pacific Economic Cooperation (APEC) forum.

Ma noted that since National Science Council (NSC) Minister Lee Lou-chuang visited Manila last year to attend the second Taiwan-Philippine ministerial- level science and technology conference and both sides reached a consensus during the meeting, bilateral exchanges have been close.
He said the Philippines is planning to send eight meteorologists to Taiwan's Central Weather Bureau to help nurture the Southeast Asian country's meteorological talent.
He also noted that NSC Deputy Minister Chen Cheng-hong led a delegation to Manila to attend a Taiwan-Philippines forum on climate change earlier this month.

At present, the bilateral cooperation includes a feasibility assessment on installing a meteorological radar station in the northern Philippines, in addition to the proposed typhoon center under the APEC framework, Ma said.

He pointed out that all nations attach great importance to regional cooperation when studying climate change and that Taiwan and the Philippines, each of which face the threat of natural disasters, should strengthen their cooperation.
Ma also said the Philippines will hold a general election in two weeks, and expressed hope that the two sides can maintain good science and technology exchanges after the polling.

DOC.HEADLINE: Media challenges discussed at international conference
DOC.DATELINE: Hong Kong, April 27 (CNA) 04/27/10 22:46:41 (By Chris Wang)

TEXT.P: Media members taking part in an international conference Tuesday discussed possible new models for the media business, which is facing enormous challenges in the Internet age.

Items such as "free vs. subscription, " the fierce competition for readership and advertising dollars and the "rethinking of the media" were discussed by participants in a debate titled "Sustainable Media Models in the Internet Age" on the second day of the 2010 International Media Conference, organized by the U.S. Congress-funded East-West Center.
Joshua Benton, Director of Nieman Journalism Lab at Harvard University, noted that it is difficult for traditional media to be profitable in an age in which fewer people read print news.
Since 2006, one-third of newsroom jobs in the U.S. have been cut, he said.
While the average time spent on a news website per user averages between 2-8 minutes per month, Benton said, the same stats for the social website Facebook is 7 hours per month.
According to Benton, most news organizations lack technical expertise and their newsrooms tend to insist on sticking with traditions, which hampers much-needed adjustment.

Benton said that a good model for increasing revenues would be to publish newspapers only two or three times per week, charging NT$315 (US$10) per paper. That way, he said, readers would be interested in news content because there would be increasing segregation between printed material and web content.

Thomas Crampton, a former New York Times journalist, said the emergence of social media such as blogs, and services such as Facebook and Twitter, have caused a structural impact, as the barrier of entry has become extremely low, while some advertisers no longer deal with the print media at all.
Charging readers does not sound like a good idea because "a lot of people will be happy with the free alternatives, " he said.
In terms of the negative impact suffered by the emergence of the Internet, the media business is a lot like the music industry, Crampton went on.

He advised the media to pay attention to the three pillars of "print, online and in-person, " which means media companies should provide their news stories online and in print, and should probably organize real-life events to create closer bonds and better communication with readers.

Reginald Chua, editor-in-chief of the Hong Kong-based South China Morning Post, said the media suffers because the revenue it receives from advertisements and subscriptions and the costs of news production do not match.

Chua urged the media to think hard about how to generate revenue, how to change its way of telling stories, how the newsroom can help with reporting and how to restructure the newsroom, which according to him has not changed much since the 1950s.

DOC.HEADLINE: Government embarking on `golden decade' for Taiwan: CEPD
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, April 27 (CNA) 04/27/10 22:52:02 (By C. Wei Hsieh and Flor Wang)

TEXT.P: To help Taiwan cope with a fast-changing global economy, the Council for Economic Planning and Development (CEPD) has started working on a program with the aim of creating a "golden decade" for the country, CEPD Vice Chairman Hu Chung-ying said Tuesday.

In addition to crafting an economic strategy to sharpen Taiwan's competitiveness, the "2020 national visionary program" will outline projects for the country's development on a broad range of fronts over the next decade, Hu told a news conference.
"The CEPD will iron out a development blueprint for the major challenges that Taiwan is likely to encounter in the coming 10 years, ranging from an aging society to green industry," he said.

As Taiwan and China are expected to soon ink an economic cooperation framework agreement (ECFA) that might lead to a fundamental change in Taiwan's economic structure, Hu said it is vital that Taiwan explores its niche in long-term development at a time when most countries have already begun to do so.

Hu's remarks came after President Ma Ying-jeou revealed the "golden decade" vision Sunday in a debate with opposition Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) Chairperson Tsai Ing-wen on whether or not Taiwan should sign the ECFA with China.
In contrast to Tsai's fear that the proposed ECFA will hurt Taiwan's economy and sovereignty, Ma said the agreement is vital to Taiwan's survival after eight years of inaction under the DPP.

DOC.HEADLINE: Today in history
DOC.TEXT:
Today is Wednesday, May 28, or the 15th day of the third month of the Year of the Tiger according to the lunar calendar. Following is a list of important events that have occurred on this date in the past:
1738: French physician and revolutionary Joseph Ignace Guillotin is born. He developed the execution device which was so heavily used during the "reign of terror" in the French revolution that it would later bear his name.
1754: George Washington, then in the service of the British Crown, destroys a French regiment under Jumonville near Uniontown, Penn., in the first battle of the French-Indian Wars.
1759: English statesman William Pitt the Younger is born. He became prime minister at the age of 24, the youngest-ever British prime minister.
1912: Patrick White, the Australian novelist who won the Nobel Prize for Literature in 1973, is born.
1934: Cecilie, Emilie, Marie, Annette and Yvonne Dionne are born to Olivia Dionne in Callender, Canada. They are the world's first surviving quintuplets.
1932: Dutch engineers complete the world's biggest dam, a major victory in their 900-year battle to push back the sea. The new dam, or dike, is 29 km long and turns the Zuider Zee into a vast freshwater lake, called the Ijsselmeer.
1933: Chinese Gen. Feng Yu-hsiang revolts at Kalgan Pass, near Changkiakow, capital of China's Chahar Province.
1956: Republic of China Foreign Minister George K.C. Yeh informs Philippine Ambassador Narciso Ramos that the ROC has full sovereignty over the Nansha, or Spratly Islands.
1959: The United States launches its Jupiter rocket into space with two monkeys aboard. The monkeys return to earth safely, opening the way for manned space flight.
1966: Construction of Taiwan's Northern Cross-Island Highway is completed. An inauguration ceremony is held at Tahsi, Taoyuan County.
1966: The Cultural Revolution begins in mainland China after the central committee of the Chinese Communist Party sets up a "central cultural revolution group" to lead the movement.
1967: Francis Chichester, a 65-year-old British yachtsman, receives a hero's welcome when he arrives in Plymouth 119 days after setting out on a solo round- the-world trip.
1972: The Duke of Windsor, the British king who abdicated to marry American divorcee Wallis Simpson, dies in Paris at the age of 77.
1974: The Pacific-Asian Congress of Municipalities opens its third conference in Taipei.
1978: Chiang Ching-kuo, who was sworn in as the 6th president of the ROC on May 20, tells Reader's Digest that "our interests and those of America cannot be divided. If we stick together, both will benefit. If we go our separate ways, both will suffer. In any case, the Republic of China will persist."
1981: The ROC Executive Yuan approves Premier Sun Yun-suan's appointment of Konsin Shah as ambassador to the Republic of Uruguay and Loh I-cheng as ambassador to the Republic of Guatemala.
1982: Pope John Paul II arrives in Britain for the first papal visit to Britain since 1531.
1985: President Luis Alberto Monge Alvarez of the Republic of Costa Rica arrives in Taipei for a visit.
1986: The ROC Ministry of Foreign Affairs protests an Argentine gunboat attack on an unarmed ROC trawler in the seas off the Falkland Islands that left one dead, one missing, and six injured.
1987: Mathias Rust, a West German teenager, flies his Cessna light plane from Helsinki to Moscow and lands in Red Square, evading the entire Soviet air defense system. Both the Soviet defense minister and the air defense commander were sacked as a result of the prank.
1989: The Ching Kuo, the first ROC-developed and manufactured indigenous defense fighter, successfully completes its first test flight.
1995: A strong earthquake rocks the Russian Far East oil-producing town of Neftegorsk on Sakhalin Island, killing more than 1,980 people.
1996: The ROC exchanges economic and trade representative offices with the Republic of Belarus. Belarus is the second (Russia being the first) member of the Commonwealth of Independent States to establish such a level of relations with the ROC.
1998: Pakistan conducts five nuclear test blasts and declares a state of emergency, triggering economic sanctions by Japan and the United States.
2000: Taiwan's Tseng Hsin-feng wins Japan's three-day Kosaido Ladies' Golf Tournament in the Tokyo suburb of Ichihara.
2001: The New Taiwan dollar plunges three percent, or 1.0005 against the U.S. dollar to close at 34.5 on the Taiwan Foreign Exchange market.
Confucius' lesson of the day: "Men of totally different principles can never act together."

DOC.HEADLINE: Four bodies dug out from freeway landslide rubble
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, April 28 (CNA) 04/28/10 09:13:41 (By Chen Chin-ping, Wang Hung-kuo and Elizabeth Hsu)

TEXT.P: Four bodies had been dug out of rubble of the No. 3 National Freeway landslide in northern Taiwan as of Wednesday morning, according to the Keelung City Fire Bureau.
A couple, identified as Kuo Wen-han and his girlfriend Lee Shi-ji, were first found in a black Mercedes at 3: 40 a.m., the bureau said.

Then on the northern end of northbound lanes, rescuers discovered the body of the missing taxi driver Lin Huei-hsin at 5 a.m. before they dug out the driver of a Q5-1452 sedan, identified as Yeh Mao-chu, at 7:22 a.m., the bureau said.
The bodies were delivered to their family members after being examined by a prosecutor, it added.

More than 1,000 rescue workers, manning 200 excavators and other heavy equipment, have been working non-stop since Sunday to rescue four cars and five people feared buried in the landslide, which covered 300 meters of the freeway's Keelung-Sijhih section with around 200,000 cubic meters of soil and rock.

DOC.HEADLINE: International cooperation critical to homeland security: president
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, April 28 (CNA) 04/28/10 11:45:20 (By Garfie Li and Sofia Wu)

TEXT.P: President Ma Ying-jeou said Wednesday that a stronger international cooperation network should be established to better protect homeland security.

Addressing the opening of a two-day international seminar on homeland security, Ma said he hoped concrete measures could be proposed through discussions at the seminar to facilitate the establishment of a loophole-free international security net.

The issue is more pressing today because the concept of homeland security has expanded since the 911 terrorist attacks on the United States and now covers many non-conventional security considerations.

In addition to conventional military and terrorist attacks, homeland security also encompasses health and economic threats, such as the 2008-2009 global financial crisis and swine flu outbreaks, Ma said.
In those two cases, the international community worked together to help mitigate their impact on various countries around the world, he noted.

Stressing that Taiwan is more than willing to cooperate with other countries in addressing public health issues, Ma said Taiwan not only actively contained the spread of the influenza A (H1N1) virus through school closures but also produced vaccines for a nationwide immunization campaign.

To better cope with the consequences of climate change, Ma said Taiwan has assisted the Philippines in establishing 15 automatic weather observation stations to improve the accuracy of typhoon forecasting.

In terms of more conventional security challenges, the president said, Taiwan benefited from international cooperation in obtaining intelligence to prevent possible security glitches during two major international sports events held in Taiwan's two largest cities in 2009 -- the Taipei Deaflympics and the Kaohsiung World Games.
The homeland security seminar brought together scholars and experts from Taiwan and five other countries to boost international cooperation in preventing security incidents.

Speaking on the same occasion, Premier Wu Den-yih said global weather changes have made it all the more important for each country around the world to devote more energy and effort to ensure international peace and order as well as protect safety of human lives and property.

Noting that Taiwan often encounters natural disasters and is active in international trade and other international activities, Wu said Taiwan must fulfill its obligations as a member of the international community and fully cooperate with other peace-loving democratic countries in enhancing homeland security.

DOC.HEADLINE: China Times: Original survey data should be made public

TEXT.P: The results of recent surveys released by various media outlets consistently show that most people think President Ma Ying-jeou performed better than opposition Democratic Progressive Party Chairperson Tsai Ing-wen in the Sunday debate on the proposed economic cooperation framework agreement (ECFA) with China. People's awareness and support for the ECFA have also increased significantly after the debate, according to the results.
The only exception is the Liberty Times, which published figures that are totally at odds with the other surveys.

A polling organization that operates normally usually conducts more than 100 surveys a year. However, the Liberty Times "poll center" has only released the results of three surveys over the past five years, all of which came at crucial times, such as before an election, and contained figures that were totally opposite to those obtained by others.
We are curious about when the "poll center" was established, who its manager is and the background of its members.

We are not insinuating that the survey is fake. Our question is: Why not make public the questionnaire? Other details that were not provided also include the demographics of the sample, the political affiliation of the respondents and the response rate.

The best way to clear up the doubts is for the Liberty Times "poll center" to provide the telephone numbers of the respondents and recording of the interviews with them as well as other data files for reexamination by a neutral academic institution. If the "poll center" did conduct the survey, it should not be difficult at all to make public the "original data." (April 28, 2010)

DOC.HEADLINE: United Daily News: Landslide exposes flaws in disaster prevention

TEXT.P: The landslide that occurred Sunday on the Cidu section of the No. 3 National Freeway has seriously dented the public's confidence in the freeway system. How could the slope have collapsed barely two months after it passed a spot check that showed "no abnormalities"?

Conducting a comprehensive inspection and strengthening the monitoring of the freeway system is probably the only way out. We should no longer use naked-eye observation but should employ instruments for the purpose.
A fundamental way to tackle the problem is to set up a database of sites that constitute potential geological risks, draw a disaster prevention map, and restrict the use of high-risk land.

Just like the collapsed Siandu Mountain that buried Siaolin village during Typhoon Morakot last August, the site of the latest landslide is a dip slope consisting of alternating layers of sandstone and shale with particularly big gaps in between. Rainwater making its way into those gaps could act as a lubricant helping the slope slide down. Unfortunately, we did not learn a lesson from the loss of more than 400 lives in Siaolin village.
Many government agencies regularly survey sensitive, high-risk land. Regrettably, the data collected have not been integrated for practical use.

Only if the fundamental work is done properly will we be able to forecast, prevent and avoid disasters. Taiwan must not continue to allow such disasters to erode its national strength. (April 28, 2010)

DOC.HEADLINE: Economic Daily News: Tax cut should be able to create triple wins
DOC.DATELINE: 04/28/10 12:13:57 (By Elizabeth Hsu)

TEXT.P: The government's proposed amendment to the income tax law is expected to clear the legislature's floor this coming Friday. Once it is passed, the corporate income tax rate will fall to 17 percent.

Although the tax cut will lower tax revenues by an estimated NT$34.3 billion, it is expected to boost industrial development and increase Taiwan's tax income in the middle and long run. The ruling Kuomintang has estimated that the tax cut will create NT$69 billion in economic benefits.

There is optimism that the tax cut will end the seemingly hostile stand-off between large and small enterprises, raise tax income in the long term and sharpen the competitive edge of Taiwan's businesses. But we're skeptical the win-win-win situation can just pop up out of nowhere. Is there a possibility the triple wins could become a triple defeat?

Could the tax cut lead to the erosion of the country's tax base, expand the gap between rich and poor due to an imbalance in the tax system, and lower national competitiveness because the tax change affects resource distribution and industrial activity in a negative way?

It depends on where the money that companies save thanks to the tax adjustment will go. The best scenario is that the funds will be spent on creating innovation, cultivating talent and increasing employment. If so, we see it as the beginning of the win-win-win scenario.

However, we've observed that many local enterprises are relocating overseas or reducing investment in Taiwan not because of high tax rates but because of government restrictions and a bad investment environment.
The government needs to put forth measures that can harness the potential benefits the expected tax cut can generate.

Taiwan faces serious problems, including high unemployment and an aging population. The government needs to build a solid social welfare system and an economic security mechanism for the country. Those measures are just as important to improving the investment environment as cutting taxes. (April 28, 2010).

DOC.HEADLINE: Changhua County to develop cultural, creative industries
