DOC.HEADLINE: Research team reveals how staph infections resist antibiotics
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, April 28 (CNA) 04/28/10 14:31:55 (By Sunnie Chen)

TEXT.P: A Taiwanese research team has discovered a key molecular mechanism that contributes to antibiotic resistance in "Staphylococcus epidermidis, " a type of staphylococcus that lives on the skin, according to Academia Sinica, Taiwan's top research institute.
Staphylococcus bacteria are notorious for quickly developing resistance to antibiotics and are the main culprit in hospital-acquired infections that can kill patients admitted for other diseases.
Among them, the staphylococcus epidermidis usually lives off skin and causes no harm to healthy people, according to the team from Academia Sinica's Institute of Biological Chemistry.

But it can cause severe infections in immune-suppressed patients and those with catheters or other surgical implants, said Andrew H.J. Wang, vice president of Academia Sinica and the research team's leader.
The key to understanding the mechanism described by Wang's team is that the bacteria protects itself from the host's immune system and enhances its resistance to antibiotics by producing a biofilm.

The groundbreaking research revealed the structure of the protein component, called Teicoplanin-Associated Locus Regulator, or TcaR, that effectively prevents the formation of the biofilm under normal conditions.

But when antibiotics are introduced, they induce the inactivation and departure of TcaR from the DNA it would normally bind with, allowing the antibiotic- resisting biofilm to form, according to Wang.
"It is very exciting to note that our study has clearly delineated the antibiotic binding site of TcaR and the mechanism of how antibiotics induce biofilm formation, " Wang said.
"It is expected that additional drugs will be designed and developed through the help of structural biology."
Chang Yu-ming, the study's lead writer, said future research should be targeted at identifying or developing antibiotics that do not precipate the changes that lead to the inactivation of TcaR.

One approach, he said, was to screen existing antibiotics to see if any avoid interacting with cells TcaR. Researchers could also develop 3D structural models to run simulations of the biofilm formation mechanism that might help lead to more effective medications.

The article "Structural Study of TcaR and its Complexes with Multiple Antibiotics from Staphylococcus epidermidis" was published in the scientific journal "Proceedings of the National Academy of Sciences (PNAS)" on April 27.

DOC.HEADLINE: Talk of the day -- TSMC bullish on semiconductor growth
DOC.DATELINE: Taiwan Semiconductor Manufacturing Co. (TSMC) 04/28/10 14:47:17 (By Sofia Wu)

TEXT.P: Chairman Morris Chang was bullish on the semiconductor sector's growth prospects in the near future, predicting that the global semiconductor market will grow 22 percent and the contract chip making business will grow 36 percent in 2010.
The following are excerpts from local media coverage of the issue: Economic Daily News:

TSMC, the world's largest contract chip manufacturer by revenues, posted better- than-expected results for the first quarter of this year, with net earnings per share of NT$1.3, higher than the NT$1.2 forecast by foreign financial institutions.
Chang said TSMC's Q2 sales are expected to grow by 8.5-10.6 percent to a record high of NT$100 billion to NT$102 billion, based on an exchange rate of NT$31.1 to the greenback.

He further said that as global semiconductor demand in the first half of this year is stronger than normal, growth in the second half of the year may be slower. The global semiconductor business will remain robust for all of 2010, he said, with growth reaching 22 percent, higher than the previous forecast of 18 percent. (April 28, 2010). China Times:
TSMC's Q1 sales totaled NT$92.19 billion (US$2.94 billion) which generated anet profit of NT$33.66 billion, or NT$1.3 per share, the highest in the past eight quarters.
Chang revealed for the first time in Tuesday's conference call that TSMC will launch construction on its 15th wafer foundry at the Taichung Science Park in central Taiwan later this year.
According to Chang, the company's Fab15 will start with 40 nm processes but plans to add 28nm and 20nm processes in the future.
Construction on Fab15 is scheduled to start in mid-2010, Chang said, adding that the project will help increase job opportunities in the Taichung area. (April 28, 2010). Commercial Times:
Fab15, TSMC's third 12-inch wafer foundry, is expected by equipment manufacturers to be its most advanced 28nm fab.

TSMC decided to accelerate its construction of the NT$100 billion foundry because the demand for memory chips using processes more advanced than 0.13 micron technology outpaces supply by 30 percent to 40 percent.
By the end of this year, the company's 12-inch wafer fab production will increase by 35 percent, with the volume accounting for 50 percent of its total production. (April 28, 2010).

DOC.HEADLINE: First Chinese fishing workers enter Taiwan under new system
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, April 28 (CNA) 04/28/10 15:21:18 (By Johnson Sun and Elizabeth Hsu)

TEXT.P: The first group of Chinese fishing workers to be hired by Taiwanese fishing boats under a new screening system arrived in Taiwan Wednesday.

The 48 Chinese workers, the first group hired under an agreement on fishing crew cooperation signed by Taiwan and China last December, were ferried to the Danshuei second fishing port in northern Taiwan's Taipei County from Fujian, southern China.
Soon after the Chinese workers arrived, security inspectors from the Maritime Patrol Directorate General under the Coast Guard Administration boarded the boat to confirm their identities.
Five of the workers got off in Danshuei and immediately underwent health exams and had their personal documents and luggage checked.
The other workers were later dropped off at the ports of Yehliu (20) and Shenao (8) in Taipei County, Badouzih (6) in Keelung City, and Daxi (9) in Yilan County, according to the Fisheries Agency.
They had all been hired in advance by local fishing boat owners through qualified manpower brokerage agencies.

Before the agreement on fishing crew cooperation was signed late last year, Chinese nationals working on Taiwanese fishing boats were not allowed to set foot in Taiwan. They had to stay on fishing boats or so-called "hotels on the sea" off the country's coast.

The agreement also enables local fishing boats to better screen Chinese workers they hire. Previously, no mechanism existed to systematically check the identities, backgrounds, or health of the Chinese nationals they employed.

Since the pact was signed on Dec. 22, 2009, 14 brokerage agencies, including the Taiwan Provincial Fishermen's Association, were approved to introduce Chinese fishing workers to Taiwan, the agency said.

DOC.HEADLINE: Taiwan needs to restore its coastal forests: COA
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, April 28 (CNA) 04/28/10 16:03:33 (By Yang Su-min and Fanny Liu)

TEXT.P: Taiwan needs to put more effort into restoring its coastal forests so that they can serve as protection against wind and tides, the Cabinet-level Council of Agriculture (COA) said Wednesday.

Chen Tsai-hui, an analyst at the COA's Taiwan Forestry Research Institute, said that the country's coastal forests have declined substantially in recent years because of the establishment of coastal industrial parks, fishing ports, and recreational and wind power facilities.

The western coastline is suffering serious erosion, Chen said. The overuse of concrete armor units and bulwarks defeat the purpose of their construction, often resulting in encroachment of the sea, he added.
Land subsidence along the southwest coastline has also resulted in coastal forests being swamped, he said.
Another problem is air pollution caused by wind-blown sand in the monsoon season, which is becoming more serious in the area near the mouths of the Jhuoshui and Dajia rivers, he noted.

In order to limit the damage from high tides and sandstorms, more forests should be planted along Taiwan's 1,250 kilometers of coastline, and the mangrove forests near river mouths need to be restored, Chen advised.

DOC.HEADLINE: Taiwan share prices close lower
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, April 28 (CNA) 04/28/10 16:11:56 (by Olivia Wang)

TEXT.P: Taiwan's share prices were down Wednesday, with the weighted index -- the market's key barometer-- falling 64.89 points, or 0.79 percent, to close at 8,081.55.
The local bourse opened at the day's low of 7,944.70 and rose to 8,092.48 before dropping again. Market turnover totaled NT$123.68 billion (US$3.94 billion).

All eight major stock categories lost ground, with financial and banking stocks dropping the most at 1.88 percent, followed by paper and pulp issues at 1.2 percent, construction shares at 1.19 percent, foodstuff issues at 0.73 percent and machinery and electronics stocks at 0.62 percent.
Textile issues dropped 0.56 percent, plastics and chemicals stocks 0.53 percent and cement shares 0.36 percent. Losers outnumbered gainers 2,402 to 914, with 158 stocks remaining unchanged.
Foreign investors and Chinese QDIIs were net sellers of NT$7.15 billion in shares.

DOC.HEADLINE: U.S. dollar up on Taipei Forex
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, April 28 (CNA) 04/28/10 16:24:07 (By Olivia Wang)

TEXT.P: The U.S. dollar gained ground against the New Taiwan dollar on the Taipei Foreign Exchange Wednesday, rising NT$0.127 to close NT$31.539, its high for the day.
A total of US$1.59 billion changed hands during the trading session.
The U.S. dollar opened at NT$31.412 and fell to a low of NT$31.360 before rebounding.

DOC.HEADLINE: KMT promises speedy legislation of geological bill
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, April 28 (CNA) 04/28/10 17:03:13 (By Justin Su, Wang Shu-feng and Lilian Wu)

TEXT.P: A massive landslide on the No. 3 National Freeway that killed at least four people has brought home the urgency of passing a geological bill, and the ruling Kuomintang will speed up its screening, a KMT whip said Wednesday.
Lin Hung-chih said that although a geological bill almost passed during the previous legislature, lawmakers had requested the proposal be reconsidered.

At the time, legislators said the bill would conflict with around 10 existing laws, and even require farmers to submit geological safety assessments if they want to build houses on their own farmland.
But Lin said that in light of the landslide Sunday, passing the bill is a high priority.
"The Executive Yuan has submitted a new version of the geological bill, and KMT lawmakers will speed up the screening process, " Lin said.

In the wake of the tragedy, Lin also asked the government to make a thorough assessment of dip slopes -- geological formations often created by the erosion of tilted strata -- on national, provincial and county roads and residential areas.
Lin made the remarks at a press conference with Tsao Su-chung, chief of the Planning Office of the Central Geological Survey under the Ministry of Economic Affairs, attending.

Tsao said that if the bill passes, the government will publish a list of geologically sensitive regions. Development of the regions would have to pass geologic surveys and safety assessments and then certified by the technicians.
"The passing of the law will also help the government compile and manage the geological information," he added.

Tsao said that for large-scale sensitive areas, the government could install strain measuring instruments to monitor land changes, and take preventative measures. For small-scale sensitive areas, the government could reinforce existing structures.
But installation of the devices would have to take cost into consideration, Tsai said.

Meanwhile, the Taipei City government said that 30 out of the city's listed 135 residential communities on slopes were near dip slopes. Officials urged the public to check the Internet for related information.

The Construction and Planning Agency under the Ministry of the Interior said there should be a law on the publication of related information, but conceded it would trigger controversy as it would include private property.
Housing brokers said that the incident might affect the prices of housing units near slopes.

On the fourth day after the landslide, the Ministry of Transportation and Communications said that clearing work will continue and that aerial photos will be posted on the Internet to help the public follow its progress.

Three cars and four people were buried in the landslide, which covered 300 meters of the freeway's Keelung-Sijhih section with around 200,000 cubic meters of soil and rock. Four bodies were dug out on Wednesday.
As of noon Wednesday, 55,466 cubic meters had been cleared from the landslide area.

DOC.HEADLINE: Scholars discuss ECFA, arms sales in cross-Strait relations forum
DOC.DATELINE: Hong Kong, April 28 (CNA) 04/28/10 17:10:47 (By Chris Wang)

TEXT.P: Scholars from Taiwan and China recognized the positive direction in which bilateral relations are heading but disagreed on U.S. arm sales to Taiwan, at a forum on cross-Taiwan Strait relations in Hong Kong Wednesday.

Highlighting improving relations are negotiations over a proposed economic cooperation framework agreement (ECFA) that Taiwan's president, Ma Ying-jeou, hopes to sign in June, according to the speakers.

The agreement would not only represent the normalization of bilateral trade relations but also a needed step before both sides enter a phase of political negotiations, said Chu Shulong, deputy director of the Institute of International Strategic and Development Studies at China's Tsinghua University.

Chu and his Taiwanese counterpart Alexander Huang, a professor in Tamkang University's Graduate Institute of International Affairs and Strategic Studies, addressed more than 100 media members at the forum, moderated by American Institute in Taiwan (AIT) Chairman Raymond Burghardt, on the final day of the 2010 International Media Conference, organized by the U.S. Congress-funded East- West Center.
The AIT is the U.S. representative office in Taiwan in the absence of formal diplomatic ties. Burghardt doubles as director of East-West Seminars in the East-West Center.
Huang described the ECFA as signifying Taiwan's intention to "reconnect with the Asia Pacific region and the ASEAN community, " Huang said.

He also brushed off the concern of the opposition Democratic Progressive Party that it would make Taiwan's economy too dependent on China, saying that "no matter what happened, Taiwan's investment kept flowing to China over the past 20 years."

While Chu said Beijing is ready to talk to Taiwan on political issues, including confidence-building measures (CBMs) , after the signing of the ECFA, Huang said the Ma administration is hesitant to do so because of domestic politics.

The subject of U.S. arm sales to Taiwan also popped up at the forum, with Chu saying that Beijing recognized that Taiwan had the right to possess and seek to procure weapons from other contries, but that countries like the U.S. or Japan have no right to sell weapons to Taiwan because Taiwan is a part of China.

Taipei has defended its purchases of weapons because of Beijing's threat to use force against Taiwan, backed by a heavy military build-up that includes more than 1,000 missiles targeted across the Taiwan Strait.
Ma has said that any negotiations on a cross-strait peace pact could not begin until Beijing had removed or dismantled the missiles.
According to Chu, China needs to maintain its military deployment, including the missiles, to prevent against a worst-case scenario.

He said Beijing continues to monitor Taiwan's independence movement, a sentiment it believes still enjoys strong support in Taiwan, and remains prepared for the possibility that the DPP will return to power.

Also, better cross-strait ties have not led to a fall in U.S. arms sales to Taiwan, Chu noted. The Obama administration still approved the sale of a US$6.5 billion package of weapons to Taiwan in January, a fact that Chu said was difficult for China to accept.

Huang responded that the U.S. is the only country that provides Taiwan the weapons it needs, and Taiwan does not challenge China's military deterrence or posture across the Strait with its weapons procurement and would not attack China.
Burghardt pointed out the paradox of the triangular U.S.-Taiwan-China relationship, which he said the U.S. side "basically wrestles with every day."

Any Taiwan government, he said, wants clear U.S. public support before dealing with China, which was why issues like arm sales, extradition, avoidance of double taxation, and visits by Cabinet members have been important to Taiwan.
That helps Taiwan's president show Taiwan's people that he is not ignoring the U.S. as he tries to improve cross-Strait ties, he said.

China, however, constantly objects to U.S. moves that show its support for Taiwan even though the U.S. has warned that cross-Strait relations would possibly grind to a halt if China failed to realize the mindset.

Huang said most Taiwanese people do not oppose better economic relations with China, as almost one-tenth of Taiwan's population live in China to do business. And they want an elected government that is able to manage or nurture better cross-strait relations.

What Taiwanese people need in cross-strait exchanges, Huang said, is a strategic reassurance that there will be no war, and they want to preserve their democratic system so their future generations can enjoy basic freedoms and choose their lifestyles, while also being able to elect their president once every four years.

DOC.HEADLINE: President observes silence for landslide victims
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, April 28 (CNA) 04/28/10 17:18:45 (By Lee Shu-hua, Garfie Li and Fanny Liu)

TEXT.P: President Ma Ying-jeou observed one minute of silence Wednesday for victims of the massive landslide on the No. 3 National Freeway.

Three cars and four people are believed to have been buried in the landslide, which covered 300 meters of the freeway's Keelung-Sijhih section with around 200,000 cubic meters of soil and rock. Four bodies were dug out earlier Wednesday.
At the beginning of the ruling Kuomintang's Central Standing Committee meeting Wednesday afternoon, Ma led participants in observing a minute's silence.
Meanwhile, Premier Wu Den-yih said earlier that the government will give NT$1 million (US$31,786) to each victim's family and will do its best to rescue possible survivors.
"Such a massive landslide disaster will not be allowed to happen again," Wu said after attending a seminar on homeland security.
Vice Premier Eric Liluan Chu also expressed his condolences to the victims of the tragedy, saying that the government hopes to clear the freeway as soon as possible.

DOC.HEADLINE: ECFA will help cross-strait peace: president
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, April 28 (CNA) 04/28/10 17:42:53 (By Garfie Li and Y.L. Kao)

TEXT.P: President Ma Ying-jeou said Wednesday that signing a proposed economic cooperation framework agreement (ECFA) with China will promote peace between the two sides.

Ma cited a report by a London-based economic policy institute as saying that the best way for two rivals to ease hostility is to initiate a free trade agreement (FTA), raising the costs if they opt to enter war after the pact is signed.
Ma made the remarks at a tea party celebrating the 100th birthday of former Republic of China Ambassador to Malawi Chao Chin-yung at the Taipei Guest House.
Ma also expressed his respect for Chao, who worked at the Ministry of Foreign Affairs between 1939 and 1984 and still serves as a foreign affairs adviser.
While praising Chao for his contribution to the country, Ma said that few people understand the pressure and hardship that Taiwan's diplomats encounter.
Ma said that he has been striving to expand Taiwan's international space and enhance ties with countries by improving cross-Taiwan Strait relations.
Although some see danger in the detente with China, Ma said he believes the policy is going in the right direction because it seeks to resolve the problem at its root.

He said that the United States, Japan, Europe, New Zealand, and Australia have become more at ease about improving ties with Taiwan due to an improvement in cross-strait relations over the past two years.

Taiwan's promotion of economic and trade exchanges, as well as humanitarian and cultural diplomacy with other countries, has drawn attention from the international community that could better protect its safety and interests, Ma added.

As a result of government efforts, local companies received procurement orders worth about US$50 million last year after Taiwan became the 41st member of the Government Procurement Agreement (GPA) under the World Trade Organization last July. The figures could reach US$400 million this year, the president said.

DOC.HEADLINE: Endangered Taiwan sassafras trees found in unexpected location
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, April 28 (CNA) 04/28/10 18:05:29 (By Lin Heng-li and Elizabeth Hsu)

TEXT.P: Researchers found a sizable group of endangered Taiwan sassafras trees in central Taiwan for the first time last month, an unexpected surprise that prompted the Forestry Bureau to decide to preserve their genes and try to cultivate them in the future.

The group of trees was found by forest bureau inspectors while they were doing a field survey in the Danda mountain area in Sinyi Township of central Taiwan's Nantou County, the bureau's Nantou office said Tuesday.

Tseng Yen-hsieh, an assistant professor at the Department of Forestry of National Chung Hsing University, who was commissioned to verify the finding in Danda, said there are over 20 trees in the group, measuring 20 to 30 centimeters in diameter.

It was the second biggest group of the endemic species, listed by the International Union for Conservation of Nature as endangered, ever to be found in Taiwan and the first to be discovered in the central part of the country.

The only bigger population group of the species has been found in Sheipa National Park, which straddles Miaoli and Hualien counties in northern and eastern Taiwan, according to Liu Fu-sheng, the director of the bureau's Nantou office.
Tseng said he advised the bureau to preserve the trees' seeds for regeneration after observing that they had developed a healthy population.

Taiwan sassafras (Sassafras randaiense) is native to Taiwan but rarely observed now in the wild, Tseng said. He noted that the plant plays a vital ecological role in Taiwan because it is the sole food source for caterpillars of the endangered broad-tailed swallowtail butterfly (Agehana maraho).
Once the plant dies off, it will lead to the extinction of the butterfly, which is also endemic to Taiwan, Tseng said.

According to the Nantou forestry office, sassafras grew widely around the globe before the Ice Age, when it nearly went extinct. Now only three kinds of the species exist in the world -- the one in Taiwan, one native to eastern North America and one native to China.
Taiwan sassafras has existed on the island for 1.8 million years, and the office's Liu said that from the viewpoint of conservation, it must urgently be protected and researched.

DOC.HEADLINE: Nearly half of Taiwan firms willing to hire Chinese graduates
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, April 28 (CNA) 04/28/10 18:19:43 (H. C. Lin the Flor Wang)

TEXT.P: Some 47 percent of Taiwanese firms are willing to hire university and college graduates from China or Hong Kong, a recent survey found.

Chinese university graduates have good communication and foreign language skills as well as international vision, Taiwanese companies that have employed Chinese graduates told the 104 Job Bank, which conducted the survey March 8-19.

Although graduates in Taiwan and China possess different qualifications, Fang Kuang-wei, 104 Job Bank public relations manager, said Taiwanese college students remain competitive in the local job market, as local university graduates are strong in professional expertise, respect team work and follow ethic principles.
Citing the results of previous polls, Fang said the overall competitiveness of Taiwanese graduates is 1.86 times better than that of their Chinese counterparts.
Vickey Chen, chief of human resources at Standard Chartered Bank, said that Taiwan acts as a "talent bank" in Asia, exporting high-end power to China and the rest of the region.

Chen praised Chinese graduates as more ambitious and braver than their Taiwanese peers. "This is something which enterprises appraise very much when they need personnel to explore new markets," she said.

Meanwhile, graduates from National Cheng Kung University, National Taiwan University and Tamkang University are the most popular among local businesses, the survey found. Graduates from Feng Chia University and Fujen Catholic University ranked in the fourth and fifth spots, the same survey found.
The job bank said graduates of private universities such as Tamkang, Feng Chia and Fujen were also highly praised by local companies.

According to Fang, 62.63 percent of enterprises said students at local universities and colleges should increase their work experience. Some 47.71 percent said foreign language abilities should be improved and 42.29 percent recommended getting professional aptitude certificates.
As Taiwan and China will soon sign an economic cooperation framework agreement (ECFA) with China, Fang said Taiwanese students will definitely face stiffer competition from China and other countries.
"Foreign language ability is thus very important, " he said, adding that obtaining higher degrees or spending time abroad would not necessarily improve an applicant's chances of obtaining a job.
The job bank collected 1,127 valid samples for the survey, which had a margin of error of 1.98 percent.

DOC.HEADLINE: Yunlin County set to hold watermelon festival
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, April 28 (CNA) 04/28/10 19:12:32 (By Yang Shu-min and Sofia Wu)

TEXT.P: A watermelon festival will be held in the south-central county of Yunlin this weekend to showcase different varieties of the fruit, the Council of Agriculture (COA) said Wednesday.
At the 2010 Taiwan Watermelon Festival, people will be given an opportunity to discover possibilities for innovative use of watermelons, the council said in a press statement.

The trade fair, to be held at Yunlin County Stadium, will include a number of competitions and events such as a feast at which watermelon will be used as the main ingredient in the dishes that will be prepared by professional chefs in the Yunlin area.
As a warm-up to the fair, a "high-quality watermelon" contest was held Wednesday, drawing the participation of some 578 watermelon growers from around Taiwan, the COA said.
The top winner in each of the four categories -- large, medium, small and mini- size watermelons -- was given a plaque and a cash prize of NT$16,000 (US$509.55).
The festival is being jointly sponsored by the COA, the Yunlin County government and a farmers welfare fund.

DOC.HEADLINE: Despite government scrutiny, property lending still balloons
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, April 28 (CNA) 04/28/10 19:23:54 (By Frances Huang)

TEXT.P: Although financial authorities have stepped up efforts to prevent real estate bubbles, Taiwan's bank loans to property developers are still on the rise, partly fueling the sky rocketing property prices, analysts said Wednesday.
In March, bank loans for construction totaled NT$1.06 trillion, up NT$24.2 billion from a month earlier, even hitting a new 13-month high, statistics from Taiwan's Central Bank showed.

Local property prices in the first quarter of 2010 rose by about 10 percent from the same period a year earlier and are expected to grow further for the rest of the year, according to real estate agency Taiwan Realty Corp., adding that a recovering local economy was also a factor.
In recent months, the government authorities have put the booming local property market under close scrutiny in an attempt to prevent escalating market speculation.

The speculation is largely driven by anticipation of a boom in property values after Taiwan signs a landmark trade agreement with mainland China, which is expected to bring an infusion of Chinese capital to Taiwan's market. Also driving the speculation is extra cash flowing around from people who are still cautious about investing too heavily in stock markets.
Market observers remain skeptical of the impacts of the government's efforts to stabilize the property market as loans for property purchases are still growing.

"The move adopted by the financial authorities is not harsh at all. I do not expect it will impose any immediate impact on property prices, " Lee Jian-ming, an analyst with Sinyi Realty Inc., told CNA.

Meanwhile, the central bank and the Financial Supervisory Commission are tightening measures in examining banks' lending practices due to fears that rising bank loans to property speculators will boost housing prices.

In the initial stage, the financial authorities targeted bank lending to luxury residential property buyers, and now they are also monitoring loans to land investors as well as loans to property developers by asking banks to keep an eye on risk control.
Last week, the authorities staked out about 10 banks to check whether they have followed government instructions to cut investment property lending and raise interest rate levels for property loans.
Under the examination, banks had to show the authorities how they reviewed property loan applications and how they set interest rates.

Through such strict examination measures, the authorities hope they can get a better sense about whether and how property developers are hoarding land for future profits, and how the property market will evolve.
"But what property investors fear is interest rate hikes by the Central Bank," Lee said.
But he added that was unlikely to happen.
"As the local economy remains on the way to a recovery, it is unlikely for the central bank to employ such a dramatic way to hurt the real economy," Lee said.
Lee said foreign funds are expected to continue to flow into the island and local real estate will be one of their major investment targets.
Taiwan Realty analyst Brian Lee agreed, adding he expects local prices for the whole of 2010 to rise by up to 15 percent from 2009 levels and the peak is expected to be seen in the third quarter.
Banks also said they believe the government has no intention of depressing property prices, but just want to "stabilize" the local real estate market.

DOC.HEADLINE: Taiwan Red Cross delegation visits Shaanxi
DOC.DATELINE: Mian, Shaanxi, China, April 28 (CNA) 04/28/10 19:35:10 (By Chen Cheng-wei and James Lee)

TEXT.P: A delegation assembled by the Red Cross Society of the Republic of China visited a post-earthquake school reconstruction project in Mian County in the northwestern Chinese province of Shaanxi Tuesday.
The delegation was headed by Wang Ching-feng, vice president of the Red Cross Society who once served as minister of justice.
In a ceremony held at Yifu Elementary School in Mian County, Wang presented scholarships to students in need.

After the ceremony, a woman told Wang that her husband had been working far away in the south for long time so that he could pay for medical treatment for their daughter who has leukemia and that the earthquake had exacerbated the situation.
Hugging the child, Wang said, "Let's do something about that."
Another parent, Chang Hsu-hsin, said that it is heartbreaking that he has to work a part-time job building homes for other people while his is still a wreck.
According to Chang, he is thankful that his daughter is very sensible and sweet and does her homework on her own, which means he doesn't have to worry.
Asked if she is afraid of earthquakes, Chang's daughter said bashfully that she hopes the reconstruction work can be finished soon so that she can go to school and do her homework in a decent place.
A magnitude-7.9 earthquake that was centered in Sichuan Province in May 2008 caused serious damage also in the neighboring Shaanxi Province.

DOC.HEADLINE: Premier says drugs are biggest threat to public security
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, April 28 (CNA) 04/28/10 20:08:53 (By Hsieh Chia-chen, Justin Su and Fanny Liu)

TEXT.P: Premier Wu Den-yih said Wednesday that the problem of drugs poses the biggest threat to Taiwan's public security at present, and the authorities should intensify their clamp down against drugs.

During the first three months of this year, police seized a total of 1,922 kilograms of drugs, up 1,099 kg, or 75 percent from the same period last year, according to the National Policy Agency (NPA) under the Ministry of the Interior.

Police investigated a total of 12,225 cases involving the possession of drugs in the first quarter, up 987 from the same period last year, the NPA said at a conference on public security in the Executive Yuan.
And 12,816 suspects were arrested, up 1,068, or 9 percent, from the same time last year, the agency said.
One of the reasons why the number of drug cases and people arrested have increased is because ketamine has been classified as an illegal drug, according to the agency.

Under a law revision that took effect last November, individuals who possess more than 20 grams of "third-grade" banned drugs like ketamine are subject to a jail sentence of up to three years. Those who possess less than 20 grams of the drug will be fined between NT$10,000 (US$317) to NT$50,000.

To further prevent the spread of ketamine, a legislative judiciary and laws and statutes committee asked the Ministry of Justice Wednesday to discuss within one month whether ketamine should be reclassified from a "third-grade" to a "second- grade" banned drug, so that heavier criminal responsibility will be applied to those drug possessors.
Deputy Minister of Justice Wu Chen-huan said that most members of the ministry's drug review committee considered ketamine as a party drug with limited drug dependence.

Classifying the drug as a second-grade drug may increase the cost to society, Wu said. Such a change could also result in more people who would be arrested dropping out of school or losing their jobs, he said.

Premier Wu on Wednesday requested the police agency to not only step up investigations and crackdowns against drugs, but to also join forces with social and private groups and use education, counseling and other methods to raise public awareness about the dangers of drug use.

DOC.HEADLINE: Mexican trade, culture office unveils gallery
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei April 28 (CNA) 04/28/10 20:24:42 ( by Sunnie Chen)

TEXT.P: The Mexican Trade Services Documentation and Cultural Office in Taiwan is embracing the arts with a new art gallery in the waiting area for visa applicants, greatly changing people's impression of the space, the head of the office said.

Cultural communication is the most natural and best way to let Taiwanese people know more about Mexico, Martin Munoz Ledo Villegas , head of the Mexican office, told the Central News Agency when asked about the reasons for establishing the gallery.
The current exhibit showcases 12 works by 11 contemporary Mexican female artists and runs through May 28.

Munoz Ledo said he thought of setting up the gallery because "the area is not only for applying papers, but can be a corner presenting artworks. Actually we also have used the space for all kinds of activities, such as concerts, lectures, arts and many others since last year."
He also welcomed other foreign offices in Taiwan to use the space to present their cultures.
The exhibition, which opened this month, features porcelain and oil paintings by female Mexican artists including Monica Castillo, Alicia Paz and Irma Palacios.
"Most of these works are strongly influenced by world-famous Mexican painters Diego Rivera and Frida Kahlo, " the office chief said.
"I hope that we can also bring Diego Rivera's and Frida Kahlo's works here in the future. This event is to pave the road for that, " he said.
Having been assigned to Taiwan for three and a half years, the office chief thinks that the key for promoting exchange is based on a mutual understanding of the countries' people.
Munoz Ledo said he hoped to increase tourism and business opportunities by introducing Mexican culture, food and art, and expanding local understanding of his country.
Statistics from the office show that in recent years, the number of Taiwanese tourists to Mexico has increased greatly, propelling Taiwan into second place after India for Asian tourists, he said.

"In 2006, my office issued about 4,000 visas, of which business visas accounted for approximately 85 percent to 90 percent, " Munoz Ledo said. "But in 2009, we issued 6,000 visas, with business visas dropping to 60 percent of the total and the remainder being tourist visas."
Munoz Ledo said he was encouraged by the numbers and has set a goal this year to persuade even more Taiwanese people to go to Mexico.
"I hope that the number from Taiwan will surpass the number from India," he said.

DOC.HEADLINE: Government urged to hire more social workers in schools
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, April 28 (CNA) 04/28/10 20:35:37 (Huang Ming-hsi and Y.L. Kao)

TEXT.P: A children's rights advocacy organization said on Wednesday that increasing reports of child abuse showed Taiwan needed to hire 2,500 more social workers.
On average, there is one case of child abuse reported every two days, said Yeh Ta-hwa, secretary-general of Taiwan Alliance for Advancement of Youth Rights and Welfare.
Yeh attributed the situation partly to a dearth of social workers trained to work with children.
From January to April there were 61 cases of child victims of murder-suicides, child abuse and sexual abuse on campuses or in homes, with 19 deaths and 17 injuries.
The figures showed that the existing Child and Youth Welfare Code is not enough to protect children, Yeh said.
Yeh said Taiwan has a severe shortage of social workers, with only 55 social workers at schools in five cities and counties.
The ratio of school social workers to students is about 1: 1,000 in many countries, and Taiwan has more than 2 million students, according to Yeh.
If the country wants to keep up, it should add 2,500 more social workers in schools and help centers, Yeh said.
The alliance is pushing for legislation to protect children and youth, and to enable Taiwan to keep abreast of international standards of child protection.

DOC.HEADLINE: More overseas Taiwan firms preparing to list on local bourse
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, April 28 (CNA) 04/28/10 20:41:22 (By Y. P. Tien and Flor Wang)

TEXT.P: Some 40 foreign-based Taiwanese companies are likely to obtain listings on the Taiwan Stock Exchange (TAIEX) by the end of this year, bringing the ratio of such enterprises listed on the local market to 5 percent, the TAIEX reported Wednesday.

As of the end of last year, 14 Taiwanese companies had listed Taiwan Depositary Receipts on the local stock market, and four more companies followed suit in the first four months of this year, the TAIEX said.
The number will hit 40 by the end of this year and hopefully will grow by 10 percent in 2011, it added.

More and more Taiwan businesses operating abroad are becoming willing to list on the local bourse because of the deregulation policies adopted by the administration of President Ma Ying-jeou, a TAIEX executive said.
"This will help boost and diversify Taiwan's capital market, which is aiming for more technology shares," the executive said.

DOC.HEADLINE: Taiwan's SEF helps fishing boat seek compensation from Chinese ship
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, April 28 (CNA) 04/28/10 20:52:02 (By M. S. Huang and Flor Wang)

TEXT.P: Taiwan's Straits Exchange Foundation (SEF) , acting on behalf of a Taiwanese fishing boat which was recently hit by a Chinese fishing vessel, wrote a letter Wednesday to its Chinese counterpart asking for compensation from the Chinese ship.
It was the reported that the Taiwanese boat from Suao in eastern Taiwan's Yilan County was scraped on the side by the Chinese vessel that was operating nearby in the area.

Four Indonesian fishermen working for another Taiwanese fishing ship boarded the Chinese boat to try to help with the incident, but the Chinese vessel nevertheless escaped from the scene at full speed.
The four fishermen were later brought back to Taiwan after Taiwan's coast guard authorities dispatched a vessel to their rescue.
SEF said Wednesday it is now asking ARATS to help the Taiwanese vessel seek NT$11 million in compensation from the Chinese ship.
According to SEF Deputy Secretary General Kao Wen-cheng, the SEF immediately sent the letter to the ARATS over the compensation issue after it got relevant papers from the Taiwanese ship owner.

"We soon contacted the Beijing-based Association for Relations Across the Taiwan Straits (ARATS) for some NT$11 million in compensation from the Chinese ship after learning that the Suao-based fishing boat was hit by it on April 12 while operating in the Taiwan Strait, " Kao told a coordination meeting sponsored by Kuomintang Legislator Lee Ching-hua Wednesday.
SEF and ARATS, representing Taipei and Beijing, respectively. are semi-official bodies in charge of cross-strait dealings.
The extent of the damage to the Taiwanese fishing vessel made it impossible to be used for fishing until repairs are made.

DOC.HEADLINE: Presidential Office questions DPP head over cross-strait trade pact
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, April 28 (CNA) 04/28/10 21:07:28 (By Garfie Li, Wen Kuei-hsiang and Lilian Wu)

TEXT.P: The Presidential Office on Wednesday raised several questions regarding a proposed cross-strait trade pact with China and asked opposition Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) Chairwoman Tsai Ing-wen to answer them.

Lo Chih-chiang, spokesman of the Presidential Office, said the DPP has continued to claim that President Ma Ying-jeou evaded the questions raised by Tsai during the high-profile debate between the two on Sunday over the issue, but actually, it was Tsai who failed to answer questions raised by Ma.

Lo asked that if Tsai's fear of signing the proposed cross-strait economic cooperation framework agreement (ECFA) is that Taiwan will open itself up to Chinese products within a decade, does that mean that the DPP will not sign any trade pact similar to that of the ECFA with China within the 10 year period?
Lo also asked how long the DPP thinks Taiwan can afford to drag its feet as all Asian countries are engaging in economic integration, and as Taiwan's exports to major markets are declining.

Tsai had also questioned whether Taiwan has relied too much on China in terms of its exports. But Lo said if this is so, how come the DPP did not take any action during its eight years in office when the percentage of Taiwan's exports going to China surged from 24 percent to 40 percent.

Tsai has admitted that the DPP had opened Taiwan's market to 936 mainland Chinese agricultural products during its rule between 2000 and 2008, but Ma has not added any new items since his inauguration in May 2008. Then why is the DPP accusing Ma of selling out Taiwan, Lo asked.
The Presidential Office also asked what the DPP thinks are the alternative options for Taiwan if it does not sign the trade agreement with China, Taiwan's biggest trade partner and export market.
If the high-tariff sectors go to China for investment, then the industrial exodus will lead to unemployment, Lo said, asking how Tsai would deal with the unemployment problem.

On Tsai's declaration the previous day that if the DPP returns to power in 2012, it will initiate a national referendum to scrap the ECFA, Lo said that this shows that the DPP only thinks about the 2012 presidential election and has not thought about the economic future of Taiwan.

In response, a DPP spokesman said Wednesday that Tsai has provided the Ma administration with good recommendations based on her professionalism and knowledge of related issues, but Ma did not want to address the issues of the impact of the ECFA on Taiwan's people, the government's contingency measures, as well as the public's misgivings about the trade pact.

DPP spokesman Tsai Chi-chang said the questions raised by the Presidential Office are for political gains, and the DPP will have no time for it, but it welcomes Ma to have more debates on the trade agreement issue if he is willing to return to a more professional stance.

Tsai Chi-chang also said that if President Ma continues to ignore the voice of the people, and insists on signing the ECFA in June, then if the DPP returns to power, it will initiate a referendum to let people decide whether to continue or terminate the ECFA.
Tsai Chi-chang said that the signing of the ECFA will trigger the most serious wealth redistribution in Taiwan's history.
"Shouldn't the government listen to the people's voice and let the people decide through a referendum on the process of this kind of wealth redistribution?" he asked.

Tsai Chi-chang said that as the gap between the rich and poor in Taiwan is already big, judging from the experience of the Closer Economic Partnership Arrangement (CEPA) signed between Hong Kong and China, if an ECFA is signed, the gap will be even wider.
Tsai Ing-wen believes that if a policy will change the wealth map and benefit only a few, then why not listen to the people and let them decide, according to Tsai Chi-chang.

DOC.HEADLINE: Taiwan to open cultural academies in U.S.
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, April 28 (CNA) 04/28/10 21:24:28 (By Tsai Hsin-hua and Sofia Wu)

TEXT.P: Taiwan is preparing to open academies in Los Angeles and Houston to promote Taiwanese culture and help Americans understand the value of traditional Chinese characters, a senior official said Wednesday.

"The initiative to set up a Taiwan Academy in Los Angeles and Houston is entering a final stage and could be put in practice as soon as the end of this year, " said Emile Sheng, minister of the Council for Cultural Affairs (CCA).

Fielding questions at a hearing of the Legislative Yuan's Committee on Education and Cultural Affairs, Sheng said the CCA will discuss details regarding the Taiwan Academy initiative with other government agencies in May and that if all goes well, the program to promote the study of traditional Chinese characters and introduce Taiwanese culture will be launched late this year.
Sheng admitted that the Taiwan Academy initiative echoes China's efforts to set up Confucius Institutes to promote Chinese language and culture.

China has so far established more than 500 Confucius Institutes around the world. The rapidly growing number of Confucius Institutes has even prompted some Americans into thinking that Confucianism is a religion, according to ruling Kuomintang (KMT) Legislator Chiang Nai-hsin.

Speaking at the same session, KMT Legislator Hung Hsiu-chu said Taiwan should not sit idly by while China actively promotes Chinese language and culture, as Taiwan has been a stronghold for preserving traditional Chinese culture.
"We may be unable to compete with China in terms of quantity, but we have an edge in presenting Chinese culture experts and enthusiasts an alternative choice," Hung said.

In addition to letting the international community know that there is another Chinese-speaking world, Hung said, Taiwan Academy should provide a unique core value or concept to distinguish it from China's Confucius Institute.
Sheng said he shares Hung's views.

"Our top goal is helping foreigners understand that Taiwanese traditional culture and traditional Chinese characters are more valuable than the simplified Chinese characters presently used in China," he said.

DOC.HEADLINE: President expedites help to families of landslide victims
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, April 28 (CNA) 04/28/10 21:27:12 (By Lee Shu-hua and Y.L. Kao)

TEXT.P: President Ma Ying-jeou ordered the Ministry of Transportation and Communications (MOTC) Wednesday to help the families of those who were killed in massive landslide on the No. 3 National Freeway to apply for national compensation.

Ma, who is also chairman of the ruling Kuomintang, issued a directive by phone to Transport Minister Mao Chi-kuo for the MOTC to show the government's sincerity by offering help to the families instead of waiting for them to appeal for assistance, said KMT spokesman Su Jun-pin.
The president gave the directive before a KMT Central Standing Committee meeting at which he asked for a moment of silence in memory of the victims and in sympathy with their families.
Rescue workers on Wednesday dug out four bodies from the rubble at the site of the landslide that occurred Sunday.

Mao said later in the day at a press conference that Deputy Transport Minister Yeh Kuang-shih had met with the relatives of the victims and given each family condolence compensation of NT$1 million (US$31,786) . He also provided them with information on how to apply for national compensation, according to Mao.

Yeh said that the relatives of Kuo Wen-han, the driver of a black Mercedes Benz that was crushed by the landslide, have said they will apply for national compensation but the other three families have not yet decided.
The MOTC will do its best to help the families, Mao stressed.

Meanwhile, a 10-member investigation committee commissioned by the ministry to investigate the cause of the landslide was assembled Wednesday, with Liao Hung- jiun, a professor at National Taiwan University of Science and Technology, serving as the head. Its members will include experts in the areas of geology, civil engineering, soil and water conservation, and earth science.

The committee will search for clues to the cause of the disaster -- the worst on a freeway in 30 years -- and will mobilize 50-60 engineers to carry out safety checks on all the slopes along the freeway.
Lao said the results of the checks can be completed within a week if the weather permits.

DOC.HEADLINE: GIO announces list of music groups that will receive subsidies
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, April 28 (CNA) 04/28/10 21:43:13 (By Tsai Hsin-hua and Lilian Wu)

TEXT.P: The Government Information Office (GIO) announced Wednesday the first batch of eight local music groups that will receive its subsidies for taking part in international popular music activities.

The GIO said that the local music groups, including Tizzy Bac, which is very popular among the youngsters, will take part in international music activities in the United States, Lithuania, and Germany.

To upgrade the level of and help raise the international prominence of Taiwan's pop music groups, the GIO has since last year begun to subsidize local music groups to take part in international music events.

This year, the subsidies have also been expanded to include participation at international music seminars, invitations extended to international music figures to travel to Taiwan for seminars, or those in Taiwan's music sector to take part in short-term courses overseas.
The subsidies also will be raised from NT$600,000 to NT$1 million per case.

DOC.HEADLINE: Taipei City faces housing shortage of nearly 75,000 units: MOI
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, April 28 (CNA) 04/28/10 21:50:44 (By Hsieh Chun-wei and Fanny Liu)

TEXT.P: Taipei City suffered the worst housing shortage among all the cities and counties in Taiwan in the last quarter of 2009, falling short of demand by 74,868 units, the Ministry of Interior (MOI) said Wednesday.
According to the MOI's Construction and Planning Agency, Taichung City in central Taiwan was out front in terms of housing supply, with a surplus of 73,104 units in Q4 2009.
In addition to the capital city, other areas that recorded housing shortages in the fourth quarter of last year included Yunlin County, Kaohsiung County and Kinmen County, the agency said.

Figures for that quarter show that the total number of households in the country was 7.8 million units, up 1.96 percent from the same period of 2008, and the supply of housing units was 7.83 million, up 0.91 percent year-on-year, the agency said.

Although there was a country-wide surplus of 33,000 units, it did not necessarily mean that there was an adequate supply of housing, an official at the agency said, adding the figures did not reflect the movement of residents.

The number of building permits in Q4 was 18,223, up 28.4 percent from the same period of 2008, while the number of permits for occupancy of residence was 17,387, down 33.7 percent year-on-year, the agency said.
The worst housing shortage in Taipei City occurred in Q3 2006, when demand exceeded supply by 81,861 units, according to the agency.

DOC.HEADLINE: President Ma to be interviewed on CNN
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, April 28 (CNA) 04/28/10 22:03:53 (By Carfie Lee and Flor Wang)

TEXT.P: President Ma Ying-jeou will be interviewed by CNN host Christiane Amanpour Wednesday night via video conferencing and the interview will be broadcast April 30 at 8: 00 p.m. (Taipei time) on the U.S. cable news network, according to the Presidential Office.

During the 20-minute segment on "Amanpour: The Power of Interview," President Ma will talk about his policies on major issues such as cross-Taiwan Strait relations, a proposed economic cooperation framework agreement (ECFA) with China, the six new star industries being promoted by his administration and about epidemic prevention, the Presidential Office said in a press release.
Ma will link up with Amanpour via video conferencing at a TV studio in Taipei, while she will speak from a CNN studio in New York.

Since the launch of the program in September 2009, Amanpour has interviewed Zimbabwe President Robert Mugabe, South African President Jacob Zuma, former Israeli Prime Minister Ehud Barak and U.S. Secretary of State Hillary Clinton, among others.

DOC.HEADLINE: Ma's Harvard University speech listed in U.S. Congressional Record
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, April 28 (CNA) 04/28/10 22:41:27 (By Hsieh Chia-cheng and Lilian Wu)

TEXT.P: President Ma Ying-jeou's speech on Taiwan's future, which he gave in a video conference with faculty and students of Harvard University earlier this month, has been included in the U.S. Congressional Record, the Ministry of Foreign Affairs (MOFA) said Wednesday.
The MOFA said in a press release that the speech was listed in the Congressional Record one day after U.S. Congressman Dan Burton (R- IN) issued a statement calling for its inclusion.

During the address on April 6, Ma talked about a wide range of issues, including the prospects for cross-Taiwan Strait relations, his approval ratings and Taiwan's opening to China's financial institutions.

DOC.HEADLINE: British Museum plans to acquire Taiwanese artist's paintings
DOC.DATELINE: London, April 28 (CNA) 04/28/10 22:57:52 (By Jennifer Huang and Sofia Wu)

TEXT.P: The British Museum plans to acquire two paintings by Liu Kuo-sung, one of the most famous Taiwanese modernist ink painting masters, when an ongoing exhibition of his works in London ends, arts sources said Wednesday.
A collection of 25 of Liu's paintings that is currently on display in the U.K. has been highly acclaimed by the British arts community.
It is the 78-year-old painter's first exhibition in London after a 30-year hiatus.

The British Museum has shown keen interest in acquiring two of the works on display -- "Rising Sun," a color ink painting created in 2008 and "Sun and Moon: Floating? Sinking? " that was done in 1970, sources close to the museum said.

Chang Siao-yue, Taiwan's representative to the United Kingdom, told the Central News Agency after visiting the exhibition the previous day that she admires Liu's work and is very happy to learn that the British Museum plans to acquire some of his masterpieces.
"Buying master Liu's paintings will never be a bad decision," she added.

Liu's paintings have been shown at many well-known museums in the United States, Switzerland, Italy, Germany, Australia, Malaysia, the Philippines and other countries. The Beijing Palace Museum has not only held an exhibition of his works but has also acquired some of them.
If the British Museum, one of the world's top three museums, indeed acquires two of Liu's paintings, it will be yet another milestone in his career which spans more than six decades.
Liu described the two paintings sought after by the British Museum as exquisite and impeccable works that rank among his favorites.
Michael Goedhuis, an arts agent who organized Liu's London show, said Liu was the first artist of Chinese descent to diligently study Western painting art and techniques, in the 1950s.
Goedhuis said Liu has spent 40 years creating a new painting style that incorporates Western arts concepts and classic Chinese civilization.

Liu's efforts to blend Western and Chinese arts and cultures have infused new life into traditional Chinese ink and brush paintings, said Goedhuis, adding that Liu has been a trailblazer in the modernization of Chinese fine art.
Liu's exhibition has been highly praised by the British media, arts critics and museum curators and many orders have been received for his paintings.
Liu and his wife have already left London for a lecture tour in China.

DOC.HEADLINE: NTU team unveils 'zero-energy building'
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, April 28 (CNA) 04/28/10 23:10:02 (By Hsu Hsiung-hsin and Y.L. Kao)

TEXT.P: A "zero-energy building" developed by a team led by a National Taiwan University (NTU) professor were unveiled Wednesday at a seminar titled 2010 Solar Building Technology and Industry Development at the university in Taipei.

Huang Bin-juine, director of NTU's New Energy Center and a professor in the Department of Mechanical Engineering, presented the technology -- the result of concerted efforts by more than 10 graduate students and engineering researchers at the center.

The 13-square-meter building, which was constructed using thermal insulation and high-efficiency environmental control technologies as well as solar energy generation systems, can be used by three people, according to Huang.
He said it was developed to run on solar power alone, without the need for petrochemical energy.
With only a few members of the team specializing in architecture, there is room for improvement in the design and planning of the structure, according to Huang.

A new generation of zero-energy buildings is expected to be rolled out within six months and the technologies for mass production of such buildings are near completion, Huang said, adding that they could spawn a new industry. He called on the construction industry to tap business opportunities in the sector.

Two years ago, the NTU team was awarded NT$100 million by the King Abdullah University of Science and Technology (KAUST) in Saudi Arabia for the development of the Solar Energy Research Center, making the university the only one in Asia to win the award.

DOC.HEADLINE: Today in history
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, April 29 (CNA) 04/29/10 08:56:09
DOC.TEXT:
Today is Thursday, April 29, or the 16th day of the third month of the Year of the Tiger according to the lunar calendar. Following is a list of important events that have occurred on this date in the past:
1429: French military leader and heroine Joan of Arc enters Orleans, France, and defeats English forces. She was later tried for heresy and witchcraft and was burned at the stake in Rouen.
1661: Cheng Cheng-kung, also known as Koxinga, a national hero and one of the Ming loyalists and resistance fighters against foreign invasion, claims Taiwan from the Dutch and chooses Anping (present-day Tainan) as his capital, in the hope of returning to mainland China one day to restore the Ming dynasty.
1667: John Arbuthnot, Scottish physician and writer, is born. He was noted for his satirical anti-Whig pamphlets published in 1712 as "Law Is a Bottomless Pit" and later retitled "The History of John Bull."
1769: Arthur Wellesley, Duke of Wellington, English soldier and later the prime minister known as the Iron Duke, is born. He defeated Napoleon at Waterloo.
1818: Alexander II, the czar of Russia who emancipated the serfs in 1861, is born. He was assassinated in 1881 after severe repression of political opposition.
1863: William Randolph Hearst, American newspaper and magazine publisher, is born. Beginning with the San Francisco Examiner in 1887, he built the world's largest publishing empire, comprised of 28 major newspapers.
1901: Hirohito, the Japanese emperor who advocated the country's unconditional surrender that ended World War II, is born. He renounced his divine status in 1946.
1903: After Russia refuses to leave Manchuria when the troops of other foreign powers withdraw from Chinese territory, and prior to the outbreak of the Russo- Japanese War, Chinese students studying in Japan meet in Tokyo and set up a "Resist Russia" volunteer corps.
1937: American chemist Wallace Hume Carothers commits suicide just two months after he patented nylon.
1942: Japanese troops capture the Burmese town of Lashio, cutting off the Burma Road between China and India.
1945: U.S. forces in Germany liberate 32,000 victims of the Nazi death camp at Dachau, just northwest of Munich.
1946: Former Japanese leaders are indicted in Tokyo as war criminals.
1948: Li Tsung-jen is elected vice president of the Republic of China in the republic's fourth ballot.
1957: The first nuclear reactor goes into operation in the United States.
1969: Hsu Peh-yuen, governor of the Central Bank of China, is released from office and succeeded by Yu Kuo-hwa, the incumbent minister of finance.
1975: The last U.S. troops are evacuated from Saigon as thousands of foreigners and South Vietnamese are ferried out by helicopter from the roof of the American embassy.
1976: Edward Y. Kuan, ROC vice minister of foreign affairs, is named by the Executive Yuan as first ambassador to South Africa.
1976: The Sino-U.S. Seminar on Food Science and Nutrition opens in Taipei with 24 food scientists attending.
1980: Alfred Hitchcock, the British-born film director and the silver screen's master of suspense, dies in Los Angeles at the age of 80.
1985: The space shuttle Challenger is launched, and Dr. Wang Kan-chuen becomes the first Chinese American astronaut in space.
1992: Bolivian Vice President Luis Ossio Sanjines officiates at the inauguration of the Bolivian Commercial and Financial Representative Office in Taipei.
1993: Representatives of the Straits Exchange Foundation (SEF) and its mainland counterpart, the Association for Relations Across the Taiwan Strait, sign three agreements and a joint accord at a historic meeting in Singapore; the agreements and accord went into effect on May 29.
1996: On the third anniversary of the Koo-Wang cross-strait talks, SEF Chairman Koo Chen-fu appeals to mainland China not to postpone the second round of talks so that both sides can resume their pursuit of reunification.
1998: North Korea publishes an open letter by its leader Kim Jong-Il calling for unification with South Korea.
2000: Premier-designate Tang Fei checks out of Taipei Veterans General Hospital after fully recovering from surgery removing a benign thymoma on April 16.
2001: The Ministry of National Defense says that in accordance with relevant government laws, military generals on active service will not be allowed to travel to mainland China either for meetings or visits.
Confucius' lesson of the day: "A workman who wants to perfect his work first sharpens his tools. When you are living in a country, you should serve those nobles and ministers in that country who are men of moral worth, and you should cultivate the friendship of the gentlemen of that country who are men of moral worth."

DOC.HEADLINE: Taiwan shares open higher
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, April 29 (CNA) 04/29/10 09:15:42 (By James Lee)

TEXT.P: The Taiwan Stock Exchange's main index opened higher Thursday than its previous close, moving up 24.41 points at 8,105.96 on a turnover of NT$5.034 billion (US$160.32 million).
