DOC.HEADLINE: Taiwan headline news
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, April 29 (CNA) 04/29/10 10:54:59

DOC.HEADLINE: Apple Daily: No death, no action

TEXT.P: In Taiwan, a lot of legislation can be described using the Chinese proverb "not shedding a tear until one sees the coffin." One example is the geology bill, which has long been stalled in the Legislative Yuan and is now receiving attention from lawmakers only after people were killed in a recent landslide on the No. 3 National Freeway.

It is shameful to even speak of why legislators refused to review the bill for so many years. It was because of their collusion with property developers, who could suffer great losses if their hillside development projects were to be banned under the proposal. Legislators even failed to change their minds when the Lincoln Mansions -- a hillside residential complex in Sijhih, Taipei County -- collapsed in 1997.

The bill even cleared the legislature in 2004. However, a group of 42 legislators, most of whom were from the blue camp, wanted it to be reconsidered on grounds that it would cause inconvenience for the public. It has since been paralyzed.

The bill would require the government to publicize areas with sensitive geological conditions and limit development projects there. Permission to build in those areas would only be granted if they passed geological surveys and safety assessments. No wonder property developers are opposing it vigorously.

It is frightening to see high-rise buildings covering the hillsides of the greater Taipei area. With constant earthquakes and the increased frequency of heavy rains because of climate change, those households can only rely on luck or pray for their safety because they have legislators who collude with business groups.

DOC.HEADLINE: United Daily News: ECFA, a springboard for globalization
DOC.DATELINE: 04/29/10 12:48:33 (By Deborah Kuo)

TEXT.P: Opposition Democratic Progressive Party Chairperson Tsai Ing-wen recently said that by attempting to sign an economic cooperation framework agreement (ECFA) with China, the ruling Kuomintang (KMT) is trying to lead Taiwan's economy to the world via China.
During her debate with President Ma Ying-jeou, Tsai said that the DPP, which held power from 2000 to 2008, had on the contrary taken steps to "lead Taiwan toward China via the world."

Tsai opposed Ma's push to sign an ECFA with China too quickly, which she said would make Taiwan's economy overly dependent on China. She suggested Taiwan first build multilateral trade ties with China and the rest of the world under the World Trade Organization (WTO) framework.
Tsai's suggestion was unrealistic, given that the WTO's Doha round of talks has stalled and trade liberalization has not worked in Taiwan's favor.

The ECFA, however, is seen to open Taiwan's market "in a gradual manner" and pave the way for Taiwan to enhance trade ties with other WTO member countries and strike free trade agreements (FTAs) with other countries.
This can be seen as a two-step approach that will act as a springboard for Taiwan to trade globalization.
If Taiwan can survive the ECFA trial and gradually improve its business and trade relations with China, the country will be in a better position to meet the challenges of opening its market.

Tsai is mistaken in supporting the WTO but opposing an ECFA. Taiwan would have to open its doors much wider to imports from China and many other WTO member countries if the Doha agreements are put into force, but an ECFA would allow freer two-way trade only across the Taiwan Strait, with Taiwan enjoying room to maneuver. (April 29, 2010).

DOC.HEADLINE: Astrophysicists unveil shape of dark matter's distribution
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, April 29 (CNA) 04/29/10 13:44:38 (by Sunnie Chen)

TEXT.P: An international team of astrophysicists including Japanese scholars working at Academia Sinica discovered clear, direct evidence about the shape of dark matter's distribution, according to a press release from Taiwan's top research institute Thursday.

Dark matter is an enigma of the cosmos that has fascinated astrophysicists for many years. The existence of dark matter was originally hypothesized to account for discrepancies found between measurements of the mass of galaxies, clusters of galaxies and the entire universe.

As dark matter is invisible and no "dark matter particle" has been discovered, however, its existence is only inferred from a gravitational effect on other visible celestial matter or theoretical models, the scientists said.

Recently, astrophysicists from Japan and Taiwan, including Postdoctoral Fellow Nobuhiro Okabe from the Institute of Astronomy and Astrophysics at Academia Sinica (ASIAA), have evidence that dark matter is distributed in an elliptical shape in massive clusters of galaxies, a finding that confirms a major prediction in the prevailing theory about dark matter.

The team observed the clusters of galaxies using the Subaru Telescope's Prime Focus Camera (Suprime-Cam) . Observations with Suprime-Cam yielded wide-field images of massive clusters of galaxies -- typically located 3 billion light years from Earth -- which the team then used to measure and analyze dark matter distribution, the institute said in a press statement.

From their analysis of the images, the team obtained evidence that the distribution of dark matter in the clusters has, on average, an extremely flattened shape rather than a simple spherical shape. The degree of the flattening was quite large, corresponding to ratio of 2: 1 in terms of the ratio of the major to minor axes of the ellipse.

The team's article, entitled "Direct measurement of dark matter halo ellipticity from two-dimensional lensing shear maps of 25 massive clusters, " was published online April 23 in Monthly Notices of the Royal Astronomical Society, a leading astrophysics journal.

DOC.HEADLINE: Talk of the day -- New momentum on geological bill

TEXT.P: The mudslide that buried a section of a freeway and took four lives last Sunday has led to new momentum on discussion of legislation intended to govern the development of geologically fragile areas.
The following are excerpts from local leading newspapers' reports of the issue. China Times:

Last Sunday's mudslide that buried a section of the No. 3 National Freeway and killed four has drawn public attention to the enactment of a draft geological act, with lawmakers across the political spectrum vowing to railroad it through the legislature.

The Legislative Yuan's Economics Committee decided to alter its agenda on Thursday to listen to a brief by Minister of Transportation and Communications Mao Chih-kuo on the disaster and potential mudslide threats to the country's highways.

Tsao Shu-chung, director of the Central Geological Survey under the Ministry of the Economic Affairs, said the bill was crafted to make public the geologically sensitive areas around the country, regulating their development and improving the management of geological data.
The geological bill was intended to safeguard the security of the public by stepping up geological surveys and the management of geological data and employing them in construction projects.

The bill went through the Legislative Yuan in 2004 but was put on hold after a group of legislators led by current Nantou Magistrate Cho Po-yuan asked for reconsideration on the grounds that parts of it conflicted with existing laws. The group also said the proposal would oblige farmers to conduct unnecessary geological surveys before building their houses.
Their request for reconsideration was approved by the legislature and the bill was remanded to the Executive Yuan for improvement, but it soon lost momentum.
Legislator Wong Chin-chu of the Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) said that current Premier Wu Den-yih helped kill the bill by endorsing Cho's request in 2004.
"It is ridiculous that he would change his mind and push for it now," Wong said.
The premier said he asked for reconsideration because of conflicts in the bill and that he would urge the legislature to support it now that the bill has been revised.

Legislator Lin Hung-chi, secretary of the legislative caucus of ruling Kuomintang (KMT) , said Sunday's mudslide underscored the importance of the bill and that the KMT caucus will shepherd it through as soon as possible. (April 29, 2010) United Daily News:
Public Construction Commission Minister Fan Liang-shiow said no geologically sensitive areas should be developed. "The government will set an example in this regard," he said.

Legislator Chien Chao-tong of the DPP is one of the 41 lawmakers who endorsed Cho's reconsideration request in 2004. He said he supported the request because of the bill's restrictions on farmers. Liberty Times:
The DPP criticized Premier Wu Den-yih for blocking the geological bill in 2004 and now, finding he was mistaken, going all out to push for it.

President Ma Ying-jeou's administration revised the bill and presented it to the legislature again earlier this year. However, it was returned to the Executive Yuan for additional review by the Economics Committee in March.

Legislator Huang Wei-cher of the DPP prodded the government to disclose housing projects and public construction projects that are threatened by mudslides, without regard to the impact on housing prices and pressure from real estate developers. (April 29, 2010)

DOC.HEADLINE: Economic Daily News: Unexpected discoveries from ECFA debate

TEXT.P: Following the debate between President Ma Ying-jeou and opposition Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) Chairperson Tsai Ing-wen on a proposed trade pact with China, we find that two issues crucial to Taiwan's economic development deserve further discussion.

First, Ma's statement that "trade is Taiwan's life" indicated that he fully understood where the true problem lies, and he also put forth possible solutions. Now that he is heading in the right direction, he should persist and remove all obstacles to carry out the plans.
Second, when speaking of the differences between the DPP and Ma's Kuomintang (KMT) , Tsai said "the DPP is approaching China via the world, while the KMT is approaching the world via China."
However, the DPP's indirect approach of trying to use multilateral arrangements to gain access to China has been proven a failure. After missing out for eight years, can Taiwan continue to wait?

Tsai also said that by signing a trade pact with China alone, Taiwan could tilt the regional strategic balance and lead to the creation of a "China-centered" East Asia. But in fact, no country can block China from becoming the center of East Asia. With all the countries in the region scrambling to get on the high- speed train driven by China's economic growth, Taiwan will only end up in a dead end if it allows itself to be shut out.

The differences should be resolved through rational discussion in the Legislative Yuan. The strategy that is considered the most favorable to Taiwan and is accepted by most people should be considered the right strategy. (April 29, 2010)

DOC.HEADLINE: Most Taiwan consumers look product reviews before buying: poll
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, April 29 (CNA) 04/29/10 14:52:07 (By Kao Chao-fen and Frances Huang)

TEXT.P: A majority of Taiwan consumers refer to product reviews by marketing analysts when making decisions on the purchase of goods and services, according to the results of a recent survey.

Some 40 percent of Taiwanese consumers in the poll said that before making a purchase they take into consideration product reviews by experts, 26 percent said they refer to scientific research reports, and 24 percent said they pay attention to the views of their peers.
The survey by Reader's Digest magazine asked consumers in Taiwan, China, Hong Kong, India, Malaysia, the Philippines, Singapore and Thailand how they go about buying brand name products and services.

The 104 products and services specified in the annual survey, which began 12 years ago, included consumer electronics goods, financial services, restaurants, health care products, information technology products, luxury goods and telecommunications items, 50 of which were made in Taiwan.
Consumers aged 40 and over in Taiwan said they considered product reviews that were based on scientific research, while younger Taiwanese said they paid attention to the views of their peers.
In the purchase of flat screen TVs, Taiwan consumers favor those made by Sony of Japan, followed by Chi Mei of Taiwan, LG of South Korea and Panasonic of Japan, the survey showed.
As to cameras, Canon, Nikon and Sony of Japan are the top choices among Taiwanese consumers, according to the poll.
In terms of financial services, Taiwan's consumers see Cathay Life Insurance, Fubon Life Insurance, Nan Shan Life Insurance and Shin Kong Insurance as the most reliable, the survey showed.

DOC.HEADLINE: Effects of dust storm ease: EPA
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, April 29 (CNA) 04/29/10 14:55:19 (By Hsien Feng Lee and Hsin-Yin Lee)

TEXT.P: The air quality in most of Taiwan has returned to normal, which suggests that the effects of a dust storm from China has lessened, the Environmental Protection Administration (EPA) said Thursday.

Chu Yu-Chi, director-general of the EPA's Environmental Monitoring and Information Management unit, said observation stations islandwide have recorded safe levels of air quality, thanks to heavy rainfall over the past few days.
However, in Taiwan's outlying islands such as Kinmen and Matsu, a higher volume of dust particles -- 200 micrograms per cubic meter -- was recorded, Chu said.
Also, the levels still remain slightly higher than normal, at around 150 micrograms per cubic meter, in several regions of northern Taiwan such as Kuan Yin, Wan Li and Shih Lin, Chu added.
Due to strong winds that could carry the dust around, the air quality is likely to vary in different regions of the country from time to time, he said.

DOC.HEADLINE: Taiwan debt in Europe 'controllable': finance chief
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, April 29 (CNA) 04/29/10 15:37:13 (By Chou Yung-chieh and Deborah Kuo)

TEXT.P: Taiwan's top financial regulator said Thursday that the country's risks in Europe are "at a controllable level" amid fears that Greece will collapse financially and drag all of Europe down with it.

Sean Chen, chairman of the Cabinet-level Financial Supervisory Commission (FSC) , said during a legislative session that financial investments Taiwanese banks and securities houses have made in Europe totaled about NT$33.7 billion (US$1.07 billion) , an amount that can be handled if problems there escalate.

Chen made the remarks in response to ruling Kuomintang Legislator Lai Shyh-bao, a Legislative Yuan Finance Committee member, who said that Greece's debt crisis could trigger a financial plague throughout Europe as national credit dries up in Italy, Portugal and Ireland.
Lai asked Chen whether he thought the credit crisis could sweep through Europe or even the whole world, and what possible impact Greece's credit collapse could have on Taiwan's finance market.
Chen responded that soon after Greece's credit worries started, the FSC surveyed Taiwanese banks and financial service firms that operate in European funds and securities.
"I'm not sure whether those Taiwanese investors will eventually bear some of the weight of the Greek crisis, but it looks manageable to me as of now," Chen told Lai.

Chen also said he was waiting for a signal from Berlin on how quickly a bailout could be delivered to rescue Greece. German Finance Minister Wolfgang Schauble is currently head of the International Monetary Fund.

The German government was highly intelligent, Chen said, adding that it had decided to make known the bailout plan on May 10, one day after the federal elections, out of consideration that a majority of the German public are against financial aid.
Chen said he believes Germany will grant aid to Greece to help ease the burgeoning debt load and keep the euro-zone stable.

DOC.HEADLINE: Southern Taiwan might face water shortage from June
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, April 29 (CNA) 04/29/10 15:41:40 (By S. H. Lee and Flor Wang)

TEXT.P: Premier Wu Den-yih ordered government agencies Thursday to step up monitoring of water management in southern Taiwan, as the Kaohsiung and Tainan areas would face a shortage if the current dry spell continues.
Although the situation in northern Taiwan has eased after recent rainfall, Wu said the Kaohsiung and Tainan areas could see problems starting in June.

"All government agencies should cooperate in saving water and the Ministry of Economic Affairs (MOEA) should continue promoting the campaign," the premier said after hearing a briefing on water supply situations by ministry officials at a weekly Executive Yuan meeting.
According to MOEA officials, normal water supply in the two areas could be affected if the amount of rainfall fails to reach 40 percent of the annual average by the end of June.
The premier also ordered relevant authorities to take full anti-flooding precautions as typhoon season approaches.
Cultivation of rice for the first harvest in some central and southern counties has been suspended to save water.
There has been limited precipitation in southern Taiwan since Typhoon Morakot lashed the region in August last year.
The effect of government efforts at generating artificial rain has been limited.

DOC.HEADLINE: Taiwan plans to attract 500 graduate students from India next year
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, April 29 (CNA) 04/29/10 15:55:11 (By Garfie Li and Fanny Liu)

TEXT.P: Taiwan is planning to attract 500 self- funded graduate students from India next year, following a bilateral agreement signed in March under which both countries agreed to mutually recognize higher education diplomas on each side, a Ministry of Foreign Affairs official said Thursday.

Lee Shieh-ming, director-general of the ministry's Department of East Asian and Pacific Affairs, said that attracting some of the roughly 500,000 Indian students who study abroad every year will bring significant economic and cultural value to Taiwan.

The students will be provided with free Chinese classes during their stays in Taiwan, said Lee, who added that after graduating, they will be the best candidates for managerial jobs in Taiwanese companies operating in India.
"That could also increase Taiwanese businessmen's willingness to invest in India or expand their investments there, " Lee said at a press conference.

As Indian students generally excel in math and English, attracting more Indian students to study in Taiwan is also expected to help inspire Taiwanese students' research and learning abilities, according to Lee.
Lee said that in the initial stage, the program will focus on enrolling Indian graduate students and will gradually expand to include undergrads.
There are 370 Indian graduate students studying in Taiwan at present.

Lee said the MOFA is also discussing with other Asian countries, including the Philippines and Vietnam, similar cooperation programs in order to implement President Ma Ying-jeou's target of attracting 20,000 overseas students to study in Taiwan during his four-year term.

DOC.HEADLINE: Taiwan share prices close lower
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, April 29 (CNA) 04/29/10 15:59:29 (By James Lee)

TEXT.P: Taiwan's share prices were down Thursday, with the weighted index, the market's key barometer, falling 27.5 points, or 0.34 percent, to close at 8,054.05.

The local bourse opened at the day's low of 8,105.96 and fluctuated between 8,107.36 and 8,053.02. A total of 4.65 billion shares changed hands on a market turnover of NT$132.64 billion (US$4.22 billion).

Five of the eight major stock categories lost ground, with machinery and electronics issues dropping the most at 0.58 percent, followed by cement issues at 0.44 percent, plastics and chemicals at 0.39 percent, textile issues at 0.32 percent and financial and banking stocks at 0.21 percent.
The other three major stock categories gained ground, with paper and pulp issues gaining the most at 1.66 percent. Foodstuff shares rose 0.94 percent and construction shares moved up 0.86 percent.
Gainers outnumbered losers 1,649 to 1480, with 319 stocks remaining unchanged.
Foreign investors and Chinese QDIIs were net sellers of NT$4.61 billion-worth of shares.

DOC.HEADLINE: Cloud computing sector to be new trillion-dollar industry
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, April 29 (CNA) 04/29/10 16:09:43 (By Lee Shu-hua and Deborah Kuo)

TEXT.P: The Executive Yuan approved a draft bill Thursday on the development of cloud computing -- outsourcing online data storage and applications -- and making it a new industrial sector in Taiwan worth over NT$1 trillion (US$31.85 billion).

The plan, proposed by the Ministry of Economic Affairs (MOEA) , calls for the investment of NT$24 billion (US$764 million) in cloud computing development by the government over the next five years, in the hope that the initiative will spur some NT$100 billion-worth of investment from the private sector, including NT$12.7 billion for research and development, said Wu Ming-ji, director of the MOEA's Department of Industrial Technology.
The government envisions that the cloud computing development project will create some 50,000 jobs, while the new industry will become a NT$1 trillion sector over the next five years, Wu said.
"The project will be accelerated under the guidance of "4C" -- cloud, commerce, connectivity and client," Wu continued.

Meanwhile, Premier Wu Den-yih instructed the establishment of a Cabinet-level supervisory task force on the development of the cloud computing industry, with Minister-without-Portfolio Chang Jin-fu named as convener.

Taiwan should take advantage of its well-established information and communications technology (ICT) industry to develop cloud computing and expedite industrial upgrading and transition, as well as achieve energy-saving, low-emissions targets as soon as possible, Wu said.
An office for the development of the cloud computing industry will also be established by the MOEA to offer assistance to investors from the private sector, according to Wu.
The draft bill still needs to be referred to the Legislative Yuan for approval.

DOC.HEADLINE: Taipei sporting goods show kicks off
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, April 29 (CNA) 04/29/10 16:19:53 (By Lin Shu-yuan and Frances Huang)

TEXT.P: The 2010 Taipei International Sporting Goods Show opened Thursday, with organizers expecting to attract more than 2,800 potential buyers from abroad.

Huang Wen-jung, deputy secretary-general of the semiofficial Taiwan External Trade Development Council (TAITRA) , told reporters that this year's show, which runs through May 2, is the largest in the exhibition's 37-year history.
The 2010 show boasts a total of 385 exhibitors, compared with 311 a year earlier.

Huang said the show highlighted Taiwan's advanced production technology and innovation, adding that the island has launched its own brands of sporting goods and is no longer just a contract producer for foreign companies.
At the opening ceremony, Vice Economics Minister Liang Kuo-hsin said Taiwan has proposed that the World Trade Organization eliminate all sporting good tariffs to boost sales.
Liang said the proposal has won support from the United States, Switzerland and Singapore.
The TAITRA said fitness equipment accounts for 40 percent of all products in the show, making it the largest exhibition category.
"But, as an organizer, the TAITRA is trying hard to diversify the products, expecting to attract more foreign potential buyers," a show manager said.
The 2010 show also features products for outdoor sports such as skiing, skating and water sports, she said.
"We expect more than 2,800 foreign buyers to come, higher than the 2,600 last year," she added.

Representatives from Icon Health & Fitness, the world's largest fitness equipment producer and marketer, as well as Nature & Decouvertes, the largest camping equipment distributor in Europe, will be among the foreign visitors, the show manager said.

DOC.HEADLINE: Preliminary report on mudslide to be ready in a week
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, April 29 (CNA) 04/29/10 17:11:34 (By Maubo Chang)

TEXT.P: A preliminary report on the cause of the April 25 mudslide that buried a section of the No. 3 Freeway, killing four people, will be ready by May 7, Minister of Transportation and Communications Mao Chi-kuo said Thursday.
The minister told the Transport Committee of the Legislative Yuan that an ad hoc panel of experts and scholars has been set up to probe the cause of the disaster.
Mao said the panel will examine whether the freeway was designed, built and maintained according to norms, and whether those norms should be revamped.
A detailed joint report and recommendations will be made by the panel, working with an international panel.

In order to prevent similar mudslides on other freeways and railways under the jurisdiction of Ministery of Transportation and Communications, Mao said his ministry will conduct a survey before mid-May and install monitoring devices in places with signs of landslides, such as cracks triggered by strain on retaining walls, falling rocks and dilapidated protection devices.

On the same occasion, Vice Minister of Transportation and Communications Chang Chiu-chun said it is impossible to determine whether human error was involved in the mudslide before the ad hoc panel presents its report.

Lin Chao-chung, chief of the Central Geological Survey under the Ministry of Economic Affairs, repeated the vice minister's line while fielding lawmakers' questions, adding that the scene of the accident was located beneath a dip slope and was thereby vulnerable to mudslides.

However, lawmaker Wong Chin-chu of the opposition Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) said human error was to blame after learning from Chang that no monitoring devices had been set up at the scene of Sunday's disaster.

Mao said his ministry would help the families of the dead to claim compensation from the government, but stopped short of agreeing with lawmakers' demands of immediate compensation, saying legal procedure must be followed.
Three DPP lawmakers, led by Chai Trong-rong, called for Mao's resignation for the disaster, saying he should kneel down to the victims to allay the anger of their families.

The disaster took place when a retaining wall along the National Freeway No. 3 near Chidu in Taipei County collapsed without warning, burying a section of the freeway under hundred of thousands tons of earth.
Three cars were covered by the earth, while many other vehicles escaped by the skin of their teeth.

A round-the-clock rescue operation began immediately after the accident. The wreckage of the three cars and the four bodies of their occupants had been found, but the route was still closed to traffic.

The accident has snarled traffic to and from Keelung, the port city at the beginning of the freeway, and President Ma Ying-jeou's administration -- which was criticized for its bungled relief efforts in the wake of Typhoon Morakot last August -- has tried much harder to cope with this most recent diaster.

DOC.HEADLINE: U.S. dollar down on Taipei Forex
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, April 29 (CNA) 04/29/10 17:13:04 (By James Lee)

TEXT.P: The U.S. dollar lost ground against the New Taiwan dollar on the Taipei Foreign Exchange Thursday, dropping NT$0.089 to close NT$31.450.
The U.S. dollar opened at the day's high of NT$31.539 and fell to a low of NT$31.400 before rebounding.

DOC.HEADLINE: Han Kuang No. 26 military drill held in Pingtung
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, April 29 (CNA) 04/29/10 17:26:58 (By Kuo Chih-hsuan and Y.F. Low)

TEXT.P: The Taiwan military conducted amphibious and anti-parachute maneuvers in the southern county of Pingtung Thursday as part of its annual Han Kuang No. 26 exercise.
The wargames, which involve a total of 5,000 military personnel from different branches of the armed forces, are being held on the largest scale in recent years.

More than 3,000 military personnel participated in the amphibious assault maneuver that took place on a beach in Jialutang with the aim of testing the military's combined land, sea and air combat capability.
In the drill, an underwater demolition team from the Marine Corps used explosives to destroy obstacles prior to landing on the beach, while F-16 fighters were deployed to try to repel the attack.

Another anti-parachute maneuver, carried out on a farm in Jiadong township, deployed more than 1,400 military personnel, 16 aircraft of various types, 10 vehicles, and 42 kinds of missiles and artillery.
A total of 128 paratroopers dropped onto the farm from six transport aircraft to fight off invading forces. Armored vehicles and artillery were also used in the simulated battle.
According to military officials, it was a great challenge for the paratroopers to maneuver on a farm where there were many pineapple plants, banana trees and betel nut palms.
As a protective measure, the paratroopers were outfitted with special apparel made of puncture-resistant fabric.

DOC.HEADLINE: Government should create conditions for indigenous autonomy: president
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, April 29 (CNA) 04/29/10 17:32:39 (By Amy Huang and Fanny Liu)

TEXT.P: President Ma Ying-jeou said Thursday that the government needs to create better conditions to allow indigenous people to organize autonomous communities.

Addressing a national indigenous people's administration conference, Ma said the government will push for autonomy for indigenous people, and he expressed hope that the conference -- which has not been held for the past nine years -- can help solve the problems faced by indigenous people.

"The government should aggressively create conditions for making indigenous autonomy a reality, " said Ma, adding that the government will review existing laws, allow the establishment of a test autonomous demonstration area, and help develop indigenous people's abilities to manage their own affairs.
The Cabinet is reviewing the indigenous autonomy bill to determine if any revisions are needed before the bill is further addressed in the legislature.

Sun Ta-chuan, minister of the Cabinet-level Council of Indigenous Peoples, said the bill is not only good for indigenous people, but also meaningful for Taiwan and he expressed hope that it can be passed in the current legislative session.

The government plans to offer indigenous people 32,000 jobs over four years, while indigenous students will be provided with tuition waivers and living subsidies from kindergarten to graduate school, Ma said.
He also pointed out that it will be a big challenge to preserve Taiwan's indigenous languages, which have decreased from some 40 kinds to only about 20 at present.

DOC.HEADLINE: Financial services high on 'early harvest' list: FSC
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, April 29 (CNA) 04/29/10 17:43:36 (By Chou Yung-chieh and Sofia Wu)

TEXT.P: Financial services will be high on the "early harvest" list for preferential market access under an economic cooperation framework agreement (ECFA) with China, Financial Supervisory Commission Chairman Sean C. Chen said Thursday.
Fielding questions at a hearing of the Legislative Yuan's Finance Committee, Chen said financial services were tabbed for the the "early harvest" list from the very beginning of the ECFA talks.

During the hearing, ruling Kuomintang Legislator Sun Ta-chien asked whether financial services will be on the "early harvest" list if the ECFA, a scaled back free trade agreement, is signed in June as scheduled.

"Of course, financial services will definitely be high on the 'early harvest' list... They have been on the list from the beginning of the talks.... There have not been any changes, " Chen told lawmakers.
When the negotiations are completed, Chen said, the FSC will unveil details of the package, with the consent of the other side.
Noting that the two intermediary bodies on the two sides of the Taiwan Strait are arranging a new round of ECFA talks, Chen said the FSC has been asked to "stand by" for the planned meeting.
The first round of ECFA talks took place Jan. 26 in Beijing and the second round was held in Taoyuan, some 40 kilometers south of Taipei.

The quasi-official Straits Exchange Foundation and its Chinese counterpart, the Association for Relations Across the Taiwan Strait, have not yet announced the date or venue for the third round of ECFA talks.
The "early harvest" list, referring to a list of goods and services to be subject to tariff waivers or favorable market access treatment, forms the backbone of the proposed ECFA deal with China.

DOC.HEADLINE: ECFA could marginalize US in East Asia: DPP chair
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, April 29 (CNA) 04/29/10 17:44:16 (By Chris Wang)

TEXT.P: The U.S. presence in East Asia could be compromised as China is expected to emerge as the region's leader if a cross-Taiwan Strait trade pact forces South Korea and Japan to seek closer economic ties with China, Taiwan's main opposition party leader said Thursday.

At a 60-minute press conference, Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) Chairperson Tsai Ing-wen addressed dozens of international media members on various political matters, most notably her debate with President Ma Ying-jeou last Sunday on the proposed economic cooperation framework agreement (ECFA).
Ma said the agreement, which he intends to sign before June, would ease cross- strait tension and benefit Taiwan's economy.
Tsai said the pact would pressure regional powers such as South Korea and Japan to actively seek free trade agreements (FTAs) with China and eventually shift the power balance in the region.
"China will be the center of this region and the U.S. will be marginalized," she said.
"We don't have a problem with China leading the region -- if it's a democracy and a market economy, " she added.

Tsai said that her party, which has been widely seen as adopting a "zero-sum" strategy in managing it's cross-strait relations, will pursue a "more stable, consistent and predictable (China) policy." The DPP will use its experience ruling the country from 2000 to 2008 to draw up "10-year policy guidelines" that will improve its ability to manage relations with China as well as the U.S. and Japan, Tsai said.
According to the pro-independence DPP, the guidelines will be unveiled in August and offer flexible strategies for resolving problems facing Taiwan.
In terms of the ECFA, "it's not as urgent as President Ma said and the benefit is not as much as the government claimed," Tsai said.

The ECFA is not necessary to ease cross-strait tensions, Tsai said, adding that cross-strait relations have been relatively stable due to extensive trade activity. The real tensions Taiwan needs to address are domestic economic and social matters, she said.

Tsai said that the World Trade Organization (WTO) would provide enough room, protection and mechanisms for Taiwan to boost its economy and deal with countries all over the world. "There's no need to go beyond the WTO," she said.

While Ma contended that Taiwan will be able to secure FTAs with other countries after signing the ECFA, Tsai added, it will set a bad example and appear that Taiwan needs China's consent before engaging in activities with the international community.

At the same time, trade volume between Taiwan and China is expected to increase after the pact is signed and could cause reduction of trade with other countries, compromising the incentive for them to sign FTAs with Taiwan, she said.

Responding to a question, Tsai said that if the deal is signed and the DPP returns to power in 2012, it could terminate the agreement or adjust its content after receiving public consent through either referendum or legislative discussions.

Tsai said that one of her biggest domestic concerns is the widening wealth gap. Citing a poll, she said that only one-third of Taiwan people stand to benefit from globalization, while two-thirds fail to gain -- or even suffer -- from trade liberalization.

The DPP supports a referendum proposal submitted by a minor opposition party, the Taiwan Solidarity Union (TSU), that calls for a vote on the ECFA. Tsai said it would give people "an opportunity to make decisions" on major policy issues.
The DPP is still assessing the impact of the referendum on five year-end special municipality elections, she said.

DOC.HEADLINE: Unclaimed vouchers returned to national coffers
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, April 29 (CNA) 04/29/10 17:48:48 (By M. T. Lee and Flor Wang)

TEXT.P: The Executive Yuan approved the audit of the central government's 2009 budget Thursday and decided that unclaimed consumer vouchers, valued at about NT$1 billion (US$32 million), would be returned to national coffers.
The vouchers, worth a total of NT$83.37 billion, were issued by the central government in early 2009 to Taiwan citizens as part of efforts to prop up the economy during the global financial crisis.

According to financial statements provided by the Director-General of Budget, Accounting and Statistics in the weekly Executive Yuan meeting, NT$1.809 trillion in spending and NT$1.673 billion in revenue were approved for last year's central government.
The NT$ 136.5 billion deficit was offset by government agencies through public borrowing, bank loans and NT$36.5 billion in surplus left over from 2008.

Premier Wu Den-yih praised retrenchment efforts last year by government agencies at all levels, lauding the agencies for managing their finances amid sharply falling revenue due to damage from the global economic downturn and typhoon Morakot.

DOC.HEADLINE: U.S. congressmen call for free trade pact with Taiwan
DOC.DATELINE: Washington, April 28 (CNA) 04/29/10 18:14:35 (By Zep Hu and Maubo Chang)

TEXT.P: Three U.S. congressmen urged the U.S. government Wednesday to negotiate a free trade agreement with Taiwan in light of the fact that China is ready to sign a trade liberalization pact with Taiwan.

In a seminar organized by the Washington-based pro-Taiwan group, Formosan Association of Public Affairs, U.S. Rep. Ileana Ros-Lehtinen said a free trade pact with Taiwan will increase U.S. exports to Taiwan by 16 percent, citing a study by the United States International Trade Commission.

Taiwan's government hopes to sign a trade liberalization agreement with China - called the economic cooperation framework agreement (ECFA) - by June, saying it is crucial for helping Taiwan avoid economic isolation. The opposition Democratic Progressive Party, however, has warned that the agreement could make Taiwan too dependent on China, and hurt Taiwan's workers and industries.

Branding ECFA as a Trojan horse which led to the fall of Troy according to Greek legend, the congressman said China is expanding its presence throughout the whole of Asia, and Washington should not sit on its hands while watching China's rising dominance in the Asia-Pacific region.
Rep. Robert Andrews dismissed worries that Washington would raise eyebrows in Beijing by negotiating a free trade pact with Taiwan, asking why the U.S. should care so much about what Beijing thinks.
Andrews said he is seeking sponsorship from other congressmen for an appeal for the U.S. administration to start free trade negotiations with Taiwan.
Rep. Scott Garrett echoed Andrews' view, urging his congressional colleagues to sponsor the appeal in droves to show their determination.

However, former Deputy Assistant Secretary of State for East Asian and Pacific Affairs Randall Schriver said he was not optimistic about a free trade pact between the U.S. and Taiwan for the time being, citing the reluctance of the U.S. Democratic administration to push for one.

He suggested instead the resumption of talks with Taiwan under the Trade and Investment Framework Agreement, which was suspended after Taiwan reneged on a promise to allow previously banned U.S. ground beef and offal to be imported to the island.
John Tkacik, a fomer State Department official, said the problem with the trade deal between Taiwan and China is the lack of transparency in negotiations.

Citing the list of industries to enjoy the earlier tariff reduction privileges as an example, Tkacik pointed out that the list has still not been published even though the pact is set to be inked in June.

Taiwan's government has said the full list cannot be revealed as doing so would jeopardize Taiwan's ability to negotiate a deal that is favorable to Taiwan. The government has said it will avoid placing on the list local industries that would need time to adjust to competition from China.

DOC.HEADLINE: Taiwan representative in Canada highly commended
DOC.DATELINE: Toronto, April 28 (CNA) 04/29/10 18:31:10 (By Paul Chang and Deborah Kuo)

TEXT.P: Taiwan's representative to Canada, David Tawei Lee, and his office were again highly commended recently by an Ottawa-based foreign policy weekly for his diplomatic clout and the office's attractions.

In its latest annual "Embassy Sexy and Savvy Survey" published Wednesday, Embassy, Canada's foreign policy newsweekly, awarded Lee's office -- the Taipei Economic and Cultural Office in Canada, Taiwan's de facto embassy in Canada -- the title of "Embassy with Best Business Lunches."
Lee himself, meanwhile, was voted by the weekly as the "second most influential ambassador" in Canada.

Lee, who has been Taiwan's representative to Canada since April 2007, attributed the title mainly to the office's hosting of major parties such as the Taiwan Night and the Double-Ten ROC National Day reception.
He attributed the success of those activities to the support extended by the Ministry of Foreign Affairs in Taipei and the hard work carried out by his staff.

It was the fourth survey of its kind conducted by the magazine. In the previous three, Lee was voted the "hardest working ambassador" and the "second most influential ambassador, " and was ranked third in the category of "ambassador with the best inside scoop on Canadian politics."
His office has also previously won the title of "Embassy with Best Food at Receptions."

Embassy, published every Wednesday, has a circulation of around 70,000. It is considered an important publication in Canada's diplomatic circles and a "must read" for Canadian public officers, parliamentarians and think-tank experts.

DOC.HEADLINE: Second-generation NHI premiums to be 2.57-3.06 percent: minister
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, April 29 (CNA) 04/29/10 19:01:24 (By Chen Ching-fang and Fanny Liu)

TEXT.P: Department of Health (DOH) Minister Yaung Chih-liang said Thursday that premium rates for a second-generation National Health Insurance (NHI) program based on total household income will be between 2.57 percent and 3.06 percent.

This was the first time that the DOH revealed details of the proposed second- generation NHI program, which is expected to be introduced within two years. In early April, Yaung said the premiums will be between 3 percent and 4 percent.

At a legislative committee meeting, Yaung presented 16 versions of plans for the second-generation program. Yaung said, however, that under any of the versions, about 60 percent of households will enjoy lower health insurance premium rates, with 40 percent of singles paying lower rates.

The proposal's lowest premium rate -- for total household income of at least NT$150,000 -- is 2.57 percent. Yaung said the rate couldn't be lower because the government is required to pay for 30 percent of total medical expenses and no reserve fund is allocated.
Under the lowest premium rate, Yaung said, households earning less than NT$150,000 a year will pay a monthly fee of around NT$300 per person.
If total household income exceeds the upper limit of NT$7.5 million, each person in the household will pay NT$16,062 per month.
Yaung said the second-generation plan improves on the first-generation program, and that it is expected to last for 15 to 20 years.

Before the second-generation plan is introduced, a temporary plan that took effect on April 1 raised the health insurance premium rate to between 4.55 percent to 5.17 percent of an individual's salary.

As of the end of last year, the national health insurance program had accumulated debts of NT$58.8 billion, an amount officials said could soar to an estimated NT$101.5 billion by the end of 2010 if no adjustments are made.

DOC.HEADLINE: Hot money inflow slows: central bank
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, April 29 (CNA) 04/29/10 19:04:21 (By Y.C. Chou and Flor Wang)

TEXT.P: In response to a noticeable fall in the local currency a day earlier on the foreign exchange market, the central bank denied speculation Thursday that it had interfered in the market, despite its efforts to stem the influx of hot money.

"The value of the New Taiwan dollar is decided by market forces and the central bank did not interfere to make it weaker, " Central Bank Deputy Governor Chou A-ting told a legislative committee meeting.

"After talking with several foreign institutional investors, we found that the influx of speculative money had slowed down and more than NT$300 billion in funds remitted into Taiwan is currently deposited in local banks," Chou said.
As to the question of whether Taiwanese companies have also been lining up to speculate on a rising local currency, he promised that the central bank will closely monitor the situation.

In a bid to ease a noticeable influx of hot money into Taiwan, the central bank has been monitoring the movement of foreign institutional investors since the beginning of this year. Some 20 of them have been named by the bank on its "watch list."

Central Bank Governor Peng Fai-nan has repeatedly asked foreign institutional investors to buy Taiwanese shares or take their idle money out of Taiwan in an effort to prevent them from taking advantage of an appreciating local currency and to avoid a possible assets bubble.
The New Taiwan do lar closed at 31.539 against the U.S. dollar Wednesday in the Taipei foreign exchange market, down by NT$0.127 from Tuesday's finish.

DOC.HEADLINE: Eight NBA players to meet in dunk competition in southern Taiwan
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, April 29 (CNA) 04/29/10 19:20:43 (By Chris Wang)

TEXT.P: Reigning dunk champion Nate Robinson will head a group of eight National Basketball Association (NBA) players who will take part in a dunk competition in the southern port city of Kaohsiung in late August, organizers said Thursday.

The competition will be the first time an NBA dunk contest will have been held in Taiwan, said Chen Han-chuan, marketing manager of Bros Sports, the sports marketing company that organized the first NBA exhibition game in Taiwan last October.

Robinson, who plays for the Boston Celtics, is the first three-time dunk contest winner in NBA history. He will meet a pair of semi-finalists at this year's NBA dunk competition in Kaohsiung -- Demar DeRozan of the Toronto Raptors and Shannon Brown of the Los Angeles Lakers.

Other participants include Nick Young of the Washington Wizards, Will Bynum of the Detroit Pistons, Dahntay Jones of the Indiana Pacers, Carl Landry of the Sacramento Kings and Terrence Williams of the New Jersey Nets, Bros Sports announced.
Robinson, who boasts a reported vertical leap of 110-centimeters, won the NBA dunk contest in 2006, 2009 and 2010.

DOC.HEADLINE: Taiwan, Australia sign MOU on marine research
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, April 29 (CNA) 04/29/10 19:48:01 (By Lin Hui-chun and Sofia Wu)

TEXT.P: Taiwan and Australia signed a memorandum of understanding (MOU) Thursday for cooperation in the area of oceanographic research, the National Science Council (NSC) said Thursday.

The MOU was signed at the headquarters of the Australian Institute of Marine Science (AIMS) in Townsville, Queensland on the northeastern coast of Australia by NSC Vice Minister Chang Wen-chuang and Ian Poiner, a chief executive of the Australian institute, on behalf of the two sides, the NSC said in a press statement.

The two sides have agreed to promote exchanges of research staff, to co-sponsor strategic seminars and conduct of joint research programs and they look forward to achieving breakthroughs in oceanographic research through various cooperative projects, according to the NSC.
Poiner was quoted as having said at the signing ceremony that international cooperation is critical to unveiling the mysteries of marine life.

He noted that the AIMS is strong in several core research fields such as marine biodiversity, aquaculture of tropical crustacean species, water quality and ecological health, and climate change and its effects on marine ecology.
Taiwanese research fellows are welcome to conduct joint research projects with their AIMS peers and to utilize the AIMS' world-class research facilities, he added.
Echoing Poiner's views, the NSC said that although oceans cover 70 percent of the surface of the Earth, there is far less research and knowledge pertaining to the sea than to the land.
As 64 percent of oceans around the world are open seas outside of national boundaries, the NSC said, international cooperation is necessary for marine research.
"We hope the cooperative programs with the Australian institute will produce remarkable results," the NSC said.

DOC.HEADLINE: Firm helps hemophilia carrier have healthy child
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, April 29 (CNA) 04/29/10 20:11:31 (By Alex Jiang)

TEXT.P: A biotechnology company in Taiwan said Thursday that it has helped a local woman who carries the hemophilia gene to conceive a baby who will not suffer from hemophilia -- a genetic disease that makes bleeding uncontrollable -- and hailed it as the first case in Asia.

"Women often choose abortion after finding out that they have a baby with hemophilia, which is painful for them, both physically and psychologically," Joanna Teng, the manager of Bionet Corp., said at a press briefing.

The woman, whose name was not revealed, had lost four sons over the past 10 years, one of whom died during surgery, possibly because of hemophilia, when he was 7 months old, while the other were aborted after being diagnosed with hemophilia.

"She did not give up despite a series of failed attempts. Now, she is having a healthy child due in August after using an advanced biotechnology technique called pre-implantation genetic diagnosis (PGD)," said her doctor, Stork Lai.
"The biotechnology helps find out if an embryo is free of the hemophilia gene before the embryo is implanted in the womb, " he told reporters.
At the press briefing, Lai donated NT$1 million (about US$32,000) he received from the woman's husband as a gift to benefit more of those in Taiwan who fear having a hemophiliac baby.

The donation will go to Genesis Genetics Asia (GGA), a subsidiary of Bionet that offers the biotechnology. The donation is expected to benefit 15 people, each of whom will receive a subsidy of NT$75,000 that will pay for the biotechnology to screen out the hemophilia gene.

"The biotechnology is expensive and we hope the government can also provide funds to better cover the expenses, " said Jacky Liao, head of Hemophiliacs' Rights Taiwan, a body dedicated to the welfare of hemophiliacs.
There are more than 900 hemophiliacs in Taiwan, many of whom want to have children, he added.
Hemophiliacs are the top receivers of government subsidies for their disease expenses under Taiwan's national health program, according to government figures released in March.

The PGD technology, which was invented by U.S. doctor Mark Hughes in 1990, has helped some 5,000 cases in the United States and Europe, covering hemophilia and nearly 200 other hereditary diseases, according to GGA.

Bionet sought to obtain the biotechnology eight years ago, but did not get authorization for the Asian region until 2008 after beating competitors from Malaysia, Japan and China, said Chris Tsai, the company's chairman.
Bionet established GGA in late 2008 as a joint venture with Hughes' Genesis Genetics Institute.
A number of hospitals in Taiwan have recently announced that they have developed and applied similar biotechnologies for those who suffer from various other genetic diseases.

DOC.HEADLINE: Taiwan Red Cross helps rebuild health centers in China
DOC.DATELINE: Mian, China, April 29 (CNA) 04/29/10 20:24:40 (By Chen Cheng-wei, Chen Po-hua and Sofia Wu)

TEXT.P: A Chinese official expressed gratitude to Taiwan's Red Cross Society Thursday for its help in rebuilding public health facilities damaged in a devastating earthquake that struck China's Sichuan Province in May 2008.

Wang Pohua, head of the Wuhou public health center in Mian County in Shaanxi Province in northwestern China, expressed thanks to Wang Ching-feng, vice president of the Red Cross Society of the Republic of China, who is visiting China to review various post-earthquake reconstruction projects financed by the charity.

The Red Cross Society decided to help rebuild 15 healthcare centers, including a rural health station, in Mian County in the aftermath of a magnitude-7.9 earthquake that was centered in Sichuan and affected parts of neighboring Shaanxi Province.

Because of the wide urban-rural gap in public health conditions and a lack of health consciousness among many local residents, the reconstruction process had many twists and turns, according to Wang Ching-feng. It took much hard work and coordination to complete the project, she added.

In an interview with the Central News Agency, Wang Pohua said that the new Wuhou healthcare center not only offers basic healthcare services to local residents, but also provides epidemic prevention and health education.
"The local people are very grateful for Taiwan's generous effort to rebuild our public healthcare system that now offers much better services than before the earthquake," he added.

On Tuesday, the Taiwan Red Cross Society delegation headed by Wang Ching-feng visited Yifu Elementary School in Mian County which was rebuilt also with funds from the charity. Wang, who once served as Taiwan's minister of justice, presented scholarships to students in need during the visit.

DOC.HEADLINE: Taiwanese artist debuts paintings at Red House in Taipei
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei April 29 (CNA) 04/29/10 20:34:42 (By Sunnie Chen)

TEXT.P: Taiwanese artist Heidi Huang debuted 20 of her paintings at the Red House in Taipei for the first time recently.
The 28-year old's exhibit covers three themes -- figures, animals and plants -- and will run through June 27.
In all her paintings, there is a cute little rabbit called "Heidi Doll" which appears. Huang also designs and makes by hand rabbi bags, key chains, pillows and many other products.
"Creation of this doll actually is inspired by a thought I had that I want to comfort people, so I use my own image to create the doll," she told the Central News Agency Thursday.
Huang has wanted to be a painter from the time she was in kindergarten.
"I have never changed my mind,"she said.

After graduating from National Taiwan University of Arts, Huang worked as an arts editor at a company, but she was not happy then. She later bravely decided to follow her own path -- making creative works in the field of art.
But the road she has chosen is not easy.
"I used to take a simple briefcase to show my works on the street in front of the Eslite Dun-nan (book) store, or in an arts fair, " Huang said.
Now, she is happy to have a small booth showing her works at the Red House.
Actually, Huang already has many fans from different countries. She revealed that people from Hong Kong and Singapore love her rabbit products, while tourists from the West prefer her paintings.
"Painting and making creative products are my life," Huang said.

She added that she was inspired by this opportunity of being able to exhibit her works at the historical building, and said that she will keep working hard and plans to write picture books in the future.
She will also take her creations to Japan where she will present them at the International Design Festival on May 15-16 and share her paintings and handicrafts with artists from other countries.
"I hope to communicate with young artists from all over the world through this opportunity," Huang said.

DOC.HEADLINE: Consumers urged to report food problems to health authorities
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, April 29 (CNA) 04/29/10 20:52:41 (By Chen Ching-Fang and Hsin-Yin Lee)

TEXT.P: The Health Department on Thursday urged the public to report to the relevant authorities any problems relating to substandard health foods that they purchase.

If people develop side-effects from the consumption of health foods, they hould immediately stop eating the products and report the problem to the health authorities via the Web site http: //hf.doh.gov.tw, or call the toll-free number 0800-625-748, the department advised.

According to a recent survey by Common Health magazine, around 54 percent of the public would inform the Consumers' Foundation if they develop any adverse reaction after eating non-certified health foods, while 38 percent would seek help from city or county consumer protection commissions and the Health Department as a whole.
The magazine reminded consumers to check for proper labeling when choosing health foods.

DOC.HEADLINE: ECFA is purely economic, not related to politics: MAC
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, April 29 (CNA) 04/29/10 21:22:34 (By Liu Cheng-ching and Fanny Liu)

TEXT.P: The Mainland Affairs Council (MAC) said Thursday that the proposed economic cooperation framework agreement (ECFA) with China is purely an economic issue that has nothing to do with politics.

MAC Vice Chairman Liu Te-shun made the comment following China's Taiwan Affairs Office Director Wang Yi's mention of the so-called "1992 Consensus" at a cross- Taiwan Strait entrepreneurs summit in the Chinese city of Nanjing.

Addressing the opening ceremony of the summit earlier that day, Wang said that both China and Taiwan should continue to consolidate a key political foundation of opposing Taiwan's independence and supporting the "1992 Consensus" -- which will serve as a sustainable and reliable political guarantee for developing economic cooperation between the two sides.
Liu responded at a press conference that there has been nothing -- either in ECFA discussions or within the content of the ECFA -- related to any political appeal.

Liu said that it's understandable that Chinese officials need to make statements in line with their political positions, but added that as both sides have their own political viewpoints and directions, he also hopes that China can show empathy toward Taiwan.

The "1992 Consensus" refers to an understanding the ruling Kuomintang claims was reached in Hong Kong in 1992 between the two sides of the Taiwan Strait that there is only one China, but with both sides free to make their own interpretations of what "one China" actually means.

DOC.HEADLINE: Greek debt impact on Taiwan 'limited': European banker
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, April 29 (CNA) 04/29/10 21:32:15 (By Alex Jiang)

TEXT.P: An official of the European Bank for Reconstruction and Development (EBRD) said Thursday that the debt crisis in Greece is having a "very limited" impact on Taiwan.
"I haven't heard anybody express any concerns, " said Manfred Schepers, the body's vice finance president.
Schepers was in Taipei for a meeting with representatives of Taiwan's central bank, commercial banks and insurance companies Wednesday.

He told the press that he learned that the central bank, insurance companies and banks in Taiwan have conservative investment strategies and added that their concerns over the crisis are more about "the overall impact."

Describing the crisis in Greece as "more of an inside-the-eurozone problem, " Schepers said he told the bank representatives during the meeting that he is confident "this issue will be resolved inside the eurozone."

The EBRD was established in 1991 to help countries in central and eastern Europe and central Asia to develop a market economy. Taiwan has been working with the EBRD in providing consultancies to companies in these countries.
In addition to the information and communications technology (ICT) and urban transport, Taiwan can offer its expertise in trade finance, as it has an export- based economy, Schepers pointed out.

DOC.HEADLINE: Labor rights groups to stage anti-poverty march on May Day
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, April 29 (CNA) 04/29/10 22:24:13 (By Chen Shun-hsieh and Sofia Wu)

TEXT.P: Labor rights activists renewed their call Thursday for wage earners around the country to take to the streets this weekend to protest declining wages and the rising prevalence of dispatch work.

Representatives of various labor rights groups, including the Taiwan Confederation of Trade Unions (TCTU) , made the appeal in a news conference held in front of the Council of Labor Affairs. It marked the third time in the past two weeks that labor rights groups have appealed for like-minded activists to take part in the May 1 protest march to mark Labor Day.
Huang Yu-teh, spokesman for a labor alliance against poverty, said the appeals against poverty and dispatch work have won the support of many workers, both blue collar and white collar.
"We believe more than 10,000 people will turn out for the anti-poverty parade this weekend," Huang said.

The demonstrators will march from Liberty Square at the Chiang Kai-shek Memorial Hall complex on Taipei's Zhongshan South Road to the intersection of Zhongshan South Road and Zhongxiao West Road near the Executive Yuan to voice their appeals, Huang said.

The protest march will focus on four appeals -- "fighting poverty and forbidding dispatched work," "labor union autonomy, " "labor participation in and democratic supervision of ECFA, " and "allowing all wage earners to receive monthly pensions," he added.
Dispatched workers refer to those who work for manpower agencies and are "dispatched" full-time to companies on a contract basis.
Some companies prefer this arrangement because of the flexibility it gives them in managing their work forces and because they do not have to pay benefits or severance to the contract workers.

DOC.HEADLINE: Cross-strait fraud ring smashed
DOC.DATELINE: Kaohsiung, April 29 (CNA) 04/29/10 23:07:04 (By C.F. Chen and Flor Wang)

TEXT.P: A 32-member fraud ring operating across the Taiwan Strait has been uncovered through joint efforts by law enforcement units on the two sides of the strait, Kaohsiung city police announced Thursday.

Thirteen suspects were arrested in Taiwan, including the mastermind, surnamed Yeh, along with account books, computers, cellphones, travel documents and remittance records that were used to commit the fraud.
Earlier that same day, 19 accomplices were also detained in a raid carried out by Chinese public security agents in China.

According to the Kaohsiung police authorities, the criminal group had made about NT$500 million (US$15.87 million) over the past six months by posing as personnel of Chinese telephone companies or public security authorities to cheat people on both sides of the strait.

The public security authorities in Quanzhou City in China's Fujian Province first received complaints from local residents and passed the information to the Taiwanese authorities in line with a cross-strait cooperation mechanism that was established by the two sides to crack down on rampant cross-strait fraud.

Meanwhile, Taiwan's Ministry of the Interior (MOI) reported that 4,837 attempted telephone fraud cases have been successfully thwarted over the past six years thanks to an exclusive anti-fraud telephone line under its jurisdiction.

"As much as NT$657.69 million in potentially swindled money was secured thanks to the help of the anti-fraud unit during the six-year period, " Chiu Feng- kuang, deputy chief of the Criminal Investigation Bureau under the MOI's National Policy Agency, reported in a news conference.
Between the start of this year and April 27, 422 attempted fraud incidents were stymied by the anti-fraud unit, he elaborated.

Although the MOI's anti-fraud line workers took around 3.27 million inquiries from members of the public questioning whether they had been targeted by a fraud ring, more than NT$8.8 billion was still raked in by con artists working various telephone scams, he reported.
According to Chiu, the public are very easily taken in by scamsters if they claim to be law enforcement personnel, such as judges, prosecutors, investigation agents or police.

DOC.HEADLINE: Taiwan, Australia sign MOU on marine research
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, April 29 (CNA) 04/29/10 19:48:01 (By Lin Hui-chun and Sofia Wu)

TEXT.P: Taiwan and Australia signed a memorandum of understanding (MOU) Thursday for cooperation in the area of oceanographic research, the National Science Council (NSC) said Thursday.

The MOU was signed at the headquarters of the Australian Institute of Marine Science (AIMS) in Townsville, Queensland on the northeastern coast of Australia by NSC Vice Minister Chang Wen-chuang and Ian Poiner, a chief executive of the Australian institute, on behalf of the two sides, the NSC said in a press statement.

Taiwanese research fellows are welcome to conduct joint research projects with their AIMS peers and to utilize the AIMS' world-class research facilities, he added.
Echoing Poiner's views, the NSC said that although oceans cover 70 percent of the surface of the Earth, there is far less research and knowledge pertaining to the sea than to the land.
As 64 percent of oceans around the world are open seas outside of national boundaries, the NSC said, international cooperation is necessary for marine research.
