DOC.HEADLINE: Taiwan Red Cross helps rebuild health centers in China
DOC.DATELINE: Mian, China, April 29 (CNA) 04/29/10 20:24:40 (By Chen Cheng-wei, Chen Po-hua and Sofia Wu)

TEXT.P: A Chinese official expressed gratitude to Taiwan's Red Cross Society Thursday for its help in rebuilding public health facilities damaged in a devastating earthquake that struck China's Sichuan Province in May 2008.

Wang Pohua, head of the Wuhou public health center in Mian County in Shaanxi Province in northwestern China, expressed thanks to Wang Ching-feng, vice president of the Red Cross Society of the Republic of China, who is visiting China to review various post-earthquake reconstruction projects financed by the charity.

The Red Cross Society decided to help rebuild 15 healthcare centers, including a rural health station, in Mian County in the aftermath of a magnitude-7.9 earthquake that was centered in Sichuan and affected parts of neighboring Shaanxi Province.

Because of the wide urban-rural gap in public health conditions and a lack of health consciousness among many local residents, the reconstruction process had many twists and turns, according to Wang Ching-feng. It took much hard work and coordination to complete the project, she added.

In an interview with the Central News Agency, Wang Pohua said that the new Wuhou healthcare center not only offers basic healthcare services to local residents, but also provides epidemic prevention and health education.
"The local people are very grateful for Taiwan's generous effort to rebuild our public healthcare system that now offers much better services than before the earthquake," he added.

On Tuesday, the Taiwan Red Cross Society delegation headed by Wang Ching-feng visited Yifu Elementary School in Mian County which was rebuilt also with funds from the charity. Wang, who once served as Taiwan's minister of justice, presented scholarships to students in need during the visit.

DOC.HEADLINE: Taiwanese artist debuts paintings at Red House in Taipei
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei April 29 (CNA) 04/29/10 20:34:42 (By Sunnie Chen)

TEXT.P: Taiwanese artist Heidi Huang debuted 20 of her paintings at the Red House in Taipei for the first time recently.
The 28-year old's exhibit covers three themes -- figures, animals and plants -- and will run through June 27.
In all her paintings, there is a cute little rabbit called "Heidi Doll" which appears. Huang also designs and makes by hand rabbi bags, key chains, pillows and many other products.
"Creation of this doll actually is inspired by a thought I had that I want to comfort people, so I use my own image to create the doll," she told the Central News Agency Thursday.
Huang has wanted to be a painter from the time she was in kindergarten.
"I have never changed my mind,"she said.

After graduating from National Taiwan University of Arts, Huang worked as an arts editor at a company, but she was not happy then. She later bravely decided to follow her own path -- making creative works in the field of art.
But the road she has chosen is not easy.
"I used to take a simple briefcase to show my works on the street in front of the Eslite Dun-nan (book) store, or in an arts fair, " Huang said.
Now, she is happy to have a small booth showing her works at the Red House.
Actually, Huang already has many fans from different countries. She revealed that people from Hong Kong and Singapore love her rabbit products, while tourists from the West prefer her paintings.
"Painting and making creative products are my life," Huang said.

She added that she was inspired by this opportunity of being able to exhibit her works at the historical building, and said that she will keep working hard and plans to write picture books in the future.
She will also take her creations to Japan where she will present them at the International Design Festival on May 15-16 and share her paintings and handicrafts with artists from other countries.
"I hope to communicate with young artists from all over the world through this opportunity," Huang said.

DOC.HEADLINE: Consumers urged to report food problems to health authorities
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, April 29 (CNA) 04/29/10 20:52:41 (By Chen Ching-Fang and Hsin-Yin Lee)

TEXT.P: The Health Department on Thursday urged the public to report to the relevant authorities any problems relating to substandard health foods that they purchase.

If people develop side-effects from the consumption of health foods, they hould immediately stop eating the products and report the problem to the health authorities via the Web site http: //hf.doh.gov.tw, or call the toll-free number 0800-625-748, the department advised.

According to a recent survey by Common Health magazine, around 54 percent of the public would inform the Consumers' Foundation if they develop any adverse reaction after eating non-certified health foods, while 38 percent would seek help from city or county consumer protection commissions and the Health Department as a whole.
The magazine reminded consumers to check for proper labeling when choosing health foods.

DOC.HEADLINE: ECFA is purely economic, not related to politics: MAC
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, April 29 (CNA) 04/29/10 21:22:34 (By Liu Cheng-ching and Fanny Liu)

TEXT.P: The Mainland Affairs Council (MAC) said Thursday that the proposed economic cooperation framework agreement (ECFA) with China is purely an economic issue that has nothing to do with politics.

MAC Vice Chairman Liu Te-shun made the comment following China's Taiwan Affairs Office Director Wang Yi's mention of the so-called "1992 Consensus" at a cross- Taiwan Strait entrepreneurs summit in the Chinese city of Nanjing.

Addressing the opening ceremony of the summit earlier that day, Wang said that both China and Taiwan should continue to consolidate a key political foundation of opposing Taiwan's independence and supporting the "1992 Consensus" -- which will serve as a sustainable and reliable political guarantee for developing economic cooperation between the two sides.
Liu responded at a press conference that there has been nothing -- either in ECFA discussions or within the content of the ECFA -- related to any political appeal.

Liu said that it's understandable that Chinese officials need to make statements in line with their political positions, but added that as both sides have their own political viewpoints and directions, he also hopes that China can show empathy toward Taiwan.

The "1992 Consensus" refers to an understanding the ruling Kuomintang claims was reached in Hong Kong in 1992 between the two sides of the Taiwan Strait that there is only one China, but with both sides free to make their own interpretations of what "one China" actually means.

DOC.HEADLINE: Greek debt impact on Taiwan 'limited': European banker
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, April 29 (CNA) 04/29/10 21:32:15 (By Alex Jiang)

TEXT.P: An official of the European Bank for Reconstruction and Development (EBRD) said Thursday that the debt crisis in Greece is having a "very limited" impact on Taiwan.
"I haven't heard anybody express any concerns, " said Manfred Schepers, the body's vice finance president.
Schepers was in Taipei for a meeting with representatives of Taiwan's central bank, commercial banks and insurance companies Wednesday.

He told the press that he learned that the central bank, insurance companies and banks in Taiwan have conservative investment strategies and added that their concerns over the crisis are more about "the overall impact."

Describing the crisis in Greece as "more of an inside-the-eurozone problem, " Schepers said he told the bank representatives during the meeting that he is confident "this issue will be resolved inside the eurozone."

The EBRD was established in 1991 to help countries in central and eastern Europe and central Asia to develop a market economy. Taiwan has been working with the EBRD in providing consultancies to companies in these countries.
In addition to the information and communications technology (ICT) and urban transport, Taiwan can offer its expertise in trade finance, as it has an export- based economy, Schepers pointed out.

DOC.HEADLINE: Labor rights groups to stage anti-poverty march on May Day
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, April 29 (CNA) 04/29/10 22:24:13 (By Chen Shun-hsieh and Sofia Wu)

TEXT.P: Labor rights activists renewed their call Thursday for wage earners around the country to take to the streets this weekend to protest declining wages and the rising prevalence of dispatch work.

Representatives of various labor rights groups, including the Taiwan Confederation of Trade Unions (TCTU) , made the appeal in a news conference held in front of the Council of Labor Affairs. It marked the third time in the past two weeks that labor rights groups have appealed for like-minded activists to take part in the May 1 protest march to mark Labor Day.
Huang Yu-teh, spokesman for a labor alliance against poverty, said the appeals against poverty and dispatch work have won the support of many workers, both blue collar and white collar.
"We believe more than 10,000 people will turn out for the anti-poverty parade this weekend," Huang said.

The demonstrators will march from Liberty Square at the Chiang Kai-shek Memorial Hall complex on Taipei's Zhongshan South Road to the intersection of Zhongshan South Road and Zhongxiao West Road near the Executive Yuan to voice their appeals, Huang said.

The protest march will focus on four appeals -- "fighting poverty and forbidding dispatched work," "labor union autonomy, " "labor participation in and democratic supervision of ECFA, " and "allowing all wage earners to receive monthly pensions," he added.
Dispatched workers refer to those who work for manpower agencies and are "dispatched" full-time to companies on a contract basis.
Some companies prefer this arrangement because of the flexibility it gives them in managing their work forces and because they do not have to pay benefits or severance to the contract workers.

DOC.HEADLINE: Cross-strait fraud ring smashed
DOC.DATELINE: Kaohsiung, April 29 (CNA) 04/29/10 23:07:04 (By C.F. Chen and Flor Wang)

TEXT.P: A 32-member fraud ring operating across the Taiwan Strait has been uncovered through joint efforts by law enforcement units on the two sides of the strait, Kaohsiung city police announced Thursday.

Thirteen suspects were arrested in Taiwan, including the mastermind, surnamed Yeh, along with account books, computers, cellphones, travel documents and remittance records that were used to commit the fraud.
Earlier that same day, 19 accomplices were also detained in a raid carried out by Chinese public security agents in China.

According to the Kaohsiung police authorities, the criminal group had made about NT$500 million (US$15.87 million) over the past six months by posing as personnel of Chinese telephone companies or public security authorities to cheat people on both sides of the strait.

The public security authorities in Quanzhou City in China's Fujian Province first received complaints from local residents and passed the information to the Taiwanese authorities in line with a cross-strait cooperation mechanism that was established by the two sides to crack down on rampant cross-strait fraud.

Meanwhile, Taiwan's Ministry of the Interior (MOI) reported that 4,837 attempted telephone fraud cases have been successfully thwarted over the past six years thanks to an exclusive anti-fraud telephone line under its jurisdiction.

"As much as NT$657.69 million in potentially swindled money was secured thanks to the help of the anti-fraud unit during the six-year period, " Chiu Feng- kuang, deputy chief of the Criminal Investigation Bureau under the MOI's National Policy Agency, reported in a news conference.
Between the start of this year and April 27, 422 attempted fraud incidents were stymied by the anti-fraud unit, he elaborated.

Although the MOI's anti-fraud line workers took around 3.27 million inquiries from members of the public questioning whether they had been targeted by a fraud ring, more than NT$8.8 billion was still raked in by con artists working various telephone scams, he reported.
According to Chiu, the public are very easily taken in by scamsters if they claim to be law enforcement personnel, such as judges, prosecutors, investigation agents or police.

DOC.HEADLINE: Today in history
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, April 30 (CNA) 04/30/10 08:51:07
DOC.TEXT:
Today is Friday, April 30, or the 17th day of the third month of the Year of the Tiger according to the lunar calendar. Following is a list of important events that have occurred on this date in the past:
1770: David Thompson, the Canadian explorer who followed the Columbia River to its mouth in 1881 and mapped much of western Canada, is born in England.
1777: Karl Friedrich Gauss, the German mathematician and astronomer known for his contributions to algebra, differential geometry, probability theory and number theory, is born in Germany.
1789: George Washington is inaugurated as the first president of the United States in a ceremony at Federal Hall in New York.
1803: The United States buys Louisiana Territory and New Orleans from the French.
1893: Joachim von Ribbentrop, the German politician who was Adolf Hitler's foreign minister, is born.
1900: The republic of Hawaii cedes itself to the United States.
1909: Juliana, queen of the Netherlands from 1948, is born. She abdicated this day in 1980 in favor of her daughter Beatrix.
1919: The Paris Peace Conference allows Japan to take over Germany's prewar rights in China's Shantung Province, whereupon China leaves the conference.
1945: Adolf Hitler, the German dictator known as "Der Fuhrer" who reduced his country and much of Europe to ashes, commits suicide with his mistress Eva Braun after bidding farewell to the few aides remaining with him in his Berlin bunker hideaway.
1946: The national government of the Republic of China issues an order moving the national capital back to Nanking from Chungking.
1948: A total of 21 American nations sign the "Charter of Bogota," setting up the Organization of American States (OAS).
1957: Egypt reopens the Suez Canal to traffic.
1967: Muhammad Ali, who first won the world heavyweight boxing crown as Cassius Clay in 1964, is stripped of his title for refusing to be drafted into the U.S. armed forces.
1968: ROC President Chiang Kai-shek approves a set of "Guidelines for the Lives of Citizens" drafted by the National Committee of Chinese Cultural Renaissance Movement.
1973: U.S. President Richard Nixon accepts responsibility for the bugging that took place at the Watergate apartment complex in 1972.
1974: Adm. Maurice F. Weisner, commander in chief of the U.S. Pacific Fleet, arrives in Taipei for a four-day visit.
1975: The Vietnam War ends with South Vietnam's surrender to the communists after North Vietnamese tanks capture the Presidential Office in Saigon.
1977: Public and private buses begin joint operations in Taipei City.
1989: Finance Minister Shirley Kuo leads an ROC delegation to the 22nd annual Asian Development Bank meeting in Beijing.
1990: Elected ROC officials of all levels are permitted to make private visits to mainland China during recesses. Veterans who were stranded on the mainland after the nationalist government moved to Taiwan in 1949 are allowed to apply for resettlement in Taiwan.
1991: Cyclone hits Bangladesh, killing more than 125,000 people.
1991: ROC President Lee Teng-hui declares the termination of the Period of National Mobilization for Suppression of the Communist Rebellion, effective May 1. He abolishes the Temporary Provisions and promulgates the Additional Articles of the Constitution, also effective May 1.
1997: Trains collide at Rongchiawan Station in Yuehyang City, in mainland China's Hunan Province, killing 58 people and injuring hundreds of others.
1998: Secessionist rebels sign a permanent ceasefire with the Papua New Guinea government to end a nine-year rebellion on the South Pacific Island of Bougainville.
2000: Taipei Mayor Ma Ying-jeou inaugurates Taiwan's first tap water museum.
2001: The Second Asian Physics Olympiad concludes in Taipei after more than 10 days of competition with Seven gold medals, five silvers and 11 bronzes, as well as 16 honorary citations awarded to the winners.
Confucius' lesson of the day: "If a man takes no thought for the morrow, he will be sorry before the day is out."

DOC.HEADLINE: Eleven Taiwanese financial groups apply to enter China
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, April 30 (CNA) 04/30/10 10:32:13 (By Hsieh Chun-wei and Deborah Kuo)

TEXT.P: Eleven Taiwanese banks and financial service houses have applied to venture into China since a law liberalizing local investment in China was enacted April 19, the Financial Supervisory Commission (FSC) said Friday.

Of the 11 firms, six are publicly owned banks who applied to establish branches in China -- Taiwan Cooperative Bank, First Commercial Bank, Land Bank of Taiwan, Chang Hwa Bank, Cathay United Bank and Hua Nan Commercial Bank.

Meanwhile, the publicly owned Medium Business Bank of Taiwan applied to set up a representative office in China, according to the FSC, while ChinaTrust Commercial Bank applied to establish a subsidiary and First Financial Holding, a securities firm, registered to set up a representative office.
Two investment and trust firms -- Fuh Hwa Investment Trust and Polaris Investment Trust -- also applied to set up representative offices, according to the FSC.

The Taiwanese financial service firms filed the China-bound investment applications after amendments to three revised statutes governing the operations of banks, insurance companies and securities houses were enacted, which paved the way for such companies to file applications to break into China.

After the FSC gave the green light to the Taiwanese banks and firms, FSC Chairman Sean Chen said, it would take another four to six months for the Chinese authorities to process the applications before granting licenses.
"I'm afraid that it will be the end of the year at the earliest before Taiwanese banks will be able to formally venture into China, " Chen said.

Meanwhile, Banking Bureau Director Kuei Hsien-nung said the screening and supervising of Chinese banks making inroads into Taiwan will be a "dual track" mechanism, with the FSC and the Investment Commission under the Ministry of Economic Affairs in charge of the issue.
So far, no Chinese banks or financial service firms have submitted applications to the Taiwanese authorities for such branch-out investment moves.

DOC.HEADLINE: Taiwan drops slightly in press freedom rating: Freedom House
DOC.DATELINE: Washington, April 29 (CNA) 04/30/10 10:45:16 (By Zep Hu and Sofia Wu)

TEXT.P: Taiwan's freedom of the press world ranking has declined slightly, but its level of media freedom has not shown any significant change over the past year, a Freedom House report released Thursday said.

Taiwan ranked 47th on the U.S.-based human rights watchdog body's 2010 global press freedom rating, which was based on the findings of a survey on the media situations in 196 countries and territories around the world in 2009.
Taiwan dropped four notches from its ranking of a year ago, but Freedom House said Taiwan's media freedom status did not show any significant changes or numerical shifts in 2009.

According to Freedom House's Freedom of the Press Index, Taiwan's scores on its legal environment and political environment for the media remained the same at 7 and 9, respectively, while its score on the economic environment increased one point to 8. Lower scores represent higher levels of freedom in the Freedom House survey.

DOC.HEADLINE: Kuomintang claims ownership of slush fund
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, April 30 (CNA) 04/30/10 12:08:26 (By Lee Shu-hua and Maubo Chang)

TEXT.P: The ruling Kuomintang (KMT) has claimed ownership of a slush fund of NT$240 million (US$7.65 million) two days after the frozen money was collected from the court by James Soong, chairman of the now-marginalized People First Party.

KMT spokesman Su Jun-pin told a news conference Thursday that the KMT decided from Soong's previous public accounts that the funds belong to the KMT and Soong had intended to return the cash to the party.
"James Soong should explain publicly, with evidence, if he now thinks otherwise," Su said.
"The Kuomintang will deal with the issue carefully and with total transparency to avoid any damage to its image," Su went on.
He said the funds will be donated to public interest projects if they are returned to the KMT.

In order to verify the party's claims, Su cited Soong as disputing an order for him to pay tax on the funds at a public rally in Nanao, Yilan County in 2002, on the grounds that the money, accumulated by Soong during his term as KMT secretary-general between 1989 and 1993, belonged to the KMT and that he therefore should not be asked to pay tax on it.

The funds came to light in 1999 when Soong fell foul of then-President Lee Teng- hui, who doubled as KMT chairman from 1988 to 2000, over his bid to run for the presidency against Lee's hand-picked KMT candidate, Lien Chan.

Soong, who was engaged in a three-way presidential race at the time, told a news conference Dec. 14, 1999 that the funds were entrusted to him by Lee for party use during Soong's term as KMT secretary-general.
Soong did not hand over the money to his successor when he left his KMT post to take over as Taiwan provincial governor in 1994.
Lee denied that he had any previous knowledge of the funds, much less entrusted it to Soong.

In order to show he had no intention of embezzling the money, Soong deposited the funds with the court Jan. 25, 2000, with Lee as the receiver, after Lee rejected Soong's offer to return the money to the KMT.
The KMT filed a complaint with the prosecution against Soong on Feb. 16, 2000, accusing him of siphoning off NT$360 million from the party coffers.
The prosecutors decided not to indict Soong after finding no evidence to support the KMT's complaint and closed the case Jan. 17, 2005.
The case made headlines again Wednesday after an attorney collected the funds from the court on behalf of Soong earlier this month.
President Ma Ying-jeou, who also serves as KMT chairman, decided to deal with the issue fairly rather than turning a blind eye to it.
One of his close aides said that whoever lays claim to the funds -- Soong or Lee -- should verify his claim with evidence, or the funds should go to the KMT.
"We are compelled to deal with the issue, and must show our hand," the aide said on condition of anonymity.
However, Soong, who was on a private trip to Shanghai, told reporters Friday that the KMT should not be washing its dirty linen in public.
His attorney, Huang Shan-shan, who was holding the funds on Soong's behalf, said Thursday in Taipei that she was surprised by the KMT's claim of ownership.

Noting that during an investigation into the case the party denied having entrusted any funds to Soong, did not claim ownership and did not try to collect the money over the last decade, Huang questioned how the party could now demand the money.
Soong and Lee, who fell out during the 2000 presidential election, reconciled only recently, evidenced by Lee's consent for Soong to collect the funds from the court.

DOC.HEADLINE: United Daily News: City makeover worth a lift
DOC.DATELINE: 04/30/10 12:28:14 (By Deborah Kuo)

TEXT.P: The Taipei city government has encouraged the rebuilding of low-to-mid-rise residential buildings in the city that are 30 years or more old through financial and technical assistance programs. The move, however, has drawn questions and criticism from the Ministry of the Interior and lawmakers.
The critics have expressed doubts that the city government's plan can work and have claimed that it could, on the contrary, fuel the surging residential housing prices, which are already too high.

However, the plan is an innovative move that has imagination and guts, given the fact that under a free and democratic system, urban renewal in Taiwan is a complicated, constantly changing and hard-to-control process.
The makeover plan is worthy of support from the points of view of improving the capital city's overall look and elevating the quality of living for residents.

Taipei is a rather unattractive city compared with other metropolises around the world. The numerous old residential buildings -- many of them built in the same period of time to a uniform design -- not only make the city look tired, but the outdated road system and utilities also prevent its residents from enjoying a quality of life equal to those in other modern cities.

The city government's makeover plan is worthy of central government encouragement and support, as the plan will provide residents with an opportunity to renovate their own residences, help facilitate a facelift for the run down-looking metropolis, and indirectly help arrest the spiralling housing prices.
Better late than never, but if the plan is procrastinated over for too long, it will be too late for the city to rejuvenate itself. (April 30, 2010).

DOC.HEADLINE: Spring sleet chills Yushan: weathermen
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, April 30 (CNA) 04/30/10 13:59:03 (By Chen Shun-hsieh and Deborah Kuo)

TEXT.P: Sleet had been falling on Yushan, also known as Jade Mountain, Taiwan's highest peak since early Friday, the Central Weather Bureau (CWB) announced later that day.
Sleet is not unusual for Yushan in April, with an average of four days of snow each April on the mountain, CWB meteorologists said.
There are also snowy days on Yushan in the month of May and even on into July, they went on, pointing out that it snowed there on July 25, 1974.
As of 11 a.m. that day, 5.5 centimeters had accumulated on flat ground around the CWB weather station on the 3,952-meter summit, the CWB forecasters quoted weathermen posted there as reporting.
Sleet is precipitation composed of rain and partially melted snow. It occurs when temperatures in the lower part of the atmosphere are slightly above freezing point.

DOC.HEADLINE: Talk of the day -- Housing market shows no signs of cooling

TEXT.P: Despite recent measures taken by the government to try to cool the overheated housing market, it seems that the efforts are producing few results.

According to the latest issue of real estate monthly magazine My Housing, realty developers are set to roll out presold housing projects totaling NT$158.6 billion in value in the northern part of Taiwan between May 15 and June 15 -- boom season for the country's housing market.
The volume represents a 140 percent increase from the same period of last year and a rise of 34 percent compared to the time prior to the outbreak of the global financial crisis.

Meanwhile, a realty index released Thursday by Cathay Construction Co. reveals that housing prices around Taiwan have been rising for three consecutive quarters. The average transaction price for presold housing projects in Q1 2010 reached NT$190,700 per ping (one ping equals 3.3 square meters) , up 2.86 percent from the previous quarter.
The following are excerpts from local leading newspapers' reports on the issue.
United Daily News:

Chang Chin-oh, a professor at National Chengchi University's Department of Land Economics, said it is a "very strange" phenomenon that the housing market is demonstrating a V-shaped recovery when there has not been a significant upswing in the country's overall economy and national income.
This shows the soaring housing prices lack fundamental support and are the result of excessive liquidity, Chang said, describing the increase as "a temporary rebound amid a downturn."

He said the outlook for the housing market will depend on factors such as changes in liquidity supply and demand, the central bank's monetary policy and measures taken by the government in reaction to public outrage over the skyrocketing housing prices. (April 30, 2010).
Economic Daily News:

Ni Tzu-jen, chief R&D officer of My Housing, predicted that housing prices in premium areas of greater Taipei will continue to rise due to a limited supply of land available for housing development, when these areas are the main target of Chinese and foreign investors seeking to make real estate purchases in Taiwan.

Chang Ding-shuan, an associate professor in Jin Wen University of Science and Technology's Department of Finance, cautioned that there are signs that the market mechanism is out of order as a result of a monopoly on land resources and strong demand for investment targets that are depreciation-resistant. (April 30, 2010).
China Times:

Despite the central bank's attempts to stop domestic banks from wooing loan customers with low interest rates, some of the local banks, faced with a liquidity glut, have dropped their interest rates for construction loans to 1.2 percent and even 0.9 percent.

Statistics compiled by the central bank show that as of the end of March, outstanding construction loans had topped NT$1 trillion, up NT$24.2 billion from the month-earlier level. The increase was the highest for the past 13 months.
Meanwhile, outstanding housing loans had hit a record high of nearly NT$5 trillion as of the end of March, an increase of NT$21.7 billion from the month- earlier level. (April 30, 2010).

DOC.HEADLINE: Taiwanese vegetable vendor makes Time magazine list of heroes
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, April 30 (CNA) 04/30/10 14:18:18 (By Lu Tai-cheng and Sofia Wu)

TEXT.P: A vegetable vendor from eastern Taiwan has made the U.S. Time magazine 2010 list of the 100 most influential persons in the world based on her philanthropy.
Chen Shu-chu was ranked eighth in the "heroes" category of the 2010 TIME 100 list.

"Out of her modest living, Chen, 59, has managed to donate nearly NT$10 million (that's US$320,000) to various causes, including US$32,000 for a children's fund, US$144,000 to help build a library at a school she attended and another US$32,000 for the local orphanage, where she also gives financial support to three children," the magazine states.
Chen, who did not complete elementary school because of poverty, said she doesn't know anything about TIME 100.
"I feel kind of ashamed... but I appreciate all the concern shown to me, " she said, adding that she was never informed about the Time magazine honor.
Chen began selling vegetables at a traditional market in Taitung City on Taiwan's eastern coast when she 13 years old to support her six siblings.
Almost five decades later, she continues to earn every penny the hard way, getting up at 3 a.m. to prepare for her workday. In the market, her stand is always the first to open and the last to close.

"What's so wonderful about Chen's achievement is not its extraordinariness but that it is so simple and matter of fact in its generosity, " states the citation in the magazine, which was written by New York-based Taiwanese film director Ang Lee.
She was quoted as having told a newspaper that "money serves its purpose only when it is used for those who need it."
According to Time Magazine, she is planning to establish a fund to help the poor with education, food and health care.
"Amazing, but of all she has given away, her greatest gift is her example," the citation states.

Other people on the Time list in the "heroes" category include former U.S. President Bill Clinton at No.1, South Korean Olympic gold medal skater Kim Yu-Na (2nd) , former Iranian Prime Minister Mir-Hossein Mousavi (3rd) and Chinese kungfu actor Jet Li (18th).
In March, Chen was selected by Forbes magazine of the U.S. as one of the 48 heroes of philanthropy from Asia.

DOC.HEADLINE: Acer sees challenge from HP
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, April 30 (CNA) 04/30/10 14:18:53 (By Erin Ho and Frances Huang)

TEXT.P: An official of Acer Inc. said Friday that he expects Hewlett-Packard (HP) to present a strong challenge to the company after the Taiwanese computer giant replaced its U.S. rival as the global leader in first quarter notebook computer sales.
Acer Chairman J.T. Wang said he expects HP will try hard to make a comeback by boosting its low-priced notebook shipments in the world market in an effort to regain its position as the world's No. 1.

Citing statistics compiled by Gartner, an information technology research firm, Wang said he was glad that Acer accounted for 19.4 percent of the global notebook market, beating HP for the first time to grab the Q1 No. 1 title.

"But the competition is far from over," Wang said, adding that as Acer's global notebook shipments were only around 20,000 units higher than those of HP over the past three months, it is unlikely that HP will sit on its hands.
According to Gartner, Acer sold 9.49 million notebooks in Q1, up 54.5 percent from a year earlier.
"Acer had strong shipment growth across all regions, " Gartner said in a statement.

Wang said Acer is aiming to boost its sales in China, a market that is coveted by all of the world's personal computer vendors, and has listed the China market as the company's top marketing priority.
He said his company will introduce new notebooks exclusively tailored toward Chinese consumers by the end of this year.

China accounted for 5 percent of Acer's Q1 revenue -- worth NT$162.1 billion (US$5.1 billion) -- while Europe, the Middle East and Africa represented 50 percent, the Americas took 27 percent and the Asia-Pacific accounted for 16 percent.
Acer posted NT$3.29 billion in net profits for the three-month period, up 62.6 percent from the year-earlier figure, while earnings per share hit NT$1.25, compared with NT$0.78 recorded a year ago.
Wang said he expects Acer will continue to post significant growth in the second quarter thanks to recovering global demand for high tech products.
He added that his company is also planning to launch four new smartphone models and Internet-related products this year.

DOC.HEADLINE: Taiwan competes for invention prize in France
DOC.DATELINE: Paris, April 30 (CNA) 04/30/10 14:58:50 (By Lo Yuen-shao and Hsin-Yin Lee)

TEXT.P: Taiwanese entries made a strong showing at the Concours Lepine International Paris 2010, a world-renowned contest for inventions that opened Friday in the French capital.
With 17 inventions in the running, Taiwan is the third-largest competitor behind Poland, with 31 entries, and China with 27.

The most distinguishing characteristic of this year's contest is that most of the entries are already on the market, said Hsu I-chuan, chief of the Taiwanese delegation and a professor in the department of Industrial Design at National United University in northern Taiwan's Miaoli County.
He said that according to global statistics, only three out of every 100 inventions make it as far as commercial production.

The 17 Taiwanese entries cover a wide range of categories and include a cake knife, an ergonomic chair, an umbrella incoporating its own lighting system, an emergency kit that can be transformed into a rope, and a tea cup that automatically separates tea leaves from water.

Other notable entries include an air cleaning system invented by Hsiao Yen-kun that has already won numerous international prizes and is being widely applied in the manufacture of respiratory care equipment.
Concours Lepine International Paris is now in its 109th year. There are 14 countries taking part in this year's contest, with more than 500 inventions. The winners will be announced May 8.

DOC.HEADLINE: Taiwan share prices close lower
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, April 30 (CNA) 04/30/10 15:17:39 (by Olivia Wang)

TEXT.P: Taiwan's share prices fell Friday, with the weighted index -- the market's key barometer -- falling 49.8 points, or 0.61 percent, to close at 8,004.25.
The local bourse opened at 8,116.39 and fluctuated between 7,999.28 and 8,163.94. Market turnover totaled NT$152.04 billion (US$4.85 billion).

Six of the eight major stock categories lost ground, with paper and pulp issues dropping the most at 2.33 percent, followed by textile issues at 1.43 percent. Foodstuff shares and machinery and electronics moved down 1.1 percent, construction shares were down 0.92 percent and cement issues lost 0.33 percent.
The other two major stock categories gained ground. Financial and banking stocks rose 0.52 percent and plastics and chemicals were up 0.17 percent.
Losers outnumbered gainers 2,403 to 871, with 264 remaining unchanged.
Foreign investors and Chinese QDIIs were net buyers of NT$12.92 billion in shares.

DOC.HEADLINE: Environmentalists highlight need for shared responsibility
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, April 30 (CNA) 04/30/10 16:13:35 (By Alex Jiang)

TEXT.P: Nearly 200 leaders and environmental activists from home and abroad met in Taipei Friday at the start of a regional forum that highlighted the importance of shared responsibility in protecting natural resources.

"Our interdependence is integral to our survival. Our resources as well as our responsibilities need to be equitably distributed in order to sustain the quality of life for future generations, " said the Taiwanese organizers of the Second Congress of the Asia Pacific Greens Network (APGN).
The first APGN congress was held in Kyoto in 2005, days before the Kyoto Protocol, an international agreement designed to fight global warming, entered into force.

"We have convened the second congress five years later -- five years that have seen unprecedented growth of chaos and denial, " said Robin Winkler, a co- convener of the event and a local environmentalist, in his opening remarks.

There have been "escalation of wars and military expansion, short-sighted corporate control of more and more of the world's resources, media repression, and all manner of social, economic and environmental abuse," he added.

For his part, Australian Greens leader and Senator Bob Brown said that "we have a big burden on our shoulders, but a warmth in our hearts and a smile on our face. We must replace the old politics of development, consumption and greed."
In his address, Pan Han-shen, the convener of the Green Party Taiwan, said he looks forward to seeing an expansion of green parties worldwide.

"There are more than 100 green party lawmakers in the Asia Pacific region and over 1,000 worldwide, " he noted. "I hope that in the next five or 10 years, there will be at least one green party lawmaker in every country."
The APGN, which is mainly a political alliance, is hosting the three-day event at the Tianmu Convention Center, with the participation of more than 20 nations,

Tuvalu's Prime Minister Apisai Ielemia is expected to give a speech at the forum on Saturday. Ielemia received much attention after warning at last year's Copenhagen climate change summit that rising sea levels might submerge his homeland.
Discussions on major challenges, policies and strategies for dealing with climate change in the Asia Pacific region will also be held during the congress.

At the opening, the participants took turns to introduce themselves in English and deliver greetings in their native languages, after which an indigenous dance and a traditional top-spinning ritual was presented by members of Taiwan's Bunun Tribe.

Environmentally friendly items such as bamboo cups, cotton handkerchiefs and recycled bags are being used at the event and the organizers have provided bicycles as transportation for the participants.
A landscape garden consisting of edible plants and a rainwater recycling system is also on display.
The forum will be streamed live on the Internet in an effort to reach a wider audience.

DOC.HEADLINE: Memorial park honoring late Japanese engineer to open next year
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, April 30 (CNA) 04/30/10 16:59:36 (By Lee Shu-hua and Deborah Kuo)

TEXT.P: President Ma Ying-jeou said Friday that a park being built to commemorate Japanese civil engineer Yoichi Hatta, whose work contributed greatly to the success of an irrigation system in southern Taiwan, is slated to be inaugurated May 8 next year.

The Yoichi Hatta Memorial Park, located at Wushantou Reservoir in southern Tainan County, will mark another milestone in the historical and cultural exchanges between Japan and Taiwan, Ma told a group of parliamentarians from Japan led by Yoshihide Suga, a Lower House Liberal Democrat dietman who formerly served as a minister of internal affairs and communications.
Wushantou Reservoir is the centerpiece of the Chia-Nan Irrigation System, a flagship civil engineering project of Hatta's that was completed 80 years ago.

Ma told his guests that Hatta is revered and memorialized by farmers in southern Taiwan, where his irrigation system -- a 10,000-km water distribution system -- has played a major role in irrigating some 150,000 hectares of farmland in Tainan and Chiayi counties since 1930 following the completion of Wushantou Reservoir.

Ma expressed hope that after the Hatta Memorial Park is completed next year, it will become another major tourism attraction for southern Taiwan that will help attract tourists from Japan, particularly those from Hatta's home town of Kanazawa, in Ishigawa Prefecture.
The president also noted that although formal diplomatic relations between Taiwan and Japan were severed in 1972, bilateral exchanges have remained close.
"Taiwan and Japan are closely linked, both historically and geographically, and no countries in the world are as close as these two countries, which exchange 250 flights each week, " according to Ma.
Japan is one of Taiwan's three largest trade partners and the number of Japanese tourists that visit Taiwan tops the tourist numbers from all other countries in the world, Ma noted.
At the same time, he went on, Taiwan is also one of Japan's major sources of tourists.
Despite the close relations, however, Taiwan and Japan maintain no formal diplomatic relations, Ma continued.
"I therefore designated 2009 as the year for promoting special partnerships between Taiwan and Japan," he said.

Since then, bilateral exchanges have improved further, including the signing and implementation of a working holiday project that benefits the youth of both countries, the establishment of a branch office in Sapporo by Taiwan's representative office in Tokyo, and the launch of two-way flights between Taipei's Songshan Airport and Tokyo's Haneda Airport slated for this October, he added.

DOC.HEADLINE: Universities to provide English proficiency tests
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, April 30 (CNA) 04/30/10 17:11:16 (By Lu Chi-hua and Frances Huang)

TEXT.P: Seven universities around Taiwan announced Friday that they will provide English proficiency testing administered by the U.S.-based General Test of English Language Proficiency (G-TELP).
The seven universities, including National University of Tainan and Chinese Culture University, said they will promote the G-TELP tests throughout the island this year.

According to university officials, the tests will offer opportunities for local students to secure English language proficiency certificates, which they said will enhance their international competitiveness.

The G-TELP tests originate from a language center at the University of San Diego in California and are aimed at helping non-English speakers to obtain a reliable English language evaluation so that they can eliminate possible learning obstacles and eventually improve their language skills, the officials said.
Chiu Ping-yuan, an executive director of G-TELP Taiwan, said the G-TELP tests have been widely applied in more than 100 countries and have earned a reputation for reliability and accuracy.
Chiu said G-TELP written tests will be held every quarter, while oral testing will be carried out once each year.

DOC.HEADLINE: Apple Daily: National compensation in landslide disaster
DOC.DATELINE: 04/30/10 17:36:15 (By Maubo Chang)

TEXT.P: The families of the four people who were killed in a landslide on National Freeway No. 3 last Sunday are entitled to national compensation. No one could take issue with this. But as taxpayers, we are entitled to know whether any government officials were responsible for the disaster; if there were, who they were and would they be punished for failing in their duties.

Under the law, there are two types of compensation that could be claimed in such cases. The first type is for damages as a result of negligence on the part of government officials, and the other is for damages in the case of fault or failure of public facilities not necessarily as a result of human error.

The disaster on National Freeway No. 3 was caused by a landslide on a dip slope that had been shaved at the base to build the freeway. This cannot be categorized as a natural and unavoidable catastrophe over which government officials had no control. There was no rain or storm near the slope that day that could have triggered the landslide.
In addition, the ground anchors used to retain the slope had rusted and were therefore weak, which belies the claim by government officials that human error was not a factor.
It seems that the government is trying protect its officials by offering compensation under the category unrelated to human error, but this would not go down well with the public. (April 30, 2010)

DOC.HEADLINE: Commercial Times: Ministry of Finance should not keep mum
DOC.DATELINE: 04/30/10 17:36:52 (By Maubo Chang)

TEXT.P: After slashing the business income tax from 25 percent to 17 percent through the Industrial Innovation Act, two ruling Kuomintang lawmakers suggested increasing the tax rate for businesses undistributed dividends from 10 percent to 15 percent, or requiring businesses to distribute their dividends when they have accumulated to half of their capital.

Business profits should be subject to business tax and personal income tax when they are distributed to individual shareholders, and business income tax should be credited against personal income tax.

When the rate for business income tax is much lower than that for personal income tax, individual stock owners will prefer to keep their profits as retained earnings in the company -- thereby raising its net assets and stock prices -- and then sell their shares to transform stock earnings into stock transaction gains.
In order to close the loophole, most countries impose a tax on retained earnings, and Taiwan follows their examples by levying a 10 percent tax in this regard.
According to one estimate, business income tax revenues used to make up a third of the country's personal income tax takings.

As we have explained above, the bigger the difference between the rate of business income tax and the rate of personal income tax, the heavier the influence it will exert on companies decisions on whether to retain earnings, which will in turn affect the government's income tax revenues.
This complicated issue has been discussed in detail by the tax reform commission that was dissolved at the end of last year after mapping out a plan to streamline the country's tax system.

To address the problem triggered by the sharp cut in business income tax from 25 percent to 17 percent, the government could either increase the tax on retained earnings or ban businesses from accumulating their earnings inappropriately.
The Ministry of Finance, however, should create its own options and stick to them, and should not merely swim with the tide of public opinion. (April 30, 2010).

DOC.HEADLINE: President calls for early signing of ECFA
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, April 30 (CNA) 04/30/10 18:12:33 (By Lee Shu-hua and Y.F. Low)

TEXT.P: President Ma Ying-jeou reiterated Friday his call for an early signing of the proposed economic cooperation framework agreement (ECFA) with China, an arrangement he said is essential to ensuring an equal footing for Taiwan in competing with other countries.

Ma noted that with China having become the world's second-largest economy and exporting country, manufacturers around the world are desperate to get a foothold in the vast market of 1.3 billion potential customers.
"This is a reality that we cannot evade, " he said while receiving a group of worker representatives at the Presidential Office ahead of May 1 Labor Day.

The ECFA is especially important to Taiwan as the country has been excluded from free trade arrangements with most countries, a situation that has seriously undermined Taiwan's competitiveness, Ma said.

He stressed that Taiwan will not open its market to Chinese laborers under the ECFA and said again that the government would rather give the pact up altogether if it cannot not bring any benefits to Taiwan's overall economy.

The president recalled that prior to Taiwan's accession to the World Trade Organization in 2002, there were also widespread concerns about the entry of cheap products from other countries that it was feared could impact local industries.
However, it was later proven that joining the WTO was favorable to Taiwan, with the country's foreign trade volume having doubled during the seven years following accession, he said.
According to Ma, there is a consensus between Taiwan and China that the impact of the ECFA on Taiwan's conventional industries must be kept to a minimum.

In the worst case scenario, he said, the ECFA could affect 100,000 workers in 17 industries. This, however, does not mean that the workers will lose their jobs, but it does mean that their benefits or pay might decrease, he added.

DOC.HEADLINE: Lawmakers to review bills on allowing in Chinese students
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, April 30 (CNA) 04/30/10 19:03:38 (By Kelven Huang and Y.L. Kao)

TEXT.P: Legislators across party lines reached a consensus Friday to reinitiate the review of two bills that would allow Chinese students to study in Taiwan.

The two parties agreed that the KMT would resubmit revised versions of the draft amendments to the University Act and the Junior College Act in early May and that they would then be screened in committee, said Legislator Lin Yi-shih, chief of the KMT's Central Policy Committee.
The original versions of the bills, which would pave the way for local universities and colleges to recruit Chinese students, were first reviewed by the Education and Culture Committee on April 21.
But scuffles broke out among the legislators when the opposition Democratic Progressive Party tried to block the proceedings.

Ruling Kuomintang (KMT) Legislator Chao Li-yun, who was chairing the meeting, fainted amid the commotion after she announced that the two bills had completed their first review and were to be referred to the full legislature for further deliberation.
A free-for-all erupted again April 26 when the opposition Democratic Progressive Party tried to block the committee's move to confirm the minutes of the April 21 session.

Despite the fierce clashes, the KMT legislative caucus asserted that the result of the first review was valid. The DPP disagreed, saying the result of the April 21 meeting was announced by Chao as she was fainting.
In a meeting to bridge their differences, Legislative Speaker Wang Jin-pyng called on the ruling and opposition parties to make concessions on the issue during a meeting Friday.

He proposed that the two parties either recognize the validity of the first review and negotiate on the issue further before referring it to the full legislature or allow the committee to hold another session to review the bills again.
The two parties agreed that KMT lawmakers will submit revised amendments on May 3, and that the full legislature will approve sending them to committee on May 7, the KMT's Lin said.
The new amendments will then be reviewed by the Education and Culture Committee May 10.

At the same time, the Internal Administration Committee will review draft amendments to the Statute Governing the Relations Between the Peoples of the Taiwan Area and the Mainland Area that would lead to the opening of local universities and colleges to Chinese students, Lin said.
The DPP promised that it will follow the rules of procedure and not resort to violence.

DPP caucus whip Lee Chun-yee said the DPP was happy to see the KMT agree to reinitiate the review of the bills. He defended his party's blocking the majority KMT from "railroading" bills through the legislature as an action taken to protect the rights of Taiwan's workers.

Recognition of Chinese academic credentials could lead to an exodus of Taiwanese students to China and chaos in Taiwan's job market and would affect the employment rights of Taiwan's students, Lee argued.

DOC.HEADLINE: Legislators pass name-change amendment
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, April 30 (CNA) 04/30/10 19:05:18 (By Su Long-chi and Fanny Liu)

TEXT.P: Lawmakers passed an amendment under the Civil Code Friday allowing adults to change their surnames without their parents' written consent, but the change will be restricted to one time only.

If parents are divorced, however, or if either or both parents are dead or have been missing for more than three years, a person or either parent will be able to request court approval for a name change an unlimited number of times. People will have the same right if their parents are deemed unable to protect or educate the children.
Under existing law, adults must obtain their parents' written consent to change their surname.

DOC.HEADLINE: Taiwan farmers seek Halal certification of ponkan orange cake
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, April 30 (CNA) 04/30/10 19:50:50 (By Chao Hung-chin and Kay Liu)

TEXT.P: The farmers' association in Shihkang in central Taiwan's Taichung County is applying for Halal certification of its new ponkan mandarin orange cake, in an effort to tap into Muslim markets abroad, a spokesman said Friday.
Halal certification is recognition that products are permissible under Islamic law and are thus edible, drinkable or usable by Muslims.
The Shihkang farmers' association has been forced to add value to its ponkan mandarin oranges, which is a major crop in that area, following poor sales in 2009.
After much trial and error, it came up with the orange cake, which is expected to hit the market in May.

If it obtains Halal certification for the cake, the association plans to export it to Southeast Asian countries with large Muslim population, such as Malaysia and Indonesia, which have been importing the fruit from Taiwan for years.

DOC.HEADLINE: Ma hopes China will not block Taiwan's FTA hopes
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, April 30 (CNA) 04/30/10 19:52:51 (By Lee Shu-hua & Bear Lee)

TEXT.P: President Ma Ying-jeou reiterated Friday that he has requested China not to hinder or block Taiwan's bid to forge free trade agreements (FTAs) with other countries, but he did not indicate if he has received a response.
"As a member of the World Trade Organization (WTO) , Taiwan is entitled to signing the FTAs, " the president said while meeting a group of presidential advisers on industrial affairs.
China has been said to be behind Taiwan's failed attempt to reach FTA arrangements with the world's major economic players.
On the proposed economic cooperation framework agreement (ECFA) that his administration hopes to sign with China in June, Ma said it is a part of Taiwan's global economic strategy.
"The ECFA is just one important step in Taiwan participating in regional economic integration," the president said.

Taiwan stands a greater chance to strike FTAs with other countries after inking the trade pact with China, as it is expected to help Taiwan become stronger, establish better links with other parts of the Asia Pacific region, and reshape its global deployment.
President Ma said he will personally lead a government task force to expedite Taiwan's FTA drive.

He also told his advisers that the International Monetary Fund has recently forecast 6.5 percent economic growth for Taiwan this year, showing that the country is doing well in reviving its economy and the government also foresees continued improvement in the near future.

DOC.HEADLINE: Ex-premier to step up push for referendum on ECFA
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, April 30 (CNA) 04/30/10 20:29:45 (By Wen Kuei-hsiang and Lilian Wu)

TEXT.P: Former Premier Frank Hsieh announced Friday the establishment of an action alliance that will step up the pace of the push for a national referendum on a proposed trade pact between Taiwan and China.

He said that the alliance will stage a massive rally on May 20 -- the second anniversary of President Ma Ying-jeou's inauguration -- to highlight the call for a referendum on the cross-strait economic cooperation framework agreement (ECFA).

According to Hsieh, Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) Chairwoman Tsai Ing-wen made the case well for a referendum, during a televised debate with President Ma on April 25, but there is not enough momentum in the drive to reject the trade pact.

If the DPP waits until June to hold a major rally against the ECFA, it will not be able to build enough momentum to reject the deal, as the Ma administration hopes to sign the pact with China by mid-year, Hsieh said.

With this in mind, he and the eight civic groups, including the Taiwan Association of University Professors (TAUP) and Alliance of Referendum for Taiwan, have forged an action group to push harder and faster for the referendum, he said.
"We want to block the ECFA which is gathering steam," he added.
Heish said that the two strategies of opposing the ECFA -- taking to the streets in protest and arguing against it in the legislature -- should be integrated.

To this end, in the lead up to the rally on May 20, a sit-in will be held and a series of speeches will be given in front of Kaohsiung Arena on May 2 to inform the public about the danger the ECFA poses to Taiwan, said a former chairman of the Council of Labor Affairs, Lee Ying-yuan.
TAUP President Chen Yi-sheng said that the series of activities are aimed at informing the public about the importance of referendum as a tool for rejecting the Ma administration's China policy.
"Only through referendum can the people decide their own fate, " he said.

DOC.HEADLINE: Taiwan to help Tuvalu tackle rising sea levels
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, April 30 (CNA) 04/30/10 20:34:48 (By Lee Shu-hua and Lilian Wu)

TEXT.P: Taiwan is willing to help Tuvalu grapple with the threat it is facing from rising sea levels caused by global warming, President Ma Ying-jeou said Friday.

The Taiwan government will be fulfilling its responsibility as a member of the international community while working with Tuvalu, Australia and New Zealand to help the Pacific island country overcome its difficulties, he told visiting Tuvalu Prime Minister Apisai Ielemia at the Presidential Office.
Ielemia was invited to Taiwan to take part in the Asia-Pacific Young Greens Network, during which he will deliver a speech on the rising sea level problem.

Ma noted that Taiwan and Tuvalu have had close solid diplomatic ties for more than 30 years, and that they have carried out cooperative projects in the areas of agriculture, medical care, vocational training, and environmental protection.

DOC.HEADLINE: Taiwan, Japan sign MOU to promote cooperation
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, April 30 (CNA) 04/30/10 20:44:49 (By Hsieh Chia-chen and Y.L. Kao)

TEXT.P: Taiwan and Japan signed a memorandum of understanding (MOU) Friday with the aim of strengthening exchanges and cooperation between the two sides this year.
The two countries have designated 2010 "Taiwan-Japan Tourism Exchange Year."
The MOU was signed by Peng Run-tzu, chairman of Taiwan's Association for East Asia Relations under the Ministry of Foreign Affairs, and Reijiro Hattori, president of Japan's Interchange Association.

The two countries agreed to promote cooperation in the areas of trade and economics, tourism, academics, culture, technology, disaster prevention, environmental protection, energy conservation, maritime safety, crime-fighting, the media, agriculture and fisheries, and city-to-city exchanges.

The document said that because of the globalization of crime, the two sides will join hands to fight international crime. To facilitate economic cooperation, the two sides will enhance information sharing and opinion exchanges.

It states that the two sides are pleased that the number of tourists traveling between them have reached 2 million a year and pledged to make joint efforts to promote large-scale tourism exchanges. Small and medium-sized industries will cooperate to expand their businesses globally.
The MOU is expected to substantially boost friendship between the two countries, a Ministry of Foreign Affairs spokesman said.

DOC.HEADLINE: ECFA is not a Trojan horse: Presidential Office
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, April 30 (CNA) 04/30/10 20:46:55 (By Lee Shu-hua and Sofia Wu)

TEXT.P: A proposed economic cooperation framework agreement (ECFA) with China will not be a Trojan horse as a U.S. congressional member has reportedly said, Presidential Office spokesman Lo Chih-chiang said Friday.

Speaking at a seminar organized by the pro-independence Formosan Association for Public Affairs (FAPA) in Washington, D.C. Wednesday, Ileana Ros-Lehtinen, a Republican congresswoman from Florida, likened the deal to a Trojan horse Beijing is using to help it annex Taiwan, according to news reports.
Responding to the report, Lo said Ros-Lehtinen had misunderstood the essence of the ECFA.

As an export-oriented country, Taiwan needs to sign a free trade agreement (FTA) with its major trading partners to ensure the free flow of merchandise and capital, which Lo said is the only viable option to sustain Taiwan's economic lifeline.
Noting that both the United States and China are Taiwan's key trade partners, Lo said Taiwan has been working hard to expand trade ties with both countries.

Moreover, Lo said, improved cross-strait economic and trade relations will help stabilize the Taiwan Strait situation which is in U.S. interests and is also a direction that the U.S. government looks forward to seeing.
At the briefing, Congressman Robert Andrews, a Democrat from New Jersey also suggested that the United States should take steps to negotiate a free trade agreement with Taiwan.
Lo said the administration of President Ma Ying-jeou welcomed such an appeal.

Meanwhile, commenting on opposition Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) Chairwoman Tsai Ing-wen's claim at an international news conference held the previous day that the United States will be marginalized once Taiwan and China strike the ECFA deal, Lo said Tsai's speculation was unfounded and unnecessary.

"Both the U.S. government and the American Chamber of Commerce in Taipei (AmCham) have voiced explicit support for the ECFA initiative because the deal will not only benefit Taiwan but is also in U.S. interests," Lo said in an interview with local news media.

Stressing that the U.S. government has been positive toward the cross-strait ECFA initiative, Lo said American Institute in Taiwan Director William A. Stanton, who is the top U.S. representative in Taipei, has on many occasions welcomed closer cross-strait commercial exchanges and cooperation to help maintain regional stability and prosperity.

In its 2009 white paper, Lo said, AmCham even pointed out that Taiwan would be forced out of the vast Chinese market because of tariff disadvantages if it cannot sign a cross-strait ECFA, a scaled-back free trade pact.
Lo also reminded Tsai that AmCham once urged Taiwan's opposition camp to refrain from politicizing or complicating ECFA issues for the sake of Taiwan's overall economic interests.

DOC.HEADLINE: Government to expose names of big tax defaulters
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, April 30 (CNA) 04/30/10 21:47:42 (By Lin Y-feng & Bear Lee)

TEXT.P: The Ministry of Finance will make public on Saturday names of big tax defaulters that owe the government a total of NT$130.8 billion (US$4.15 billion) in taxes, a ministry official said Friday.
The list of 1,558 defaulters will consist of individuals who owe at least NT$10 million in unpaid tax and businesses that owe over NT$50 million.
The list will be posted on the Web sites of the National Tax Administration's branches around the country for seven days.
At the top of the list of individual tax defaulters is Huang Juo-ku, who owes NT$3.1 billion, while a now defunct company leads the corporate category after defaulting on NT$2.7 billion in taxes.

DOC.HEADLINE: CEPD studies possibility of building spur MRT line to Danhai
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, April 30 (CNA) 04/30/10 21:57:13 (By Hsieh Chun-wei and Fanny Liu)

TEXT.P: The Cabinet-level Council for Economic Planning and Development (CEPD) is considering the feasibility of extending the Danshui MRT line to Danhai New Town to help accelerate the community's development, the CEPD said Thursday.

The planned elevated Danhai line, a medium-capacity light rail transit system (LRT) , would run from Hongshulin Station on the existing Danshui line to Danhai New Town and allow the new community's residents to get to Taipei Main Station in one hour.

Following a meeting on the project's feasibility that also included the Ministry of Transportation and Communications (MOTC) , CEPD Deputy Minister Hwang Wang- hsiang said the project would contribute to the new town's development.

The new community has been planned to accommodate 300,000 residents, but to date, only 453 hectares of the community's 1,756 hectares have been developed, largely because of the lack of convenient transportation and peripheral services.

Hwang said the line would take six to seven years to build and could also be extended to Danshui Station and provisions existed for another spur line that would connect Danhai New Town and Fisherman's Wharf, a popular tourist destination at the mouth of the Danshui River.

The MOTC has estimated that the line from Hongshulin Station to Danhai New Town would cost an estimated NT$9.7 billion (US$310 million) to build. Adding a loop line to Danshui Station would cost an additional NT$2.1 billion, an MOTC official said.
According to a local media report, the project had been previously rejected by the MOTC over fears that it was too expensive but that it was being revived out of election considerations.
Officials from both the CEPD and MOTC told the Central News Agency, however, that the report was wrong on both counts.
The MOTC did ask for additions to be made to an initial project plan but had not turned it down, the MOTC official said, and its evaluation has followed a schedule unrelated to election activities.
Taipei County, which is to be upgraded to a special municipality called Xinbei City, will elect a new mayor in late 2010.

One CEPD official told CNA that the light-rail project will contribute to Danhai New Town's development, but other supplementary measures will also be needed to boost services and other industries to entice more people to move to the new community.

Hwang said the MOTC will include a neighborhood development plan as part of the project, and will submit it to the CEPD for review. After it is approved by the CEPD, it will be submitted to the Executive Yuan for final approval.

DOC.HEADLINE: Taiwan students win big at Asia Physics Olympiad
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, April 30 (CNA) 04/30/10 22:15:42 (By Lin Szu-yu and Y.L. Kao)

TEXT.P: Taiwanese students amassed five gold, one silver, four bronze and six honor medals at the 11th Asia Physics Olympiad (APhO), which concluded in Taipei City Friday.
Wang Si-buo from Taipei Municipal Jianguo High School emerged as the competition's biggest winner, with the highest total score and a gold in physics theory.
The competition brought together 130 students from 16 countries or regions.
As host, Taiwan entered two teams with a total of 16 students in the competition. One of the teams took gold in a group event.

Wang, a gold medal winner at the International Mathematical Olympiad and at the International Olympiad in Informatics, has been granted automatic admission to National Taiwan University's Department of Electrical Engineering.
Wang said that to win an award, contestants had to read extensively and familiarize themselves with past test questions. "There is no shortcut to success," he added.

Silver medalist Hsu Nai-lun, who has been offered a place in NTU's Department of Physics, said that mathematics and physics were his favorite subjects and that he is deeply interested in physics because it is closely related to situations in everyday life.

Lin Min-juey, a physics professor at National Taiwan Normal University, which was responsible for training Taiwan's students, said they would have performed well even if their Chinese counterparts had participated.
At last year's contest in Bangkok, China took home eight gold medals to Taiwan's seven, with China's Lei Jin named the overall winner.
China is absent from this year's competition due to "political considerations, " according to Lin, who is also chairman of the Olympiad's organizing committee.

DOC.HEADLINE: Taipei has targeted 9,850 households to levy 'luxury house tax'
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, April 30 (CNA) 04/30/10 22:24:01 (By Lin Yi-feng and Lilian Wu)

TEXT.P: The Taipei Revenue Service said Friday that it has identified 9,850 households in the city that will be assessed a "luxury house tax, " which will increase their housing tax burden by as much as 320 percent.
Service Director Hsieh Sung-fang said the "luxury house tax" will be launched in July 2011, after the publicly assessed house values of "luxury houses" are adjusted upwards.

The publicly assessed housing value is an estimate of a house's worth, not including the land, made by a public agency and is used to calculate the housing tax. Taiwan does not assess taxes on land or houses based on actual transaction values.
The city will only start benefiting from the increase when it begins collecting the tax in May 2012. The tax is expected to add NT$800 million to the city's revenues.

Hsieh said that since Taipei Mayor Hau Lung-bin announced that the city would impose a 'luxury house tax" in February, it had identified as of Friday 9,850 houses in Taipei that should be classified as "luxury houses."
But due to confidentiality considerations and the safety of taxpayers, the office will not identify the houses.
He said the upwards adjustment of the publicly assessed house value was not only based on trying to raise tax revenues but also on the principle of tax fairness.

DOC.HEADLINE: Warming cross-strait ties beneficial to tourism industry: premier
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, April 30 (CNA) 04/30/10 22:32:33 (By Hsieh Chia-chen and Y.L. Kao)

TEXT.P: Premier Wu Den-yih urged local tourism operators to take advantage of the peaceful development between Taiwan and China to expand travel markets on both sides so that the tourism industry could become one of the locomotives driving Taiwan's economy.

At the opening of the 2010 Taipei International Tourism Exposition, Wu said that despite the global financial crisis, Taiwan's tourism industry reported a 14.3 percent growth last year compared to 2008, making it one of the few countries that reported tourism growth in the Asia-Pacific region in 2009.
Taiwan hosted 4.39 million foreign visitors last year, including 970,000 from China.

Next month, Wu said, the Taiwan-based Taiwan Strait Tourism Association and the China-based Cross-Strait Tourism Exchange Association will establish offices on each other's side of the Taiwan Strait, which is expected to give a further boost to tourism in both directions.

DOC.HEADLINE: Four death row inmates executed: MOJ
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, April 30 (CNA) 04/30/10 22:57:15 (By Lee Shu-hua and Sofia Wu)

TEXT.P: Taiwan executed four death row inmates Friday, the first time the death penalty had been carried out in the country since December 2005.

The Ministry of Justice (MOJ) confirmed Friday evening that four death row convicts, identified as Chang Chun-hung, Hung Chen-yao, Ko Shih-ming and Chang Wen-wei, were executed earlier in the day, two days after Justice Minister Tseng Yung-fu signed the warrants for the executions, the ministry said in a statement.

Taiwan last executed death row convicts in December 2005. The lack of executions since then drew attention earlier this year when former Minister of Justice Wang Ching-feng insisted on promoting the abolition of capital punishment and refused to sign death warrants.
Wang was later forced to resign March 11 amid a public outcry of victims of violent crimes and their families.

When Tseng assumed office March 22, he made it clear that while abolishing the death penalty is an ultimate goal, he would abide by the rule of law in dealing with issues regarding death row convicts.
Following Friday's executions, Taiwan still has 40 individuals on death row.

Presidential Office spokesman Lo Chih-chiang said that since Taiwan is a country that upholds the rule of law, it must deal with death row convicts according to existing law, unless there are reasons prescribed in the law that justify suspending the execution.
Acknowledging that scrapping the death penalty is a mainstream trend in a majority of countries around the world, Lo said local residents remain highly divided on the issue.
Because there is still no consensus on capital punishment in Taiwan, more rational discussion is needed before a final decision can be reached, he said.

In the interim, the government will study the feasibility of extending prison terms for certain kinds of felonies, raising thresholds for parole of those who have been given life sentences and tightening procedures for meting out the death peanlty.
The government will also seek to cut back the use of capital punishment through legal amendments, Lo added.

DOC.HEADLINE: Taiwan-U.S.-China ties now best in 60 years: President Ma
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, April 30 (CNA) 04/30/10 23:21:48 (By Bear Lee)

TEXT.P: President Ma Ying-jeou said the triangular relations among Taiwan, the United States and China are the best they have been in 60 years in an interview broadcast on CNN Friday night Taipei time.

In an interview with Christiane Amanpour that was recorded on Wednesday, Ma said that since he was sworn in on May 2008, he has made great efforts to ease tensions across the Taiwan Strait by inking 12 cooperative agreements with China, successfully turning the Taiwan Strait from a flash point into a peaceful and prosperous area in the Asia Pacific area.
He stressed, however, that all of the pacts were reached without compromising the sovereignty of the country.

Questioned on whether the U.S. would continue selling weapons to Taiwan, Ma said Taiwan needed to purchase weapons to defend itself and its democracy, and that the U.S. has been providing Taiwan with defensive weapons in accordance with the Taiwan Relations Act.
He said arms deals are in the interests of both Taiwan and the U.S, and Washington understands arms sales to Taiwan will help maintain stability in the region.
Amanpour early on asked Ma about domestic opposition to a proposed economic cooperation framework agreement that Taiwan hopes to sign with China in June.

He said that after his debate with an opposition leader last Sunday, support for such a pact has increased, and that his government will continue to explain it to the general public to solicit more support for a deal that he argued would benefit Taiwan very much.
Amanpour also questioned Ma about possible plans to meet Chinese leader Hu Jintao, but the president said there were no such plans at present because the time for such a meeting was not right.
He said he would seek to consolidate the foundation for better cross-strait relations by increasing economic, cultural and educational exchanges between the two sides.
